column2: BONN, Germany, Nov. 11 -- West Germany began consulting with its Western allies today on the call of Nikita S. Khrushchev, Soviet Premier, to wind up four-power responsibility for Berlin.
HUY, Belgium, Nov. 11 -- The Rev. Georges Pire performed the duties of both a Dominican priest and a social-work administrator today and then discussed the Nobel Peace Prize he won yesterday.
Vance, Sanders Co., Boston investment concern, regularly surveys the stock market investments of college endowment funds.
SADDLE RIVER, N. J , Nov. 11 -- An amendment modifying the strict Sunday closing law was introduced at the Borough Council meeting here last night. It is expected to receive final approval Dec. 8.

OSLO, Norway, Nov. 11 -- Foreign Minister Adam Rapacki of Poland has convinced Norwegian officials that his proposals for an atom-free zone in Central Europe is a genuine Polish initiative and not dictated from Moscow.
MILWAUKEE, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves said tonight that Red Schoendienst, their second baseman, had been a hospital patient since Saturday. He may have tuberculosis.
SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Nov. 11 (UPI) -- Harry S. Truman warned today that the United States had better heed the lesson taught by the decline and fall of the Roman Empire.
MOSCOW, Nov. 11 -- The Soviet Union and Poland announced tonight that they found it necessary to strengthen the Warsaw Pact because United States "delaying" tactics had prevented a summit conference.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Nov. 11 (Reuters) -- Nearly 90,000 voters -- European, Asian and African -- will go to the polls tomorrow to elect fifty-nine members to the Central African Federation's second Parliament.
TACOMA, Wash., Nov. 11 (AP) -- A motion for postponing Dave Beck's trial for income-tax evasion was denied today.
Israel is one of the chief bulwarks for the integrity of the Kingdom of Jordan, and King Hussein knows it, former Senator Herbert H. Lehman declared last night.
Six more Harlem mothers have been summoned to appear in the School Part of Domestic Relations Court "for failure to comply with the provisions of the compulsory education law."
T. Norman Hurd, who will be the State Budget Director, declined yesterday to rule out the possibility of tax increases to balance the next budget.
Jake Crouthamel, Dartmouth halfback from Perkasie, Pa., was named yesterday as the Ivy League's "back of the week" for his performance on Saturday against Columbia.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- David Sarnoff said today that only with unwavering courage could the nation face up to the Communist campaign of "bluster and blackmail, nibbling and intimidation."
Commuters using Grand Central Terminal received assurances yesterday that from now on there would be fewer snags in the operation of their trains.

Paperboard production continued at a high level last week with the output at 311,196 tons, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday. This was the second highest figure. The previous week's 317,809 tons was the historic high.
Maria Meneghini Callas plans to sing opera in New York again, but she says it is too soon to say "when, where or with whom I will appear."

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 11 (UPI) -- Yevgeni Dolmatov, the director of racing at the Moscow Hippodrome, was a smiling, gracious and affable loser after the Washington D. C. International turf handicap at Laurel today.
NEWARK, Nov. 11 -- A capricious breeze wafted over Pennsylvania Station here yesterday and blew a check for $2,500,000 into the hands of a young man working his way through college.
BOSTON, Nov. 11 -- Legislation to tighten the requirements for teen-age drivers will be introduced in New York State in January.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Senator William Proxmire said today that he and other senators classified as liberal would support strongly the legislative program outlined by Lyndon B. Johnson, of Texas, the majority leader.
CARMEL, N. Y., Nov. 11 -- Two poachers from the Bronx were jailed here today on charges of first-degree murder in the slaying of a deputy game warden who had taken away their licenses.

Renata Tebaldi of the Metropolitan Opera will sing two excerpts from "Madama Butterfly" when she appears on the first program of the television series of the "Bell Telephone Hour" titled "Adventures in Music."
A joint effort by grocery manufacturers and distributors to increase public appreciation of the job they do was urged yesterday by two top executives in these fields.

The decision of the Postmaster General to lessen the projected increase in rates for sending printed matter abroad means that he has heeded widespread protests against exorbitant tariffs on the export of ideas.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Tunisia has let the United States know that she does not intend to have arms shipments from this country be subject to French consent.
TOKYO, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Japan's booming stock market, which has been setting new highs almost every day since early October, received a strong warning from the Government today.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 11 -- It costs a lot to keep a volunteer fireman happy here. The Representative Town Meeting learned this last night during debate over a $400, 000 appropriation for a new firehouse in the Sound Beach section of Old Greenwich.

THE old-fashioned fish market, usually with sawdust on a tile floor and always with a whiff of the sea in the air, is much more difficult to find now than it was a few decades ago. But the few such establishments that still operate are excellent sources for fine, fresh fish, both the common varieties and others that are more unusual.

When Barbara and James Bickham, a young couple from Upper Sandusky, Ohio, won the Appalachian Mountain rally last week-end in a Mercedes-Benz 190 SL, the largest and most successful national rally program in the history of the Sports Car Club of America was closed.
West Germany's riders and mounts were best in the afternoon and best again at night to win a new trophy at the end of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden yesterday.

HAVANA, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The rebels said a Cuban navy plane had flown low over the place agreed on for transfer of the captives. They said the plane and pilot had been intercepted and captured. They did not say how.
The annual theatre benefit of the Smith College Club of New York will take place at the Dec. 2 performance of "La Plume de ma Tante" at the Royale Theatre.
A vigorous deefnse of extracurricular activities was offered yesterday by Dr. William J. Sanders, Commissioner of Education of Connecticut.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 11 -- Although Mike Iseman, a 200-pound wingback, has been lost with a knee and ankle injury and Dan Sachs and John (Silky) Sullivan, the top two tailbacks, are not in good shape, Princeton expects to come up with one of its best games of the season against Yale in the Bowl at New Haven Saturday.

AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 11 -- Jordan announced today that she had requested Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, to submit for Security Council consideration the action by the United Arab Republic against King Hussein's flight over Syria.
Delayed returns from Nassau County gave state-wide leads of more than 25,000 votes yesterday to two housing propositions that appeared to have suffered defeat last week.
LYONS, France, Nov. 11 -- Lyons is divided into three parts by nature and five parts by the Ministry of the Interior.

Bus company executives were advised by a traffic engineer yesterday that they must find ways to stem the loss of riders to the family car. He said there was a direct relationship between the continuing decline in transit riding and increased automobile ownership.
ALBANY, Nov. 11 -- The first staff appointments by Governor-elect Rockefeller have raised again the perennial issue of financial sacrifice versus public service.

MOSCOW, Nov. 11 -- The declaration by Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev that the Soviet Union would turn over its remaining occupation functions in Berlin to East Germany set off hasty activity in Western embassies here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Trans World Airlines said today that nonstop service between New York and San Francisco by additional airlines would be a serious blow to the development of a sound air transportation system.

THOMASTON, Conn., Wednesday, Nov. 12 -- A crew of construction workers labored under lights early this morning in an attempt to uncover a fellow-worker who lay buried with his power shovel under a landslide of rock and dirt on a mountain side here.
In an advance that added about $2,000,000,000 to the market value of stocks on the New York Stock Exchange, the market went to new highs yesterday.

DOMENICO CIMAROSA, contemporary of Mozart, wrote opera buffa with bouncing good humor, and when he turned to a solemn undertaking like a requiem, his style hardly changed. As an Italian he approached the things of the spirit with an unaffected lightness that strikes Northerners as naivete.

SEATTLE, Nov. 11 -- President Eisenhower's proposal for expansion of aid to South and Southeast Asia by private investment has had a cautious welcome at the annual meeting of the Colombo Plan Consultative Committee.
Manny Migliorisi, a second-string halfback last week, was switched to quarterback on the Columbia varsity football team yesterday at Baker Field.
Eight suspected messengers for a Harlem policy bank that moved to Hoboken after raids here last March were seized yesterday en route to the bank's headquarters.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 11 -- The Lebanese Parliament has been summoned to meet at 5 P. M. tomorrow to discuss the Cabinet's request for emergency powers.
A 35-year-old man died in a police station yesterday about an hour after he had been arrested on a charge of feloniously assaulting a policeman.

A HELPFUL guide to the problem of what to serve for dessert is a new booklet, "Out of This World Desserts." It is a collection of the most popular dessert specialties developed in the test kitchens of the National Biscuit Company.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Nov. 11 -- Dr. Thomas C. Mendenhall, Associate Professor of History at Yale University, will become president of Smith College on July 1.
The National Orchestral Association opened its season last night in Carnegie Hall with its first concert under a new musical director: John Barnett.
Fordham Prep, New York's Catholic schools cross-country titleholder, won the Jesuit Schools' cross-country championship yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.
Stock purchases by the general public have shown a swing away from long-term investment, according to the eighth study of public transactions by the New York Stock Exchange released today.

Jim Lee Howell, the coach of the New York Giants, made the startling statement last Sunday afternoon that his offensive coach and his quarterback "agreed" on the plays for the first three downs in any Giant sequence and that he decided the fourth-down plays.

YONKERS, Nov. 11 -- Those among the 19,842 fans who sent Speedy Pick off as the 9-20 favorite in the ninth annual Good Time Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight had no worries. Charley Fitzpatrick Jr. gave the 5-year-old bay gelding a perfect drive en route to a length victory in the commendable time of 2:08 3/5 for the mile and a sixteenth.
A hospital bill sometimes contains a charge for laboratory work. The story behind this item sometimes holds all the drama of a detective story.
CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- A prominent industrialist accused ranking Republicans and Democrats today of "copying each other's sloppy sentimentalism and economic baby talk."

West Penn Electric Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the nine and twelve months ended Sept. 30. The report noted that declines in industrial revenues were more than offset by increases in residential and commercial revenues for both periods.

CHICAGO, Nov, 11 (UPI) -- The Boston Bruins snapped out roof a two-game losing streak tonight and routed the Chicago Black Hawks, 8 -- 4, in a rough game. As a result, the Bruins move into first place in the National Hockey League.

ROME, Nov. 11 -- The democratic parties won ground and the Communists were weakened in many cities and towns where local elections were held last Sunday and yesterday. Almost 600,000 Italians went to the polls in areas scattered from the Alps to Sicily.

ALBANY, Nov. 11 -- The Public Service Commission refused today to permit changes in the handling of two Long Island grade-crossing projects that threaten to cost the state $1,100,000 extra in construction costs.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- Price movements on the stock market today were somewhat irregular. Falls predominated in many sections. However, industrials regained some of their buoyancy in late dealings and closed very firm. But net changes usually did not exceed a few pence.

The election of officers to head Golden Press, Inc., a new book publishing concern, was announced jointly yesterday by the Western Printing and Lithographing Company and Affiliated Publishers, Inc., a subsidiary of Pocket Books, Inc.

This is the time for all good citizens to rally to the cause of court reform -- the simplification and integration of the disorganized clutter of often overlapping courts which has too long disgraced this state. The report of the Judicial Conference, "For Modernization of the Court Structure," can be a catalyst to precipitate and make effective the public's demand for thoroughgoing change.
TRENTON, Nov. 11 -- The demotion of eighteen Jersey City detectives to patrolmen last year was upheld today by the New Jersey Civil Service Commission.
Laszio Szabo of Hungary, who triumphed in the eighth and ninth rounds yesterday, regained first place in the international chess tournament in Tel Aviv, according to a report from Israel.

Your editorial of Nov. 7 pointed to the apparent difficulty encountered by the President during the recent campaign in espousing the cause of economy because his budget for the current fiscal year has gone from a prospective surplus of $500 million in January to a prospective deficit of $12.2 billion.

The Nottingham, a nine-story building containing small apartments at East Thirtieth Street between Madison and Fourth Avenues has been purchased by an investing client of George Ross, attorney. The plot is 65 by 98.9 feet. The sale was for cash over a mortgage of $144,563.

Net income of the Anaconda Company and its subsidiaries for the first nine months of this year fell 45 per cent to $19,288,460, the producer of nonferrous metals and uranium reported yesterday. The profit equaled $1.80 a share on 10,714,627 shares outstanding.
KIEL, Germany, Nov. 11 -- Rear Admiral Heinrich Gerlach predicted last night that German seapower would return to the Atlantic Ocean within three years.
NEVER have so few been so funny as the French troupe in "La Plume de ma Tante," which opened at the Royale last evening.

KINGS POINT, L. I., Nov. 11 -- A blueprint for the formation of a Long Island College Athletic Conference was presented today. Representatives from Adelphi, Hofstra, C. W. Post and the United States Merchant Marine Academy surveyed a proposal that would establish a stronger athletic tie among their institutions.

The appointment of Senate Majority Leader Lyndon Johnson of Texas to represent this country when the subject of outer space is debated at U. N. Headquarters next week is a happy comment on the recent election. Senator Johnson was chosen partly for his keen interest in space exploration but also, as Secretary Dulles told him, "in order to emphasize the basic unity of our country on this issue."

FRANKFURT, Germany, Nov. 11 (UPI) -- Communist Rumania has imposed a harsh new "reign of terror" penal code that provides the death sentence in cases of minor embezzlement or contact with foreigners, Radio Free Europe reported today.

The staff of the New York City Cancer Committee observed the Veterans Day holiday yesterday by showing up for work. They wore their oldest clothes and spent a full day preparing 604,160 pieces of literature for mailing.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Julie Harris, actress, told students at the world's only college for the deaf today that there were places in the theatre for deaf persons.

PARIS, Nov. 11 -- Symptoms of a contest for new power alignments are now manifest in Western Europe, the free world area to which the United States is most closely allied. This struggle has nothing to do with Soviet Russia. It is intramural, in essence, between Paris, Bonn and Rome on the one hand, and London on the other.

Five dancers will receive awards of honor from the Women's Division of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York at the organization's second International Festival of Dance. The event will be held on Nov. 25 in the Grand Ballroom of the Astor Hotel.

The International Paper Company's sales and earnings increased in the third quarter over those in the second quarter, but results for the nine months of this year were substantially lower than last year.
There is a growing trend in hospital laboratories toward methods for getting more information from relatively less material, a specialist said here yesterday.

Within a week after his election Nelson A. Rockefeller has chosen a Budget Director, one of the key posts in any administration and an office that urgently needed filling, since preparation of the 1959-60 budget must proceed forthwith.

The seventy-fifth anniversary Horse Show at Madison Square Garden, which was a drawing card for audiences of prominent persons since its opening on Nov. 4, was the occasion for many prefatory dinner parties before its closing performance last night.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Nov. 11 (UPI) -- Jan Lundquist and Ulf Schmidt of Sweden scored singles triumphs over two of the world's leading amateur tennis players today at the South Australian championships.
SOCIAL butterflies who take one look at Elizabeth Arden's new lingerie and hostess gowns will want to spend the Christmas holidays at home.
NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 11 -- Navy demolition experts began a third attempt today to rid Chesapeake Bay of the navigational hazard posed by the partly submerged battleship San Marcos.

TOKYO, Nov. 11 -- Violent agitation by organized labor in Japan is building up to a Communist-led national "revolutionary movement," Justice Minister Kiichi Aichi declared in a report to the Cabinet today.
The Nov. 20 performance of the Walter and Jean Kerr musical, "Goldilocks," at the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre has been chosen by the Manhattan School of Music for its annual theatre benefit.
The stock market's newest rise carried it past a historic milestone yesterday.

GENEVA, Nov. 11 -- One of the penalties of a rational, far-sighted disarmament policy in the divided world of today is that it seldom makes good propaganda. This is being demonstrated daily to the United States delegations at two conferences with the Soviet Union here.
THE Soviet Union and American television viewers had something in common yesterday afternoon. The running of the Washington, D. C. international horse race was a letdown for both.

The Pittsburgh and Lake Erie Railroad, an affiliate of the New York Central, had a net income of $5,266,088 in the first ten months this year, but none of it was derived from transportation for shippers.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 11 (Reuters) -- Ferhat Abbas, Premier of the Algerian rebel government, told a Belgian news agency correspondent in Cairo today that he was ready to accept a temporary cease-fire in Algeria provided the United Nations supervised negotiations between France and the "free Algerian government."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The Secretary of Defense, Neil H. McElroy, who ended last week a tour that took him to defense installations around the world, with stress on those in Asia, conferred with President Eisenhower today for the first time since his return.

CHESTER, Vt., Nov. 11 -- This was the day for seeing the wildlife of Popple Dungeon, Town of Chester, Vt., except deer. Something has happened to the deer around here and eight hunters at Russell Hosmer's Camp can't find out what it is.
BANGOR, Me. Nov. 11 -- The Air Force formally began operational tests tonight of a new all-weather-approach lighting system at Dow Air Force Base.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Nov. 11 -- A husky, brawling young coal miner with a reputation for racial bigotry was questioned today by local police officials and agents of the F. B. I. in connection with the dynamiting early yesterday of Osage Junior High School, where whites and Negroes have attended classes together for four years.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 10 -- A long-term economic aid program for Turkey and Greece under the auspices of the Atlantic alliance may be proposed by West Germany at a meeting of the North Atlantic Council in Paris in December.

Senator Joseph S. Clark urged yesterday that Secretary of State Dulles be replaced. He said Mr. Dulles had become a symbol of the country's dissatisfaction with the foreign policy of the Eisenhower Administration.
Patty the platypus, one of the most privileged animals in the world, has died of pneumonia at the Bronx Zoo.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- A new and broader bill to curb labor racketeering was promised today by Senator John L. McClellan.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 11 -- The United States set out today to obtain maximum support for a resolution under which the General Assembly would establish a special committee to study projects for international cooperation in outer space. The debate will begin tomorrow in the Assembly's Political Committee.

The acquisition of the Springfield Boiler Company of Springfield, Ill., by the Cleaver-Brooks Company of Milwaukee was announced yesterday. The transaction, according to Cleaver-Brooks, calls for an investment of $1,000,000.

The election of Raymond F. Kelley as chairman and president of The Dynamics Corporation of America, succeeding the late David T. Bonner, was announced yesterday by the concern. Mr. Kelley, who has been a vice president and a director since 1952 also was named chairman and president of Reeves Instrument Corporation and president of Waring Products Corporation, both subsidiaries of Dynamics.
Most New York commodity exchanges were closed yesterday in observance of Veterans' Day. Only the New York Cotton, Mercantile and Produce Exchanges remained open.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The Government's new oil import formula is shaping up as a compromise between the established system, based on a company's past imports, and the orginally proposed revision, which would have been based on a company's refinery activity.

IN the basement of the made-over old dwelling at 54 West Forty-sixth Street you stand, after you have passed through a series of doors protected with burglar alarms, among crates of rocks -- blue rocks, green, golden yellow, pink, red, purple, some that look like anthracite. Some--the brown ones--look like beer bottle shards. Grays look like housewreckers' chippings. They are worth a maharajah's ransom.

A biographical study of Theodore Roosevelt by Edward Wagenknecht will be published Nov. 24 by Longmans, Green, Called "The Seven Worlds of Z Theodore Roosevelt," the work considers Roosevelt as a father soldier, hunter, man of letters, politician, statesman and peacemaker.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Wednesday, Nov. 12 -- Uncertainty over the Chinese Communists' immediate intentions toward the offshore islands overshadowed a day of listless shelling yesterday. By midnight Communist guns had fired only 680 shells in the Quemoy area.
ROME, Nov. 11 -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery has reappraised judgments expressed in his wartime memoirs and has professed respect for the Italian fighting man.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The Government, under the impetus of the Soviet submarine threat, is preparing to take the biggest step in over a quarter of a century to accelerate oceanographic research by the United States.

GENEVA, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Australia, Peru, Mexico and other lead and zinc exporting nations agreed in principle today to a proposal for stabilizing world market prices of the metals by a one-year cut in production and exports.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 11 -- The capitalistic colts were much too swift for the proletarian beasts from Horse Factory 33 today in the seventh running of that global gallop that is the International. One steed from the steppes, Garnir, finished sixth and the other, Zaryad, was last.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (UPI) -- John F. Floberg, a member of the Atomic Energy Commission, said tonight the Government has begun an "agonizing" reappraisal to determine the future of peacetime nuclear power.
LONDON, Nov. 11 -- The House of Commons approved the Government's pension plan, 308 to 261, tonight.
A new port-wide system of hiring dock workers, based on elaborately scaled standards of seniority, becomes part of New York's longshore labor contract today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The Supreme Court cleared the way yesterday for the Crummer Company, Florida dealer in municipal bonds, to press a suit for $30,000,000 damages from Jessie Ball duPont and others.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 11 -- Advertisers and agencies have buried the hatchet in the controversy over the 15 per cent commission, according to leaders of the Association of National Advertisers.
A demand by John L. Lewis for a ban on handling non-union coal has stalled negotiations for a new wage contract covering 180,000 soft-coal miners.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 11 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller rode horseback up a 5,000-foot mountain today to visit a rain forest at the top. It was something he had wanted to do for ten years but never had found the time for before.

BELGRADE Yugoslavia, Nov. 11 -- The strained relations between Yugoslavia and East Germany deterioriated further today as a result of an attack by Otto Grotewohl, East German Premier, on Belgrade's policy.
PARIS, Nov. 12 -- French official circles expressed some confidence today that the Soviet Union would not pursue a unilateral course in Berlin to the danger point.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J. Nov. 12 -- The South Orange Garden Club will hold its annual tour of five homes in this area on Nov. 20. The proceeds will provide funds for flowers for the Veterans Hospital in East Orange.
LONDON, Nov. 12 -- The Board of Trade announced today that British exports and imports had risen last month above the September levels.
Douglas Powell, planning director of the Regional Plan Association, predicted yesterday that the population of the New York metropolitan area would increase by 4,000,000 in the next twenty years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- An Air Force inspector general has blamed faulty procurement policies for delays and excessive costs in the Air Force's development of a long-range missile, House investigators disclosed today.
DAMASCUS, United Arab Republic, Nov. 12 (AP) -- An all-Arab ban was announced today against nine United States and six European concerns for "violating the pan-Arab boycott of Israel."

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 12 -- The subject discussed here this morning was "Rescue in Space." Except for the generals and distinguished scientists present, it would have seemed a preposterous journey into science fiction.

Events today: Ernest White, organist, St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, noon; Faculty String Quartet, Jerome K. Aronow Concert Hall, City College, 12:30; "The Tales of Hoffmann," Metropolitan Opera, 8; "The Silent Woman," New York City Opera Company, City Center, 8:15.

Tickets are still available for Monday's performance by the Beryozka Russian Dance Company at the Broadway Theatre, which will benefit Prescott Neighborhood House. They may be obtained from Miss Jessie Fanshawe, 136 East Sixty-fourth Street.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Eleven Air Force crewmen died today in the flaming wreckage of a KC-97 refueling tanker.
A large, modern center for 3,000 teen-agers and young children has been built in the heart of Harlem and will be dedicated Nov. 25.
Pierre La Mure's dramatization of his novel, "Moulin Rouge," is being readied for Broadway presentation this season by the new producing partnership of Stephen Bono and David Durston.
WARSAW, Nov. 12 -- Wladyslaw Gomulka assailed West Germany today and again pledged Poland's support of Soviet policy in Germany.
Mayor Wagner cited various organizations at City Hall yesterday for their "outstanding contributions" to the city's Salute to Fall.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- Waldo Frank, author, filed a suit in Federal District Court today to compel John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, to validate Mr. Frank's passport for travel to Communist China.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Harold E. Stassen discussed the future of the Republican party with President Eisenhower today and then attempted to read Vice President Richard M. Nixon out of a leading role.

GERTRUDE RIBLA sang her first Turandot, in Puccini's opera of the same name, with the New York City Opera last night at the City Center. The Brooklyn-born soprano, who had made her debut with the company in 1947 before going to the Metropolitan Opera in 1949, made a valiant try at this most demanding of dramatic soprano roles.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- A television official testified today that his station was told it would have to pay $50,000 to the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission or lose its chance to operate Channel 4 in Pittsburgh.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Lyndon B. Johnson, the Senate Democratic leader, appeared today to have on his hands a budding conference with newly elected Democratic Senators -- even if he doesn't want it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The Harmon International Aviation Trophies for 1958 were presented by President Eisenhower today to Gen. Curtis E. LeMay, Air Force Vice Chief of Staff, and Navy Comdr. Jack R. Hunt.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The Administration plans to ask Congress for substantially more mortgage insurance authority than had been sought in the past, the head of the Federall Housing Administration announced today.

The State Commission Against Discrimination yesterday reaffirmed its 1950 decision that, because of restrictive measures by Saudi Arabia against Jews, the agency must exempt the Arabian American Oil Company from its regulations.
State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz made public yesterday a request that a Federal organization be set up to help the states combat consumer frauds.
A messenger said he was robbed of $763 yesterday and shot in the leg when he resisted two hold-up men who had forced him into their automobile.

I was shocked by Professor Sumner Rosen's letter of Oct. 21 which assumed that American aid should be withheld from Turkey until it returns to the ways of democracy. I wish to present more realistic criteria for aid in the Middle East and Asia.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 12 (AP) -- A court restraining order obtained at the eleventh hour by a major stockholder here today prevented American Screw Company stockholders from acting on a proposal to sell the Willimantic, Conn., concern to Textron, Inc. for $5,897,000.
WALTHAM, Mass., Nov. 12 -- A Harvard Law School authority on the Supreme Court came to its defense tonight.
The board of trustees of the New York Public Library yesterday elected as a member David A. Shepard, a director of the Standard oil Company (New Jersey).
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 12 -- The five members of the city's six-man school board who advocated compliance with desegre-action, effective at midnight courts announced their resignations tonight.

TELEVISION seems to be taking to the couch with a vengeance. Seven dramatists who have contributed to the home screen braved the cameras late Tuesday evening on David Susskind's "Open End" program over Channel 13.

MORE than half a century's intensive work as art critic and historian has not exhausted Prof. Lionello Venturi's fund of love and attention. In New York briefly before visiting Pittsburgh, where he will serve on the jury for the Carnegie International Exhibition, the 73-year-old master critic spends most of his hours here seeking out work by contemporary American artists.

GENEVA, Nov. 12 -- The Soviet delegation to talks on a cessation of tests of nuclear weapons made today what it considered a major concession to the Western powers. Semyon K. Tsarapkin, leader of Moscow's delegation to the three-power meeting, made the offer to the United States and British delegations.
"The breeder is the builder, the good judge the architect of the breed and the written standard a rough draft of an architect's blueprint."
Thirteen men described as "the top men in the policy racket" received six-month suspended sentences yesterday from General Sessions Judge Charles Marks.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Lack of ore carriers and the slow replacement of tramp steamers were cited today as weak spots in the merchant marine. Clarence G. Morse, Maritime Administrator, also warned that the tanker fleet was still short of mobilization needs.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- Time may run out Sunday on Steve Van Buren's 10-year-old ground-gaining record in the National Football League. Cleveland's Jimmy Brown, with a total of 1,011 yards behind him, has only to cover 135 yards to break the former Eagle's mark.

BUENOS AIRES, Thursday, Nov. 13 -- The Argentine Government accused Vice President Alejandro Gomez last night of plotting with members of the armed forces and opposition political leaders to overthrow President Arturo Frondizi.

Shipping and yachting interests urged the Coast Guard yesterday to install adequate aids to navigation if the service should decide permanently to withdraw the Cornfield Point Lightship in Long Island Sound.
AFTER crowing in other parts of North America, Sean O'Casey's "Cock-a-Doodle Dandy" flapped its wings and crowed last evening at the Carnegie Hall Playhouse.

THERE was a time when the Soviet Union engaged in international sports competition only when the odds were stacked preponderantly in favor of the Soviet athletes. But the world of sports is not governed by the rigid rules of Marxism. Upsets and unexpected results have a disconcerting habit of intruding on the picture.

THE best battle book I have read in a long time is Leon Wolff's "In Flanders Fields."* This is the story of the immeasurably murderous fight between the British and the Germans on the Western Front in 1917. It is told mainly in terms of personalities.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 12 -- Huge shopping centers across the nation were said today to have made radical changes in the nature of competition in the retail field.

The attorney for a man who wants to build a gasoline station in Ozone Park, Queens, charged yesterday that the station had been blocked by Queens Borough President James J. Crisona to win votes for local Democratic candidates. Mr. Crisona wants the site for a park.
FOR the first thirty-five years of his political life, until 1946, Otto Grotewohl was a Social Democrat. Today he is one of the men who have done most to make and keep East Germany Communist.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- The United States oil industry will be able to supply a major part of the nation's fuel for a long time, the head of a leading domestic producer said today.
CARACAS, Nov. 12 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller is becoming disturbed by speculation that he is a rival of Vice President Richard M. Nixon for the Republican Presidential nomination.

The difficulties of dealing with the Soviets are again illustrated at the two East-West conferences in Geneva on nuclear weapons tests and surprise attacks. After thirteen days of the first and three days of the second both conferences are still deadlocked on what to talk about, because the Soviets insist on perverting what are supposed to be serious working conferences into frivolous propaganda forums.

Edward Beneson, realty investor, has purchased two five-story buildings on plot 125 by 154 feet at 2763-65 Sedgwick Avenue in the Bronx. The seller was M. Wertheimer. The houses contain sixty-two apartments.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- University of Rochester undergraduates today are mapping a rousing send-off for their Yellowjackets on Saturday when the squad leaves for Troy to play Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute with a hope of making a clean sweep of the season's football schedule.
A union of Sanitation Department employes warned yesterday that its 10,000 members would soon begin a check on 6,000 pieces of the department's mechanical equipment.

VANCOUVER, B. C., Nov. 12 -- Formation of a company to develop hydroelectric power on the Peace River in northern British Columbia was announced here today by representatives of Swedish Wenner-Gren interests.

SEATTLE, Wash., Nov. 12 -- The United States Government urged today that under-developed countries take measures to stimulate private investment by their own nationals to complement private investment by outsiders.
Two jet-black baby gorillas arrived yesterday from Africa. They looked like teddy bears in repose but were as scrappy as unhappy tigers when they got out of their shipping crate.

Ismael (Milo) Valenzuela scored his first victory of Jamaica's fall meeting yesterday. He drove Nashville to a head victory over Admiral Vee in the $7,500 Amityville Handicap at a mile and a sixteenth.
BOSTON, Nov. 12 -- A searching re-examination of the operations of state agencies concerned with highway problems was advocated today by a leading traffic safety consultant.
The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development plans to borrow $100,000,000 in the United States during the week of Nov. 17, Eugene R. Black, president, announced yesterday.

A television stage manager for the Columbia Broadcasting System who was dismissed last June 19 after invoking the Fifth Amendment before a Congressional committee, was ordered reinstated yesterday by an arbitrator.
Mayor Wagner swore in five members of the Commission for the Foster Care of Children yesterday. All had recently been reappointed to six-year terms in the non-salaried post.
Six persons were killed in city traffic last wek, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. This compares with eight killed in the same period in 1957, a decline of two deaths.

THANKSGIVING DAY long has been a family affair in this country. However, lacking any relatives in the East, one hospitable New York couple decided several decades ago to invite other "naturalized" New Yorkers, similarly bereft of near-by families, to join them for a holiday dinner at their country home.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- Ashley Cooper and Neale Fraser of Australia defeated Sweden's Jan Erik Lundquist; and Ulf Schmidt, 6 -- 1, 7 -- 9, 6 -- 4, 15 -- 13, today in the semi-finals of the South Australian men's doubles tennis championships.

YONKERS, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Prince Lullwater, a 4-year-old son of Scotland, rallied from sixth at the far turn and won tonight's featured trot by a length and a quarter from Long Song at Yonkers Raceway. The time for the mile was 2:05 1/5.
Students and staff of the New York University College of Dentistry will give blood to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program in Bellevue Hospital today.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 12 -- Dr. Gerard P. Kuiper, a leading authority on the moon and planets, described Dr. Kozyrev as a distinguished Soviet astronomer.
HAVANA, Nov. 12 -- The forces of Fidel Castro have opened an offensive against Government troops in Oriente Province, the rebel radio announced tonight.
MOSCOW, Nov. 12 -- A Soviet, scientist reported tonight that he had detected a volcanic eruption on the moon last week.

I hear constantly the assertion that we have no foreign policy. It seems to me that President Eisenhower and Secretary Dulles have not only repeatedly stated our foreign policy but have acted upon it when the need arose. First, in the Suez crisis, again in the Iraq-Lebanon situation and now in the Far East.
MIAMI, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon had a tooth pulled today and while under sedation talked about the American way of life to the two dental surgeons and three nurses.
New York University has announced plans to expand the educational programs offered at its Bronx campus, which has been designated the University Heights Center by the board of trustees.

At almost any meeting of the Poetry Society of America it is possible to start a near-riot by propounding the simple question, "What is poetry?" Similarly, among professional educators an exciting catch-as-catch-can mental wrestling match can be incited by asking ingenuously, "What should be the major aims of American education today?"
VIENNA, Nov. 12 -- Severe measures have been reintroduced in Bulgaria to deal with crimes against the state and with economic offenses.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The State Department assured Tunisia today that her arms deal with the United States was not subject to any kind of veto by France.
A social action group of Reform Judaism called on the Senate today to amend its rule that permits the filibuster.
The death of Peter Ellis, 35 years old, who died in the West 152d Street police station on Tuesday, was the result of acute alcoholism, the city's chief medical examiner said yesterday.
The Geneva conferences on the prevention of surprise attacks and the banning of tests of nuclear weapons provide a test of Soviet intentions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission approved a reorganization plan for the Florida East Coast Railway today that would give control of the line to the St. Joe Paper Company of Port saint Joe, Fla.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- The Soviet Union said today that the United States was attempting to ban or control the use of Soviet intercontinental ballistic missiles while keeping American bases in foreign countries.
MOSCOW, Nov. 12 -- The Communist nations of Europe have begun a concerted campaign to discredit the Government and policies of West Germany.

The New York Hakoah Club triumphed as indoor soccer returned to Madison Square Garden last night after a seventeen-year absence. Hakoah, the American League champion for the past two years, beat Brookhattan, 4 to 3, in the final of an elimination tournament.

Leon Kirchner and Beethoven were placed in a provocative juxtaposition at the concert of the Albeneri Trio last night at the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, Lexington Avenue and Ninety-second Street.

There has never been a time in hemispheric history when it was more important for North Americans to learn about Latin Americans. The journey of thirty members of major United States private organizations to seven of the ten South American countries is a worthy project which will be followed with interest.
I should like to comment briefly on the letter of Frank E. Karelsen III, published on Nov. 8, concerning the Rockefeller victory over Governor Harriman.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Nov. 12 (UPI) -- Saturday's scheduled football game between Swarthmore College and Pennsylvania Military College at Chester, Pa., was canceled today because of a student prank that caused injury to seven Swarthmore players.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 12 -- Carl Foreman, who produces for Columbia in England under the banner of Highroad Productions, plans to film "The League of Gentlemen," a novel by John Boland. The story is said to deal with a group of former British Army officers who utilize military tactics to carry out a successful raid on a London bank.
Jack Soble, confessed Soviet spy, collapsed yesterday after completing his testimony in the perjury trial of Mark Zborowski, whom he had described as a member of his espionage ring.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- A large increase in Canadian-United States trade within the next few years was predicted here today by Gordon Churchill, Canada's Minister of Trade and Commerce. He warned, however, that factors leading to misunderstandings between the two nations must be examined if the growth is to be satisfactory.

Auburn and Iowa State stand firm for another week as the best defensive football teams in the nation at the major college level, according to statistics released by the National Collegiate Athletic Bureau yesterday.
Eight recreation leaders have appealed for a comprehensive recreation program to combat group hostilities and "aid youth in establishing a firm base for improved human relations."
GARDEN CITY, L. I., Nov. 12 -- An Air Force jet plane with brake trouble landed safely at Mitchel Air Force Base today through the first emergency use here of a runway crash barrier.
Robert Battipaglia, Queens Democratic leader, began polling members of the county executive committee yesterday for nominations for the Borough Presidency.

Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that he would discuss the city's fiscal program for 1959-60 with Governor-elect Nelson A. Rockefeller soon after Mr. Rockefeller's return from his South American vacation trip next week.
How does the composer and his music fare in the Soviet Union today?
Ed Eschenbaum moved up to the starting right-tackle spot as the Columbia football team engaged in a defensive scrimmage at Baker Field yesterday.
Some new faces probably will be in the Giants' starting line-up when the New Yorkers meet the Steelers in Pittsburgh on Sunday.
Eleanor Knapp, an attractive young mezzo-soprano, who has appeared widely in opera and concert in this country and abroad, made her Town Hall debut last night.
HICKSVILLE, L. I., Nov. 12 -- Petitions asking the Hicksville Public Library to rescind its cancellation of a showing of four old Charlie Chaplin films were circulated among taxpayers here today.

These menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are designed to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

BOMBAY, India, Nov. 12 (Reuters) -- The 15,749-ton Liberian tanker Chloe, which sent contradictory radio signals about murder and mutiny aboard yesterday, is expected to arrive here tomorrow to put her radio officer ashore.
WASHINGTON, "Nov. 12 -- Western diplomats here were doubtful today that the Soviet Union and East Germany intended to create a major crisis over West Berlin.
PARIS, Nov. 12 -- The Minister of the Armed Forces, Pierre Guillaumat, said today that the military situation in Algeria had "clearly improved" since a year ago.
LONDON, Nov. 12 -- Industrial stocks resumed their advance on the stock market today. Gains, however, were generally less than a shilling (14 cents).

TACOMA, Wash., Nov. 12 (UPI) -- United States District Judge George H. Boldt reprimanded Dave Beck's chief defense attorney, Charles S. Burdell, today during Beck's income tax-evasion trial. Mr. Burdell had objected to what he called the Government's inference that the defense had had time to study documents being introduced in the trial.

More than nine hundred thousand Arab refugees are still homeless ten years after the end of the war which made Israel an independent state. Two-thirds or fewer of these may have come out of Israel at the end of the fighting. Nearly half are under 16 years of age.

ATHENS, Nov. 7 -- A temple dedicated to Artemis (Diana), mythical virgin goddess of the moon, of the forest and of women in childbirth, has been unearthed near here. The site is about twenty-four miles to the east at Vravron, on the Attic coast, between the seaside resorts of Rafina and Porto Rafti.
RICHMOND, Nov. 12 -- Gov. J. Lindsay Almond Jr. said today he would appoint a commission to study a new antiintegration approach if Virginia's "massive resistance" laws were declared illegal.
ROCHESTER, Nov. 12 (UPI) --Ranking Democrats in thirteen upstate counties joined last night in demanding a larger role within the party framework.
Production of raw steel rose sharply last month, to the highest level since October last year, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 12 -- The need for greater creativity held the spotlight during the fall meeting here of the Association of National Advertisers.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 11 -- Rear Admiral Wolfgang Larrazabal is to step down Friday as chairman of Venezuela's Government junta to become a presidential candidate formally.

The Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., attained in the first nine months this year the highest profits, revenues and sales in its thirty-one-year history, it was announced yesterday by William S. Paley, chairman, and Frank Stanton, president.
The Army is solving the problem of producing palatable irradiated foods, according to Maj. Gen. A. T. McNamara. Quartermaster General, United States Army.

"The Reporter's Trade," a look at journalism by Joseph and Stewart Alsop, will be published Nov. 19 by Reynal. In the first part, the two newspaper men give an account of how they collected news and their philosophy of the reporter's role in the national life.
The cotton futures market closed barely steady on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. Final prices were 5 to 17 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) lower than on Tuesday.

A brilliantly colored collection of upholstery fabrics was introduced yesterday by the Isabel Scott Fabrics Corporation. Called the Vermont Group, it was designed by Elisha Prouty, a native of that state, who derived many of his simple, modern styles from old Vermont patterns.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan said today that his Government would try again in the forthcoming United Nations debate on Cyprus to arrange a conference with Greece and Turkey under the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's auspices.
State mediation efforts to resolve a strike of 1,000 bakery workers employed by the A. P. food stores were scheduled yesterday to resume this afternoon.

A spectacular performance in the New Haven game Saturday, in which he gained 396 yards, put Bob Anastas, the American International quarterback, way out in front as the best passer in the Eastern College Athletic Conference.

SHIZUOKA, Japan, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- Ernie Broglio, a 200-pound right - hander acquired from the San Francisco Giants, made another strong impression on Manager Solly Hemus today. Broglio yielded only one hit in seven innings as the St. Louis Cardinals beat the Japanese All-Stars, 8 -- 0.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- West Germany today promised economic aid to Greece involving more than 300,000,000 marks ($71,600,000).

Stocks opened with boiling activity yesterday, and for sixty-five of the first ninety minutes the tape ran late. Profit-taking touched off stop-loss orders, and at noon losses were general. By the close, however, confidence had reasserted itself.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Senator Olin D. Johnston, Democrat of South Carolina, said today $600,000,000 in German assets seized in the United States during World War II ought to be returned to their German owners.
BOSTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Bob Turley of the New York Yankees was named the winner of the Cy Young Memorial Award tonight as the outstanding pitcher of the 1958 major league baseball season.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 12 -- The Westchester Bar Association said today that a legal aid society would be in operation in the county by early next year to represent the needy in civil and criminal cases. It would replace one that functioned from 1936 to 1941.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson, the Democratic leader of the Senate, has moved quickly since the election to establish a pattern of bipartisan cooperation in the field of foreign affairs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, Nov. 5:

Nothing in recent history has exploded the immense bluff and the complete hoax of any "possibility of fruitful cultural relations" and "cultural exchanges" with Khrushchev's Soviet Union so completely and beyond repair as has the Pasternak case.

BERLIN, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Premier Grotewohl beat a hasty retreat tonight -- apparently on orders from the Kremlin -- after he had indicated that the Soviet Union might be willing to withdraw its troops from Germany without waiting for the West to pull out.
Several hundred persons prominent in society, the theatre and arts attended last night's supper dance in the Trianon Room and Ballroom of the Sheraton-East after a film preview at the Astor Theatre.

There were 87,300 babies born last year in the eighty-one voluntary hospitals that are members of the United Hospital Fund. The hospitals are very proud of being ports of entry for these new little citizens and have done much to make their entry safer and easier.

THIS fellow Smith who is training a bird dog out of a book, has been turning in some juicy reports, and some of them quite likely are true. A couple of his friends appear to back him up, anyway, in a casual sort of way that might be deceptive.

Unionization efforts among the white collar workers of the steamship industry suffered a setback yesterday as American Export Lines employes voted down Local 153, of the Office Employes International Union.
The greatest scorer in the history of college basketball has been occupied for the past year with an unusual problem -- how to get off the bench.

Two enterprising Smith College sophomores who felt lonely in New York last Thanksgiving have taken steps to eliminate that risk this ThanksgivingNot only for themselves but also for "one to two thousand" other collegians.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Following is the text of a statement read to reporters today by Lincoln White, State Department press officer, on yesterday's Soviet-Polish statement:

COOKING has not always been easy for Elena Zelayeta. She learned to separate eggs by breaking them into her palm and letting the whites slip through her fingers; to tell the temperature of deep fat by smell and the doneness of meat by touch. In the beginning, she timed her cooking by fifteen-minute radio breaks.

ROME, Nov. 12 -- Pope John XXIII is sharpening his English so he can talk with visitors and pilgrims who understand only English. He indicated this in an audience today with about twenty priests from France, Ireland and other countries.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- The Department of Agriculture today estimated the 1958 corn crop at a record 3,785,000 bushels, nearly 100,000,000 bushels higher than the October estimate.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The Government announced today that it would permit exports of "wonder" drugs to the Soviet Union and her European satellites, effective immediately.
TRENTON, Nov. 12 -- The New Jersey Republican State Committee postponed action today on the selection of a permanent state chairman.

Charles F. Noyes, president of the realty brokerage company bearing his name, has added the two five-story buildings at 71-73 and 75-77 Worth Street to his investments in the downtown textile district centering on Worth Street from Church Street to Broadway.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 12 -- It's a long way from Greenwich to Chirgua, but an architect here made sixteen trips there last year to design the Venezuelan farmhouse in which Nelson A. Rockefeller is spending his post-election holiday.
JACQUES LESUR, head of one of the world's most renowned woolen fabric houses, is here from Paris to visit his New York branch office.

The Port of New York Authority raised $25,000,000 in the public market yesterday by the sale of serial bonds maturing from 1959 to 1978 at an interest cost of 3.5678 per cent. The money will be used to finance improvements at the La Guardia and New York International airports.
ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 12 -- The President's Special Assistant for Aviation warned air safety experts tonight against complacency in making flying safer.

Samuel Reshevsky scored points 2 yesterday in the international chess tournament at Tel Aviv. He thus moved back into a tie for first place with Laszlo Szabo of Hungary, also a winner in the tenth round according to a report reaching here from Israel.

THE homes of many prominent New Yorkers will be open next Tuesday and Wednesday for the seventh annual Cook's Tour. Kitchens again will be the center of attention on the tours, which benefit the programs of the Yorkville Youth Council and the Parents League of New York.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 12 -- Otto Grotewohl, Premier of East Germany, seemed to tone down today the Soviet Union's suggestion that it would end its occupation role in Berlin, thus requiring the Western allies to deal with East Germany.

DETROIT, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The Chrysler Corporation said today it would halt operations at all its assembly plants and at many supplier plants across the nation because of the continuing strike of 8,000 salaried office workers and engineers.
Harry Golden, author of the book "Only in America," said here last night that ethnic restrictions on immigration should be amended to regain "the intellectual vitality of the immigrant."
YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif., Nov. 12 (UPI) -- Three climbers scaled the 3,604-foot perpendicular face of El Capitan Peak early today. They were the first persosn to climb it from that direction.

MIAMI, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Express company and railroad officials searched frantically today for Christopher T. Chenery's First Landing. The juvenile champion thoroughbred was missing for several hours on a trip from New York to Florida.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Nov. 12 (Reuters) -- Aharon Cohen, a prominent member of the Left-wing labor party Mapam, is to be charged with betraying Israeli state secrets to an agent of a foreign power, the Government announced today.
PARIS, Nov. 12 -- A new Soviet move to split West Europe has been made just when West Europe seemed busy splitting itself in its quarrel over a free trade area.
THE Middle East and oil were the ingredients of "Shirley Temple's Storybook" last night on Channel 4.
R. H. Macy Co., Inc., in its first fiscal quarter, the thirteen weeks ended on Nov. 1 last, had estimated sales of $116,000,000, one per cent more than the $114,814,000 recorded a year earlier.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- Eddie Perkins, a club fighter, blasted Frank Ryff's comeback campaign tonight with a unanimous decision over the New York lightweight in a televised ten-rounder at Chicago Stadium.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The Civil Rights Commission prepared today to force Alabama officials to hand over voting records for an investigation of alleged denial of Negro voting rights in the state.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Johns Hopkins can't put two offensive backfields together. As a matter of fact, it can barely scrape up two teams.

Queen Frederika of Greece spent yesterday at Columbia University adding to her knowledge of nuclear physics. The Queen was escorted by Col. Elias Deros, air attache to the Greek Embassy in Washington, and university officials.

The daily index of wholesale commodity prices of the Bureau of Labor Statistics climbed to 88.3 on Monday, the highest mark in more than a year. The rise in the index was 0.2 from last Friday's level of 88.1. The index was not issued for Tuesday because of the Veterans Day holiday.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Michael J. Prendergast said yesterday he had "absolutely no intention" of resigning as Democratic state chairman.
The Securities and Exchange Commission has filed suit in Federal Court here asking that the American-Hawaiian Steamship Company register as an investment company or be liqunidated.

Radio and television performers here have empowered their union leaders to call a strike against three networks, if suitable contract agreements are not obtained by midnight Saturday, when current contracts expire.
BOSTON, Nov. 12 -- James M. Curley, the last of the big city political bosses, died today at Boston City Hospital. He would have been 84 years old on Nov.20.

Ambulance-chasing indictments against a lawyer and an investigator who worked for him -- true bills voted nearly four years ago -- were dismissed yesterday by General Sessions Judge Mitchell D. Schweitzer. He acted for lack of prosecution by the District Attorney's office.

Futures prices closed irregularly lower yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Coffee, copper, sugar, wool, hides and rubber declined; cottonseed oil, zinc and lead rose, and price movements for cocoa and potatoes were mixed.
CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (AP) -- A combination of profit-taking and hedging turned the grain futures market downward again today, almost erasing some gains of yesterday and more than cancelling out others.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12-Sterling Cole, Director General of the International Atomic Energy Agency, said today that United States policy was undermining the agency.
EASLEY BLACKWOOD'S Symphony No. 1, which was introduced to New York at Carnegie Hall last night by Charles Munch and the Boston Symphony Orchestra, sounds like a reflection of the beat generation.
TORONTO, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- The Montreal Canadiens climbed back atop the National Hockey League standing tonight with a 4-1 victory over the last-place Toronto Maple Leafs.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 12 -- The convention of the Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners will decide tomorrow whether to authorize the union's withdrawal from the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Tickets are still available for the theatre party at Monday evening's performance of Eugene O'Neill's "A Touch of the Poet," at the Helen Hayes Theatre. The event will benefit the Third Street Music School Settlement.
A quota system to regulate textile imports from countries with wage and living standards well below those of the United States was urged yesterday to protect the textile industry here.
LONDON, Nov. 12 (Reuters) -- British independent airlines today called on the Government to remove restrictions that have limited their expansion.

An "ocean" is being built at Chester, N. J., about eight miles west of Morristown, N. J. There, Bell Telephone Laboratories engineers are constructing an unusual dry-land facility for testing telephone cable. It will have a simulated depth of two nautical miles.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- Red Schoendienst, the Milwaukee Braves' star second baseman, was transferred today from St. John's Hospital to Mount St. Rose Tubercular Hospital to await the outcome of tests.

In the two remaining days of American Education Week, and at the same time Open School Week in New York City, we urge parents and others who have not already done so to visit their schools and see for themselves. A great deal of the taxpayer's treasure goes into education, and we venture to say that he carries no part of his burden so willingly and so uncomplainingly as that going to education.
A damaged liver may lead to the erroneous diagnosis of thyroid trouble, a scientist at the State University of New York Downstate Medical Center suggested last night.

Halle Stieglitz and Henry Herrman Co., both member firms of the New York Stock Exchange, plan to merge Jan. 1. The successor company will operate under the name of Halle Stieglitz. The latter was formed in 1889, while Henry Herrman Co. was organized in 1939.

It would be surprising if there were not disappointment in Poland over the results of Wladyslaw Gomulka's two-and-a-half-week visit to the Soviet Union. As Poles watched the spectacle of M. Gomulka traipsing around Russia pledging fealty to the Soviet Union and the "socialist camp," they must have assumed that there would be at least some material reward for this obsequiousness.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 12 (UPI) -- Smiley Quick of Whittier, Calif., shot a 32, 32 -- 64 -- seven under par -- and led all contestants in the pro-amateur phase of the $5,000 Gardena Valley open golf tournament today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The estimate for the corn crop was raised 99,326,000 bushels from last month's record forecast of 3,686,218,000 bushels to 3,785,544,000 bushels.
DETROIT, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The United Auto Workers Union has agreed not to seek higher pensions in future bargaining with the nation's major auto makers, for employes who have retired.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The presidents of land grant and state universities today proposed a program of direct Federal aid to public colleges for construction of academic buildings.
HONG KONG, Nov. 12 -- Officials in Communist China have decided that piece-work wages are retrograde and un-Communist.

Differences between the Federal Government and an important group of lawyers on whether the Government should press for an international agreement to "police" the use of outer space developed at a meeting here last night.

Savings bankers will press again for widened branch privileges at the next session of the Legislature at Albany, the president of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York said yesterday.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 12 (UPI) -- Army today rejected bids for its football team to play in the Cotton or Orange Bowl and reaffirmed its traditional policy against post-season bowl invitations.

Those of us working for the revival of real two-party government in the north country have been gratified by the attention The Times has paid to Vermont's new Democratic Congressman, William H. Meyer.

Besides the impetus lent by inflation psychology, a major reason for the continuing rise in prices of stocks is believed to be the relatively small market supply of stock in relation to the big demand. But there are indications that the shortage may not last long.
New advertising media are opening up frequently. The latest is the Pocket Books' edition of the "Standard Bartender's Guide," which will start taking advertisements early next year.
Eugenio Fernandi sang his first Cavaradossi with the company when "Tosca" was performed at the Metropolitan last night.

LAUREL, Md., Nov. 12 -- The success of yesterday's seventh annual Washington D.C. International horse race, from the promotion standpoint, has convinced the Laurel track management that the "race is here to stay."

The red and white colors of the New York Society of Colonial Wars were carried out in floral decorations, table coverings and flags at the organization's annual dinner in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria last evening.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- Good football players come in different sizes at the United States Military Academy.
Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy accepted an invitation yesterday to appear this morning before the Brooklyn grand jury investigating chiseling in city relief.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 12 -- C. H. Bartlett, vice-president of Westinghouse Electric Corporation, said today American industry would spend at least $8,000,000,000 for research this year. He added that by 1960 such expenditures would reach $9,000,000,000 a year in an all-out effort to apply scientific knowledge to industrial problems.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Once more the Allied-Russian agreement by which West Berlin became a free-world island entirely surrounded by Soviet territory has been employed as an aggressive weapon of international communism. This time Khrushchev has brandished it. The last time, in 1947, the hand was Stalin's.

TUNIS, Nov. 13 -- President Habib Bourguiba said today he was trying to buy arms for Tunisia from Communist countries. He asserted that his traditional Western friends had offered to supply them only under unacceptable circumstances.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Following is the text of a statement issued here today by the Roman Catholic Bishops of the United States:
CARMEL, N. Y., Nov. 13 -- Martin Anzalone, 28-year-old Bronx baker, was indicted today on a charge of first-degree murder in the death of a game warden last Monday.

The two principal agencies of the Federal Government primarily concerned with protection of civil rights both showed signs of intense activity this week, to the undoubted benefit of civil rights but also to the possible confusion of the public.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Harold E. Stassen's suggestion that Vice President Richard M. Nixon should not head the 1960 Republican ticket came as a surprise to President Eisenhower, the White House said today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The Government is issuing a new appeal to inventors to help the armed forces solve "impossible" problems.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- The State Department announced new regulations today to prevent arms supplied as foreign aid from finding their way back into United States markets. The regulations become effective Saturday.

Metal companies increased their bank borrowings by $43,000,000 at the larger New York City banks in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. These companies had been cutting the level of their borrowing since mid-year.
Ramon Serra, 20-year-old street gang leader who killed a rival gang leader in a Bronx candy store last April 26, was sentenced yesterday to a prison term of twenty years to life.

Blocked on Wednesday by a temporary restraining order from buying the assets of the American Screw Company, Textron, Inc., has offered to purchase control of the Willimantic, Conn., fastener concern directly from its stockholders.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 13 -- Israel announced today the liquidation of a United Arab Republic spy ring.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 13 -- The Council of Bishops of the Methodist Church unanimously reaffirmed today its support of the Supreme Court decision outlawing segregation in public schools.
Five New England railroad presidents met in Portland, Me., yesterday to discuss a possible merger of their lines into a single system.
LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Aneurin Bevan, once the stormiest figure in the Labor party, topped the poll tonight in elections to the party's so-called shadow Cabinet.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Nov. 13 -- Sir Roy Welensky's United Federal party has won a sweeping victory in the general election of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland.
