The football fraternity swarmed around him in genuine delight. Few football officials have been more popular than the dynamic carrot-top from Pittsburgh.
A 43-year-old mother of four children was arraigned yesterday in General Sessions Court on a charge of fraudulently obtaining more than $10,000 in welfare payments.

PALERMO, Sicily, Nov. 13 -- (AP) -- The wife of an elderly American who was kidnapped while on a homecoming visit to his Sicilian birthplace said tonight she had been asked to pay 5,000,000 lire ($8,000) for his return.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., Nov. 13 (UPI) -- Shadow Brave, who captured the second leg of the $75,000 American Pacing Classic last Saturday in the record time of 1:56 3/5 for one mile, today was declared from this Saturday's third heat because of lameness.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- Lewis L. Strauss, former chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, was sworn in today as Secretary of Commerce. He promptly asserted his confidence in the future of the American economy.

Columbia will invade Philadelphia tomorrow for its football game with Penn and the Lions will take with them a new starting quarterback. Emanuel (Manny) Migliorisi), a sophomore from Arnold, Pa., will get the call since two Columbia regulars are still on the injured list.

A new flakeboard plant, costing about $5,500,000 and capable of producing 40,000,000 square feet a year, will be opened formally today at Farmville, N. C., by the Formica Corporation. The flakeboard will be used as a base for laminated plastics such as Formica.

THE dimension of an artist is not to be measured by the size of his creations or the medium used to execute them. But there are moments when an artist's dream assumes a grandeur, a soaring insistence that can only be accommodated with huge forms.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- President Eisenhower threw his support today behind the Air Force's refusal to turn over to Government investigators complete copies of a report criticizing the service's missile program.

An eerie atmosphere pervaded the huge staduim as rain bathed the field. It was the kind of day to remain in bed with a day book -- any book -- but the football Giants practiced as usual at Yankee Stadium yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- A discharged announcer for the Voice of America charged today that some fellow-workers had inserted anti-West, pro-Nasser views in broadcasts beamed to Iran.

A 15-year-old Brooklyn art student, who told the police that she had been molested in an elevator, drew a likeness yesterday of her alleged attacker. Within twenty minutes the police seized the suspect.

OSLO, Norway, Nov. 13 -- Four Nordic nations sought to warn the European common market countries today that collapse of the Paris talks for a free trade area could lead to disastrous economic warfare.
Governor Harriman announced yesterday that he would not call the tri-state conference on the commuter rail crisis that he had promised.
MOSCOW, Friday, Nov. 14 -- The Soviet Government announced today that it planned to increase gross industrial production by 80 per cent in the next seven years.

SEATTLE, Wash., Nov. 13 -- The Colombo Plan Consultative Committee adjourned late today in agreement that the economic development of the world's underprivileged areas constituted a major challenge of these times.

The nation's highways will be more crowded by year-end than ever before, despite a decline in auto sales this year. The Automobile Manufacturers Association released preliminary estimates yesterday that showed that 68,470,000 vehicles would be registered by the year-end, including 57,000,000 passenger cars.

SEATTLE, Nov. 13 -- Secretary of State Dulles charged today that the Chinese Communist rulers were creating a "vast slave state to enhance the power of the international Communist movement." But he expressed doubt that they would succeed.

Francis Thompson's prize-winning short subject, "N. Y., N. Y.," will be featured tomorrow at 2:45 P. M. at the Museum of the City of New York in the first of this season's monthly programs devoted to local film-makers.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- The transfer of established art masterpieces from private to public collections will be virtually complete within two decades, trustees of the National Gallery said today. They urged the Government to buy before it was too late.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Eastern Airlines and the Pilots Union agreed today that the third man in jet airliner cockpits would be pilot-trained. A spokesman for the flight engineers threatened a strike.
A new self-loading "mountain-mover," more than 100 feet long and said to be as powerful as a railroad locomotive, was introduced yesterday by R. G. LeTourneau, Inc., in Longview, Tex.
BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Nov. 13 -- The Westchester County American Legion has reopened an attack on Sarah Lawrence College for allegedly retaining faculty members who have "Communist-front" records.
CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- The United Auto Workers today called a strike against fifteen International Harvester Company plants.
The Port of New York Authority yesterday acquired the bulk of the Brooklyn waterfront property of Beard's Erie Basin, Inc., for $7,500,000.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- A Jewish Welfare Fund leader suggested today a five-year plan for Israel, "setting year-to-year objectives to overcome the backlog we already have."
LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Prominent British scientists consider it unlikely that the Russians have detected signs of a volcano on the surface of the moon.

Ambassador Lodge's proposal for a U. N. Committee "On the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space," made yesterday before the General Assembly's Political Committee, did not grow out of hate or suspicion. It was a typically American approach to a universal problem.

An increase of 734,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 169,210,000 barrels, compared with 168,476,000 a week earlier, and 180,805,000 a year ago.

Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy denied yesterday that he had transferred a subordinate because the subordinate had allegedly "leaked" departmental information to an official inquiry on the misuse of welfare funds.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- A twelve-member advisory committee met today to help the Agriculture Department develop new and improved methods for the humane slaughter of food animals.

Some time today groups of youngsters in the Bronx will be asking Mrs. Helen Martini about the tigress in her kitchen that snoozes on thick woolen blankets, drinks milk from a bottle and has a heating pad.
CHICAGO, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
The Screen Actors Guild said yesterday it would support the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists if the latter went on strike against the broadcasting networks.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 13 -- A temporary injunction was issued today in Pulaski Chancery Court to stop the Little Rock school district from paying $19,741 to dismiss Superintendent Virgil T. Blossom.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Record Christmas sales for the nation's department stores this year and a stronger automobile market in 1959 were predicted here today.
Only three of the seven games scheduled in the eleventh round of the chess tournament at Tel Aviv were decided last night, according to a report from Israel.

Affectionate sympathy is one of the main threads running through Richard Strauss' "The Silent Woman." That thread in the New York City Opera's production was strengthened last night when a new singer took over the role of the Housekeeper in the company's fourth and final presentation of the opera this fall.
FRENCH LICK, Ind., Nov. 13 -- A three-day meeting of top officers of the independent Amalgamated Lithographers of America and the International Typographical Union ended today.

HAMBURG, Germany, Nov. 13 (AP) -- A world-wide boycott by trade unionists of ships flying "flags of convenience" will begin before Dec. 15, Omer Becu, secretary general of the International Transport Workers Federation, said here today.

The Argentine struggle for internal stability and civilian governmental control is obviously far from over. The oil strike instigated by Peronists; the state of siege and arrests which were President Frondizi's reply; the answering threat from the labor unions, and now the alleged plot by Vice President Alejandro Gomez have come along in dramatic succession.

NEWARK, Nov. 13 -- The Public Service Electric and Gas Company moved today to increase its electricity rates by $21,400,000 a year. The increase would raise by 9 per cent the average monthly bill for 1,200,000 residential users.

As is well known, artists like the top floor where there is a good north light. As a result a lot of mothers (and some fathers) who have children attending the Little Red School House are suffering from charley horses.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The Roman Catholic Bishops of the United States called today for decisive but prudent action to eradicate racial segregation.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 13 -- The Administration's housing chief said today that he believed the Federal Government had no responsibility to promote the ending of racial discrimination in residential accommodations.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Nov. 13 -- Nationalist China has intelligence agents operating effectively in every province and in every major city on the China mainland, Lieut. Gen. Chiang Ching-kuo asserted in an interview today.
Bank clearings for twenty-six of the nation's major cities showed a moderate decline in the week ended Wednesday from the preceding week, Dull Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 3 points (15 cents a bale) up on the old December contract yesterday to 2 to 18 points (10 to 90 cents a bale) off on other months.
Ford C. Frick, the commissioner of baseball, said last night that "baseball is not going to be sledge-hammered into putting a club into New York because of a threat of a third league."

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 13 -- The head of B'nai B'rith predicted tonight a deepening religiosity in American Jewish life in the next ten years because of the accelerated progress in Jewish religious education.

MITO, Japan, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Bob Blaylock, eager to win a regular berth on the St. Louis staff next year, turned in another impressive pitching performance today as the Cardinals defeated the Japan All-Stars, 5 -- 1. The victory increased the Cards' lead in the sixteen-game series to 11 -- 2.
The United States must double its spending on education to keep pace with the Soviet Union, Dr. Frank H. Sparks, educator and fund-raiser, warned yesterday.

Mayor Wagner's baseball committee, as eager as ever to bring another major league franchise to New York, revealed yesterday it was planning to organize a third major league. The committee has abandoned hope of obtaining a National League franchise.
An Eastern-based agency and one in the Midwest will merge next week to form a company with billings of $20,000,000 a year, according to an informed source.
MOSCOW, Nov. 13 -- The Soviet press refrained today from elucidation of Premier Khrushchev's speech calling for a renunciation of the four-power occupation of Berlin.
It is perhaps not generally known that some of this country's best teachers are not paid. These are the doctors who give their services to our great teaching hospitals.
A Southern college professor who founded a chain of libraries for Negro children and a citizen's group that cleared its city of corruption were honored yesterday for exceptional voluntary services.

Average net free reserves of member banks increased $146,000,000 to $193,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Net reserves are excess reserves less borrowings.
Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, warned yesterday that underdeveloped countries might swing to communism if the West did not help them raise their standards of living.
TO judge by the actors, some intelligent people are interested in "Hamlet of Stepney Green," which opened at the Cricket last evening.
ATLANTA, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Georgia Baptists turned down a resolution today aimed at the Presidential candidacy of Senator John F. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, a Remain Catholic.
Memorable incidents in the colorful career of the late Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia will be incorporated into a musical comedy, bearing the title of "Fiorello."

The sign carried an air that was partly a warning and partly a threat. "Better Order Your Thanksgiving Turkey Now," it said. Although the morning in question was some days away from the time the bird would be needed, the implication was clear.
MILAN, Italy, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Italy counted nine dead and twenty - seven injured tonight after two days of rain. The wintry storms also gorged the Po River into a flood threat.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- State Department officials feel that Wladyslaw Gomulka's recent demonstrations of friendship for the Soviet Union led him to unnecessary demonstrations of hostility for the United States.

The election of Frederick Sundermann as executive vice president of the National Bank of Westchester, White Plains, was announced yesterday. Mr. Sundermann, formerly vice president in charge of administration, joined the bank in 1955.
GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 13 -- The abolition of the Fairfield County Republican Organization was urged today by four prominent Republicans here.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 658,086 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
Tony Anthony, a top contender among the light heavyweights, will meet Sonny Ray in a televised ten-round fight tonight at Madison Square Garden.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 13 -- Following is the text of an anti-segregation statement adopted today by the Council of Methodist Bishops:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Miss Eleanor Voss, 22 years old, of 697 West End Avenue, Manhattan, a student at Harvard Law School, was killed early today in the collision of a motor scooter and a taxicab.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The International Boxing Club told the Supreme Court today it was punched so hard by an antimonopoly decree that even its twice-a-week nationally televised fight series is in jeopardy.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- A former Barbers Union official testified today that the president of the union arranged with Dave Beck to have Teamsters members picket the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in 1956.

DALLAS, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The American Dental Association condemned today what it called false and misleading advertising of dentifrices. It assailed advertising, directed toward children, that said dentifrices prevented dental disease.
Events today: Verdi's "La Traviata," Metropolitan Opera House, 8; Carlisle Floyd's "Susannah," New York City Center, 8:15; Gounod's "Faust," Amato Opera Theatre 159 Bleecker Street, 8:15.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- A crowd of only 9,833 turned out today for the opening program on Pimlico's thirty-day fall meeting and saw Fred A. Simmons' Snommis, the 7-5 favorite, take the $7,500 added Pimlico Breeders' Stakes.
CHICAGO, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Jim Wilson, who recovered from a fractured skull and went on to a noteworthy major league pitching career, today was placed on the Chicago White Sox voluntarily retired list.

The Gulf, Mobile and Ohio Railroad, which last February halved its quarterly dividend to 25 cents a share and distributed 10 cents a share in June and 15 cents in September, returned yesterday to the 50-cent quarterly rate that prevailed last year.
BOWLING GREEN, Va., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Two white women were shot and killed in their home north of here tonight by a Negro man who had held seven persons hostage for several hours.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., Nov. 13 (AP) -- The Soviet Union got a head start on the United States on heavy rocket engines, but neither side has "any really marked advantage" in military strength, the Air Force chief at the Cape Canaveral (Fla.) Rocket Base, said today.

YONKERS, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- Trader Horn sharpened up for next week's $50,000 Eastern Trotting Championship in impressive fashion before 16,918 at Yonkers raceway tonight. He posted an effortless two-length decision over Willis L. in the $8,000 Oakdale Purse.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Bump Elliott, backfield coach, will replace Bennie Oosterbaan as head football coach at the University of Michigan effective Jan. 1, it was learned tonight. Michigan's Athletic Board has passed a resolution recommending that the university's Board of Regents make the change.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The United States will soon announce an accelerated program of bartering surplus farm products for strategic materials.
Many cocktail and dinner parties will precede the autumn dance to be held tonight for the benefit of the South Shore Planned Parenthood Center at the Seawane-Harbor Club, Hewlett Harbor, L. I.
Northwest Airlines, Inc., registered yesterday 449,040 shares of cumulative convertible $25 par preferred stock with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The hands-off policy of the Government toward American-owned ships flying the flags of Panama, Liberia, Honduras and Costa Rica will not be changed as a result of a threatened boycott of such shipping by world trade unions.
The Republic of Austria registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday a proposed public offering of $25,000,000 of bonds in the United States market.
A program to promote manufacturing in the Colon Free Zone of Panama, now a duty-free assembly and distribution center, was disclosed yesterday by the zone's general manager, M. Everardo Duque.

One year ago today scores of expensive automobiles driven by men in broad-shouldered suits arrived at the home of Joseph Barbara Sr., an ailing, middle-aged beer and soft drink distributor, at Apalachin, N. Y.
An Army colonel who has been dead for fifty-two years provided dinner last week for 250 veterans of his old regiment.

PRESENT attempts to define "the father role" in terms of precise duties and responsibilities are useless and potentially dangerous, a family-life specialist said yesterday. Even if it were possible for "the experts" to agree on a blueprint for the "ideal family man," he declared, no human being could meet its specifications.
SEATTLE, Wash., Nov. 13 -- Following is the text of the communique issued at the close of the annual Colombo Plan conference:
YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- The Wiltwyck School, a philanthropic institution for boys, met another barrier today in its attempt to move from Esopus.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The United States sharply reminded Premier Khrushchev today that the Soviet Union failed the last time it tried to force the Western powers out of Berlin.
LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Closing pirces on the stock market today had a mixed appearance, although gains outnumbered losses.

Herbert von Karajan, permanent director of the Vienna State Opera, the Berlin Philharmonic, and the Salzburg Festival, made his first appearance as conductor of the New York Philharmonic last night at Carnegie Hall.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The Attorney General has ordered a Federal grand jury inquiry into the arrest of three Negro ministers in Birmingham, Ala.
Cuyo is a long, thin island in the Philippines' Sulu Sea, but Cuyo and its school children now seem quite close to the pupils at Public School 99 in Kew Gardens, Queens.

The impression is growing in diplomatic quarters that Premier Khrushchev's blast against four-power rule in Berlin must be taken as the opening shot in a new drive for a new summit meeting on Germany, at which the Soviets would undertake to dictate their terms under threat of a new Berlin blockade.
After three victorious appearances on the road, the New York Knickerbockers returned to Madison Square Garden last night and delighted a crowd of 13,850 with their sparkling play.

TRENTON, Nov. 13 -- A look forty years into the past to find what has happened to World War I radium-dial watch painters is expected to help man understand the present dangers in exposure to radiation.

Former President Herbert Hoover received a gold medal and citation last night from the National Institute of Social Sciences, the first individual to be honored twice in the organization's fifty-nine-year history.

ONE hatter who never goes mad is Mme. Paulette. While all other milliners around her make brow-covering cloches or flowering wigs, she continues to design berets and pillboxes that are as flattering as a ten-watt bulb.

Tankoos Co., New York realty investor, has announced the purchase of ten store properties in Canada by Tankoos Yarmon, Ltd., of Toronto, its Canadian affiliate. The properties were bought from the F. W. Woolworth Company, Ltd., the Canadian branch of the international chain-store organization.
The Hotel Corporation of America has completed an agreement with the American Express Company to participate in the new Amex credit card service, it was announced yesterday.

THERE seems to be a marked trend here toward the opening of restaurants not much bigger than a bistro. Two recent additions to this roster are the Serendipity at 225 East Sixtieth Street and the 234 East Fifty-eighth Street.

Boris Krylov, cultural counselor at the Soviet Embassy, yesterday found a group of Barnard College students more interested in Boris Pasternak than in the Russian educational system he had come from Washington to explain to them.
WINCHESTER, Va., Nov. 13 -- Senator Harry F. Byrd reaffirmed today his faith in Virginia's policy of "massive resistance" to school integration.

Committees have been meeting at the Savoy-Hilton to complete arrangements for the fifteenth annual Christmas Fair to be held in Watson Hall of the Brick Presbyterian Church next Thursday evening and Friday. The Women's Association of the church is sponsoring the event.
BOSTON, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- The Detroit goalie, Terry Sawchuk, was thwarted in a bid for his second shutout of the season tonight as the Red Wings defeated the Boston Bruins, 3 -- 1, at the Garden.

TACOMA, WASH., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Claude J. Watson, an Internal Revenue Service agent, told a Federal Court jury today that he had visited at least eight major cities in the United States and Canada in checking finances of Dave Beck, former teamsters union president.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The winners of television Channel 4 in Pittsburgh were denounced by Representative Charles A. Wolverton today for "buying off" the other applicants.
The Central Railroad of New Jersey applied to the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday for permission to install automatic trippers on the approaches of the Newark Bay Bridge near Bayonne, N. J.
CHESTER, N. Y., Nov. 13 -- A cable company president today shot and killed a convicted thug who was seeking to force recognition of an independent union at the company's plant here.

Ground has been broken for a two-story office and warehouse building on Zarega Avenue, between Gleason and Ellis Avenues, in the Bronx. The building will be occupied by John's Bargain Stores, operator of eighty dry goods shops in the New York and Philadelphia areas.

IT seems certain now that North Carolina and Puerto Rico are going to have a blue marlin duel, but on a high level of Southern and Spanish politesse. There will be no ugly element of competitive ferocity in this deal.

The Societe Parisienne De Distributing Cinematographique (Discina) and Cady Films obtained a show cause order yesterday in Supreme Court from Justice Jacob Markowitz to prevent the licensing or exhibition of the motion picture "Mr. Hulot's Holiday" on television.
SKIING, once the sport of those born with muscles as well as money, is now a pleasure enjoyed by anyone with enough self-confidence to carry a pair of skis through a railroad car.
"THE WINSLOW BOY," Terence Rattigan's play on the rights of the individual citizen, received an immaculate production last night on the "Du Pont Show of the Month" over Channel 2.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Capital Airlines announced today the indefinite adjournment of a meeting called to seek a settlement of a strike of airline mechanics. The walkout has halted the company's operations for twenty-seven days.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 13 -- Dean Martin will return to Paramount in February to star in the Hal Wallis production of "Career," the James Lee play staged Off Broadway last year.
Joseph M. Roebling's Point Pleasant closed stoutly on the outside to win the mile-and-a-sixteenth Center Moriches at Jamaica yesterday.
Premier Khrushchev's 1965 goals for key industrial commodities are well below last year's United States output.
A high official of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters said yesterday that the union had spent $800,000 in the fight against right-to-work laws.
CHICAGO, Nov. 13 (AP) -- A late rally turned most grain futures prices higher today on the Board of Trade. However, it left corn and oats still under selling pressure and small losers for the day.

Many New Yorkers want to share their Thanksgiving with others but may not know how to do so in our vast city. Lenox Hill Neighborhood House plans a festive Thanksgiving dinner for some 150 members of the Friendship Club, elderly people over 60. Many of them live alone and our Neighborhood House is truly home for them.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 13 -- Vice President Alejandro Gomez rejected tonight demands that he resign. His position opened a wide rift in the Administration of President Arturo Frondizi.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The motion-picture industry practice of withholding films from theatres for some time after they have been shown in first-run houses cleared a big legal hurdle today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The United States asked the Soviet Union again today for information on the whereabouts of eleven American airmen who crashed two months ago in Soviet Armenia.
North American Aviation, Inc., missiles and airplane manufacturer, reported yesterday a decline of 20.9 per cent in earnings during its fiscal year ended Sept. 30. Sales dropped 27.3 per cent.
HAVANA, Nov. 13 -- Some 240 rebels were killed in the last twenty-four hours in Oriente Province, according to a communique issued this afternoon by the Presidential Palace.

The New York County grand jury investigating charges of graft and corruption in the Department of Buildings met yesterday for three hours in the longest session since the investigation began last year.
FORT SMITH, Ark., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Jim Kenner of Fort Smith missed when he fired at a 175-pound buck today. But he got his deer with a knife.
Nassau County, L. I., sold six issues of serial bonds totaling $21,643,000 yesterday to finance sewerage and other public improvements.

Morris Gesell, baritone, was heard last night in a song recital at Carnegie Recital Hall. His program consisted of a group of English, French and Italian lute songs, a group of old American songs and works by Schumann, Debussy, Ravel and Poulenc.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 13 -- Communist authorities in East Berlin loosed new verbal threats against the Western Allies' occupation of the Western sectors of Berlin today. But neither the Soviet nor East German officials made any attempt to interfere with the Western powers' communications.
RUTH SLENCZYNSKA gave her silver anniversary piano recital last night in Town Hall. She was 8 years old when she made her famous debut in the same hall, exactly twenty-five years ago to the day.
A luncheon commemorating the 125th anniversary of Edwin Booth's birth was given yesterday at the headquarters of The Players, 16 Gramercy Park. Howard Lindsay presided and 100 members attended.

MOSCOW, Friday, Nov. 14 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev decided today that he could finally tell his people the real reason for the steady demotion of his old traveling companion, former Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin.

Lumber production last week was 9.8 per cent above the level of a year ago, according to reports to The New York Times by regional associations. Shipments were up 9.5 per cent and orders up 1 per cent.
MIAMI, Nov. 13 (AP) -- J. H. (Casey) Hayes and his champion horse were united today after one of the greatest mix-ups in travel plans since Henry M. Flagler built his Florida railroad.

Stock prices moved erratically yesterday and ended moderately lower. Most of the steels, nonferrous metals, motors, oils and business machines were down, and most of the drugs and aircrafts were up, but there were contradictory performers in all groups.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 13 -- The United States urged the United Nations today to set up a committee to promote international cooperation in the peaceful uses of outer space.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 13 -- One of small college football's most talented class units of recent years has been working feverishly this week to assure its right to a permanent place of honor among Williams College's athletic heroes.

IN the ruins of Berlin in the summer of 1945 the American soldiers of occupation had plenty of time and opportunity to contemplate the vanity of human wishes and the guilt and criminal madness of a large percentage of mankind. One of those who did was a young soldier in his early twenties named Thomas Berger.
The Long Island Rail Road announced yesterday that on Nov. 24 it would discontinue two of the four trains it operates between Pennsylvania Station and Ozone Park, Queens.
GENEVA, Nov. 13 -- The United States proposed today a program to end the testing of nuclear weapons throughout the world under international controls.

The Political Committee of the General Assembly of the United Nations has again taken its position on the unification of Korea. The result was roughly the same as that of last year. The Soviet bloc, nine votes in all, voted against unification of the country through the instrument of free elections supervised by the United Nations. There were eighteen abstentions, chiefly from the so-called Asian-African bloc.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Federal spending for scientific research and development increased by 13 per cent in the last fiscal year to a total of $3,400,000,000, the National Science Foundation reported today.

Price of cocoa futures advanced the 1 cent-a-pound daily limit in all positions yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Volume was only 230 lots, but there were 490 unsatisfied bids at the close of trading.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Heads of ninety-three major public colleges and universities attacked today current moves to raise tuition fees. If continued, they said, the trend would "be disastrous to American society and to American national strength."
The Churchwomen's League for Patriotic Service will have its only fund-raising event of the year on Monday in the ballroom of the Colony Club.
HAVANA, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Bob Rosburg of Palo Alto, Calif., shot 69 in thirty-mile-an-hour winds today for a one-stroke lead in the $45,000 Havana international golf tournament.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- British business men are encouraging their employes to buy shares of the companies for which they work and of other concerns. The trend toward employe participation in business ownership has been observed for some time, but it has received fresh impetus through a plan just announced by Aims of Industry.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UPI) -- Western Union Telegraph Company asked the federal communications commission today for permission to raise its service charges on teleprinters an average of 15 per cent on a temporary basis.
Stress endured during surgery seems to awaken, a mysterious body defense mechanism, mobilizing it against cancer cells that may be present in the blood stream.

BUFFALO, Nov. 13 -- Legislation may be necessary to "persuade" health insurance companies to provide coverage for mental illness equal to that they give to other illnesses, a medical economist told the Joint Legislative Committee on Health Insurance Plans here today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The Social Security Administration is trying to reach about 400,000 persons who may be eligible for payments under the 1958 amendments to the Social Security law.

For a few hectic moments in South Brooklyn last night it looked like a scene from a Keystone Cop revival, with policeman chasing policeman, until the solitary suspect was collared and the fourteen abashed blue-coats put away their revolvers and billies.
The sixty-sixth annual meeting of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers opened yesterday with one of the heaviest technical schedules in recent years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The Secretary of Defense outlined today in detail the United States' global military strategy. In some respects, he restated earlier positions, but in others he indicated new approaches.
The general executive board of the International Jewelry Workers Union yesterday overruled the decision of the union's president to suspend its secretary-treasurer.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Rutgers today turned down an offer from the Quantico Marines to waive the rules and let Billy Austin wear a cast on his broken left hand Saturday. The fleet senior back may play with sponge rubber protection, however, if the hand is improved enough to permit it.

The daily index of wholesale commodity prices of the Bureau of Labor Statistics remained at 88.3 on Wednesday, the same as Monday's level. The index was not issued for Tuesday because of the Veterans Day holiday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 13 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold cautioned today against any effort to alter the present aims of the United Nations' information activities.

CARACAS, Nov. 13 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller disclosed today that he probably would resign as chairman of the board of the International Basic Economy Corporation before taking office as Governor of New York.
Two youngsters, only handle-high to their shovels, helped to plant fifteen plane trees in East Harlem yesterday as part of the city's Salute to Fall program.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- In the published comment on the recent elections one widely noted phase is the choice of Catholic candidates for Congressional and state offices in areas where adherence to this creed was long presumed to presage inevitable, or nearly inevitable, defeat. The rout of this bogy in Pennsylvania and Minnesota has been especially remarked.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Nov. 13 -- A relentless search by the security forces for a man-and-wife team among Communist terrorists in the southern state of Johore ended with their killing a week ago, the Government dislosed today.

The seventeen-story apartment building at 309 West Fifty-seventh Street, part of which is a church, has been sold by the Cab Properties Corporation. It was bought by the 309 West Fifty-seventh Street Associates, investing clients of Thaler Kandell, attorneys.
The Federal Government has complained to Mayor Wagner about the continued spread of blight near redevelopments for which it has contributed millions of dollars in slum-clearance funds.

Increased city cigarette tax collections were reported yesterday by City Treasurer Hilda G. Schwartz for the four months ended Oct. 31. The collections totaled $3,581,758, which was $141,377 higher than in the same period a year ago.

TOLSTOY wrote that "time is infinite movement without one moment of rest." Plato called time "the image of eternity." Seventy-two years ago the Pratts and Bedfords, Brooklyn aristocrats who had made fortunes in oil, conceived of time as something to sell.
The death of Dorothy Canfield Fisher points up the terrible emptiness of that "cult of personality" which is being discussed in political circles these days as the decisive factor in American voting.

NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 13 -- The Common Council approved last night a $24,000,000 face-lifting plan of capital improvements over the next five years. The figures for the over-all project, which is a compilation of projects proposed recently, were presented by City Controller Bernard Newman.

AN audio planning service that promises to take the baffle out of hi-fi has just opened at 135 East Fifty-sixth Street. The three young proprietors of Custom Music Consultants have as their motto: "Keep the living room intact!"

MOSCOW, Nov. 13 -- The results of Tuesday's running of the Washington D. C. International at Laurel were reported here casually today in two Soviet newspapers. They said the participation of the Soviet 3-year-old thoroughbreds, Garnir and Zaryad, had increased interest in the race considerably.
Two $4,400-a-year dock watchmen were charged last night with operating a usurious loan business of more than $150,000 yearly.

Speakers at the seventeenth annual rally of the National Council of American-Soviet Friendship at Carnegie Hall last night called for United States recognition of Communist China and a world ban on nuclear weapons.
ARCHIBALD MACLEISH, the poet, sat for a television portrait yesterday afternoon and the program was one of the season's more engrossing hours.

Merger of the Clinton Trust Company, into the Chase Manhattan Bank, has been approved in principle by directors of both banks. Negotiations continue that are expected to produce a proposal that can be laid before the stockholders.
The chief of the Navy's Bureau of Ships said yesterday that nuclear-powered submarine tankers or cargo ships would be too expensive for commercial use for some years.

ROME, Nov. 14 -- The coat of arms of Pope John XXIII was reproduced today. Osservatore Romano, Vatican newspaper, is identical with his coat of arms as Cardinal Patriarch of Venice with the addition of the tiara and crossed keys of St. Peter, symbols of the papacy.
HONG KONG, Nov. 14 -- The Governor of Shantung has been dismissed in a sweeping crackdown by the Peiping regime on officials in that North China province.

WITH the holiday season almost upon us, many parents are busy planning children's parties. Although the threat of pandemonium invariably exists, steady nerves, a maximum of organization and a liberal amount of adult supervision are one way to overcome it.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 14 (UPI) -- Bennie Oosterbaan resigned today after eleven years as football coach at the University of Michigan and Chalmers (Bump) Elliott was named to succeed him. The announcement confirmed a report yesterday that the athletic board had recommended the change.
TORONTO, Nov. 14 -- One of this continent's great horse shows, the Royal Winter Fair, began today in a pleasant maelstrom that included all the sights and sounds of a gigantic farm.

HERBERT VON KARAJAN is one of the busiest conductors in Europe,. He holds five or six of the most important posts on the Continent, but has found time to accept a two-week engagement as guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic. One wonders whether other maestros regard him as a combination in restraint of trade.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission ordered the St. Louis-San Francisco [Frisco] Railway Company today to divest itself of control of the Central of Georgia Railway Company within thirty days.
LONDON, Nov. 14 -- Industrials turned irregular in the stock market here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The Tuscarora Indians won at least a temporary victory today in their fight to keep the New York Power Authority from taking part of their reservation for the Niagara power project.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 14 -- Scientists of six nations will work together in a nuclear energy research center to be established by the European Community of Atomic Energy.

WASHINGTON. Nov. 14 (AP) -- James R. Hoffa, Teamster Union president, ordered postponement today of new officer elections scheduled for Local 377 at Youngstown, Ohio. A factional fight is in progress in the local.

Straus-Duparquet, Inc., manufacturer of hotel and restaurant equipment, has sold the six-story office and showroom building at 33-35 East Seventeenth Street to a client of Walter Scott Co., brokers. The seller leased back three floors. The property fronts seventy feet on Seventeenth Street and 110 feet on Eighteenth Street.

ALCOA, Tenn., Nov. 14 -- More than 400 union workers at the smelting plant of the Aluminum Company of America have voted to strike "if the company carries out its stated intentions of further decreasing crew sizes and increasing the work load."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 14 -- Joseph L. Mankiewicz is considering an invitation from Buddy Adler to reassociate with Twentieth Century-Fox. The writer - director-producer would head his own unit under terms of the proposition advanced by the studio chief at a recent meeting in New York.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 14 -- Opposition politicians assailed one of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's senior Cabinet Ministers today.

TO make reveries concrete is the task of the artist, and few artists knew this better than Odilon Redon (1840-1916). "My drawings inspire," he wrote. "They determine nothing. They place us, as does music, in the ambiguous realm of the undetermined."
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that he had "complete confidence" in Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy, whose department is being investigated by a grand jury in Brooklyn.
Amid boos from many in the crowd of 2,500, Tony Anthony of New York scored a unanimous ten-round decision over Sonny Ray of Chicago in Madison Square Garden last night.

DAMASCUS, United Arab Republic, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Sacred College of Orthodox Archbishops today elected Archbishop Theodoseos Abu Rjeileh of Tripoli, Lebanon, as Patriarch of Antioch and the Entire East.

The Modern Jazz Quartet, which is quite out of place in the smoky clamor of a night club and often seems a bit too brittle in the stiff formality of a concert hall, found a happy medium last night at a small art gallery, the Nonagon, 99 Second Avenue.
The United States Field Hockey Association's eight sectional tournaments -- five in the East, two in the Midwest and one in California -- will be conducted today and tomorrow.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 14 -- Alejandro Gomez, like some other Vice Presidents, has talked in a deprecatory way about the importance of his job. Short, heavy-set and amiable, the 50-year-old former teacher has frequently said: "A Vice President is like a spare tire on an auto mobile."

During the years when Nov. 11 was known as Armistice Day two minutes of silence was observed at 11 o'clock in the morning. As during our present-day air-raid exer cises, vehicles pulled over to the curb and remained motionless.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 14 -- The Yugoslav Government publicly buried today its long-cherished hopes that Poland's leaders would remain friendly despite the Soviet bloc's campaign against the Tito regime.
Slum conditions in the Hammels area of the Rockaways were surveyed yesterday by investigators from the Queens District Attorney's office and the Departments of Health, Housing and Buildings.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 14 -- A Yugoslav student magazine published today a blunt appeal to the Soviet people to halt the attacks on Boris Pasternak and allow him to receive the Nobel Prize for Literature.
CHICAGO, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Iowa's Charles (Deacon) Jones, national collegiate cross-country champion two years ago, won his first Big Ten harrier title today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 (UPI) -- About 100 refugees chased the car of Soviet Ambassador Mikhail A. Menshikov through a Chicago Loop street today. They tussled with Mr. Menshikov's bodyguard and one pounded the Ambassador's car with an anti-Communist sign.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Nov. 14 -- According to Lieut. Gen. Chiang Ching-kuo, who directs Nationalist China's underground operations on the mainland, the Chinese Communist leaders are beginning to realize they have pushed the Chinese people too far.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 14 -- Adherents of the Orthodox branch of Judaism were urged here today to extend their concern to the total needs of American Jews rather than limit their program to their own movement.
Three million Presbyerians will be asked to set aside Sunday, Dec. 7, as a day of prayer for "the reconciliation of men with God and with each other" in the conflict over racial integration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- A survey of patients in Jewish hospitals in four large cities shows that a third of the patients who stayed longer than thirty days did not require hospitalization beyond the thirty-day period.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Treasury announced tonight that it would pay an average interest rate of 2.997 per cent for $3,000,000,000 borrowed through a sale of 214-day tax anticipation bills.
CARACAS, Nov. 14 -- Governor-elect Nelson A. Rockefeller today described cooperation between the United States and Latin America as "terribly important" to both.

IN the two weeks between Monday morning and Dec. 2 about a half-million hunters will enter the woods of New York State to pursue deer. If they follow the pattern of recent years eleven of them will die of gunshot wounds and 116 others will be wounded.

OTTAWA, Nov. 14 -- Canadians decided today to wait and see how the expanded United States barter program will affect their own sales of agricultural commodities before taking a strong stand on the issue. This became clear today with an official statement from the Prime Minister's office.
The four major broadcasting networks will meet with the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists this morning in an attempt to forestall a strike at midnight tonight.

HAMBURG, Germany, Nov. 14 (UPI) -- The International Transport Workers Federation, in a move to enforce standardized shipping conditions, proclaimed today a four-day world-wide boycott for next month against the estimated total of 1,200 ships that fly "flags of convenience."

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- Dr. James B. Conant said today that American high school education was sound enough to meet all challenges. He deplored as ill-advised proposals that the European educational pattern be followed.

As many as one quarter of the cases of uterine cancer that are tested for throughout the United States today may be escaping detection during stages in which they could be most easily and successfully treated, a scientist said here yesterday.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 14 -- (UPI) -- Harold E. Stassen made another attack on Vice President Richard M. Nixon last night. He also outlined plans to revitalize the state Republican organization.
The State Labor Department reprimanded two supervisors yesterday for assigning a telephone operator in the Brooklyn office of the Employment Service to "spy" on another employe.

Having won two in a row, the New York Rangers will clash tonight at 8:30 with the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden -- the Blues' only Saturday night home game of the National Hockey League season.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday, 3 points higher to 1 point lower. (A point equals 5 cents a bale).
WHAT makes a good party menu for children? Mothers with a flair for pleasing the young may not agree on a specific menu, but they are guided primarily by age.
Unemployment in this state, as measured by applications for jobless insurance benefits, dropped slightly last week.

Is Saturday really a day off? True, the factory whistle does not blow that morning, nor does the time clock tick a few more pennies into the pay envelope. The boxes flippantly nicknamed Incoming and Outgoing remain empty on the desk, except for the hard core of unresolved problems at the bottom of Outgoing.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UPI) -- Representative John E. Moss accused President Eisenhower today of flouting the law by allowing the Air Force to withhold parts of a report criticizing its missile program.

Cleanliness is a prime requisite in a new plant opened this week at Danbury, Conn., by the Barden Corporation. The $2,500,000 plant produces ball bearings for aircraft and missile guidance control systems, instruments, computers, high speed cameras and dental drills.
BAY ST. LOUIS, Miss., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Mel Ott, former New York Giants baseball star, was critically injured tonight in an automobile collision that killed a man. Mrs. Ott was injured seriously.
MOSCOW, Nov. 14 -- The Soviet people were summoned to work today with a 32,000-word document that was as much a political manifesto as an economic plan.

Sales of the nation's major chains and mail order companies in October topped those of the 1957 month by 7.4 per cent, the best gain of the year. A compilation by The New York Times yesterday showed total sales by forty-four major chain stores of $1,584,708,763 against $1,475,620,393 in October, 1957.

Two or three dozen speculative favorites rushed wildly ahead in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange. The rest of the list followed more sedately, with the result that the market averages again showed fair gains.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The White House announced today that President Eisenhower had accepted the resignation of Charles I. Schottland as Commissioner of Social Security. The resignation will take effect on Jan. 1.
PARIS, Nov. 14 (Reuters) -- A new French law designed to open the Sahara to international research and oil development received Cabinet approval today.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 14 -- The remote and lonely man who leads India had a wonderful time this afternoon playing locomotive engineer.
Dr. Per Jacobsson, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, warned here last night against the danger of further inflation if the price of gold was raised.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 14 -- Harvard has added one part strained Latin to one part diced French to list its 1959 schedule in the program for tomorrow's game with Brown.
PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 14 -- Army's 150-pound football team crushed previously undefeated Princeton, 48 -- 12, today on University Field.

The Women's Association of Grace Protestant Episcopal Church is sponsoring a Christmas Fair to be held Wednesday at Grace House, 802 Broadway. Proceeds will be used to further the religious and social service work undertaken by the association.
The city needs about $135,000,000 of additional revenue to finance an adequate expense budget for the fiscal year starting July 1, Budget Director Abraham D. Beame declared yesterday.

The baleful handcuffing a few days ago of Albert Freedman, former producer of the "Twenty-One" program on TV is a shocking case of human degradation -- alien to the cherished traditions of Anglo-Saxon jurisprudence.
Prices for cocoa futures yesterday rose for the second consecutive day the 1 cent-a-pound daily limit in all positions on the New York Cocoa Exchange.

Miles Laboratories, Inc., producer of pharmaceuticals and chemicals, is planning to offer $6,035,400 of convertible subordinated debentures to holders of the company's common stock for subscription at the rate of $100 of debentures for each twenty shares held. The issue was registered yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Gibraltar, the famous Rock guarding the entrance to the Mediterranean, is the subject of a history by Allen Andrews. Dutton will publish it Jan, 28. Called "Proud Fortress: The Fighting History of Gibraltar," the book discusses the Rock from Moorish times, but it deals mainly with the fortress under British control and as the symbol of Britain's military and naval traditions.

AMERICANS have always recognized Italy as a great treasure house of art. It is also a great studio for American artists. We see that, with the shock of recognition, in Van Wyck Brooks' engaging and perceptive panorama, "The Dream of Arcadia: American Writers and Artists in Italy, 1760-1915."*
Plans now under consideration by the city call for an ultimate expansion of Harlem Hospital at a cost of $29,000,000.
CHICAGO, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The number of students enrolled in medical colleges in this country has reached a record total of 29,473.
MONTCLAIR, N. J., Nov. 14 -- Mrs. C. T. Woodford of Montclair was elected president of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association at the annual meeting today at the Montclair Golf Club.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Gerald T. (Jed) Hanley Jr., a Warren (R. I.) restaurateur was named president of the American Power Boat Association as the group's annual convention opened today at the Hotel Willard.

CAIRO, Nov. 14 -- The economic ties that bind the United Arab Republic and the Soviet Union were drawn closer today with the arrival of a group of experts to work out the details of Soviet aid in building the High Dam at Aswan on the Nile.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Greenwich Republican Town Committee withdrew tonight from the Fairfield G.O.P. county organization on the eve of the election of a new Republican county chairman.

CHESTER, N. Y., Nov. 14 -- Malcolm Richard White, 48-year-old industrialist accused of first-degree murder in the killing of a union organizer, will seek release on bail Monday from the Orange County Jail at Goshen.

ATLANTA, Nov. 14 -- Mayor William B. Hartsfield of Atlanta advocated a vote of the people today to determine whether the city's public schools should be sold or closed to sidestep pro-integration moves in Federal courts.

The Government has set a none too enviable record of abundance. Its investment in the surplus of one farm commodity -- wheat -- has just topped $3,000,000,000. That's a large sum to carry in a bread basket.

Stefan Osusky in his letter published Oct. 20 claims to throw new light on the events leading to the Munich agreement of 1938 and the Communist coup d'etat of Feb. 25, 1948. Although in a general sense I can agree with Mr. Osusky's essential statements, it is necessary to emphasize that not all his views on the subject are original.
Prizes for the best stories written by New York newspaper women in the last year were awarded last night at the annual Front Page Ball of the New York Newspaper Women's Club.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- An Akron industrialist testified today that economic warfare waged largely through legal loopholes by a labor union had cost his concern millions of dollars.
PALERMO, Sicily, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Sicilian police moved cautiously today in the kidnapping of an elderly New Yorker, fearing his captors might harm him if they acted hastily.
BERLIN, Nov. 14 -- Soviet soldiers detained three United States Army trucks and their drivers for eight and a half hours at a Soviet checkpoint on the Autobahn outside Berlin today.

SAN BRUNO, Calif., Nov. 14 (UPI) -- Manuel Ycaza, Panamanian jockey who rode mounts to victories worth more than $1,000,000 in the short time he was permitted on United States tracks this year, was injured seriously today in a three-horse spill at Tanforan.

YONKERS, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Chief Rainbow, a 6 - year - old horse by True Chief, shot from the No. 8 post at the start and never was headed in winning tonight's feature pace by a lengths and a half over Morris Eden at Yonkers Raceway. The time for the mile was 2:03.

ALBANY, Nov. 14 (UPI) -- The Public Service Commission authorized the New York Central Railroad today to close seven of its Putnam Division freight stations and to discontinue the handling of carload freight at three others.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Eddie LeBaron, the National Football Ieague's leading passer, is sick and may not be able to play for the Washington Redskins against the Cleveland Browns on Sunday.
A DINOSAUR under the Christmas tree might, at first glance, seem odd.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 14 (Reuters) -- The Foreign Ministry issued a statement today accusing Prime Minister Harold Macmillan of Britain of "crudely" offending Czechoslovakia.
While pedestrians on West Forty-third Street stopped to stare yesterday, an industrious motorcycle patrolman attached a ticket for illegal parking to a white Cadillac in front of the Century Club.
Nat Burns and Doro Merande will have two of the leading roles in "Starward Ark," the Thomas Sweeney comedy-melodrama about a space ship bound for the colonization of another planet.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The index of average wholesale prices in primary markets rose 0.1 per cent to 118.8 per cent of its 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

GENEVA, Nov. 14 -- The West's refusal to discuss political issues in the technical talks on surprise attack has brought about a concession. The East has decided not to submit the Rapacki plan to the conference.

Three new films will open today at first-run theatres. "Wind of Hate," a Greek-made drama with George Fountas and Smaro Yiouli, is at the Cameo Theatre. Eighth Avenue and Forty-fourth Street. Greek Motion Pictures, Inc., is distributing the import, with English titles.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- Dr. Klaus Fuchs, scientist who gave the Soviet Union atomic secrets, plans to go to Communist East Germany as a "convinced Marxist" on his release from prison next year.
PARIS, Nov. 14 -- France and the Soviet Union agreed here today to increase trade exchanges by about one-fourth in the next four years.

Geisenger Germain, realty operators, bought two five-story apartment houses on plot 100 by 100 feet at 607-11 East 139th Street in the Bronx from the Bellehr Realty Corporation. The building contains fifty-four apartments and were sold for cash over a first mortgage of $85,500. Sidney Newman Co. were the brokers.
CHICAGO, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Grain futures brokers showed a decided preference for the near-by contracts in an irregular market today on the Board of Trade.
PARIS, Nov. 14 -- It seemed likely tonight that some substitute for the European free trade area proposed by Britain would be sought by seventeen nations.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- A New York public relations man has designed an "obedience" dog collar that asserts authority without giving the dog a pain in the windpipe.

Premier Khrushchev has certainly not been stingy with the generous promises and bright forecasts in his report unveiling the main features of Soviet economic plans to 1965 and 1970. By 1970 the Soviet people are to have the world's highest standard of living and outdo our own production levels, both absolutely and on a per capita basis.

BUENOS AIRES, Saturday, Nov. 15 -- Representatives of President Arturo Frondizi, negotiating with Vice President Alejandro Gomez on his dispute with the President, said early today that Dr. Gomez had agreed to resign.

The report recently published by the Citizens Committee to Keep New York City Clean, Inc., covering its three years of progress in combating the city's litter problem, evokes commendation of the fine job done by this independent, public-spirited, nonpolitical group.

One workman was overcome by gas and 1,494 Bronx pupils were evacuated from Public School 70 yesterday afternoon when construction workers on the Cross Bronx Expressway ruptured a gas main at 174th Street and Weeks Avenue.
CAIRO, Ill., Nov. 15 (AP) -- The world's biggest goose hunt is in full swing. And it's big business.

Jay Morton Krause, a student rabbi from Queens, flew 600 miles yesterday to minister over the week-end to his Reform congregation in Florence, S. C.

If the man in the street was a mite confused yesterday as he strove to digest the report of Mayor Wagner's baseball committee, which aims to promote a third major league, he wasn't far behind men who make baseball their business. And that even went for the baseball commissioner, Ford C. Frick.
A symposium on the problems of migratory agricultural workers will be the highlight of the fourth annual Migrant Luncheon to be held Thursday in the Waldorf-Astoria.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Government dropped today a four-year lawsuit to keep trade-mark holders from excluding imports of goods made by affiliated foreign companies and bearing the same trade-marks

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Industrial production increased in October for the sixth consecutive month, the Federal Reserve Board estimated today. For the second consecutive month, however, the increase was held back by strikes in the automobile industry.

Shipments of refined copper to foreign consumers set a record last month, while deliveries in this country were the largest since June, 1956. Producers' stocks of copper dropped sharply throughout the free world.
Mayor Wagner assigned Deputy Mayor Paul T. O'Keefe yesterday to confer with Federal officials who have complained that the city is not doing enough to prevent the spread of slum conditions.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Hanna Building, Hanna Annex and the Hanna Theatre at Playhouse Square have been acquired by a Cleveland group -- including members of the Hanna family -- for approximately $5,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UPI) -- Two House investigators urged the Federal Communications Commission today to reconsider its award of Pittsburgh television Channel 4 to Television City, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UPI) -- The Census Bureau made it official today. This is still the land of opportunity for the single woman in search of matrimony.

The De Beneditis Realty Company sold the building containing thirty-two apartments and two stores at 656 Metropolitan Avenue, Brooklyn, to a client of S. Goldsmith for investment. The parcel is 50 by 100 feet. It was sold through the Knox Realty Company, broker.
The volume of new corporate financing next week will be somewhat heavier than has been the case this month.

NEWARK, Nov. 14 -- Newark's new Police Director opened an investigation today into the operations of a multi-million-dollar lottery syndicate. The ring was believed smashed last night by agents of the Treasury Department in three simultaneous raids.

TACOMA, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Dave Beck, former president of the Teamsters' Union on trial for income tax evasion, expressed concern today over possible publicity for political figures who have received cash contributions from the union.

BUDAPEST, Nov. 14 -- The bullock, cow and horse still reign supreme as work animals in the Hungarian countryside despite two five-year plans designed to mechanize agriculture and establish a modern industrial system.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 14 -- Dr. Auguste R. Lindt of Switzerland was re-elected by the General Assembly today to another term as United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.
PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 14 -- Amidst a throng of 100 curious spectators, five Princeton students said goodbye to Nassau Hall today and pedaled into the morning fog on their tandem bicycle.

Electric power production last week fell to 12,311,000,000 kilowatt hours from 12,330,000,000 in the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported. In the week ended Nov. 9, 1957, the output was 11,914,000,000 kilowatt hours.

PARIS, Nov. 14 -- France's Fifth Republic can be built upon a firmly democratic base only if the army's political aspirations are first smashed. General de Gaulle has recognized this from the start. Ever since he was projected back to power by an alliance of Right-Wing officers and Right-Wing civilians he has been quietly endeavoring to destroy that same alliance.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 14 (AP) -- A maid pointed to an itinerant Negro at State Police headquarters here tonight and said, "that's the man." She accused him of shooting two white women to death in their home near Bowling Green.
The season for talking to well-bred, well-groomed cats opened yesterday along with the fifty-fifth championship cat show of the Atlantic Cat Club at the New York Trade Show Building.
A former textile worker wept yesterday as he testified before a Senate subcommittee here on events of the four years since the Alexander Smith Carpet Company shut its Yonkers plant.
HAVANA, Nov. 14 (AP) -- George Bayer carded a six-under- par 64 today and gained the halfway lead in the $45,000 Havana international golf tournament. Bayer had a 139 for thirty-six holes.

The Hershey Chocolate Corporation yesterday reported its net income for the first nine months this year at $9,072,622, equal to $3.74 a share on 2,399,761 shares of common stock outstanding. The preferred stock was called for redemption last May 15.

It looks as if American women will find their waistlines again some time next spring. After a year of furious controversy over the chemise and its successors, in which the waist was up, down or just plain out, American designers seem to be sneaking back to a fitted middle.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower approved today an expanded list of strategical minerals that the Agricultural Department may seek from abroad through barter transactions.
The National Endorsement Corporation, 527 Madison Avenue, has surrendered its license to do business as a sales finance company in order to avoid revocation.
John Magliocco, a right half-back, scored twice and kicked an extra point as Poly Prep's eleven downed Horace Mann, 19 -- 0, in an Ivy Prep League game on the loser's field in the Bronx.

MOSCOW, Nov. 14 -- The Sovit Union accused the United States and Britain today of using "gross pressure and blackmail" in support of a United Nations resolution calling for a temporary cessation of tests of nuclear weapons.

COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., Nov. 14 (UPI) -- Ernest J. Lanigan, a founding member of the Baseball Writers Association of America who did his first writing on baseball in 1888, has retired as historian of the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum, it became known today.
CARIO, Nov. 14 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic continued his fence-mending tour of the lower Nile delta today.

LONDON, Nov. 14 (Reuters) -- Nikita S. Khrushchev said today that the Soviet Union intended to make "definite proposals" on the status of Berlin to the countries that fought against the Axis powers in World War II.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 14 -- Charges of accepting or offering bribes were preferred today against Hans Kilb, former personal secretary of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, and three directors of the Daimler-Benz Motor Company.

Herman H. Maass, president of the Security National Bank of Long Island, Huntington, L. I., denied yesterday that recent merger discussions with the Meadow Brook National Bank, Hempstead, L. I., meant that his institution was for sale.

Lewis Conger, 125-year-old New York specialty and house-wares retailer, emerged yesterday from reorganization under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Act. The concern is under new management and will operate under somewhat different policies than it did before.
The Protestant Council of the City of New York began a drive last night to raise $100,000 for its work with young people in areas of high delinquency.
Carlisle Floyd's "Susannah" received a fine performance last night at the City Center, and a large share of the credit must go to two young singers who were heard in the opera for the first time.

Guests at the ninth annual Fan Ball last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza danced, beneath a canopy of yellow and white satin streamers and dined tat yellow-covered tables with centerpieces of purple orchids.
HIGHLAND, N. Y., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Two members of the district school board said today they would continue to authorize corporal punishment with a soft rubber hose in the Highland school system.
CARMEL, N. Y., Nov. 14 -- Martin Anzalone of the Bronx pleaded not guilty today to a charge of first-degree murder in the slaying of a deputy game warden.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Jordanian Minister Thabet Khalidi took up with Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold today his Government's charges that Syrian jet fighters set upon King Hussein's plane.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 14 -- The General Assembly adopted today the report of its Political Committee and called for a settlement in the divided Korean Peninsula by elections under United Nations supervision.

BAYONNE, N. J., Nov. 14 -- The ranking house-cleaning job at the Navy's Supply Depot here is held by a woman. Lieut. Cmdr. Natalie T. Bell, as chief disposal officer, has the task of assembling, listing and disposing of surplus, obsolete or worn out Navy material amounting annually to more than $25,000,000 in original cost.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The United States sought to assure its European Allies today that it had no intention of withdrawing behind batteries of intercontinental ballistic missiles based in this country.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., NOV. 14 -- The General Assembly voted today to finance the continued operation on a temporary basis of the United Nations Emergency Force, which is patrolling the border between Egypt and Israel.
The largest cargo carrier built in the United State will go down the ways of the Bethlehem Steel Company's shipyard in Quincy, Mass., today.

Events today: Nerdi's "OtelIo," 2 P.M., and Puccini's "Madama Butterfly," 8; both at Metropolitan Opera; "Madama Butterfly," 2:30, and Verdrs "La Traviata," 8:15, both at New York City Center; Gounod's "Faust," Amato Opera Theatre, 159 Bleecker Street, 8:15; Verdi's "Aida," Carl Yohst Mastersingers, High School of Fashion Industries, 8; Mozart's "Don Giovanni," Opera Workshop, Public School 75.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 14 -- Rear Admiral Wolfgang Larrazabal resigned the Presidency of Venezuela's governing junta today to devote himself to his campaign to become constitutional President.
MIAMI, Nov. 14 (AP) -- John Forbes led the Maryland Terrapins to a 26-14 victory over the University of Miami Hurricanes before 26,747 football fans in the Orange Bowl tonight.

Princeton has the chance to wrest the Big Three championship from Yale today in football's oldest continuous rivalry. While the Tiger and the Bulldog are meeting, for the eighty-first time, in the Bowl at New Haven, Cornell and Dartmouth, tied with Nassau for the Ivy leadership, will confront each other on Schoellkopf Field in Ithaca.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- President Eisenhower said today that the Government's three - year - old rural development program was providing a framework for strengthening the nation's agriculture on a long-term basis.

TORONTO, Nov. 14 -- Jack Kent Cooke, owner of the Toronto Maple Leafs of the International League, said today that the New York baseball committee's proposal for a third major league might compel club owners in the American and National Leagues to change their views.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Gov. Goodwin J. Knight declared today that Vice President Richard M. Nixon was the unchallenged leader of the Republican party in California.
ATHENS, Nov. 14 -- Archbishop Makarios, exiled primate of the Greek Cypriotes, said today that the Greek Government would ask the United Nations to seek independence for Cyprus.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 14 -- Sweden suggested today that the United Nations establish its own radio broadcast facilities to "have its voice heard in the four corner of the world."

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 14 (UPI) -- Perry Jones, the non- playing captain, and Jack Kramer, the coach, brought the vanguard of the United States Davis Cup tennis team to Australia today. Kramer scheduled the first practice session for tomorrow in the drive to recapture the cup from Australia.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The Administration is giving serious consideration to an increase in the Federal tax on gasoline next year.
JERSEY CITY, Nov. 14 -- An ordinance was adopted today calling for a referendum on whether a charter study commission should be set up to determine the best form of government for Jersey City.
An assistant vice president of a Richmond Hill, Queens, bank was shot dead yesterday as he emerged from his office to remonstrate with a hold-up man.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 14 -- Withdrawal of the 840,000-member carpenters union from the A.F.L.-C.I.O. was authorized today.
A program to train fifty community-organization specialists for employment by social welfare departments in fifty major city and state concils of churches was approved yesterday.

In the aggressive self-satisfaction of the American people over their standard of living there is a tendency to concentrate attention on those in the upper reaches of the income scale and to forget those at the lower levels. For several years Governor Harriman's Interdepartmental Committee on Low Incomes has been doing its best to correct this imbalance and to coordinate efforts, both public and private, to deal with the problems of the underpaid.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Army's rate of rejection for Selective Service registrants has increased about 10 per cent as a result of higher standards made effective last August.

OSLO, Norway, Nov. 14 -- With one dissenting vote, Swedish, Danish, Norwegian and Icelandic representatives joined today in pledging an all-out effort toward setting up a European free trade area.

GRUENSTADT, Germany, Oct. 26 -- The morning fog had burned away by noon, and the checkerboard countryside of the Rhineland-Palatinate lay placid in the smoky autumn atmosphere. Beneath the broad green leaves of the sugar-beet plants partridge lay. Pheasants were hidden from sight in the harvested hay fields. Roebuck dozed in the patches of oak and birch woods that dapple all of Germany.
INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Former President Harry S. Truman and the Democratic National Chairman conferred today on election strategy for 1960.

Samuel Reshevsky of the United States gained the lead with a score of 10 -- 2 in the international chess tournament at Tel Aviv last night, according to a report from Israel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organization heartened by the results of last week's elections, called on its affiliates today for a still greater effort in the political campaigns of 1959 and 1960.
NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 15 -- A member of Congress who was defeated for re-election on Nov. 4 was chosen today to head the Fairfield County Re publican Organization for the next two years.

HOUSTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -Charley Milstead, an injured tailback who was a doubtful starter, scored two touchdowns and passed for another today in leading Texas A. M. to a 28-21 upset victory over Rice. The setback knocked the Owls out of a tie for the Southwest Conference lead.

LILLE, France, Nov. 15 -- In a campaign where nearly everyone but the Communists professes to be Gaullist, it is fortunate for the voters that the 121 candidates for the National Assembly from the Department of Nord are not all campaigning against each other.

PARIS, Nov. 15 -- Two weeks of the electoral campaign for the first Parliament of the Fifth Republic have apparently failed to arouse great voter interest or provoke any great debate on France's major problems.

The appointment of John C. Niedermair as consulting naval architect was announced yesterday by Gibbs Cox, one of the world's foremost firms of naval architects and marine engineers. Mr. Niedermair has ship-design experience dating back to World War I. One of the most spectacular "growth industries" of them all -- plastics -- will put its newest materials, processes, machines and products on display to the trade tomorrow in Chicago.

IF the musical revue has lost the vogue it used to have on American stages, "La Plume de Ma Tante" may suggest part of the answer. American musical shows are generally produced under terrible pressure.

SEVERAL novel ideas are incorporated in the new series of Explorer automatic slide projectors just introduced by Bell Howell of Chicago. Enclosed in a self-contained, low-silhouette machine of attractive design and light-gauge steel construction, the projectors have an illuminated control board (including focusing knob) at the back; remote control for moving slides forward or in reverse; and a slide holder with a bubble for mechanically preventing the slide from going out of focus.

MADRID, Nov. 15 (Reuters) -- A Spaniard who was alleged to have engaged in Communist activities in the United States and Cuba, headed a list of twelve accused Communists who were sentenced today to prison terms ranging from six months to twenty years.

NEWARK, Nov. 15 -- The appointment of an Essex County planning officer by the Board of Freeholders was proposed in a report made public this week by a special committee of members of planning agencies throughout the county.

THE poetry of Stanley Kunitz, which has been a matter of artistic record for many years, has never had the general praise that it deserves. Gardening does not have to stop with colder weather. The hobbyist can carry on in a window greenhouse. Made of slim aluminum framing and glass, it can be fitted to almost any size window. The heat from the room is sufficient, but for very cold climates heating units may be added.

Stabilization of the political situation in the Middle East is one of the major challenges to world diplomacy, Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the World Zionist Organization, said last night.

BURKITTSVILLE, Md. -- To the list of the Maryland mountains' scenic and historic spots a new site was added last week with the official dedication of the new Gathland State Park on South Mountain, a mile west of here on State Route 572.

Retailers in the New York area estimated sales last week were 1 to 4 per cent above the 1957 level. Gains of about 10 per cent in Veterans Day sales over those of the 1957 holiday contributed heavily to the results.

A rewritten edition of the American Practical Navigator -- better known to mariners as "Bowditch" -- wil be published on Dec. 6 by the United States Navy Hydrographic Office in Washington.

For though the word "Zen" is Japanese and though Japan is now its home, Zen Buddhism is the creation of the T'ang dynasty of China. . I do not say this as a prelude to harping upon the incommunicable subtleties of alien cultures.

THIS Saturday one of America's most colorful Vice Presidents will be 90. As the day approaches, John Nance Garner quietly passes the time in his usual way -- "just reading and living" -- here in his home town where he started his forty-six-year career of public service in 1895,

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- For the last six years, the attention of the capital has been focused on the person of the President and the conduct of the Presidency. Now it is centered on the Senate of the United States and on the person of the majority leader there, Senator Lyndon Johnson of Texas.
