SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 13 -- The first manned rocket to Mars may be powered by a fusion engine, carry a crew trained in the high Andes, a goat and ingenious devices to avert boredom.
HARTFORD, Nov. 15 -- The appointment of four more members to the Board of Regents of the new University of Hartford was announced today. The university will be constructed soon in West Hartford.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 15 (AP) -- The smallest Michigan Stadium crowd in thirteen seasons watched in the rain today as Indiana upset Michigan, 8 -- 6. There were only 31,000 persons in the bowl, which seats 100,001.

THE excitement over stereo records has obscured the fact that stereo as such is not really new. It has been quite popular among serious hi-fiers for about two years in the form of stereo tapes. An estimated half-million tape enthusiasts were enjoying two-channel sound long before the new disks loosened the current stereo landslide.
MY brother, Morris Gest, was responsible for the fame of the Moscow Art Theatre in this country. He was ably assisted by Oliver Sayler, who died at the age of 71 on Oct. 19.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Penn State ran through its football repertory for the benefit the home folks today. Almost everything the Nittany Lions tried worked as they rolled up a 32-0 victory over Holy Cross.
I READ appreciatively the review by Lynn Montross of Leon Wolff's book "In Flanders Field."

TAMPA, Fla. -- A snow carnival with a ski run sixty feet high and ice skating performances, a definite novelty for Florida, will be staged here for one week starting next Wednesday. It may be continued for another week or two if the ice and snow can be made to stay put long enough under the Florida sun.

It may be continued for another week or two if the ice and snow can be made to stay put long enough under the Florida sun.

HUNTINGTON, Pa., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Bill Berrier, the fullback, scored three touchdowns, two on rusn of 84 and 65 yards, today as he led Juniata to its fifth undefeated season in six years with a 33-12 victory over Albright.
FIVE local galleries are currently displaying photographic exhibits varying widely in content and treatment.
QUINCY, Mass., Nov. 15 -- The Queen of Greece gave her blessing today to the largest commercial cargo ship ever built in the United States.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 15 (AP) -- James T. Karam, a close associate of Gov. Orval E. Faubus, withdrew tonight as a candidate for the Little Rock school board. But fifteen others filed for the six positions.

ATLANTA, Nov. 15 (UPI) -- Gov. Marvin Griffin called an unusual Saturday morning news conference today to announce that the State of Georgia would not permit integration of Atlanta public schools under any circumstances.

Vassar College received a record total of $3,701,361 in gifts during the year ending last June 30. . . . New grants amounting to $150,000 were recently awarded to Fordham University to support research in the physical sciences during the current academic year. . . .

HOW does one write about the artist in America? The job is not so easy as one might think. The true artist, though he may live around the corner, as E. E. Cummings does in New York's Greenwich Village, rightfully guards his elusive character.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 15 -- An exhibition of famous paintings, letters and documents honoring William Pitt, first Earl of Chatham, for whom Pittsburgh was named, was opened to the public today at Chatham College. The exhibition, a prelude to this city's bicentennial celebration, will remain open until June 9.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov. 15 (UPI) -- West Virginia's Mountaineers, led by the passing and running of Dick Longfellow, smothered William and Mary, 56 -- 6, today to nail down their fifth Southern Conference football title in six years.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 15 (UPI) -- Gene Etter, a 155-pound tailback, squirted and struggled 75 yards for a fourth-period touchdown today that enabled downtrodden Tennessee to upset Missippi, 18 to 16.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- For the last six years, the attention of the capital has been focused on the person of the President and the conduct of the Presidency. Now it is centered on the Senate of the United States and on the person of the majority leader there, Senator Lyndon Johnson of Texas.

THE magnet of popularity and dollars attracting twentieth century European art to this country still draws on apparently inexhaustible sources. The latest haul, and an important one, is now being shown at the Rose Fried Gallery, 40 East Sixty-eighth Street.
The Knickerbockers, weary from an all-night train trip from Syracuse, built up enough steam yesterday to derail the Minneapolis Lakers, 98 -- 90, before 5,243 at Madison Square Garden.

The Thursday performance of the musical comedy "Salad Days" at the Barbizon Plaza Theatre will be a benefit for the National Council of Women of the United States. Mrs. Lloyd K. Garrison and Mrs. G. E. Kidder Smith are co-chairmen of the benefit committee.
Samuel Reshevsky of the United States and Laszlo Szabo of Hungary adjourned their thirteenth-round game in the Israel international chess tournament, according to a report last night from Tel Aviv.

HAVANA, Nov. 16 (AP) -George Bayer defeated Sam Snead in a sudden-death play-off for first place in the $45,000 Havana international golf tournament today. Snead three-putted the first extra hole after he and Bayer had tied with 72-hole scores of 286.

CAMPOBELLO DI MAZARA, Sicily, Nov. 16 (AP) -- An elderly American, kidnapped a week ago, walked to freedom today. He had been held in a remote cave after being seized while visiting his Sicilian birthplace.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Jim Brown, fullback; Paul Brown, coach, and all the other Browns -- Cleveland variety -- are again sitting by themselves on top of the Eastern Division of the National Football League.

GENEVA, Nov. 16 -- Suggestions that the foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union be summoned to break the deadlocks in the two East-West conferences here were made by Communist sources today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- (UPI) George Shaw completed nine straight passes and Alan Ameche bulled for 142 yards today in leading the Baltimore Colts to a 17-0 victory over the Chicago Bears. It was the first shutout of George Halas' eleven in 149 National Football League games.

The annual Christmas bazaar of the French-American Wives will be held at the Rattazzi Restaurant on Dec. 6. Proceeds will aid French charitable organizations, such as Les Petits Freres des Pauvres and Le Centre Francais de Protection de l'Enfance.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 16 -Chaminade clinched the Catholic High Schools Football League championship today by defeating Holy Cross, 32 -- 19, before 4,500 fans. The championship is the Flyers' second in three years.
AHMADABAD, India, Nov. 16 (Reuters) -A masterly display by Nari Contractor, Indian opening batsman, enabled the Cricket Board of Control President's XI to force a draw with the West Indies today.

PURCHASE, N. Y., Nov. 16 -- The newly selected Northeast all-star team defeated the reserve eleven, 3-0, in the finale of the two-day women's Northeast field hockey tournament at Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart today. The squad will represent the area in the national tournament.
Stavros Niarchos, the Greek shipping executive, announced yesterday that he would build the world's largest tanker despite what he called illegal threats from the world's maritime labor unions.
Organized labor insists that a sharp rise in industrial productivity is keeping unemployment high while pushing corporate profits toward record levels.

The co-author of the Taft-Hartley Act of 1947 called it "entirely too weak" in a television broadcast yesterday. Fred A. Hartley Jr., New Jersey Republican who has retired from the House of Representatives, urged stricter measures against mass picketing and secondary boycotts.
ONE of Paris' foremost couturiers, Alix Gres, is now touring India in a move designed to bring the ancient Indian handcraft of weaving more in tune with the modern Western market.
John D. Rockefeller 3d announced yesterday the completion of the team of architects that will design the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.
An expanded Zionist youth program in this country to exploit the increased interest in Israel was advocated here yesterday.
HUNTSVILLE, Utah, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Two of eight airmen who parachuted from a disabled military cargo plane into a blizzard Friday were dead when rescuers found them, the Air Force reported today.
KEARNY, N. J., Nov. 16 (AP) -- The police booked a former convict tonight on suspicion of murder in the shooting of Joseph E. Barbito in gangland fashion.

The "fundamental good relations'' between Southern Jews and their neighbors have not changed because of synagogue bombings and other anti-Jewish outbreaks in the South, Philip M. Klutznick, president of B'nai B'rith, declared yesterday.

THE Danish National Orchestra, which toured this country in 1952, is back in, our midst and appeared at Carnegie Hall last night. This is the ensemble that performs not only under the patronage of its King Frederik IX but also under his baton.

Rudolf Bing, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, and John H. Johnson, Chicago magazine publisher, were honored last night at the second annual Freedom Fund dinner sponsored by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

MILAN, Italy, Nov. 16 (AP) -- When Maria Meneghini Callas sang her farewell at La Scala Opera last May 31, she said that she would not be back next season. The soprano won't be anywhere on La Scala's bill when the opera season opens in three weeks.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Twenty-eight types of items bought regularly by the Post Office Department henceforth will be purchased exclusively from small business concerns, the department and the Small Business Administration announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Spending on new construction will rise 7 per cent next year to a record of $52,300,000,000, the Government estimated today. This will be based on a wave of home and highway building, it was said.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov.16 (Reuters) -- President Mohammed Ayub Khan announced tonight that all troops would be withdrawn from martial-law duties and that all standing military courts would be dissolved immediately.
An off-duty policeman and an off-duty fireman led forty persons to safety yesterday from a smoky fire in a four-story dwelling in Brooklyn.

ST.-GAUDENS, France, Nov. 16 -- As of 10:30 A. M. yesterday, St.-Gaudens, in the foothills of the Pyrenees, fifty miles south of Toulouse, had 8,023 inhabitants, most of them friends of Hippolyte Ducos.
Many young Americans were depicted yesterday as feeling that military service right after high school did not seriously interfere with their pursuit of either a college education or a career.
PARIS, Nov. 16 -- The Government has just completed a series of agreements with various businesses to push exports.

The passing of the noted artist Charles Robert Patterson, recorded in your issue of Nov. 10, is indeed a loss to American art and to all who have seen his magnificent paintings of American sailing ships in the great days of the clipper.
The suggestion that earth satellites and atomic clocks be used to prove whether or not time slows down as velocity increases has been renewed by an astronomer at Columbia University.

" Kitchener: Portrait of an Imperialist," a new biography by Philip Magnus, will be published by Dutton on Jan. 19. It covers all aspects of the soldier-administrator's life, shedding new light on British relations with Egypt.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- A method of avoiding dangerous radioactive fall-out was suggested today by Dr. Willard F. Libby, a member of the Atomic Energy Commission. He said it could help save 10,000,000 lives in wartime.

Amor Musicae, the group that offers baroque music played on baroque instruments, opened its sixth season with a concert at Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon.

Italian politics are in a storm-and-stress period that does not make headlines outside of the country but has potentialities that could be important to all of us. The Government of Premier Fanfani is operating on the narrowest majority of any Italian regime since 1948. When Signor Fanfani won his initial vote of confidence last July he had a margin of only eight seats in the Chamber of Deputies.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 16 -- The Roman Catholic Church in Venezuela warned its adherents today against voting for Communists in the elections Dec. 7.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 16 -- The Ruhr steel companies have canceled coal import contracts worth about $20,000,000 to United States producers, the Iron and Steel Industry Association has announced.

Econo Laundry leased the commercial building at 2712 Hudson Boulevard, Jersey City, N. J., from the R. E. Realty Corporation for occupancy as a coin-operated laundry. The George J. Wolf Realty Company was the broker.
PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Nov. 16 -- The West Indies Federal Government will begin its second session -- a critical one -here tomorrow.
Cotton futures prices, after experiencing wide fluctuations, dropped last week.

Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy announced yesterday the awarding of 446 citations to members of the force for meritorious service. The last previous awards were made in September.
The work of the Church Charity Foundation Woman's Board of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island will be aided by the proceeds of a Fall Festival to be held on Thursday in Brooklyn.

WILLIAM O. DOUGLAS, Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court, must wonder sometimes if he is not in considerable danger of becoming better known as a writer than as a jurist. Since his appointment to the high court nineteen years ago he has written eleven books, five of them popular accounts of his strenuous travels in the more inaccessible regions of Asia.

The National Recreation Association at 8 West Eighth Street is appealinng for games, materials for arts and crafts, and recreation equipment for use in an experimental project to provide recreational activities in nursing homes that cannot afford them.
TOKYO, Nov. 16 (UPI) -- The St. Louis Cardinals swept their last two games today for a record of fourteen victories against two losses in their goodwill series against the Japanese AllStars.
A plastic molding technique said to permit important manufacturing savings has been released by W. R. Grace Co. under a licensing arrangement to the entire thermoplastic molding industry.
THE Composers Showcase, a series of concerts with discussions begun last season at the Nonagon Art Gallery, 99 Second Avenue, opened its second season last night.
Johann Strauss' "Die Fledermaus" will be revived at the Metropolitan Opera in a special nonsubscription performance Thanksgiving evening, Nov. 27.
The networks and a television and radio performers union appear to be still somewhat apart on one major contract issue, despite an agreement to delay a strike deadline seventy-two hours.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- The Most Rev. Albert G. Meyer was enthroned today in Holy Name Cathedral here as the fifth Archbishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Chicago.

The Rev. Dr. John M. Krumm, chaplain of Columbia University, yesterday called on American Protestantism to "repudiate publicly" those of its leaders who "are outdoing themselves these days in anti-Catholic bigotry."
Cash dividends paid on common stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange inched up to a new record during the first nine months of the year, the magazine Exchange said today.
Contracts for four new merchant vessels were placed with American shipbuilders last month, ending a seven-month drought.

Last spring Pete Rothermel, St. George's football coach, sounded out William A. Buell, the school's headmaster, about playing a home-and-home series with the Kent (Conn.) school. Buell was not enthusiastic.
An aircraft lighting system designed to help prevent mid-air collisions was demonstrated last week during the Flight Safety Foundation meeting in Atlantic City.

Shipments of folding paper boxes in October fell 5.1 per cent below the same month last year, according to a report by the Folding Paper Box Association. Dollar volume was off 5.5 per cent from a year earlier.

" SMALL WORLD," Edward R. Murrow's international conversation piece, had a lively session yesterday afternoon on the role of the public relations officer in government. In touching on a subject that is so seldom explored, the pity was that the program over Channel 2 could not have lasted longer.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 16 -- The supply of credit for home loans will be bolstered in the coming year by a record total of repayments on loans currently in force, it was predicted here today.
DETROIT, Nov. 16 -- Chrysler Corporation and the United Auto Workers came to terms tonight on the last company-wide contract, thus ending a strike that started five days ago.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Resentment is growing among the armed services over alleged personnel raids by the new National Aeronautics and Space Administration.
" La Boheme," which closed the season of the New York City Opera Company at the City Center last night, also featured a debut, that of Maria Candida as Musetta.

TETUAN, Morocco, Nov. 16 -- A three-day national holiday opened here today with a show of force as King Mohamed V and the Government reviewed 13,000 troops in this northern capital on the rim of the trouble-infested Rif Mountains.
When the members of the Distilled Spirits Institute meet in Washington, D. C., on Thursday, some long-standing taboos may be revised.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Nov. 16 - Dealing in Interhandel stock was by far the most conspicuous feature of stock exchange business all last week. Dealers adopted the slogan: "The cold war goes on." Nevertheless, volumes were large.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 16 -- There was a pause today in the campaign by President Arturo Frondizi's Administration to eliminate Vice President Alejandro Gomez from the Argentine Governmnt. But Administration sources said that Dr. Gomez, whose differences with President Frondizi seem irreconcilable, would submit his resignation to the Senate this week.
McMURDO SOUND, Antarctica, Nov. 14 -- The savage cold of the Antarctic winter has been found to produce its own tempering mechanism.
HONG KONG, Nov. 16 -- Rationing of rice ended yesterday in Canton, according to the Communist daily, Ta Kung Pao of Hong Kong.
The oil industry's leading trade association called yesterday for a halt to any further rise in the Federal tax on gasoline.

Your editorial of Nov. 11 on the Algerian elections fully understands the crucial importance, for the survival of French democracy and the West's moral position, of assuring freedom for the Algerians. Unfortunately, even Premier de Gaulle, with all his excellent intentions, seems to share the inability to rise above the past, to accept the present and thus to strengthen liberty at home and abroad.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Nov. 16 -- The Hungarian Communist party's voting machinery functioned smoothly and efficiently in parliamentary elections today.
CARMEL, N. Y., Nov, 16 -New York State game wardens, wary of gun-happy hunters, intensified their patrol on poachers today in Putnam County.
FOR those with a premonition of a pre-Yuletide turmoil, Irvington House is offering an unusual Christmas card service.
HAMBURG, Germany, Nov. 15 (Reuters) -- The Hamburg Stock Exchange, second oldest in West Germany, celebrated its 400th anniversary today.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Nov. 16 -- Glen Foster, at the tiller of Ordeal, triumphed for the second successive week in the Larchmont Yacht Club's championship frostbite racing today.

BOSTON, Nov. 16 -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation and its director, J. Edgar Hoover, are being subjected to "a smear attack" for their zeal in exposing the enemies of this country, Archbishop Richard J. Cushing declared today.

A team of American surgeons left New York last night for five weeks of volunteer work in the Middle East. The group, part of an organization called Medico, will do special surgery among Arab refugees.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 16 -- A happy, scholarly band of Civil War buffs met here in the fog and drizzle today to start rehashing the conflict.

El Paso Natural Gas Company and subsidiaries reported over the week-end higher sales and lower net income for three and nine months ended Sept. 30. Sales for nine months totaled $262,200,675 against $214,013,976 a year earlier.

The capacity gathering of 115,925 clamored for action in the National Hockey League game between the New York Rangers and the Montreal Canadiens at Madison Square Garden last night. Rhodesian Selection Trust, Ltd., a holding company for mining interests, in its report for the fiscal year ended June 30, released today shows a net income of 956,047 ($2,676,931). This compares with a profit of 3,027,624 ($7,477,347) in the previous year.

Ed Kennedy of the Manhattan College Athletic Association captured the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union five-mile handicap cross-country race yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx. Thirty-seven runners started.

VICTORY GARDENS, N. J., Nov. 16 -- The residents of this little town learned today what it is like to be a refugee. They were tagged, they were counted and they were dependent on neighbors for food and clothing.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- The stock market was patchy here last week and lacked the buoyancy that had characterized the preceding two months. But the undertone was steady enough to permit good features to develop, particularly in the mining and oil sections.
ALBANY, Nov. 16 (AP) -State controller Arthur Levitt announced today the distribution of $24,204,663 as per capita assistance to the state's cities, towns and villages.

Traffic of the nation's intercity common carrier truck operators rose 2.3 per cent in September, despite a teamsters' strike that seriously crippled the operations of most lines in eleven western states. The work stoppage ended on Sept. 19.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 16 -- The stock index reached 243 points last week, which was above the 1957 high. It compares with 168 at the beginning of last January.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Nov. 16 -- Donald A. Quarles, deputy secretary of defense, declared today that the United States and other Free World nations must change their educational systems to meet the Soviet challenge.

DETROIT, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Gene Gedman, forgotten man in the Detroit Lions' attack, passed for one touchdown, plunged for another and caught a pass for a third as the Lions beat the San Francisco Forty-Niners, 35 -- 21, today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- An official analysis of two recent Soviet explosions of nuclear weapons strongly suggests that they were staged primarily for their psychological impact on the West.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The "Committee of Twenty-one," consisting of representatives of the American republics, will begin conferring here tomorrow on the economic problems of Latin America.
CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Speculative trading dominated the grain futures market almost entirely last week, but it lacked a strong moving force either way.

PLAINEDGE, L. I., Nov. 16 -- The "coffee-klatsch" approach to obtain voter approval for a new junior high school is being tried by members of the Board of Education and school officials here. Coffee, cake, a homey atmosphere and pleasant discussions about $2,250,000 are being mixed to make the plan more palatable to taxpayers of the school district.
CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- An American Medical Association publication issued yesterday says that school examinations do not have to be nightmares.

Unless the city receives a substantial increase in state aid it must impose new taxes or increase existing ones to have an adequate and balanced expense budget for 1959-60, City Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs declared yesterday.

People today are living in "an age of repression in which men are not only persecuted for their political ideas and their religious beliefs but even for the color of their skin," the Rev. Bernard P. Donachie declared yesterday.
NEWARK, Nov. 16 -- Ch. Westhay Fiona of Harham won best-in-show honors today among 887 dogs in the Newark Kennel Club's fortieth event at the 113th Infantry Armory.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Rams, spurred by a 93-yard touchdown pass play from Billy Wade to Jim Phillips, defeated the Green Bay Packers, 20 -- 7, today. The Rams moved into a tie for second place in the National Football League's Western Conference with the Chicago Bears. A crowd of 28,051 saw the game.

PARIS, Nov. 16 -- Soviet policy has long been guided by a cynical version of the theory conceived by that brilliant German general, Karl von Clausewitz. Clausewitz considered war "a continuation of state policy by other means." The Communist leaders have inverted this.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -The national party chairmen who directed the Congressional campaign of 1958 appeared likely today to continue to guide their parties toward the Presidential campaign of 1960.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 16 -- The American electorate was praised today for having voted in the recent elections "on the basis of the candidates' qualifications as individuals and not in terms of membership in minority religious groups."
Evening coats have come into their own glory this season. This beautiful coat fashion is sweeping down theatre aisles and making grand entrances in ball rooms and at special parties.

The outstanding supply of local government bonds, now estimated at about $55,000,000,000, will rise to within $100,000,000,000 within ten years, according to the Chicago bond house of John Nuveen Co., the nation's oldest investment house dealing exclusively in local government securiteies.

Msgr. Louis D. Berube, Vicar General of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Ogdensburg, N. Y., urged Catholic laymen yesterday to become "witnesses for Christ" in promoting the influence of their church over the world.
By the margin of an extra point, Louisiana State remains the only major college eleven with a perfect record.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 16 -- An Israeli-sponsored Asian-African seminar on cooperation opened here today.
HAVANA, Nov. 16 -- Army headquarters here announced last night that 113 rebels had been killed by Government troops in Oriente Province. Three soldiers were killed and four wounded, the army said.

Adolph Flashner, owner of the King of the Sea Restaurant at 879 Third Avenue, has taken title to the adjoining, four-story building at 877 Third Avenue, on the northeast corner of Fifty-third Street. He began assembling property there in 1932 and now controls the entire blockfront on the east side of the avenue from Fifty-third to Fifty-fourth Street. He has announced plans for a twenty-one story apartment building on the block.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16 -- (UPI) -- Clarence 'Peaks scored three touchdowns within five minutes in the second period today and added one in the third period as the Philadelphia Eagles trounced the Chicago Cardinals, 49-21.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 16 -- Buddy Adler, Twentieth Century-Fox production chief, has brought Bing Crosby into the studio fold on a two-picture contract with Bing Crosby Productions.
WASHINGTON, Nov, 16 (UPI) -- A Government survey disclosed today that at least thirty-one of 111 labor unions elect their top national and international officers by secret ballot.

For many weeks Fifty-seventh Street about Sixth and Seventh Avenues has been continually torn up and replaced, each time leaving huge holes and protruding manhole covers, over which the traffic can be continuously heard crashing its way.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The fourth, and perhaps last, annual battle over how to tax the income of life insurance companies will begin tomorrow. Observers expect this one will end the war, on a compromise formula now circulating through the industry and government offices.
Waste and extravagance in the school construction program of the Board of Education will be charged in a report to be made public soon, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa said yesterday.

FREDERICK-THOMAS Associates today are opening a new Christmas Boutique, in their shop at 210 East Sixtieth Street, No gift in the boutique costs more than $15.

Net income of the Coco-Cola Company rose to $10,978,036, or $2.60 a share, in the third quarter of this year from $10,215,086, or $2.41 a share, in the similar three months of last year.

The near-by December cocoa position rose the daily limit of 1 cent a pound yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. This was the third consectutive trading day of limit rises for the position. Other months Were not as strong, and the distant positions registered the smallest advances.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The Treasury today announced its new "middle ground" theory for taxing the income of life insurance companies. It would combine the two historically established approaches to this controversial question. That is, it would base the tax on income from investments and on other income, including premium receipts. At present, the tax is based only on income from investments.
