Earnings of Litton Industries Inc., in the quarter ended Oct. 31 totaled about $1,150,000, Charles B. Thornton, chairman and president, told stockholders yesterday. Their annual meeting was held in Beverly Hills, Calif.
Billy Flamio, 146 1/2 pounds, of the Bronx, easily outpointed Eddie Lynch, 149, West New York, N. J., in the main ten-round bout before 1,320 spectators in the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
IS there a feline fancier on your Christmas gift list? Georg Jensen, 667 Fifth Avenue (Fifty-third Street), has a suggestion that would make any cat lover purr.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Nov. 17 -- Increases in the minimum wage rates for industrial workers in the United States and Puerto Rico were urged today at the opening of a five-day meeting of the executive board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 17 -West Germany accepted under strict limitations today a Soviet proposal that work get started on the long-delayed peace treaty for Germany.

GENEVA, Nov. 17 -- The ninth and shortest meeting of the conference on nuclear tests ended today with the East and West as far apart as ever despite the Soviet Union's contention that its delegation had made a "concession."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -The United States protested to the Soviet Union today that Soviet Air Force planes attacked one United States plane and made provocative passes at another over international waters on Nov. 7.
Reruns of "I Love Lucy" are expected to move into the morning television hour now occupied by Arthur Godfrey, whose show will move to an earlier one period, effective Jan. 5.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Sam Rayburn, speaker of the House of Representatives, has urged the Administration to postpone the December bipartisan conference of Congressional leaders until just before Congress convenes Jan. 7.

What Senator Lyndon Johnson said yesterday, before a United Nations committee, about what he called "the essential unity of the American people," was even more important than the resolution with which he was dealing.
Alaska represents a wideopen consumer market for companies willing to promote their products in the area personally, according to an advertising agency man who surveyed the future state.
The New York Diabetes Association announced yesterday that 27,220 New Yorkers had taken voluntary tests for diabetes since Nov. 1.
ALBANY, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The big-game season opened in the Catskills, southern and western sections of the State today and an Amsterdam man was the first hunting fatality reported.
Michigan soon will join most of the rest of the nation in a recovery from the recession, Walker L. Cisler, president of the Detroit Edison Company, predicted yesterday.
PARIS, Nov. 17 -- Senator Henry M. Jackson urged here today that member nations of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization cooperate to send up a satellite for peaceful outerspace research by 1960.

SEVENTEEN years ago this month, Daniel Carrasso arrived here from Paris to set up a yoghurt plant in this country. He was not the first to introduce the cultured milk product here. It had been made on a small scale before, chiefly for those who came from the Balkans, where it is as much a dietary staple rice in China, or spaghetti in southern Italy.

Among the many pointed truths set down by Aline B. Saarinen in "The Proud Possessors," her lively volume describing outstanding American art collectors of the last seventy years, is the statement that the disappearance of the attic has changed the pattern of collecting in this country. "

One hundred fifty persons attended a sidewalk rally yesterday in front of 488 Madison Avenue between Fifty-first and Fifty-second Streets. The purpose was to persaude employes of fifty concerns in that building and one across the street, at 477 Madison Avenue, to give blood next Tuesday to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program.
Gov. G. Mennen Williams of Michigan will mix business, a family visit, a speech and politics in a visit here starting today.
The Rockefeller Foundation made grants amounting to $1,776,864 in the third quarter of 1958 for a variety of projects around the world.

TIMES SQUARE was temporarily roped off last night for the premiere of a new motion picture, "Mardi Gras," at the Paramount Theatre. Celebrities arrived in hansom cabs and bands of Mummers from Philadelphia marched up and down.

NEWARK, Nov. 17 -- The Passaic Valley Sewerage Commission was put on notice today by a committee of Mayors representing twenty-one municipalities that legislation would be introduced to abolish the commission and transfer its functions to the municipalities.
New York's major orchestras, Broadway shows and radio and television networks were charged with "a pattern of economic discrimination" against Negro musicians in a report yesterday.

Most of the local qualifying rounds for the eighteenth annual national All-Star tournament were completed last weekend and the list of non-qualifiers is as impressive, if not more so, than the list of those who made the grade.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 -The elevation of Archbishop John Francis O'Hara to the rank of Cardinal was greeted today with grateful prayers by joyful Roman Catholics in the ten-county Archdiocese of Philadelphia. His flock numbers 1,443,000.

The opinions of Vice Admiral Hyman G. Rickover will be presented in two books to be published this season. Next month Public Affairs Press of Washington will issue "What Rickover Thinks," a collection of the admiral's views on atomic energy, defense, communism, education, democracy and other subjects.
Dan Sachs, hero of Princeton's triumph over Dartmouth last year, and his understudy at tailback, John (Silky) Sullivan, will be ready for the decisive Ivy League game with the Indians on Saturday
The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development set a postwar speed record yesterday for raising money in the public market.
A junior committee has been aiding in plans for the Fiesta of Casita Maria, a cocktail party and tea dance that will take place in the Plaza on Friday.

TRENTON, Nov. 17 -- The nine major railroads operating in New Jersey informed Gov. Robert B. Meyner today that they would pay more than $18,000,000 in state taxes due Dec. 1 on their passenger facilities.
JUDGING from a number of recent exhibitions from Japan, the Japanese artist is not averse to group activity, or at least, group identification.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 17 -- Canada and Norway urged today that the extent of territorial waters and fishery rights be settled at an international conference to be called not later than next February. Iceland reluctantly consented to such an approach.

BAYONNE, N. J., Nov. 17 -An Internal Revenue Service agent was questioned today about the presence in his home of $14,000 in cash, together with stocks and bonds of undisclosed value and burglar tools.

Senator-elect Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey said last night that American foreign policy had "shown a dangerous tendency to let events take their course in relations with all parts of the world -- Asia, South America, Europe and particularly the Middle East."
The Interstate Commerce Commission has challenged a securities deal that management of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad made more than three years
A cocktail party in the State Suite of the Plaza on Thursday will mark the opening in metropolitan New York of Connecticut College's Fiftieth Anniversary Fund Drive.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The organizing committee of the international championship and Canada Cup golf matches tonight rejected a new system of pairings for the 72-hole competition starting Thursday.
KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Nov. 17 -- Lieut. Gen. Ibrahim Abboud, Commander in Chief of the armed forces, took control of the Government of the Sudan this morning.
Directors of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad voted an extra dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock yesterday. They also put the stock on a $1.50 dividend basis for 1959.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 17 -- Israel expressed willingness today to give compensation to Palestine Arab refugees without insisting, as she had until now, that such payment await a general ArabIsraeli peace settlement.

California Getranka (drink from California), is telling its sales story on the move to consumers in West Germany. Its message is being carried electrically on four sides of a street car in regular operation in Oberhausen.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 17 -Attempts by Congress or the Administration to end racial segregation in Federal-assisted housing could bring disaster to the program, Senator John J. Sparkman warned today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 17 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has bought movie rights to the play, "The Golden Fleecing," which is scheduled to arrive on Broadway early next year.
At the start of every football season (and before he issues uniforms), Coach Bill Ashley of Freeport High School gathers his players in the locker room and tells them about Bill Glassford.
The Department of Buildings condemned a Harlem tenement as "hazardous" yesterday and ordered fifteen families to vacate within ten days.

CAIRO, Nov. 17 (UPI) -- Following is an unofficial translation of the text of the communique issued by the Sudanese Army commander, Lieut. Gen. Ibrahim Abboud, on his seizure of power, as broadcast in Arabic by the Omdurman radio:
John D. Ames of Chicago has been nominated for re-election as president of the United States Golf Association with a slate that includes four new officers.

In cases of speech loss resulting from brain damage the patient's prospects for recovery are as closely tied to his personality as to the extent of his injury, a metting of specialists was told here yesterday.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 7 points up to 1 point off yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
Katharine Cornell's next stage assignment will be the role of Mrs. Patrick Campbell in a new comedy by Jerome Kilty called "Dear Liar."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -President Eisenhower conferred today with David K. E. Bruce, United States Ambassador to West Germany, on the Berlin situation
The Mayor, "instead of going to the political clubs, should go to the educational societies to get competent people" for the city's school boards, a New York educator said last night.

In early February, 1955 -- nearly four years ago -- Mayor Wagner ordered legislation drafted to outlaw the portable kerosene stove. He did so at the advice of Fire Commissioner Cavanagh a few days after such a stove caused a fire in a tenement that killed six members of a family.
OTTAWA, Nov. 17 -- Canada's two major railroads won a 17 per cent freight rate increase today.
The Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday that seven persons were killed in city traffic last week. This compares with sixteen killed in the same period in 1957, a decline of nine deaths.

Bus-borne pickets circled the General Electric Company headquarters in midtown Manhattan yesterday. Eight buses brought 400 unionists from Bloomfield, N. J., to protest company plans to move some work from that community to plants in other areas.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -Nelson A. Rockefeller is in for a surprise when he comes to Washington next Saturday for a meeting of President Eisenhower's Advisory Committee on Government Organization.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UPI) -- The United States abandoned today its promise to hurl a fully instrumented basketball-size earth satellite into orbit with a Vanguard rocket during the International Geophysical Year.

Bob Pettit of the St. Louis Hawks chalked up a National Basketball Association record by averaging 30 points a game for the first nine games this season. But George Yardley of Detroit remained the scoring leader throughout last Sunday because he had played more games.

GRIFFIN, Ga., Nov. 18 (UPI) -- Quimby Melton Jr., a Georgia editor and legislator who has a long record as a segregationist, said today the state should reassess its firm position on publicschool integration.

HAVANA, Nov. 18 -- Four policemen were killed and seven wounded in a machine-gun attack on a suburban Havana police station yesterday. Eleven civilians allegedly involved in the attack were killed in the pursuit and gun battles that followed, the police said.
The new Adolph S. Ochs School at West Fifty-third Street and Tenth Avenue, named in honor of the late publisher of The New York Times, was dedicated last night.

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- The most surprising aspect of the troubled Middle Eastern situation is that Moscow and Washington, for the moment, are backing the same horse in Iraq. That horse is Abdul Karim el-Kassem, the soldier who became Premier last July by coup d'etat.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 18 (UPI) -- Two staff members of the 1960 Winter Olympic Games resigned today after criticizing the way plans were being handled. However, the games' executive director, Robert L. King, indicated the charges were unfounded.
A member of the Eisenhower Cabinet warned last night that the United States would be unable to retain world leadership unless it gave equal rights to Negroes.
Iowa leads the nation's major college football powers in total offense for the second straight week.
The Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee announced yesterday that it would ask the next Legislature to order the drafting of a "clear and definite program" to end rent controls.
Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, president of City College, called yesterday for immediate financial assistance from the state for the city's municipal colleges.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 18 (UPI) -- United Airlines reported today that one of its airliners had to take evasive action to avoid a collision course with a military transport plane while letting down for a landing at San Francisco International Airport.
The City Council refused unanimously yesterday to give owners of multiple dwellings an additional year in which to convert from kerosene to central heating or gas or electric space heaters.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Miccosukee Seminole Indians had little luck today in trying to make an international issue out of their argument with Florida over land.
" THE MAGIC FLUTE" has been absent at the Metropolitan for only a season, but it seems longer than that. Is it because last night's performance was the first Mozart we have had this season?

YONKERS, Nov. 18 -- Darn Safe, Something Special and Model Heir, three outstanding trotters that have been campaigning on the Pacific Coast, are being flown to Yonkers Raceway to challenge the favored Trader Horn in the $50,000 Eastern Championship trot Friday night.
IT usually takes ages and ages for a cliche to reach a state of tired repugnance. But Leo Durocher once uttered a pungent sentence that became worn out from overuse in just a couple of months.

The American Opera Society made its contribution to the Handel bicentennial last night at Carnegie Hall. It consisted of a star-studded revival of the Allen Sven Oxenburg and Arnold Gamson concert version of "Giulio Cesare," which the society first presented two years ago at Town Hall.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 18 -- A decline in the number of patients in public mental hospitals for the third straight year was reported here today.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 18 -- John Foster Dulles warned the new independent nations tonight against the blandishments of international communism.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UPI) -- Legal experts from government, law schools and private practice offered House investigators a broad range of ideas today on how to protect Federal agencies from improper influence.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Agreement on a new two-year contract involving some 2,100 mechanics and related employes of Northwest Airlines was announced today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury indicted Arnoldo Goenaga Barron of New York today on charges of acting illegally as an agent of the revolutionary movement in Cuba.

Two insurgent directors of Loew's, Inc., who have opposed a management plan for separating the company's theatre from its motion-picture production operations yesterday withdrew their threat of a proxy fight.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 18--The West German Government announced today a number of drastic measures to overcome the country's continuing coal crisis. The measures were taken to reduce stockpiles of coal and coke at pitheads now standing at more than 13,000,000 tons and to prevent the curtailment of miners' work shifts.
RABAT, Morocco, Nov. 18 -King Mohamed V announced today Morocco's determination to obtain the "total and unconditional'' evacuation of United States bases as well as French and Spanish troops.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -Officials here believe the Berlin situation will get worse before it gets better.

CARACAS, Nov. 18 -- Venezuelan oil production reached a high for the year during October, according to figures released today. The average of 2,689,721 barrels a day also exceeded that of the 1957 month.

ATLANTA, Nov. 18 (UPI) -Attorneys for five men indicted for the bombing of an Atlanta Jewish temple sought an injunction today to bar top Atlanta police officials from "molesting, harassing and intimidating" the accused.
Gov. G. Mennen Williams of Michigan spoke here yesterday on national problems and was praised by Governor Harriman as "one of the fine candidates" for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1960.
Eighteen Soviet motion-picture personalities arrived in New York yesterday and quickly started to become acquainted with the city.

Battle lines already are being sharply drawn for another merry scrap between baseball's haves and have-nots. They'll be at it beginning Dec. 1 when both the majors and minors hold their annual winter meetings in Washington.

Dick McCann, general manager of the Washington Redskins, yesterday said his team "could have beaten the Cleveland Browns" last Sunday at Washington. The Redskins, with such possibilities, will play the New York Giants in a National Football League contest at Yankee Stadium Sunday.
Yes Virginia, a small agency can compete successfully with larger ones for a major account.
Issues of $28,000,000 of bonds of Los Angeles, Calif., school districts were sold in the public market yesterday to a banking syndicate headed by Bank of America National Trust and Association.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov. 18 -- Lacrosse at Hofstra College is regarded as an aid to football.

The Board of Estimate hearing on the proposed capital budget for 1959, descending as it did into a name-calling dispute between Controller Gerosa and Board of Education officials over school construction, was hardly an edifying example of democracy at work. Mr. Gerosa apparently has a poor opinion not only of the Department of Education but also of the City Planning Commission, which prepares the capital budget.

MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 18 -Coordination of all forms of transportation must replace "ruthless duplication" of facilities, E. George Siedle, Assistant Postmaster General for Transportation, declared here today.

Prices of cotton futures closed barely steady on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and final prices were off 2 to 22 points (10 cents to $1.10 a bale). Old crop months showed the greatest weakness.

Tuberculosis can be eliminated as a public-health problem, if the disease is handled intelligently by using new antibiotics and by pooling knowledge and experience, an international health expert said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UPI) -- The Air Force disclosed today that it was working on a missile that would fly on fuel scooped from the atmosphere. It would be propeled by atomic oxygen.

The directors of the Eastman Kodak Company, producer of photographic equipment, created a new executive committee yesterday and named Donald McMaster as its first chairman. William S. Vaughn was elected to succeed Mr. McMaster as vice president and general manager.
The city's taxpayers have paid about $100,000,000 more than necessary for new school construction since 1951, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa declared yesterday.

Consolidated net earnings of the Kaiser Industries Corporation for the first nine months this year amounted to $8,745,000, or 33 cents each on the common stock. The net is after giving effect to a non-recurring loss of $633,000.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -Fatin Rustu Zorlu, Turkish Foreign Minister, argued today the Turkish cause in the future of Cyprus before Secretary of State Dulles and Washington newsmen.
CHARLEVOIX, Mich., Nov. 18 -- A cargo ship with thirtyfive aboard apparently broke in half and sank in gale-swept northern Lake Michigan today after striking a reef.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Early United States recognition of the new Sudanese, Government was forecast today.

BERLIN, Nov. 18 -- The Soviet Embassy in East Berlin produced a klieg-lighted press conference today designed to portray West Germany and West Berlin as United States-backed espionage centers that threaten world peace.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -Delegates from twenty-four nations discussed today how to keep scientists of the world informed on developments in their fields.
LONDON, Nov. 18 -- Britain believes the Soviet Union will use increasing pressure to force her, the United States and France out of Berlin.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -Surgeon General Leroy T. Burney said today that a definite association between air pollution and diseases, notably cancer, had been established.
Research suggesting that vision is an important factor in language development for young children was reported here yesterday to the American Speech and Hearing Association.
RYE, N. Y., Nov. 18 -- The search by the United Aircraft Corporation for a new home for its Norden Division appeared to be near an end tonight.
MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Charles (Sonny) Liston of Philadelphia scored an eighth round technical knockout over Ernie Cab of Brooklyn tonight before 1,813 fans at Miami Beach Auditorium.

Archie Oldham, Columbia's basketball coach, reports that everyone on his squad is hustling for a starting job. It's been a day-to-day competitive fight in practice at the University Hall gymnasium and only a few men are set as starters.

Voting control of Investors Diversified Services, Inc., the nation's biggest investment company group, would be vested in the Alleghany Corporation, under a recommendation of Robert J. Fitzsimmons, special master of the Federal District Court and also a referee of the New York State Supreme Court.
Yesterday I reported some impressions of the formidable growth of Soviet industry as I saw it from Leningrad to Siberia.

It is a good idea to take out the cook every now and again, buying her a meal in a restaurant. This should not be done with rigid regularity, however, nor on a weekly basis. Thursday used to be her day off, but that was when there were professionals.

BARCELONA, Spain, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Fourteen Catalan Socialists, including five prominent lawyers, were reported to have been arrested today for working under cover against the Government of Generalissimo Francisco Franco.

THE man who swept into power in the coup in the Sudan Monday bears little resemblance to the typical leader of recent Middle Eastern revolutions. The leader of the uprising, Gen. Ibrahim Abboud, is an amiable family man who is fond of gardening.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 18 -Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of the Washington Area of the Methodist Church proposed today that Russians visit the United States by the "tens of thousands."

CARBO, Va., Nov. 18 -- Some 700 industrial executives were shown here today how coal, a railroad and electricity can be combined to carve an industrial empire out of a wilderness. The Appalachian Power Company, the Clinchfield Coal Company division of the Pittston Company and the Norfolk and Western Railway were hosts in a day-long tour of Southwest Virginia, where the three companies have earmarked $150,000,000 for the state's largest industrial development.
Thelma Matesky, composersoprano, offered a program of songs by herself and other composers at Town Hall last night.

COLOR and size are dominant in the Whitney Museum's annual exhibition of sculpture, paintings and drawings, which opens to the public today. The big show brings together one work each by 184 artists -- forty-one pieces of sculpture, 134 oils, watercolors and pastels, and nine drawings.

Cocoa futures fell the 1-centa-pound daily limit in all positions yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Volume was 930 lots (30,000 pounds to a lot), the seventh largest figure of the year. There were ninety-two unsatisfied offerings down at the maximum price at the close.
ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 18 -New Jersey was told today it must adopt a workable property assessment and tax equalization policy and help communities redevelop.
Moscow, Nov. 18 (UPI) -The Kelowna Packers of Canada battled to a 1-1 tie against the Soviet Wings, a Russian trade union team, in an exhibition ice hockey game today.
Contract discussions between the networks and a television of radio performers' union the continuing informally by this morning.

About 17,500 longshoremen roared their approval yesterday of their union's demand that the clock be turned back on waterfront automation. The men had streamed off the docks to take part in a mass meeting called by the New York District Council of the International Longshoremen's Association. cheered when the shipping industry was warned that it would have to "share the benefits" of automation with the workers who would be displaced.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission said today the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company had formally applied for listing of its common stock on the New York Stock Exchange.

FOR years now numerous novels have begun in the middle with, for instance, a terrified heroine staring down at a brand new corpse, or with a hero staring at an inadequately dressed lady. Obviously the events leading up to the crime or to the situation are part of the story and are yet to be told.
SAO PAULO, Nov. 18 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller arrived in Brazil today for a busy twoand-a-half-day visit to inspect his business and philanthropic interests here and meet with Brazilian officials.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -Following are excerpts from the address of John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, to the National Council of Churches Conference in Cleveland today, as released here by the State Department:

Frank Finney, Brown's quarterback, finished his last season of Ivy League Football competition leading the circuit in total offense, passing and scoring. Two of his team-mates, a fullback, Paul Choquette, and an end Bill Traub, also lead in their specialties

We of the free world owe it to ourselves, and to the future of freedom everywhere, to make it clear that if there is a failure of the Geneva talks on nuclear-test suspension and controls the responsibility for that failure will not be ours.

Optimism as to the business outlook leads eighteen to one, according to the latest survey by Dun Bradstreet. Of 1,548 business men polled, it found 72 per cent expected sales in the first quarter of next year to exceed those of the same period of this year.
Directors of the Duquesne Light Company voted yesterday to split the stock on a two-for-one basis and declared an increased dividend of 55 cents a share on the common stock.
BERLIN, Nov. 18 (Reuters) -- A United States Army convoy of two trucks and a jeep reached West Berlin from West Germany today without Soviet interference, an Army spokesman said.
Presiding Justice Bernard Botein of the Appellate Division appealed yesterday for support of the new Judicial Conference plan to reform the state's courts.

LAYING the foundations for architectural careers and aiding in the reconstruction of others is the unusual job of Muriel Feder. As the owner-operator of a placement service for architects, industrial and interior designers at 58 Park Avenue, Mrs. Feder finds her services on twenty-four-hour call.

Many dinner parties will be given before tomorrow night's performance of "La Plume de Ma Tante," at the Royale Theatre. The theatre fete will benefit the Kips Bay Boys Club, of which James Butler is president.

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Erie and the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroads began construction today that will enable them to use the same tracks for seventy-five miles between Binghamton and a point near Corning, N. Y.

Louisiana State, the only major undefeated and united college football team in the nation, was first again yesterday in The Associated Press' poll of sports writers and United Press International's rankings of coaches. In both instances the Tigers solidified leads they enjoyed last week.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Nov. 18 -The union whose members make America's dresses gave thanks today for the controversial chemise.
MILWAUKEE, Nov. 18 (UPI) -- Red Schoendienst, the star second baseman of the Milwaukee Braves, has been striken by tuberculosis and probably will not play next season, the club said tonight.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -The United States made two proposals today to stimulate private foreign investment and improve public development programs in Latin America.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UPI) -- An attorney for Judy Garland urged the Supreme Court today to reject the appeal of a New York columnist who was found guilty of contempt of court after she had refused to identify a news source.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -Texas Rangers helped the Senate rackets committee in attempting to show today how the Teamsters Union had used dynamite and related forms of persuasion in its organizing campaigns.

PARAMUS, N. J., Nov. 18 -Frank H. Simon, executive director of the Metropolitan Rapid Transit Commission, asserted today that the Port of New York Authority would not undertake the development of interstate rapid transit, regardless of the merits of the demands that it do so.
The State Commission Against Discrimination yesterday ordered an immediate investigation into charges of discrimination against Negro musicians by New York orchestras.
CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (UPI) The Chicago White Sox disclosed today the failure of a plan to wire the pitchers' mound for sound during the 1958 season.
The Academy of American Poets, now celebrating its twentyfifth anniversary, will be the beneficiary of a theatre party at the Dec. 17 evening performance of "J. B." at the ANTA Theatre.

The major part of the fifth floor of the new office building at 630 Third Avenue at Forty--first Street has been leased by Advertising Publications, Inc., publisher of Advertising Age, Industrial Marketing and Advertising Requirements. The lessee now is at 480 Lexington Avenue.

A maritime history of the Western World to about 600 A. D. is planned for January publication by Macmillan. It will be titled "The Ancient Mariners." The author is Lionel Casson, Associate Professor of Classics at New York University, who conducted a television course last summer called "Classic Civilization 43."
NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 18 -Racial segregationists won a test of voter sentiment in Norfolk today on Virginia's policy of "massive resistance" to public school integration.
PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 18 -- Picked as the co-favorites in the pre-season polls, Princeton and Dartmouth will meet here Saturday for the Ivy League football championship as they did a year ago.
With a great deal of pleasure I read your editorial of Nov. 14 concerning illegal parking.
The Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association yesterday accused Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy of spying on its activities.

THE tiny brownstone at 16 East Fifty-fifth Street is bulging with decorating news. Yesterday, Jack Lenor Larsen showed his new collection of drapery and casement fabrics and his fellow tenant, Karl Mann, introduced two groups of wall coverings.
MIAMI, Nov. 18 (AP) -Trainer Jim Fitzsimmons arrived from New York today and promptly claimed the horseof-the-year title for Bold Ruler.
LONDON, Nov. 18 -- The stock market appeared uncertain today, although on balance minor gains outnumbered losses among the equities.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 18 -Vice President Alejandro Gomez resigned today. The Argentine Congress will hold a special joint session tomorrow night to weigh his "irrevocable" decision.
THE home cook, especially at this season when apples are at their peak of flavor, wonders how she can duplicate the perfect baked apples served in fine restaurants.
" CHOICES of Morrell," an antique art gallery that specializes in fine objects, has just opened at a Washington Place, near Washington Square West.

The mobilization of 2,000,000 transport workers for a fourday boycott against "flags of convenience" began yesterday in a joint call issued by the leaders of the nation's rival unlicensed seamen's unions.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 18 (AP) -- A first-string fullback, Jim Rogers, turned up at practice with a sprained ankle today as the Rutgers football team ran through its first workout this week.

The south side of Central Park South between Columbus Circle and Seventh Avenue is posted for onehalf-hour metered parking 9 A. M. to 10 P. M. On Friday, Nov. 14, at 6:30 P. M., there were three of the eighteen parking meters in this block legally occupied by cars.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 18 -- A proposal to convene another international conference on sea law was formally placed before the United Nations today by eleven countries, including the United States and Britain.
The New York Legislature was urged yesterday to end the "freeze" on establishment of new bank holding companies and to encourage wider direct bank branching.
DETROIT, Nov. 18 -- Eight plants of the Bendix Aviation Corporation were struck today by the United Automobile Workers.
KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Nov. 18 -- A Supreme Council of Army officers and a Cabinet that includes five civilians were named today to govern the Sudan.

Miss Constance Ann Fagan, daughter of Mrs. Arthur Lawrence Fagan of 850 Park Avenue and the late Mr. Fagan, and Miss Marilyn Moore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Moore of New Canaan, Conn., are among the sixteen young women who will make their debuts at the Englewood Junior League Cotillion.
MOSCOW, Nov. 18 (UPI) -Former Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin has been removed from his economic post in Stavropol since his denunciation for "antiparty" activities, diplomatic sources reported today.

Your editorial "'No Parking' Means Nothing" is well-written and has a strong, well-directed punch. Living in Connecticut, driving into the city with my car is a frustrating experience because of the parking problem. There is never a place to park, yet I see thousands of cars parked illegally and overtime in the parking meter areas.

The electoral campaign in Venezuela began officially on Monday. It is going to be a threecornered race and, according to present signs, a close one. Rear Admiral Wolfgang Larrazabal, President of the Junta of Government, resigned his position over the week-end to run as one of the candidates, supported by the Republican Democratic Union. Romulo Betancourt, ex-President and leader of the Acci6n Democrftica party, and Rafael Caldera of the Catholic COPEI a,'e the other contestants.
The creation of an invisible force filed to ward off incoming missiles or other "concrete objects" is no longer in the realm of fantasy, it was reported here yesterday to the American Rocket Society.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov. 18 (AP) -- A pretty 20-year-old bank teller pulled a silent police alarm as she handed $4,000 to a robber today, and by the time he had reached the bank door two radio patrolmen seized him.

Spyros P. Skouras, president of the Twentieth Century-Fox Corporation, confirmed yesterday that his company was negotiating an arrangement with Magna Theatres to make films in the Todd-AO wide-screen process.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 18 -- Ahmad Shukairy of Saudi Arabia attacked today an Israeli conditional offer to compensate Palestinian Arab refugees. He called the offer an unscrupulous suggestion that belonged "to the jungle" and not in the United Nations.
Paperboard production last week continued at near record levels with the production of 313,809 tons, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday.

MONTREAL, Nov. 18 (UPI) -- Andy Bathgate of the New York Rangers and Eddie Litzenberger of the Chicago Black Hawks remain tied for first place in the National Hockey League scoring race with 20 points each.
LONDON, Nov. 18 -- A member's cry, "I spy strangers," cleared the galleries of the House of Commons tonight for a session so secret that even the stenographers were expelled.
A fire high in the mist-en-shrouded steel skeleton of the unfinished Time-Life Building provided an eerie spectacle last night for theatre crowds in the Rockefeller Center area.
More standardization could produce savings of an estimated $4,000,000,000 a year for the American economy, according to H. Thomas Hallowell Jr., president of the American Standards Association.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Dr. James E. Allen, New York State Commissioner of Education, was elected today chairman of the executive committee of the board of trustees of the Joint Council on Economic Education.

SYDNEY, Australia, Wednesday, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Perry Jones, the United States Davis Cup team captain, tonight turned down Jack Kramer's offer to quit as team coach because of a squabble with the Lawn Tennis Association of Australia.
New York's 717 air raid warning sirens will get their monthly test at 11 A. M. today.

The swift approach of the jet age in air transport threatens to confront United States-flag airlines with a serious dilemma. Not one regular "line" pilot has flown a jet for training and familiarization.

Stock prices fell sharply at the opening yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, but after about an hour of retreat new reserves of courage came to the fore. The resulting advance lasted until just before the close.
Herbert H. Lehman predicted yesterday that civil rights would prevail in the South and throughout the nation "much sooner than most people realize."
MIAMI, Nov. 18 (UPI) -There'll be no drive-in betting window at Tropical Park race track this year.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Nov. 18 -- The Communist Government of Hungary has imported American jukeboxes to soothe the restless Hungarian temperament.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18--President Eisenhower wrote a letter to the man who will be President of the United States fourteen years from now asking that he demonstrate "the gratitude of the nation" by appointing the infant son of an Air Force test pilot to the Air Force Academy.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -Regardless of the intercontinental ballistic missiles, the United States believes it must retain its world network of military bases.
A "crisis action program" to help solve the city's financial difficulties was urged on the Board of Estimate yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Air Force is in the running for a spot in the Sugar Bowl football game on New Year's Day, but there are a lot of "ifs" attached to a possible invitation for the unbeaten but once-tied Falcons.

The New York Rangers, who have been moving on high lately, will attempt to post their fifth straight triumph tonight when they meet the Toronto Maple Leafs in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden.
GENEVA, Nov. 18 -- The United States and Britain offered today to compromise with the Soviet Union on the central issue deadlocking their conference on a cessation of tests of nuclear weapons.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- A special committee of mutual life insurance companies received a cool reception today upon the presentation of their plan for the taxation of life insurance company income. They presented it to a House Ways and Means subcommittee.
An American jet airliner beat a British one into New York International Airport from London yesterday by eleven minutes. The American plane had taken off thirty-six minutes after the British plane.
CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The report of today's
CLEVELAND, NOV. 18 (AP) -- The majority stockholders of the Cleveland Indians today bought the stock of the former general manager, Hank Greenberg, and of the Baxter Brothers, Charles and Andrew.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 18 (Reuters) -- Iraq today ordered the ending of a concession to the Khaniqin Oil Company, a subsidiary of the British Petroleum Company, Ltd., formerly the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company, Ltd., and one of four companies operating in the country.

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle and his principal ministers were reported tonight to be bent upon healing the split in West Europe over a free trade area. The split resulted yesterday in the suspension of negotiations on the subject. The negotiations had been going on among seventeen nations for more than a year.
BELHAVEN, N. C., Nov. 18 -- Goose-hunting is like jail-breaking in one respect: It is best when the weather is worst. This was no day for jail-breaking.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Nov. 18 (AP) -- A silver-colored Air Force Navaho missile exploded in the sky over the Atlantic Ocean today sixty seconds after it had left its launching pad.
Teddy Atkinson likes to rate his mounts "up front." Master Teddy is of the opinion that once you get out ahead of the others, they have to catch you.

Headed for the stage are Katherine Morrill's "And So, Farewell" and Norman Vane's "The Purging of Simon Madden." Both have been taken under the wing of Norman Twain, the ambitious associate of Warner LeRoy.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., Nov. 18 -- Gas street lamps are disappearing gradually in this city over the protests of residents who have a nostalgic affection for them. Because of a demand for better illumination of the streets at night, officials have ordained that the gas lamps be replaced by modern electric fixtures.

Revenues of the Hertz Corporation should exceed $200,000,000 a year by 1963, Walter L. Jacobs, president, predicted yesterday. This would be more than double the current domestic annual rate of $90,000,000 for the car and truck rental organization.
CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP) -Still lacking any strong commercial influences, the grain futures market fell back into narrow price ranges again today on the Board of Trade.
John D. Rockefeller 3d, president of Lincoln Center for the Parforming Arts, said last night that the center could exert considerable national influence.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The Government announced today a short-term refinancing of $12,201,000,000 of maturing debt, and the issuance next month of a new regular series of twenty-six-week securities.
Forty-one of the leading retail advertisers in the city have agreed on a set of standards for presenting price reductions, comparisons and savings in advertising to the consumer.
Prospects for a vast expansion of world trade were envisioned yesterday at the forty-fifth National Foreign Trade Convention.
CAIRO, Nov. 18 (AP) -President Gamal Abdel Nasser trimmed today the powers of Akram Hourani, his last remaining Syrian Vice President.

The Madison Avenue Sports Car Driving and Chowder Society had its most distinguished gathering of the year at Sardi's yesterday. During the lull in racing and rallying before the international speed weeks at Nassau, Bahamas, starting Nov. 29, outstanding figures of the sports car world make New York the main crossroads in their globe trotting.
DETROIT, Nov. 18 (UPI) -Johnny Wilson scored three goals to lead the Detroit Red Wings to a 6-0 victory over the Boston Bruins tonight.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Nov. 18 -Despite the danger from bombardment, primary schools on Quemoy, closed since the spring semester ended in July, will be reopened this week. In fact, one school, in the central part of the island, opened yesterday.

I trust that your editorial in today's Times headed "'No Parking' Means Nothing" is but the opening one on this subject. However, I must disagree with your suggestion of removing the parking signs, even though it might make the police look better.

THERE'S magic in the carpet designs Bittan Valberg has created for Cabin Crafts. The collection of fourteen area rugs by the Swedish textile artist introduced yesterday at the American Scandinavian Foundation, 127 East Seventy-third Street, bridges the gap between the craftsman and industry.
The expansion of the National Hockey League to the West Coast is still "a long way off," Clarence Campbell, the president of the six-team circuit, said yesterday.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 18 -President Juscelino Kubitschek announced today that he was freezing the prices of staple foods and the rates of public services.
Mrs. Sigourney B. Romaine and her committee will make final arrangements today at the home of Mrs. German H. H. Emory, 770 Park Avenue, for the Grosvenor Debutante Ball.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 18 -- The State Education Department has begun mailing checks to public and private schools that are teaching Little Rock's displaced high school students.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 18 -- A public hearing conducted by the Metropolitan Regional Council here today demonstrated strong support for the organization but little backing for it to seek formal status as a new layer of government.
SOMETIMES the Whimsey Gods work amusing patterns into the looms of human history.
The Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday raised $80,000,000 on thirty-two year debentures at an interest cost of about 4.52 per cent.
A number of able backs will be on display at Palmer Stadium Saturday when Princeton and Dartmouth have their showdown for the Ivy League football title.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Nov. 18 -- The Soviet Union made a new approach today its proposals for international control of outer space. waived its demand that, as condition to agreement, United States bases be withdrawn from foreign territory.
Ogilvy, Benson Mather, Inc., is going the way of most growing agencies -- it is opening its first branch office. This will occur in February when the organization sets up shop in Hollywood.
A rich old lady whose friends had found her starving was sent to a hospital, where she found herself with people who gave her nourishing food.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 18 -- One of several curious features of the 1957.58 recession, the ability of consumers to continue paying :off their debts without wide default or even serious delinquency, was pointed up here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -The Supreme Court heard arguments today on the power of a Virginia legislative committee to investigate "racial activities" and of the House Committee on Un-American Activities to investigate communism in education.
MOSCOW, Nov. 18 -- The Soviet Union indicated today that in an attempt to force the Western powers out of Berlin it would renounce all agreements sanctioning the Big Four occupation of that city.

The Royal McBee Corporation, office equipment manufacturer, had a net loss of $100,000 in the three months ended on Oct. 31, the first quarter of the company's fiscal year. This was reported by Allan A. Ryan, chairman, to stockholders at their meeting yesterday.

Directors of the Pet Milk Company voted a two-for-one split of the common stock yesterday. The new shares will be distributed on Jan. 16 to holders of record of Jan. 2. The action will increase the number of shares outstanding from 472,500 to 945,000.
Former presidents of the New York Junior League will be the honor guests at this year's Debutante Ball to be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on Nov. 26.
A survey by the B'Nai B'rith Vocation Service has found that college scholarships available from all sources are not meeting half of the present need.
Shockingly filthy living conditions were exposed yesterday by District Attorney Edward S. Silver of Kings County in a brief tour of slum tenements in Brooklyn.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 18 -West Germany remains gravely concerned by the Soviet threat to West Berlin, sources close to the Government warned today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif.,Nov. 18 -- George Stevens is going, after all, to direct and produce "The Greatest Story Ever Told" for Twentieth Century-Fox. The drama about the life of Christ, to be taken from the book by the late Fulton Oursler, will be a co-production by the Stevens Company and the studio, which will provide all the financing.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -The value of goods licensed by the United States for export to Soviet bloc nations in Europe rose sharply in the third quarter of 1958, the Department of Commerce announced today.
TORONTO, Nov. 18 (Canadian Press) -- Eaton Hall Roma, a chestnut gelding owned by Lady Eaton of King, Ont., today won the Governor General's Cup at the Royal Winter Fair.
Harrison Tweed urged lawyers last night to take the lead in getting a court-reorganization plan through the 1959 Legislature.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Nov. 19 (Reuters) -- The new military regime announced tonight, it would honor Sudan's obligations to the United Nations and the Arab League. It also said it would honor accords concluded since the nation became independent in 1956.

Most comparisons between one business recession and another have a tendency to stress, almost exclusively, changes in the direction and magnitude of the principal domestic elements in the picture. Comparatively little attention has been paid to the fact that between mid-1957 and early 1958 American exports were falling at an annual rate of $4 billion, a decline that was offset only in a very small part by a contraction in our imports.
PARIS, Nov. 19 -- A United States missile expert suggested today that the West was in as strong a position in the missile field as the Communists.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UPI) -- The Navy announced today that it would soon begin hunting submarines from planes equipped with a top-secret "new concept" in underwater detection devices.

State Housing Commissioner Joseph P. McMurray announced a plan yesterday for doubling the amount of new private housing to benefit from the $100,000,000 state loan fund authorized in the recent election.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 19 -- John Diefenbaker, Prime Minister of Canada, said today he was confident that the military rulers of Pakistan wished to return to a parliamentary government at the earliest possible moment.
Three statues that have crouched over Broadway at Fulton Street for sixty-two years will be shipped to Indianapolis for use as a romantic ruin in Holliday Park.
Bonds of the Government of New Zealand will be offered for public subscription in the United States market for the first time today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Signals went up today for a drive in the new Congress to put more domestic and foreign cargo aboard American-flag Merchant Marine vessels.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- A system of tax rates that would vary automatically with economic ups and downs was suggested today by Dr. Arthur F. Burns.
HAVANA, Nov. 19 -- An unidentified plane has twice bombed the United States Government-owned Nicaro nickel plant on the north coast of Oriente Province, the American Embassy said today.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 19 -- The Rumanian Government extended a long-term credit of $11,000,000 to help finance the construction of a Government-owned refinery in Assam in northeastern India. It would carry interest at 2.5 per cent repayable in seven years.
WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 19 -- The plans for a Westchester sportsmen's center on fifty acres of the 4,180-acre Ward Pound Ridge Reservation were rejected today by the County Park Commission.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Nov. 19 -- Truck traffic on the Boston Post Road here has fallen 43 per cent since the opening of the parallel New England Thruway. But city officials urged more truckers today to switch from the free road to the toll thruway.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 19 -- Representatives of some Western nations questioned today the new Soviet proposals for international supervision of outer space and the prohibition of military experiments there.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UPI) -- The White House refused today to say what star designs are under consideration for the new American flag.

The Times recently reported (Oct. 30) that Superintendent Theobald has asked the State Education Department to study conditions in junior high schools now under attack from parents in Harlem. The Public Education Association believes this is a commendable step.

The previously announced move of certain departments in the Warner Brothers home offices will get under way tomorrow when about 100 executives and their staffs are transferred to the West Coast. They are mainly in the domestic and foreign sales and the accounting departments.
An arms cache reportedly for shipment to the outlawed Irish Republican Army was uncovered yesterday in an East Bronx house by a rookie patrolman.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 19 -- The United States repudiated today Soviet allegations of pro-American bias in the information services of the United Nations.
The short interest position on the New York Stock Exchange aggregated 4,890,991 shares on last Friday, Nov. 14. This was 149,931 shares fewer than 5,040,922 reported as of Oct. 15.

Those days and nights of wonderful nonsense now called the Roaring Twenties are back again as exhibit pieces pieces in the Museum of the City of New York. In a parlor, flappers and their boy friends put aside the ukuleles and fling up their heels in the Charleston.

Three of the half dozen injured Giants players were unable to work out with the team yesterday and probably won't play against the Redskins in their National Football League game at the Yankee Stadium next Sunday.
The American Stores Company, one of the nation's larger grocery chains, showed record sales and earnings for the six months ended Sept. 27.

American industry was urged yesterday to participate in efforts to set up international standards. Henry Kearns, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for International Affairs, gave that advice at the award luncheon of the American Standards Association at the Roosevelt Hotel, held in conjunction with the group's fortieth annual meeting.
PARIS, Nov. 19 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle will visit Chancellor Konrad Adenauer next Wednesday in Bad Duerkheim, in the Rhenish Palatinate. The meeting was announced in Paris and Bonn today.
BALBOA, C. Z., Nov. 19 -- Commercial tolls collected for Panama Canal transit last month topped all previous months in the waterway's history. The sum collected was $3,814,015.

The Soviets are obviously stepping up their campaign to cut free Berlin's lifelines. Whether they are doing this as a gambit in a drive for a new summit meeting on Germany on their own terms or for some other reason is immaterial. The indications, now taken seriously in all Western capitals, are that they are determined to force a new showdown on this issue.
The rapid rate of population growth is the "most urgent and the most critical problem confronting the world," Dr. Harrison Brown of the California Institute of Technology declared here yesterday.
The Norfolk Western Railway and the Virginian Railway are weighing the possibility of a merger. The two roads carry coal from the southern West Virginia fields to the port of Norfolk.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 19 -- The United States and the Soviet Union are expected to join in supporting a compromise Argentine resolution endorsing "peaceful and neighborly relations."
Three foundations have given a total of $120,000 to the Manhattan School of Music development fund.
The forty-fifth National Foreign Trade Convention ended here yesterday on a confident note.

One of the memorable sights you see if the Russians let you travel as far east as Sverdlovsk in the Urals is a white stone shaft in a birch and pine forest by the side of a winding road about thirty miles east of town.
SEATTLE, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Credit card business, which restaurant owners here say has turned from a boon to a burden, will carry a 5 per cent service charge in many Seattle eating houses after Jan. 1.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 19 -- The State of Virginia said today that the shutdown of schools to avoid racial integration was "temporary" and consequently did not violate the constitutional rights of pupils assigned to them.

An account of this country's accomplishments in overcoming racial injustice is given by Harriet Harmon Dexter in her new book "What's Right With Race Relations." It will be published by Harper next Wednesday. The book tells of the people and forces at work to ease the transition from "rigid, hostile attitudes and customs" to an "atmosphere of goodwill and mutual appreciation."
A Russian dance company from Moscow went on a droshky driver's holiday in New York yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- A prediction that world production of plastics would rise in the next ten years to 27,000,000,000 pounds, compared with 9,000,300,000 pounds this year, was made tonight by H. E. Humphreys Jr., chairman of the United States Rubber Company. He made the forecast in a speech to the international dinner of the eighth annual conference of the Society of the Plastics Industry in the Drake Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Desmond A. Barry, a Texas trucker, testified today that his competitors, not the Teamsters Union, had been guilty of a boycott against his company.

The Royal McBee Corporation, office equipment manufacturer, had a net loss of $100,000 in the three months ended on Oct. 31, the first quarter of the company's fiscal year. This was reported by Allan A. Ryan, chairman, to stockholders at their meeting yesterday.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Nov. 19 -- Abraham Lincoln was pictured here today by a military leader as a classical exponent of modern warfare.

Directors of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company elected J. Victor Herd and Kenneth A. Spencer as members of the board at a meeting here yesterday. The board also accepted the resignations of Elihu Root Jr. and Thomas I. Parkinson.
FOR two months every year Mrs. Robert M. Cushing "forgets" her friends, becomes a name-dropper and does some gracious begging from Park Avenue to the Garment District -- all for a worthy charity.
Darius Milhaud has written an original TV musical score for "The Twentieth Century" show about "Peron and Evita" on Sunday at 6:30 P. M.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- Selwyn Lloyd, the Foreign Secretary, said today Britain would not accept any plan for military disengagement in Europe that changed "the balance of military security to our disadvantage."

"Are you going to The Game?" You hear that question frequently this week, particularly in Penn Station and Grand Central during the commuting hours and on Madison Avenue and Wall Street between 10:30 A. M. and 3:30 P. M.
