BERLIN, Nov. 19 (AP) -- A responsible Soviet source said tonight that the Soviet Union intended to give Communist East Germany control over all the Western Allies' supply lines to Berlin -- air, rail and highway.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Four airlines have bought twenty turbo-prop airliners and five helicopters on guaranteed loans under a one-year-old Federal aid program.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 19 -- The I. G. Farben Corporation denied today that it was out to sabotage a possible settlement between the United State Government and a Swiss company in a $100,000,000 "enemy assets" controversy.
CHICAGO, Nov. 19 (UPI) -- Gale force winds still battered the Great Lakes area today after one of the most vicious early November weather onslaughts on record.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19 -- (UPI) -- Jim Brown, the Cleveland Browns' big fullback, will aim for another record in Sunday's game with the Philadelphia Eagles.
LONDON, Nov. 19 -- Mrs. Barbara Castle, chairman of the Labor party, gave Britain's correspondents in Parliament a lecture today on how they should report.
New York City sold a surplus hippopotamus yesterday for $2,450.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Yale football team held a long, full-scale scrimmage today. The Elis tried out a defensive alignment they hope will give them their fourth victory in a row over Harvard.
The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court yesterday upheld unanimously the Waterfront Commission's right to subpoena the books and records of a dock union local.
Precinct police patrols have been ordered to supplement the city's undermanned traffic force in a drive to cut illegal parking in midtown.
Automobile company researchers are probing consumers' subconscious minds as well as car hoods in attempts to find explanations for lagging sales.
Macy's flight-tested its storybook character balloons yesterday for its Thanksgiving Day parade. They flew, but as they never had over the years.
Yes Virginia, a small agency can compete successfully with larger ones for a major account.
The Board of Education decided yesterday to delay its answer to charges that about $100,000,000 had been spent unnecessarily on school construction in the last seven years.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 18 -- In claiming a twelve-mile limit for its territorial waters, Iraq announced today that if waters of neighboring countries were affected she would be prepared to solve any problems in accordance with international law or by mutual agreement.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Nov. 19 (UPI) -Paul M. Butler Democratic National Chairman said today that it might help the Democratic party to hold its 1960 convention in a segregated Southern state like Florida.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, Nov. 20 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller was told today by the Governor of Sao Paulo State that Brazilians would like to see him continue his political career so "his friends in Brazil may one day see him in the White House."

The roar of approval with which 17,000 longshoremen in Madison Square Garden greeted proposals to resist job reductions due to automation is an ominous reminder of a major crisis on the waterfront. It is one which faces management and labor almost everywhere in this age of dizzying acceleration in the nation's shift from human to machine power.

There is one Government career girl who has been growing pleasingly plump. Fanny May (the Federal National Mortgage Association) has an equity growth quite apart from the weight she tosses around in the home mortgage market with sales and purchases of Government-guaranteed liens.
DETROIT, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The sinking of the Bradley yesterday added another chapter to a long list of maritime disasters on the Great Lakes.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 19 -- The Government employe in the gray smock turned away from the pay window and fingered the crisp 100-peso bills. "They are brand new," he muttered. They were, just like bills totaling 800,000,000 pesos issued last week by the Central Bank.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 20 -- A sentence of death was pronounced tonight by a high military court on Ahmed Mukhtar Baban, a minister in ten former cabinets of the old regime.

FRANK GLAZER, who looks as young as ever but who made his debut in 1936, returned to Town Hall last night for a piano recital. His program was a serious one, and at all times it was intelligently played.

The Textile Workers Union called yesterday for a general wage increase for its 250,000 members. The union's executive council asserted that the rise was necessary to offset higher living costs and to compensate for increased productivity.
KEARNY, N. J., Nov. 19 -- A former boxer and loan shark was held in $50,000 bail today as a material witness in the slaying of a 26-year-old longshoreman who had turned safecracker.
A Coast Guardsman was accused yesterday of fatally stabbing the helper with whom he had manned a lonely lighthouse at the tip of Fort Wadsworth on Staten Island.
THE first contact Charles Joseph Bensley had with New York City schools was in 1915 when, as a child of 7, he entered first grade at old Public School 59, on Fifty-seventh Street and Second Avenue.

Lou Rossini, who took over as New York University's basketball coach after last season, spoke with candor yesterday about the Violets' chances of a successful campaign this winter. Seated in his office in Alumni Gymnasium on N. Y. U.'s Bronx campus, Rossini said, "The season all depends upon the bench, shooting power and the schedule."

The citizens of Norfolk, now Virginia's largest city, held an advisory referendum this week to decide, in effect, whether there should be an effort to reopen on an integrated basis their six white high and junior high schools that have been closed to preserve segregation under state law.

An offer by the Israeli Government to compensate Arab refugees for the properties they left behind in Israel was described yesterday by the American Jewish Congress as a "giant step" toward the solution of the Arab refugee problem.
MEN can count Alfred of New York as among their best friends. He has just designed a shirt that also serves as a jacket.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Nov. 19 -- Suffolk County's second "land grab" trial ended in a mistrial at an extraordinary term of the State Supreme Court here today at 2:30 A. M.

Issues of Orange County, Calif., Sanitation District bonds totaling $15,880,000 were sold in the public market yesterday to a syndicate headed by Security-First National Bank of Los Angeles and Blyth Co., Inc.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 19 -- (UPI) -- Spider Webb battered Joey Giardello's face tonight and gained a seventh-round technical knockout victory over the Long Island battler in a scheduled ten-rounder.
Pete Dawkins of Army is the nation's leading college football scorer.

The name of Mark Harris, scholar and writer whose talents are highly regarded in literary circles, may become equally well known on Broadway next season. Three of his novels are being dramatized for the stage, the author himself undertaking one of the adaptations.

Four thousand Department of Sanitation employes were an hour late for work yesterday morning. The action followed the rejection by their union on Tuesday of pension-plan revisions proposed by the city.

A civil service unit of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters announced yesterday that it would go to court to force the reinstatement of a municipal correction officer. The man had lost his job because of Sabbath observance.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 3 points off to 4 points up yesterday, holding in a 10-point range all day. (A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.)

Proxies are being sought by a committee of stockholders of North American Van Lines, Inc., in preparation for a contest at the company's annual meeting. Their aim is to make major changes in the management of the Fort Wayne, Ind., moving concern.
The Women's League for Christian Service of the West End Collegiate Church will hold its annual bazaar tomorrow in the church parlors at 245 West Seventy-seventh Street.
PARIS, Nov. 19 -- Professors and students of the Paris Faculty of Sciences began a thirty-six hour strike today to protest against the lack of teachers and room to work.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Rudy Bukich, little used by the Washington Redskins, was tentatively offered to other National Football League clubs and claimed today by the Chicago Bears.

AN examination of the freedom of the individual was offered last night in the second installment of "The Hidden Revolution" over the Columbia Broadcasting System's radio network. It was a stimulating affirmation of the right of dissent in an age of widespread orthodoxy.

The Bronx County Medical Society voted last night to withhold its decision on a proposal of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine at Yeshiva University to give tranquilizing pills to emotionally disturbed school children.

A real shipper was put over in the $28,600 Firenze Handicap at Jamaica yesterday when Roy Hunt's Hoosier Honey won the mile and a sixteenth event. In the idiom of the turf, a shipper is a horse that has been transported to a particular locale for a particular race.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 19 -- Princeton's ailing tailback, Dan Sachs, engaged in contact work today for the first time in three weeks as coach Dick Colman's forces prepared for Saturday's Ivy League championship game here with Dartmouth. He had been sidelined by a knee injury.

THE invention behind "The Mask," an exhibition of African and pre-Columbian ceremonial masks at the Aaron Furman Gallery, 46 East Eightieth Street, is unlimited. If the mask has become for us a monotonous Halloween item, for the societies represented in this show it was a cultural essential conceived in a thousand varied ways.
ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 19 -- The president of the World Zionist Organization appealed to the Soviet Union tonight to restore "basic communal, religious and political rights" to Russian Jews.
CHICAGO, Nov. 19 (AP) -Corn futures made another advance today on the Board of Trade, the third successive day of gains, as short interests began to feel the squeeze and joined other buyers.
Is baseball a sport or a business? The question can win you a good argument, but not much else, regardless of which side you care to defend.
HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 19 -- Greater emphasis on reclamation projects was urged today by speakers at the convention of the National Reclamation Association.

A certified public accountant was arrested yesterday by the Internal Revenue Service and charged with giving a $25,000 bribe to an Internal Revenue agent. The accountant was accused of trying to get a diamond concern's tax reduced from $2,500,000 to $75,000.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 19 (AP) -- When the Rev. Bennie Morris starts a new church in Arizona, he won't be leaving his flock behind. The congregation has voted to sell its church and move to Phoenix with the pastor.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 19 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold announced today that he had decided to liquidate the United Nations Observation Group in Lebanon.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 19 -- Stanley Kubrick resigned today as director of Marlon Brando's first independent movie effort, "One-Eyed Jacks."
WASHINGTON Nov. 19 -- The Defense Department set in motion today the reductions in the size of the armed forces that were postponed last July because of the Middle East crisis.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 19 (UPI) -- A huge cattle ranch owned by two United States companies in the state of Chihuahua and bordering on the United States will be expropriated by the Mexican Government, official sources said today.

Events tonight: The New York Philharmonic with the Westminster Choir in a Beethoven program, Herbert von Karajan, conductor, with soloists, Leontyne Price, Maureen Forrester, Leopold Simoneau and Norman Scott, 8:30; "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci," Metropolitan Opera, 8; "La Traviata," Amato Opera, 8:15.
The Board of Higher Education yesterday received a tentative budget totaling $36,185,097 for the operation in 1959-60 of six municipal colleges under its jurisdiction.

TORONTO, Ont., Nov. 19 -- Plans are afoot for a merger under one roof here of the Toronto Stock Exchange, the Montreal Stock Exchange and the Canadian Stock Exchange. The move -- one of the most important in Canadian financial affairs in years -- would make this city the only large stock-trading center in Canada and elevate it olose to the rank of New York among the financial capitals in North America.
MOSCOW, Nov. 19 -- Further study of a set of photographs of the moon has convinced Soviet scientists that they have evidence of a volcanic eruption on the moon.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 19 (UPI) -- Sam Snead and Ben Hogan, teaming in an effort to restore the United States International golf prestige, were watching each other as well as rivals from thirty-one nations tonight on the eve of the International Trophy and Canada Cup championships.

Secretary Dulles is reported to have stated that the increased number of Democrats in both houses of the new Congress will not affect foreign policy, that this is now a bipartisan affair. The Democrats, no matter what their gains in the recent election, will go along with the foreign policy of the Administration.
Midway in the 1957-58 season, Bail Watson, the New York Ranger coach, called Dean Prentice the most valuable player on this team.

The visitor entered and sat down, wheezing a little, and while the telephone was engaged in bringing important intelligence from the busy world outside he looked moodily about while he filled a stubby-stemmed briar with a bowl about the size of an average lemon.
CHICAGO, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock marketes here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Nov. 19 -- A bit of the atmosphere of the New York garment district is to be found in Budapest's biggest clothing factory.

The American Can Company announced yesterday a new pricing policy, which it said would result in lower can prices for most of its customers. William C. Stolk, president, estimated the saving to consumers at more than $9,000,000.
GENEVA, Nov. 19 -- Italy introduced today a detailed "survey of techniques which would be effective in the observation and inspection of instruments of surprise attack."

YONKERS, Nov. 19 (UPI) -- Sam J. Direct, owned and driven by Alan Myer of Laurel, Del., rallied from fourth place in the backstretch and won tonight's featured pace by a length and a half. Mister Knight was second before 18,923 fans at Yonkers Raceway.

John A. Latimer, a New York stock broker, said yesterday that he would consent to the revocation by the Securities and Exchange Commission of the broker-dealer registration of his concern, J. A. Latimer Co., Inc.
Gov. G. Mennen Williams of Michigan visited again yesterday with New Yorkers who might favor him in 1960, as a Democratic Presidential possibility.
The scholarship fund of the Professional Children's School will gain by the concert of the National Symphony Orchestra of Washington at Carnegie Hall on Nov. 28.

We congratulate the City Council on its unanimous rejection of a year's delay in the requirement that landlords of cold-water tenements begin to furnish central heat, or a safe alternative, as a companion measure to the outlawing of the portable kerosene stove which has taken many lives so tragically through the years.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UPI) -- Corporations making public reports paid $772,000,000 in cash dividends last month, the Department of Commerce said today.

Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa announced yesterday that he would go to Albany to ask the 1959 Legislature to reject the proposed constitutional amendment that would permit the city to borrow up to $500,000,000 outside its debt limit to finance new school construction.

A junior committee of post-debutantes and their husbands or fiances has been appointed to aid the senior committee in plans for the ninth annual Gotham Ball. The debutante fete will take place at the Plaza on Thanksgiving night.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 (UPI) -- Ron Murphy scored two goals tonight to lead the Chicago Black Hawks to a 3-2 triumph over the Boston Bruins. It was the Hawks' first triumph in four starts against the Bruins this season.
CHICAGO, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The trustees of the University of Illinois approved today the construction of the world's largest radiotelescope.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Nov. 19 -- Long Island cauliflower growers reached the peak of production here this week with promise of "good buys" of the fall specialty vegetable for Thanksgiving.
SANTA ANA, Calif., Nov. 19 -- The Santa Fe's San Diegan smashed into a crippled jet fighter today after the bat-wing plane had skidded to the tracks in a take-off mishap.
Dividends that fell below Wall Street hopes harried the market yesterday and stocks ended with small gains in the averages.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- A group of seventeen organizations advocating civil rights legislation published today a letter they had sent to Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas opposing his stand to date on the change in Senate Rule XXII and on civil rights legislation. Mr. Johnson is Senate Democratic leader.

The Sheraton Corporation of America announced yesterday it would expand its operations beyond North America for the first time. It disclosed plans to open a new 450-room hotel at San Juan, Puerto Rico.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Democratic party is flushed with victory, but it owes more than $700,000. The Republicans had all bills paid as of Nov. 1.

"Carnival in Havana," a dinner dance for the benefit of the Florence Pritchett Smith Scholarship for Commercial Design, will be held tomorrow night, Nov. 21, in the Jade Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The establishment of an Eastern interstate air pollution control region was proposed today before the National Conference on Air Pollution.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Nov. 19 -Plans were made here today for a school to train promising young Puerto Ricans for positions of leadership in public service, labor and industry.
"Unless you reconfirm six hours before flight time your ticket will be canceled,"

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 19 -- The foreign communities of Beirut were alarmed today by an announcement that the government was suspending all work permits for foreigners and planned to cut permits by more than 80 per cent.
The audience at the Lexington Avenue Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association got a big dose of old-fashioned virtuoso pianism last night.
AMSTERDAM, N. Y., Nov. 19 (AP) -Directors of Mohasco Industries, Inc., voted today to pay off more than a million dollars in arrearages in dividends on the preferred stock.
The P. Lorillard Company announced top executive changes yesterday, including the election of Lewis Gruber as chairman and chief executive officer and of Harold F. Temple as president.
The New York State Welfare Conference heard yesterday that progress was being made in helping families whose income was inadequate even in good times.
Ogilvy, Benson Mather, Inc., is going the way of most growing agencies -- it is opening its first branch office. This will occur in February when the organization sets up shop in Hollywood.
THE violin recital of John Creighton Murray last night in Carnegie Hall was a study in tonal contrasts.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program will collect blood today at the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, 1 Madison Avenue, and the New York Telephone Company, 151 East Ninety-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission called for new arguments today in the Indianapolis Channel 13 television case. Commissioner T.A.M. Craven, who broke a 3 -3 tie when the commission awarded the permit to Crosley Broadcasting Corporation, announced that he would not take part in the new proceeding.
Russian estimates of the amount of cosmic dust in space near the earth must be wrong, it was suggested here yesterday at the American Rocket Society's annual meeting at the Statler Hilton Hotel.
LONDON, Nov. 19 -- Britain is consulting the United States, France and the West German Government about the implications of Premier Khrushchev's recent statements on the future of Berlin.
Special to The New York Times.
Negotiations to avert a strike national radio and television networks continued early this morning without having reached a formula acceptable to both sides.
Sound comparable to a million automobile horns blaring at a listener twenty feet away is being used to test nose cones of the Titan and Minuteman intercontinental ballistics missiles.

A visit to Todmorden, Ont., a rural suburb of Toronto, served the dual purpose of getting better acquainted with the Canadian Kennel Club and seeing the Dominion's foremost kennel. Mrs. M. Eileen McEachren was the source of information on both. She is the president of the Canadian Kennel Club and owns the Tailteann Kerry Blue Kennels.
MOSCOW, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Canada's Kelowna Packers skated to a 2-2 tie tonight against a reinforced Moscow Dynamo team in a rough-and-tumble hockey game.
Soviet Ambassador Mikhail Menshikov came up against two American institutions yesterday, the "horse laugh" and golf.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Carleton Putnam, author and former airline executive, said today the Roman Catholic hierarchy of the United States was acting as an accessory to "crime against the South" in opposing segregation.
MARK CROSS has all but doffed the old school tie. As Christmas nears, a note of whimsy has entered this shop at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth, Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UPI) -- Capital Airlines and the Machinists Union agreed today on a new wage contract to end a thirty-five-day mechanics strike that had halted Capital flights to seventy-seven cities east of the Mississippi River.

Cocoa futures fluctuated sharply in heavy trading on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The near-by months opened the limit lower, recovered most of the losses, tumbled again and then steadied toward the close. Final prices were off 8 to 49 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 1,048 lots (30,000 pounds to a lot), the third largest volume of the year.

EMISSARIES from the newly formed Federal League were standing on the pier, impatiently waiting for the Lusitania to dock. A baseball expedition was just completing a triumphant world tour. On it John McGraw of the Giants was as majestic a figure as any of the kings and princes he'd met and Charley Comiskey of the White Sox was regarded as the noblest Roman of all.

SELDEN RODMAN spent his last week in Mexico fighting his way to the finals of a tennis tournament at the French Club. He spent his last day reloading his station wagon with what it had carried down -- and adding to that twice as much in the way of pictures and statues and books and Indian costumes and a bullfighter's suit and similar trophies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UPI) -- The former head of two Federal regulatory agencies said today the President's veto power over the Civil Aeronautics Board and the United States Tariff Commission puts a "premium on lobbying in its worst characteristics."
The Government charged yesterday that Mark Zborowski, a Russian-born anthropologist, had lied to a Federal grand jury for fear of being indicted for espionage.

Seven railroads in the Eastern part of the nation, faced by the proposed merger of the nation's two biggest railroads, may turn to a counter-merger as their best defense. If they should, they would form a rail system bigger than any now in the United States.
HONG KNOG, Nov. 18 -- The last year has been a harrowing period of reform for Shanghai's former private business men.

John Lord O'Brian, former United States Attorney for the Western District of New York, was named yesterday as special counsel for the New York Power Authority for a hearing in Washington Monday in the authority's dispute with the Tuscarora Indians.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Union and management forces in the fur industry united today in a three-year, $900,000 program to revive the American woman's flagging interest in buying furs.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19 (AP) -- A fancy new batch of grass may turn Municipal Stadium into a ball carrier's paradise for the Army-Navy football game on Nov. 29.
LONDON, Nov. 19 -- The stock market generally was in a more buoyant mood today. Government securities rallied and industrials were firmer, although the demand remained selective.

These menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are designed to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe. Add bread and beverage as desired, unless specified.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 19 -- David M. Walker, regional administrator of the Federal Home Finance Agency, predicted today that by 1980 the Atlantic Seaboard from Bangor, Me., to Miami, Fla., would constitute one vast "city."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UPI) -- The Air Transport Association said today that it welcomed a proposed Senate investigation to determine whether the airlines were jeopardizing their financial health with multibillion-dollar purchases of jet planes.
ALBANY, Nov. 19 -- Governor Harriman served notice today that he would take personal charge of shaping the Democratic legislative program in the state for 1959.

CHESTNUTS, like the whooping crane, seem to be involved in a disappearing act. An excellent little publication known as The Italian Scene notes that this sweet-flavored delicacy, once the poor man's diet, may some day be sold only in luxury shops for epicures.

BELHAVEN, N. C., Nov. 19 -- Wild geese by the thousands flew against the rules today, but a few skybusters outdid their selfish bad manners of Monday's wildfowl opening. The result was that what should have been a few minutes of superb shooting became hours of angry and frustrated waiting.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson predicted today that the Democratic Eighty-sixth Congress would open a new era of prudent progressivism in Washington.

CHARLEVOIX, Mich., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Two exhausted survivors of one of the Great Lakes' worst shipping disasters arrived at this Lake Michigan port tonight. They were aboard a Coast Guard cutter that brought in the bodies of eight of their fellow crew members.
TUNIS, Nov. 19 -- President Habib Bourguiba said tonight he intended to go ahead with limited purchases of arms from Czechslovakia and Yugoslavia.

The operating sublease on the forty-story Equitable Building at 120 Broadway has been purchased by Lawrence A. Wien, lawyer and realty investor, who bought and syndicated the ground lease -- the property in February, 1956.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UPI) -- The Defense Department said today that Brig. Gen. A. W. Betts, an Army guided missile officer, had personally deleted from a recent speech criticism of "misguided political leaders" who closed schools rather than integrate them.

Imports of crude oil and products reached a historic high of 1,989,700 barrels a day, in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The previous peak was 1,926,800 barrels a day in the week ended last Sept. 26. In the week ended Nov. 7, imports were 1,609,100 barrels.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- State Department officials believe that the Soviet Union will not turn East Berlin over to East German control in the next week or two.

It has now been announced officially that there will be no further Vanguard rocket launching this year. What this means is that failure has been conceded in the original project to send a 21 1/2-pound instrument-filled Vaniguard satellite into orbit before the current International Geophysical Year ends on Dec. 31.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 19 -Belgium, Luxembourg and the Netherlands proposed tonight to France, Italy and West Germany that the six common market nations extend provisionally to eleven other European nations the trade benefits they will initiate Jan. 1.
IRVINGTON - ON - HUDSON, Nov. 19 -- A new treatment center for youngsters suffering from rheumatic fever will be established in New York City under an agreement that is to be signed here tomorrow.
In your editorial of Nov. 13 you speak of the "more than nine hundred thousand Arab refugees" who are still homeless after the end of the war which made Israel an independent state.

TORONTO, Nov. 19 (Canadian Press) -- Hans Gunter Winkler of Germany, widely regarded as the year's finest horseman in international jumping competitions, rode two horses tonight to win the five-nation two-and-two event at the Royal Winter Fair.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 19 -- Research on schizophrenia indicates an imminent breakthrough in preventing and treating the mental disease, a psychiatrist said today.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Nov. 19 -- The body of Mrs. Joyce Mary Doran, wife of the British Air Attache in Israel, was found this morning in a field of reeds near the Jordan River. She had been shot in the stomach from close range.

MOROCCO, Nov. 19 -- The Moroccan Government will take emergency measures to end a wave of criminal attacks aimed at undermining the central authority, an official spokesman declared tonight. Persons charged with fomenting disorder will be tried by exceptional proceedings.
Nine auction record prices for post-impressionist artists were set last night at the Parke-Bernet Galleries.

LONDON, Thursday, Nov. 20 (UPI) -- The Soviet Communist party organ Pravda renewed its attacks today on former Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin and other members of the "anti-party group" with whom he was linked last week.

One teen-aged boy was killed and another was stabbed repeatedly in a rumble last night between rival street gangs in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn. The wounded teenager was in serious condition at Unity Hospital.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- If the Russell compromise on Senate Rule XXII, which would enable a smaller majority than at present to close debate on legislation, is adopted when that branch of Congress reassembles, the revived dispute over whether the Senate is a "continuing body" will stay unresolved.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 19 (UPI) -- Argentina's Congress, meeting in joint session, accepted tonight the resignation of Vice President Alejandro Gomez. The Government controls all Senate seats and 130 of the 187 seats in the Chamber of Deputies, and there had been little doubt that the resignation would be accepted.
Mayor Wagner accepted yesterday an invitation from a Kings County grand jury investigating relief chiseling to accompany it on a tour of the living quarters of welfare recipients and claimants.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 20 -- An oratorio by a Turkish composer will receive its first performance in the Western Hemisphere at a concert in the General Assembly Hall Tuesday at 8:30 P. M.
Employes of Montefiore Hospital, the Bronx, picketed the institution for two hours last night in what was described as a "final effort" to avoid a strike.

The Kimberly-Clark Corporation substantially increased sales in the quarter and six months ended Oct. 31 from the 1957 totals, its report said yesterday. Earnings for the quarter dipped slightly for the pulp and paper producer, while the half-year net rose.
ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 20 -- An American religious Zionist leader declared today that Israel's principal task in the next ten years must be a return "to her ancient religious mission."
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 20 (UPI) -- Mel Ott, former New York Giant manager and outfield star, underwent emergency surgery lasting almost eight hours tonight.
Five Brownsville youths were held without bail yesterday when they were arraigned in Brooklyn Felony Court on charges of homicide growing out of a gang war.

THE story is told of a Damon-Pythias friendship in modern dress. Such was Damon's devotion to his buddy that he plunged into a raging torrent to save Pythias from drowning; he set up his pal in business; he introduced his friend to the girl that Pythias married; he lavished presents and luxuries on him.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 20 -- The United States and the Soviet Union held private talks today on problems of outer space. As a result, a compromise agreement appeared in prospect on international control of the cosmic area and the prohibition of military experiments in it.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 20 (AP) -- A New York State official said today that "Southern bigotry will derive increasing comfort and support" from a statement he attributed to Albert M. Cole, administrator of the Federal Housing and Home Finance Agency.

TRENTON, Nov. 20 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner indicated today that New Jersey's corporation taxes probably would not be increased this coming fiscal year despite the search for revenue to balance the state budget.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 20 -- Richard Brooks is one Hollywood writer-director who knows where his next $1,000,000 is coming from. It will come from Columbia Pictures over a period of seven years, according to terms of a contract negotiated by Samuel J. Briskin, head of West Coast operations for the company, and Irving Lazar, representing Mr. Brooks.
The General Dynamics Corporation is considering merger acquisition of the Material Service Corporation of Chicago.

Secretary General Hammarskjold's decision to withdraw the United Nations Observation Group in Lebanon follows the action of the Lebanese Government in dropping the charge of intervention against the United Arab Republic. The charge was made, of course, by the Government of former President Camille Chamoun, and the action taken by Foreign Minister Hussein Oueini reflects the new policies of the Chehab Government.

The Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers International Union will give limited support to a four-day world-wide boycott of "flags of convenience" ships, Lloyd Haskins, general secretary of the union, said yesterday.
Governor Harriman and Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey called on the Federal Government yesterday to set minimum living standards and wages for the country's million migratory workers.

The Chicago, Ill., Board of Education announced yesterday plans for borrowing $25,000,000 on serial bonds on Dec. 10 to finance school construction. The bonds will come due on Dec. 1 from 1961 to 1978.
MIAMI, Nov. 20 (UPI) -- The Orange Bowl committee says Syracuse will be invited to the Orange Bowl game if the Orangemen beat West Virginia decisively Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- State Department officials said today that, regardless of what the Soviet Union did, the United States intended to maintain its right of access to West Berlin by road, rail and air routes.

Davy Jones' locker, where pressures, temperatures, currents and other environmental conditions have created Gargantuan forces that have confronted exploring men, soon may be science's newest frontier.

While it was obviously not his intention, Nelson Rockefeller, returning tomorrow from a holiday and business trip in Venezuela and Brazil, proved something. This is the simple fact that Latin Americans will always offer a warm welcome to North Americans who are known to be interested in their problems and friendly in their attitude.
MOSCOW, Nov. 20 (UPI) -- Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin, former Soviet Premier, is seriously ill and is undergoing medical treatment in Moscow, it was learned to day.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 20 (AP) The American Association of Blood Banks said today it would establish twelve "reference laboratories" to catalogue persons with rare blood types.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 20. -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold cautioned today against endorsing a series of controversial policy changes in the United Nations information services.
ALBANY, Nov. 20 -- High school students did not find the Regents examinations quite so tough last June as they did the year before.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The State Department said today that no decision had been reached on granting Communist Poland's request for talks on a third installment of United States aid.

ALBANY, Nov. 20 -- Democratic attempts to cloak some fifty Harriman Administration patronage job-holders in the protection of civil service status are being frustrated by a Democratic department head.

There was a strange spectacle at Manhattan College early last night. On hand in the Jaspers' gymnasium as the Kelly Greens scrimmaged against Iona were a dozen referees togged out in their official shirts.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The Federal Housing Administration, which insures mortgages on one of three new houses, has revised its standards.
PARENTS of a child whose schoolwork does not measure up to his ability were counseled recently to steer a middle course between too little interest and too much drive.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 20 -- The Soviet Ambassador to Bonn disclosed to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer today Moscow's plans for ending Berlin's status as a four-power city.
An emergency meeting of the Mayor's Interdepartmental Traffic Council lasted thirty minutes yesterday but took no action.

The Allied Stores Corporation and its subsidiaries, which operate a chain of department stores including Stern's and Gertz in this city, yesterday reported sales increases for the three, nine and twelve months ended on Oct. 31.
The Uniformed Sanitation-men's Association yesterday announced the signing of a mutual assistance pact with a tugboat men's union whose members haul garbage-laden scows to dumping areas.
Pessimistic views about the prevalence of racial and religious toleration in New York City were expressed yesterday by participants in a meeting at the Building for Brotherhood.
Henry Barrett, an Irish-born paper handler, was charged yesterday with establishing an arsenal in the Bronx for the Irish Republican Army.

TRENTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- New Jersey's Republican county chairmen tonight voted for Webster Todd of Oldwick as the party's state chairman. Mr. Todd won over Charles R. Erdman Jr. of Princeton by a vote of 12 to 5.
For the last three years Marc Bender, a 220-pound 6-footer, has been easing the aches, pains and strains of New York jockeys, chiefly by manipulating the bones in their toes.

Jo Mielziner, long recognized as one of America's outstanding scenic artists, has been named to collaborate with Eero Saarinen in the design of the Repertory Drama Theatre at the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.

Rails set brakes on the stock market yesterday, when freight carloadings failed to make an expected rise above 1957 levels. As in the last several days, there were exciting performances by individual stocks, but the list as a whole moved little.

HONG KONG, Nov. 20 -- The Central Committee of the Chinese Communist party has ordered all physicians in Communist China who have been trained along Western lines to study traditional Chinese medicine.

The ocean marine insurance market appears as a certain candidate for investigation by the Senate Antitrust and Monopoly subcommittee, according to Frank B. Zeller, marine manager for the Royal Globe Insurance Group.
Mark Zborowski was convicted yesterday of perjury in lying to a Federal grand jury about his association with Jack Soble, a confessed Soviet spy.
A REPUTATION for "never ducking the tough ones" has gained distinction for Judge Edward Weinfeld on a court of distinction -- the Federal bench for the Southern District of New York.
Marketing men are fast becoming the fair-haired boys of the nation's executive elite, according to a study by the Alexander Hamilton Institute.
ALBANY, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals refused today to hear an appeal by Raymond Brayer, who has been sentenced to jail for contempt of court in Buffalo's investigation of paving contracts.

David Evans, playwright, was awarded a $2,500 prize last night by the Writers Guild of America for his television play "The Gadfly," a story about the last years of Socrates. The play was given on the American Broadcasting Company network.

Columbia's quarterback problem is still unresolved. With the season's football finale against a favored Rutgers aggregation coming up in New Brunswick, N. J., tomorrow, the Lions were still seeking an adequate replacement for the injured Dick Donelli yesterday.
An issue of $16,800,000 in bonds of Panama is being offered for public subscription today by a syndicate headed by Lehman Brothers.

COMMACK, L. I., Nov. 20 -- State Commerce Commissioner Edward T. Dickinson predicted yesterday that Suffolk County's population would rise to 845,000 by 1975 and reach the two-million mark by the year 2000.
A call for greater open participation by business men in politics was issued yesterday by Joseph R. Shaw, president of Associated Industries of New York State, Inc.
The City's fashion industry presented the Metropolitan Museum of Art with a handsome gift last night.

When you read that 2,474,700 patients were cared for last year in the United Hospital Fund's eighty-one voluntary hospitals, you say "impressive," but your eye wanders over to the news column where it tells about a little girl who was in a traffic accident.

OTTAWA, Nov. 20 (Canadian Press) -- The United Steelworkers of America agreed today to let the Canadian Brotherhood of Transport and General Workers represent employes on the canal system of the St. Lawrence Seaway.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The Government has twenty-seven major antitrust cases pending or in various stages of litigation.

" KISS ME, KATE," the Cole Porter musical of 1948, with the book by Sam and Bella Spewack, was revived last night on the "Hallmark Hall of Fame" over Channel 4. Much as a viewer may wish for more musicals on the air, this one was quite heavy going.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:It is a pity that your Nov. 14 editorial "'No Parking' Means Nothing" could not have been printed in heavy black type. In it you touch on two things of greatest importance to New York traffic enforcement.
LATINA, Italy, Nov. 20 -- Work started today on building Italy's first nuclear power plant. It will be part of a proposed power grid for the underdeveloped south.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- President Eisenhower has agreed to delay until after the New Year his annual bipartisan conference of Congressional leaders.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- A pen-and-ink study of "Christ at the Column," no larger than a man's hand, by the fifteenth century Venetian master Giovanni Bellini, was sold here today for 15,000 guineas ($44,100).

SHIRLEY, L. I., Nov. 20 -- Food poisoning affected more than 100 students and teachers at the William Flody School here today. The victims were stricken four hours after eating a turkey luncheon in the school cafeteria.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 20 (UPI) -- Gov. J. Lindsay Almond Jr. said today that he had ordered the United States flag hauled down from the single flagpole atop the state Capitol and the flag of Virginia run up in its place.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (UPI) -- United Press International petitioned the Federal Communications Commission today to suspend for three months proposed rate increase by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and Western Union for leased teleprinter service.

The Western Union Telegraph Company hopes to provide on Jan. 1, 1959, direct dial telegraph service, known as Telex, between New York and Chicago. Since last May the system has linked New York and twenty-one Canadian cities.

MOSCOW, Nov. 20 (UPI) -- Boris Kuznetsov, fullback on the Soviet all-star soccer team, faces expulsion under the latest decision taken by Russian football authorities in a drive to clean up the sport.
PERSIMMONS, the first native American fruit to be described by de Soto and John Smith, are ripening now in wooded eastern areas. For the most part, they are free for the gathering.
Baseball apparently hasn't yet run out of surprises for the 1958 campaign. Jackie Jensen, slugging outfielder of the Boston Red Sox, yesterday was named the American League's most valuable player.

Aided by a sound ride by Bobby Ussery, Novita carried the colors of Juan J. D'Agostino to victory in the feature event at Jamaica yesterday. In registering the score in the mile-and-a-sixteenth race, Novita won by a nose from the persevering Paris Picnic, who is owned by Emil Dolce.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- A transcript of the working papers prepared for the seminar of World Brotherhood in Bern last August is now available. In the midst of East-West tensions made more acute by the mounting crisis over the four-power occupation of Berlin some of the material produced for the distinguished international group in the Swiss capital is worth a pause for earnest consideration.

Forty years ago The New York Times hailed with understanding the endeavors of Thomas G. Masaryk, Eduard Benes and Milan Rastislav Stefanik to establish Czechoslovak independence and since has favorably commented on the democratic policies of Czechoslovakia and especially of its Foreign Minister and later President Benes.

One of the striking features of the recent recession, as viewed by Arthur F. Burns, former chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, is the new evidence it furnished that a slump in production, under modern conditions, need not involve a slump in personal incomes or in consumption.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, criticized the new Federal Civil Rights Commission today as ineffective. He said his House Judiciary Commitee would investigate it and the enforcement of civil rights legislation generally.
Production and consumption of newsprint in October registered slight gains over the 1957 levels, according to trade association reports issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- A research center to determine what happens physically and phychologically when tranquilizing and energizing drugs are used in treating mental patients was opened officially here today.

United States consumption of new rubber this year is expected to fall 9 per cent below that of last year. The outlook, however, is for gain of nearly 19 per cent in 1959, executives of the industry were told yesterday.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Nov. 20 -- Some channels that were closed to Western literary influences have been reopened since the Hungarian rebellion of October, 1956.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 20 -- President Eisenhower returned to his favorite vacation spot here today. Ten minutes later he had begun a full round of golf at the Augusta National Club, where a temporary residence and office are always his for the asking.
LONDON, Nov. 20 -- Britain cut the bank rate today from 4 1/2 to 4 per cent.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 20 -- Increased Protestant sentiment for the recognition of Communist China became apparent today at a world order study conference here.
LONDON, Nov. 20 -- A colored patch on the moon was observed last night by Dr. H. Percy Wilkins, a fellow of the Royal Astronomical Society.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 20 -- The demotion of Akram Hourani from a key position in Syria was seen by some diplomatic sources here today as a blow by President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic against efforts to retain some measure of independence for Syria.
Cotton futures closed barely steady 12 points off to 3 points up yesterday in moderate volume. (A point equals 5 cents a bale).

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Australia took a one-stroke team lead over the United States and Ireland, and a little-known Colombian, Miguel Sala, outshot the world's masters today in the Canada Cup golf competition.
PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 20 -- After a day of whirlwind activity a touring delegation of nine Soviet Union educators left Princeton in a spirit of goodwill this evening.
FROM the rich prose of William Faulkner, television derived a superlative production last night on "Playhouse 90" over Channel 2.
SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 20 (UPI) --United States Davis Cup players reached the second round in men's singles at the New South Wales tennis championships today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The nation's total output of goods and services expanded by $10,000,000,000 in the July-September quarter, $1,000,000,000 less than the preliminary estimate, the Commerce Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Dr. Margaret Mead, anthropologist, said today that the school crisis in Little Rock, Ark., was being used by Northerners as "an excuse for inaction" in solving their own racial segregation problems.
Lester Lichter, young baritone from Chicago, chose an encyclopedic array of works and styles for his New York debut last night in Carnegie Recital Hall.

Stockholders of the American Screw Company rejected yesterday a bid by Textron, Inc., to buy its assets for $5,897,600, or about $50 a share. Textron could still gain control of the company by buying more than half its stock.
Federal officials, builders and investors in urban redevelopment called yesterday for stricter enforcement of codes and other measures to prevent the spread of slum conditions in this city.
Eight men involved in an alleged Wall Street securities fraud agreed yesterday to accept a Supreme Court injunction barring them from any further stock-trading in this state.
GENEVA, Nov. 20 -- The United States and Britain decided tonight to begin presenting to the Soviet Union their proposals for an adequately policed cessation of tests of nuclear weapons.

The business of American Telephone and Telegraph Company "is on the way up" after a decline in its rate of growth during the recession, Frederick R. Kappel, president of the company, said yesterday. He added that A. T. T. would spend more than $2,000,000,000 on construction next year, for the fourth year in a row.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 20 -- The Port of New York Authority, railroad officials and the Interstate Commerce Commission were criticized sharply today by North Jersey municipal officials who met here to discuss the commuter problem in the metropolitan area.
The Board of Education has ordered an investigation into the "Undercover Teacher" articles appearing in The New York World-Telegram and The Sun.

BELHAVEN, N. C., Nov. 20 -- Nine goose hunters and their two guides put on a display of mutual consideration on the north shore of Lake Mattamuskeet today. The result was that everybody left the blinds with both a limit of geese and a sense of satisfaction.

PRINCE SERGE PLATONOVICH OBOLENSKY-NELEDINSKY-MELETZKY, direct descendant of Rurik, the Viking warrior who became the first Grand Duke of Novgorod and Kiev in the ninth century, is a remarkable man. Anyone who doubts this statement has only to watch him do his Russian dagger dance in one of New York's fashionable hotels.
Thousands of Flushing residents were late getting to work in Manhattan yesterday morning because of switch trouble at the Main Street terminal of the IRT subway in Queens.
CHICAGO, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
GENEVA, Nov. 19 -- The conviction is growing among Western diplomats here that the Soviet Union has withdrawn from the search for disarmament through practical measures of control.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (UPI) -- Pope John XXIII has praised the "vitality" of the Roman Catholic Church in America in his first message to the bishops of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The Soviet Union has indicated it is ready to permit a Roman Catholic priest from the United States to go to Moscow to minister to the spiritual needs of Catholic personnel at the United States embassy.
The tenth annual National Stamp Show will open today at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory with more than $3,000,000 worth of postal rarities on display.

DETROIT, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers today traded Billy Martin, the infielder, and Al Cicotte, a pitcher, for the Cleveland Indians' famed relief hurlers, Don Mossi and Ray Narleski, and Ossie Alvarez, an infielder.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The National Air Pollution Congress unanimously recommended today the extension and strengthening of the National Air Pollution Act of 1955.
LONDON, Nov. 20 -- The half per cent cut in the bank rate to 4 per cent brought gains in Government securities on the stock market here today.

The city can expect action against illegal parking with Police Commissioner Kennedy convinced of the seriousness of the situation and determined to have "continuous and sustained enforcement" by every radio patrol car and foot patrolman on the beat. The department labors under a heavy handicap, however, in the shortage of police manpower that we have frequently pointed out on this page, with equally frequent appeals to the city administration to remedy it.
The Union Carbide Corporation has announced changes in its top management.

Canada, long harassed by an unfavorable balance of trade, published some encouraging figures yesterday. The Dominion Bureau of Statistics announced that exports in October rose to $455,300,000, almost $50,000,000 above the level in the 1957 month.

Officers and board members of the Junior League for the Pleasantville (N. Y.) Cottage School will be guests of honor today at a cocktail party to be given at the Harmonie Club by the Jewish Child Care Association of New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- President Eisenhower named Secretary of State, Dulles today to head a delegation -- including the original "Amos" of the "Amos 'n' Andy" comedy team -- to represent the United States at the inauguration of Mexico's new President, Adolfo Lopez Mateos.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The United States will soon be ready to start building an atomic plane, but the Soviet Union may fly one sooner.
A group designed to stimulate foreign investment by private interests in this country was formed at a meeting at the Plaza Hotel yesterday.

PARIS, Nov. 20 -- A small revolution is taking place in the French haute couture. Like most revolutions, it has been brewing quietly over the last few years. This year it reached an impressive point, with ten top Parisian couturiers designing ready-to-wear clothes.
BERLIN, Nov. 20 -- Mayor Willy Brandt said today that West Berlin and its 2,000,000 people were determined to undergo the rigors of another blockade rather than surrender to Communist rule.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Nov. 20 (UPI) -- Billy Howton, president of the National Football League Players Association, tonight accused Commissioner Bert Bell of "giving us a lot of conversation" and no results on player demands ranging from bubble gum contracts to extra pay for pre-season games.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The nation's stock of gold has just registered its first sizable increase since February, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. wound up a Senate inquiry into union boycotting today with an assertion that the Teamsters Union was thrusting a "super-law" on the United States Government.

The Society of Mayflower Descendants in the State of New York will hold its sixty-fourth annual meeting this evening at society headquarters, 122 East Fifty-eighth Street. The meeting, at which members will vote on new officers, will be followed by a puppet drama, "The Mayflower's Cabin Boy."
Archbishop Makarios believes he has the "encouragement" of the State Department to ask for complete independence for Cyprus through United Nations action.
Three new features will open at first-run theatres today.

ALBANY, N. Y., Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals refused today to hear an appeal by the State Liquor Authority, which had been ordered by a lower court to temper its disciplinary action against a delegate to the Apalachin, N. Y., gangland convention.

The Chemical Corn Exchange Bank has sold part of an East-Side corner to builders for improvement with an office building, in which the seller is leasing space for a branch. The bank is playing an additional role in the project by making a construction loan to the builders.

Mrs. Molla Bjurstedt Mallory, seven times winner of the national championship, was inducted formally into the Lawn Tennis Hall of Fame last night with the presentation of her certificate of enshrinement.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Alabama Baptists expressed concern today at the possibility of the election of a Roman Catholic as President of the United States.

Bright 10 and 12-year-old children can be given the mathematics now taught at university and postgraduate levels, a leading rocket scientist told the American Rocket Society's annual meeting here yesterday.
ROME, Nov. 20 -- Premier Amintore Fanfani's Government was defeated today in the Chamber of Deputies by a 266-to-247 vote on a tax question.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The Air Force announced today discontinuance of the nation-wide voluntary corps of citizens who have manned aircraft warning stations for the last nine years. It gave the termination date as Jan. 31.
Trade policies of the Administration were endorsed and some of those on foreign aid opposed in the "final declaration" of the forty-fifth National Foreign Trade Convention released yesterday.

Loans to business by the larger New York City banks dropped $30,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with a $90,000,000 drop in the like 1957 week.
LONDON, Nov. 20 -- Foreign writers and artists will be given freer entry to live and work in Britain, R. A. Butler, the Home Secretary, told the House of Commons today.
Following are excerpts from the text of Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld's opinion yesterday enjoining the proposed merger of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation and the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company:
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 20 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller ended his post-election South American vacation today and was to head north tomorrow to tackle the problems facing him as Governor-elect of New York.

GIVE Pete Ross of Macy's an empty room and he is likely to not only furnish it but also design every piece that goes into it. As the man who probably holds the world's record for the number of rooms decorated in a year (at least 200 is his present average), he considers designing furniture the "froth" of his job.
Two aggressive middleweights clash in the featured ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden tonight, with Rory Calhoun in the role of favorite over Ralph (Tiger) Jones.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 20 -- Mental illness, Adlai E. Stevenson was told in the Soviet Union, is all in the ideology.

NEW DELHI, Nov. 20 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru told Parliament today that the attitude of the new regime in Pakistan to India had not been friendly and in some instances had even been menacing.
BORDEAUX, France, Nov. 20 -- The principal electoral issue here in France's fourth city seems to be: Who is entitled to credit for killing the Fourth Republic last May?

I admit to a feeling of joy at seeing a group of people attempting to fight the tyranny of Montefiore Hospital. The low wages paid by Montefiore Hospital are not confined to untrained workers. They make little distinction between college graduates and the lowest untrained dishwasher where low pay is concerned.
Six patrolmen subdued a 20-year-old youth last night after he had allegedly beaten a 60-year-old man and a patrolman near Eighty-third Street and Columbus Avenue.

JEKYLL ISLAND, Ga., Nov. 20 (AP) -- A group of miners entombed in a Nova Scotia coal mine less than three weeks ago gratefully breathed the warm sea air at this one-time playground of millionaires today.

" Beyond the Great Slave Lake," a book of personal experiences by Tom Lodge, grandson of Sir Oliver Lodge, the English physicist, will be published Jan. 22 by Dutton. He tells of his hitch-hiking trek, with only a small sum of money, across Canada from Montreal to Alberta.
A supper dance On Dec. 5, in the Gold Suite of the Savoy-Hilton will benefit Girls Town, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 643,795 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board ruled today that it was illegal for Trans World Airlines to provide special "sleeper seats" for its transcontinental passengers without an additional charge.
KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Nov. 20 -- Life in Khartoum returned to normal today with the withdrawal of military forces from nearly all Government offices.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Certain kinds of Haitian "voodoo dolls" can really cause the recipient harm, the Public Health Service said today.

Directors of Charles Pfizer Co., Inc., yesterday increased the quarterly dividend to 45 cents on the common stock, voted an extra of 60 cents and also recommended a 2 1/2 for one split of the common stock.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 20 -- Censorship was established tonight over the broadcasting of political news. The broadcasting of comment was barred outright.

The New York City government may be subject to criticism on other grounds, but you have to admit that when there is a Park Department surplus hippopotamus to sell it drives a hard bargain. In the first place it was no small feat to get Bertie safely born in the Central Park Zoo and reared to the age of 2 years and a weight of 1,200 pounds.

The Plaza Hotel at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street has been purchased by Lawrence A. Wien, lawyer and realty investor, for $21,000,000. It is said to be the highest price ever paid in a single hotel transaction in New York.
THE Caribbean Islands, with good reason, are increasingly popular as subject-matter for artists. Two current exhibitions are concerned with their exoticism of life and landscape.

Jack Stroud, the Football Giants' top lineman, yesterday was named to start at right tackle against the Washington Redskins at Yankee Stadium on Sunday. Except for a brief appearance against Baltimore two weeks ago, Stroud has been sidelined with a knee injury during the last four games.

There are no accurate statistical studies to substantiate this, but one would be safe in saying that spring, of all the seasons, gets preferential treatment from the poets. Amateurs and skilled professionals are alike entranced by the wonder of becoming, the miracle of renaissance, which spring works each year.

Member bank reserves tightened appreciably in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Excess reserves were down $155,000,000, on average, to $467,000,000 from a revised figure of $622,000,000 the week before.

While pondering the future of the untenanted York Playhouse, Warner LeRoy, operator of that Off-Broadway house, has found time to acquire a script destined for Broadway. It is a Madrid success of 1950, "a wild farce" temporarily labeled "The Case of the Slightly Assassinated Wife."

THANKS to the Actors Studio, Sean O'Casey's "The Shadow of a Gunman" has fallen heir to a masterly performance, which was put on at the Bijou last evening. The play is all alive; every part is brilliantly acted, included "The Shadow of a
CINCINNATI, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Rev. Maurice F. McCrackin, who will not pay income taxes and will go to court only when he is carried, was held to be mentally competent and released from jail today.
SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Mervyn Rose, Australia's suspended Davis Cup doubles star turned professional tonight. He will join Jack Kramer's touring tennis troupe.
A net reduction of $18,475,610 in the City Planning Commission's proposed 1959 capital budget of $606,880,006 was recommended by Budget Director Abraham D. Beame yesterday.
CHICAGO, Nov. 20 (AP) -- in the first general setback of the week, grain futures prices turned downward today in all but one contract on the Board of Trade.
PARIS, Nov. 20 -- Paul-Henri Spaak, Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, made a vigorous defense today of the scope of political consultation among the Atlantic allies.

NOTHING could be nicer to receive through the mail than the exquisite Belgian chocolates prepared and packed in Brussels for Marie Louise. Rich, dark chocolate coatings, smooth and delicious chocolate butter-cream fillings and amusing shapes distinguish these confections that are, it should be added, rather expensive.
CHICAGO, Nov. 20 -- A New York doctor said today that many facial cuts suffered by boxers could be traced to injuries in the kidney area.

YONKERS, Nov. 20 -- Trader Horn, the 4-5 overnight favorite, will be driven by the nation's leading driver, Billy Haughton, when he goes to the post in the $50,000 Eastern Trotting Championship at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Nov. 20 -- The advance party of a Burmese Army mission arrived in Israel this week.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 20 -- Gov. J. Lindsay Almond Jr. conceded today that Virginia might, have to yield to the "overriding power" of the Federal Government on school integration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The chairman of the Safety Committee of the Railway Labor Executive Association said today that the president of the Association of American Railroads "has clearly misrepresented the true situation in regard to accident statistics."
BALDWIN, L. I., Nov. 20 -- A community program is being tried here to aid teen-agers who have left school for lack of interest or an inability to keep up with their studies.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The dispute between the Kohler Company and the United Auto Workers was reopened today for further hearings before a trial examiner of the National Labor Relations Board.

Jobless New Yorkers have drawn more than a half-billion dollars in unemployment insurance benefits since the beginning of this year. Dr. Isador Lubin, State Industrial Commissioner, reported yesterday that the total was the largest ever paid in a single year in this or any other state.
Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, president of City College, told a group of law-enforcement officers last night that they should protect civil liberties in their work.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 20 -- Strong criticism of the Federal Government's anti-recession efforts in the home building field was voiced here today by the nation's savings and loan associations.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Ben Kerner, an owner who demands that his teams win and look smart doing it, dismissed Andy Phillip today as coach of the St. Louis Hawks, the world champions of professional basketball.

Finishing last has compensations, if one is fast enough on his feet in other ways to capitalize on it. An Amherst sophomore, who as a runner apparently saved most of his breath for oratory, delivered a speech the other day that broke the tape.

Cocoa futures fluctuated over a wide range in continued heavy trading yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The market opened strong with the March position up the 1-cent-a-pound daily limit. Later, it fell sharply, but recovered from the lows toward the close.
Contract discussions by the television and radio networks and a performers' union were in recess yesterday by mutual agreement.
MORRISTOWN, N. J., Nov. 20 -- Four youths, three of them high school students, were killed when their car rammed a tree here late last night.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 20 -- A nation-wide strike involving more than 6,500 mechanics has been called against Trans World Airlines for tomorrow morning. T. W. A. operations at airports at thirty points in the United States will be affected.

LONDON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The third-ranking official in the British Foreign Office, Ian Douglas Harvey, an Under Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, was accused in Magistrates Court today of having committed a homosexual act with a 19-year-old private in the Coldstream Guards.
Soviet education became an object of respectful curiosity for many Americans when the first sputnik jolted us out of our national complacency.

The State Commission of Investigation will make a full inquiry into charges that $100,000,000 has been lost by waste and extravagance in public school construction in New York City in the last seven years.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 20 -- Three ministers in the Venezuelan Cabinet resigned today, two of them to take part in the current Presidential campaign. The three are Dr. Numa Quevedo, Minister of the Interior, Dr. Andres Sucre, Minister of Public Works, and Dr. Carlos Perez de la Cova, Minister of Mines.

FOR a woman to have an influence on a custom men's tailoring house is the equivalent of finding a woman as captain of a ship, or a woman who is a great chef or a polo player. It is not impossible just unlikely.
An Iowa-born mezzo-soprano named Mary McMurray made her debut last night in Town Hall, accompanied at the piano by John Wustman.

VICTORIA, Nov. 20 (Canadian Press) -- Distribution of shares in the Peace River Power Development Company, Ltd., which has taken over the Rocky Mountain trench power project from Wenner-Gren interests, was made known yesterday in documents filed with the Superintendent of Companies.

The Suffolk Bomarc Base, ninety miles east of New York City, will be equipped with anti-aircraft missiles carrying nuclear warheads. The missiles, which have a range up to 250 miles, will be launchable from the site near Riverhead, L. I., perhaps in late 1959 or early 1960.
Commodore Thomas Simmons has left the new Moore-McCormack liner Brasil after two voyages, to take command of her sister ship, the Argentina, which is nearing completion.

THE Mergenthaler Linotype Company has sold the block-square manufacturing plant it started in Ryerson Street in Brooklyn, across the way from the Navy Yard, almost seventy years ago. It is setting up new plants in Wellsboro in Pennsylvania and in Plainview in Nassau County on Long Island.
BERLIN, Nov. 19 -- Herman Just is 80 years old and Brigit Lorenz is only seven weeks. They have much in common despite the huge difference in their ages.

Bernard Manischewitz, president of B. Manischewitz Company, Newark, N. J. producer of kosher foods, denied yesterday that the company had any "hidden asset" income or that an outside stockholder has a substantial position in its shares.
Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld yesterday prohibited a merger in which the Bethlehem Steel Corporation sought to absorb the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 3 per cent above the level of a year ago.
Events today: Bizet's "Carmen," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P. M.; The New York Philharmonic, Westminster Choir, Herbert von Karajan conducting, Carnegie Hall, 2:30.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (UPI) -- Senator Albert Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, said today that the new Democratic Congress must demonstrate that it stood "as one with the President" on defense of the free world.
Five children died of smoke poisoning yesterday in a fire in an apartment in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 20 -- Povl Bang-Jensen appealed to the United Nations Administrative Tribunal today to give him access to the documents used in the proceedings that led to his dismissal as a United Nations senior political officer.

IT is rare to find a young artist today using the woodcut as a primary means of expression. But young Maria Bonomi, a Brazilian artist working in New York, has concentrated thoroughly on the problem of the black-and-white woodcut and has come up with an impressive show at the Roland de Aenlle Gallery, 59 West Fifty-third Street.

NORFOLK, Nov. 20 -- The Army began a new experiment today in the overseas movement of military dependents' household goods. It involves commercial vans and the Navy's new "roll-on, roll-off" ship Comet.

TORONTO, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Hans Winkler of Germany, with a dazzling show of riding coordination aboard his horse, Halla, won his second straight international individual jumping competition at the Royal Winter Fair tonight.

Dwight Macdonald, author and critic, will introduce a new twelve-week series of films from the Nineteen Twenties at 2:45 o'clock today at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street. The afternoon's featured film is "Blood and Sand" (1922) starring Rudolph Valentino and directed by Fred Niblo.
The Upjohn Company, Kalamazoo, Mich., producer of drugs and medicines, is planning to offer its stock to the public for the first time in its seventy-two-year history.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- A group of more than fifty private utility companies offered today to build an advanced type of atomic power plant as an alternative to construction by the Government. The proposal was submitted to the Atomic Energy Commission with a prediction that the plant would represent "a significant and substantial step toward achievement" of the goal of economic nuclear power.

Bardstown, the Calumet Farm's 6-year-old that has won $475,582, is the top weight under 126 pounds for today's $58,100 Idlewild Handicap at Jamaica. He will meet eight rivals in the mile-nd-one-eighth event.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UPI) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce told the nation's business men today that it would be a "serious mistake" for them to assume that the heavy Democratic new Congress would ignore their problems.
LONDON, Nov. 21--A Labor Party member called in the House of Commons today for an independent inquiry into advertising.
MIAMI, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Don McDonald, a quarterback, guided Houston to a 21 -- 0 lead in about fifteen minutes tonight and the Cougars broke a four-game losing streak with a 37-26 victory over Miami.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- A group of western railroads asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to increase coach fares by 5 per cent.
Queens Borough President James J. Crisona charged yesterday that the tax exemption slated for two Rockaway slum-clearance projects represented a "$21,000,000 giveaway" of city funds.
ALBANY, Nov. 21 (AP) -- An attorney suggested revision today of the New Yorw law that requires life imprisonment for persons convicted of a fourth major crime.
ALBANY, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Twenty-one New York City policemen who were dismissed in the wake of the Harry Gross bookmaking scandal asked the Court of Appeals today to order their reinstatement.

Edward L. Norton, a Birmingham, Ala., financier and a director of Nehi Corporation, early this week bought 100,000 shares of Nehi common stock from the Picket Hatcher Educational Fund, Inc. according to W. H. Glenn. president of the fund and of Nehi.

A theatre party at "The Cold Wind and the Warm" on Dec. 26 will benefit the League School. The S. N. Behrman play starring Eli Wallach and Maureen Stapleton is scheduled for a Dec. 8 opening at the Morosco Theatre.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- Government securities set the pace in the stock market today and rose as much as ten shilling ($1.40) in a large turnover. They were reported as still under the influence of the reduction in the bank rate.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Close cooperation among all media in journalism was urged today by a speaker at the forty-ninth national convention of Sigma Delta Chi, professional journalism fraternity.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Paced by the first-place finish of Earl Jefferson, La Salle College cracked the eleven-year domination of St. Joseph's College to win the Middle Atlantic Conference cross-country championship by a point today.

The Concert Artists of the Pittsburgh New Friends of Music is an unwieldy title for a simple idea: young American artists are presented in chamber music recitals in Pittsburgh and on tour. Four of them were heard for the first time in New York late yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Nov. 21 (Reuters) -- Sudan's Interior Minister, Maj. Gen. Ahmed Abdel Waheb, said today the new regime would reconsider all of the Sudan's agreements with other nations and reject those unfavorable to her.
An Air Force expert yesterday blamed inadequate testing for the failure of certain United States satellites and moon rockets.
Dr. John C. Adams, president of Hofstra College, said yesterday he hoped to open an experimental branch unit next fall that will merge freshman and sophomore years for 120 students.

WINDSOR, Ont., Nov. 21 (AP)--Donald Ritchie, 38-year-old Windsor hoodlum who once said he had the solution to the 1948 shooting and wounding of Walter P. Reuther, was convicted of perjury today in an aftermath of the unsolved crime.
ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 21 -The Turkish Press Minister rebuked today a recent foreign critic of the country's press laws on the ground that he was trying to interfere with Turkey's domestic affairs.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Nov. 21 -- J. Robert Cooper was elected president of the American Trucking Association here today at the closing session of the federation's twenty-fifth anniversary meeting.

Your editorial of Nov. 14 on "The Challenge to Argentina" reflects, in my opinion, correct information, common sense and goodwill. It attributes the present state of political instability in that country mainly to the permanence of Peronism as a mass movement, to Frondizi's failure to channel it into constructive directions and to the discordance between electoral promises and the need for a realistic policy.
CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Oversize week-ends were in the news yesterday. The nation's major stock exchanges, no doubt encouraged by booming business, declared Friday, Dec. 26, the day after Christmas, a holiday, giving their employes a four-day week-end.
Angler Biddle Duke, president of the International Rescue Committee, said yesterday that an early solution of the Western European refugee problem was in sight.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 21 The State League of Municipalities called on the Legislature today to adopt a new broad-based tax, restore the expired state rent control and reappraise railroad property so that taxes on the carriers could be inceased.
ATLANTA, Nov. 21 -- Widespread popular support has developed here for the proposed repeal of state laws that would force public schools to close in the event of a Federal Court desegregation order.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy spent eighty minutes yesterday before a Kings County grand jury that has been investigating borough rackets since last March.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 21 -- President Eisenhower made it clear today that the United States would make no retreat "from its firm intentions in West Berlin."

"Great Sea Rescues," by Edward Rowe Snow, will be published by Dodd, Mead on Monday. It gives the accounts of nineteen "hairbreadth" escapes from the angry waters. Some of the stories are told in the words of eyewitnesses, including the author's account of his own experience in Boston Harbor in the early part of this century.
