IN the last act of "The Man Who Never Died," put on at the Jan Hus last evening, the author describes a dramatic situation.

Your Budapest correspondent, M. S. Handler, in his report of Sunday's "elections" in Hungary writes that "Hungarian officials are intensely embittered by the West's moral and political embargo of their Communist regime." There is reason to suspect that the Hungarian Communists are shedding crocodile tears.

Sale and leaseback negotiations between the city of Venice, Ill., and the Illinois Terminal Railroad Company over the use of the McKinley Bridge were completed yesterday with the transfer of the purchase money at Marine Midland Trust Company here.
THE high point of Bob Hope's show on Channel 4 last night came, as it so often does, at the very outset.
Democratic members of the State Legislature plan to go along with Governor Harriman's expressed desire to play a major role in shaping the party's program for the session starting Jan. 7.
ALTHOUGH many different edible nuts are available in our markets, three varieties represent half the nuts eaten in American homes. They are English walnuts, pecans and almonds.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that he would go with the Kings County welfare grand jury Monday on a two-hour tour of slum-dwellings occupied by relief families.
The Carnegie Endowment for International Peace made public yesterday a report concluding that "the large majority of Americans" approved the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Average wholesale primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent to 119.1 per cent of their 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
LONDON, Nov. 21 (Reuters) -- Representatives of Britain's dock unions decided today to support an international boycott of flags-of-convenience shipping set for Dec. 1-4.
Brooklyn and Buffalo savings banks have decided against seeking an increase Jan. 1 in the interest rates they pay on deposits lest such a move embarrass the incoming state administration.
Princeton and Dartmouth's evenly matched teams play for one of the several conference championships to be decided today on the last full program of the intercollegiate football season.
Sixty - two nylon - bearded Santa Clauses went to work yesterday for the Volunteers of America on the sidewalks of New York.

HOUSTON, Nov. 21 -- The National Reclamation Association ended its twenty-seventh convention today by passing a series of resolutions aimed at stemming increased Federal regulation of the nation's water and reclamation projects.

IN spite of the efficient refrigerators and freezers that the modern housewife now has, food storage problems still arise. From Morristown, N. J., Mrs. Edith L. Smith has written to ask why chickens and turkeys sometimes turn sour after cooking.
LONDON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Britain's General Electric Company has made an agreement with a group of Japanese concerns to build nuclear power plants in Japan and the Far East.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 21 (UPI) -- Earl Buchholz, an 18-year-old from St. Louis, stunned Australian tennis fans with the "greatest victory" of his career today when he crushed an Aussie star, Mal Anderson, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 3, 9 -- 7, in the second round of the New South Wales championship.
LONDON, Nov. 21 -- The British Government is prepared for rapid action in concert with the United States, France and West Germany if the Soviet Union provokes a crisis in Berlin.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UPI) -- The Department of Commerce reported today that Russia was the only major country to increase steel output in the first nine months of this year.
CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (AP) -- A late rally gave wheat futures prices modest gains on the Board of Trade today. But corn and soybeans slowly extended their declines in slow dealings.
A little girl with a big piano technique made an impressive debut last night at Town Hall. Sally MacArthur played through a difficult program with poise, stamina and strength.
LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Fifteen-year-old Caril Ann Fugate was condemned to life in prison today for aiding and abetting Charles R. Starkweather on a murder rampage last January.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregularly yesterday. The close was 24 points lower than Thursday's final prices on old December, and 6 points lower to 4 higher on other months. (A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.)
YONKERS, Nov. 21 -- Almost before the Eastern Championship Trot began at Yonkers Raceway tonight, it was over -- so far as the winner of the $50,000 event was concerned.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 21--Britain said today that Israel's conditional offer to compensate Palestinian Arab refugees was an "important statement," However, Harold Beeley, who spoke for Britain, held out little hope that the offer would lead to a break in the ten-year deadlock on the future of the refugees.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Pete Cooper of Lakeland, Fla., took the lead in the West Palm Beach invitation open golf tournament today with a 9-under-par 63.
BERLIN, Nov. 21 -- The Soviet Union made its first move here today to implement its threat to withdraw from the Big Four occupation of Berlin.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- A mosquito trap patented this week entices the male insect by broadcasting the siren song of the female of the species.
A tale of a bottle on the ocean brought satisfaction to a 10-year-old Manhattan boy the other day.

The Board of Education in its reply yesterday to Controller Gerosa's complaint of waste and extravagance in school construction remarks that the board "welcomes any fair investigation." It feels that "the public is entitled to all the facts concerning all of its activities."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Following is the text of the United States note, sent to the Hungarian Government yesterday and made public today, answering charges that the United States was conducting hostile activities against Hungary:
A $50-a-week maid, who is the agent of the Bedford-Stuyvesant dwelling where five children were asphyxiated Thursday, was sentenced yesterday to ten days in jail for a prior building-code violation.
Four leases have been reported in the new building erected by Atlas Terminals, Inc., and Arthur Belfer at 630 Third Avenue, northwest corner of Forty-first Street. Collins, Tuttle Co. are the agents.

RYE, N. Y., Nov. 21 -- Richard J. Scheuer of the Beach Point Yacht Club was elected president of the Western Long Island Sound Fleet of the 210 Class tonight at the annual meeting at the American Yacht Club.
New York City held its fifth annual party last night for United Nations delegates and their families. Mayor and Mrs. Wagner were hosts at a buffet and reception in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
The First Presbyterian Church of New York will lay the cornerstone of its new church house tomorrow, but no Bible will be placed inside the stone.

WEST CHESTER, Pa., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Jack Harrington, a quarterback, thew five touchdown passes, and Jack Wendland, a halfback, scored three more to lead West Chester State Teachers College to a 69-12 victory over Baldwin-Wallace tonight.
ALBANY, Nov. 21 -- A major revision of automobile license plates and registration fees was recommended today by a state commission studying reorganization of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 21 (Reuters) -- England's cricket captain, Peter May, returned to his best form today, hitting an unbeaten 131 which helped the Marylebone C. C. reach 290 for seven on the opening day of a match against a powerful Australian team.
WHEN decorating the first home, be it a tiny apartment or a large house, it is wise to invest in one good piece of furniture, even if it devours practically the entire...
CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Mental illness has reached such scope that it must be termed a world-wide epidemic, the head of the American Medical Association said tonight.

Rocket engineers discussed the use of the chemical compound hydrazine by the ton at the Statler Hilton Hotel yesterday while psychiatrists at the Barbizon-Plaza talked about using it by the milligram -- about one thirty-thousandth of an ounce.

Miss Barbara Whitcomb Herndon, debutante and Smith College freshman, Will be honored next week at a private party and at two debutante fetes. She is also a member of the Junior Assemblies, the first of which will be held Friday in the Plaza.
The Campbell Soup Company elected two directors and increased the quarterly dividend yesterday.

MOSCOW, Nov. 21 -- The extent of the bonds of friendship that Moscow and Warsaw are proclaiming for each other was demonstrated here today with the announcement that Poland had presented a jubilee medal to Marshal Konstantin K. Rokossovsky.
A 35-year-old Cuban revolutionist surrendered here yesterday on an indictment accusing him of being an unregistered agent of Fidel Castro, the Cuban rebel leader.
In a no-quarter middleweight slugging match Ralph (Tiger) Jones scored a unanimous decision over Rory Calhoun at Madison Square Garden last night.

TUNIS, Nov. 21 -- Members of the Algerian rebel government held secret meetings with Moslems deep in Algeria last month. They returned with what they consider to be a popular mandate to reject any French offer short of full independence and if necessary to continue the war regardless of cost.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 21 -- President Eisenhower motored in the warm, sunny weather to the Southern Railroad station here today to welcome Mrs. Eisenhower, who arrived by overnight train from Washington.
Dr. Fazil Kuchuk, the leader of the Turkish group in Cyprus, and Rauf Denktash, his spokesman, said yesterday that the Turkish minority on the island would press for its partition.

Directors of the L. O. F. Glass Fibers Company have called a special stockholders meeting for Dec. 12 to consider a plan to sell the company's assets and business to the Johns-Manville Corporation, producer of building materials.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Top-ranked Louisiana State, the nation's only major football team still unbeaten and untied, ends its season tomorrow against Tulane.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Nov. 21 -- Excerpts from a United Nations report on the killing of Mrs. Joyce Mary Doran, wife of the British Air Attache in Israel, were made public here today by the Israeli Foreign Ministry.

HERBERT von Karajan showed yesterday at Carnegie Hall that he could conduct with tension and virility. In dealing with the first and last symphonies of Beethoven, he proved that he could combine an awareness of tradition with a strong feeling of personal involvement.

"What is it like in Russia?" "Are the people happy?" These are the common questions people ask me. And before I conclude these reports I want to say something more about Russia and the people, of whom we know as little as they know of us.

In professional basketball they speak of "big men" and "good big men." The National Basketball Association is loaded with big men, but only a few are so endowed as to be labeled "good." For years Knickerbocker fans have lamented the New York team's lack of such a performer -- a consistent 20-point scorer who could take up the defensive burden as well.
LITTLE AMERICA, Antarctica, Nov. 19 -- The Navy icebreaker Glacier arrived here today after a 400-mile trip from McMurdo Sound.

The glory of Bach's B minor Mass is such that amateur choristers, like those of the justly famous Collegiate Chorale, will slave through weeks, months or even years and count the music its own reward, even if they were never to give a public performance.

ROME, Nov. 21 -- Pope John XXIII left the Vatican for the first time today since he entered it Oct. 25 to attend the conclave of the Sacred College of Cardinals that elected him Pope three days later.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 21 -- In 1947, Rutgers lost its opener to Columbia, then won eight in a row, registering its best record in history. Tomorrow, the Scarlet will carry a 7-1 mark into the season's finale against Columbia here with hopes of making the Lions victim No. 8.

HAVANA, Nov. 21 -- Government troops, in a new offensive against the insurgents of Fidel Castro in Oriente Province, have killed more than 100 rebels, according to a communique from the Presidential Palace today.

A TRANSLUCENT, synthetic glass material with the effect of stained glass has recently been developed by Fred Friedel, a designer. Called Stain-Glaze, this "glass" has been made into all sorts of colorful mobiles, window panels, lamp shades and screens for the home.
A program to hire civilians to handle parking enforcement is being drafted for Mayor Wagner's approval. The initial plan calls for 100 "meter maids" who would work with the city's Traffic Department.
The pace of new corporate financing will be cut sharply next week by the Thanksgiving Day holiday. It is expected that new issue volume in the following week will be unusually heavy.

Following is the text of a reply by all nine members of the city Board of Education and the Superintendent of Schools to charges by Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa of waste on frills and extravagance in new school construction.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 21 -- Army's 150-pound football team completed its second straight unbeaten season today by trouncing Rutgers, 33 -- 8, at Shea Stadium.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 21 -- Mel Ott, former New York Giants' baseball star and manager, died here today of injuries received in an automobile collision a week ago. He was 49 years old.

GOVERNMENTAL activity has been the life-long interest of Dr. Charles Rosenberry Erdman Jr., who became New Jersey's Republican State Chairman yesterday. As a student at Princeton University, he majored in political science.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 21 -- Leaders of American Protestantism voted unanimously today in favor of United States recognition of Communist China and its admission to the United Nations.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov, 21 -- Criticism of those who associate Orthodox Judaism with "mere rituals and forms of worship" was voiced here today by the head of the largest Orthodox rabbinic body in the country.

The Kentucky Utilities Company is offering holders of its common stock rights to subscribe for 206,446 shares at the rate of one new share for every twelve held. The subscription price is $33 a share. The offer, which will end on Dec. 8, is underwritten by a syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., and J. J. B. Hilliard Sons.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Court of Military Appeals held today that the armed forces power to prosecute servicemen charged with certain civilian-like offenses during the Korean War ran until July 27, 1959, or three years after the end of hostilities.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 21 -- A record total of 5,370,223 Australians have registered to vote in tomorrow's federal election.
A plant said to be the first devoted exclusively to the manufacture of glass parts for electronic devices was formally put into operation yesterday at Bradford, Pa., by the Corning Glass Works.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Nov. 21 -- The attainmment by San Diego of major stature as a commercial port was marked today with the dedication of its new $9,460,000 Marine Terminal.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21 (UPI) -- A group of scientists founded today an American organization dedicated to the study of how weather affects human behavior.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Sympathy for a policy of toughness, including the use of armed convoys, in the Berlin crisis developed in responsible quarters today.
Sol Hurok is very much interested in producing "A Lovely Light" on Broadway next season. It is a dramatization by Dorothy Stickney of the life of the late Edna St. Vincent Millay.

The radio network of the Columbia Broadcasting System is canceling a number of programs on Jan. 5 as part of its previously announced plan to give its affiliated stations more time to sell on a local basis.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UPI) -- Latin American countries urged the United States today to contribute a substantial sum of money to a proposed inter-American bank aimed at easing Western Hemisphere economic problems.

CHICAGO, NOV. 21 -- Hermann I. Schlesinger, Professor Emeritus of Chemistry at the University of Chicago, was named winner of the 1959 Willard Gibbs Medal of the Chicago section of the American Chemical Society today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The court order against the merger of two big steel companies was hailed today as "an emphatic vindication of the policy of the antitrust laws" by Representative Emanuel Celler, Brooklyn Democrat.
PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 21 -- The Ivy League football championship will be decided tomorrow when Princeton plays Dartmouth in Palmer Stadium.

Mark Bucci's one-act opera, "Tale for a Deaf Ear," which was performed at Tanglewood in the summer of 1957 and during the season of American opera at the City Center last spring, opened at the Theatre Marquee on Fifty-ninth Street last night. It was on a triple bill with two other Bucci works, "The Dress" and "Sweet Betsy From Pike."
A $250,000 suit for defamation was filed in Supreme Court here yesterday by Tobias Stone, international bridge expert, against the directors of the American Contract Bridge League.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Nov. 21 -Uprisings have swept Communist China since the commune system was introduced last summer, a leading research and psychological warfare expert said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -Lincoln White, State Department spokesman, said today that the State Department had no knowledge of a trip to Washington by Archbishop Makarios nor was it aware that any official had talked to him since his arrival in this country last week.

Sophomores and "No English" Prof. Willard Thorp of Princeton University, in a recent issue of The Princeton Alumni Weekly, has let fly in several directions against certain "voices" of the age which, he says, are muddying the American language and, as a result, are causing imitative college students to write miserable prose.
TRENTON, Nov. 21 -- Charles R. Erdman Jr. of Princeton was elected Republican State Chairman today. He succeeds Samuel L. Bodine who died on Sept. 15.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Nov. 21 -An Opposition motion of no confidence in Prime Minister S. W. R. D. Bandaranaike's Government was lost by 52 votes to 20 in the House of Representatives today.
How clean should the dinner dishes be washed? A group of scientists has received a $60,000 grant from the United States Public Health Service to find out.

FOR beginning skiers, resorts in the New York area offer abundant opportunities to learn. At most ski lodges, boots, skis and poles can be rented, but one should arrive with the other necessary ski clothes and equipment.

PARIS, Nov. 21 -- In all probability the two-stage French elections that begin Sunday and terminate a week later will prove nothing except the continued popularity of Charles de Gaulle and the decline of the Communist party on France's political power scale.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Nov. 21 -- The United States has told Hungary that improvement in the relations between their Governments is up to the Hungarians.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 21--The 7,000 union mechanics of Trans World Airlines went on strike today. T. W. A. immediately canceled all flights.
ALBANY, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The New York State Museum will remain in Albany, the State Board of Regents said today.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21 -- Webb Knapp, Inc., of New York and a nation-wide real estate syndicate were selected here today to redevelop about half of the $50,000,000 Society Hill project in the oldest section of the city.

MACON, Ga., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Judge Oscar L. Long ruled today in favor of six railroad employes and enjoined fifteen non-operating labor unions from forcing them to pay dues, a portion of which are used for political purposes.
Rent increases of $1 to $10 a month were ordered yesterday for most of the families living in public housing here.

HILLSDALE, N. J., Nov. 20 -- Twenty-six children in the sixth grade at the Ann Blanche Smith School here had a lesson on Mexico today. It was unusual only in that the teacher was not a member of the faculty, but the mother of one of the boys in the class.

Fred Winrock has been elected president of the Staten Island Home Builders Association. Other new officers are Joseph A. Santero, vice president; Adam P. Antenucci, secretary, and Eloi Le Blanc, treasurer.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Most of the betting tomorrow is expected to be on a hometown team to win the stake in the Pimlico Futurity -- the second biggest award of cash in horse racing this year.
GENEVA, Nov. 21 -- United States, British and Soviet negotiators came to grips today with the substantive issues of ending nuclear weapons tests under a world system of control.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21 -- In a game marred by elbow and fist throwing and near free-for-alls, the New York Knickerbockers defeated the Boston Celtics, 112 -- 106, in the first game of a double-header at Convention Hall tonight.
The Board of Education yesterday characterized Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa's charge of waste in school construction as an "amazing mathematical fiction."

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 21 (UPI) -- A pall of gloom was cast over the offices of the Giants today with the announcement that Mel Ott, the "greatest Giant of them all, next to John McGraw," died in New Orleans.

PARIS, Nov. 21 (Reuters) -- Lawmakers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization nations today urged an alliance military build-up. They pressed for clear plans to counter any surprise attack swiftly with nuclear weapons.

Cedar Hill, a group of two-story garden apartment buildings at 35 South Broadway, Irvington-on-Hudson in Westchester County, has been purchased for investment by Arthur Maxwell Co. Cedar Lawn Garden, Inc., the seller, erected the houses in 1950.
Dedicated to the theme, "From Jennies to Jets," the tenth annual National Stamp Show opened yesterday at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 21 -- Negotiations between the Soviet Union and the West over international control of outer space reached a deadlock today.
The Lehigh Valley Railroad has not yet deserted its passengers, but it feels they have deserted it, a spokesman for the road said yesterday.

THERE are few things in heaven or on earth that are undreamt of in Father John LaFarge's philosophy. He was working for racial integration decades before it was discovered as a cause by many contemporary adherents. His dedication as a Roman Catholic priest has taken him into all kinds of religious and social fields.

A search by Health Department inspectors for Haitian voodoo dolls, believed to be made of poisonous cashew nut shells, was unsuccessful yesterday. A spokesman, however, urged that anyone possessing such a doll take it in to the department for tests.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 21 -- The Soviet Ambassador to Bonn said tonight that he expected the Berlin question to be settled by Christmas.

The people of Long Island should be permitted to decide whether they want New York City banks to establish branches in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, Walter E. Van der Waag said yesterday. Mr. Van der Waag is president of the Meadow Brook National Bank, second largest on the island.
Events today: Verdi's "Rigoletto," 2 P. M., and Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunov," 8, both at Metropolitan Opera; New York Philharmonic, Herbert von Karajan, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 8:30.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 21 -- Some 350 men of Harvard and an equal number of Yale counterparts blocked, tackled, passed and kicked enthusiastically today in a colorful prelude to The Game.

George Alpert, president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, and William J. Quinn, president of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad (Milwaukee Road), have been elected directors of the Association of American Railroads, trade organization of the railroad industry.
A comprehensive program designed to cope with mental retardation was recommended at the close of a two-day conference here yesterday of the Council of State Governments.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 21 -- The success of a group of former mental patients in getting jobs was revealed today in a follow-up study of state hospital patients in Massachusetts.

Bizet's "Carmen" made its first appearance of the season last night at the Metropolitan Opera. The cast was largely familiar; the conductor was not. Jean Morel conducted the work for the first time in his Metropolitan career.
PARIS, Nov. 21 -- France's critical housing problem will get special attention in the 1959 budget through the direct intervention of Premier Charles de Gaulle.

DETROIT, Nov. 21 (AP) -- With all their assembly plants working overtime, United States auto makers will build 141,072 cars this week, Ward's Automotive Reports said today. This is the highest total for any week since last December.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- An international institute of scientific information was proposed today as one answer to the problem of how to keep scientists informed on scientific developments throughout the world.
James McCutcheon Co., a 103-year-old New York specialty store has asked a Federal court here to arrange its debts. During the proceedings the store and its suburban branches will continue to operate.
Reflecting a decline in sales, earnings of the Chicago Pneumatic Tool Company and its subsidiaries dropped to $5,240,000 for the first nine months this year from $8,620,000 in the 1957 period.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The National Association of Inter-group Relations officials urged President Eisenhower today to assume leadership in halting what it called growing resistance to racial desegregation.
PARIS, Nov. 21 -- Two army colonels from Algeria have invaded Paris, six months after having helped to unleash a military threat against the French capital and Government.

HONG KONG, Nov. 21 -- Gen. Chu Teh, Communist China's deputy chief of state, told a youth conference in Peiping today that "the Communist society that Communists have striven to achieve for more than a hundred years" would be realized in this generation.

A T. W. A. spokesman here estimated that approximately 1,500 persons booked as domestic passengers had been affected as of last night by flight cancellations in the New York area. Outbound trips were curtailed beginning in early afternoon.
Directors of the Kennecott Copper Corporation declared a dividend yesterday of $1 a share on the common stock, payable on Dec. 22 to holders of record on Dec. 2.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- About 750 old master drawings collected in the eighteenth century by the English enthusiast, John Skippe, were sold for a total of 91,583 5s ($256,433) at a two-day auction at Christie's that ended here today.
Stockholders of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad yesterday approved $18,542,000 of borrowings. The financing will carry a Government guarantee to the lenders.

Measures as drastic as flooding hospital floors with detergent-disinfectants and closing off patients' rooms with air-locks and radiation barriers were suggested here yester day to fight the spread of drug-resistant germs in hospitals.

Adele Levy's letter in The New York Times of Nov. 14 on behalf of the Citizens Committee for Children makes a valid point with which we agree when she argues the urgency of continuing necessary services for the people of New York City.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov. 21 -- The Hofstra College Symphony Orchestra opened its tenth annual concert series tonight with a performance of George Kleinsinger's comic opera "Archy and Mehitabel." The concert was attended by 850 persons. Elie Siegmeister conducted.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- About 750 old master drawings collected in the eighteenth century by the English enthusiast, John Skippe, were sold for a total of 91,583 5s ($256,433) at a two-day auction at Christie's that ended here today.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov, 21 -- A spokesman for the Philadelphia Electric Company said today that the proposed plant would be built outside this city in open country, somewhere in the southern end of the company's territory.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 21 (UPI) -- Harry Bradshaw, nine-time pro champion of Ireland, fired his second straight 2-under-par 70 today and sent the Emerald Isle into the individual and team lead in the Canada Cup golf tournament.
The Waterfront Commission's right to subpoena books and records of the longshoremen's union has been upheld for the second time in three days.
Commodity futures prices moved irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading in most markets was dull. Evening of positions prior to the week-end accounted for most of the volume.
Roosevelt Brown, whose presence in the offensive line-up is almost imperative if the Giants are to be successful, had a full work-out with the team at the Yankee Stadium yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UPI) -- The American Newspaper Publishers Association and several other groups asked the Federal Communications Commission today to suspend revised Teleprinter rate increases sought by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and Western Union.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that 8,943,846 running bales of cotton from the 1958 crop were ginned before Nov. 14.
WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 21 -- Children are getting taller, the Westchester County Park Commission decided today after research here and in Washington.
The stock market turned decisively lower yesterday and registered the biggest loss of the month.
Formal negotiations between the four television and radio networks and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists "presumably" will not be resumed before Monday.
After long litigation the United States Customs Court here has ruled that a work of art should not be classified as a vegetable.
WITH a month to go, wise shoppers will choose the practical present over the whimsical bauble that never is put to much use after Christmas Day.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 21 (AP) -- An artist's three-year legal fight to collect $7,500 because the Mayor of Baltimore had called his painting obscene ended today.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 21 -- Following are examples from a message adopted here today by a World Order Study Conference sponsored by the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. The excerpts refer to the recognition of Communist China.
THE mass arrest of sixty goose hunters in the fields along Lake Mattamuskeet at Hyde, N. C., last Monday has aroused some loud protests in and out of court.
IOWA CITY, Nov. 21 (AP) -Iowa, with its swift backs, faces the problem of turning them loose against Notre Dame tomorrow.
Johnny Bach, Fordham's basketball coach, is surprisingly chipper these days considering that the Rams lost Jimmy Cunningham through graduation last June.

"SHERMAN ADAMS" and "Bernard Goldfine," swadled in cloth coats of "Republican mink," set out for the moon in a rocket last night. An advertising model dreamed that she went to the New York Stock Exchange in her Maidenform Bra. And the American Stock Exchange threatened a rumble because the Big Board was fooling around with its cats and dogs.

MOSCOW, Nov. 21 (Reuters) -- Soviet oceanographers on a voyage of discovery in the North Pacific have confirmed that there are no stagnant waters in deep ocean depressions, the Soviet Press agency Tass said today.

The Board of Estimate voted yesterday to hold public hearings at 2 P. M. Wednesday on applications of two of the city's largest franchised bus companies for authority to charge 3 cents for the transfers they now provide without cost.
The city will cede the site of Grant's Tomb, at Riverside Drive and West 122d Street, to the Federal Government under authorization voted yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

We applaud the address of Presiding Justice Bernard Botein of the Appellate Division First Department at the Institute on Court Reorganization, sponsored by the League of Women Voters, and commend it to all those who are working for the modernization of our courts.

TORONTO, Nov. 21 (Canadian Press) -- A team from West Germany tonight won the international team Challenge Prix des Nations Trophy, the major jumping competition at the Royal Agricultural Winter Fair horse show.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 21 -- The series of destructive cost-of-living riots in Brazilian cities has continued despite President Juscelino Kubitschek's order freezing prices.

New data from Soviet sources have strengthened indications that former Premier Georgi M. Malenkov was deeply involved in the so-called Leningrad affair, a purge of the Communist party carried out in 1949-50.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Sigma Delta Chi, professional journalism fraternity, elected James A. Byron, news director of WBAP of Fort Worth, Texas, as president today.

Enthusiasm and optimism are important traits that often spell the difference between success and failure in business. In retailing they are reflected in window and counter merchandise displays, attitudes of the sales staff and advertising. The successful merchant is one who can impart these traits to those around him and an enthusiastic merchandising team generally will overcome obstacles that might tend to stop a group that is not so imbued.
Observers of the retail trade are predicting apparel sales this Christmas will exceed last year's volume with women's and children's clothes leading the way.

Normal waistlines may have vanished everywhere else, but on southern beaches this resort season they are not only back but also bare. Not far a decade have so many two-piece bathing suits been seen. More daring types may even try the Bikini for maximum exposure to the sun.

A charge made last week that the Board of Education spent $100,000,000 more than necessary for school construction in the past seven years has pointed up what appears to be a sensitive area in education.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Among the numerous causes to which the Nov. 4 defeat of so many Republican candidates for Congress and State office has been attributed, perhaps one credited to Senator Case, Republican of New Jersey, has the widest acceptance. The Republican party as an entity, he was quoted as saying, has created no "image" whereas the Democrats have -- the still popular "image" of the New Deal, "the party of the people."

Boys Towns of Italy will benefit from a concert to be given on Dec. 12 by the Symphony of the Air at Carnegie Hall. Leopold Stokowski will conduct and Mario Del Monaco, a tenor of the Metropolitan Opera, will be guest soloist.

The large-scale projects to tame the fusion energy of the hydrogen bomb and make it a source of almost limitless industrial power haves resulted in the emergence of a new subdivision of physics. It is known as "magnetohydrodynamics," or "hydromagnetics."

CHARLESTON, S. C. -- Eight miles before reaching Charleston on U. S. 17, a southbound motorist drives within half a mile of Boone Hall, one of the handsomest and most historic plantations in the South.

EDWIN THOMAS BOOTH'S life was bracketed in sheer theatre. On Nov. 13, 1833, the darkness of Harford County, Md., was lit by meteors showering all night out of the constellation, Leo. It was the night that Edwin Booth was born on his father's Maryland farm.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- An improved treatment for some patients with fractured thigh or disclocated hip bones is foreseen from recent work at the Orthopedic Surgery Department, University of Pittsburgh. British surgeons who have heard about the development call it a "splendid achievement."

JACKSONVILLE, Fla. -- A recent addition to the Fort Caroline National Memorial, twelve miles east of here, is the Ribault Monument, a replica of the marker which was originally planted near the mouth of the St. Johns River when Jean Ribault, French admiral, landed with an expedition of French Huguenots in 1562.
There are more modern tugboats operating in the Port of New York than anywhere else in the world, Edmond J. Moran, president of the Moran Towing and Transportation Company, said last week.
WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 22 -- Should the Westchester County branches of the American Red Cross join in the federated fund campaigns of other philanthropic organizations?
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 22 (UPI) -- The University of California at Los Angeles and Southern California played to a 15-15 football tie today after a wild second half in which all the points were scored.
FREEPORT, L. I., Nov. 22 -- Nassau's first Federally financed low-rent apartment-house project was dedicated here today.
The second annual International Vacation Festival and Ball for the benefit of the Braille Music Institute will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Biltmore next Saturday and Sunday.
Secretary-General Dag Hammarskjold's decision to liquidate the United Nations Observation Group in Lebanon brings to a close an important chapter in the post-Suez history of the Middle East.
MOSCOW, Nov. 22 -- Soviet explorers are remedy to sail on their fourth expedition to the Antarctic with equipment for a tractor journey across the continent.

LUXEMBOURG, Nov. 22 -- A miner has just come to this beautiful old fortress town to ask the High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community what it plans to do for him now that the Belgian pit in which he worked has been closed.

The National League for Nursing, Inc., 2 Park Avenue, has received a grant of $622,923 from the Commonwealth Fund. The league announced yesterday that the money would be used for a three-year extension of a program of educational awards to nurses doing graduate study.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22 -- The Friends of the Free Library of Philadelphia have given the institution the Kelmscott Chaucer, described as one of the "greatest fine-press books of modern times."
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 11 -- Thousands of Yugoslav youths are finishing a key link in a high-speed road system that eventually will cross Yugoslavia from Italy to Greece.
The Queens Library Council announced yesterday that it would seek state and Federal investigations of transactions involving a proposed site for the Queens Main Library.
Most of the health care of the 19,000,000 Burmese is provided by the Government through its Ministry and directorate of Health.
TOKYO, Nov. 22 -- Premier Nobusuke Kishi agreed today to drop the controversial police bill.

As was suggested in this column several weeks ago, there is a strange division between contemporary interest in words and the accompanying abuse of them. The year 1958 will go down as the biggest since the Twenties for foreign interests to raise debt capital in the public bond market of this country. All indications point to a period of similar activity in 1959.

THE Battle of Gettysburg was unique; it had everything. Here was a battle which Gen. Robert E. Lee and Maj. Gen. George Cordon Meade stumbled into, which neither wanted to fight, and which Meade had grave thoughts of breaking off at the end of the second day and retiring to Pipe Creek across the line in Maryland, where from the beginning he had hoped to bring on the engagement.
When the directors of the United States Plywood Corporation elected a new president two months ago there was a ripple of surprise in industry circles.

The Police Department began distributing last week copies in the Spanish language of its booklet "This Is Your Policeman." It is being sent into Spanish-speaking communities to further understanding of the New York City patrolman.
DENVER, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Stan Hack, a former manager of the Chicago Cubs and a Cub infielder for sixteen seasons, was named manager of the Denver Bears of the American Association today.

NORMAN, Okla., Nov. 22 (UPI) -- Oklahoma won it eleventh straight Big Eight Conference championship and its second consecutive Orange Bowl berth today by crushing Nebraska, 40 -- 7, in their final home game of the season before a Dad's Day crowd of 45,000. It was Oklahoma's seventy-first consecutive league game without defeat.
ALBANY, Nov. 22 -- Sportsmen probably will be paying the state more for the right to hunt and fish in 1959.

AN exhibition broadly surveying photography's past and present achievements, both American and foreign, in black-and-white and in color, will open Wednesday on the first floor of The Museum of Modern Art, where it will run to Jan. 18.
IOWA CITY, Nov. 22 -- Iowa defeated Notre Dame, 31 -- 21, today for its seventh victory in nine games. A crowd of 58,230 saw the game.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Nov. 22 -- Chuck Zimmerman threw two touchdown passes today and paced Syracuse to a 15-12 victory over West Virginia's scrappy Mountaineers before some 26,000 fans. The victory was the eighth of the season for Syracuse against one loss, a 14-13 setback by Holy Cross.

AN associate astronomer of the American Museum- Hayden Planetarium, Franklyn M. Branley has lectured to crowds of people, young and old. For those who have his book in hand, the strain of trying to take notes in the darkness of a planetarium dome will be eliminated.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo. -- Colorado's "Rush to the Rockies" Centennial starts in January, and nearly everyone, including the ski crowd, is taking a bemused look backward and discussing how things out here got to be the way they are.
I was most interested in the letter signed C. K. in the Travel Section of Nov. 16 relative to the fine job being performed by both Customs and U. S. Health officers at Idlewild.
HONOLULU, Nov. 22 -- The Democratic party this week appointed a Public Lands Reform Committee to function for the first time at the next session of the Territorial Legislature.

THERE are many names for the savory mixture that plumps a Thanksgiving bird. Here at home it is known variously as filling, dressing or stuffing. The French call it farce, a word to be used cautiously on the domestic scene.

LISBON, Portugal, Nov. 18 -- United States tourists are expected to constitute the most important dollar-producing industry in Portugal by the year's end. They are already in second place, the National Secretary of Information, Dr. Cesar Moreira Baptista, reported today.

AUBURN, Ala., Nov. 22 (UPI) -- Richard Wood, Dixie's hardest -throwing passer, straightened out Auburn's creaky attack with five straight completions in the third period to set up a 21-7 victory over Wake Forest today.

ABOUT fifty years ago, Americans began to use a new word: people would say that so-and-so was a "highbrow." The term carried with it a tinge of contempt. The highbrow, it was suggested, set himself apart from other men. His sincerity was suspect; he was "putting on airs."

DAN O'HERLIHY is a "theatrical pro," an "actor's actor," according to many Hollywood observers. In his own words, the tall, soft-spoken Irishman is "still stage-struck, an amateur at heart." Michael O'Herlihy, who was one of Ireland's top scenic designers before coming to Hollywood, thinks his big brother "is now a personality." To most moviegoers, Dan O'Herlihy is Robinson Crusoe.

AS a young man in the late Thirties, writer Budd Schulberg was engaged to collaborate on a movie, "Winter Carnival," with the renowned but declining F. Scott Fitzgerald. NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 22 -- Despite an injured left hand that was covered by a protective device, Bill Austin scored five touchdowns as Rutgers routed Columbia's football squad, 61 -- 0, today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The United States has developed a show to teach the people of India the ways of small capitalists.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- A farm control program rooted deep in twenty-five years of legislative efforts to cut crop surpluses may come to an end on Tuesday.

LATE in September, 1780, his treason unmasked, Gen. Benedict Arnold escaped downriver to the sanctuary of British-held New York. During the next week, the plotter himself was the target of one of the strangest counter-plots in American history.

The National Science Foundation has granted $500,000 to the University of North Carolina for purchase of a Univac computer for basic research. The grant is the first in a series planned by the foundation to assist in the establishment of about twelve regional computer centers. The university intends to build a computation laboratory that can be used by other institutions in the Southeast.
Art objects, paintings, jewelry and interior decorations will be sold at auction Tuesday in the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, under the auspices of noted designers and artists.

Three projects are being pressed in the city to develop a general framework of study and experience for the renewal of existing neighborhoods, Mayor Wagner said yesterday.

The oil industry may be in for serious scrutiny by the recently elected Congress after the first of the year. At least, that is what many oil executives believe and some companies already have started programs designed to give the public a basic understanding of the oil business.
WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Holy Cross sent Bob De Fino across for two touchdowns and then halted two drives inside the 10-yard line for a 14-0 football victory over Marquette today.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Kentucky repulsed repeated Tennessee threats in the first half and then sprung Glenn Shaw loose for a 24-yard scoring run and a 6-2 football victory today.

St. David's School, 12 East Eighty-ninth Street, will benefit from the proceeds of a private film party. The party will be held the evening of Dec. 5 at the Twentieth Century-Fox Studios, 444 West Fifty-sixth Street.

LONDON, Nov. 22 (UPI) -- The Communist party called today for demonstrations against Vice President Richard M. Nixon and a march on the united States Embassy when he arrives Tuesday on a goodwill visit.
ERZURUM, Turkey, Nov. 19 -- Remote eastern Turkey has just acquired the university that Kemal Ataturk said it should have.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 22 -- The Finnish coalition Government, which has come under increasing though silent pressure from Moscow, begins deliberations tomorrow on whether it can stay in office.

The Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling, editor of The Christian Herald, rebuked a conference of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. yesterday for urging United States recognition of Communist China.

Your correspondent, Miss Miriam Mermey, was sputtering indeed in her complaints over "Heloise." For one thing, she misquoted your critic. KHARTOUM, The Sudan, Nov. 22 -- Lieut. Gen. Ibrahim Abboud, head of the revolutionary government that seized power in an army coup last Monday, said tonight that as soon as "things are put right" the army would return the country to civilian control.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 22 -- Die-hard segregationists are counting on a straw poll of Norfolk voters to help them repel the slowly advancing forces of moderation in Virginia.

Last week, on Strauss Street between Pitkin and Sutter, an assortment of burly Puerto Rican, Negro and Jewish citizens fixedly watched Columbia Pictures and Paul Muni recreate "The Last Angry Man" (see photo below). From every doorway, window and fire escape the new Brooklyn waited to be shown.

The police seized more than $100,000 in stolen goods yesterday in pre-dawn raids on five Brooklyn apartments. It took six hours and the use of three patrol wagons and fifteen squad cars to cart the merchandise away.
BUFFALO, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The University of Buffalo trounced Bucknell, 38 -- 0, today to close its most successful football season in sixty-one years.

PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, Nov. 22 -- Haiti's Public Health Service and Tourist Bureau were quick to react today to reports that Haitian voodoo dolls used as beverage swizzle sticks had been condemned by the United States Public Health Service.

MIAMI, Nov. 19 -- Plans to make Miami an international business center with a new $20,000,000 sea port as its principal selling point are moving ahead steadily, in the opinion of local business men.
DETROIT, Sunday, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Bendix Aviation Corporation and the United Auto Workers Union reached agreement early today on a new three-year contract covering 13,500 workers in eight cities.

SKOPLJE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 17 -- Although it is the professed object of one of the noisiest phases of the renewed Soviet- bloc campaign against Yugoslavia, the People's Republic of Macedonia appears calm about the whole affair.

ATLANTA, Nov. 22 -- Religious leaders here warned today of the "deepening danger" of the South's racial crisis. They called for a save-the-schools plan consistent with the Supreme Court's desegregation decision.

GENEVA, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Members of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) ended their thirteenth session here today after having drawn up plans for an international program to expand world trade.

So much and precious little more is borne out in the show of his paintings and drawings at Hirschl Adler.

The price reduction on wash-and-wear cotton shirts by some producers last August is not working well. The manufacturers that held the line and kept shirts at $5 retail generally reported a decline in sales. Those that made the reduction to $4 note increased demand but have made little, if any, profit.

THE attractions of Paris that have lured many American moviemakers to the City of Light are beckoning to another local film group. Last week, if became known that Diana Productions, a recently formed independent company, plans to film its first, and appropriately titled project, "Paris Blues," in the French capital. Filming should get under way, barring unforeseen hitches, "some time in May or June," according to a spokesman for Diana.

HAMILTON, Ont., Nov. 22 (Canadian Press) -- The Hamilton Tiger-Cats coasted more or less comfortably to the Eastern Canada football championship today, striking early and late to defeat the Ottawa Rough Riders, 19 -- 7, and taking the two-game, total-point final of the Big Four League, 54-14.

AMERICAN vegetable seed researchers and seeds-men are meeting food gardening needs by furnishing finer varieties of tomatoes, peppers, beans, beets, corn and cucumbers. France begins today to select the men who will help Premier Charles de Gaulle shape and run the Fifth Republic. From the Channel to the Pyrenees, nearly 3,000 aspirants for 465 seats in the new National Assembly have been grasping every hand within reach, admiring voters' cows, children and opinions, and making an astronomical number of speeches. Several economists representing major corporations have completed a behind-the-scenes job of assisting business in its charity work.

A criminal psychologist asserted yesterday that correctional institutions were delinquent in failing to provide group psychotherapy for their inmates. Such a program could reduce the number of crime repeaters by 50 per cent, he said.
Flushing High's aggressive football team racked up its fifth successive triumph yesterday at Woodrow Wilson High Field, Baisley Park, Queens, by turning back John Adams, 28 to 12.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 22 -- A report submitted to the Cleveland school board proposes a maximum salary of $9,450 a year for teachers -- and a super-maximum of $10,650 for a specially selected group with long experience and exceptional qualifications. The present maximum is $7,250.
An expanded program under which teen-age leaders will be sent to preparatory schools and colleges was reported yesterday by the Boys' Club of New York.
HONG KONG, Nov. 15 -- Nine years ago Communist China could not produce an aspirin; today it makes all the penicillin and antibiotics its hospitals need.

BOSTON, Nov. 22 (UPI) -- Vic Stasiuk, a center, broke a fifteen-game goal drought today, tallying in the opening minutes of the final period to lift the Boston Bruins to a 2-1 victory over the Detroit Red Wings.

Zim's book the drawings, like the text, are printed in blue- purple ink. G. Warren Schloat's illustrations are chiefly photographs by the author and others. They are excellent.

Berlin is not, never was, and never could be the most beautiful of cities. The Berlin of the Kaiser's Germany had ugly slums, comfortable but also ugly middle-class dwellings and some grotesque monuments and edifices of empire. In 1945, two out of five of the city's dwellings were uninhabitable because of the vengeance that Adolf Hitler had brought down upon the doomed capital.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Michigan State, the last-place team in the Big Ten football standing, today proved it still was a powerhouse in non-conference play by whipping Kansas State, 26 -- 7, before a crowd of 39,032.
SPOKANE, Nov. 22 (UPI) -- Washington State rallied to edge Washington, 18 -- 14, today in the fifty-first meeting of these Pacific Coast Conference rivals.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits reported today that spending by thirteen major Federal departments and agencies had channeled approximately $28,000,000,000 into New York between mid-1952 and mid-1958.

BERLIN, Nov. 22 -- An important difference of approach to the Berlin crisis has cropped up among the Western Allies. The difference is between the United States and France on the one hand and Britain on the other.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Nov. 22 -- The first Snow Ball of the Glen Cove Neighborhood House, a privately sponsored charitable organization more than 100 years old, will be held on Dec. 13. The event will take place at the former indoor tennis court of the one-time George du Pont Pratt estate on Dosoris Lane, now the headquarters of the center.
The American merchant fleet lost one vessel in November, but gained 65,000 tons over last month, according to the American Merchant Marine Institute.

I have read with considerable surprise a news item which appeared on Oct. 30 entitled "Rescue in Adriatic Snags U. S. Vessel." The tanker Valley Forge had the fortune (or misfortune) to rescue six men and a woman adrift in the Adriatic who had risked their lives fleeing from persecution in Yugoslavia.

ONE of the most highly developed and gratifying forms of riding to the hounds of culture (up the hills of status, down the dales of acceptance as, in full cry, they bay at the heels of the Philistines) is attendance at the opening of an art show, a phenomenon so far removed from its original function, the exhibition of paintings for sale, as to be, like the vermiform appendix, vestigial.

THE issue that concerns Robert Cooley Angell is how a society like ours -- with its great sprawling cities, freedom of movement for persons and capital, a family institution which is neither subject to social control nor efficient in rearing individuals with strong enough moral adherence to the central values of our society -- can muster a sufficient degree of responsibility so that the necessary institutions are maintained, assayed and changed when necessary.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- A handbook to help public school teachers cope with problems of delinquency was issued today by the National Education Association. It draws a line between cultural and emotional delinquency.

VENICE, Fla. -- Only two resort cities on the lower west coast of Florida are situated directly on the Gulf of Mexico. All others are some distance inland -- St. Petersburg, for example -- or are shielded from the Gulf of Mexico by offshore islands, as at Sarasota.

HOME owners who wish to attract birds to the garden can start planning appetizing menus for hungry wintertime visitors. Winter, from a wildlife standpoint, starts with the falling of leaves in autumn and continues until the buds appear in mid-April.

Putting up some simple shelving is a home improvement project which any handyman can tackle with confidence. No power tools are needed in most cases -- and specialized hardware is available to simplify the more difficult installations.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 22 -- Africa is "crying for economic development," in the view of a Sudanese who will have a major role in developing the continent.

YONKERS, Nov 22 (AP) -- Caton Hanover, driven by Clint Hodgins, rolled from second in the stretch and won tonight's feature pace by a length and a quarter from Noble Adios before 27,941 at Yonkers Raceway. The time for the mile was 2:04 2/5.

The nation's climbing college enrollment reached 3,258,556 this fall, according to figures compiled by the United States Office of Education. It will probably be at 3,500,000 before the school year is over.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Nov. 22 -- Peace proposals received here during the last two weeks by a number of Chinese Nationalist leaders from Chinese Communist sources have all contained five major points, acording to informed sources.

Dr. John C. Adams, president of Hofstra College, has announced an unusually interesting experiment for next year on behalf of the gifted student. The college will set up a separate unit far 120 students wherein the first two years of the usual college course can be compressed into one. The academic year, from Labor Day to July 4, will be slightly longer than the present one, but the academic week will be four days.

October business in the Chicago area fell short of the pace set in September, the monthly report of the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago indicated. Based on membership replies in the latest month, the firming pattern evident in the third quarter seemed solidly established, however.
For the first time in five years the Yankees have found it necessary to increase their ticket prices.

CARACAS, Venezuela -- Governor-elect Nelson A. Rockefeller's post-election vacation trip to his three farms here has opened the eyes of Venezuelan officials and business men to the possibility of attracting American tourists in larger numbers. But being realists they are aware that any large-scale campaign to obtain visitors from the north must be preceded by a drastic simplification of Venezuelan entrance and exit requirements.

Japanese Premier Kishi has yielded to extreme pressure and has withdrawn his controversial "police bill" from consideration by the Diet. The opposition Socialists, in turn, have agreed to drop their eighteen-day boycott of the sessions and to recognize the legality of the time extension which was put through against their violent and disorderly objection. The business of the Diet can now go on.
TAIPEI, Taiwan Nov. 21 -- A major economic reform became effective here Friday with the adoption by the Government of a single rate of exchange for all imports and exports.

Palmieri, who late Friday granted approval of the management plan to separate Loew's theatres and radio station WMGM from the company's other activities. MODERN steam puddings frequently associated with the approaching holidays, are an outgrowth of the heavy hearty boiled-in-bag puddings popular in England in the early eighteenth century. Today's puddings are leavened and usually steamed in molds. They are light and delicate and eminently suited to winter meals.

Y., Nov. 23 -- The Sudan has emerged as the free world's leading supplier of high quality, long staple cotton since Egypt a few years ago took itself out of the picture through a deal with the Soviet Union.
