PITTSBURGH, Nov. 23 -- No trend was evident in steel orders and output last week. Most steel officials now believe final figures for this quarter will show a plateau pattern for production. Steel observers generally still look for an average rate of 75 per cent of capacity for the fourth quarter; others believe it may be a point below that level.

The latest United States note to Hungary has stated well the key issues in relations between the two countries. The abnormalities now existing in those relations arise from the fact that the Kadar regime was established by and continues to exist because of the power of Soviet tanks, a situation which has been condemned by world public opinion at the United Nations and elsewhere.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 23 (AP) -- John Unitas was back in the saddle today for the Baltimore Colts. The first pass he threw went for a 58-yard touchdown and the Colts rode high, wide and handsome to a 34-7 rout of the Los Angeles Rams.
The Wilson Line's former Liberty Belle, an excursion craft familiar in local waters for almost a decade, will head south next month with a new Spanish name and flying the Cuban flag.

A special committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York recommended new Federal legislation yesterday to continue -- but also to clarify and minimize -- restraints on the issuing of passports to American citizens.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today that no result of the national election had been "more tragic" than the defeat of Representative Brooks Hays, Democrat of Arkansas.

An issue of $7,358,000 in bonds of Impa County, Ariz., School District 1 will be offered for sale on Dec. 15. The bonds will be dated Jan. 1, 1959 and will come due serially on Jan. 1 from 1960 to 1979.

PARIS, Monday, Nov. 24 -- France appeared early this morning to have voted to follow Premier Charles de Gaulle on a middle-of-the-road political course in an inconclusive first round of legislative elections yesterday.
BERLIN, Nov. 23 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey said here today that the Administration's determination to defend Berlin's freedom had the whole-hearted support of the Democratic party.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 23 (AP) -- A 25-foot putt from the fringe of the green on the third extra hole gave Angel Miguel of Spain a play-off victory over Ireland's Harry Bradshaw for the International Trophy today.

AS far as Gimbels is concerned, customers can spend the holidays in a round of parties, home by the radiator, skiing down a slope or sunning in the sand. This store's collection of midwinter fashions assures a well-dressed Yule for all.
WHAT are the symptoms in a child that justify (and compel) a consultation with a physician?

ROME, Nov. 23 -- It is fair to inquire whether the United States is trying to cut its own throat in Italy. For some weeks this country has been developing a new foreign-policy line tending toward neutralism and a loosening of its bonds with NATO.
ACCRA, Nov. 23 (Reuters) -- In their joint statement on the federation, Dr. Nkrumah and M. Toure said:

The Police Department's traffic detail will be reinforced for the Thanksgiving holiday from 4 P. M. Wednesday to midnight next Monday. Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy announced yesterday that the regular radio patrol cars would be augmented by unmarked cars and helicopters.
CHICAGO, Nov. 23 (AP) -- One broad general setback in the grain futures market last week virtually unraveled the bullish trend of the first three days and left prices little changed from a week ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UPI) -- Justice Department officials said today that the department "most probably" would offer definite recommendations to a Federal judge on how to reopen four high schools in Little Rock, Ark. The schools were closed by Gov. Orval E. Faubus to block integration.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission closed the door today on its guarantee to buy all the usable uranium miners can produce.

DETROIT, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Zeke Bratkowski hit Bill McColl with a pair of third-period scoring passes that led the Chicago Bears to a 20-7 triumph over the Detroit Lions today before a Briggs Stadium throng of 55,280.
One hundred fifteen students from twenty-five countries were taken into the homes of Negro families yesterday for a taste of American cooking and an exchange of ideas.
Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts criticized United States policy last night as failing at times to recognize "the moral principles of self-determination" for colonial peoples.

Ozone Park, Queens, residents who have been racing to catch the 8:41 to Pennsylvania Station each weekday will have to rise early this morning if they insist on riding the Long Island Rail Road. Only the 7:49 will be running.
BONN, Monday, Nov. 24 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Christian Democratic party swept back into power in Bavaria yesterday, polling close to an absolute majority in state parliamentary elections.
A cessation of grain activity hit the steamship charter market last week. As a result, there was a sharp drop in the over-all volume of business.

A costume ball, called the "Roaring 20's Gala," will be held Saturday in the Stork Club. Proceeds will go to the Guideposts for Children, Inc., 545 Fifth Avenue, a nonsectarian organization that gives psycho-therapeutic treatment to retarded children of pre-school age.

An international aviation figure predicts that as soon as Russian industry can build the kind of jet airliner now being produced in the West, Soviet aircraft will become a familiar sight at the major airports of all continents.
After an absence of two seasons, Puccini's "Manon Lescaut" will return to the Metropolitan Opera on Wednesday, Dec. 3, with Renata Tebaldi singing the title role for the first time here.

It is appropriate that the Thanksgiving season should be the time for appeals of the three great religious faiths -- Protestant, Catholic and Jewish -- for funds and materials with which to carry on world-wide programs of assistance to hungry, homeless and destitute people abroad. These relief programs actually account for more than 80 per cent of this country's voluntary overseas relief efforts and are operated at the lowest possible cost.

MANY shops here are ready this week to provide prepared dishes for the Thanksgiving dinner. Some will go so far as to furnish practically the whole meal. Others offer only the extras such as the traditional mince and pumpkin pies or, more unusual, ice creams molded into turkey or pumpkin forms.
A study of the relationship between stomach cancer and the amount of stomach acidity was announced yesterday by the city Health Department.

The Regional Plan Association announced yesterday that it would have a final report by Jan. 13 on governmental changes needed to deal with metropolitan problems in the New York-New Jersey-Connecticut area.

Plans have been announced for the construction of two atom smashers, both designed to produce a greater flow of accelerated subatomic particles than similar machines now being used to probe atomic nuclei.

An epidemic of strikes threatened last night to ground more than half of the country's airliners by midnight tomorrow. With Trans World Airlines and West Coast Airlines already strikebound, unionized stewardesses threw picket lines around offices of Lake Central Airlines at Indianapolis, Chicago and Columbus, Ohio, at midnight last night.
A drive for the removal of Albert M. Cole as Federal Housing Administrator was opened yesterday by the National Committee Against Discrimination in Housing.
BERLIN, Nov. 23 -- Crisis in Berlin? Not that the visitor could notice, unless he read the newspapers.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 (UPI) -- Bobby Layne fired a 78-yard touchdown toss to Jimmy Orr with less than six minutes to play today. It gave the Pittsburgh Steelers a 27 -- 20 victory over the Chicago Cardinals.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Nov. 23 -- George Hinman gained the honors today as the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club resumed its frostbite competition.

The grand staircase in the new Metropolitan Opera House at the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts will be a memorial to Robert Walton Goelet, millionaire sportsman of New York and Newport who died in May, 1941.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- The Commonwealth Relations Office said tonight it was too early to assess the full meaning of the declaration by Ghana and Guinea that they intended to "constitute our two states as the nucleus of a union of West African states."

PARIS, Monday, Nov. 24 -- The French political world was stunned today by the defeat of Pierre Mendes-France in the legislative elections yesterday. The former Premier has been the most prominent leader of the non-Communist Left.

TUSCARORA INDIAN RESERVE, N. Y., Nov. 20 -- In this flat, sparsely wooded land of clucking chickens and roaring bulldozers sharp Indian eyes study legal briefs and newspaper clippings instead of smoke signals.
HONG KONG, Nov. 23 -- Trade between Communist China and North Korea has increased ten-fold in the last five years, Premier Kim Il Sung said in Peiping today.
Cotton prices in the domestic market continued to work lower, for the most part, last week.
Fred Thomas, bass-baritone, who was a 1951 winner of the Metropolitan Opera Auditions of the Air, sang his third recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Two law professors, Gerald Gunther of Columbia University and George Lee Haskins of the University of Pennsylvania, were were appointed today to the group assigned under a bequest of Associate Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes to write a definitive history of the Supreme Court.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Trainer George W. Bishop will begin a ten-day suspension tomorrow as a result of his outburst against two Pimlico officials.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Manufacturers are lining up new business at a rate that promises continued expansion of industrial activity, the Department of Commerce said today.

A committee representing the Protestant Council will meet Wednesday with the chairman of the Mayor's Special Committee to Study Off-Track Betting to document the council's opposition to legalized gambling.
The New York State Teachers Association, representing 73,000 members, will open its annual meeting today at the Commodore Hotel.
THE only man who can criticize a woman's appearance without risking her wrath is her hairdresser.
Communist China plants to displace Japan next year as Asia's leading industrial power, according to the chairman of the Japanese Communist party.

The Giants of yesterday at the Stadium were not the Giants who had performed so magnificently against the Cleveland Browns and the Baltimore Colts. Nor were they the Giants who had flopped so miserably against the Pittsburgh Steelers.

THE one-hundredth anniversary of the birth of John L. Sullivan slipped past unnoticed recently and that was rather cavalier treatment to the mighty John L., America's first genuine sports hero. A tempestuous swashbuckler of unbelievable color and electrifying magnetism, the Boston Strong Boy was regarded with an esteem that bordered on idolatry.

Dan River Mills, Inc., one of the country's largest manufacturers of textiles, has leased two floors in the new office building at 111 West Fortieth /Street. The Durand Taylor Company, agent for the build-i ing, arranged the lease of the 50,000 square feet.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The United States, Britain and France this week-end debated what to do to meet a series of possible Soviet threats to the Western position in Berlin.

Dr. Ernest A. Gross declared yesterday that delegates to a Protestant conference on world order last week, in backing recognition of Communist China, had in no way implied that they represented the unanimous sentiment of Protestant leaders in the United States.

DETROIT, Nov. 23 -- The auto companies have reported rising car sales. It is generally agreed, however, that a sound assessment of the 1959 market may not be possible for a month or more. Meanwhile, with major labor difficulties resolved, the industry last week reached the highest production rate this year.

Four new volumes in the Civil War Centennial Series will be published by Indiana University Press in the early part of next year. A new edition of "The Memoirs of Col. John S. Mosby" will be issued Jan. 19. It has been edited by Charles Wells Russell and has an introduction by Virgil Carrington Jones.

A portable platform for underwater drilling operations is being pushed by a tug down the Mississippi River to New Orleans for the first stop-over in its 10,000-mile voyage to the Persian Gulf. The "portable island" was built for the Italian Government by R. G. LeTourneau, Inc., at the company's marine facilities on the bank of the Mississippi River near Vicksburg, Miss.
The observations of Adlai E. Stevenson's trip to the Soviet Russia are most interesting and give us additional information on the life in Siberia. However, I wonder if I can make a correction?
ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 23 -- program calling for the expenditure of $5,000,000 in the next five years on religious zionist projects in this country and Israel was outlined here today.

A strong market with active dealings in the Canadian dollar marked the trading in foreign exchanges during the past week. British pound sterling after maintaining a steady undertone for some time sold off in the latter part of the business sessions.
Four of the nation's leading space scientists -- including Dr. Wernher von Braun -- sounded a warning yesterday against attempts to send a man into space soon.

THE National Symphony Orchestra of Mexico plays the music of its own country with energy and gusto. Under the leadership of Luis Herrera de la Fuente, its music director, it plunges into its native rhythms with exhilarating incisiveness.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Y. A. Tittle threw three touchdown passes, two of them in a 21-point fourth-quarter spree that broke a 12-12 tie, to pace the San Francisco Forty-Niners to a 33-12 conquest of the Green Bay Packers today. The National Football League game ended amid a flurry of fist fights.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- In the face of a stern White House demand for economizing, the Navy will make a final bid tomorrow or Tuesday for a second nuclear powered aircraft carrier.

DETROIT, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Agreement on a new three-year master contract was reached today by the Bendix Aviation Corporation and the United Automobile Workers. The agreement ended a strike that started Tuesday.
The nighttime version of 'Concentration," a television program that replaced "Twenty- One" on Oct. 30, has been canceled after a four-week run.
SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Alex Olmedo of the United States Davis Cup squad, entered the quarter-finals of the New South Wales tennis championships today.

GABES, Tunisia, Nov. 23 -- President Habib Bourguiba said today that several officers of the United Arab Republic had been arrested in Tunisia. He said they would face trial for trying to stir up a plot to overthrow his regime.

THIS season a corner of Bloomingdale's second floor is devoted to imported gifts for children. From England there are bone china mugs with illustrations from Alice in Wonderland, $1.79 each. From France come-hand-painted wooden savings banks in the shape of peasant women in native costumes, $1.98 each.
ZURICH, Switzerland, Nov. 23 -- The slump in the prices of nearly all German stocks was so violent on Thursday that stock exchange business in Zurich was completely deranged.
Others in addition to parimutuel clerks may be called by the New York State Commission of Investigation in its inquiry into the state's race tracks.

AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 23 (AP) -- Van Cliburn charmed three large audiences here today in his second formal appearance in his native Texas since winning the Tchaikovsky piano competition in the Soviet Union last spring.

A call for "sun men, not moon men" was voiced by Dr. Robert P. Daniel, president of Virginia State College, in a sermon yesterday. He was guest preacher at the annual Men's Day morning service at the Concord Baptist Church, 833 Marcy Avenue, Brooklyn.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 23 (AP) -- Pete Cooper sank a 7-foot putt for a birdie on the first extra hole of a sudden-death play-off today to win the $15,000 West Palm Beach open golf tournament. Wes Ellis Jr., the other golfer in the play-off, took a par 5 on the extra hole.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- The use of electronic computers in law and medical offices is among twenty subjects listed for discussion at a four-day international symposium here on the mechanization of thought processes. The meetings will begin tomorrow.

Watchful preparation for death and God's judgment afterward was urged yesterday by Msgr. Harry J. Wolff. He preached at the 10 A. M. solemn mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral. Cardinal Spellman presided.

The New York City Housing Authority is planning the sale of $32,698,000 of temporary loan notes on Dec. 9 for the financing of Wagner Houses, a federally aided development recently finished in Manhattan. The notes will be dated Jan. 6, 1959, and will come due on April 10, 1959.

IT'S been apparent for the longest while that the American League pennant race consists of seven teams on a treadmill and the Yankees. The sleepy seven go through the motions, but get nowhere. The contenders are afraid to trade with each other, fearful the other guy may. get the extra little something that would make him a strong challenger. So none makes progress.

The New York Knickerbockers, the hottest club in the National Basketball Association, will encounter the Cincinnati Royals, the coldest, in the second game of a doubleheader at Madison Square Garden tonight. This contest will be preceded by a 7 o'clock preliminary between the St. Louis Hawks and the Philadelphia Warriors.

An agricultural experiment that has been in operation for a quarter of a century may come to an end this year, depending upon the outcome of a referendum being conducted today among the corn growers of the nation.
There is no doubt the nation's schools can do the job expected of them in the space age, Dr. James E. Allen Jr., State Education Commissioner, said last night.

The explosion of strikes and strike threats by unions on the nation's airlines has raised a single national issue that transcends the many complex issues being fought about in the various separate disputes. It is the effectiveness of the National Railway Labor Act, which applies also to the airlines.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Ian Harvey, 44-year-old Conservative member of Parliament and Parliamentary Under Secretary for Foreign Affairs, who was arrested on a morals charge Wednesday night, resigned both posts today.
Employes of concerns at 477 and 488 Madison Avenue will give blood in the two buildings to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program today.
A press conference in London in which Vice President Richard M. Nixon will be questioned by British reporters will be televised here by film recording on Sunday from 3 to 3:30 P. M.
Victor Zalazar, a former brewery worker from Buenos Aires, added to his remarkable record as a professional fighter last night at the St. Nicholas Arena.

Secrecy surrounded certain activities in the offices of the New York Giants yesterday. Although the team still is in the running for the Eastern Conference crown in the National Football League, the Giants' powers-that-be were not thinking of this year. They had next year on their minds.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Supreme Court affirmed today a lower court ruling that Alabama's school placement law was not unconstitutional on its face.

Imperial Oil Ltd. of Canada followed a well-trod path of trial and error before putting into operation its new $28,500,000 petrochemical plant at Sarnia, Ont. Scientists made more than 3,000 laboratory tests to find ways of using western Canadian crude oil.

Jacob Grumet, chairman of the State Commission of Investigation, said yesterday that Benton E. Rader, who is in charge of the pari-mutuel tax section of the State Tax Commission, "may be called in the near future."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review a New York State ban on the showing of the motion picture, "Lady Chatterley's Lover."
Robert College and the American College for Girls, both of Istanbul, Turkey, formally joined forces yesterday at a meeting of their boards of directors here.
The chairman of the board of the Ford Motor Company, Ernest R. Breech, took issue last night with those who advocate the "arsenal" system for missile development.

PARIS, Nov. 24 -- The major question raised by the first round of balloting yesterday in the French legislative elections is whether the strongest "national" party, the new Gaullist Union for the New Republic, will step off on its right or its left foot.

Louis A. Green, a New York stock broker and major shareholder in Loew's Inc., filed preliminary papers with the Securities and Exchange Commission and the New York Stock Exchange yesterday afternoon as a participant in a proxy fight against the movie concern.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- By a vote of 5 to 3 the Supreme Court held today that Congress could constitutionally put new restrictions on Government-aided housing already in use.
ROME, Nov. 24 -- Italy's highest tribunal upheld today the right of all religious communities to open and operate houses of worship without police authorization.

I agree with Marcus S. Friedlander's letter, published in The Times of Nov. 9, that the vote throughout the country (in Wisconsin as in other states) was in part, at least, "a vote of censure of Mr. Eisenhower's policies and the quality of his leadership," not to mention a thumping repudiation of the so-called Old Guard.
HOBBS, N. M., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Astick of dynamite thrown through a window or skylight shattered a classroom last night at the Heizer Junion High School here. The damage was estimated at $2,000.
Dr. James E. Allen Jr., the State Education Commissioner, accepted an invitation last night by the City's Board of Education to investigate charges of waste in the school-building program.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 24 (UPI) -- Red Schoendienst issued his first statement today since he was struck down by tuberculosis. He called for support of the fifty-second annual sale of Christmas seals to support the Tuberculosis Society.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- Foreign Minister Evangelos Averoff-Tositsas of Greece said today that the violence in Cyprus would stop immediately if the United Nations recognized that the island had a right to eventual independence.
CAIRO, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Venezuela will join ten Arab states in the first Arab petroleum conference opening in Cairo April 16, the Middle East News Agency reported today.

PAUL MONASH, the author of "Guy in Ward 4" on "Goodyear Theatre" over Channel 4 last night, set forth a series of circumstances that might have resulted in an interesting drama. The effect of this filmed telecast was spoiled, however, by a facile and unsatisfactory conclusion.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- Following is the roll-call vote in the Political Committee today on the naming of the members of the eighteen-nation Committee on Outer Space:
The trial closing of the roadway in Washington Square Park has been an "unqualified success," in the opinion of Greenwich Village civic leaders.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon called today for a firm alliance of Britain and the United States as he took off for London on a ceremonial mission for President Eisen hower.
BUFFALO, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The State Conference of Mayors agreed today to oppose any proposals for replacing local with district courts.

MICHAEL HENAGHAN PRENDERGAST has been a salesman of household appliances, typist, purchasing agent, reporter, policeman, probation officer, soldier and social worker, in that order, since he was graduated from high school.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

The smorgasbord spread on a desk in the offices of the International Boxing Club ebbed away steadily yesterday, but Mike De John did not contribute to the erosion. The 27-year-old heavyweight from Syracuse sat in a corner, spoke when spoken to and never munched once.

The New York City Ballet will open a ten-week season tonight at the City Center, the second series of performances in celebration of its tenth anniversary. The program will consist of four ballets by George Balanchine, artistic director of the organization.
The Berlin crisis was still simmering over the fires of political controversy yesterday, but the possibilities of military action were under study in all the countries concerned.

Nat Holman, who started coaching City College basketball teams in 1919, is back at the old stand after an eighteen-month sabbatical. He's trying to impart some know-how to a squad that has more potential than experience.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 24 -- The United States Embassy has informed Indonesia that Washington is prepared to consider additional military and economic aid to this neutralist nation, sources here said today.
Grant Advertising Inc., has shuffled the top management of its office here.

In your issue of Nov. 20, in George Dugan's dispatch from Cleveland, Thomas K. Finletter is reported to have said' "We had better stop talking about disarmament and, indeed, about peace unless we are willing to abandon the attitude that the recognition of Red China is something which we will never accept under any conditions."
ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 24 -- The Liberty party voted to dissolve today in a move to strengthen the Opposition to Premier Adnan Menderes' Democratic party Government.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 24 (UPI) -- Ham Richardson and Alex Olmedo, a possible United States Davis Cup doubles team, gained, the semi-finals of the New South Wales tennis championships today by defeating Roy Emerson and Bob Mark of Australia, 4 -- 6, 13 -- 11, 10 -- 8, 7 -- 5.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI) -- The Federation of American Scientists said today the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union had enough nuclear bombs to kill every person in the world.
The Sinclair Oil Corporation, owner of about 29 per cent of the Texas Pacific Coal and Oil Company, moved to obtain full ownership yesterday.

YONKERS, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Chauncey Hanover, a 5-year-old gelding, moved to the front early and held off the closing strides of Cotton Prince to win the feature Class A Pace by a length at Yonkers Raceway tonight. The time for the mile was 2:04 3/5.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- The Labor party started today the most elaborate campaign in its history to acquaint British voters with its policies and to win their support.
ALBANY, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Governor Harriman made three appointments today to boards of technical institutes in the state. They were:
Values of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined $6,750,000,000 yesterday, for the widest loss since Sept. 26, 1955, the trading day following President Eisenhower's heart attack.

A book fair in the library of Trinity School at 139, West Ninety-first Street will be the first in a series of fund-raising activities in observance of the 250th anniversary of the founding of the school. It will open on Monday and continue through Friday.

A special committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, acting under a grant from the Fund for the Republic, has just concluded a reasoned study of the passport question; and we commend its sane and sensible report to the attention of both the Eisenhower Administration and the Eighty-sixth Congress.
New records were made by Federated Department Stores, Inc. for sales and earnings in the quarter and nine months ended on Nov. 1, Fred Lazarus Jr., chairman, disclosed yesterday.

The Roman Catholic Bishops have affirmed their right "to teach those moral principles which flow from the natural law and the positive law of God, and which are binding upon all men." This right to teach whatever the church deems to be the moral law is not today seriously contested.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 1 to 18 points (5 to 90 cents a bale) yesterday in quiet trading.

Agreement on new wage scales affecting 17,000 downstate telephone operators and workers in other traffic departments was announced yesterday by the New York Telephone Company and the Telephone Traffic Union.

DETROIT, Nov. 24 -- The American Motors Corporation, maker of Rambler cars, enjoying its most successful year, reported a net profit today of $26,085,134 for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, 1958. The company said this was equal to $4.65 a share.
Leaders of 2,000,000 United States transport workers, undaunted by the prospects of a Federal injunction, went ahead yesterday with plans to boycott 4,200,000 tons of American- owned ships next week.
WESTPORT, Conn., Nov. 24 -- The Westport police have solved a case of lion stealing and have tracked the culprits to their lair -- the University of Connecticut, ninety miles away.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- Disregarding a Soviet threat of a boycott, the General Assembly's Political Committee endorsed tonight the establishment of an eighteen-nation Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space.
Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey last night deplored rising college tuition costs. He said they deprived many high school students of an opportunity for continuing their education.
ACCRA, Ghana, Nov. 24 -- M. Toure said today he hoped the future would bring speedy rehabilitation of the African people.
At luncheon the other day the talk for a time was desultory. It drifted along over such casual subjects as the autumn leaves and the Golden Gate Bridge, both beautiful this year.
The facts in labor disputes involving four airlines are as follows:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Food and Drug Administration today listed 188 chemical additives "generally recognized as safe for their intended use" and thus exempt from testing under the new food additives amendment to the Food and Drug Law.

Net profits of Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd. for the fiscal year ended on Aug. 31 were $21,845,494, equal to $2.54 a share. This compared with $22,478,161 or $2.61 a share earned in the preceding fiscal year. Sales were $384,028,204 and $396,182,157, respectively.
SEBRING, Fla., Nov. 24 (UPI) -- Sebring race officials said today the Ferrari factory of Italy had asked for three entries in each of the two international races to be run here next March.
Minor mishaps caused brief delays yesterday morning on the three divisions of the city subway system. The longest tie-up lasted ten minutes, the Transit Authority said.

Yonkers Raceway will operate for 105 nights and Roosevelt Raceway for 104 nights in 1959, according to the dates for New York trotting tracks announced yesterday by the State Harness Racing Commission.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 24 -- Cambodia asked Thailand's Foreign Ministry today for "temporary suspension" of diplomatic relations.

TRENTON, Nov. 24 -- Following are summaries of statements presented today at the New Jersey General Assembly hearing on transit by Dr. S. J. Flink of Rutgers, economic adviser to the General Assembly, and by the Port of New York Authority:

The problems, customs and costs encountered in constructing and managing buildings in this city should not be used as the only guide for evaluating out-of-town properties, according to Norman Tishman.

White-collar workers of the Belgian Line in the Port of New York have gained protection against the advances of technology, according to reports yesterday of an agreement reached between the ship line and Local 153 of the Office Employes International Union.

HONG KONG, Nov. 24 -- Past events in China have become almost unrecognizable in a new English-language outline history just issued by Peiping. It is a compilation of distortions, omissions and political diatribe.
The United Nations General Assembly begins today a new debate on Cyprus -- a question on which Greeks, Turks and British are still divided.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- An expert on municipal problems told business leaders today that population growth and increasing urbanization required more Federal aid for urban renewal.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Supreme Court reaffirmed today the ancient rule that wives may not testify against their husbands, even voluntarily.
WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 24 -- Westchester was criticized today for not setting up a long-proposed county sportsmen's center. The protests came by letter, postcard, telegram and petition.
Paul Craig, composer, vocalist, pantomimist, art critic and female impersonator, made his local debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last night in a program of musical satires.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Two brothers, neither of whom had had any medical training, used a kitchen knife and a fountain pen to perform an emergency tracheotomy and save the life of their physician father yesterday.
A Kings County grand jury that has been investigating gambling and other rackets since last March will hear expert testimony from law enforcement officials from "at least two" other cities.
A grand jury took Mayor Wagner on a bus trip yesterday to look at two of Brooklyn's seamier dwellings. The Mayor called the conditions a "shame" and announced another drive against slums here.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Walter Ulbricht, East German First Deputy Premier, said today that the Soviet Union would almost certainly announce its planned withdrawal from East Berlin before the end of this week.
Pending completion of arrangements, Carol Channing and Roddy McDowall e to be starred in a Noel Coward farce, "Look After Lulu." The play had its genesis in Georges Feydeau's "Occupe-toi, d'Amelie."

" The Coming of the New Deal," the second volume of Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr.'s "The Age of Roosevelt," will be published Jan. 5 by Houghton Mifflin. The first part of the book deals with president Roosevelt's first two years in office and the New Deal's efforts to overcome the depression.

MOST men are a worry all year round, but at Christmas time they are especially troublesome. Shop Talk takes on some of the woman's burden by suggesting gifts that should brighten up a man a bit for the holiday season.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 24 -- Gov. J. Lindsay Almond Jr. ordered today that immediate steps be taken for the erection of a second flagpole so that the United States as well as the state flag might be flown from Virginia's capitol.
A bakery worker was arrested in the Bronx yesterday in the murder of a 10-year-old girl who had been beaten severely about the head and raped.
EAST LANSING, Mich. Nov. 24 (UPI) -- Michigan State completed a cross-country grand slam today by winning its seventh national collegiate championship.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Nov. 24 (UPI) -- Harry Einstein, the "Parkyakarkus" comedian of the Eddie Cantor radio show in the Nineteen Thirties, died backstage early today of a heart attack suffered at the speakers table during a banquet.
The American Association for the United Nations adopted yesterday a policy statement urging the State Department to support a United Nations debate on the admission of Communist China.

A plan to lay a special trans-Atlantic cable between Canada and Britain to improve the links in the North Atlantic's air traffic control chain has been put forth by the International Civil Aviation Organization.
The Government yesterday charged the General Electric Company, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and a Netherlands electronics company with violating the Sherman Antitrust Act.

Russia's attempts to speed up development of its electric generating plant, while notable compared with past performances, leave much to be desired according to American standards. This became apparent with yesterday's release by the Edison Electric Institute of a report on the electric power business in Russia.
Eastern Air Lines, the country's biggest air passenger carrier, was grounded by a strike of flight engineers and mechanics yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Budget Bureau announced a plan to give the Labor Department sole responsibility for putting out monthly unemployment figures and other labor force statistics. The Commerce Department will tabulate housing starts and other construction figures.
The welfare fund of the Association of Russian Imperial Naval Officers in America will benefit from a tea dance to be held at the Sheraton-East on Dec. 14.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Navy curtailed production today of the Seamaster, a large jet-powered seaplane that had been expected to usher in a new concept in naval warfare.
The District Attorney's off is concerned over grand jury witnesses in the city's Building Department investigation asking to be excused because ill health.
CHICAGO, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Calvin Griffith, president of the Washington Senators, said today he wanted to reverse a club resolution barring discussion of shifting the American League Team.
PARIS, Nov. 24 -- The French Sudan in West Africa proclaimed itself today an autonomous republic within the framework of the French community.
Steel production edged off slightly last week and was scheduled to remain little changed this week despite the Thanksgiving Day Holiday, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Directors of the Warner-Lambert Pharmaceutical Company yesterday voted an extra year-end dividend of 50 cents on the common stock, payable Dec. 10. This was in addition to the regular quarterly cash dividend of 62 1/2 cents declared Oct. 28 for payment Dec. 10.

" FROM THE TERRACE," by John O'Hara, is a tremendous story about money, love and war. It is Mr. O'Hara's biggest novel in every way. It is also his best. Here he probes more deeply, ranges more widely than ever before into the fears, triumphs and loyalties that set the standards for representative men and wo men of our dynamic century.

ATLANTA, Nov. 24 (UPI) -- Governor-elect, Ernest Vandiver said today Georgia's segregation laws would be made stronger than ever despite a plea by clergymen for obedience to the Supreme Court's integration rulings.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Government's offer to exchange new issues of certificates and notes for $12,201,000,000 of securities maturing next month drew appro ximately $11,666,000,000 exchanges, according to preliminary figures reported by the Treasury today.

A large proportion of turkeys for sale this Thanksgiving are frozen. They may be purchased unstuffed or stuffed. In either form they should be thawed before cooking to insure even roasting throughout.

LONDON, Nov. 24 (Reuters) -- British Communists called today for a protest march to the United State Embassy tomorrow night while the Vice President and Mrs. Nixon dine with Prime Minister Macmillan at 10 Downing Street.
CHRISTMAS shoppers who really like to track down good bargains might reap rewards at the thirty-eighth annual "Ye Olde English Faire" in the grand ballroom of the Biltmore Hotel, today and tomorrow.
JUNEAU, Alaska, Nov. 24 -- Tomorrow is the day that tens of thousands of Alaskans will be telling their grandchildren about.
ESTIMATES are that about 18,000,000 pounds of turkey will be sold here this week.
Louisiana State was far in front yesterday in The Associated Press weekly football poll.
SEYMOUR, Conn., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Sale of controlling interest in Waterman Pen Company, one of the oldest pen makers in this country, to Marcel L. Bich Company of Paris, was announced today.

Your editorial of Nov. 17 on health insurance reveals a surprisingly low cost for additional protection concerning nervous and emotional illness. It will be to our general benefit if this tack is more fully explored.
RABAT, Morocco, Nov. 24 -- King Mohamed V signed a decree today establishing martial rule over the troubled Rif Mountains area as disorders spread eastward to the Algerian border.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Cri de Guierre, a Florida-bred 2-year-old owned and trained by Raymond B. Archer, won the $4,000 Pikeville purse at Pimlico today, outracing Eager Beaver for a neck decision.

TEDDINGTON, England, Nov. 24 -- Researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology are drawing up a program for a computer that, they believe, will "learn" from experience in such a way that it will eventually "think" for itself.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- A nine-member committee was named today by President Eisenhower to make an independent, nonpartisan "critical appraisal" of United States expenditures abroad for military assistance and economic aid.
Dedication ceremonies were held yesterday for the new Gracie Post Office Station at 229-49 East Eighty - fifth Street, between Second and Third Avenues.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 24 -- "The Intruder," a forthcoming novel about current problems and attitudes toward segregation in the South, hast been acquired for filming by Seven Arts Productions. It is a first novel by Charles Beaumont, who lives in North Hollywood.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 24 -- Social Democratic leaders in Hesse and Christian Democratic leaders in Bavaria announced plans today to form new coalition governments to rule the two south German states for four Years more.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Children poured out of four schools this morning as bomb scares spread in the city following an explosion last night.
MOSCOW, Nov. 24 -- A rigid new order of discipline is being imposed on Soviet society as it sets out in pursuit of Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's ambitious seven-year economic goals.
The independent Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union voted last night to strike at midnight Dec. 7 if new contracts with seven New York City publishers had not been negotiated by that time.
NEWARK, Nov. 24 -- The Public Utilities Commission opened a three-day inquiry today into speed and safety control devices on railroad bridges in New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI) -- A Pittsburgh business man denied today he had been the source of bribery rumors in an F. C. C. case.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 24 (AP) -- United States golf fans may get a look at the new International Trophy champion, Angel Miguel of Spain, and Ireland's Canada Cup winners, Harry Bradshaw and Christy O'Connor, next April at the Masters.
Mandatory public education classes for severely retarded children rather than for only the group judged "educable" were urged here yesterday.

A prominent union leader warned local Democrats yesterday that the party would invite political suicide" unless it dissociated itself from City Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa's attack on school construction costs.

THERE is no such thing as a "classic" method of roasting a turkey. It can be cooked in a hot oven or a slow oven. It can be baked in aluminum foil or a brown paper bag. Many Southerners parboil the bird before roasting it.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- A long-standing policy of the National Labor Relations Board of refusing jurisdiction over the entire hotel industry was upset today by the Supreme Court.

The timing seemed perfect. Mighty Brooklyn Tech had opened its 1958 football season by losing to a mediocre Lafayette eleven. Would there be a better opportunity to arrange a game with Adam Cirillo's Tech team ? No, Sir. No, ma'm.

New orders for machine tools, the tools used to make production machinery, turned sharply upward in October to a record high so far this year. Orders remained below the levels of a year before, however.

Even though the first round of votes in the French Elections decided only forty-two seats out of 475 in metropolitan France and the overseas departments for the National Assembly, the results made history. We can see now that when the voting is completed next Sunday a new book, and not just a new chapter, is going to begin.

LONDON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- One of Britain's leading nuclear physicists came home from Moscow today and said Soviet scientists seeking to harness the power of the hydrogen bomb were at about the same stage as development in the West, but were moving faster.

J. Lyman Bingham, the executive director of the United States Olympic Committee yesterday said he was convinced by an official inspection trip to Squaw Valley, Calif., that "there isn't the slightest doubt but that the winter games of 1960 will be held there."

Mrs. Charles R. Barrett and Mrs. David M. Goodstein are chairman and vice chairman, respectively, of the twelfth annual tea dance to be held for the benefit of St. Joseph's Day Nursery on Sunday at the Stork Club.

Arthur M. Loew, former president and board chairman of Loew's, Inc., the company founded by his father, the late Marcus Loew, will return to the movie world with an independent production of "Moth for the Star."
MOSCOW, Nov. 24 -- The Soviet Union has converted one of its submarines into a "scientific laboratory" and will send the vessel on its first prolonged mission next month.

NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 24 -- The twentieth anniversary year of the Norwalk Symphony Orchestra opened tonight with a concert attended by more than 1,000 music lovers. The symphony, one of Fairfield County's most active musical groups, consists of more than seventy players from several age groups and walks of life.
The proportion of the medical dollar being spent for hospital services has more than quadrupled in the last thirty years. The primary reason is the expansion of hospital services.
TACOMA, Wash., Nov. 24 (AP) -- The tax trial of Dave Beck was halted temporarily today by the illness of a woman juror.

MANY deer hunters returning from New England are advertising one reason why some landowners post their property against hunting. Along with the deer tied to the tops of their cars they carry one, two or three small evergreen trees.

Airline reservations switch-boards here were ablaze yesterday as callers sought the latest on the strike picture. Was airline A struck or would it be soon, they asked. What were the chances of going by airline B?
ALGIERS, Nov. 24 -- The failure of M. Mendes-France to win re-election brought sharply conflicting reactions here today.
The city proposed yesterday that the Uniformed Sanitation-men's Association enter immediately into wage negotiations instead of discussing pension plan revisions.

AUGUSTA Ga., Nov. 24 (UPI) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's letter to William H. Draper Jr., chairman of the President's Committee to Study the United States Military Assistance Program:
FORT WORTH, Tex., Nov. 24 (AP) -- A Federal appellate justice said today that Congress should step into the segregation troubles stemming from rulings of the United States Supreme Court.

LEICESTER, England, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Zora Folley, a heavyweight contender from Chandler, Ariz., stopped Joe Bygraves, former British Empire champion, tonight at 2:59 of the ninth round of a scheduled ten-round bout. Folley weighed 191 1/2 pounds, Bygraves 203 3/4.

Dr. Reinhard Kamitz, Finance Minister of Austria, said yesterday that Austria's forthcoming sale of $25,000,000 of bonds here demontrated the progress of his country in building economic relations with the free world. He added that trade with Eastern Europe was sharply lower than it was ten years ago.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Tuscarora Indians fought in the Federal Power Commission today to keep their Western New York reservation intact.
CHICAGO, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Resistance to selling finally gave way late today on the Board of Trade. Corn and soybean futures had losses extending to a cent a bushel or more.
A thirty-five-foot Christmas tree was hoisted to the windswept roof of the forty-eight-story Time and Life Building yesterday to mark the topping out of the structure.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Nov. 24 -- The leaders of the Sudan's armed forces completed today one week of rule as the self-appointed Government of this three-year-old republic of about 10,200,000 Arabs and Africans.
WITH the assistance of Shakespeare, Milton Geiger has pieced together a show entitled "Edwin Booth." It opened last evening at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre with Jose Ferrer in the title role.
ALBANY, Nov. 24 -- The state's Democratic leaders, divided by convention controversy and still smarting from election results, met today for a show of unity and renewed purpose.
THE importance of physical a resemblance between children up for adoption and couples who seek to adopt them has been downgraded by public and private agencies in the state.
DETROIT, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The auto industry's effort to catch up with the demand for 1959 model cars is gaining momentum.
HOLLY, Colo., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Dr. Raymond R. Lanier, scientist, was fatally injured today in a jeep accident while pheasant hunting.

The Southern Pacific Company cleared $6,642,072 last month on gross revenues of $59,750,817. This compared with a net income of $5,989,391 reported in October of last year, when gross was $57,931,502.

A Bronx husband, reportedly resentful of alleged attentions paid to his wife by the building superintendent, was arrested last night in connection with the superintendent's murder.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- Following is the text of a twenty-nation resolution on outer space approved today by the General Assembly's Political Committee (asterisks indicate matter taken from a Soviet draft resolution offered last week):

TRENTON, Nov. 24 -- The future of bills to cope with the metropolitan rail-commuter problem remained uncertain tonight after a day-long public hearing. The session was called by two committees of the State Assembly.

All cocoa futures fell the 1-cent-a-pound limit for a day yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The spot December contract, which has no limit, tumbled 108 points (hundredths of a cent a pound). The volume was 510 lots and there were twenty-three unsatisfied offerings at the close.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Coach Eddie Erdelatz said today his Navy football team would have to play a near-perfect game to beat Army at Philadelphia Saturday.

CONCORD, N. C., Nov. 24 (AP) -- County officers received an anonymous telephone call today saying that a time bomb had been planted in the high school at Mount Pleasant, near here. They rushed to the building, emptied it of its 1,200 students and found a suspicious device in a second floor classroom.
BERLIN, Nov. 24 -- The big news in Berlin today was that there was no important news.

Elliott V. Bell, chairman of the executive committee of the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company, announced his resignation yesterday as a trustee of the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn. He laid his action to the election on Friday of Hugh G. Johnson, son of the chairman, as one of the bank's trustees.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Studebaker-Packard automobile plant was shut down today by a strike of 7,000 members of the United Automobile Workers' Union, Negotiation talks were broken off.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Secretary of State Dulles returned to Washington today as the Western Allies groped for a plan to deal with the expected Soviet move against their positions in West Berlin.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court left standing today by a 4-4 tie vote dismissal of a $15,000,000 antitrust damage suit against Loew's and R. K. O. motion picture theatre companies.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The United States has decided to support proposals to eliminate some of the restrictions on West Germany's military forces and its military manufactures.

THE Dorian Chorale, a small professional chorus of eleven women and eleven men, made a successful debut last night at Town Hall. It was led by Harold Aks, who has already won a reputation here as the director of the Interracial Fellowship Chorus, a large amateur group.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 24 -- Virginia's Chief Justice indicated today that if his court voided a state constitutional requirement for free public schools the ruling could not be contested by a Federal Court.
Governor-elect Nelson A. Rockefeller listed recruitment of "top-flight" personnel for his administration yesterday as his most urgent immediate problem.
ROD SERLING is one of the pioneer television writers who still stays in the medium even though he is as articulate as video's expatriates about TV's limitations.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 24 -- Termination of an appeal for public financial support to return the television program "Matinee Theatre" to the air was announced today.
Five-year-old Lloyd Bradley was given a 20 per cent chance to live last night after a team of surgeons performed major heart surgery at the United States Naval Hospital, St. Albans, Queens.
Qualities other than those usually expected at an art exhibition stand out at a one-man show opening to the public today at the Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation.

The proposal to set up some sort of confederated union between Ghana and Guinea, on the west coast of Africa, raises some interesting questions and holds out some provocative possibilities. Basically, the idea is sensible. Practically, it will not be an experiment that can be easily and swiftly carried out. Time and goodwill are required.
ALBANY, Nov. 24 -- The Republican State Committee borrowed $800,000 from banks to finance the campaign that elected Nelson A. Rockefeller as Governor.

The five-story building at 104-06 West Fortieth Street has been purchased by Arnold T. Milton and Alan Rabinowitz as the successful bidders at a recent auction of the property. The building, on a plot 50 by 100 feet, is between the Avenue of the Americas and Broadway. Nicholas A. Rosse was the auctioneer. Joseph T. P. Sullivan was the referee.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 24 -- All six states of the European Economic Community were said today to have shown a willingness to work out temporary measures to "soften the blow" that the formation of their common market would have on non-participating states.

A realignment of executive responsibilities has been announced by the American Brake Shoe Company. The company said the changes would allow Kempton Dunn, president, to devote more time to long-range expansion and diversification programs.

After an hour and twenty-minute hearing, the State Racing Commission reserved decision yesterday on possible revocation of the licenses of Dominic J. Falcone and Edward D'Andrea, the former owner-trainer and assistant trainer, respectively, of the horse Tally-Ho.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Most share groups lost ground on the stock exchange here today, but the losses were small.
GENEVA, Nov. 24 -- The United States outlined today methods for guarding against a surprise attack by long-range bombers.
DECORATING is hard work, according to the decorators of tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- A $563,000 loan to Albany Hospital to help finance construction of a dormitory for nurses was announced today by the Community Fscilities Administration.
Round Table, who during the year set a world record by skyrocketing his earnings to $1,336,364, yesterday was named "horse of the year" by The Morning Telegraph and Daily Racing Form.

ROME, Nov. 25 -- That secret society of East Africa's Kikuyu tribe, the Mau Mau, was renowned during its heyday for sudden, swift assaults with a bush-whacking cleaver called the panga. Much quiet knife work is being done here today by Italy's Mau Maus, a clique, within the ruling Christian Democratic party so-called because its leaders' names begin with the letter M.

RABAT, Morocco, Nov. 25 -The Government crisis here became more acute tonight as King Mohamed V called the leader of Moroccan nationalism for consultation. Allal el-Fassi, 50-year-old chief of the Independence party, is expected to be asked to form a new government.

DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 25 -Charles F. Kettering, the engineering genius whose mechanical gifts to the world included the automobile self-starter, died today in his home here at the age of 82. He had suffered a slight stroke Sunday and had gone into a coma earlier today after a second stroke.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 2 to 10 points (10 to 50 cents a bale) yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 25 -- The British Cabinet discussed today the proposed federation of Ghana and Guinea.

A probation officer who is also a Republican district leader was described yesterday as "an uncooperative witness" before the New York county grand jury investigating graft in the Building Department. As a result, questioning was deferred.

Six small buildings at 193-97 Lexington Avenue and 136-40 East Thirty-second Street, the southeast corner, were sold by the 195 Lexington Avenue Realty Corporation to a builder who will improve the 56-by-95 foot plot with a new apartment house.

VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Nov. 25 -- The nation's third major rocket base -- an amplified West Coast counterpart of Florida's Cape Canaveral -- will begin operation here early in December, Pentagon officials announced here tonight.
Efforts to discredit teaching as a profession were deplored yesterday by Prof. Margaret Lindsey of Teachers College, Columbia University.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 25 -- Harvard University announced today plans for two buildings each twelve stories high. They will house 280 students of Harvard College starting in the fall of 1960.
The Carnegie Corporation of New York announced grants of nearly $3,000,000 yesterday, including $500,000 to the proposed Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts in New York City.
LONDON, Nov. 25 -- Stock market-prices fell sharply here today following Wall Street's setback Monday.
ROME, Nov. 25 -- A twentyfour-hour nation-wide strike began tonight on the governmentowned railroads.

Shearson, Hammill Co., stock broker and underwriter, has announced the appointment of Robert C. Van Tuyl as managing partner. Mr. Van Tuyl, 44, will be the chief administrative officer. He succeeds Murray D. Safanie, who will continue as directing partner and chairman of the policy committee.

Leftovers for Wrapping As usual, the morning mail did not invite a too thorough scrutiny. There were a number of Christmas catalogues, apparently sent by firms remaining unaware the Yule season now begins in early June.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- A per capita income of $480 a year by 1980 was proposed by Brazil today as "the minimum goal of Latin-American development."

Leonard Bernstein said yesterday that in the future "I will not conduct any other orchestra in the world while I am music director of the New York Philharmonic." He returned Friday from conducting the Lamoureux and French National Orchestras of Paris and La Scala in Milan.
PARIS, Nov. 25 -- France's Gaullists indicated today that they would try in next Sunday's run-off election to elect even those candidates who finished second or third in the first round.
On Dec. 10 it will be ten years since the adoption by the United Nations of its Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

JUNEAU, Alaska, Nov. 25--Democratic nominees for the five top-echelon posts in the forty-ninth state led their Republican rivals tonight in early returns from Alaska's first state election.

Two of the National Hockey League's top right wings, Andy Bathgate and Maurice Richard, will be shooting for records tonight when the New York Rangers meet the Montreal Canadiens at Madison Square Garden.

The New York Knickerbockers dropped a 115-113 decision to the Cincinnati Royals in a National Basketball Association contest at Madison Square Garden last night.
PARIS, Nov. 25 -- Senegal, in French West Africa, decided today to enter the French Overseas Community as an autonomous republic.

Two parts scotch and one part bourbon have moved to the D'Arcy Advertising Company, giving it a lift in billing estimated at $750,000 a year.

Daniel Ericourt, the French- born pianist who has been giving concerts in America for some thirty years, gave a recital last night in Town Hall and devoted his program to a pair of French composers.

Three Brooklyn teen-agers received sentences of twenty years to life yesterday for the fatal beating of a 58-year-old house painter last Dec. 1.

The time is at hand when the Board of Estimate must at last decide whether or not the city will restore the crumbling Soldiers and Sailors Monument on Riverside Drive at Eighty-ninth Street. The capital budget for 1959 prepared by the City Planning Commission includes $92,600 for planning this restoration, and the estimated final cost of the rehabilitation job is $1,325,750.

The Dunlevy Milbank Children's Center was dedicated in Harlem yesterday with a three- President salute. Former President Herbert Hoover delivered his in person, and President Eisenhower and former President Harry S. Truman sent messages.
Directors of the Ideal Cement Company proposed a three-for-one split of the common stock yesterday. There are more than 1,500,000 shares outstanding.

QUITE a few groups of physicians, bankers and merchant princes in town get together once a week or so for private chamber music sessions. One of the oldest meets in the home of Dr. John Arnold, a physician at 270 West End Avenue.

The Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday that traffic fatalities and accidents in the city declined last week. Six persons were killed and 919 injured as compared with thirteen killed and 923 injured in the same period in 1957.

Louis A. Lotito has been elected president of the Council of the Living Theatre Foundation. The group, which is an agency to promote theatregoing in the United States and Canada, has been designated as the public-relations division of the League of New York Theatres.

Blyth Co, Inc, and associates are offering today $30,000,000 of Northern Natural Gas Company 4 5/8 per cent sinking fund debentures, due in 1978, at 100.32 to yield 4.60 per cent to maturity.

NOW that the deer hunting season is on, the sportsman is free to go after his own supply of venison. Success depends, of course, on how good a shot he is. For the lazy, the acquisition of game is much easier. All that is required is a visit to one of the several stores here that specialize in venison, game birds and bear or buffalo meat.
The Board of Education, which has been beset by troubles in recent weeks, announced yesterday that it had hired a public relations director at $16,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UPI) -- The Federal Communications Commission authorized Western Union and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company today to increase teleprinter service charges by about $13,400,000 a year, effective Dec. 2.

ALBANY, Nov. 25 -- Forty- five complaints of discrimination in employment because of age have been received by the State Commission against Discrimination in the first four months of the new law barring such discrimination.

Mike Sorrentino guided Mrs. Janon Fisher Jr.'s Lovedrop to a length victory over Robert Streuber's Fusilade in the feature race at Jamaica yesterday. The outcome was not too surprising, inasmuch as Lovedrop was the 7-5 favorite among the 17,131 fans.

PARIS, Nov. 25 -- Premier de Gaulle and Chancellor Adenauer will seek greater unity of their countries in their talks beginning tomorrow. They are seeking this unity before further talks are held with Britain.
