New York University has announced the appointment of Dr. Thomas P. Robinson as dean of the College of Arts and Science on the Bronx campus.

The Very Rev. Brother Urban was formally installed yesterday as president of St. Francis College at a convocation in the Brooklyn ,'Academy of Music, The eveht also marked the Centennial of the Franciscan Brothers as a teaching community in Brooklyn and LongI Island.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- Valerian A. Zorin declared today that the Soviet Union would boycott any meetings of a United Nations Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space such as that endorsed last night by the General Assemly's Political Committee.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25--The United States is planning to launch space probes at the rate of eight to twelve a year starting in 1959.
McMURDO SOUND, Antarctica, Wednesday, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Rear Admiral George J. Dufek, commander of the United States Navy's Antarctic operation, today completed his mission at the bottom of the world.

A trailer truck roared out of control down a main street in Tompkinsville, S. I., yesterday, setting off a chain of havoc in which thirteen persons were injured. One woman was critically hurt when she was tossed through a store window.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -Dr. Paul E. Klopsteg, former associate director of the National Science Foundation, was named today as chairman of the National Academy of Sciences Committee on Atmospheric Sciences.
The long-awaited "realistic" attitude of the Sports Car Club of America toward professional racing and sensible amateurism finally has crystallized.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday the organization of eleven slum inspection teams and a program of tenant education in the city's latest "massive new attack on slums."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Representative Oren Harris, Democrat of Arkansas and chairman of the House Commerce Committee, today forecast strong opposition in Congress to any cut in Federal aid for construction of airport terminals.
The world merchant marine, which tripled in the last four decades, continues to grow and has reached a new record size.
Harold S. Miner doubts that he will ever see an automobile lovely as a tree. But Mr. Miner is becoming a bit discouraged about the durability of trees in the age of the automobile.
Joe Lapchick has been coaching long enough to know that it is foolhardy to praise too much. He was both pleased and displeased as he discussed his St. John's University basketball team yesterday.
An unemployed Bronx man killed his wife yesterday after she had insisted she was still too ill to take back their six children from an institution and care for them, the police said.
" WHAT would you like to be when you grow up?" the American teacher asked. That is a stock question in the United States, where a 13-year-old boy might answer anything from "President" to "cowboy."
Consolidated Edison Company is planning a $60,000,000 offering of convertible debentures to common stockholders late in January, Charles B. Delafield, vice president-finance, said yesterday.

YONKERS, Nov. 25 -- Three of the nation's finest pacers -- Belle Acton, Speedy Pick and Gold Worthy -- will be put to a mile-and-a-sixteenth test at Yonkers Raceway on Friday night in the $50,000 Eastern Championship Pace.

WILD turkey, associated with earlier Thanksgivings, is hard to come by these days. Hunters will provide them for a few lucky families. Here in New York, wild turkeys can be purchased at the Maryland Market, 412 Amsterdam Avenue.

Plans are being completed for a theatre party at the Dec. 16 performance of "Flower Drum Song" at the St. James Theatre for the benefit of St. Barnabas House of the Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society.
ELMER RICE, the old pro, has written one of his most interesting plays in "Cue for Passion," which was acted at Henry Miller's last evening.
David Sackson, violinist, and Joseph Wolman, pianist, appeared at Carnegie Recital Hall last night in the first of three sonata recitals they are to perform there.

Stockholder of the Flintkote Company, building products manufacturers, at a special meeting in Boston yesterday approved the merger of the Hankins Container Company into Flintkote and the purchase of all assets and business of the Orangeburg Manufacturing Co., Inc.

IT was a proud gesture for the Turkish Government to present a concert honoring the United Nations that also honored one of its own composers. The event, which took place in the General Assembly Hall last night, was arranged
The curious debate over outer space which has just been completed at the United Nations must have puzzled many persons.
I am the father of an emotionally disturbed child. I recently had the harrowing experience of' trying to place my child in a special school for guidance and corrective help.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company announced today that it would acquire the S. Morgan Smith Company of York, Pa., under an agreement subject to approval by the Smith concern's stockholders.

The Hilton Hotels Corporation increased earnings sharply in the third quarter of this year over those of the 1957 period. The gain brought earnings for the nine months to a total only slightly below that of a year earlier, Conrad N. Hilton, president, reported yesterday.

DETROIT, Nov. 25 (UPI) -- Budweiser of St. Louis captured the national five-man match-game bowling championship tonight for the third time in four years. It defeated Pfeiffers of Detroit, 3 points to 1, in the deciding match.
SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 25 (Reuters) -- The English Marylebone Cricket Club beat a strong Australian team by 345 runs today to score its third victory of the present tour.
MONTREAL, Nov. 25 (UPI) -- Andy Bathgate of the New York Rangers tallied 8 points in three games during the past week to break open a close race for the National Hockey League scoring championship.
If it's treason to talk about the Air Force Academy during Army-Navy week, then make the most of it. The Flying Cadets are very much in the football news, too.

The Associated Dry Goods Corporation increased its sales and earnings in the three, nine and twelve months ended Nov. 1 over those of the corresponding periods of 1957, Robert J. McKim, president, reported yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Five passers are staging a battle for National Football League honors, according to league statistics released yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 25 -- A preliminary step toward establishing an over-all giant union of actors was initiated tonight in a surprise action by the board of directors of the Screen Actors Guild.

THE French program that the Philadelphia Orchestra gave last night at Carnegie Hall was a concert in which. everyone was in his element. This went for Robert Casadesus, the soloist; Eugene Ormandy, the conductor, the men and women of the orchestra and, needless to say, the audience.
DETROIT, Nov. 25 (AP)-Three former union officials and two former employes of a Detroit insurance agency pleaded guilty today in the alleged embezzlement of more than $32,000 in union welfare funds.

ROME, Nov. 25 -- Premier Amintore Fanfani took issue today with an article printed yesterday in the New York Times. The article, which appeared on the editorial page was by C. L. Sulzberger and criticized recent developments in the Italian attitude toward the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
Ernie Banks, the tall, willowy shortstop of the Chicago Cubs, was named yesterday as the National League's most valuable player for 1958.
WORKING girls who cannot bolt home before embarking on a date can still look fresh and pretty for the evening. Here are some ways and means to look crisp after an eighthour-day.
HONG KONG, Nov. 25 -- In many cities of Communist China men are rapidly disappearing as operators of stores, restaurants, hotels, pharmacies, markets, barber shops and other service enterprises.
Stocks tried to rally yesterday and failed. At the end of the day values of the New York Stock Exchange had receded by $1,500,000,000.

TOKYO, Nov. 25 -- Crown Prince Akihito's engagement is expected to be announced Thursday. It is taken as a certainty here that the future Empress of Japan will be Miss Michiko Shoda, 24-year-old daughter of a flour mill owner, who met the Prince across a tennis net two years ago.

The Boston Fund reported record sales of $6,500,000 yesterday for the quarter ended Oct. 31. The big balanced mutual fund also reported that shares rose 15 per cent in value since Jan. 31, and that net assets were at a record high.

ONE of the expressions that has long enriched the Yiddish language is: "I need it like a hole in the head." That approximates the need of the Yiddish theatre for Maurice Schwartz' labored adaptation of Arnold Schulman's "A Hole in the Head."

The Jewish Child Care Association of New York has purchased the twelve-story office building at 345 Madison Avenue between Forty-fourth and Forty-fifth Streets. It will consolidate all its non-institutional operations there.

Jacob Grumet, chairman of the State Commission of Investigation, met yesterday with Dr. James E. Allen Jr., State Education Commissioner, and agreed on a division of authority in their investigations of city school construction.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- A Special House Committee ordered investigations today of complaints on two elections in Kentucky and West Virginia.
CHICAGO, Nov. 25 (AP) -- A forecast of a cold wave and heavy snow over a large area of the Midwest raised corn futures prices today on the Board of Trade but weakened wheat.
LONDON, Nov. 25 -- The United States is as determined as ever to resist Soviet aggression in Berlin or elsewhere, Vice President Richard M. Nixon declared today.

I am afraid that your editorial of Nov. 17 on slum prevention fails to hit the mark. Were the Building Department to crack down on the main slum cause, which is the overcrowding of buildings and the deterioration from that abuse, these families would have no place to go, such is the shortage in the low-rent field.

Temperatures ranging up to 30,000 degrees Fahrenheit are employed in a new method for fabricating ultra-hard materials by mass production methods, announced yesterday by the Linde Company, a division of the Union Carbide Corporation.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 25 -After six weeks under the new Government Lebanese leaders were still trying today to find a way to break the habit of violence learned by the public during more than five months of civil fighting.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The business man seeking a new opportunity was advised today that the housing field needed a counterpart to the automobile industry's used-car dealer.
Fireman used an aerial ladder yesterday to rescue a woman and her four small children in a fire at 226 Forty-ninth Street Brooklyn.
The facts in labor disputes involving four airlines are as follows:

Dr. Leonard Greenburg, Commissioner of the Department of Air Pollution Control, watched demonstrations of two large auto-burning incinerators yesterday. The installations can burn 320 scrapped auto bodies a day without black smoke or moxious gases.

Twelve new street lights were turned on last evening on Forty-Second Street between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas. They shed six times more light than the five posts with incandescent lamps that they replace.

Eighteen persons were hurt when the 8 o'clock Pennsylvania Railroad express from Philadelphia came to a sudden halt in Pennsylvania Station yesterday morning. The train was only ten feet from where it normally would have stopped.
New York City raised $92,800,000 yesterday through the sale of tax anticipation notes and serial bonds.

Georgi Nikolayevick Zaroubin began his working life as an errand boy and ended it as an world-renowned diplomat. In between, he was a soldier, engineer and educator. Some sources have insisted he was also an important member of the Soviet secret police.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 25 -Navy's football coach, Eddie Erdelatz, admitted today that Army's use of the lonely end offense this year had caused him to make some modifications in his team's defense.
A wage agreement and a court no-strike order prevented the air crisis from worsening last night.

NEWARK, Nov. 25 -- The New York Central Railroad and the Erie Railroad today obtained major legal support in their four-year-attempt to abandon Hudson River ferry service. The New York Central has operated its service since 1883.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Noxious smog, consisting partly of sulphuric acid mist, blanketed the city today. Officials said it was one of the most severe smogs on record and they were worried about it.
Associate Justice John M. Harlan of the Supreme Court said here last night that a large part of recent criticism of the courts, especially of the Supreme Court, had been ill-informed.
IT is impossible yet to get any kind of line on what New York's half-million deer hunters have been doing in the woods. The chances are that the kill this year will exceed last year's 72,000.odd.
Nine port watchmen were suspended yesterday as an aftermath of a wholesale crackdown by the Waterfront Commission in its campaign against loansharks and pier thieves.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UPI) -- The chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board said today he had received a "substantial number" of letters from Representatives seeking to influence the board's decision in 1956 on a multi-million-dollar airline route from New York to Miami.
To commemorate the 200th anniversary of the death of Handel, the New York Department of Commerce and Public Events will sponsor a two-week Handel Festival next spring, beginning March 1.
Sam Levene and Eddie Hodges, the juvenile actor who appeared for nearly a year in "The Music Man; will star in a television comedy series titled "The Wonderful World of Little Julius".

Citations were presented yesterday for activities in behalf of equal opportunities in housing to Jackie Robinson, Harry Brandt, and Alfred J. Marrow at Gracie Mansion. A reception in their honor followed.
ATLANTA, Nov. 25 -- Georgia officials, led by Senator Richard B. Russell, have opened an attack on a proposal by Atlanta ministers for accepting limited integration to preserve public schools.
Fines were levied yesterday against 128 landlords and building agents in the Hammels area of Queens on charges of building, health and fire violations.

Seven million seafaring and waterfront workers in the ports of the seven seas plan to begin a four-day boycott on Monday of the 1,500 vessels which fly the flags of Panama, Liberia, Honduras and Costa Rica but the ownership of which is foreign to those countries -- the so-called "flags of convenience" ships. About one-third of them, mostly tankers, are United States owned.
Consolidated Retail Stores, Inc., operators of a ready-towear merchandise chain, is planning to expand into the drug store field.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 25 -Chancellor Konrad Adenauer will appeal to Premier Charles de Gaulle tomorrow, for his personal support of the "hard" policy advocated by West Germany to repel the Soviet threat to Berlin.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -The Consumer Price Index held steady in October, as declining food prices -- mostly seasonal -offset price increases in most categories of goods and services.
ROME, Nov. 25 -- Pope John XXIII celebrated his 77th birthday at work in his library as on any other day.

Jack Garfein, who directed Sean O'Casey's current hit, "The Shadow of a Gunman," has acquired the stage rights to John Hersey's novel, "The Wall." This, it will be recalled, is the story about the destruction of the Warsaw Ghetto, covering the period of 1939 to 1943 and written as though by an imaginary archivist.

The important chemical industry is reported rebounding from the effects of the recent recession. That was the word from Gen. John E. Hull (U.S.A., ret.), president of the Manufacturing Chemists Association, at the group's eighth semi-annual meeting held yesterday at the Statler Hilton Hotel here.

ALGIERS, Nov. 25 -- The French Army, in a limited offensive that lasted three weeks, has killed or captured more than 1,600 Algerian nationalist rebel fighters, a French military spokesman said here today.
ALBANY, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Republican organizations spent more than $1,786,000 on the campaign of Nelson A. Rockefeller and his running mates, reports showed today.
The Fine Arts Federation of New York, which embraces fifteen societies of artists and architects, adopted a resolution yesterday calling for a permanent end of traffic through Washington Square Park.

Assurance has returned to the market for United States Government securities. For the second straight trading session, prices moved up throughout the list yesterday, with the best gains in long-term issues.

The New York Central Railroad's earnings rose last month to $4,674,110 from $1,353,828 in October, 1957. Management said the gain was due largely to deep slashes in its ordinary operating expenses as well as to its halting last January of all expenditures for major capital improvements.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- A Presidential committee reported substantial progress today in ending racial discrimination by companies with Government contracts.

George S. Kaufman of the Kaufman Management Company has announced that his company has taken title to the one-story taxpayer containing seven stores at 1560-72 East 174th Street in the Bronx. The building, erected in 1951, has a frontage of 180 feet.

The election of Chester G. Gifford as chairman and chief executive officer of Schick, Inc., manufacturer of electric shavers, was announced yesterday. John J. Reidy was elected president. The new officers succeed Kenneth C. Gifford, brother of the new chairman, who resigned from both posts earlier this week. The changes were announced by Charles Revson, president of Revlon, Inc., which has acquired working control of Schick.

RYE, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- Two railroad presidents came to Westchester County tonight to urge 500 business leaders to help the lines get as much public subsidy as already given to the air, water and highway transports.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Rutgers made it official tonight. The Homer Hazel Trophy for the most valuable member of the football team was given to Billy Austin at a dinner given by the university and the town Touchdown Club.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- A British spokesman cautioned the United Nations today against endorsing independence or any long-term solution for Cyprus "in the absence of a general agreement."
The New Haven Railroad proposed yesterday that it receive a $1,900,000 subsidy for one year to offset losses on commuter service.
WARSAW, Nov. 25 (AP) -The United States and Chinese Communist Ambassadors to Poland met for an hour and forty-five minutes in a secrecyshrouded negotiating session today.

" Genocide in the U. S. S. R.," a symposium prepared by the research section of the Institute for the Study of the U. S. S. R., will be published in this country by Scarecrow Press on Dec. 5. The authors are a group of emigres from many parts of the Soviet Union.
Sir Winston Churchill received by proxy last night the Admiral Richard E. Byrd Memorial Award in recognition of leadership in the cause of a free world.

WALKING through West Forty-fifth street last week on the way back to the office after lunch (Irish stew and a raw apple) I suddenly realized why passers-by were staring at me. I was talking to myself. What's more, I was chanting something that was obviously inspired by the book I was carrying under my arm, "Merry Christmas, Happy New Year"* by phyllis McGinley.
NEW CITY, N. Y., Nov. 25 -Plans for transforming the onetime estate of Adolph Zukor, motion-picture executive, into a $50,000,000 industrial and housing development were disclosed today.
Custom smelters reduced the price of refined copper 1/4-cent a pound yesterday to 29 1/2 cents as sales continued slow and the market tone weakened further abroad.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 25 -- The membership of the Hotel and Restaurant Employes and Bartenders International Union will increase from its present 450,000 to a total of 700,000 or 750,000 as a result of yesterday's unanimous decision by the United States Supreme Court, the union's president, Ed S. Miller, said here today.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 25 -The nation's military high command was summoned by President Eisenhower today to a conference here Friday morning on defense spending on the next fiscal year.
RYE, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- Preliminary approval was reported today by Rye Town officials of plans of the United Aircraft Corporation to build a $6,000,000 home for its Norden Division north of Rye City.

MANHASSET, L. I., Nov. 25 -- The big red fire trucks have been having trouble finding the little red fire hydrants in some sections of North Hempstead because homeowners have "landscaped" them. That has got to stop, the North Hempstead Town Board said today.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25 -El-Tronics, Inc., filed a voluntary petition in Federal District Court here today for a reorganization under the Federal Bankruptcy Act.
A British professor reported here last night that life did not arise in one decisive step but must have come about through a series of chemical reactions, like those known in laboratories today.
Pari-mutuel employes questioned yesterday by the State Commission of Investigation were asked whether they had paid kickbacks to obtain their race-track jobs.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25--Corn producers scrapped twenty-five years of efforts to control production in a national referendum today.
The National Retail Merchants Association and the Variety Stores Association joined yesterday in urging retailers throughout the nation to keep their stores closed on Sundays.
The long-standing fight of longshoremen here against the increased use of shipping containers erupted again yesterday.

IT'S been the better part of a week since Jackie Jensen of the Boston Red Sox was elected Most Valuable Player in the American League, news that was received with profound silence. But a message, traveling across the country by pony express, finally made a delayed arrival at Times Square.
Dr. Jesse Bryant makes one point and misses two others in his letter published Nov. 19.
WHEN the National Arts Club was founded sixty years ago it was destined for august cultural aims eventually fulfilled by such members as George Bellows, Louis Tiffany, Mark Tobey and others.

The retiring president of the Federal Bar Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut urged all bar groups yesterday to assume greater responsibility for appointments to the United States Supreme Court.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 26 -- The General Assembly's Economic Committee completed debate today on a United States resolution for the registry with the United Nations of all aid resources and programs. The motion was subjected to bitter attack by the Soviet bloc.

A 70-year-old man who had served twenty-six years of a life sentence for murder was sentenced to ten to twenty years on another murder charge yesterday in Kings County Court. Judge Hyman Barshay then suspended sentence and placed the defendant on probation.
Three men were arrested yesterday in the theft of $28,000 that had been hidden in a strongbox beneath the pulpit of a Harlem church.

TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 27 -- Crown Prince Akihito's engagement to Miss Michiko Shoda, a commoner whom he met two years ago on a tennis court, was announced today. Their marriage is expected to take place not less than a year from now.

The horse-happy peregrinators who make their way to Jamaica today will have a properly named holiday feature to bet on. It will be the Pilgrim, a six-furlong race for all ages which has attracted nine starters.

Nikita Khrushchev, an arsonist of no mean talent, is taking full advantage of our defensive global fire-brigade policy to keep us jumping from crisis to crisis. Not only that, but our status quo defense causes us everywhere to leave unfinished business, once we have put out the fire.

YONKERS, Nov. 26 (UPI) -- Wealthy Widower, a 4-1 shot owned by the Musketeer Stable of Glen Head, L. I., anr driven by Buck Norris, won tonight's feature pace by a length and a quarter over McCoy Hanover before 25,590 fans at Yonkers Raceway.
These are days in Wall Street when it pays to be "quick on the draw." In an active and volatile market a decision to buy or sell is all-important. So is the matter of timing.
ROME, Thursday, Nov. 27 (Reuters) -- A twenty-four-hour strike almost completely paralyzed Italy's state rail lines yesterday. Further disruption of business came through a postal strike.
CARMEL, N. Y., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Two hunters from the Bronx were indicted on a charge of first-degree murder today in the shooting of a game warden on Nov. 10.

ALBANY, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Democratic State Committee reported today that it spent $885,191 on the election campaign of the state ticket led by Governor Harriman. The report indicated that there was a $83,819 deficit.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, said today that in his judgment the United States was spending too much on military foreign aid and not enough on economic assistance. He offered this opinion as "an abstract proposition."
PARIS, Nov. 26 (Reuters) -- A wartime French air ace and author challenged Information Minister Jacques Soustelle today to a duel over election differences. Dueling is illegal in France.

SPRINGHILL, N. S., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Thirteen coal miners came home last night from a warm Georgia vacation to chill winds, light snow and a bleak future. The men said they had been offered jobs in Georgia but would have to think over the offers.
HONG KONG, Nov. 26 -- Chen Ming laughed heartily when I asked him to comment on the fears expressed in the West that China was fast becoming the "new Japan," dumping cheap goods on world markets.

RANGOON, Burma, Nov. 26 (Reuters) -- Communist China has protested to Burma about an alleged border raid by Burmese tribesmen in which twenty Communist Chinese soldiers were killed, it was reported here today.

JUNEAU, Alaska, Nov. 26 -- Alaska lay buried today under a white blanket of Democratic ballots. The Democrats have gained the right to chart the course of government of this far north land during its formative years as the forty-ninth state.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Federal Court of Appeals upheld today a lower court decision that said the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen had the sole right to determine who it should admit to membership.

There have been some ugly rumors recently that Cus D'Amato, the sometimes misunderstood boxing manager, had hidden a big Swedish fighter all week in a dingy hotel room, brainwashed him, and thus prevented him from meeting some pure and socially prominent folks along Eighth Avenue.
Plans for the western terminus of the Cross-Bronx Express way have been revised completely to provide better links with connecting highways.
ROME, Nov. 26 (Reuters) -- Italy's state-run television service has broadcast its first program of Teleschool," a three-year preparatory course for technical commercial and professional training.
TOKYO, Nov. 26 (AP) -- A Japanese writer who has been critical of the United States has expressed sympathy for America's efforts to solve its Negro problem.
A complaint listing 112 violations against a Lincoln Square building occupied by seventy one families was brought up in Municipal Term Court yesterday in the current crack-down on slums.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 26 -- Discussion of the Cyprus question was suspended today until Friday to provide time for the preparation of a compromise resolution.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 26 -- The United States Naval Academy confirmed today that a 17-year-old high school girl had masqueraded for several hours as a midshipman. She even stood formation in the midshipmen's dormitory and ate a meal with the 3,500-man brigade.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 -- An Allentown, Pa., discount house asked the United States Circuit Court of Appeals today to issue an order restraining the Lehigh County District Attorney from arresting its employes on conspiracy charges if they worked on Sundays.
LONDON, Nov. 26 -- The Home Secretary, R. A. Butler declared today that the Government was preparing new legislation for curbing prostitution.
SHORTLY after Averell Harriman was elected Governor, he began examining important officeholders appointed by his predecessor, Thomas E. Dewey.

BIRGIT CULLBERG'S "Medea" was presented last night by the New York City Ballet as the first premiere of its season at the City Center, and a distinguished premiere it proved to be. Though Miss Cullberg's other ballet, "Miss Julie," which the Ballet Theatre presented during its recent season, was an impressive work, this one is even more so.
RUTHERFORD, N. J., Nov. 26 -- The weather was damp, dark and gloomy outside the Fairleigh Dickinson University gymnasium today. But inside on the basketball court there was an air of sunny optimism.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov. 26 -- Hofstra College has arranged to give seven courses for graduate or undergraduate credit in Port Washington, starting next February.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UPI) -- Senator Warren G. Magnuson said today the offices of the Alaskan International Rail and Highway Commission would be reopened here soon.

Your extensive news coverage and trenchant editorial comments on the plans of the Institute Judicial Administration and the Judicial Conference are valuable contributions to the cause of co-reform. Simplifying court structure and centralizing administration control doubtless make for great efficiency at less cost.
Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe has agreed to remain as State Health Commissioner under Governor-elect Nelson A. Rockefeller.
CHICAGO Nov. 26 (AP) -- A fairly broad general decline hit grain futures prices today on the Board of Trade. But some scattered buying support appeared to be developing at the extreme.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 26 (Reuters) -- Premier Abdul Karim el-Kassem said today he had foiled an "imperialistic plot" against Syria in 1956.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon told Britons tonight that the West could not allow India, Pakistan, Ghana and Malaya to fail in their "heroic" efforts to make economic progress while preserving freedom.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- The unwritten alliance of the United States and Britain, born in two world wars, was reaffirmed today in the dedication of the American Memorial Chapel in St. Paul's Cathedral. Queen Elizabeth and Vice President Richard M. Nixon were among 3,000 Britons and Americans gathered in the "parish church" of the British Commonwealth for the service of dedication.
SOMERSET, Pa., Nov. 26 (AP) -- A flaming crash inside the Allegheny Tunnel of the Pennsylvania Turnpike killed two persons today and tied up holiday traffic on the express highway for several hours.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 26 -- New Jersey is failing to meet its responsibilities for higher education, Dr. Lewis Webster Jones said today in his final annual report as president of Rutgers University.
Westchester and Connecticut town officials yesterday greeted warily two railroads' proposals for fiscal relief.

KATONAH, N. Y., Nov. 26 -- The old railroad station in this dry northern Westchester hamlet of 2,000 may soon become an oasis for liquor buyers and imbibers. It would also retain a ticket office and limited facilities for commuters.
A man who lived for ninety-six days with an electric device implanted in his heart to maintain its rhythm, went home yesterday from Montefiore Hospital.
PARIS, Nov. 26 -- In his meeting with Chancellor Adenauer today Premier de Gaulle gave the most explicit endorsement of Continental unity of his career, notable for opposition to the idea.
What is said to be the first all-plastic milk bottle cap has been developed and is now being marketed by the Seal-right-Oswego Falls Corporation, Fulton, N. Y.

Cranberry sauce is so much a fixture on the menu with roast turkey for Thanksgiving Day that it is difficult to think of having turkey without it. It is entirely proper to serve cranberry juice or to use cranberries in certain desserts without necessarily having turkey on the table, but turkey sans cranberry sauce amounts almost to flying in the face of national tradition.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Formation of a twenty-one member medical consultant group to help overcome the nation's shortage of physicians was announced today by Leroy E. Burney, Surgeon General of the Public Health Service.
ROME, Nov. 26 -- Pope John XXIII attended a funeral mass today in the Sistine Chapel for the five Cardinals who died in the last twelve months.
Brian Dennehy, a 245-pound tackle from Mineola, L. I., was elected captain yesterday of the 1959 Columbia football team. He succeeds Coy Gobble, a center who led the Lions the past season.

Middle South Utilities, Inc., and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a gain of 7.2 per cent in operating revenues for the twelve months ended on Oct. 31. The system showed an increase of 7.1 per cent for the first ten months of 1958.
Jacob Grumet, chairman of the State Commission of Investigation, denied reports yesterday that dozens of additional subpoenas had been served on employers at the Jamaica Race Track.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Nov. 26 -- Albert G. Glass, 55-year-old West Islip real estate speculator, was fined $30,000 and given a suspended prison sentence in State Supreme Court here today.

"The lemming," reports the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia "is a small, mousy animal which runs in packs over the Arctic tundra." The animal, the bank said, provides quite a contrast to the male peacock, a very fancy fellow * * * a splendid dresser [who] proudly parades his finery."
AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 26 -- President Eisenhower has asked secretary of State Dulles to confer with him here Sunday morning on the Berlin crisis.
Christians and Jews will attend services in the city today to give thanks for what they have and to give money, food and clothing to those that have not.
Formal bids to have the Democratic and Republican national conventions held in New York City in 1960 are to be submitted to the national committees of the two parties.

BY all accounts, most of the people who read the late Anne Parrish's novel "Poor Child" were shocked and horrified by its monstrous revelations of a tragic boy figure. This is likely to be the case with theatregoers who witness Richard Lortz' dramatization of the book, which opened last night at the Greenwich Mews Theatre.
The first assignment of radiological defense kits for the city's public high schools was presented to the Board of Education yesterday.

TORONTO, Nov. 26 (UPI) -- The Detroit Red Wings climbed into a tie with the Montreal Canadiens for first place in the National Hockey League tonight when they defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 5 -- 2.

LACONIA, N. H., Nov. 26 (UPI) -- A former New Hampshire school teacher and his wife settled out of court today a $300,000 libel suit against Mrs. Grace Metalious Martin, author of the novel "Peyton Place."

Deposits in the nation's 519 mutual savings banks increased $95,000,000 in October to nearly $34,000,000,000, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks reported yesterday. For the first ten months of 1958, deposit gains totaled $1,892,000,000.
LISBON, Portugal, Nov. 25 -- Legal action is to be taken against Gen. Humberto Delgado, Opposition leader, the Government stated tonight.
Controller Lawrence Gerosa has apparently neglected to consider the advances made in construction methods and materials during the past twenty years.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Five University of Michigan students have been placed on probation for their part in the sale of football betting cards.

THEODORE LETTVIN last gave a piano recital here in 1956. In the two years since then, he has made giant strides. His Town Hall recital last night was the product of a brilliant young instrumentalist and a sincere musician.

IT is time now for each and every one of us to put on our smoking jacket, light up our jimmy-pipe and sit before the roaring fire with our hand on the silken head of our adoring setter to reflect upon the things for which we ought to be thankful.
The "Ed Wynn Show," a filmed comedy series, and "Brains and Brawn," which features a quiz and a contest of athletic skills, will be canceled the latter part of December.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 26 -- A United Nations committee called today for a special meeting of the General Assembly Feb. 20 to discuss the future of the British and French Cameroons.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Roy Campanella, the former Dodger catcher, still is paralyzed from the neck down, but he was grateful today that he would be able to spend his first Thanksgiving Day at home tomorrow following his automobile accident of tea months ago.
Assemblyman Anthony J. Travia of Brooklyn was reported yesterday to have the inside track for the Democratic minority leadership of the State Assembly.
The Montreal Canadiens, power-play exponents de luxe, had to take a back seat to the New York Rangers last night.

NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., Nov. 26 -- A Board of Education policy providing that the Jewish Festival of Hanukkah should not be discussed in the public schools if it interferes with the Christmas season has drawn protests from some Jewish leaders here.
The election in which the citizens of Alaska have chosen their first full-fledged members of Congress as representatives of the coming forty-ninth state has been a triumphant Democratic victory.
Oil imports in the week ended last Friday retreated from the record level set in the preceding week, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

RALEIGH, N. C., Nov. 26 (UPI) -- Gov. Luther H. Hodges said today he had received letters and telegrams from "all parts of the country" and abroad about two Negro boys reported to have been sentenced to life for kissing a white girl.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Ezra Taft Benson called the decision of corn producers to abandon production controls today as a vote "against undue interference in their affairs," And the Secretary of Agriculture promptly put the new democratic-controlled Congress a notice that he would have further proposals to gain more freedom for other crop producers.
Two men were killed, another was injured and a fourth was missing in the crash of an Air National Guard plane in Jamaica Bay yesterday.

Charles F. Kettering was one of the benefactors of our time, practical yet an idealist, indeed something of a philosopher but a cheerful one. He called himself a mechanic, a "pliers and screwdriver man." He was always "fixing" things. But his contribution of inventive genius, his passionate interest in research -- automotive, medical and in the field of solar energy -- put the world in his debt for a better, more comfortable life.
The Union Pacific Railroad reported yesterday a net income of $9,733,051 for October, its best monthly showing so far this year. In October of 1957, net income was $8,743,111.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today that the United States "might" let the East Germans check the Western supply routes into Berlin, but warned the Soviet Union that the supplies were going through regardless of any Communist blockade.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UPI) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce said today that it would wash its hands of National Laugh Week in favor of more serious projects. The same goes for Expectant Fathers' Day, National Long Underwear Week, and all similar promotional observances.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 26 (UPI) -- A new drug factory, expected to turn Argentina from a four-million-dollar-a-year importer into an exporter of pharmaceuticals, will begin operations next Tuesday.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 26 -- According to a former Premier of the Sudan, the military coup that ousted him saved his country from a foreign-sponsored move to end Sudanese independence.
NEWARK, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Essex County Judge Ferdinand Masucci today ordered a mistrial in the case of Emilio Yanotta Jr., who was charged with the Unlawful use of a gun against a policeman.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- A chief of the Tuscarora Indians contended today that the tribe could not sell land to the New York State Power Authority because the sale would violate a compact among the six New York nations.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals today sold their Houston franchise in the Texas League on a conditional basis to Marty Marion, the former Cardinal manager and shortstop, and Milton Fischmann, a local business man.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UPI) -- The Federal Communications Commission said today it would ask the new Congress to bar anyone -- presumably including members of Congress from behind-the-scenes attempts to influence the commission's decisions.

A Federal Court jury convicted two officers of the International Longshoremen's Association of extortion yesterday. They were found guilty on forty- three counts of shaking down James J. Ball Sons, an export packing concern at 32 Moore Street, for $4,200.
HUNTINGTON, L. I., Nov. 26 -- A police escort and marching band led 1,500 students through this village today to take possession of their new $4, 777,000 high school building.

A former Welfare Department investigator, now employed as a probation officer in Queens Domestic Relations Court, was called one of the "lowest types" of criminals yesterday by Assistant District Attorney Frank J. Blangiardo.
The stock market may be on a roller-coaster these days, but the average investor -- "the little fellow" -- is far from queasy from the up-and-down ride.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 20 -- Between the old city and the new, Delhi has at least as many faces as there are days in the week.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 26 (AP) -- A miniature "cold war" between William Hartack and Calumet Farm appeared to have ended with the announcement today that Hartack would ride Bardstown in the $50,000 Pimlico Special on Saturday.

BERLIN, Nov. 26 -- Secretary of State Dulles staggered West German and other Allied officials today by intimating the West's readiness to deal with the East German Communists on the Berlin crisis as "agents" of the Soviet Union.

NEWARK, Nov. 26 -- It appeared today that the Hudson River ferries would run at least for another week. Three judges of the Federal Court here agreed to hear a plea next Wednesday for a temporary stay of a decision by a majority members of the same court giving the New York Central and Erie Railroads permission to abandon their services.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Following is the text of a telegram sent Oct. 19 by Vice President Richard M. Nixon to Republican Congressional candidates:

WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 26 -- With all the excitement engendered by Army's "lonely end" attack, it has been largely overlooked that this West Point eleven has compiled the best defensive record of any cadet team since the powerhouses of 1944-45.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Caterpillar Tractor Company and the United Auto Workers reached agreement today on a new contract covering 12,000 employes at Caterpillar's plants at East Peoria and Morton, Ill.
RAPID City, S. D. Nov. 26 (AP) -- A towering plastic balloon, being prepared for a manned stratosphere flight, ruptured and collapsed today at the Strato-Bowl launching site near here.
For seven hours yesterday the long-abandoned Court Street station of the IND subway was returned to service. Trains moved in and out of the Brooklyn stop, and about 200 persons used it.

The Ravel Realty Company has leased a one-story industrial building it will erect at the southeast corner of Peach Avenue and Woodbine Street in Avenel, N. J. The lessee is the Symphonic Electronic Corporation, manufacturer of high fidelity sound equipment.
LONDON. Nov. 26 -- Man must master an entirely, new language related to, but more complex than mathematics if he wants to build machines that can "think" in the accepted sense of the word.

TACOMA, Wash., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Some of the nation's labor leaders, besides Dave Beck, were on Nathan Shefferman's "I can get it for you wholesale" list, the Federal District Court jury hearing Beck's income tax evasion trial was told today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today that he had "no evidence at all" that Italy's policies were moving toward loosening tie with the North Atlantic alliance.

PARIS, Nov. 26 -- Raymond Laporte, a career diplomat, has been named French Consul General in New York. M. Laporte will replace Jacques Baeyens, who will become director of American affairs in the Foreign Ministry.
"BOY!" said the little girl from the suburbs. "Supposing that was a teacher looking at you!"
Thanksgiving Eve brought no cheer for strikebound air travelers. Labor trouble kept one-third of the country's airliners on the ground yesterday, and all peace moves proved fruitless.

Flight engineers and pilots presented yesterday their differing points of view on the basic issue that divides their unions: whether the third man in the crew of a jet airliner should be a pilot or a flight engineer.
ROME, N. Y., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Lieut. Col. George F. Gaerttner Jr., head chaplain at Griffiss Air Force Base, faces a new experience in his service career. He will become an airman first class.
The New York Football Giants held a full workout yesterday despite the rain, doing part of their exercising under the Yankee Stadium stands.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 26 -- A "substantial majority" of the 1,200 members of the Screen Actors Guild who attended the union's annual meeting last night voted to explore the feasibility of a merger of all actors' unions that comprise the Associated Actors and Artistes of America.

Joseph Durst, builder of the office building at 200 East Forty-second Street, has leased space in the new structure to the Fibreboard Paper Products Corporation of San Francisco. Louis M. Beckstead of the Cross Brown Company negotiated the lease.
The armed services are testing a new parachute that promises to reduce all the major hazards of paratrooping except enemy gunfire. It also is said to offer great savings in weight and bulk.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The United States has "some slight evidence" that the Soviet Union may be continuing secret tests of nuclear weapons, Secretary of State Dulles reported today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 26 -- Andrew W. Cordier, executive assistant to Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold, said today that Povl Bang-Jensen had done "grave injury" to the United Nations in defending his refusal to yield the names of eighty-one Hungarians who had testified anonymously before a United Nations committee,
A detailed study of the Atomic Energy Commission's new uranium-buying program indicates it may be a "blessing in disguise," a spokesman for the Uranium Institute of America said yesterday.
SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The South Korean Navy reported today that one of its patrol boats had captured a North Korean vessel after a running battle in which four North Koreans were killed.

In the next few weeks the Board of Estimate will be deciding the fate of the Soldiers and Sailors Monument on Riverside Drive and Eighty-ninth Street in Manhattan. Time and the elements have joined to take their toll of the crumbling monument.

The Royal Dutch-Shell Group reported yesterday net income for the third quarter was $107,408,000, compared with $159,236,000 for the similar three months of last year. Sales proceeds and other income came to $1,864,539,600, against $1,870,117,200.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- The stock market quickly recovered from yesterday's setback. By the end of today's session most sections had erased the better part of the preceding day's losses, although the buying remained relatively small.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UPI) -- The Internal Revenue Service yielded one-eighth of an inch today and thereby handed a victory to Elmer L. Hall, public accountant of Long Beach, Calif.
BAD KREUZNACH, Germany, Nov. 26 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and Premier Charles de Gaulle abandoned today the stalled project to create a free trade area in West Europe.

THE Thanksgiving drumstick having been devoured, the march of toy seekers begins in earnest tomorrow. By Christmas Eve, as in years past, it probably will swell to a near stampede in stores across the nation.

I fail to understand Dr. Henry Steele Commager's irritation at the airlines' six-hour confirmation rule. If he flies as often as I do and on such short notice he should realize that without this rule he would frequently be grounded while seats were empty due to "no-shows."

Putting aside the more serious aspects of their lives for a brief interval, forty-three young women on vacation from their schools and colleges were officially introduced last night to the gayer world of society.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan has told Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev of the Soviet Union that Britain has no intention of getting out of Berlin or of recognizing the East German Government.

GENEVA, Nov. 26 -- The United States said today that the conference on guarding against surprise attacks would fail unless the Communist bloc joined the West in a techni cal study of detection systems.

THROUGHOUT the country today, Americans will be giving thanks for the things that have made life worth living in the last twelve months. In the serious spirit of the day, they will express gratitude for many vital blessings -- from the continuing fruits of medical research to the continuing fact of general world peace, however shaky.
HONG KONG, Nov. 26 -- Mao Tse-tung has presided over a Chinese Communist party meeting in Wuhan, believed to be concerned with the future development of the new system of communes.

TORONTO, Nov. 26 (Canadian Press) -- Public attention should be turned to protecting the economy against inflation, John S. Proctor, president of the Imperial Bank of Canada, said today at the bank's annual meeting.

Commodity futures closed irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Sugar, rubber, wool and zinc rose; coffee, cocoa and cottonseed oil declined, and price movements for copper, lead, platinum, potatoes and hides were mixed.

Among the setbacks President Nasser of the United Arab Republic has suffered recently apparently should be listed the military coup in the Sudan, where the army under General Abboud has taken over the Government. According to former Premier Khalil, who confirms previous speculations to this effect, the coup was staged with his approval and cooperation as a desperate measure to save the Sudan from Nasser's grasp.

The Board of Estimate decided yesterday to add $12,000,000 to $13,000,000 to the proposed school capital budget for 1959. City Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa, who accused the Board of Education last week of wasting $100,000,000 in school construction funds over the last seven years, did not attend the executive meeting.

The protestant Council of the City of New York submitted a twelve-page statement of opposition yesterday to Mayor Wagner's committee that is studying his proposal to legalize off-track betting as a possible source of city revenue.
Archibald Williams will fly back to his native Barbados tomorrow to rest, convalesce, muse about the hundreds of New York children he has taught and perhaps find new children to teach.
Lake Ontario Portland Cement Company, Ltd., of Picton, Ont., is offering 671,376 new shares of common stock to its shareholders.

Stocks rallied sharply yesterday, making the best one-day gain since Nov. 27, 1957. Values on the New York Stock Exchange rose about $4,200,000,000, canceling almost 40 per cent of the losses of the three preceding sessions.
Directors of the General Cigar Company proposed yesterday a three-for-one split of the common stock, subject to approval of shareholders at the annual meeting on April 4.
A broker whose security sales allegedly defrauded investors of more than $500,000 was ordered yesterday not to engage again in the securities business in the state.
Midwestern football players won four berths on the college all-America team announced yesterday by United Press International, but two halfbacks from other sections of the nation led the balloting.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 -- Pennsylvania and Cornell wind up their most prosperous football seasons in recent years tomorrow in their Thanksgiving Day game on Franklin Field.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 18 points off to 1 point up yesterday in modest business, A point equals 5 cents a bale.

Electric power production kilowatt week rose to 12,579,000,000 kilowatt hours from 12,378,000,000 the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. In the week ended Nov. 23, 1957 the output was 12,136,000,000.

IN 1922, eighteen years before his death, F. Scott Fitzgerald published "Tales of the Jazz Age." One reason for the book, he said, was that a story in it, "Jemima," seemed to him worth preserving for a few years -- "at least until the ennul of changing fashions suppresses me, my books and it together."
Retailers are reported optimistic about spring business.
Prof. George C. de Hevesy of Sweden, a chemist and Nobel Prize winner, was named yesterday as the second recipient of the $75,000 Atoms for Peace Award.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov 26 -- Long Island is famous for its sandy beaches, parkways, potatoes, ducks and race tracks, but not for college football or giant-sized stadia.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 -- The Curtis Publishing Company reported today that its earnings declined to $1,736,446, or 12 cents a share, during the first nine months of this year. This compared with $4,975,116, or $1.05 a share, in the 1957 period.

Richard Lee Chappell, an Eagle Scout, served as a junior scientific aide to the scientists of the International Geophysical Year program in Antarctica. He spent the long winter night and summer of 1957-58 on the ice-bound waters of the Antarctic continent, where he celebrated his nineteenth birthday.
Sales and earnings of the Duro-Test Corporation in the quarter ended Oct. 31 were at record levels, Walter S. Simson, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Secretary of State Dulles, who has long been associated with the National Council of Churches of Christ, was asked by a reporter today to comment on a recommendation by a study conference of the council that the United States recognize Communist China.

When the baseball clans gather next week in Washington for the annual major-minor meetings, the proposed amendment calling for unrestricted draft of all one-year minor league players is certain to receive top billing.

PARIS, Thursday, Nov. 27 -- Pierre Mendes-France, defeated leader of the French moderate Left, warned today of the danger of a slide toward an authoritarian Right-wing regime in France as a result of the current legislative elections.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Eleven persons were sent to prison today for the theft of $2,800,000 worth of uniform cloth from the Quartermaster Depot.

When Mrs. Anne W. Korotnev takes her 3-year-old Italian greyhound, Blue Heather, for a walk along East End Avenue, children sometimes exclaim: "Oh, look at the little deer!" Italian greyhounds do look a little like deer, particularly in repose.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 26 -- The Government confirmed today that it had been meeting increasing difficulties in trade with the Soviet Union as a result of the Moscow-led campaign against the Tito regime.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 26 -- Elated by the spirit and results of Navy's final scrimmage, Coach Eddie Erdelatz today said he believed his football squad of midshipmen "was ready for anything" that Army would fire at it Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon's office released today the text of a telegram sent by Mr. Nixon last month advising Republican candidates to campaign against "the radical wing" of the Democratic party.

BETWEEN Thanksgiving and Christmas, America goes about pacifying its sweet tooth with abandon. Despite the fact that the nation has never been more calorie conscious, candy manufacturers know that, within the next four weeks, more than 500,000,000 pounds of sugar plums, bon bons and other confections in various shapes and sizes will be eaten. This is one-fourth of the year's total.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Earl F. Reed, a television executive, repeated under oath before the subcommittee today that he could not remember where he had heard rumors of bribery attempts in a Pittsburgh television case.

Appropriations for new plant and equipment in the metal- working industry fell sharply in the first half of this year, compared with those in the 1957 period. However, three important segments of industry increased appropriations, according to a survey published today by Iron Age, trade magazine.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Studebaker - Packard Corporation and the United Auto Workers agreed to resume negotiations today, the third day of a strike.

BOSTON, Nov. 26 -- Nothing resembling a fight developed tonight when the Knickerbockers and the Celtics crossed paths for the first time since last Friday's near free-for-all on a Philadelphia floor.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Nov. 26 (AP) -- A record field of thirty-two horses was entered today in Tropical Park's opening feature tomorrow. Therefore, officials announced the Hurricane Handicap will be run in two divisions, with sixteen horses each section.
George W. Aljian has been elected a vice president of the California Hawaiian Sugar Refining Corporation, San Francisco, Calif. He had been director of purchasing and packaging for the company.
Starting at 12:05 A. M. on Monday there will be a 3-cent charge for transfers now given free on the lines of two of the city's largest franchised bus companies.

New York said hello and good-by at the time yesterday to a new ship -- the 36,650-ton tanker Hans Isbrandtsen.

In St. Paul's Cathedral, London the bugler first played taps and then the trumpeters answered with the reveille. The eternal round of sleep and awakening, death and rebirth, was the fitting symbol for all that went into the American chapel which was dedicated there yesterday.

OTTAWA, Nov. 26 -- The Canadian Government granted the country's two trans-continental railways a 17 per cent increase in freight rates today to enable them to meet wage demands from their non-operating unions.

Mrs. Betty Elliot and Miss Michele Saint, who are Protestant missionaries, are living in tiny village on the Tiwaenu river in the eastern Ecuadorin jungle.

The Chase Manhattan Bank made public yesterday terms of its proposed merger offer to the Clinton Trust Company. The New York Chamber of Commerce announced yesterday that it would press for wholesale changes in this state's "Little Wagner Act." The changes are designed to make New York's law governing labor relations conform with the Federal Taft-Hartley Act.

ALGIERS, Nov. 27 -- Remy Montagne, who defeated former Premier Pierre Mendes-France in his bid for re-election to the Assembly, came her today to help a cousin purge himself of a charge of being a "Mendesist."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- A simple design of seven rows of seven stars appeared today to be the likeliest form the nation's flag will take after Alaska has been formally admitted as the forty-ninth state.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 27 (UPI) -- Earl Buchholz of St. Louis, 18-year-old United States junior tennis champion, reached the men's singles final of the New South Wales tournament today and sent America's Davis Cup stock soaring.

PARIS, Nov. 27 -- Jacques Soustelle, Minister of Information, said this evening that the "important point" to note in the Soviet proposal was that Berlin, as a free city, would be "detached" from West Germany.

This season skirts are definitely on the rise. They have an entirely new look that stems from an interest above the waist. The newest ones start just beneath the bosom and are held in place by stiffened, soaring waistbands that hug the ribcage. These waistbands are topped by ruffles, trimmed with tailored bows and cinched in by drawstrings or narrow self belts.

The Little Antelope has outdistanced many other more eligible young ladies and has been chosen to be the next Empress of Japan.

Four of the most personal interpreters of modern jazz -- Thelonious Monk, Miles Davis, Gerry Mulligan and Jimmy Giuffre -- brought their groups to a concert at Town Hall last night.

Stock prices on the New York Stock Exchange moved erratically in November. The market finally managed to rally in late trading and end with small gains for the month. Electronic issues and specialties were strongest.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 28 -- An amnesty decree canceling the prison sentences of 839 persons and shortening the terms of 1,178 others was announced today by the government of President Tito.

LISBON, Portugal, Nov. 28 (UPI) -- Four critics of the regime of Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar who were arrested last Saturday, are to be released while charges of subversion are drawn against them, the National Information Secretariat said today.

The $55,000,000 contemplated now by the city administration to build a new Bellevue Hospital will not buy what $85,000,000 would have built. So a new study of scope of reconstruction and preliminary planning is the next step, and the proposed capital budget for 1959 includes $533,000 for this purpose.
JAMMU, Kashmir, Nov. 28 -- In a newly built court beside a newly built prison, Sheik Mohammed Abdullah, former Prime Minister of Kashmir, agreed today to hear himself arraigned for treason.

HAVANA, Nov. 28 -- The water supply of the United States Naval Base at Guantanamo in Oriente Province was cut off Tuesday and again yesterday, according to informed sources. It may happen again, the sources said.
OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Nov. 28 -- A new kind of atom-smasher will be installed in a building to be built for research at Oak Ridge National Laboratory.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (UPI) -- Senator Paul H. Douglas of Illinois said today that public opinion would turn against the South if that region's Senators tried to talk to death his proposal to curb filibusters, or prolonged debate.
Arrangeme/tts have been made for the showing in Czechoslovakia of ten American-produced motion pictures for a payment of $125,000 in United States currency.
Earnings of the Long Island Rail Road held relatively steady last month Net income was $195,337, compared with $193,748 in October of last year.

RACINE'S "Britannicus" opened in expert hands last night at the Phoenix Theatre, Second Avenue and Twelfth Street. This somber tale of the imperial court of Nero was handsomely acted by the Vieux-Colombier troupe of Paris. It was given in French and the French was superb.
The number of persons receiving unemployment insurance benefits in the state rose sharply last Week under the impact of lay-offs in seasonal industries.

An eight - count indictment was returned yesterday by a Bronx grand jury against Henry Barrett, 51-year-old Irish Republican Army sympathizer. A cache of arms was found in the basement of his home, 1340 Purdy Street, the Bronx, on Nov. 19.

ROME, Nov. 28 -- The Italian Renaissance is studded with names of condottiere captains, those tough military adventurers who sold their services to warring city-states and principalities. It is therefore not astonishing to see once more looming upon Italy's horizon the shadow of a modern condottiere.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (UPI) -- The trial of three Rochester, N. Y., brothers charged with violating Federal firearms laws in an alleged sale of arms to Cuban rebels ended today with a deadlocked having deliberated fourteen jury.
The 67-year-old operator of a Lincoln Square slum building was sentenced yesterday to fifteen days in jail and ordered to pay a $500 fine.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 28 -- The International Court of Justice rejected today a Dutch charge that Sweden was acting contrary to a 1902 agreement by keeping a 13-year-old Dutch girl under "protective upbringing."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- After fuller study of yesterday's Soviet note on the Berlin situation many State Department officials and Western diplomats reacted with a mixture of concern and relief today.
IDAHO FALLS, Idaho, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission said today that an accidental release of radioactive material occurred Nov. 18 at its national reactor testing station near here.

The second phase of France's historic legislative elections under the new Gaullist Constitution began yesterday with the balloting in Algeria. Unfortunately, the delegates who are to be chosen in these three days of Algerian voting will not be representative of all shades of opinion, as Gen. Charles de Gaulle had originally hoped they would be.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:
MEDEA, Algeria, Nov. 28 -- Europeans and Moslems in rural Algeria went to the polls under heavy army protection today to elect their Deputies to the French National Assembly.
A strike next week at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx is "inevitable" unless the institution changes its stand on recognizing a union, a spokesman for the union said yesterday.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Outdoor gatherings and demonstrations of all kinds were banned today by the South Korean police. Police Chief Lee Kang Hak said "a serious North Korean Communist subversion plot against the Republic of Korea" had been uncovered.

Louis Hand, Inc., curtain manufacturer, has leased a floor at 16 East Thirty-fourth Street and will move after several years at 55 East Thirty-fourth Street. The lease was negotiated by Edward E. McNally, vice president of the Charles F. Noyes Company.

The Anglo-Lautaro Nitrate Corporation reported yesterday a net profit of $4,491,805, or $1.01 a share, for the fiscal year ended June 30. This compared with $193,413, or 4 cents a share, in the previous year.

With the foresighted initiative we like to see when New York City goes out to get business the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau has plunged impartially into the sea of politics and urged the Democrats and Republicans to hold their national conventions here in 1960. The bureau, supported by business men, has been highly successful in bringing conventions of all sizes and shapes to New York.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's proposal of free-city status for West Berlin would, if accepted, result in three Germanys rather than two and is no solution of the German problem, Vice President Richard M. Nixon declared tonight.

The National Symphony Orchestra came up from Washington to give a program last night in Carnegie Hall. Howard Mitchell, the conductor, introduced to New York a new score -- the Concerto for Piano and Orchestra by John La Montaine. Jorge Bolet was the soloist.

The work of Histadrut, the Israeli labor federation, in overcoming political hostility from Israel's Arab neighbors was praised here last night by Moshe Sharett, Israel's former Premier and Foreign Minister.
TOKYO, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Hitachi, Ltd., plans to ship 350 Diesel cars worth $18,500,000 to the Egyptian National Railways.

An off-duty patrolman on his way home from work last night came upon an armed man in the act of holding up a change agent in the IND subway at Lafayette Avenue and Fulton Street, Brooklyn. The hold-up man was promptly arrested.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 28 (Reuters) -- The Dutch Government announced plans today to recruit volunteers to strengthen its defense forces in Netherlands New Guinea, a territory claimed by Indonesia.

ONCE in a while a book about fishing comes along that is neither a loosely strung series of screaming-reel stories connected by trite generalities nor a suffocating scientific treatise. When it is written by a man who is both an aquatic scientist and a fine fisherman it can be a pleasure to read and a thing of value.

Early this week George Abbott asked the French singer Genevieve if she would be interested in hearing the outline or a musical especially tailored for her talents. The dark-haired mademoiselle listened attentively and readily agreed to play the leading feminine role.
Dr. John J. Theobald, Superintendent of Schools, yesterday called for an end to the controversy over charges of waste in city school construction.

Jacob Markowitz, Justice of the State Supreme Court, approved yesterday a recommendation that the sale of securities of the Universal Oil Products Company be made through a negotiated sale with one or more investment banking houses.
Thousands of homes in the metropolitan area were blacked out last night as gale winds ripped limbs from trees and knocked down power lines.

Federal Judge Frederick van Pelt Bryan announced yesterday that he would decide today whether to issue an injunction restraining 2,000,000 United States transport workers from implementing a four-day boycott against ships flying the flags of Liberia, Panama, Honduras and Costa Rica.
Loans to business by the seventeen major New York banks rose $6,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 28 -- "A country that has such beautiful social laws deserves a better economic break: Do you know our Constitution?"
Eastern Air Lines raised its earnings in the first nine months this year to $6,247,000, from $4,995,000 in the corresponding period last year, the carrier reported yesterday.
PASSAIC, N. J., Nov. 28 -- An unusual program designed to aid pre-school children and their parents is under way here.

A six-story building containing sixty-one apartments and six stores at 1105 Morrison Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by the Binker Realty Corporation, which was represented by Hofmann Katz, attorneys.
A 22-year-old Brooklyn machinist was sentenced to two to four years in prison yesterday for hurling his four-month old daughter out of a first-floor window last spring.

NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., Nov. 28 -- An "unfortunate choice of words" was blamed today for having touched off a controversy over the observance of the Jewish festival of Hanukkah in this community's schools.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregular, down 39 points to up 3 points. (A point equals 5 cents a bale.)
BERLIN, Nov. 28 -- Vice President Nixon promised the people of West Berlin today "undiminished American support."
Poland's most popular poet, speaking from Warsaw, will join in a conversation about literature and culture in general on the "Small World" television show Sunday, Dec. 7.
Alex Webster, the Giants' hard-running right halfback, who has missed two games, won't miss tomorrow's National Football League game with the Philadelphia Eagles at the Yankee Stadium.
RABAT, Morocco, Nov. 28 -- The Moroccan Government crisis took a grave turn today as the leader of the ruling Istiqlal party, Allal el Fassi, failed in his attempt to form a cabinet.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 28 (AP) -- On an afternoon marked by cold winds, drizzling rain, icicles at the rooftops and a heavy fog, the Flamingo Farm's 4-1 Madok won the twenty-first running of the $11,070 Jennings Handicap today at Pimlico.

A 29-year-old woman testified yesterday in Felony Court that although her rent was paid in advance she returned home from out of town only to find herself evicted and her belongings, valued at $10,000, missing.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 619,350 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

Stocks closed November's trading sessions yesterday with a display of strength. The day's gains, added to those of Wednesday, canceled more than two-thirds of the losses in the three previous trading sessions of the New York Stock Exchange.
GENEVA, Nov. 28 -- The Communist bloc submitted today its own proposals on how to guard against surprise attack.
American Airlines offered last night to sit down "anywhere and anytime" with the Air Line Pilots Association to try to head off a threatened strike.
TORONTO, Nov. 28 (Canadian Press) -- Billy Reay was dropped as coach of the Toronto Maple Leafs today. Bert Olmstead, bought from the Montreal Canadiens last summer, has been appointed playing coach.
The new capital market is entering its most active period in months. A score of major sales of securities is slated next week.

The problem of how to certify "the good moral character" of bingo operators under recently enacted legislation has posed difficulties that could delay the game's legal start, scheduled here on Jan. 1.

LONDON, Nov. 28 (Reuters) -- Hawker Siddely Aircraft Company, Ltd., one of Britain's leading aircraft concerns, announced today that its net profits had dropped from 4,700,674 ($12,160,000) in the last fiscal year to 3,221,106 ($9,018,000) this year.

Average net free reserves of member banks increased $21,000,000 to $37,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Net reserves are excess reserves, less borrowings.

S. Klein's new department store on Central Park Avenue in Yonkers is expected to be completed April 15. Excavation was begun July 8 and the concrete foundation was completed Oct. 31.

RAHWAY, N. J., Nov. 28 -- The Rahway Planning Board today released a summary of a master plan for a major portion of the community.

SUGGESTIONS for using persimmons, which appeared here recently, prompted Mrs. Joseph C. Holbrook of Westwood, N. J., to send her favorite formula for a pudding employing that fruit. HARTFORD, Nov. 28 (AP) -- A filmed documentary of an actual spinal operation was too realistic for some 100 lawyers today.

BERLIN, Nov. 28 -- A Soviet Embassy spokesman in East Berlin was reported today to have said that the six-month limit for proposed negotiations on Berlin was not rigid.

Topp Industries, Inc., Los Angeles makers of products used in the aircraft and missiles industries, has sold a subsidiary, Heli-Coil Corporation. The price was $3,500,000.

Directors of Montgomery Ward Co. yesterday declared the regular quarterly dividend of 50 cents on the common stock, payable Jan. 15. LONDON, Nov. 28 -- The stock market continued to recover strongly today. Prices closed at the highest point of the day with widespread and good gains among Government securities and industrial shares alike.

BUKIT LANJAN, Malaya, Nov. 29 -- A couple of headmen, one in a loin cloth and the other in a single breasted suit, exchanged small talk here today over an eight-foot bamboo blowgun and a quiver of poison-tipped darts. Neither understood a word the other said but they hit it off nicely anyway.
WACO, Tex., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Al Hartman, Bill Bucek and Hart Peebles led Rice to a 33-21 victory over a wild-passing Baylor team today.

BERLIN, Nov. 29 -- The most extraordinary thing about West Berlin in these days of its new uncertainty is that it looks ordinary. A little-noticed provision of a recent Federal tax law will give Wall Street more headaches on Jan. 1 than all the celebrations of the previous night. The so-called Forand Bill, headlined as easing the tax burdens of whisky distillers, movie theatres and air taxi services, has buried in it a change in the transfer tax on stocks that could multiply many times the average tax now paid by sellers of securities.
