A 5-year-old imported greyhound, Ch. Seagift Parcancady Royalton, became best in show last night in the thirtieth event of the Queensboro Kennel Club. It was held in the State Armory in Jamaica and drew 839 dogs.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -- The annual pilgrimage to the Army-Navy game is made by 100,000 persons, give or take a few, who are well prepared for almost anything concerning weather, game surprises and entertainment of the midshipman and cadet variety.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The cost of living, as represented by the Labor Department's Consumer Price Index, has happily fallen or held stable for three whole months.

THE first couch of psychiatry in the human school must have been held by some prehistoric dawdler on a mud bank. There, stick in hand, he traced the wanderings of his mind in the perishable slop. Freudian fears; his wife was spared a measure of gloomy companionship, and he saved a cool twenty-five feet of whatever passed for wampum in the dawn of history.
CORBIGNY, France, Nov. 29 -- This sleepy rural community of 2,000 inhabitants was asked last night to help make the next French National Assembly a little less one-sided.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N, J., Nov. 29 -- The glass makers' art, fifty centuries old, is being explored here for modern military purposes.
HONG KONG, Nov. 29 -- Wang Feng-shu, a 17-year-old girl, is a battalion commander at a "people's commune." She directs the works, efforts and lives of 1,595 men, women and children.
NEWARK, Nov. 29 -- Trends in vocational and technical education indicate a future need in Essex County for a separate facility on a post-high school or adult level.
Instruction in mouth-to-mouth resuscitation of suffocation victims was started last week at the Fire Department's Fire College in Long Island City, Queens.

ATLANTA, Nov. 29 -- Emory University faculty members declared today that for the South to close its public schools "at this critical stage of world history is to play directly into the hands of communism."

NEXT year's bicentennial of the death of Handel has been greeted by a salvo in advance at the Covent Garden Opera House, where the oratorio "Samson" has been staged in operatic form. This was one of three events that aroused unusual musical interest at the opening of the theatre's new season.
OSSINING, N. Y., Nov. 30 (UPI) -- Sing Sing's oldest prisoner, in age and in length of confinement, will be released soon at the age of 77.
A plan to get traffic permanently out of Washington Square has been outlined by a citizens' group.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $82,888,791,810. They consist of Treasury securities as follows:

The Bulgarian tenor, Dimiter Uzunov, will make his American debut as Don Jose in Bizet's "Carmen" on Dec. 10 at the Metropolitan Opera. Madelaine Chambers, Heidi Krall, Frank Guarrera and Paul Franke will be singing their roles for the first time this season. Rise Stevens will sing Carmen.
CHICAGO, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The trend of grain futures prices was down last week on the Board of Trade, although there were a few scattered small plus signs in the list.

TELEVISION took gentle liberties with the work of a great composer yesterday. The result was an enchanting hour for children and adults. It was called "Art Carney Meets 'Peter and the Wolf'" and was presented over Channel 7.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Nov. 30 -- Repeated predictions that local government borrowing will continue rising to new records were underscored at the opening of the forty-seventh annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America here today.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 30 -- The steel order backlog increased last week as more and more customers were reported ordering further ahead. While this will not produce any appreciable increase in shipments next month, it is said to forecast a better first quarter for 1959 than had been forecast.
LONDON, Nov. 30 -- The fluctuations on Wall Street last week were reflected on a smaller scale in the stock markets here.
After a firm start, cotton prices in the domestic market weakened last week to close the period with irregular net changes.

New York had what was probably its last chance to see the carrier rocket for the Soviet satellite Sputnik III as it came into view at 5:03 last evening. It is expected to burn up on its way through the lower layer of the atmosphere late tomorrow night.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 30 -- There is no need for future physicians to concentrate on pre-medical subjects in college, according to a Harvard study.
The threat of a slowdown by sanitation employes eased yesterday when the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association agreed to negotiate with the city for wage increases.
CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- Clarence Nicholas Sayen, president of the 28-year-old Air Line Pilots Association, is an economist, geographer and teacher as well as a pilot by training.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The United States is preparing for a long series of negotiations, first with its allies and ultimately with the Soviet Union, on the future of Germany and the security of Western and Central Europe.
THERE is one time in a girl's life when she can give in to whim and buy a dress that she knows will do for only one occasion her -- wedding.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The National Aeronautic Association announced today the award of the Wright Brothers Memorial Trophy to Dr. John Francis Victory, assistant to the Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

The city school system is working on a complete overhaul of its salary structure, going beyond pay rises. The aims are to improve benefits for teachers moving into administrative ranks as well as to recognize merit among those remaining in teaching.
Three new films will arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The assistant Democratic leader of the Senate said today that he saw "no reason" to broaden the membership of the Senate Democratic Policy and Steering Committees to include more liberals.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 30 -- Iran circulated a resolution this week-end calling for a negotiated settlement of the Cyprus dispute "with due regard to the fundamental rights of the two communities living on the island."
Marshall Field Co., Chicago department store, reported over the week-end a net income of $3,555,271 or $1.57 a common share, for the nine months to Sept. 30. Net sales were $145,256,320.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Small Business Administration announced today that it was ready to receive applications for the licensing of investment companies to help small businesses.

Television-Electronics Fund, Inc., reported net assets of $204,710,884, equal to $12.75 a share on 16,059,119 shares outstanding, as of Oct. 31. This compared with $135,100,234, or $10.36 a share on 13,038,227 shares, a year earlier.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UPI) -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, said today the rejection of further acreage quotas for corn was a better indication of the popularity of his policies with farmers than the Nov. 4 Congressional election.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UPI) -- Representative Brooks Hays said today that a protest to a House committee would charge ballot "irregularities" in his defeat by a write-in segregationist candidate.
CHICAGO, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Twenty-two women today were named to the United States' first and reserve women's field hockey teams by the selection committee of the United States Field Hockey Association.

Two railroad executive backed a New Jersey consultant yesterday in his demand that the Port of New York Authority assume at least part of the responsibility for commuter rail service in the metropolitan area.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 30 -- The Amsterdam stock market has had a hectic week. Following the trend on Wall Street, prices fell sharply on Tuesday. Then came a spectacular recovery. The stock index reached 240 against 245 the preceding week. At one point the index was down to 233.
Bamberger's-New Jersey has appointed three senior vice presidents to keep pace with the planned growth of this major division of R. H. Macy Co., Inc.

The city's tentative fiscal program for 1959-60 will be discussed this week at a meeting of Budget Director Abraham D. Beame and T. Norman Hurd, who will be Budget Director for Gov.-elect Nelson A. Rockefeller.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 30 (UPI) -- Quarterback Milt Plum sparked the Cleveland Browns to two fourth-period touchdowns today as the Eastern Division leaders rallied to whip the Washington Redskins, 21 -- 14, at Municipal Stadium.

A program for Togetherness along with some apartness has been evolved by two agencies with total billings estimated at $50,000,000 a year.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 30 -- As measured by Austrian standards, Czechoslovakia is prosperous. As compared with the Communist-ruled countries in Eastern Europe, Czechoslovakia is rich.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 (AP) -- A meat industry spokesman said today that the trade expected meat production in 1959 to reach the second highest level in history.

MADRID, Nov. 30 -- At least eighty young lawyers, physicians, scientists, students and industrial workers have been arrested in the last three weeks in Spain.
The first Sunday of Advent and the beginning of forty hours of devotion to the Blessed Sacrament were marked yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral.
THE dilemma of the narcotics addict was presented with sympathy and taste yesterday on "The Twentieth Century."

ALBANY, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Appellate Division, Third Department, urged lawyers today to take advantage of its experimental effort to cut the cost of appealing lawsuits.

Another attempt will be made today to end the dispute that has stopped most New York City newspaper deliveries in Nassau and Suffolk Counties since last Thursday.

God can be offended most easily in the church, the Rev. Dr. Edward N. West, canon sacrist of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, said in a sermon yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- As every one knows, there is little kinship between baseball and betting. However, the odds were 6, 2 and even tonight that the Yankee-sponsored "bonus rule" wouldn't get to first base in the minor and major baseball conclaves which open tomorrow.

In the numbing cold of Philadelphia's vast Municipal Stadium, Army fought its way out of a Navy ambush to earn a place high among the football teams coached by Earl (Red) Blaik.
Former President Harry S. Truman said yesterday that Taiwan was among the world's trouble spots where internationalization "could be accomplished.''
CHRISTMAS decor is the subject of many displays now on view at the Design Center for Interiors, 415 East Fifty-third Street.
Former President Harry S. Truman and former Prime Minister Earl Attlee of Britain engaged in a televised conversation yesterday on Channel 2's "Small World."

When Philippine President Garcia arrives in Japan this morning he and Mrs. Garcia will be met at Tokyo's airport by the Emperor and the Empress. This should give some idea of the importance that the Japanese attach to this week-long official visit.

ONE-OF-A-KIND antiques that would make ideal Christmas gifts have been assembled by Roslyn Rosier, 40 East Fifty-seventh Street. Included is everything from rare toys to elegant white opaline punch bowls and cups.

The National Committee for Labor Israel set a goal of $5,000,000 yesterday to be raised during 1959. The money will be used in Israel to carry on the rehabilitation program of Histadrut, the General Federation of Labor.

The hiring of Negro personnel by large department stores was referred to yesterday as "commonplace" by the State Commission Against Discrimination. Its study showed the situation in sharp contrast to that of ten years ago when such Negro employes were exceptions.
The challenge of the Soviet Union was cited yesterday by high school students in a discussion of economics on the New York Times Youth Forum.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Senator Mike Mansfield urged today a scaling down of foreign aid costs by substituting food for dollars in help to hungry world areas.

BORGOSESIA, Italy, Nov. 30 (Reuters) -- Four young Italians walked for forty days across the desert and mountains of western Algeria in an attempt -- successful for three of them -- to escape from the French Foreign Legion.
DETROIT, Monday, Dec. 1 -- The Men's and Women's Contract Bridge Teams of Four National Championships, opening events of the annual nine-day winter tourney, ended here early this morning.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- Sir Winston Churchill briefly interrupted a family celebration of his eighty-fourth brithday today to thank his well-wishers all over the world and to pose for photographs at the door of his country house.

Pancho Villa, the Mexican bandit, is the pivotal character in a new musical entitled "Viva!" The show is to be presented in New York next Oct. 7 by Paul Gregory, sponsor of the Broadway hit "The Marriage-Go-Round."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- It is more commonplace for people to own airplanes in six big Western states than anywhere else in the country.

More than 2,700 persons assembled at Carnegie Hall last night for Elisabeth Schwarzkopf's only New York recital of the season. The German soprano rewarded them with an exquisite evening. Not the least of its pleasures was a group of three songs by Richard Strauss never before sung in public.
A settlement appeared imminent last night in the ten-day-old machinists' strike against Trans World Airlines. However, negotiators recessed at midnight. Talks will continue today in Kansas City, Mo.

After fifteen months of horse-trading, city and state officials have reached a compromise on construction of the often-proposed Lower Manhattan Expressway.

This has caused renewed speculation about the possibility of the former French colony joining the sterling area.

WASHINGTON, Nov 30 -- The State Department is eager to send John D. Jernegan, one of its Middle Eastern experts, to fill what has become the most delicate diplomatic post in the Middle East -- that of Ambassador to Iraq.

The magazine Aviation Week reports that the Soviet Union has been flying a bomber partly powered by atomic energy.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Civil Air Patrol, official civilian auxiliary of the Air Force, celebrates its seventeenth anniversary tomorrow.

The country's shoe manufacturing industry is expected to close the year with a total output of more than 590,000,000 pairs, or only abut 1 per cent below the record 598,000,000 pairs produced last year.
Canon A. Edward Saunders, a clergyman who ministers to the needs of dockers, was honored yesterday at a service at Christ Church, Protestant Episcopal, in Brooklyn.

Election of the board of directors and officers of Hilton Credit Corporation, newly formed universal credit card subsidiary of Hilton Hotels Corporation, was announced yesterday. The directors are Henry Crown, president of Materials Service Corporation; Horace C. Flanigan, chairman of Manufacturers Trust Company; Patrick Frawley, president and director of Eversharp, Inc.; Conrad N. Hilton, Barron Hilton; Edwin W. Pauley, independent oil producer, and Robert P. Williford, executive vice president of Hilton Hotels.

PARIS, Nov. 30 (UPI) -- The French automobile industry, riding high on prosperity at home and a booming market abroad for small European cars, appeared certain today to set new production and export records this year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 30 -- Rod Serling will write the screen play for "633 Squadron," first of three pictures John Sturges is to direct and produce on a partnership basis for the Mirisch-Alpha Company. The independent unit is affiliated with United Artists.

PARIS, Monday, Dec. 1 -- France chose an overwhelmingly Gaullist National Assembly, heavily weighted toward the Right, in the elections yesterday for the first Parliament of the Fifth Republic.

An Episcopal priest in Queens has begun to offer Solemn Evensong on Sunday nights part live and part on tape. The live part is his reading of the evening prayers. The tape is traditional church music, sung by large choirs, that he has recorded and spliced into whole services.

Senator-elect Kenneth B. Keating said yesterday that he could foresee no movement to get the Republican Presidential nomination for Governor-elect Nelson A. Rockefeller in 1960.

It has been said that around 3 o'clock in the morning life is at its lowest ebb. Whoever said that probably was some sage who woke up one morning about 3 and was unable to get back to sleep. That being a time set somewhere between the arrival home of the last neighborhood party-goer and the tinkling visitation of the milkman, it is a very quiet hour when most honest, hard-working folk are asleep.
The New York State Power Authority, headed by Robert Moses, wants to be designated as the state's agency for the development and operation of nuclear power plants.
The steamship charter market marked time last week as grain, its only solid support in recent weeks, failed to retain the firmness it had a forthnight ago.
HIGHLANDS, N. J., Nov. 30 -- This community on the North Jersey Shore will be without commuter rail service tomorrow for the first time since 1891.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Nov. 30 -- Alaskans are looking anxiously toward the forty-ninth state's first legislative session. Already preliminary unofficial budget requests for the first year's operation under statehood exceed the cost of government for the present biennium.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 30 -- Communist China is in the midst of a tremendous drive to reforest vast areas that have been denuded over the centuries. Officials assert that reforestation goals were exceeded by 70 per cent from 1953 to 1956. By the end of 1958, it is said, the margin will be 100 per cent.

Rosalind Russell swept all before her last night in the two-hour version of her Broadway vehicle "Wonderful Town" over Channel 2. In an extremely lavish production for TV, she triumphed mightily in a show that otherwise was frequently rather less than distinguished.

When the Giants scored their first touchdown at Yankee Stadium yesterday they were inadvertently softening up the Eagles for the final New York score. For out of the sweep play that gave the Giants 6 points in the second period came the pattern for the pass play for another 6 points in the fourth period.

In the period of a little more than nine months between mid-February and late November of this year the nation's gold stocks fell by $2.2 billion, a decline exceeding that of any full calendar year in the past.

By proclamation of Mayor Wagner this is "Brazil Day" and the period through Sunday is "Brazil Week." PEORIA, Ill., Nov. 30 -- Striking United Auto Workers at Caterpillar Tractor Company's East Peoria works and two smaller plants ratified a new contract agreement today and ended a seven-week strike.

Five four-story store and apartment buildngs on a plot 92 by 80 feet at the southwest corner of First Avenue and Nineteenth Street have been sold by the Estate of Anna Abendschein to Frederick A. Jambes for investment.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The U.S.S. Constellation, the Navy's oldest fighting ship still afloat, cast off anchor again today. And, although the voyage was short, it was not without peril.

BOMBAY, India, Nov. 30 (Reuters) -- Subhas Gupte, Indian leg-spinner, joined the small band of bowlers to take 100 wickets in test matches when he dismissed Rohan Kanhai in the West Indies' second innings on the third day of the cricket test today.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Baltimore Colts, trailing by 20 points at the half, tallied four touchdowns in the last two quarters for a 35-27 victory over the San Francisco Forty-Niners today. The Colts also gained the Western Conference championship of the National Football League.
"HEAVENLY MUSHROOMS" is the name of a new recipe leaflet that is available to the public without charge.

WASHINGTON, Nov 30 -- Lituya Bay was shaken on the night of July 9 by a massive earthquake that scraped clean the side of a mountain and sent 200-foot high waves cascading down the small land-locked harbor on the Alaskan Coast.

CAVIAR is slimming because there is little fat in the "black pearls of the Caspian Sea." According to G. F. Hansen-Sturm, the caloric content of caviar is negligible. "Eating it," he says, "is a delightful way of getting a balanced diet."

Of the 247,000 corn farmers who voted on the question of (1) continuing the acreage control system in operation since 1933, with its high price supports for "complying" producers, or (2) removing restrictions on production and relating supports to the market price, upward of 71 per cent voted to adopt the new program, sponsored by the Department of Agriculture.
