SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 30 (AP) -- Members of United Auto Workers Local 5 at the Studebaker-Packard Corporation ratified today a contract they have been working under since Friday.

RABAT, Morocco, Nov. 30 -- A Moroccan Leftist group is ready to form a Government if called on by King Mohamed V. according to former Vice Premier Abderrahim Bouabid, whose resignation Nov, 22 started a Cabinet crisis.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Nov. 30 -- Foxchasers from the stables of Mr. and Mrs. Henry D. Paxson at Holicong, Pa., captured two hunter championships and one reserve as the thirty-fifth annual Boulder Brook Club horse show closed a record-breaking two-day stand late tonight.
LOS ALAMOS, N. M., Nov. 30 (AP) -- The propulsion of a rocket by a series of small nuclear explosions will be studied by the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, it was announced today.

THE four most desirable honors at West Point are these: First Captain of the Corps, captain of the football team, class president and star man (the top 5 per cent of the class academically). Rare is the cadet who can attain two of these goals. But Pete Dawkins is the sure-shot future five-star general who made all four this year.

LONDON, Nov. 30 (UPI) -- The British Aluminium Company, Ltd., one of the world's largest producers of aluminum, tried to stem a rising financial furor today by denying it would sell out to an American company.

The Estate Securities Company bought the five-story apartment house for forty-four families at 1625-27 University Avenue in the Bronx. Phil-Mar Associates, Inc., was the seller in the deal, which was arranged by Eric Oling, broker.

BOSTON, Nov. 30 (UPI) -- Johnny Bower, filling in for the ailing regular goalie, Ed Chadwick, kicked away twenty-three shots tonight. He helped the last-place Toronto Maple Leafs snap a nine-game winless streak with a 2-1 victory over the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League game at the Garden.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- State Department officials charge that, contrary to Moscow's complaint that the West has violated the Potsdam Agreement, the Soviet Union itself has broken that agreement as well as other accords on Germany.

Velisa Mugosa, 29-year-old distance runner from Yugoslavia, thrives on rigorous workouts and scoffs at injuries. Despite a painful muscle twinge in his right calf, Mugosa won the senior Metropolitan Association Amateur Athletic Union individual cross-country championship yesterday.
NASSAU, Bahamas, Nov. 30 -- Heavy rain squalls rolling in from the north today washed out the first scheduled race of Nassau's fifth annual international sports car week.

The Giants beat the Philadelphia Eagles, 24 -- 10, to the satisfaction of 35,438 half-frozen fans at the Yankee Stadium yesterday. That Jim Lee Howell's men won and kept pace with the Eastern Division-leading Cleveland Browns, whom the New Yorkers trail by one game, was clear to everyone on hand.
PARIS, Nov. 30 -- French industrialists will try to penetrate South African markets further next March on the occasion of Johannesburg's International Trade Fair.

HONOLULU, Nov. 30 -- Five members of the Interior and Insular Affairs Committees of the United States Senate and House investigated Hawaii's case for statehood here last week. They concluded that the chances were excellent that Hawaii would become the fiftieth state during the next session of Congress.

WASHINGTON Nov. 30 (UPI) -- Senate rackets investigators announced today that they had subpoenaed about 100 witnesses for questioning about alleged gangland infiltration of the coin-operated machine business.

Every now and then a liberty-loving subway rider whose body and spirit have not yet been completely crushed by the greatest transit system in all the world rises up and voices his undying protest against the hopeless, heedless and hapless confusion in New York City's subway lines. He has our sympathy.

A good deal of the drive went out of the stock market's recovery from last week's sharp losses yesterday. Prices opened at gains and the tape quickly fell two minutes behind transactions. In the afternoon, however, profit taking developed and stocks eased for the rest of the session to end irregularly higher.

The Boys Clubs of America announced plans yesterday for a new national headquarters building to be named for former President Herbert Hoover. The six-story structure will be at 771 First Avenue, across from the United Nations.
A new sign flashed in the Times Square area last night. The newest light of the billboard firmament urges pedestrians: "Cross at the Green and Not In Between."
BRISBANE, Australia, Dec. 1 (Reuters) -- Queensland batted all day for 105 runs on the third day of its match against the touring English Marylebone cricket team here.
BERLIN, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Lothar Bolz, East Germany's Foreign Minister, said at a political rally in East Berlin today:
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Dec. 1 (AP) -- Textron, Inc., ended tonight its month-long fight to acquire control of the American Screw Company of Williamantic, Conn.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- Panic aided the flames at Our Lady of the Angels School today. While some children recalled the disciplines of fire drills to make their way to safety, others perished in their confusion.
The Lehigh Valley Railroad plans to quit the passenger traffic business and to operate solely as a freight carrier.
Steel production declined slightly last week, as expected, but was scheduled to increase this week to the highest level in more than a month, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 1 -- The stock market was quieter here today. The industrials became irregular after a strong start.
NEWMARKET, England, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Patrick J. O'Neill, the manager of a Kentucky breeding farm, today paid $57,335 for Sanlinea, an 11-year-old mare in foal, at the Newmarket bloodstock sales.

In revealing the plans for its December financing the Treasury has announced its intention to raise $2.6 billion in additional cash over the 13-week period beginning Dec. 11. It will do this through the bill market.

Arthur Cantor, theatrical publicist, has added a second play to his Broadway production schedule for next season. It is called "Come Blow Your Horn" and it is written by Neil Simon, one of television's busiest writers.

Charles Abrams, chairman of the State Commission Against Discrimination, said yesterday that more complaints had been filed with his agency in the first nine months of this year than at any other similar period since its organization in 1945. Its work, he said, forms part of a "morality contest that is going on between two sections of the country."

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 1 -Senator Albert S. Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, chairman of the Senate Subcommittee on Roads, suggested here today that the Government's General Fund be used for the Federal Highway Program, which is costing $13,000,000,000 more than expected.

FOR the holiday season now under way, restaurants with private dining rooms are one solution for those who wish to entertain but do not have adequate facilities at home. Prices for such service range from $3.50 to $50 a person, depending on the restaurant, the menu and on how freely wines and liquors are poured.
PARIS, Dec. 1 -- The last obstacle to Premier Charles de Gaulle's assumption of the French Presidency was removed today by Preseident Rene Coty. M.
Iain Macleod, British Minister of Labor and National Service, was the guest of honor last night at the 202d annual dinner of the St. Andrew's Society of New York.
BEING in an amiable frame of mind, Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d have written a pleasant musical play, "Flower Drum Song," put on at the refurbished St. James Theatre last evening.

The leaders of New York's 25,000 longshoremen voted overwhelmingly yesterday for a showdown fight against the off-pier "containerization" of ship freight and what they call the automation of dockside cargo handling.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Following is the text of a statement today by Secretary Flemming on the closing of public schools:
American transport workers yesterday tied up seventy-two "flag of convenience" ships in a boycott scheduled to last until Thursday.

FRESH cranberries are reaching their peak of supply in local markets with the advent of the holiday season. The plump, firm berries with their bright color and high luster are invitingly packaged in one-pound cellophane bags and see-through window boxes.
I take strong exception to the statement in your Nov. 18 editorial "Israel and the Refugees" that "Israel did, in fact, readmit 48,500 refugees."

GENEVA, Dec. 1 -- Western experts at the conference on guarding against surprise attack said today that technical proposals made last week by the Communist bloc were irrelevant to the problem of modern weapons.
PARIS, Dec. 1 -- France took a leap into the unknown yesterday in a legislative election that was basically a plebiscite approval of Premier Charles de Gaulle. I

HAVANA, Dec. 1 -- Cuban rebels have cut off the water supply of the Preston sugar mill, owned by the United Fruit Company. Plans are being made to evacuate the United States employes and their families, William G. Raines, vice president of the company, said today.
MEXICO CITY, Dec. 1 -Adolfo Lopez Mateos, who became Mexico's President today, made his mark politically by speaking little but exceedingly well.
MEXICO CITY, Dec. 1 - Adolfo Lopez Mateos, 48-year-old lawyer and former Minister of Labor, was inaugurated today for a six-year term as President of Mexico.
Roland LaStarza, a heavyweight from the Bronx who once fought for the title, failed in his first bid for a comeback at St. Nicholas Arena last night.

VAN NUYS, Calif., Dec. 1 (UPI) -- Federal Bureau of Investigation agents today arrested John E. Petersen on charges of embezzling $1,000,000 from the Sun Valley National Bank, where he was vice president.
Richmond, Va., announced yesterday it proposed to offer $4,920,000 of public improvement bonds, due from 1960 to 1979, on Dec. 17.
Size, speed and savvy are the trademarks of the 1958 Associated Press All-East football team.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Dec. 1 (UPI) -- Harry Gross was accused by the Federal Government today of evading more than a million dollars in taxes during one of the years he headed a $20,000,000-a-year bookmaking ring in Brooklyn.
LONDON, Dec. 1 -The Aluminum Company of America Alcoa) said in a statement tonight that it had no intention of acquiring control of the British Aluminium Company, and had no desire to.

A standing-room-only crowd of 20,350 fans, most of whom screamed, jumped up and down and cheered heroes, filled Madison Square Garden last night for the final professional wrestling theatrical show of the year.
Don Carter, the defending champion, is favored to win the men's world invitation match-game championship at Chicago's Coliseum next week. The tournament, which starts Thursday, will finish Dec. 12.

Whether or not one is personally an adventurer at heart, it is an encouraging sign of the frontier spirit that many Americans are willing, even eager, to face the unknown. It was reported in the newspaper recently that more than 25,000 people have already applied by letter for the single berth on the first flight to the moon.

Directors of the Chain Belt Company authorized a stock distribution of one additional share for each two shares held at a meeting yesterday in Milwaukee. They also declared their intention to increase the regular quarterly dividend.
November sales in the eight major department stores in the New York metropolitan area fell 1 per cent below those of the 1957 period, a survey made yesterday by [The New York Times showed.
Contracts for future construction soared above the $3,000,000,000 mark in October, the F. W. Dodge Corporation reported yesterday.
RALEIGH, N. C., Dec. 1 (AP) -- North Carolina State unveiled its 1958-59 basketball squad today with a 70-54 victory over Penn State.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Nov. 30 -- The new Government has decided that an agreement with the United States on assistance should stand and that all restrictions imposed by Parliament should be swept away.

The New York Knickerbockers, pace-setters in the Eastern Division, will be seeking a 3-1 season's edge over Boston when they engage the rugged Celtics in the feature game of the National Basketball Association double - header at Madison Square Garden tonight.

John Kenneth Galbraith, Professor of Economics at Harvard University, has been chosen to receive the ninth annual Tamiment Book Award for his volume "The Affluent Society." The presentation of the $500 award will be made by Senator Paul H. Douglas at a luncheon ceremony Dec. 13 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Dec. 1 -- The issue of fluoridation of water, the source of much heated debate in this north Westchester community for more than two years, was settled tonight. The village's fluoridation plan will be dropped.

ATHENS, Dec. 1 -- Stratis Andreadis, chairman of the Union of Greek Shipowners, told a press conference today that Scandinavian, Dutch and British shipping interests were behind the boycott of vessels flying "flags of convenience."
BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Dec. 1 -- A new educational film intended to promote savings was shown for the first time today at the annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Conflicting views between major mining groups apparently snagged negotiations today for a labor contract in the soft coal industry.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Treasury announced today that it would take bids for $400,000,000 in twenty-six-week bills at the start of a new program leading to a half-year cycle.
Henry Cabot Lodge spoke yesterday in below-freezing weather at a brief groundbreaking ceremony for the new office building to house the United States mission to the United Nations.

The New York City government is excused from a bad bargain by the decision of Sanitation Department workers to forget pension revision, at least for a while, in favor of better wages. Last summer the Wagner administration, apparently in an effort to ward off a threatened strike that would have been illegal, offered pension revisions in a direction long sought by union leaders.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The annual battle over the nation's foreign economic policy started today with the Administration more divided than ever over how to deal with the Communist world's economic offensive.
Chandelier earrings, great glitter pins paved with mock diamonds and huge-domed sparkler rings are all around to dazzle the evening season. Their only big failing: total eclipse when worn in groups.

Bruno Eisner, Vienna-born pianist and teacher, has not been heard in recital here since 1940. His concert last night at Carnegie Recital Hall included the Sonata in A minor, Op. 164, of Schubert, the Etudes Symphoniques of Schumann, Two Polish Dances by Karol Rathaus and two works of Liszt.

The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday declines in operating revenues and net income for the first ten months of this year. But the big utility showed gains for October in comparison with 1957 results.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 1 -- Dr. James R. Killian Jr. stepped down voluntarily today from the presidency of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. On his recommendation Dr. Julius A. Stratton, its chancellor, will become president of the institute Jan. 1.

The Lambert Trophy, representing the Eastern major college football championship, was voted yesterday to the Army eleven. It completed its first unbeaten season since 1949 last Saturday by beating Navy to gain the award for the seventh time.
CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- A fastspreading fire today killed at least eighty-seven Chicago school children and three nuns.

With the year-end approaching, Christmas bonuses have become a major topic of conversation. Yesterday the National Industrial Conference Board reported that of 110 companies that gave their employes a monetary Christmas present last year, sixty-eight reported they would do so again this year.
The big get bigger by going regional. This appears to be one way for the advertising industry's larger agencies to enlist new business without running into account conflicts.

The French electorate voted not wisely but too well. Premier de Gaulle hoped for a moderate, centrist, balanced National Assembly. Instead he has a Parliament heavily weighted toward the Right, with its main party, the Union for the New Republic, fully expected to strive for the "integration" of Algeria into Metropolitan France. General de Gaulle has been aiming at Algerian autonomy within a broad confederation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Secretary of Defense Neil H. McElroy said today he was "highly skeptical" about the possibility that the Soviet Union had flown the world's first atomic-powered airplane.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 1 -- The story of the Boy Scouts and the British founder of the movement, the late Lord Baden-Powell, will be the subject of Cecil B. De Mille's next motion picture, "On My Honor."

The Federal Bureau of Investigation says it has located a stolen copy of this country's greatest airmail rarity, a twenty-four-cent stamp showing a mistakenly inverted airplane. However, the Midwest dealer who has the copy denies that it is the stolen stamp.
PARIS, Dec. 1 -- The number of former territories to join the new French Overseas Community rose to eight today with the accession of Ubangi-Shari in French Equatorial Africa.

COLUMBUS, Ga., Dec. 1 (AP) -- A commission of the Presbytery Of Southwest Georgia has proclaimed the right of a minister of the Southern Presbyterian Church to speak openly but with humility on the racial issue.
PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 1 -- A committee, of Princeton University seniors today unanimously recommended acceptance of all sophomores by eating clubs for upperclassmen.

Rajkumari (Princess) Amrit Kaur, a member of Parliament in India and secretary to the late Mohandas K. Gandhi for fifteen years, urged American churchgoers yesterday to take the lead in seeking world peace.

THE incident is still clear in memory although some of the details have grown a trifle hazy over the years. The Manhattan College basketball team was to play a game in the little campus gymnasium atop a Riverdale hilltop. An hour before the start there were as many eager fans trying to gain admittance as there were inside.
MOSCOW, Dec. 1 -- The city of Leningrad appears to have been chosen to lead the way in a nation-wide campaign against drunkards and hooligans and vigilance against foreign agents.
A tax on legalized off-track betting offers a solution to the city's fiscal problem, the Democratic minority leader of the State Senate said yesterday.
Rush-hour commuters were delayed for short periods yesterday morning by four mechanical failures in the Bronx, Queens and Brooklyn.

New York University officially said it with flowers yesterday to prove that "the Violets" haven't faded after all. Vic Obeck, the director of athletics, said that the school's old nickname was back in bloom. "Vikings,'' a substitute nickname chosen in 1957, has been discarded.
The subfreezing cold that seized the city and its environs Sunday stayed on yesterday, but its bite was a little less sharp.
A clearing house for political information will be set up in mid-Manhattan this week to facilitate insurgent movements within the Democratic party.

Dividend Shares, Inc., reported yesterday new highs in net assets and number of shareholders as of Oct. 31, end of the fiscal year. The mutual fund's stockholder list increased to 92,400 from 87,000 at the end of the preceding fiscal year.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 1 (UPI) -- Following is the text of the letter from President Eisenhower to President Adolfo Lopez Mateos:
A television adaptation of Ernest Hemingway's "For Whom the Bell Tolls" will be presented in two ninety-minute installments on "Playhouse 90" later this season.

The Chase Manhattan Bank, which became the first bank in New York City to offer retail charge account credit yesterday, said that three times as many merchants had signed up under its plan as had been expected to do so initially.
PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 1 -Frank C. Szvetecz, brother of the captain of the 1956 Army football team, was elected captain of the 1959 Princeton eleven tonight.
TOKYO, Dec. 1 -- The Japanese welcomed President Carlos P. Garcia of the Philippines here today with an unusual show of eagerness.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 1 -- Nearing the end of his golfing vacation here, President Eisenhower today scheduled a Wednesday meeting with his National Aeronautics and Space Council. It will be followed by the first of two sessions with the National Security Council.
The New York State Advisory Committee of the Federal Civil Rights Commission chose Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, president of City College, as temporary chairman at its organizational meeting yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 1 -- A United Nations committee adopted four measures today and then quit for the day after a twenty-minute session. It thereby established an unofficial speed record for this General Assembly.
Montgomery Ward Co. yesterday reported that sales for the quarter and nine months ended with Oct. 31 were above were last year's, but earnings somewhat lower.
A union of hospital employes met last night to set the date for a strike against Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx. The date decided on will be made public today, according to a union spokesman.
THREE new developments have made possible a greater selection of Fiberglas casement and drapery fabrics.
DETROIT, Dec. 1 (AP) -Milk route truck drivers, angered over price cuts in supermarkets, today cut off most of the milk supply to homes and stores here and in Pontiac.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- British dock workers today boycotted a majority of ships flying "flags of convenience." In only one instance was the boycott ignored. That was at Hull, where unloading of a Liberian freighter continued.
The Crompton-Richmond Company, Inc., textile manufacturer has announced the election of Howard Richmond as president.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Dec. 1 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion survived a parliamentary attempt today to unseat him for having accused an Israeli Chief Rabbi of "maliciously misleading" the public.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Air Force has studied a new automatic air freight handling system.

THE sun never sets on discussions of what caused the decline and fall of the Roman Empire -- ostensibly rich in lessons for our own day. A question, of course, is which lesson to accept as historically accurate and germane. The cinematic arts dearly love to show us stupendous spectacles of frenzied and rather expensive revels on the road to Roman ruin.

GREAT NECK, L. I., Dec. 1 -- A 14-year-old boy shot his mother and sister and then turned his .22-caliber repeating rifle on himself in the family's nine-room split level home in Saddle Rock Village near Great Neck tonight, the Nassau County police said.

Events today: Rossini's "Mose" in concert form, American Opera Society Arnold Gamson conducting, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Herbert Rogers, pianist, Town Hall, 8:30; Beatrice Ohanessian, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- A special hearing examiner recommended today that the Federal Communications Commission revoke its grant of television Channel 10 in Miami because of attempts at improper influence.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UPI) -A Washington lawyer said today that his operatives had been using an electronic device to eavesdrop on Representative Coya Knutson (Democrat of Minnesota).

The inquiry into charges of extravagence in the city's school-construction program is a "herculean job" requiring months of intensive effort, Jacob Grumet, chairman of the State Commission of Investigation, said yesterday.

The wartime failure of the United States to assess correctly the strategic and political importance of Berlin was magnified by mistaken judgments and decisions reached during the long discussions (with British and Soviet leaders) that led to the formulation of occupation zones in Germany.
Fifty-four art students tried yesterday in oils, water col ors and ink to capture the day's events on the New York Stock Exchange.

While threatening to drive the Western powers out of Berlin, the Soviets continue to hamstring the two East-West conferences on armament controls now under way in Geneva. These are the conferences on a controlled nuclear weapons test ban and on reducing the hazard of surprise attacks.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 1 -- The United States approved today an Indian draft resolution asking the United Nations Scientific Committee on the Effects of Atomic Radiation to "continue its useful work."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- A 55-year-old medical officer who has spent more than half his life in military service is the new Surgeon General of the Air Force.
TRENTON, Dec. 1-- Gov. Robert B. Meyner presided today at a Democratic conference called to select party officers for the 1959 session of the Assembly and Senate.
The race track inquiry by the State Commission of Investigation continued yesterday as three clubhouse messengers at the Jamaica Race Track were questioned in the commission office, 270 Broadway.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 -- The Green Bay Packers picked first in the National Football League's annual preliminary draft today and got Iowa's Hearst (Randy) Duncan, generally acknowledged the nation's No. 1 college quarterback.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Dec. 1 -- A number of Ceylonese were reported today to have been the objects of an unsuccessful assassination plot two weeks ago.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -Libya, one of the West's best friends in the Arab world, is seeking more economic assistance from the United States.

MOSCOW, Dec. 1 -- The major assignment of Soviet science in the next seven years will be to find ways of controlling thermonuclear reactions to harness the power of the hydrogen bomb for peaceful energy.
Talks between state and city representatives on the city's tentative fiscal program for 1959-60 will begin tomorrow afternoon at 2:30 o'clock.

This is the season for buying gifts, running up bills, avoiding all-night office parties and picking all-star football teams. No fair-minded citizen will deny that choosing gifts or being a party-pooper is far easier than selecting all-star teams.

Exchange visits by Italian-American youths from East Harlem and similar groups of youngsters from Puerto Rico will be sought by a "good neighbor" committee formed to reduce Italian-Puerto Rican friction in East Harlem.
The prospects for producing usable power from hydrogen-bomb reactions appear to be about the same for deep underground explosions and for reactions tamed in machines.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 1 (AP) -The Cincinnati Royals, who are last in the Western Division of the National Basketball Association, today ousted Bobby Wanzer as coach. Tom Marshall was named to succeed him.
MASSENA, N. Y., Dec. 1 (AP) -- A $7,000,000 toll bridge over the St. Lawrence River between Massena and Cornwall Island, Ont. was dedicated today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UPI) -- An engineer for the New York State Power Authority charged today that its Niagara project on the Tuscarora Indian Reservation was being sabotaged.

In their search for more revenue to meet an expected deficit of $200,000,000 in the state budget next year, Republican leaders are considering increases of 2 cents in the gasoline tax and 1 cent in the cigarette tax.

Pan American World Airways won a union pledge yesterday that the line's operations would not be hampered by strikes or slowdowns until all peace-making machinery of the Railway Labor Act had been exhausted.

A sixty - four - foot white spruce that four days ago was growing in a Maine forest stood in Rockefeller Plaza yesterday, a white plastic star at its tip, its branches reaching over hurrying crowds. It was the Christmas-tree gift of the Pine Tree State to Rockefeller Center.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., announced yesterday a reduction of 10 cents a pound in the price of Dacron polyester filament yarn. The company also announced that certain categories of Dacron staple and tow had been reduced about 8 per cent. Excepted from the price decrease were 1,100 denier Dacron and Fiberfill stuffing.
BOSTON, Dec. 1 -- The growth of metropolitan problems was pictured before the nation's mayors today as a possible menace to the nation's survival.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Dec. 1 -- The nation's investment bankers were told here today that the American economy would probably run below full capacity for many months, but that powerful expansionary influences would carry it in due course to new records of production.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 -- Bert Bell, the commissioner of the National Football League, today told the twelve club owners to "quit your squabbling and make your coaches quit their squawking." Bell threatened to quit unless his warning was heeded.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 1 (AP) -- First Landing, the winner of ten of his eleven starts this season, was named the 2-year-old champion colt of 1958 and Neji the champion steeplechase horse of the year, by the Thoroughbred Racing Associations today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The major leagues today put into operation the minor league draft machinery they adopted in Colorado a year ago. It produced some bizarre results. In the end there were twelve players drafted.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Donald C. Rarick, a leader of an insurgent element within the United Steelworkers of America, went on trial today before five fellow union members on charges of violating the union's constitution.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The grain futures market showed some indications today of making a general, if limited, advance but after a test of both sides it fell back into its recent narrow, irregular range.
CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (AP) -- A safety expert predicted today that 50,000 persons would be killed in traffic accidents in 1966 unless effective action was taken.

Disbandment of the Civil Aeronautics Administration's technical development center in Indianapolis and its consolidation with new air research activities in Washington and Atlantic City are scheduled to take place by next June 30.

The heart of the controversy between Controller Lawrence Gerosa and the Board of Education lies in the Controller's bitter opposition to spending money for building schools. Although his immediate target is the $500 million bond issue outside the debt limit, his opposition is more deep-seated and long-standing.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -Arthur S. Flemming reported today that more than a million student-days already had been lost by the closings of public schools to avoid integration.
A two-hour meeting yesterday failed to resolve a dispute that has cut off deliveries of most New York City newspapers in Nassau and Suffolk Counties since Thursday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Third United States Circuit Court of Appeals has agreed to look into the constitutionality of a 164-year-old Pennsylvania law that forbids nonessential business on Sundays.

THE artist as explorer is nowhere better revealed than in his drawings. Attention, inexhaustible patience and ever - renewable excitement are the traits of the explorer - draftsman, and Jack Tworkov is richly endowed with all of them.

Ellen Benn announced last night that she had resigned as a probation officer of the Children's Court. She had been termed as an "uncooperative witness" before a grand jury investigating alleged graft in the Building Department.

The East squad for the thirtyfourth annual Shrine East-West football game at Kezar Stadium, San Francisco, on Dec. 27, was named yesterday by the managing director, William M. Coffman. It is made up of players representing twelve universities and eleven states.

TOKYO, Dec. 1 -- Asia's increasing population engaged the attention of some of the world's leading social scientists today in the opening business session of the ninth International Conference of Social Work. The problem was described as "explosive."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- (UPI) -- The executive committee of the National Federation of Post Office Clerks suspended the officers of nine city locals today and placed them in the hands of trustees.
JAMMU, Kashmir, Dec. 1 -- The Kashmir treason case was temporarily suspended today when a special magistrate granted a two-week postponement to the chief defendent, Sheik Mohammed Abdullah.
Only two school fires in the last 100 years of United States history have cost more lives than the tragedy in Chicago yesterday according to The Associated Press.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Maj. Gen. Alvin R. Luedecke was sworn as general manager of the Atomic Energy Commission today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Carlos Lozano, 10, whose leg was injured in a leap from a second floor window, said:
The Central Railroad Company of New Jersey estimated yesterday that its losses for 1958 would total about $2,000,000.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 1 -- The rural wing of the opposition National party emerged today as the winner of Uruguay's general election yesterday. The governing Colorado party was crushed.
New developments in automation, nucleonics and electronics will bring with them "priceless benefits," Harvey S. Firestone Jr. predicted here last night.
LONDON, Dec. 1 -- The Soviet Union may be prepared to alter its policy and to negotiate realistically on the future of Germany for military reasons, British sources said today.
LONDON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Fire broke out in a clothing factory today. Three cutters on the fourth floor were blacked by flames and smoke from the fire escape.
DETROIT, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The United Auto Workers called a strike against Electric Auto-Lite Company plants in six cities today. About 8,500 workers are affected.
FRAMINGHAM, Mass., Dec. 1 -- Sir Hubert Wilkins, the noted polar explorer, was found dead of a coronary occlusion today in his hotel room here. He was 70 years old.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Adlai E. Stevenson says "I am not and I will not" be a candidate for a third Presidential nomination in 1960.
WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 1 (AP) -- A suit by a group of Mesabi Iron Company stockholders against that company and the Reserve Mining Company was remanded to the Delaware Court of Chancery today.

The Union Carbide Corporation announced yesterday it had exercised its option to buy from the Amoco Chemicals Corporation "the utilizable facilities" that remain on a 306-acre tract at Brownsville, Texas, where Amoco formerly operated a chemical plant. The price was not disclosed.

Sharp declines in cocoa futures were registered yesterday for the third consecutive trading day on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The market closed at or near, the lows of the day. Final quotations were 42 to 86 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) lower on 458 lots.
The so-called "privileged parkers" seem to be the most glaring offenders of New York's parking regulations.
FAIRPORT, N. Y., Dec. 1 (AP) -- A Baptist minister, the Rev. Russell Moore, 56 years old, was killed today when his automobile skidded off a little-used road and plunged into the Barge Canal.
PARIS, Dec. 1 -- The Prix Goncourt, France's principal literary prize, was awarded today to Francis Walder, a Belgian.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 1 -- President Tito left Belgrade tonight on the first leg of his long-awaited trip to Indonesia, Burma, India, Egypt and Ethiopia. He is expected to be gone for two and a half months.

Leonard L. Farber and Frank Wittman, owners of the real estate concern of Farber-Wittman, Inc., have announced that the company has been dissolved. The former associates have opened separate real estate offices.
A retired Long Island brick-layer who was kidnapped by Sicilian bandits last month returned to the United States yesterday. He vowed that he would never return to Sicily.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) --The Washington Post said tonight that the Government had settled its $8,000,000 tax case against Frank Erickson, the gambler, for $2,700,000. The Government conceded Erickson had been overcharged, the paper declared.

" Rally Round the Flag, Boys!" will be the next attraction at the Palace Theatre, upon the completion of the run there of "The Roots of Heaven." "Rally Round the Flag, Boys!" is Twentieth Century-Fox' film version of the Max Shulman novel.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 1 - Chancellor Konrad Adenauer took the unusual step today of conferring with the leaders of West German political parties other than his own in an effort to mold a national policy on the Berlin crisis.

Americans live with a "fun morality," but that is not necessarily an evil nor does it presage a disintegration of the family or society, the president of the New York So ciety for Clinical Psychiatry said yesterday.
CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Workmen began turning off the water taps in twelve old buildings near City Hall yesterday, preparatory to starting demolition next week on the site of an $8,000,000 cooperative housing project. It is being sponsored by the Municipal Credit Union and the State Credit Union League.

BERLIN, Dec. 1 -- The Soviet Union's insistence on turning over its occupation responsibilities to East Germany has voided any chance that the Western Allies might accept East German control of access to Berlin, according to responsible diplomatic sources.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Dec. 1 (AP) -- Army's year of the lonesome end also was the year of the forward pass for the unbeaten cadets.

In your editorial of Nov. 25 "Air Strikes and Labor Law" you refer to the apparent ineffectiveness of the Railway Labor Act in preventing strikes on the nation's airlines. You refer to the failure of mediation, the refusal of either or both parties to refer the disputes to arbitration, and the inability of the emergency boards appointed by the President to provide a basis for the resolution of these disputes.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezrk Benson today told a convention of bankers that every agricultural lender should try to help borrowers find ways to meet high farm costs and investments.

A brief and simple ceremony at the southwest corner of First Avenue and Forty-fifth Street yesterday morning expressed a certain faith on the part of the United States in the future of the United Nations. To be exact, about $3,750,000 worth of faith. The occasion was the dedication of the site for the office building, opposite the main U. N. structures, which we plan to complete in 1960.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Villanova, making use of its height advantage, defeated LeMoyne College, 83 -- 67, in the opener of a Palestra basketball double-header tonight.
More than $18,000,000 of common stocks in five different companies are being offered to investors today. The offerings are:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 1 -- India proposed today that the General Assembly endorse "self-government" for Cyprus and the "preservation of its integrity." This would rule out Turkish proposals for the partition of Britain's island colony.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Performance in the Victorian tennis championships here probably will decide the make-up of the American Davis Cup team for the inter-zone final, the United States captain, Perry Jones, said today.
The facts in labor disputes involving four airlines are as follows:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UPI) -- The Army said today that its Nike-Hercules anti-aircraft missile had destroyed a supersonic target flying faster than 1,500 miles an hour and more than twelve miles high.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Government began a nation-wide search today to recruit some 200 talented young engineers and scientists for research work in key Federal laboratories.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Administration will soon offer a comprehensive plan, including special tax incentive, to encourage increased private investment abroad, a House inquiry was told today.

GENEVA, Dec. 1 -- Member states of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation outside the six-nation European Common Market met here today to plan a joint approach to the market's threat of discrimination to their trade.

MOURA LYMPANY gave a piano recital at Carnegie Hall last night that was full of delicate nuance and was continuously interesting. However, it was only toward the end of her program that she came fully into her own and played with the sort of authority that holds an audience as if in a spell.
ATLANTA, Dec. 1 (AP) -The first of five men charged with dynamiting The Jewish Temple here went on trial for his life today.
IT may not be a white Christmas, but it definitely will be a furry one.

DETROIT, Dec. 1 -- The thirty-second annual winter national championships continued here this afternoon at the Sheraton Cadillac Hotel. Three hundred fifty-six contract bridge players are competing in three simultaneously conducted individual championships.
Eleven city inspection teams poked through eleven buildings yesterday in the heart of once-proud Morningside Heights in an effort to determine whether they were slums.

The Louisiana State Tigers, who compiled the only perfect record in major college football this fall, yesterday were named the 1958 national champions by United Press International's board of coaches.
It's fortunate that Dan Lynch, the St. Francis College basketball coach, has a sense of humor. If he didn't, he would be an unhappy fellow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The index of wholesale prices in primary markets remained steady at 119.1 per cent of its 1947-49 level during the week ended Tuesday, Nov. 25, 1958, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 1 -- The Finnish Cabinet of Premier Karl-August Fagerholm was still in office today, with negotiations toward the formation of a new Government scheduled to continue tomorrow.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregular yesterday, 14 points lower to 3 points higher, with a moderate amount of business. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

The old Washington Retail Market is among 119 parcels of city-owned real estate that will be offered at public auction on Dec. 15. The sale will be held by the Bureau of Real Estate, with Joseph P. Day, Inc., as auctioneer, at the Biltmore Hotel.
BERNARDSTON, Mass., Dec. 1 -- The Massachusetts deer season opened this morning under half-ideal conditions, whatever that means.
Samuel G. Blackman was appointed general news editor of The Associated Press yesterday. He will work directly under the executive editor, Alan J. Gould.
THE Ricardo family of television -- Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz -- and the Williams family -- Danny Thomas and Marjorie Lord -- joined forces last night for an hour of broad comedy on Channel 2.

DETROIT, Dec. 1 (AP) -- General Motors Corporation said today that its production of cars and trucks in United States and Canadian factories in November totaled 313,939 units, the highest since last January.
Senator Jacob If. Javits said yesterday that he would ask ttle State Department wt%ether the United States Embassy in :South Africa has a social color !bar.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- A team from industry, universities and government will be formed soon to deal with air pollution problems.

THE home cook who has several party meals scheduled for the holiday season might find it worth-while to invest in Mrs. Evelyn R. Patterson's "Gourmet Kitchen" (Abelard-Schuman, 158 pp., $3.50). Between the covers of this new cookbook are recipes for many delightful dishes that neatly combine distinctive flavor with ease and economy of preparation.

SADDLE ROCK, L. I., Dec. 2 -- An investigation disclosed today that James Wiener, the 14-year-old boy who killed his mother, sister and himself with rifle shots last night, had been referred to a school psychologist recently for examination.
Robert Moses, holder of many public offices and the storm center in many civic controversies, has declined to bow to a new opponent -- Father Time.

COMFORT is evident in the Cumberland Furniture Corporation's new group of contemporary designs. These pieces, all of which have well-proportioned, clean lines, are on display in Cumberland's new showroom at 4 East Fifty-third Street.

Thomas W. (Teddy) Gleason Sr., the diminutive dynamo of the International Longshoremen's Association, defied doctors' orders yesterday in an effort to head off a threatened collapse of relations between the union and waterfront employers here.

Final voting results issued yesterday by the Board of Elections showed that Nelson A. Rockefeller increased the Republican vote for Governor in New York City by 245,350 over the Republican total in 1954.

A plot of land occupying the blockfront on the west side of Broadway from Mosholu Avenue to West 259th Street in the Riverdale area of the Bronx has been purchased by Irving and Hyman Shapiro. It will be improved with two buildings containing 250 apartments. The plot is 400 by 100 feet. It is north of the Riverdale Inn.
LILLIAN HORINBEIN is doing her utmost to make retailing a woman's world

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 2 -- Last season John (Honey) Russell, Seton Hall University's basketball coach, couldn't have had more miserable luck. He lost his first five players before the Pirates began their schedule.
The public was invited yesterday to visit the city's new schools and judge for itself whether funds were wasted on frills in building them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Cleveland Indians tonight obtained Jim Piersall, the Boston Red Sox' crack outfielder, in exchange for a first baseman, Vic Wertz, and a pitcher-outfielder, Gary Geiger. No cash was involved.
Earnings of the Sears Roebuck Acceptance Corporation rose sharply in the nine months ended Oct. 31, reflecting the increase in installment receivables above those in the 1957 period.

ALBANY, Dec. 2 (AP) -- At least sixteen hunters were killed by gunfire during New York State's big-game hunting season, which ended today. Five of the victims were small-game hunters. The total was the highest in recent years.

The vote of the nonprofessional employes at the Montefiore Hospital for a walk-out next Monday if their demands aren't met raises issues more far-flung than the state of things in that particular hospital -- important though that is. Most important, of course, is the threat to the health and welfare of the public implicit in any hospital strike.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., Dec. 2 -- The annual Christmas Bazaar of St. Mark's Protestant Episcopal Church will take place on Saturday at the Church House. Mrs. Theodore Hobbs is chairman of the fair.
CHICAGO, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Buyers for baking interests helped the grain futures market today and set off a light to moderate general demand on the Board of Trade.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Jack Kramer's answer to the ban imposed on his professionals by the Lawn Tennis Association of Australia is a twenty-four-ton portable court, which he says may revolutionize the game.

MALIBU BEACH, Calif., Dec. 2 (AP) -- A mountain brush fire, officially pronounced as bad as the blaze of two years ago, swept to the Pacific Ocean tonight after destroying twenty- five homes and sending hundreds fleeing.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Federal Government filed an antitrust suit today against three Standard Oil companies, accusing them of restrictive trade practices in five states.
I The City Council adopted , ilocal law yeterday requiring fall commercial and public build. l ings to post in their lobbies signs telling how to sound a fire !alarm as quickly as possible.

An invitation to a weekend in the country calls for clothes completely different from a city wardrobe. There is no rule of thumb for country dressing, but clothes should be less somber and more casual than those worn in the city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The volume of consumer installment, debt rose again in October, for the second time since January. The gain was after allowance for normal seasonal trends. The change included an increase in repay ments of old debt, and a larger increase in extensions of new credit, both seasonally adjusted.
Reading A. H. Raskin's report in your Nov. 28 issue it is evident that the State Chamber of Commerce has misread the election returns.
A survey conducted by the National Association of Manufacturers indicates larger sales next year, but possibly lagging profits.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Dec. 2 -- There is a good chance that Congressional hearings next month will develop bipartisan agreement on certain aspects of tax reform, the convention of the Investment Bankers Association was told here today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 (AP) -The larzesll bulcher hog supply since ,/an. 2 weakened the market sharply today and prices were mostly 50c a hundred pounds lower. The offerings of 1,000 head were 4.000 higher titan expected and nnly 1,000 below th. Jan. 2 high of tile year, The report of today's livestock markets here by tile Department ot Agriculture follows;

Celtics Tie Knicks for Lead in Eastern Division -- Hawk Quintet Victor, 105-81 A whirlwind start, which gave the visitors a 12-0 lead before three minutes had elapsed, sent the Boston Celtics to a 109-90 victory over the New York Knickerbockers last night at Madison Square Garden.
MADRID, Dec. 2 -- The United States is reaping a harvest of favorable attention in Spain because it helped an angel.

Considerable fanfare greeted the Giants' "acquisition" of Lee Grosscup, the ace quarterback from Utah. One of three collegians drafted by the New York club in the National Football League's preliminary draft on Monday, Grosscup already has assured the Giants that he is "delighted to be with you."

Everyone likes the first snow of the year. As it drifts down slowly from the clouds which make no effort to disguise their intent, it lifts the spirit. In some odd way the first snow of the year has much the effect of the first warm day of spring.

American consumers in the last five months have exhibited growing confidence in the country's economy in general and their own financial situations in particular, according to a nation-wide survey made public yesterday.
PARIS, Dec. 2 -- The French Government re-established the post of Inspector General of National Defense today on the eve of Premier Charles de Gaulle's fifth visit to Algeria.
WINDSOR, Ont., Dec. 2 (Canadian Press) -- Michael Patrick was returned as Mayor of Windsor last night with the highest plurality he has received in his three successful bids for the office.

The elections in Uruguay on Sunday came up with a dramatic surprise. For the first time in ninety-three years the Blancos, or Nationals, have won a clear majority. The Colorados went down to a resounding defeat as a party, and their leader for thirteen years, who appeared to have an unbeatable political machine, Luis Batlle Berres, was repudiated.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 2 (AP) -- A Federal judge upheld James R. Hoffa today in ruling three rank-and-file members of the Teamsters Union ineligible to run for office in a Youngstown local.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 2 -- The United States will vote for an Iranian resolution calling for negotiations on the future of Cyprus, authoritative sources said tonight.
Maj. Gen. John B. Medaris, director of the Army missile and space programs, said last night that engineering skills ultimately would resolve the problems of space exploration.

"Suburbia: Its People and Their Politics," by Robert C. Wood, will be issued Jan. 13 by Houghton Mifflin. Since the author is a political scientist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, his book is described as "a political scientist's lively birds-eye view of the areas where one of every four Americans now live."
LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan promised today to keep an open mind on proposals for negotiation with the Soviet Union on Berlin and Germany.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 2 -- Annual pay increases of $800 for this city's 1,400 firemen and policemen were approved on first reading today by the City Commission. There will be a public hearing on the increase two weeks from today, and then the commission will take final action.
SHUSHAN, N. Y., Dec. 2 -Doe day here against the western border of Vermont seemed to cast some doubt on the hardihood of the strong, hardy outdoorsmen, but it didn't prove anything much.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- This was the day the players took over in the annual winter sessions of baseball's major and minor leagues today. They made it a long and exciting inning.

PARIS, Dec. 2 -- The real winner of France's parliamentary elections was not General de Gaulle but the right wing of the Gaullist movement. It was obvious that the General himself would emerge triumphant, for every valid party save the Communists campaigned in his name.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Dec. 2 -- Despite the possibility of another European crisis over Berlin, Western business men are streaming into Prague to get a cut of Czechoslovakia's big investment program. It is estimated at 300,000,000,000 crowns for the next seven years.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 2 -- The United States called on the Soviet Union today to drop the bars on communications into and out of the Soviet Union.

The American Floor Machine Company, manufacturer of polishing and finishing machines, leased the one-story office and warehouse building at 31-19 Thirty-seventh Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, from the Kimlark Construction Corporation.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 2 -- Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg will become one nation economically early next year, under a timetable worked out here today.
Nat Hiken is expected to produce at least one more "Man of the Hour" show for presentation over the Columbia Broadcasting System television network.

Thirteen persons were killed by automobiles in the city last week, when vehicular traffic was much heavier because of the Thanksgiving holiday. Sixteen persons were killed in the same period in 1957, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 2 -- another postponement was necessary today in the start of Nassau's fifth annual international sports car events. The opening race for the Tourist Trophy, put off from Sunday because of the rain squalls, now has been delayed until Thursday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- John L. Lewis has won a $2-a-day wage increase and other concessions for his soft coal miners in northern mines, informed sources reported tonight.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- The Japanese Government signed a contract today for 10,000 square feet of exhibit space at the 1959 Chicago International Trade Fair. This made Japan the largest single exhibitor booked so far.
A rare serum needed for a critically ill boy was flown by jet to Chicago yesterday after an all-night search from coast to coast.

THE most intriguing aspect of the voting for the most valuable player in the National League was not the landslide victory of Ernie Banks with 283 points. The Cub shortstop was the logical choice even though logic hasn't always governed these elections. The more fascinating part of the tabulation was at the bottom.
BERLIN, Dec. 2 -- West Berlin businessmen and banks are paying a price for operating in an isolated city suddenly made less secure by Soviet threats.

ATLANTA, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The state said today that it intended to prove that George Allen Bright was on the scene at the time the Jewish temple was dynamited here in the early morning hours of Oct. 12.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- One month after the Republican defeat in the November election, and another month before the State of the Union Message to the new Democratic Congress, Vice President Richard M. Nixon has quietly started trying to rebuild the Republican party organization.

The Cooper Union Forum will continue its Music in the Making series during 1959. A fifty- symphony orchestra, to be piece conducted by Howard Shanet, will be organized for the five Friday evening concerts.
One of the more interesting all-America football teams appeared in print yesterday in the form of the National Football League's annual draft list.
GENEVA, Dec. 2 -- The Soviet Union called today for simultaneous negotiation on its inspection plan to guard against surprise attack and the geographic limits of the zones it proposed for inspection.
Deliveries of most New York newspapers in Nassau and Suffolk Counties were still halted last night despite all-day efforts to resolve the dispute that caused the stoppage.
Industrial sales will increase in 1959 but profits will not keep, 'pace, according to 3,212 busi-[ ness executives polled by the National Association of Manufacturers.
More than $100,000,000 in new utility bonds, preferred and common stocks and new bank capital shares are on the market today. The offerings are:

Investment bankers led by Kuhn, Loeb Co. and Ladenburg, Thalmann Co. are joining today with the World Bank in a combined operation to provide $50,000,000 for various projects in the Republic of Austria.
An advertising card included in error in 5,260,000 copies of the Oct. 20 issue of Life magazine may cost that publication as much as $1,000,000 in postage due.
The Soviet threat to drive the Western troops out of Berlin presents the Western powers not only with a challenge but also with an opportunity.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- An announcement is scheduled for tomorrow of a compromise between the Army and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration on control of the personnel and facilities of the Army's present space programs.

Carmen Di Biasi, who surrendered to the police last August because he was "disgusted with hiding out" since 1952, was convicted of first-degree murder last night. He will be sentenced to death Jan. 12.

The prices of shoes at retail will rise about 10 per cent next spring, according to spokesmen for the Popular Price Shoe Show of America. Higher costs of leather and labor cannot be absorbed by the industry, it was said yesterday at the five-day event, which opened Sunday at the New Yorker and Sheraton-McAlpin Hotels.
The Philippine Ambassador to the United States warned Americans last night that the Far East must be considered the first line of defense in the free world's struggle against communism.

The producing routine at the Phoenix, a nonprofit venture, keeps its operators, T. Edward Hambleton and Norris Houghton, hopping. As soon as one of the bills at the Second Avenue and Twelfth Street cultural citadel is about to open, the management becomes immersed in another.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 2 -- Out of radio sets throughout Uruguay's farm lands came the familiar voice of Benito Nardone today at 11:30 A. M., as usual.
LONDON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Soviet Union has started supplying jet fighters, tanks and other arms to Iraq, diplomats said today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- Investigators searched without success today for the cause of yesterday's fire that took ninety lives in Our Lady of the Angels parochial school on Chicago's West Side. Eighty-seven of the victims were children attending the grade school and three were nuns, who were their teachers.
Pete Dawkins, Army's captain and versatile right half-back, yesterday was named the Heisman Trophy winner as the outstanding college football player of the year.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Dec. 2 -The financial ills of two ailing transportation industries, aviation and railroading, were aired at the second general session of the Investment Bankers' Association convention here today.
REDDING, Conn., Dec. 2 -- A public library founded in this small community in Fairfield County by Samuel L. Clemens will observe the fiftieth anniversary of its incorporation tomorrow.

CREDIT the American Opera Society with the curiosity to rediscover neglected works of significance and the determination to present them no matter how imposing their difficulties. Its effort in behalf of Rossini's "Mose" at Carnegie Hall last night was a prime example of its ambition.

GREENSBORO, N. C., Dec. 2 (UPI) -- The head of one of the nation's biggest textile companies called today for an increase in the Federal minimum wage from $1 to $1.25 an hour as "the only equitable...

Commodity futures closed generally lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cottonseed oil, copper, zinc, lead, potatoes, rubber and wool declined; sugar and hides rose, and price movements for cocoa and coffee were mixed.
CAIRO, Dec. 2 -- Iraq looks with deep concern on a reported security agreement between Iran and the United States, the Iraqi Ambassador to Cairo said today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- Arthur S. Link, Professor of History at Northwestern University, has been named editor in chief of the comprehensive edition of Woodrow Wilson's letters and papers by Woodrow Wilson Foundation, the university announced today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 2 -- Guinea will ask tomorrow to become the eighty-second member of the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UPI) -- The United States urged a committee of twenty-one American nations today to focus attention on concrete short-term measures to uplift sagging economies.

The State Industrial Commissioner declared yesterday that employers in the state would have to provide nearly a half million new jobs in the next twelve months if unemployment was to be brought down to the level of September, 1957. of the state's labor force was unemployed. To get back to that level, he said, employers must absorb about 200,000 additional workers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UPI) -- Senate rackets investigators called for a perjury inquiry today after a top official of the Sheet Metal Workers Union denied sworn charges that he had sold labor peace to Midwestern concerns for as much as $27,000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Strategists planning the fight to kill Senate filibusters rejected today the possibility of compromise with the South.

WHEN Edward VII came to the throne of England in 1901 he was 59 years old and had been Prince of Wales so long that his reign was inevitably short. He died in 1910, a fat and genial monarch noted for his enthusiasm for beautiful women, fine food and all of the pleasures available to a royal connoisseur of pleasure.
American Airlines wants unionized pilots to pay it $90,000 a day in damages, even though a court order has kept the line's planes flying in the face of a union strike threat.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy yesterday ordered the removal of the lieutenant in command of detectives at the Charles Street Station, and the return to uniform of three members of his squad.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board estimated today that airmail subsidies in the next fiscal year would total $61,786,000. This would be an increase of $10,455,000 over the current year's subsidy total, and the largest total payment since 1953-54.
The New York County Democratic Committee certified Dennis J. Mahon for a second term on the Board of Elections last night.
LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Stock market prices dipped on a broad front today in the face of small selling.
So many inquiries are now being made on school building in New York City, with jurisdictions overlapping, that what is really needed is an umpire to manage the umpires.

AFTER assiduous research in Harold's Show Spot Cafe in Forty-fifth Street, Michael V. Gazzo has assembled the materials for a sentimental drama, "The Night Circus," which was put on at the Golden last evening.
George Meany, president of the merged labor movement, yesterday handed down his first decision as sole arbitrator in a labor-management dispute and apparently satisfied management.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 2 -The United States has offered Lebanon a $10,000,000 loan or grant to help her out of the economic doldrums created by more than five months of civil disturbance.

The New York Rangers, who have not played well in their last few games, will attempt to get back on the right track tonight when they meet the Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden.

THE Matinee Theatre Series, sponsored by the Greater New York Chapter of the American National Theatre and Academy under the direction of Lucille Lortel, devoted itself yesterday afternoon at the Theatre de Lys to three Works by the Mary Anthony Dance Theatre.

Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa's contention that our school building program is wasteful and has resulted in bad planning and refinements unnecessary to adequate education certainly must stem from a considerable experience with the new construction in the city.

HAVANA, Dec. 2 -- Cuban Army headquarters denied late today the arrest of two lieutenant colonels on charges of "cowardice" and conspiracy. The colonels were reported to have been seized with four other officers.
Servel, Inc., has contracted to purchase the Burgess Battery Company for $17,000,000 in cash and the assumption of Burgess liabilities "with certain limitations."

A group of commercial and investment bankers headed by the Chase Manhattan Bank won the award yesterday of $30,000,000 of Ohio capital improvement bonds. The group bid 100.04299 with a variety of coupons to set a net interest cost to the state of 2.7157 per cent.
CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- Flags at half-staff fluttered limply today over a city shocked and heartbroken.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Dec. 2 (AP) -Alfred E. Darby, president of the Outlet Company, notified employes of the store and its television and radio stations today that holders of a majority of the stock in the company had agreed to sell their shares to an undisclosed purchaser.
MOSCOW, Dec. 2 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey is convinced after an eight-hour meeting with Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev that the growing Berlin controversy is "fraught with danger."

Elgin Baylor, Minneapolis Laker rookie, held the top position in pro basketball scoring. The former Seattle collegian had a total of 505 points in games through Monday, according to National Basketball Association figures released yesterday. St. Louis' Bob Pettit was the runner-up with 478.
DETROIT, Dec. 2 -- Mrs. Sylvia Stein of Detroit led 111 contract bridge experts today as the 1958 Life Masters Individual Championship reached the half-way mark.
The Transit Authority yesterday signed a contract to buy 110 new IRT subway cars for $11,726,000.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 2 -- Doctors may still be underestimating their heart patients' work capacity through failure to distinguish between the demands of continuous and intermittent activity, an American Medical Association session was told here today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 2 -- Plans to record the "Pilgrimage Play," a religious drama, on video tape as an hour-length television show were announced today by the Hal Roach studio.

A half-hour's talk with Neil MacCarl in Toronto made it obvious that the only ice in Canada not cluttered with curlers was the kind that came in cubes. He's a curler who keeps a close watch on the game's developments.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 2 -- Britain charged today that Iceland's largest coast guard vessel, the 700-ton Thor, had fired live ammunition at a crippled British trawler in the fishery dispute two months ago.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 2 -- Mrs. Barbara Kahle Wheat received a one-year suspended jail sentence today on her conviction in the shooting of her husband, John P. Wheat, an artist, in their Darien home. The shooting took place April 16.
LONDON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Soviet Union advised Japan today to give up what it called "shackling military commitments" and adopt a policy of neutrality.
After more than twenty years at 322 West Sixty-seventh Street, file New York Builders Supply Company will move to the Starrett Lehigh Building, Eleventh Avenue and Twenty-seventh Street.

Today's new film is "China Doll," a United Artists melodrama starring Victor Mature and Li Li Hua, at Loew's State Theatre, Broadway and Forty-fifth Street. Frank Borzage produced and directed the adventure, which is being presented by Romina Productions.
The formation of the Aircraft Exchange was announced yesterday by a group headed by Robert I. Helliesen.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 2 -- Faculty friends of Dr. Eugene Paul Wigner hope he will spend part of the $50,000 Enrico Fermi award to buy new mattresses for the Wigners' summer cottage at Lake Elmore, Vt. They say the present mattresses are lumpy.

TRADITIONALLY, merchants deck their halls with holly at this time of year. But not Helena Rubinstein. She hired an artist, Pallavicini, to redecorate her boutique for Christmas. He scorned tinsel and even bypassed Santa Claus.
Stocks eased yesterday in the lightest trading in a month.
A house in Bayside, Queens, was lifted six feet from the right of way of the new Clear-view Expressway yesterday.
An immediate "cellar-to-rooftop" inspection all schools here was ordered yesterday by Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. to prevent any disaster such as the Chicago fire.

Mrs. Millicent C. McIntosh, president of Barnard College, and about twenty-five students climbed to the roof of the college's new library building yesterday afternoon for the topping-off ceremony. The event marked the completion of the fifth story of the building at Claremont Avenue and 118th Street.

THE large audience that delightedly follows the piquant impressions of the theatre in Al Hirschfeld's drawings for The New York Times and other publications may see the originals at the John Heller Gallery, 63 East Fifty-seventh Street.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 2 -Chancellor Konrad Adenauer declared today that an "absolutely firm" Western stand would deter the Soviet Union from pushing the Berlin crisis to a showdown.
LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Derick Heathcoat Amory, Chancellor of the Exchequer, said today he did not think the Treasury would delay its decision on the rival bids for shares of the British Aluminium Company.

DETROIT, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The University of Detroit, shooting for national football prominence with a stepped-up recruiting program, dismissed Coach Wally Fromhart today because of a disappointing season. His team won four games, lost four and tied one.

THE second premiere of the New York Ballet's season at the City Center last night introduced a new choreographer to its repertory in the person of William Christensen and the work with which he made his local bow was Stravinsky's "Octet" for woodwinds.

A fine debut recital was played at Town Hall last night by the pianist Herbert Rogers, a pupil of the late Olga Samaroff, who more recently studied with Rosalyn Tureck and with Sascha Gorodnitzki at the Juilliard School.

Lado, Inc.. will give its annual dinner and concert for tile benefit of its scholarship fund on Sunday in the main ballroom of the Biitmore. Laurel Hurley, soprano of the Metropolitan Opera, and Daniel Abrams, pianist, will donate their services for the concert.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Senate investigation of textile industry problems ended today with a prime target on the witness stand -- an official of the International Cooperation Administration.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board stepped in today to protect airplanes from the hazards of amateur rocketry.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 2 -- The season for movie awards got off on an early start here tonight when the American Cinema Editors presented trophies to eight members whose theatrical and television films were voted as "Best Edited" pictures of the year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- State Department specialists tied today to find the answer to the Soviet Union's call for a Western withdrawal from Berlin. Out of far-ranging studies by its experts on Germany, the Soviet Union and European affairs, the department hopes to distill a draft reply to the Soviet Thanksgiving Day note proposing that West Berlin become a demilitarized free city.
MONTGOMERY, Ala. Dec. 2 (AP) -- Civil rights investigators subpoenaed voter registration files in three Alabama counties today.
On Nov. 28 you reported that our old friend the Police Department's crowd-estimator has been at work again.
ALBANY, Dec. 3 -- Although the state faces a $200,000,000 deficit next year, it is preparing to turn over more than $8,000,000 of tax revenue to private harness tracks.

American seamen's unions tightened their grip on ships flying "flags of convenience" yesterday as a world-wide boycott against Liberian, Panamanian, Honduran and Costa Rican vessels entered its second day.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UPI) -- The Civil Service Commission warned Federal workers today to take heed of the new Code of Ethics for Government Service.
Baseball for Italy, a recently formed organization, started its campaign at a reception in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Army expects its forthcoming shot at the moon to demonstrate for the first time the feasibility of communicating with space vehicles billions of miles from earth.

The quest for a quiescent plasma -- one of the principal goals in efforts to harness hydrogen-bomb power for peaceful purposes -- was described here last night at the annual meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers.
Paul M. Butler and Meade Alcorn, Democratic and Republican national chairmen, respectively, received awards from the American Heritage Foundation last night for outstanding citizenship.
The Fordham University basketball team launched its campaign last night, trouncing Roanoke College of Virginia, 93 -- 50, at the Rose Hill gymnasium.
An appeal for "an open society" and governmental candor to cope with "the fearful peril that faces mankind" was made here last night by Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, the atomic physicist.
The New York office of Grant Advertising, Inc., has been shaken by a wave of personnel changes, it was learned last night.

OTTAWA, Dec. 2 (Canadian Press) -- The flow of foreign capital into Canada through trade in stocks and bonds dropped to $126,000,000 in the months of July through September from $251,000,000 in the June quarter. It compared with $135,000,000 in July through September, last year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Eisenhower returned to the White House today from his Georgia vacation. He immediately began preparations for a series of conferences with Administration and legislative leaders incident to the convening of the Eighty-sixth Congress next month.

HONG KONG, Nov. 30 -- A boy about 10 years old had enough of wandering through Shanghai, so he sprawled on streetcar tracks. Traffic pulled to a halt, a crowd gathered, and the boy stayed there, grinning.

Dillon, Read Co., Inc., and associates are offering today in the United States capital market $25,000,000 of external loan bonds of the Union of South Africa. At the same time the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development is lending an equal amount to South Africa.
ROBERT COURTRIGHT, whose recent collages are on view at the New Gallery, 601 Madison Avenue, has sustained an interest in the beauties of Renaissance architecture for a number of years.
The quarterly magazine Art in America announced yesterday that its first annual award of $1,000 for a major contribution toward furthering interest in American art had been won by Mark Tobey.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 2 -- Soviet buyers are snapping up Uruguay's new wool stocks at a rate that will put the Communist bloc ahead of any Western country as Uruguay's best customer.

TOKYO, Dec. 2 -- President Carlos P. Garcia of the Philippines said in the Diet (Parliament) today that considerations of "mutual security" should guide the future relationships of the Phillipines and Japan.
The election of Feodor D. Cekich and Roy S. Greer as vice presidents of the Marine Midland Trust Company of New York has been announced by George C. Textor, president.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UPI) -- The armed forces told a House subcommittee today that the Government owned nearly $1,500,000,000 worth of industrial plants that were producing nothing.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Dr. Eugene P. Wigner received the Atomic Energy Commission's $50,000 Enrico Fermi Award today for his contributions to the development of atomic energy.

Louisiana State, the nation's only major unbeaten, untied college football team, won the final Associated Press poll by a landslide vote yesterday to cap an amazing comeback. Only a year ago the Tigers wound up with a 5-5 won-lost record.
A request that Washington Square Park be "permanently closed to all vehicular traffic, including Fifth Avenue buses, before Dec. 26" was made yesterday to Mayor Wagner.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., Dec. 2 (UPI) -- A plan to assign students to schools without regard to race was revealed today by the City of Alexandria, where schools have been ordered to integrate next February.
The city's "massive new attack" on slums spread yesterday into the legislative field.
Frank Finney, Brown quarterback, was named to both the all-East and all-Ivy League football teams yesterday.

HUMAN moles, now seen all over town digging under roadways, started to multiply during the Eighties, mostly after, and because of, the Great Blizzard of 1888. The first burrowers worked for the telegraph, telephone, gas and water services.
Only small net changes were recorded in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. Final prices were unchanged to 4 points higher. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
A total of 10,3S5 pints of blood was contributed in November to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program.

Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, said yesterday that the public must be prepared to pay higher taxes if the nation was to meet its increased level of Government expenditures without inflation.
A union of hospital employees announced yesterday it would strike Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx at 6 A. M. Monday unless it gained bargaining recognition from hospital authorities.
MONTREAL, Dec. 2 (AP) -Andy Bathgate of the New York Rangers has kept his lead in the National Hockey League scoring race, but four Montreal Canadiens are pressing him.

ROCHELLE PARK, N. J., Dec. 2 -- State Highway Commissioner Dwight R. Palmer tonight outlined plans by which the department hopes to meet an expected increase of 100 per cent in the volume of Bergen County traffic by 1980.

In the Nov. 17 issue of The Times there appeared a report of a sermon preached by Dr. John M. Krumm in St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University. In this serious accusations were made against P. O. A. U. (Protestants and Other Americans United for Separation of Church and State) of anti-Catholic bigotry.

PORTLAND, Me., Dec. 2 (AP) -- The Gulf Oil Corporation of Pennsylvania has filed a $2,000,000 libel suit against the United State Government, charging negligence in the collision of two oil tankers in Narragansett Bay, Rhode Island, on Aug. 7.
LONDON, Dec. 2 -- The gold and dollar reserves held by Britain as central banker for the sterling. area showed another substantial gain last month.

GENEVA, Dec. 2 -- Seven European countries said today that a split in the seventeen-nation Organization for European Economic Cooperation over the proposal for a free trade zone would be particularly regrettable because of the need for economic expansion.
