POETRY, Robert Frost has said, "begins in delight, and ends in wisdom." This may be a variant on John Masefield's saying that "The days that make us happy make us wise." But in any event there is no reason why we should not pleasurably read Frost's judgment backwards and acknowledge that verses written out of a poet's wisdom may add considerably to our delight.
The Atlas Corporation's oil negotiations with the Argentine Government are well along, Floyd B. Odlum, president, told the investment company's annual meeting in the Commodore Hotel yesterday.

MARRIAGE has become only a part-time career for a woman. It demands her close attention for less than a third of her adult life. Therefore, the college woman of today owes it to herself and the nation to select a life-work with the same care exercised by men.
ALBANY, Dec. 3 (UPI) -- The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court today unanimously rejected Joseph (Socks) Lanza's plea for freedom.
MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 3 -- A technique for stopping massive ulcer bleeding by drastic cooling of the patient's stomach has been described here by surgeons of the University of Minnesota Hospitals.
LONDON, Dec. 3 -- The Ministry of Education announced today plans for spending u400,000,000 ($1,120,000,000) on building and improving schools over a five-year period beginning in 1960.

John A. Latimer and Hyman Marcus consented yesterday to a Securities and Exchange Commission stipulation of facts upon which the commission may order revocation of the broker - dealer registration of J. A. Latimer Co.

The American consumer, according to the most recent periodic sampling of opinion by the University of Michigan's Survey Research Center, has developed a sort of split personality concerning his economic outlook since the last poll of the kind was taken in May and June of this year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The Defense Department announced today a long-range satellite program aimed at placing mice, monkeys, then man in space.

Directors of the Jewel Tea Company have authorized a two-for-one stock split, Franklin J. Lunding, chairman of the food chain, announced yesterday. The board also increased the quarterly dividend on the present shares to 60 cents a share from 50 cents paid previously.
One of the last of a fleet of American troop transports designed to keep German U-boats in World War I guessing has been scrapped.
COFFEE connoisseurs may differ as to the blend of coffee they prefer, but all agree that the best coffee is brewed from beans that are freshly roasted and freshly ground.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The American Telephone Telegraph Company lost an important round today in a fight to extend its activities in the field of private mobile radio.

The Lincoln Securities Corporation, 42 Broadway, and its president, Lester Ober, of 163-30 102d Street, Rego Park, Queens, were permanently barred from the securities business in New York State by the State Supreme Court here yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Spencer J. Drayton, the president of the Thoroughbred Racing Protective Bureau, today resigned as the executive secretary of the Thoroughbred Racing Associations, a post he had held twelve years.

" Search Me," a new book by Patrick Anderson, will be issued Monday by the British Book Centre. Combining fact and fiction, Mr. Anderson tells of his experiences in England, on the Continent and in Canada, giving a picture of a "sensitive mind as it wrestles with the problem of its own identity." Mr. Anderson is the author of "Snake Wine."

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 3 -- The European Economic Community decided today to extend to all nations in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade the 10 per cent cut in tariffs it will institute Jan. 1.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Support mounted today for Don Jordan of Los Angeles in his burning ambition to unseat the world welterweight champion, Virgil Akins of St. Louis, Friday night.
With several players in questionable physical condition, the New York Giants yesterday went through their "Wednesday long-day" drill on Yankee Stadium's frozen turf.
The Jewish Theological Seminary of America has reorganized its program of training of rabbis.

Alan Schneider, Broadway director, has bought a new play, "The Trees of Promise," by Mann Rubin.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- United States sources confirmed today that a Soviet ship had delivered to Iraq a cargo of light and heavy arms made in the Soviet bloc.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 3 -Lieut. Gen. Gustavo Rojas Pinilla, former dictatorial President, was arrested tonight after a state of siege had been decreed. He was flown to the Caribbean coastal city of Cartagena and will be held at the Colombian naval base there.

P. F.) in a major step forward in Argentina's drive for petroleum self-sufficiency.

NEW DELHI, Dec. 3 -- K. D. Malaviya, Minister for Mines, today assured foreign oil companies that Government had no intention of nationalizing their holdings in India. CHICAGO, Dec. 3 (AP) -Some bullish influences which usually attract active buying of grain futures failed to stir them today and prices on the Board of Trade drifted into weakness generally.

Dr. John C. Adams, president of Hofstra College, is to be congratulated on his venture in establishing a three-year college for bright students. May other college presidents follow his example and convert their finishing schools and clubhouses into institutions of learning.
Industrial accidents in the state have dropped to their lowest total in seventeen years, Angela R. Parisi, chairman of the Workmen's Compensation Board, reported yesterday.

Manhattan College won the final event, the 400-yard freestyle relay, and defeated City College, 45 -- 41, in a swimming meet at the loser's pool yesterday. The Jaspers were timed in 4:01.3. The meet was the Metropolitan Collegiate Swimming Conference opener for both teams.
Paul M. Butler and Meade Alcorn, chairmen of the Democratic and Republican national committees, traded charges yesterday at the sixty-third annual Congress of American Industry.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 3 -Prentice-Hall, New York publishing concern, a literary agent and a lawyer were indicted last night on charges of having conspired to smuggle a manuscript out of San Quentin Prison.

FAMAGUSTA, Cyprus, Dec. 3 (Reuters) -- A British coroner declared today an "entirely unjustified" degree of force was used on some persons arrested here Oct. 3 in a mass round-up of Greek Cypriotes conducted by British troops.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The Court of Claims held today that carriers were entitled to mail pay from the Government for the weight of mail sacks as well as the letters inside.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Developments in baseball's current windjamming sessions continued today at a breathtaking pace.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Britain's hard-pressed coal industry, squeezed between an operating deficit, falling demand and surplus stocks, caught another blow today. The miners were awarded an unconditional and retroactive wage increase.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Spokesmen for several business organizations complained to Congress today that United States tax and tariff policies were penalizing foreign investment by American industry.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission was asked today to equalize New Jersey's Port Newark and Elizabeth-Port Authority pier developments with competing public waterfront terminals in the New York commercial zone.

The Architectural League of New York yesterday entered the controversy over alleged waste in the city's school-building program with a defense of school murals and other art forms.

The Robert Moses Power Dam of the St. Lawrence Power Project at Massena, N. Y., will produce its first billionth kilowatt today. The dam began generating power early last July, less than four years after construction started on Aug. 10, 1954.

CRESSKILL, N. J., Dec. 3 -The proprietors of The Cresskill Bulletin, a mimeographed monthly paper published in this borough, have been ordered by Mayor Jack deSevray to stop publication.

The operator of a row of Brooklyn houses that had been described as filthy was sentenced yesterday to a year in the workhouse. In another action on substandard housing, seven arrest warrants were issued for an elusive "slumlord" in Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -Twelve appointments to a national advisory committee to study such new educational media as television and tape recordings were announced today by Dr. Lawrence G. Derthick, United States Commissioner of Education.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The Department of Commerce proposed today tighter regulation on imports of surplus Government property -- mostly military -- that Government agencies have sold in foreign countries.

The silver anniversary season of college basketball in Madison Square Garden will be observed tonight. New York University will meet Cincinnati in the feature contest after St. John's University faces Providence in the opener of the program at 7:15 o'clock.

Roy E. Larsen, president of Time Inc., said yesterday that the dispute with the Post Office Department over the secondclass mail status of two issues of Life magazine had not yet been settled.

The nation's gasoline inventories increased 4,024,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 173,600,000 barrels, compared with 169,576 a week earlier and 185,203,000 a year ago.
Owners of boycotted Liberian and Panamanian vessels turned to the courts in increasing numbers yesterday in an effort to get their immobilized ships back on the high seas.

The Ford Motor Company has switched car lines in two of its agencies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Heating contractors in the Chicago area swore today that to go into business they had to make pay-offs to Arthur H. Cronin and other officials of a Sheet Metal Workers Union local.

The New York Rangers came mighty close to letting a victory slip from their grasp last night at Madison Square Garden. After building a 3-0 lead, they had to scramble for a 4-2 verdict over the Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League contest.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Penn downed Rutgers, 63 -- 55, in the second game of a basketball double-header at the Palestra tonight.
PRINCETON, N. J., Dec 3 -Queen Frederika of Greece paid a visit to Princeton University today.
LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Prices again declined on the stock market here today an the volume of business slackened.

The two buildings containing forty apartments at 1742-46 Union Street, Brooklyn, have been sold by the Ritjac Realty Corporation for cash over mortgages amounting to $110,000. The buyer, an investor, acquired the property through Charles W. Fairbanks of Hussey Hoeh, brokers, in cooperation with J. H. Katz Co.

The irresponsible rebellion of longshoremen against economic progress on the docks, which got out of hand during the last few days, has been brought under at least some control. But peace on the waterfront still hangs in a delicate balance that could be easily upset by the mounting pressure of labor-saving machines and the workers' growing fear of losing their jobs.
CHICAGO, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
The question of whether Wagner's basketball team will be able to mold an entirely different type of offense from last season is the Staten Islanders' paramount concern.
Pop Warner Midget League football will take over Downing Stadium on Randalls Island this Sunday. Two New York teams will meet Philadelphia all-star squads.

MANY crisscrossing musical influences were revealed last night in the concert Leopold Stokowski conducted for the Contemporary Music Society at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UPI) -- House investigators warned Government departments today to stop dragging their feet on manpower cuts because of the "obvious desperate necessity" to reduce non-defense spending.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 3 -A major research program aimed at getting a better understanding of mental depression -an important factor in all phases of mental illness -- was described here today by one of the scientists in charge of the study.

The most recent wave of arrests in Spain has aroused a lot of interest in and out of that unfortunate country, and rightly so. It has also aroused many hopes in the breasts of Spanish exiles and liberals everywhere, but wrongly so. There is no reason to suppose that the regime of Generalissimo Franco is being shaken.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Dec. 3 -- Under Secretary of State Christian A. Herter called today for a "positive approach" in American foreign policy to press political and psychological competition with the Sino-Soviet bloc in under-developed areas of the Americas.
VIENNA, Nov. 28 -- Communist party functionaries in Hungary have not yet recovered from the shock of the anti-Communist revolt in October, 1956.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- A leader of the African community in Kenya accused Britain today of having "miserably failed" to provide any guidance in the establishment of a democratic government in her colony and protectorate.
Dr. Leroy E. Burney, Surgeon General of the United States, yesterday rated the need for more and better nursing-home personnel above more regulations to govern the institutions.
No early resumption of the delivery of most New York newspapers on Long Island appeared in prospect last night.
RABAT, Morocco, Dec. 3 -The Algerian rebel government gave unconditional freedom today to eight French soldiers captured by the Algerian National Liberation Army from January to May of this year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The trading mart, not too lively at baseball's winter meeting, got a fresh shot in the arm tonight when the San Francisco Giants and the Phillies announced a deal involving three players.
RABAT, Morocco, Dec. 3 -- King Mohamed V has accepted the resignation of Premier Ahmed Balafrej, a palace spokesman disclosed tonight.

Electric power production last week fell to 12,274,000,000 kilowatt hours from 12,579,000,000 in the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. In the week ended Nov. 30, 1957 the output was 11,613,000,000 kilowatt hours.
COLRAIN, Mass., Dec. 3 -- It turned out today that the deer in a certain section of this vicinity were guilty of unethical practices, as defined by the McClellan subcommittee.
INADEQUATE packing and improper marking often result in gift packages being damaged or lost in transit. Suggestions to avert this have been advanced by the Railway Express Agency.

DAVID KIRKPATRICK ESTES BRUCE, United States Ambassador to West Germany, and a principal participant in talks on the Berlin ferment, is perhaps the most professional non-professional diplomat in the service of the United States.

Brown, which finished fourth in the Ivy League during the 1958 football season, dominated the final league statistics, released yesterday, by winning the total offense title and placing first in four of six individual categories.

Governor-elect Nelson A. Rockefeller announced yesterday that his Secretary of State would be Mrs. Caroline K. Simon. She will be the second woman Secretary of State in the history of the office and the first in thirty-three years.
The Hudson Pulp and Paper Corporation attained record sales and production in the fiscal year ended Aug. 31. Earnings, however, dipped to $2,830,625 from $3,061,994 in the previous fiscal year.
HAVANA, Dec. 3 -- The Preston sugar mill of the United Fruit Company is unable to function under present conditions, according to William G. Raines, vice president in charge of Cuban operations.
Cocoa prices fluctuated over a wide range yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Prices were strong early in the session on short covering which reflected higher London quotations.

Hitting golf balls into the water -- usually an easy trick for most golfers -- was tough work yesterday for four swinging professionals on the flight deck of the Navy's newest and largest aircraft carrier -- the U. S. S. Independence.

Lawrence D. Maran, realty operator, bought the building containing twenty-three apartments at 532 West 159th Street from the estate of Frank Allen. The cash deal was made through E. Osborne Smith, Inc., and Ralph Marx, brokers. The property was remodeled in 1940 and this was its first change of ownership in thirty-five years.

A merged syndicate jointly managed by the Bank of America, National Trust and Savings Association, San Francisco, and Bankers Trust Company won award yesterday of $100,000,000 of California state building construction and school building aid bonds.
As a former New Yorker and constant reader of The Times I was much interested in your announcement of the new Federal building to be erected in Foley Square.

TOKYO, Dec. 3 -- The Foreign Ministry accused the Soviet Union and Communist China today of a "joint attempt" to estrange Japan from the United States over the pending revision of the Japanese-United tSates security treaty.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Ohio Supreme Court ruled today against the simultaneous payment of supplemental unemployment benefits and state jobless compensation.

A SOLIDLY-BUILT man with grayish hair meandered about the clubhouse of the Football Giants last Sunday. Few of the players paid him heed. Yet when Tuffy Leemans spoke to them at the Section Five's testimonial dinner to Coach Jim Lee Howell that night, his fervor gave them a glimpse of the driving force that had impelled him to greatness.
In The Times of Nov. 29 Erling D. Naess, chairman of the recently organized American Committee for Flags of Necessity, upholds the status of American-owned foreign-flag operations.

TOKYO, Dec. 3 -- The carelessness toward human life often associated with the overpopulated and underdeveloped nations of the East has become a thing of the past, a leading authority on physical rehabilitation said today at the ninth International Conference of Social Work.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 3 (AP) -Vern Hatton scored two field goals in the last fifty-three seconds tonight for the edge that gave the Cincinnati Royals a 110-108 National Basketball Association victory over the New York Knickerbockers.
CHICAGO, Dec. 3 (AP) -Harold Johnson, a leading lightheavyweight contender, piled up points tonight with a savage body attack and gained a unanimous ten-round decision over Howard King of Reno.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 3 -- One of California's worst brush fires in recent years raged for a second day today in the Santa Monica Mountains forty miles west of Los Angeles.

Twelve thousand twinkling white lights were added to Park Avenue's traditional Christmas glitter last night when one of the old street's newest structure -- the bronze Seagram Building -- was lighted up in a massive Christmas display.
ALBANY, Dec. 3 -- Governor Harriman has made the first move to enable Robert Moses to remain as chairman of the State Power Authority after he reaches the age of 70 on Dec. 18.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., Dec. 3 -- A new United States' effort to plumb the mysteries of outer space appears set for this weekend at the Cape Canaveral Missile Testing Center near here.

A wide-ranging program of modernization and improvement that will cost more than $4,000,000 and take two years to complete was announced yesterday by Stern's, New York department store, for its Forty-second Street parent unit.
The Bach Aria Group presented the first concert of its 1958-59 subscription series at Town Hall last night, with Frank Brieff conducting.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UPI) -- Government officials said today that the recent improvement in unemployment was expected to end soon. As a result, they said, more than 4,500,000 Americans may be looking for work in mid-winter.

WHETHER women artists in general are esthetically more conservative than men is a delicate question. However, the thirty-fourth annual exhibition of the New York Society of Women Artists, opening today at the National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue, is a strong argument for the affirmative.
After a series of fits and starts, stocks closed slightly higher yesterday. Trading was moderate in an unspectacular market.

A public school in the Bronx, a private school in Brooklyn and a dormitory in Manhattan were ordered closed yesterday as Fire Department inspectors searched the city for fire hazards in schools. The city-wide inspection was pressed by Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr.

Five eminent Brazilians -- a musician, two educators, a bank president and the Minister of Finance -- received honorary degrees yesterday at a ceremony that closed New York University's first conference on Brazil.
BOSTON, Dec. 3 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits urged mayors today to lobby for a Federal housing program.
Columbia opened a new basketball season under a new coach and scored a 64-56 triumph over City College last night.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 3 -Argentine union leaders buckled under military pressure today and ordered an end to the fiveday railroad strike.
Whirlpool Corporation's sales in 1959 will rise 15 to 20 per cent above the $402,000,000 to be chalked up this year, John A. Hurley, sales vice president, predicted yesterday.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Dec. 3 -- The Paramount Ruler of the Federation of Malaya read the Government's annual policy statement in Malay today before the Legislative Council. It was his first address in Malay to that assembly.

Today's new film is "Auntie Mame," Warner Brothers color version of the stage comedy, starring Rosalind Russell, at the Radio City Music Hall. Morton DaCosta directed and Betty Comden and Adolph Green wrote the scenario, adapted
Jim Brown of the Cleveland Browns paces National Football League ground-gainers with a total of 1,241 yards this season, according to statistics released yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- No clues have been uncovered to explain the cause of Monday's fire in Our Lady of the Angels parochial grammar school here. Eighty-seven children and three nuns, teachers in the school, perished in the blaze.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Harry S. Truman arrived today with his usual quota of controversial political views.

DETROIT, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Ford Motor Company today charged Edward N. Gadsby, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission with a "serious injustice" in his remarks about Ford's 1956 stock issue.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The Federal Reserve Board has asked the District Court here to dismiss a suit that challenges the board's authority over branch banking that results from a bank merger.
A mink coat and mink stoles worth $25,000 at wholesale were taken by two selective gunmen last night from the proprietor of a fur wholesale house on the West Side.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 9 to 43 points (45 cents to $2.15 a bale) yesterday with the old crop months weakest.
NEWMARKET, England, Dec. 4 (AP) -- American breeder plunged for $112,378 more in five purchases at the Newmarket sales today.
LEON, Mexico, Dec. 4 -- The city of San Luis Potosi apparently has been isolated by a city-wide strike for the last two days.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4 (UPI) -- Two University of Southern California students confessed today that they had planted a dangerous home-made bomb under a cheerleader's stand at Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum as a prank for the U. S. C.-U. C. L. A. football game.

Whatever else the United Nations is, it is a "natural given opportunity for permanent contact between the United States and the Soviet Union." This was one of the sensible remarks made yesterday in a speech in this city by Dr. Charles Malik of Lebanon, who is President of this year's General Assembly. Dr. Malik's observations made one think of an old folk saying that in one form or another has been familiar for many centuries.
Every year, towels soak up hundreds of millions of United States consumers' dollars.
The Soviets continue to block progress at the Geneva conferences on a controlled nuclear test ban and on the technical requirements of an alarm system against surprise attack.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The earth is covered by 40 per cent more snow and ice than previously believed, the Antartic apparently is a divided continent and vast mineral riches lie at the bottom of the Pacific Ocean.

NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 4 -- A local manufacturer has won his fight to prevent this city from taking over his plant in connection with a proposed redevelopment program. Housing and Home Finance Agency officials in the New York Regional Office informed Mayor Irving C. Freese yesterday that the Board of Review in Washington had excluded the plant of Voltare, Inc., on Cross Street, from the plan as now being considered.

Directors of the Colgate-Palmolive Company yesterday voted an extra dividend of 50 cents a share payable to common stockholders on Dec. 24. This was in addition to the regular dividends of $3 a share for the year, bringing the total to $3.50 a share.

A program of award-winning films at the recent Brussels International Film Festival will be presented by Cinema 16, starting Sunday morning at the Beekman Theatre and continuing there on the two following Sundays.

The problem of inflation still is a major concern of the business community. At two meetings yesterday leaders in various fields expressed themselves on the danger of an other price spiral. James F. Oates Jr., president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society proposed a "national policy against inflation."
ALBANY, Dec. 4 -- A tax expert suggested today that the state should ease its income tax on nonresidents who worked in New York.

EVERY family has a decorating skeleton to hide. Unfortunately, they are not always in a closet, but right out in plain sight. They include an exposed radiator or protruding air-conditioner, the steam pipe in the corner, the kitchen in the alcove and the perennially untidy desk.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 539,191 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

Elena Powstuck, a Russian-born pianist who teaches at the Juilliard School of Music, made her debut last night in Town Hall. Her program consisted mostly of tried and true numbers -- Beethoven's "Waldstein" Sonata, Prokofieff's Third and the Chopin B flat minor sonata.
A Louis XVI decor of emerald green and gold provided a setting befitting the rank of the honor guests at last night's Imperial Ball in the Grand Ballroom of the Astor.

Inspectors and records of the Building, Fire and Police Departments will be examined as a result of graft charges made by a minister who has been crusading against slums, Mayor Wagner's office announced last night.

The service and education program of the Brooklyn Association for Mental Health will benefit from a theatre party to "Of Mice and Men" on Dec. 12. The musical version of John Steinbeck's play opened at the Provincetown Playhouse last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Army, under criticism for a contract settlement involving Sherman Adams, former Presidential Assistant, said today it had forbidden any settlements for more than the original claim.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 4 -- The Westchester Republican County Committee will continue to be headed by Edwin G. Michaelian, the County Executive.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 4 -- Nassau's fifth annual international sports car week finally got under way today. Squally weather had forced two postponements from last Sunday. It was squally again today but postponements space had run out and in a mixture of rain, wind and sunshine the first races were run.
THE Imperial Ball held last night at the Astor Hotel was the best-dressed social gathering of the season.

The Union of American Hebrew Congregations appealed yesterday to American Jews to work with other religious groups in giving moral and financial support toward solving the Arab refugee problem in the Middle East.
New York City has "the most meagerly supported safety program of any community in the nation," the head of the Greater New York Safety Council declared yesterday.
A sharp increase in state aid to the city's municipal colleges will be recommended by the State Education Department.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 4 -- The Government announced tonight "with special satisfaction" terms of oil contracts with subsidiaries of the Royal Dutch group and the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey). At the same time, Arturo Sabato, President Frondizi's representative in the administration of Yacientos Petroliferos Fiscales (YPF), the Government oil monopoly, expressed skepticism that a deal would be reached with the Atlas Corporation.

Net sales of George A. Hormel Co. in the fiscal year ended Oct. 25 reached a record $360,959,810, but earnings dipped from those of the year before H. H. Corey, chairman, and R. F. Gray, president, reported yesterday.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 4 -- Brazil, a traditional exporter of coffee beans, prepared today to meet the challenge of the increasing use of soluble coffee.
The following reports were provided by operators of the ski areas. Messages were filed at telegraph offices yesterday at the times indicated in parentheses.

Listed below are retail price ranges of produce available in this area. These prices, from the city's Department of Markets, are based on a city-wide survey of supermarkets, chain stores and neighborhood grocery stores.

This being all-America week, it was proposed that an all-America football player be tracked down and brain-washed. As an around-the-corner resident of Fanwood, N. J., and also the first Rutgers man to be so honored since Homer Hazel in 1928, Bill Austin was nominated.

THE New York City Ballet, in an anniversary mood this season at the City Center, last night stepped out of its normal field of ballet to revive the 25-year-old "Seven Deadly Sins," created originally by Kurt Weill, Bertolt Brecht and George Balanchine in close collaboration. It is a stunning revival of a minor masterpiece.

IN the summer of 1957 an Alaskan tourist was traveling in Oregon. "Who is your king up there now?" asked one of the natives. Such benighted ignorance is probably not the rule in Oregon, which, after all, is the second nearest state to Alaska. Nevertheless, few citizens of this country are very well informed about our forty-ninth state.
COLRAIN, Mass., Dec. 4 -- Four inches of new snow and three aimless women made deer hunting a misery around this Western Massachusetts town in the foothills of the Berkshires today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 1 per cent above the sales level of a year earlier.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The United States implied today it was delaying further economic talks with Communist Poland partly because recent public statements by Wladyslaw Gomulka, the nation's Communist chief, had taken a sharply anti-American tone.
BONE, Algeria, Dec. 4 (Reuters) -- Premier Charles de Gaulle flew to the Sahara tonight to inspect France's big oil, mining and natural gas enterprises there.
The Transit Authority will begin tomorrow to operate extra long trains on many of its lines to accommodate Christmas shoppers. The service will continue through Christmas Eve.
Hempstead, L. I., has set Dec. 16 as the date on which it will offer $8,000,000 of various purpose general obligation bonds. The issue will mature from 1959 to 1986.
LONDON, Dec. 4 (Reuters) -- A giant, two-ton statue of Sir Winston Churchill was described today as "gorilla-like" and a "disgrace."

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 4 -- Brazil's economic situation has deteriorated so markedly in the last four or five weeks that President Juscelino Kubitschek's ability to remain in office for more than six months is being questioned by responsible persons.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- All Christians must remain alert to their responsibility to support law and order where churches are desecrated and schools are bombed, the closing session of the general board meeting of the National Council of Churches said here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec 4 -- The trading mart at baseball's winter convention came to life feebly today. Just as the club owners were hustling to make train and plane connections, the Los Angeles Dodgers and St. Louis Cardinals announced a straight player swap involving two outfielders and a rookie pitcher.
The threat of a strike of non-professional employes at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx has intensified, spokesman for the institution and the employes' union said yesterday.
The announcement last Sunday of exhibition openings of the week included only those through today. Exhibitions opening tomorrow are as follows:
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 4 -- Britain suggested today that the United Nations set up a monitoring system in an attempt to check inflammatory attacks by one country against another.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Maynard Reece of Des Moines today became the first three-time winner of the annual duck stamp design competition.

A lengthy thematic, rhythmic and harmonic analysis of Aaron Copland's Orchestral Variations by Leonard Bernstein, conductor, was a feature of last night's preview concert of the New York Philharmonic at Carnegie Hall.
How to win with short basketball players is the problem of Placido Gomez, the coach of Brooklyn College's quintet.
Your editorial of Nov. 26 "Seven Seas Boycott" was timely and very wise to point out that boycotts are dangerous weapons.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (UPI) -- A group of liberal House Democrats opened a drive today to curb the power of conservatives on the House Rules Committee.
The Securities and Exchange Commission filed yesterday in Federal Court an advisory report on an amended plan of reorganization of the bankrupt Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company.
Two rare Indonesian dragon lizards had their claws clipped in the Bronx Zoo yesterday in a two-hour project performed with surgical bone clippers.

HULATA, Israel, Dec. 4 -- Half of this communal farming village of 500 persons will have to be reconstructed or repaired. Every other building was blasted or riddled by shrapnel during the artillery duel yesterday between Israeli and Syrian forces.

A compromise contract demand by striking mechanics on Eastern Air Lines narrowed yesterday the issues involved in their eleven-day-old walkout. However, there was no headway toward settlement of a parallel strike by Eastern's flight engineers.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., Dec. 4 -- The Army's moon rocket has successfully passed a simulated flight test at the near-by missile launching center at Cape Canaveral.

BENTWATERS, England, Dec. 4 -- Five 1,200 - mile - an - hour fighter-bombers roared into this East Anglia air base today as the beginning of a greater deterrent striking force for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

An intensive search for the "pivotal juvenile lead" in "Tall Story" has been successfully concluded. The coveted part went to Donald Hotton, an unknown performer. He is to portray a bright college senior, who is a star basketball player.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 4 (AP) -- Average prices paid at auction for Kentucky's burley tobacco rose state-wide to a record of $69.07 a hundredweight yesterday, topping $69 for the first time in history.
A woman social investigator has been suspended by the Welfare Department on charges of operating four Brooklyn rooming houses and renting rooms to seventeen recipients of Welfare Department relief.

A LOT of talent and conconsiderable effort have gone into "Of Mice and Men," which opened at the Provincetown Playhouse last night. But despite all the good intentions and the theatrical abilities of several members of the cast, the musical version of John Steinbeck's saga of human loneliness never measures up to the distinction achieved by the original straight play.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Southern Coal Producers Association signed today the new $2-a-day pay rise for soft-coal miners but provided that any of the association members can refuse to go along with the contract by Dec. 15.
LONDON, Dec. 4 -- Dr. Erhard placed before Britain today the concessions offered by the European Economic Community to break the deadlock over the terms of a proposed free trade area.
A YEAR ago last August a 15-year-old boy was stabbed to death in High-bridge Park, on Washington Heights. Four other neighborhood boys are now in prison for the murder.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Dec. 4 -- No occupation is so fascinating and challenging as the investment banking business, in the view of William D. Kerr, the new president of the Investment Bankers Association of America.

Station WCBS-TV and three others owned by the Columbia Broadcasting System suddenly canceled plans yesterday to present the motion picture "For Whom the Bell Tolls" two months before a live dramatization of the Ernest Hemingway novel on the C. B. S. network.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- A Senate investigation of coin-machine rackets brought demands today that the Treasury Department explain why Frank Cammarata, a mobster, had not been prosecuted as a tax evader.

TWO well-matched teams, Boston College and Holy Cross, should provide prime entertainment during the regional football telecast on the morrow. But if the electronic waves had transmitted the 1942 version of this ancient series, it would have alarmed the country almost as much as Orson Welles' invasion of the Martians.

UNITED NATIONS, N Y., Dec. 4 -- A second international conference on sea law, to determine the extent of territorial waters and fishery rights, was approved today by the General Assembly's Legal Committee.

A LEGISLATIVE leader must command respect to succeed. Those who know Anthony John Travia best say he has the essentials to make good in his new assignment as leader of the Democratic minority in the State Assembly.
HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 4 -- The Socialist-led coalition Government resigned today, a victim of Soviet pressure and internal political bickering.
Some Wall Street investment bankers reacted sharply yesterday to criticism by Edward N. Gadsby, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

DORADO BEACH, P. R., Dec. 4 (AP) -- Howie Johnson of Glenwoodie, Ill., one-putted five greens today and took the first-round lead in the $30,000 Dorado Beach invitation golf tourney with a two-under-par 70.
The New York Knickerbockers last night forwarded a formal protest of their 110-108 loss to the Cincinnati Royals Wednesday night to Maurice Podoloff, president of the National Basketball Association.
EASTBOURNE, England, Dec. 4 -- British, United States and Canadian business men exchanged ideas here today on ways to increase British sales to North America.
TORONTO, Dec. 4 (Canadian Press) -- Nathan E. Tanner of Calgary today resigned as chairman of Trans-Canada Pipe Lines, Ltd.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Dec. 4 -- Israel decided today to ask for an immediate meeting of the United Nations Security Council to discuss the shelling yesterday of eight Israeli villages along the Syrian border.
Laurance S. Rockefeller, who last week was elected chairman of the board of Rockefeller Center, Inc., succeeding his brother, Nelson A. Rockefeller, has announced several executive promotions.
The Board of Estimate acted yesterday to determine whether the city's Croton reservoirs faced a pollution hazard that might endanger the future usefulness of the system.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Grain futures traders pushed the short side of the market again today on the Board of Trade. But the market appeared to have hit the saturation point on small fractional declines in most contracts.
A NEW fashion outpost on the East Side is a hat shop at 331 East Sixty-fifth Street. It is the home of two designers whose label is Vincent Harmik.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The vast power of a Federal administrative agency, in particular its power to establish and then to wipe out a large investment of private enterprise, was exemplified again today by an action of the Federal Communications Commission.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 4 -- A resolution calling for negotiations on the future of Cyprus was approved tonight by the General Assembly's Political Committee by a narrow margin.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 4 (UPI) -- The Kerr Stable's Round Table, holder of the world money-winning championship and several track records, was hailed as the Thoroughbred Racing Association's American champion for 1958 at the organization's annual dinner tonight.
CASES of puppy love and other infatuations already are beginning to cause seasonal bedlam in local pet shops.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (UPI) -- A Health, Education and Welfare official said today that his department would abolish 684 jobs in line with President Eisenhower's order to cut the Federal payroll 2 per cent by next June. 30.
The first Casa Italiana Merit Awards were presented last night by Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, to eight persons prominently associated with its founding.
ROME, Dec, 4 -- Premier Amintore Fanfani's Government suffered an embarrassing parliamentary defeat tonight. It was beaten, 314 to 263, in the Chamber of Deputies on a vote on the price of gasoline.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 4 -- Walt Disney announced today plans for a $5,600,000 expansion program at Disneyland Park, amusement center in Anaheim, south of Los Angeles.

Twenty-five persons were named yesterday in a Federal Court indictment charging a stock swindle in which the public was said to have been defrauded of more than $2,000,000 through boiler-room operations.

Four widely scattered stations in the United States have reported hearing unexplained signals on the 20-megacycle frequency of the Soviet Union's sputniks. However, the Naval Research Laboratory in Washington does not believe that they come from a new satellite.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 4 -- Former President Gustavo Rojas Pinilla was outside territorial Colombia today aboard the naval frigate Capitan Tono.

The Reuben H. Donnelley Corporation, publisher of directories, leased office space in the new building at 200 East Forty-second Street from Joseph Durst, the builder. The space will be used for the offices' of Donald R. Arnold, operating vice president.
A syndicate ot investors represented by Irwin A, Lowenfeld, attorney, has purchased the fourteen-story office building at 421 Seventh Avenue, northeast corner of Thirty-third Street.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The American and National League club owners, sitting in joint session with Commissioner Ford C. Frick, closed their annual winter baseball conclave today with a flourish.

PARIS, Dec. 4 -- The current issue of the liberal Paris weekly L'Express was seized by the police last night at the request of the Ministry of the Army for an alleged "attack on the morale and honor of the army."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Retail sales in October, seasonally adjusted, rose sharply to $17,000,000,000, equaling the record established in the summer of 1957, the Department of Commerce reported today.
LONDON, Dec. 4 -- The industrials took a definite turn for the better on the stock exchange here today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The United States, Britain and France began talks here today on Premier Charles de Gaulle's suggestions for improving consultation among the Big Three.

TRENTON, Dec. 4 -- New Jersey moved today to crack down on speeders. Beginning Jan. 1 drivers convicted of traveling sixty miles an hour or more in fifty-mile zones will have their licenses revoked immediately.
A 16-year-old youth yesterday withdrew his charge that two Queens detectives had attempted to extort money from him and his brother.

Bank clearings for this city declined 7.5 per cent in the holiday week ended Wednesday from those of the similar week a year ago. As a result, the total for the twenty-six major cities of the nation were off 1.2 per cent to $21,846,757,000 from $22,099,293,000 last year, according to the report of Dun Bradstreet. Inc.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Dec. 4 -- The Suffolk County District Attorney's office suggested today that a state-wide ring, led by a master forger still at large, was selling bogus drivers' licenses for $60 to $80 each.

Herbert H. Lehman, former Democratic Senator for New York, said yesterday that it was the moral duty of the United States to take the lead in pressing for the explusion of the "Hungarian puppet delegates" from the United Nations.
The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service began efforts yesterday to prevent a strike of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union at midnight Sunday.
The 1958 Research Corporation Award has been won by Dr. Chien Shiung Wu, Professor of Physics at Columbia University, for her part in disproving the parity law, the foundation announced yesterday.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 4 -- Widespread support for a state-wide system of registering all children not living with their parents was expressed today at a legislative committee's hearing on revision of the state's adoption laws.
ALBANY, Dec. 4 (AP) -- New York City's "mad bomber" lost a court move today aimed art gaining compensation for an injury that he blamed indirectly for his reign of terror.

The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith said yesterday that anti-Semitism in this country was still "basically and most accurately reflected" in housing, employment, education and social attitudes, despite incidents like the bombings of temples.
The directors of the Committee for Modern Courts unanimously endorsed a proposal by the State Judicial Conference for modernization of the courts.
Twenty-five years ago today Prohibition was repealed and the era of the speakeasy ended.
PARAMUS, N. J., Dec. 4 -The Bergen Mall Cannonball chugged off with a load of dignitaries this afternoon, thus putting into service a train with no timetable and no deficit.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Dec. 4 -- The growing skepticism of the American people about holding fixed-income investments in an economy scarred by inflation was cited today as a serious problem that the Treasury must face in managing the public debt.

The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday suspended trading, effective today, in the stock of the F. L. Jacobs Company, Detroit auto parts maker. The stock closed at 7 7/8, off 1/4 point on the day.

Despite statistical indications of tighter reserve conditions, money market conditions were somewhat easier in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York indicated yesterday. In contrast to the nation as a whole, banks in New York operated under generally easier credit conditions.

Loans to business by the seventeen large New York City banks rose $35,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The increase compared with one of $89,000,000 in the week a year earlier.
Skiers were marking time yesterday before deciding to embark this week-end on their first junkets of the season into the northlands. Conditions were far from good in many areas.
NEWARK, Dec. 4 -- Users of the New York Central's Hudson River ferries were assured today of continued service for an indefinite period.
United States leadership is declining in key areas of the world, speakers declared yesterday at the sixty-third annual Congress of American Industry in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
One of the last of a vanishing breed in the East -- a railroad that advertises extensively for passenger traffic, has changed agencies after twenty years.
The largest tanker ever built will be launched tomorrow at Kure, Japan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board raised broad questions today about the mutual anti-strike aid pact of six major airlines. It scheduled a hearing for Jan. 14 to determine whether the agreement should be approved.
Pete Dawkins, Army halfback, and Zeke Smith, Auburn guard, illustrate the determination and versatility which mark the members of the 1958 Associated Press all-America football team named yesterday.

Five thousand toys rehabilitated by inmates at the Hart Island Workhouse were presented yesterday by Anna M. Kross, Commissioner of Correction, to the Police Athletic League. The toys will be given to needy children for Christmas.
A capital budget of $603,065,395 for 1959 was unanimously adopted by the Board of Estimate yesterday. It was $3,814,611 less than the $606,880,006 budget proposed by the City Planning Commission.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 (AP) -- A farm boy who overcame physical handicaps to win the 1958 grand champion steer award at the International Live Stock Exposition received $23,125 today for his calf. It came to $25 a pound.

BERLIN, Dec. 4 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer flew here today and pledged West Germany's support for West Berlin. Standing in a gray drizzle at Tempelhof Airport, the Chancellor said that recent Soviet moves threatened the city's security.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:
The City Athletic Club and Harmonie remained in a first-place tie in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class C Division I competition as a result of victories yesterday.
In choosing Mrs. Caroline K. Simon to be his Secretary of State Governor-elect Rockefeller makes an unusual appointment of an unusual person.
A fortune of $4,500,000 fell like a ripe plum into the lap of the Metropolitan Museum of Art yesterday.

Events today: New York Philharmonic, Claudio Arrau, pianist, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunov," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Witold Malcuzyanski, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Leyna Gabriele, soprano, Town Hall, 8:30; Trio di Bolzano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.
FASHION was full of paradoxes yesterday.

THAT vigorous, daring and dramatically intense music is being written in present-day Czechoslovakia was shown at Carl Fischer Hall last night, when Eric Simon's organization known as New Music Concerts opened its fourth season with an all-Czechoslovak program.
The final obstacle to city approval of the long-stalled Narrows Bridge project is slated to be removed on Dec. 18.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 4 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today that it was essential to the United States peace and security to maintain American forces in West Germany and Berlin.

KATOWICE, Poland, Dec. 4 -- This was the day of "Barburka" -- the time when the Polish miners come out of the pits for a bit of fun and the important men come down from Warsaw for a bit of politicking.

THE cocktail hour is now such an important part of our social life that we are likely to think of it as one of America's more venerable institutions. Actually, it came into recognized existence just twenty-five years ago today, when Prohibition ended with the ratification of the Twenty-first Amendment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower will meet with Republican Congressional leaders on Dec. 15, it was announced today. The meeting will be the first of a series of conferences with Senate and House leaders of both parties on his legislative program.
The State Racing Commission yesterday revoked the licenses of two New York trainers whose drugged horse won a race at Jamaica. The horse, Tally-Ho, never had won before.

It may be remembered that after the New York City loft-building fire last March in which twenty-four garment workers lost their lives, state and city officials promptly investigated and announced that the building was in compliance with the regulations of the state labor law and the local New York City regulations.
Anthony J. Travia of Brooklyn was chosen yesterday to become the Democratic leader in the Assembly when the new Legislature convenes Jan. 7.
DETROIT, Dec. 4 (AP) -- A spreading labor dispute brought to 17,200 today the employes of the Chrysler Corporation made idle in plants in Detroit and Newark, Del.
LONDON, Dec. 4 -- The British Government has prepared a three-point plan for assuring European security after reunification of Germany, Selwyn Lloyd, the Foreign Secretary, disclosed today.

Futures prices closed irregularly higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cocoa, sugar, copper, zinc, lead and platinum rose; coffee, cottonseed oil, potatoes and rubber declined, and price movements for wool and hides were mixed.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Dec. 4 -- A 28-point output by George Carter marked Iona's 84-56 basketball victory over Roanoke College in O'Connell Gymnasium tonight.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 4 -- The Argentine Ministry of Labor announced today the opening of a new round of wage negotiations.
The average industrial work week will be reduced "probably very soon" to twenty hours, the retiring president of the New York Academy of Sciences predicted last night.
PARIS, Dec. 4 -- The one Socialist party expressed tonight its "present hostility' 'to participating in or supporting the first government to be formed under the Fifth Republic.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Democrats were urged today to develop a "Western accent" and to take their 1960 national convention to California, in Vice President Richard M. Nixon's "back yard."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 4 -- Gore Vidal has been signed by Sam Spiegel, producer, to collaborate with Tennessee Williams in writing the screen adaptation of the latter's short play, "Suddenly, Last Summer." Elizabeth Taylor will star in the movie to be released by Columbia.

DETROIT, Dec. 4 (UPI) -- Gordie Howe scored his 399th regular season goal tonight to pace the Detroit Red Wings to a 4-0 victory over the Boston Bruins, before a crowd of 9,277. This moved the Wings into second place in the National Hockey League, and dropped the Bruins to third.

TACOMA, Wash., Dec. 4 -- Dave Beck was pictured in Federal Court here today as an open-handed friend of former football stars, especially All-America players of the University of Washington. He staked them to loans of up to $25,000, on unsecured notes, to buy homes, businesses or furnishings.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 4 -Gov. J. Lindsay Almond Jr. of Virginia labeled as "Federal N. A. A. C. P. propaganda" today a statement by a Cabinet member deploring the effects of school closings in Virginia and Arkansas.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 4 (Reuters) -- A Kenya cabinet minister said today that the Government was taking step to smash a new African secret society similar to tile anti-white terrorist May Mau underground.

Jose Torres, the unbeaten puncher from Puerto Rico, finished Ike Jenkins in 2:35 of the fifth round last night and scored a technical knockout before a niosy sellout crowd of 2,470 at Sunnyside Gardens, Queens.

PARIS, Dec. 4 -- The Council of Ministers of the six common market nations made in Brussels yesterday what was intended as a conciliatory move toward the eleven other members of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation. But it seemed doubtful today that the move would go far to overcome the split between the six and the others.

The First National City Bank of New York proposed yesterday to convert its trust affiliate the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, from a state-chartered to a national bank. The name of the institution, which has operated under a state charter 136 years, would be changed to the First National City Trust Company.
The heavy rain Wednesday night and the following morning did not keep the football Giants from engaging in a long drill at Yankee Stadium yesterday.
Mobility was restored to 129 ships in United States ports flying "flags of convenience" when a four-day boycott ended at midnight last night.

One of the burdens that modern life casts onto the shoulders of those who are advancing into middle age and beyond is the fact that grocery stores in recent years have undergone such drastic transmutations as to become almost unrecognizable.
Queens College has notified the Air Force of its intention to discontinue in June, 1960, the Reserve Officers Training Corps now in operation at the institution.

Mary Slessor, the daughter of an improvident Scots shoemaker, arrived in 1876 at a mission at Calabar in West Africa. In 1880 she went into the hinterland where no white person had gone and stayed there until her death in 1915.

An auditorium at New York University on Washington Square became a court room yesterday when Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman temporarily transferred two cases on his calendar for the benefit of 500 law students.

" Requiem for a Nun," starring Zachary Scott and his wife, Ruth Ford, is due at the Golden on Jan. 28. William Faulkner, recipient of the Nobel Prize (1949) and the Pulitzer Prize (1955), is the author of the drama, based on his novel.
Members of the Sons of the Revolution in the State of New York yesterday elected Gilbert Rogers Byrne president of the society.

A Holiday Hop for students at five Brooklyn Schools will be held on Dec. 30 in the Roof of the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn, to benefit the New York Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation. The proceeds will go toward the $100,000 goal of the foundation's Brooklyn Division.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- Premier de Gaulle's proposals for increased military effectiveness in the West go beyond the North Atlantic Alliance to reorganization of the military system of the free world, authoritative sources said tonight.
The city-wide drive against fire hazards in schools continued yesterday with the closing of a private school in Queens and the reopening of a Bronx school that had corrected its violations overnight.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 4 -- A session of the Security Council on Israel's new charges against the United Arab Republic probably will not be held before next week, United Nations sources indicated today.
New York University's Bronx campus, open only to male students since it was established in 1894, will become coeducational next September.

Godfrey M. Weinstein Co., builders, bought four tenement houses at 317 to 323 East Forty-eighth Street. They plan to demolish the structures and erect an apartment building Oh the plot of 100 by 100 feet.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -There is nothing like a slow boat from California to restore a man's faith in the human race. Take it from Senator William F. Knowland, the retiring Republican leader in the Senate.
MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 4 -- The policy-making body of the American Medical Association adopted today a proposal aimed at cutting health insurance costs for elderly persons with low incomes.

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad went into the State Supreme Court yesterday to try to force the New York Central Railroad to grant it a 50 per cent interest in a twenty-story office building at 52 Vanderbilt Avenue that the Central purchased more than two years ago.

Michael H. Prendergast, Democratic state chairman, charged yesterday that Senator Walter J. Mahoney, the Republican majority leader, was "attempting to falsify the record" to justify his support of a gasoline tax rise.

ATLANTA, Dec. 4 (AP) -- An Atlanta business man who joined two anti-Negro, anti-Jewish groups and turned over information to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, today associated a man on trial for dynamiting the Jewish temple here with John Kasper, a segregationist.
City labor unions affiliated with the old American Federation of Labor last night voted approval of merger terms with the Congress of Industrial Organizations.
New York City, the biggest port of entry in the nation, is expected to handle more foreign travel this year than at any time since World War II.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board approved today the selection of the Federation Bank and Trust Company and the United States Trust Company, both of New York, to act as trustees in an exchange of stock by Pan American World Airways and National Airlines.

The development of social psychiatry teams to examine the factory, the community, the university, the government agency and other organizations to identify factors fostering mental illness was suggested here yesterday.
CHICAGO, Dec 4 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

PARENTS who give vent to their own frustrations by pushing their children into unreasonable competition were scathingly scored last night in "Free Week-nEd,' by Steven Gethers, on "Playhouse 90" on Channel 2.

One reason that theatregoers may have found it hard to get tickets for Broadway hits came to light yesterday in an accountant's report on the finances of the scandal-stained International Jewelry Workers Union.

IT is high season now for smaller works of art in New York, and high time, too. The fact that water-colors, drawings and prints can at times assume the majestic and quintessential esthetic character of masterworks, and that they often can be purchased at unbelievably low prices, has too long been obscured by a condition of calculated inflation.

Miles Laboratories, Inc., is offering its common stockholders rights to subscribe for $6,035,400 of convertible subordinated debentures, due 1978, at par on the basis of $100 of debentures for each twenty shares held.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 4 -- Following is the rollcall vote by which the General Assembly's Political Committee adopted tonight the Iranian resolution on Cyprus:

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 4 (UPI) -- Earl Buchholz, Barry MacKay and two other members of the United States Davis Cup squad scored straight-set victories over Australians today in first-round men's singles matches at the Victorian tennis championships.
BUFFALO, N. Y., Dec. 4 -- An official of the American Iron and Steel Institute predicted tonight that Soviet steel products would appear in world markets in greater volume.

Led by the spectacular Oscar Robertson, who scored 45 points, the University of Cincinnati basketball team rallied and beat New York University last night, 88 to 67. The game was the feature of a twin bill that marked the twenty-fifth anniversary of the sport at Madison Square Garden.
GENEVA, Dec. 4 -- The Soviet Union wants to restrict to itself, the United States and Britain an agreement for the control of a halt in nuclear testing, Western sources said today.
Twenty-three thousand inbound commuters were delayed twelve minutes to an hour yesterday after separate freight train breakdowns blocked tracks used by the Long Island and New Haven railroads.

Prices fell sharply in the last few minutes of stock market trading yesterday, but the session managed to close with an inconspicuous gain. Steels and rubbers were generally higher. Other major groups were lower, or thoroughly mixed.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- Funeral services were held this morning in Our Lady of the Angels Church for three nuns who died Monday in the fire that destroyed their school and also took the lives of eighty-seven children.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4 (UPI) -- Virgil Akins will make his first defense of the world welterweight crown tomorrow night against the rugged Don (Geronimo) Jordan at the Olympic Auditorium.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads today estimated the net income of Class I rail carriers in October at $97,000,000, the highest earnings reported for a month since the October, 1956, net of $103,000,000.
DETROIT, Dec. 4 -- The Life Masters Individual Championship, most coveted individual national championship title in United States tournament bridge, was won today by Mrs. Sylvia Stein of Detroit.

In your Nov. 26 editorial "New Look at Foreign Aid" you state that the focus of concern has shifted from military assistance during the Korean war, particularly to concern over the political gains which the Communist nations may make from their economic aid to underdeveloped countries.
SAN BRUNO, Calif., Dec. 4 (UPI) -- Silky Sullivan returned to the races today as he put on his celebrated come-from-behind finish to win the six-furlongs feature at Tanforan.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Organized labor celebrated the twentieth anniversary of the Fair Labor Standards Act today by opening a drive to extend the act's coverage and to raise the minimum wage.
Plans to begin a community drama program in East Harlem were announced yesterday at a meeting at the Museum of the City of New York.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 4 -- The active role of France in the two-day meeting here of the Council of Ministers of the European Economic Community is a source of satisfied comment among participants from the five other nations.
BOSTON, Dec. 4 -- Archbishop Richard J. Cushing applied today what was believed to be the decisive blow against a state lottery in Massachusetts.
ALBANY, Dec. 5 (UPI) -- The State Commerce Department reported the fololwing ski conditions today:
CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- A single funeral was held today for twenty-seven victims of the fire Monday at Our Lady of Angels parochial school.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 5 -- Iceland rejected, in a statement circulated here today, a complaint by Britain that a fishing trawler had been illegally fired upon and detained by an Icelandic coast guard vessel.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The Evening Star was struck today by members of the American Newspaper Guild.

CHRISTMAS ornaments with an "heirloom quality" have been introduced at Place Noel, 203 East Sixty-second Street. Here luxurious trees, balls and decorative objects are made to order in brilliant jewels, metals, rich fabrics and crystals.

STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 5 -- The Connecticut chairman of national defense of the Daughters of the American Revolution is seeking a list of all textbooks used in the state's primary and secondary schools.

The Stouffer Corporation has announced plans for Stouffer's Eastchester, a restaurant with a seating capacity of 610 to be built in the Lord Taylor-Westchester Shopping Center on White Plains Road, Eastchester N. Y.
HONG KONG, Dec. 5 -The opening of an international trade fair here today set off political repercussions from Communist China.

The Trio di Bolzano appeared in a distinguished debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. Before the evening was out it revealed a strong and distinctive personality as a group, with many individual excellences as well.
SAN LUIS POTOSI, Mexico, Dec. 5 -- This important industrial city of nearly 200,000 people was virtually paralyzed today by a strike of business and labor organizations.

Bids for control of the Iron Fireman Manufacturing Company are expected to be made soon by several interests, according to reports in Wall Street. Iron Fireman stock was freed this week from a thirty-year voting trust.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 5 (UPI) -- Don (Geronimo) Jordan, lanky Los Angeles boxer, wrested the world welterweight championship from Virgil Akins tonight, scoring a unanimous fifteen-round decision with a consistent left-jabbing and hooking attack.
MOSCOW, Dec. 5 -- The Soviet Government is taking every opportunity to stress the firmness of its resolve to get the Western powers out of Berlin.

SAN BRUNO, Calif., Dec. 5 (UPI) -- Johnny Longden, who was riding winners when Jack Dempsey was a heavyweight champion, returned to racing today and finished second aboard Royal Reserve, despite a brilliant bid.

The American Stock Exchange continually scrutinizes electronic developments for devices to speed its operation. But at the critical phase -- the hectic trading on the floor -- it clings stubbornly to a primitive communications system.

The Boys Clubs of America has announced plans for a new six-story headquarters building to be built at 771 First Avenue at Forty-fourth Street facing the United Nations. It will be named the Herbert Hoover Building in honor of the former President of the United States who has been chairman of the board of the organization for more than twenty years.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 5 -- The Yugoslav Government voiced approval today of Soviet proposals on Berlin insofar as they represented a bid for negotiations on the future of that city and of Germany as a whole.
The cruise liner Arosa Star of the Swiss-owned Arosa Line was abruptly ordered to put into Bermuda yesterday, less than twenty-four hours before she was due to return here with 183 cruise passengers.

The Western railroads are taking new bold steps to recover freight traffic from the trucks. Yesterday, the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific; the Chicago and North Western and the Union Pacific Railroads announced that starting on Monday freight shipped from Chicago to Los Angeles would arrive there on the third morning after shipment.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 5 -- The basketball season opens for St. Peter's College tomorrow night and the contest is being awaited with anticipation. Students as well as members of the college's asphalt alumni (local residents) are all keyed up.
A SPANISH couturier who likes the height of American women and Park Avenue buildings is in New York on his first visit here.
Witold Malcuzynski, absent last season from these shores, returned to Carnegie Hall last night for a piano recital. He has a large following, and the hall was comfortably filled.
JERSEY CITY, Dec. 5 -- A Woodbridge municipal ordinance setting a 12:30 A. M. curfew on drive-in theatres was set aside today by Judge John B. McGeehan in the Hudson County Courthouse here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UPI) -- Elwood R. Quesada, head of the new Federal Aviation Agency, hinted today that the Administration might increase its spending next year for the development of modern electronic traffic-control equipment.
A three-member citizens' committee was appointed yesterday by the State Education Commissioner to look into charges of waste in the city's school-construction program.
SHOP TALK today ferrets out the undercover story on lingerie gifts.
LAWRENCE, Kan., Dec. 5 (AP) -- Three young chemical engineers were killed and two injured critically today in a forbidden rocket experiment.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent to 119 per cent of their 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Democratic and Republican leaders agreed informally today to seek an agreement on a single city for their 1960 national conventions.
Gerardo (Jerry) Anastasio, one of the family of the New York waterfront figures, died Tuesday in Long Island College Hospital, Brooklyn, it became known yesterday.

PARIS, Dec. 5 -- The new Director General of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, Dr. Vittorino Veronese, is a man of many talents. But foremost, to many observers, the 48-year-old Italian is a "European intellectual" who can well be ex pected to place stress on the cultural and aesthetic aspects of UNESCO as the simple and natural reflex of his character and personality.
The northwest corner of Park Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street has been purchased by Austin Daniels, builders, for improvement with a sixteen-story cooperative apartment house.

The other day, at about 6 P. M., drove south on the Grand Concours from 195th Street to 138th Street without a single stop -- and in medium to heavy traffic! Congratulations and thanks to those who have made this possible.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 5 -- The General Assembly unanimously approved today a resolution asking that an International Health and Medical Research Year be organized.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 5 -- The Lackawanna Railroad declared its intention today to seek abandonment of all of its New Jersey passenger services in 1959 unless it is relieved before then of all of its property taxes.

The University of Baltimore, paced by Bill Frantz and Jack Bychick, defeated Long Island University's quintet, 63 -- 60, at the Brooklyn Central Y. M. C. A. last night. Frantz had 22 points and Bychick made 21.
NORWALK, Conn. -- The town's Charter Revision Commission voted last night, 9 to 6, to recommend a strong mayor rather than a council-manager form of government.

THE O-the-Wild-Wonder-of-It-All School of writing about the American West fulfills a national and international need for vicarious adventure. The Frenchman, the Briton, the Slav and the Asian enjoy it as much as the citizens of our own Republic. In truth, it is even more popular, globally speaking, than books about the War Between the States. And that's saying a lot, isn't it ?

The fifth annual series of free Evenings-by-the-River summer concerts on the Lower East Side will continue as a result of a theatre party at the Feb. 4 preview performance of "Redhead." Gwen Verdon will star in the new musical, scheduled to open at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre on Feb. 5.
NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 5 -- Lance Reventlow of Beverly Hills, Calif., drove one of his Chevrolet-powered Scarabs to an easy victory today in the 112.5-mile Governor's Cup race.
Four years ago, when tall, broad-shouldered Paul Dietzel, then only 30 years old, took over the head coaching job at Louisiana State University, he expressed his football philosophy in simple terms.

Plans for a ten-story parking garage for 550 cars were announced yesterday by the U. S. Parking Corporation, which has contracted to buy the blockfront on the east side of Whitehall Street from Bridge to Stone Streets opposite the Custom House.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The National Consumers League today set as goals for the next Congress the liberalization of unemployment insurance and a Federal medical care program for the aged.
NEWTON, Mass., Dec. 5 (AP) -- Holy Cross tonight watched its "favorite" tag fade on the eve of its fifty-fifth football meeting with Boston College.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- A Federal Reserve Board hearing examiner today recommended approval of a proposed merger, which would give the Firstamerica Corporation control of the California Bank of Los Angeles.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 5 -- An agreement between Maryland and Virginia, signaling an end to their historic oyster war, is expected to be signed Dec. 20 at the estate of George Washington, Mount Vernon, Va.
The new tanker Kings Point missed out on her debut by an hour here yesterday.
ZABRZE, Poland, Dec. 4 -- The store manager lovingly straightened a can of sardines on the shelf and then took in the whole glistening shop with a sort of happy, embracing gesture.
A world-wide boycott by the International Transport Workers Federation against "flags of convenience" ships has resulted in the defection of one of the organization's most important members.

Last July many of the nation's suavest city slickers suddenly became aware of an almost incredible group of country bumpkins who made moonshine and tall tales in a snuff-dipping Texas town called Cut 'n' Shoot.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 5 (AP) -- An admitted Ku Klux Klansman was convicted today of bombing a Negro home. He was sentenced to ten years in prison by a jury, which recommended probation.
LONDON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Fog-bound Britain's pneumonia and bronchitis deaths jumped sharply in November, totaling 3,532 against 2,682 the year before.

HASSI MESSAOUD, Algeria, Dec. 5 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle seemed today to have been impressed by reports of progress at two Saharan oil fields that France regards as a main source of her future prosperity.
Some of the drug, electronic and chemical issues pushed forward boldly yesterday, but the market as a whole was uncertain and closed with moderate losses.

The American Academy of Arts and Letters, an honorary society of artists, writers and composers, announced yesterday the election of Samuel Barber, composer; Charles E. Burchfield, painter; the Rev. Dr. Reinhold Niebuhr, theologian, and William Carlos Williams, poet.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- A new applicant asked the Federal Communications Commission today to let him get into the fight for television Channel 10 in Miami.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- George V. Allen, director of the United States Information Agency, has changed his mind and has decided to authorize the book, "The Ugly American" for so-called "subsidized" sale abroad.

The Chicago Black Hawks will engage the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League contest today that will be nationally televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System. The game at Chicago Stadium will start at 2 P. M. New York time.

BARBARA WILSON has sent 80,000 brides down the aisle in the last sixteen years. From this day forward, she is resolved that each of her future brides will look different from the others. Mrs. Wilson is starting a new wedding gown service at Tailored Woman, where she has just been appointed bridal director.
ROME, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's Italian tailor wants to give President Eisenhower a vicuna coat. He says that he knew nothing about Sherman Adams when he announced his plans.
LONDON, Dec. 5 (UPI) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey said tonight he believed that Premier Khrushchev's plan to make West Berlin a demilitarized free city was "phony."
AGNES Martin, whose talent was seasoned on the New Mexican desert, is exhibiting her oils for the first time in New York at Betty Parsons' Section Eleven Gallery, 11 East Fifty-seventh Street.

The recent statement of Mayor Wagner blaming New Jersey for much of the polluted air hanging over New York does not at all correspond with the facts. This became vividly apparent to me on a recent inter-airport helicopter ride.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The Democratic Credentials Committee turned back tonight an effort to replace Louisiana's national committeeman in the face of warnings that the action might promote a Southern bolt.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- Until military vehicles began speeding along its roads during World War II, traffic had been slight. Since then it has picked up momentum.

PORT SAID, Egypt, Saturday, Dec. 6 -- President Tito of Yugoslavia dropped anchor here yesterday on a cruise to Ceylon for a brief meeting with President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic.

In early September Nelson A. Rockefeller was asked if his election as Governor would assure restoration of "forgiveness" in the income tax rate in New York State. He refused to make any such promise, and said he didn't think the fiscal picture was "very encouraging." In early October, as the campaign warmed up, he said New York was "entering into its most serious financial crisis in a generation."

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The National Amateur Athletic Union track and field meet in Boulder, Colo., June 19-20, will serve as the United States trials for the Pan-American Games in Chicago Aug. 27 Sept. 7.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- A special House Elections Committee ordered Arkansas officials today to impound all ballots in the election that defeated Representative Brooks Hays, Democrat.
WASHINGTON, Saturday, Dec. 6 -- A scientist said early today that the Army's Juno rocket would not reach the vicinity of the moon because it had not attained sufficient velocity.
A group of young business men and Macy's joined yesterday to enable 1.216 orphaned or unwanted children to purchase a little Christmas joy.
The Irving Trust Company announced yesterday that it was entering the Federal Funds market as a money broker. It is the first bank to enter the field.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Dec. 5 (UPI) -- Johnny Bulla, whose erratic putting has cost him top money more than once, shot a brilliant seven-under-par 65 today to win the 54-hole Southern California Open golf tournament by two strokes.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- A Pennsylvania doctor patented a substitute for the human vocal cords this week. He hopes it will help rehabilitate the many persons whose larynxes have been removed by surgery.

PAWTUCKET, R. I., Dec. 5 (AP) -- S. B. Crawford's Epic Lad today became the 161st winner this year for Frank H. Merrill Jr., the leading trainer of North America. The 3-year-old Epic gelding won the Centredale Purse by half a length before 8,920 at Narragansett Park.
