HAVANA, Dec. 5 -- A battle between rebels of Fidel Castro and Government troops at Guisa, Santa Barbara and El Corojo in Oriente Province has been reported by both the rebels and the Government.
Experiments believed to have demonstrated for the first time the existence of electrons that behaved as though they had negative mass have been reported to the American Physical Society.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Earl E. T. Smith, Ambassador to Cuba, began consultations at the State Department today about the increasingly dangerous position of the Cuban Government of President Fulgencio Batista.
EASTBOURNE, England, Dec. 5 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan declared tonight that expanding trade was "an essential condition of the continuing strength of the nations of the free world."
PARIS, Dec. 5 -- Dr. Vittorino Veronese of Italy took over the directorship of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization today.
Northeast Airlines has reached an agreement with its mechanics.
CHICAGO, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Futures dealers displayed a warm friendliness for soybeans today on the Board of Trade. But they still were indifferent toward the grains.

DETROIT, Dec. 5 (UPI) -- Howard (Hopalong) Cassady today was added to the ever-growing list of Detroit Lion casualties. The halfback sprained his ankle in practice today and Coach George Wilson said he would miss the Giants' game.
President Eisenhower will propose new legislation to curb the power of labor unions, Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield told the National Association of Manufacturers last night.
A child's hostility toward his parents may even drive him to communism in later years, a psychoanalyst reported here yesterday.

Recently a fire broke out in the apartment next to mine. I seized my telephone and dialed O for Operator. There was no reply and I could hear no ringing. After a few seconds I thought the line was dead, but then hung up and tried again.
Hopes for a contract settlement next week were expressed yesterday by a source close to the negotiations between the four major radio and television networks and a performers' union.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 5 -- Gov. Orvil E. Faubus today attacked four men and a woman who are candidates for the Little Rock school board as "the integration slate."
HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 5 -- Finland put aside her Cabinet crisis today and prepared for tomorrow's observance of the forty-first anniversary of her independence.
Tammy Grimes is set for the title role in Noel Coward's farce "Lulu," the adaptation of Georges Feydeau's "Occupe-toid' Amelie."
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy announced yesterday the adoption of a new working schedule for detectives that will standardize their hours.
Leyna Gabriele's Town Hall recital program last night was made up in great part of operatic music. Nevertheless, there was little that was familiar or hackneyed.

DORADO BEACH, P. R., Dec. 5 (UPI) -- Tommy Jacobs, a 155-pound golf professional from Whittier, Calif., putted brilliantly today and shot a four-under-par 68 for 139 to take a one-stroke lead in the Dorado Beach invitation tournament.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The disclosure of union financial reports was one of many provisions in the Kennedy-Ives labor reform bill, which died in the last session of Congress.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The top Soviet cultural official expressed bewilderment today at "all the noise" in the United States about the affair of Boris Pasternak and his novel, "Doctor Zhivago."

While private contributions to higher education have been rising sharply -- reaching $833 million last year, more than double the amount of two years before -- there remains a major "blind spot" in American educational philanthropy.
A little known man whose name is synonymous with navigation is being honored today, 185 years after his birth and 156 years after the work that made him famous was published.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 5 -- By unanimous vote, a General Assembly committee adopted a resolution today calling on all states to promote "peaceful and neighborly relations." The count was 68 to 0, the total number of those present and voting.

Events today: Mozart's "The Magic Flute," 2 P. M., and Puccini's "Tosca," 8, both at the Metropolitan Opera; the New York Philharmonic, Claudio Arrau, pianist, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 8:30.

MONTREAL, Dec. 5 -- The Dominion Steel and Coal Corporation, a subsidiary of the A. V. Roe industrial complex, is negotiating for the construction of both hot and cold rolled steel mills at Contrecoeur near here.
Six more school buildings were ordered closed here yesterday in the Fire Department's drive to end fire hazards.
The Phillips-Van Heusen Corporation, makers of men's furnishing's and sportswear, has acquired control of Kennedy's, Inc., a New England group of fifteen men's clothing and furnishings stores.
Deputy Police Commissioner Walter Arm said yesterday that a new investigation had been ordered into the case of two Queens detectives who were demoted.
City Investigation Commissioner Louis I. Kaplan appealed yesterday to "all public-spirited citizens" to give information about misconduct in any city agency to his office.
A crane operator and several others involved in reroofing the north wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art laid duty aside to hoist a huge wreath to the museum's main entrance yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- A new kind of electronic gavel, plated in gold, was presented to the National Press Club tonight at the club's fiftieth anniversary celebration.

DETROIT, Dec. 5 -- The official timer said that exactly a second and a half remained when Frank Selvy's one-hander gave the New York Knickerbockers a 110 -- 108 victory over the Detroit Pistons tonight.
Villanova's swimming team defeated Fordham, 53 -- 32, at the Rams' pool in the Bronx yesterday. It was the Wildcats' opening meet of the season. The setback was Fordham's first in two starts.
The arrest of a truck dispatcher and the recovery of $12,000 worth of infants' comforters, pillows and decorative sofa cushions was announced yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
An improving and confident Roy Campanella accepted a call yesterday to help slum-area children in a drive on delinquency.
Columbia's swimming team opened its season yesterday with a 58-27 victory over City College at the Beavers' pool.
A classroom built inside its factory was dedicated yesterday in Kalamazoo, Mich., by the Brunswick-Balke-Collender Company, manufacturer of school furniture and allied equipment.

Cocoa futures prices advanced the one-cent-a-pound daily limit yesterday in all positions on the New York Cocoa Exchange. December, the spot month, which has no limit, advanced 153 points (hundredths of a cent a pound).
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- A Soviet virologist said today that his country was producing a better poliomyelitis vaccine than the United States but not in such great quantity.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Saturday, Dec. 6 -- The United States launched a 12.9-pound package of delicate instruments toward the moon at 12:45 A. M. today.
Hanukkah, one of the major festivals of Judaism, will begin at sundown today and will be observed for eight days.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Members of the Eighty-sixth Congress, convening next month, will find that Capitol Hill has some unusual contours.
FLORENCE, Ariz., Dec. 5 (UPI) -- Forty-six inmates of the Arizona State Prison who rioted last night were placed today in cells whose doors were welded shut.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 5 -- The Security Council was called today to meet at 3 P. M. Monday on Israel's complaint of border violence by troops of the United Arab Republic.

THE city of Paris never tires of posing for its portrait. Nor, apparently, does the painter Bemelmans tire of painting it. No less than fifty of his new pictures of the city and its inhabitants are on view at the Hammer Gallery, 51 East Fifty-seventh Street.
GENEVA, Dec. 5 -- Britain proposed today an international inspection system to prevent surprise attacks by ground forces.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 5 -- We cannot permit Communist-sponsored crises in such distant places as Quemoy or Berlin to deflect our attention from the basic cold war struggle. This has now shifted to the economic field and here we are losing out.
LONDON, Dec. 5 -- Over the last two months the British Government has gradually assumed the position of accepting United States policy on China as unalterable under the present conditions.

An "All-African People's Conference" is getting under way in Accra, capital of Ghana. It is not an official meeting of representatives of states, although its host will be a Ghanian political party headed by the Prime Minister, Kwame Nkrumah. There will be about 500 delegates from various types of groups -- political, agricultural, trade union and social -- and many foreign observers.

EASTBOURNE, England, Dec. 5 -- Comdr. Edward Whitehead, president of Schweppes (U.S.A.), Ltd., advised a group discussing "British industry's public relations" today not to send "squares" to North America to represent them.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- A Federal grant of $45,510 was promised today to help rebuild the Clinton (Tenn.) high school, which was bombed by anti-integrationists Oct. 5.

TACOMA, Wash., Dec. 5 (AP) -- A teamsters' union attorney retrieved a statement about Dave Beck's financial condition only a few days before an Internal Revenue Service agent asked to see it, a witness testified today.
A pool shark whose Christmas business was said to be the manufacture of bathtub perfume was arraigned yesterday in Upper Manhattan Court.

In his letter published Nov. 28 Murray Lincoln Miller considers as "pure propaganda beamed at America" Khrushchev's proposed program to shorten high school education, thus bringing youth earlier into production. Dr. Miller believes that "Khrushchev wants the United States to ease up on education improvements."

The threat of a strike of non-professional employes at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx appeared to have abated somewhat last night following a two-hour conference of hospital and union officials with Mayor Wagner.

ATLANTA, Dec. 5 (AP) -- A state witness quoted George Bright today as having said he had served as a lookout for the dynamiting of the Jewish Temple Oct. 12. The witness said Bright had told him another of the five defendants placed the explosive.

A thousand diamonds in thanksgiving for 500 diamonds stolen and returned six years ago will be bestowed upon the statue of the Blessed Virgin in the Regina Pacis Votive Shrine in Brooklyn tomorrow afternoon.

DETROIT, Dec. 5 -- Sixty-six contract bridge teams played the semi-final round in the Open Teams of Four championship of the 1958 annual Winter National championship this afternoon. The event is being held here at the Sheraton-Cadillac Hotel.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Prince Georges Golf and Country Club team of Landover, Md., put together a nine-under-par best-ball of 59 today to win the sixth annual Goodwill golf tournament.

Rosalind Elias took the part of Marina for the first time in last night's performance of Mussorksky's "Boris Godunov" at the Metropolitan Opert. The capacity audience gave a warm reception to her dramatic and artistic portrayal of the Polish princess.

WHEN Aaron Copland's Piano Variations were new in 1930, they were described as austere and forbidding. These adjectives and others like them were trotted out regularly for this abstract piece, which marked an important plateau in the composer's development.
LONDON, Dec. 5 -- Helped by several good company statements and a steady but highly selective demand, industrials closed the week with prices rising.
MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 5 -- Soviet medicine may be ahead of the United States in employing the technique of restarting hearts that stop in the operating room or hospital ward, a surgeon said here today.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Taft-Hartley Law makes it mandatory for a labor organization to provide its members with financial reports, the Tenth United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled today.
A citation for "inspired planning that has created a gateway of welcome to our nation" at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, was awarded the Port of New York Authority yesterday.

BERLIN, Dec. 5 -- The East German Government announced tonight that it was holding in custody a United States Army pilot who parachuted from his small liaison aircraft into East Germany Wednesday evening.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UPI) -- The committee of the twenty-one American republics set up a seven-nation working group today to coordinate a new plan for the economic development of Latin America.
HONG KONG, Nov. 28 -- One of the products at a local department store specializing in the sale of goods from Communist China is perfumed cotton cloth for women's clothing.
The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith contended yesterday that "sectarian observances of religious holidays" had no place in the public schools.
BRISBANE, Australia, Dec. 5 (Reuters) -- Australia dealt a staggering blow to England on the opening day of the first of a series of cricket test matches today.
BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Dec. 5 -- Hobart's quintet defeated Harpur, 55 -- 44, in the second game of a double-header tonight. In the first game, Wooster downed Hamilton 78 -- 48.

Directors of Wilson Co. yesterday increased the dividend with the declaration of 35 cents a share for each of the four quarters of next year. The dividends are payable on the first of February, May, August and November to holders of record of Jan. 9, April 10, July 10 and Oct. 9, respectively.
ACCRA, Ghana, Dec. 5 -- Tom Mboya, moderate nationalist leader of Kenya's Trade Union Federation, was elected chairman of the All-African People's Conference here today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 5 -- The General Assembly, in an unexpected move, adopted a new resolution on Cyprus today.
Two of the nation's largest aluminum producers yesterday promised their customers, in effect, that aluminum prices would not be raised for at least six months.
Many foreign dignitaries attended the third annual Gala de la Mediterranee last night in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.
The city's newspaper publishers said last night they would try to continue publication if their deliverers struck tomorrow night and other union employes stayed on the job.

Philips Lamp Works (N. V. Philips Gloellampenfabrieken) of the Netherlands showed sharp increases in sales and earnings for the nine and twelve months ended Sept. 30, according to the report released yesterday.

Stephen F. Voorhees and Ralph Walker have withdrawn as partners in the architectural firm of Voorhees, Walker, Smith, Smith, Haines. They will become consultants to the firm, which will continue without change of name under the direction of Perry Coke Smith, Benjamin Lane Smith and Charles Haines.
The long Thanksgiving week end contributed to a rise last week in the number of newly unemployed persons in the state claiming insurance benefits, and to an apparent decline in continued claims.
The possible means that the Treasury may use to lengthen the public debt without trying to sell a long-term bond next year inspire some varied thinking.
A prediction that there will be a "definite reduction, a very significant one." in the 1960 Federal budget was made yesterday by Maurice H. Stans, Director of the Bureau of the Budget.

COLRAIN, Mass., Dec. 5 -- The deer put on an exhibition today of extreme stealth, or extreme laziness. Six hunters spent most of the day trying to drive several of them out of a small patch of pines. None of them came out.

DETROIT, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Auto dealers averaged 18,400 new car deliveries a day from Nov. 21 to 30 and manufacturers scheduled the highest production this week since November, 1957, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

"The Sugar Pill," a look at the modern newspaper by T. S. Matthews, will be published Jan. 5 by Simon Schuster. Mr. Matthews, a former editor of Time Magazine, begins his work with these statements: "This is a book with a thesis.

Sidney Meyers, scenarist and director, will be today's speaker in the second of this season's programs on contemporary local film-makers at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street. He will show a long sequence from "The Quiet One" and an excerpt from "Adventure in the Arts." The program starts at 2:45 P. M.
THERE are two ways of viewing a room divider, says Alexander Girard, architect. They are "the way it looks and the way it works."
CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- Gov. Lane Dwinnel of New Hampshire urged today that State Governments be more active in helping cities to cope with slum clearance.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 5 -- An Alabama judge defied the Civil Rights Commission today to make him surrender voter registration records in his custody.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Two Teamsters Union leaders who were charged by a Senate committee with misappropriating union funds were re-elected overwhelmingly in their local's election.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 55 points down to 3 points up yesterday. A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies won't televise their National League games into New York City next season, Bob Carpenter, the club's president, said today.
Two Long Island druggists who admitted substituting penny cold tablets for an expensive antibiotic prescribed by a physician were fined $1,500 each and placed on three years' probation yesterday.

Stockholders of U. S. Vitamin Corporation yesterday approved a proposal to distribute one additional share of common stock for each share now held. At a special meeting, the stockholders authorized an increase in the common stock to 3,000,000 shares from 1,000,000.
RABAT, Morocco, Dec. 5 -- A captain in the French Foreign Legion was killed today during a riot in Casablanca stirred by a reported French attack on a camp of Algerian refugees in Morocco.
New stock and bond flotations promise to set an even faster pace next week than last.

OLD-FASHIONED, steel-cut oatmeal, once a staple in grocery stores, is hard to find nowadays. Martha M. Case of Jamestown, N. Y., would like to know if it is possible to buy it anywhere in this country.
PEIPING, Dec. 5 (Reuters) -- Two of Communist China's eight non-Communist parties have re-elected six demoted "Rightists" to their Central Committees, according to press reports here today.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Wheatley Stable's Gray Phantom equalled the Tropical Park track record for six furlongs while winning the featured seventh race today.

KAMPALA, Uganda, Dec. 5 -- The Lukiko (native council) of Buganda adopted a resolution today to write to Queen Elizabeth saying that the time had come for her, as the symbol of British power to relinquish her protectorate over the territory.
Dr. Lee L. Davenport, president of Sylvania-Corning Nuclear Corporation, Bayside, L. I., has been elected to the board of the Connecticut Instrument Corporation, Wilton, Conn.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 5 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru went to bat today for his controversial Defense Minister, V. K. Krishna Menon, in a lively parliamentary debate on India's arms procurement policies.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 5 (UPI) -- Earl Buchholz of St. Louis gained the third round in men's singles today at the Victorian tennis championships but suffered an injury that may hurt the chances of America's Davis Cup team.

The first outlines of a comprehensive Western peace program to end the cold war by solving the inextricably linked problems of Berlin, Germany, European security and armament control have now been advanced by British Foreign Secretary Lloyd.

TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 6 -- President Carlos P. Garcia of the Philippines left for Manila today. He said he was convinced that "the Philippines and Japan as friends will contribute to the peace and prosperity not only of free Asians, but of the whole world."

Your "Random Notes From Washington" on Dec. 1 makes the post that the automatic seniority system for selecting committee chairman in Congress has stalled the otherwise desirable plan to divide in to the cumbersome House Committee on Education and Labor.
The New York Knickerbockers will meet the "Ex-Knickerbockers" -- now wearing the uniforms of the Detroit Pistons -- in a National Basketball Association game at Madison Square Garden tonight.
The baseball sessions just ended in Washington might best be described as probably having attained the last word in utter futility.
ALTHOUGH John Ford's seventeenth century "'Tis Pity She's a Whore" has a scandalous title, it is a serious-minded and interesting play.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 5 -- Despite protest by a domestic manufacturer, the Tennessee Valley Authority was committed today to installation of three Swiss-made hydroelectric generators.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 5 (UPI) -- The Los Angeles Rams, who sink or swim on the strength of their passing game, on defense as well as offense, welcomed two key men back today on the eve of their National Football League game with the Baltimore Colts.
LONDON, Dec. 5 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan formally opened an eight-mile stretch of express highway today and termed it as historically memorable as the first jet engine.

LONDON, Saturday, Dec. 6 (Reuters) -- Some 7,000 stockholders in the British Aluminium Company were urged today to support a recent decision by the board to sell a one-third interest in the company to the Aluminum Company of America (Alcoa).
Army, Post Office and longshore union officials failed yesterday to come up with a solution to the question of shipping overseas military mail in large containers.
The New York Giants left Grand Central Station at 7:15 last night for Detroit and their National Football League game against the Lions in Briggs Stadium Sunday.
One of New York's historic landmarks, Grace Protestant Episcopal Church at Broadway and Tenth Street, will begin tomorrow a month-long observance of its 150th anniversary.
SYRACUSE, Dec. 5 -- A Negro social worker declared today that too many social agencies were automatically classifying babies as unadoptable because they had mixed racial backgrounds.
LONDON, Dec. 5 -- The Soviet Union's intention to transfer power in East Berlin to the East German Government by June 1 was emphatically repeated by Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev tonight.

WOULD there be anyone so unromantic as to gainsay the notion that spring is a most appropriate season in which to behold again Robert Browning's courtship of Elizabeth Barrett? No objecting hands being observed, the notion is carried.

HONORS for prolific production in America this year go to Evan Hunter, who has published five and a half suspense novels, mostly as Ed McBain. But he's easily topped by England's John Creasey, with six novels under four names. . . . plus an omnibus of four novels all new to America.

Many business organizations are preparing for changes that must be made in pension and other welfare plans on Jan. 1, 1959, because of new laws. Private employe benefit programs then will be policed by the Government for the first time and Social Security payments will rise to a new record level.

VANCOUVER, B. C., Dec. 6 -- Louis Lourmais plunged into the Fraser River at Hixon, in northern British Columbia, this morning on the third day of his attempt to swim 500 miles down the ice-packed river to the sea. The temperature was 13 degrees below zero.

Without venturing further into the discussion evoked by Prof. Seymour Harris' suggestion of a long-term credit basis for the payment of college tuition charges, and by Prof. Dale H. Sieling's reply in your issue of Nov. 30, I cannot forbear to point out a popular fallacy into which the latter has fallen in his concluding paragraphs about the exemption of so-called private institutions from taxation.

THE Moscow-to-Hollywood traffic hit a new high in recent days, but whether understanding between the moviemakers of the United States and the Soviet Union was advanced proportionately in relation to the number of visitors is a moot question.

THE name of Nobel, through the prizes established by him, has become a household word. Even many adults have only a vague idea of the man whose figure stands behind the periodic awards in the sciences, for peacemaking, and for literature.

THE members of the George Saintsbury Poetry Club have found all in all that George Saintsbury (1845-1933) is the most useful critic who has ever lived. We also know what Aristotle, Hazlitt, Sainte-Beuve, Croce and others had what George Saintsbury didn't.

MONTICELLO, N. Y. -- Although the lower Catskills, specifically in Sullivan County, do not have a great wealth of skiable snow under normal conditions, this teeming resort area has earned the title of the artificial snow capital of New York State.

With reference to the letters in last Sunday's issue of The New York Times, may I say that we at the Metropolitan could not be more in agreement with the objections to interruptions of the music by ill-timed applause.
CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (UPI) -- Police and fire experts will question at least 500 of the 1,200 boys and girls who escaped the fire at Our Lady of the Angels School, which claimed ninety-one lives.
GENEVA, Dec. 6 -- The United States, Britain and the Soviet Union agreed today on the first article of a proposed treaty to prohibit nuclear weapons tests.

COLRAIN, Mass., Dec. 6 -- Deer hunting in these foothills of the Berkshires is about as informal as hunting can get. This is country-type hunting, where every hunter does as he pleases, nobody directs or manages, and organization is held to a minimum. It is satisfactory.

IN Robert Gorham Davis' excellent article on the Columbia-Esquire Writers' Symposium, "Readers and Writers Face to Face," I found but one serious omission. That is mention of the audience's reaction to Leslie Fiedler's second address, which Mr. Davis accurately describes as, if anything could be, more vituperative than his first.

IT looks as if Rosalind Russell is most successfully reversing the course you might ordinarily expect a top actress to pursue as she gets along with her career. Where it would seem more than likely that one with her wide experience, which has pretty much ranged the acting spectrum, would be aiming toward more dramatic things as she reaches the higher age brackets, she's going the other way.

MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Dec. 6 -- A total of 279 patrons have lent their support to the annual benefit Holiday Ball of the Mount Kisco Junior League. Mrs. Werner Gubelin of Chap paqua is chairman of the fete, which will take place Dec. 20 at the Mount Kisco Country Club.

As a finale to its activities year in support of the Godmothers League Day Treatment Center and School for Emotionally Disturbed Children, the Essie H. Bierman Group is planning a New Year's Eve Ball. The dinner dance will take place at the Sherry-Hilton Hotel on Dec. 31.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Dec. 3 -- Czechoslovakia and the Soviet Union are the only two creditor and capital-exporting countries in the European Communist bloc.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- The Costa Brava Wine Company said here tonight it had received a message from Spain saying that two truckloads of Spanish champagne destined for the British market had been turned back by the French at the frontier.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 -- The University of Pennsylvania has passed another milestone in an expansion for which neither a time nor a total cost has been set.

CHARLESTON, S. C. -- About midway between New York and Miami lies the Carolina coastal country. It is a thawing-out place for tourists escaping from the Northern deep freeze to the subtropical playgrounds of Florida.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Dec. 6 -- The Army failure to curl a scientific missile to the vicinity of the moon followed a launching that inspired official confidence.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Dec. 1 -- A merchant at Sitka was complaining the other day because he had expected business to increase five or six times in volume this year as a result of Alaska's prospective statehood. Instead, it had merely doubled.

In the summer of 1956, Boris Leonidovich Pasternak, then known as a leading Russian poet and translator of Shakespeare, submitted to the Moscow literary monthly, Novy Mir, the manuscript of his just completed novel "Doctor Zhivago."
HONG KONG, Dec. 6 -- An intensified "hate America" campaign began in Peiping last week and is continuing in all Chinese Communist publications.

THIS life of Lucretia Mort, the liberal Quaker reform leader, is of special interest to us today because a hundred years after the struggle for abolition in which she was active we are confronted by a similar problem in the struggle to achieve integration.

THE historical novel for young people is a risky medium. The writer is too often tempted to rely on name dropping, local color and archaic dialogue; and since the reader, if he has been paying attention in class, knows how things are going to come out anyway, suspense is hard to generate.

MORE than 14,000 Americans will celebrate this Christmas at sea as passengers on cruise ships. Their plans have kept port stewards, commissary superintendents, booking clerks and cruise directors busy with preparations for what all agree should be the happiest Christmas at sea of the post-war travel season.
CLIFTON, N. J., Dec. 6 -- Some municipal appointments here will be distributed by formula in the future under a City Council plan.
TOKYO, Dec. 6 -- Seemingly annoyed by publicity of offenses by United States servicemen in Japan, the American commander here has presented the other side of the picture.

SYDNEY, Australia, Sunday, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Italy's Nicola Pietrangeli and Orlando Sirola were favored to win their doubles match against the Philippines today and gain a berth in the interzone Davis Cup tennis final against the United States.
ALBANY, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The death toll on highways patroled by the State Police dropped 13 per cent this year, Governor Harriman reported today.
WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., Dec. 6 (AP) -- At first glance, Camp Monterey, with its Khaki-clad youths, appears to be a small military base.
Miss Margaret Iliffe, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Geoffrey Iliffe of England, will be presented at the Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball on Dec. 22 at the Waldorf Astoria.

LEVITTOWN, L. I., Dec. 6 -- Voters here last night turned down three propositions calling for a total expenditure of $6,085,690 on schools in Union Free School District No. 5. Each of the propositions won majority approval, but all fell short of the two-thirds yes vote needed to carry.

NEWARK, Dec. 6 -- Vince Martinez, formerly of Paterson but now living in Miami, had to call on all his skill to beat Stefan Redl of Passaic in a ten-round welterweight fight in the Sussex Avenue Armory tonight.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Joe W. Brown's Tenacious regained championship form today with a strong stretch run to win the $10,000 Baton Rouge Handicap at the Fair Grounds.

I am sorry that Maria Callas will not be singing at the Met this season and perhaps not in the seasons to come. Whatever the reason for her dismissal, I think two facts are clear: first, this time Miss Callas hardly seems to be as much at fault as she seems to have been on certain past occasions (i.e., Rome); and second, she is one of the truly great artists of our time.
BOSTON, Dec. 6 -- Ambitious Democrats are watching both Massachusetts Senate seats for developments these days.
An Italian tailor arrived in New York yesterday bearing gifts for President Eisenhower -- a sports jacket and a vicuna overcoat.
The New York Chamber Soloists, Margaret Hillis, musical director, presented their second concert of the season at Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Kentucky, last season's national collegiate basketball champion, held off a determined Temple team tonight and pulled out a 76-71 victory in the second game of a double-header in the Palestra before 6,198 fans.
AT the old Capitani Studios in the heart of Rome -- where parts of "Open City" were filmed just after the war -- a group of exotically dressed men and women stand in front of a painted "flat."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Senator William F. Knowland left the Capital today saying he had no regrets over his only defeat at the polls in twenty-five years of politics.

Gov. G. Mennen Williams of Michigan, making his second visit to New York City since the election, outlined last night his views on the requirements for a Democratic victory in the 1960 Presidential race.

THE concerto the with organ as the stellar instrument is a musical form that Handel invented almost single-handed. And Handel himself wrote sixteen such concertos: six that were published in 1738 as Op. 4, six more that were published after his death as Op. 7, and four others that in a fine confusion are generally listed as Nos. 13, 14, 19 and 20.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- Although Queen Elizabeth has declined an invitation to visit Bermuda during its 350th Anniversary year which begins Jan. 1, Prince Philip will make a brief stop-over here in April, toward the end of his globe-girdling tour.

AMONG innovations this travel season is the family-plan cruise with father paying full price, mother and minors half price. Another first will be jet plane service to Miami next week and Los Angeles next month. For more leisurely vacationists there are still the fast "name" trains to the South, on which booking is proceeding briskly.
NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 6 -- Shipping volume for Hampton Roads is off almost 20 per cent from the high of 1957, according to a report issued this week by the Hampton Roads Maritime Association.

MADRID, Dec. 6 -- The recent wave of arrests of young, liberal Socialists in Spain highlights a factor of prime importance in this dictatorship -- the clash between the rising generation and the nation's aging rulers.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 6 -- Argentina's armed forces extended today their police powers to arrest profiteering merchants.

THE Stockholm Opera has commissioned an opera that is set in a space ship and that will contain a lot of electronic music. Karl Birger Blomdahl, who is, at 42 years old, one of Sweden's leading composers, is writing the music. The work will have its premiere during the Stockholm Festival next June and in August the company will present it at the Edinburgh Festival.

YONKERS, Dec. 6 -- Myles Scully, a retired police lieutenant here, died this morning in St. John's Riverside Hospital of injuries after having being hit by an automobile last night at Park Avenue and Shonnard Place.

HONOLULU, Dec. 6 (UPI) -- A third string quarterback, Ken Vierra, led the University of Utah to a 47-20 victory over the University of Hawaii before 18,000 at the twenty-eighth Shrine Aloha Bowl in Honolulu Stadium today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- In some respects the entrance into Washington this week-end of the Democrats of the National Committee and the Advisory Council was in the nature of a Roman triumph. The Republican President, in the role of Consul, was in a state of political siege in his palace on the Pennsylvania Avenue Palatine, and the legislative seats of his beleaguered fellow-partisans at the Capitol were reduced to a handful.
The rabbi with the longest tenure as spiritual leader of any New York congregation is observing his fortieth anniversary in the same pulpit this month.

FORCES are at work that may bring a termination of "Keep Talking" on Feb. 1 and a return of "Richard Diamond, Private Detective" the next week, "Keep Talking" is the comedy game show, televised on Sundays from 10 to 10:30 P. M., that replaced "The $64,000 Question" last month.

THE last national tournament of the year is winding up today in Detroit. The next public bridge event -- saving the Greater New York masters' individual contest at the McAlpin Hotel Dec. 12-14 -- will be the world-championship matches in New York early in February.

GERMAN literature these days is, if not great, big. The recently ended book fair at Frankfurt unfolded with all the landscaped splendor of a General Motors show. ATLANTA, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The case of George Bright, 31- year-old engineer charged with dynamiting the Jewish Temple here, went to a jury tonight. Shortly before midnight the jury retired to a hotel for the week-end.

MORRISTOWN, N. J. -- Snow or no snow, the season will soon be in full swing at the winter resorts that dot the hills and mountain slopes of northwestern New Jersey. Here the vacation or holiday-bound fugitive from the metropolitan area may enjoy skiing, ice skating, skeet shooting, horseback riding and hunting. Once the mercury has fallen to proper winter levels there will also be ice boating and ice fishing.

IT is not surprising that in these early days of stereo strange things occasionally happen to the "positions" taken up in your living room by the musical performers in the recordings. The technical ingredients of the stereo illusion must be rather precisely mixed.

EVERY naturalist has his own "wild paradise," and Guy Mountfort, British ornithologist, found his in the remote, almost inaccessible Coto Donana of southern Spain. Traveling over its marshes, deserts and dune-lands, he and his parties saw half the bird species of Europe, red and fallow deer, lynxes, snakes, lizards, wild boars, and scenes of "indescribable tranquillity."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UPI) -- The National Consumers League called today for a national health insurance plan that would make "the full services of doctors and hospitals financially available to everybody."

IT is curious to think that tea, a beverage so closely associated with the British, is a relative newcomer to the Western world. Although the drink has been known and enjoyed in China for more than 4,000 years, the first shipments to reach Europe and America did not arrive until the beginning of the seventeenth century. One of the first mentions of its existence in England is in Samuel Pepys' diary.

ONE day early in World War II, the American newspaper men in London who came to the noonday press conference at the Foreign Office were startled by an apparition. Later in the day, when they were able to exchange their impressions, they agreed with one of their number that what they had seen might best be described as "a mustache that walked like a man."

NAPLES, Fla. -- A large marina development, estimated to cost more than a million dollars, has been planned for this south-westernmost city in Florida. Although Naples fronts on the broad Gulf of Mexico, its phenomenal growth of residents and out-of-state visitors has seemingly pointed to the need for more sheltered mooring space for small boats that have been growing in numbers faster than facilities to take care of them.

DETROIT, Dec. 6 -- Jim Lee Howell was particularly pleased with the attitude of his Giants during today's brief final workout at Briggs Stadium, where tomorrow they meet with the ailing but anxious Detroit Lions.

KING SAUL and three of his sons had met their deaths in the Philistine victory at the Battle of Gilboa. Only Saul's pathetic son Ish-bosheth barred David, who had then been crowned King of Judah, from ruling over all Israel as well. At this tense moment in history, a murderous battle took place at the "pool of Gibeon" between Ish-bosheth's forces, under Abner, and David's army, commanded by Joab.

Governor - elect Nelson A. Rockefeller announced yesterday that he would retain Dr. Paul H. Hoch as Commissioner of Mental Hygiene. Dr. Hoch, 56 years old, has held the post since his appointment by Governor Harriman July 7, 1955.
LONDON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey said today that he was taking personal message from Nikita S. Khrushchev to President Eisenhower.

MARIE BYRD LAND, Antarctica, Nov. 27 -- Threatening weather kept the Byrd traverse party in camp today, but it was not a day of rest. Dr. Bentley and Mr. Leonard Leschack continued their seismic soundings, and two of the glaciologists, Mr. Darling and William E. Long, dug a pit in the ice 10 feet deep and 6 feet square for their glaciological studies.

FIRST prize in the national contest sponsored by The Intercollegian, magazine for college students published by the National Student Y. M. C. A. and Y. W. C. A., has been awarded to Richard Stallman, Drake University senior, for the picture "Students USA" reproduced here.

APPARENTLY and fortunately indefatigable in his translations from the Latin poets, Rolfe Humphries follows his recent Ovid with a complete rendering of the sixteen Satires of Decimus Junius Juvenalis, who wrote at Rome in the first century of our era.

Thirty leaders of business, labor and other organizations returned from a "people-to-people" mission to South America last night with a conviction that the majority of the South Americans are friendly to the United States.
MAKASSAR, Indonesia, Nov. 26 -- "Ski air," anyone?

Brutal men with muscles used to beat up skinny Bob Hoffman, kick him around and steal his girls. So Bob bought a set of barbells and soon his biceps were popping from his T-shirt. The bigger he got, the more barbells he bought, until finally he bought a whole barbell factory.
Twenty-five years may seem a long time for someone to be handling toys, but not to Robert B. M. Barton. Mr. Barton is president of Parker Brothers, Inc., Salem, Mass., producer of games.

A brilliant young Rumanian engineer decided about ten years ago that he didn't want to move to Brazil and follow his career in that fast-growing country. As a result, maybe this country's railroads will have an easier time retrieving some of the freight traffic they have lost to trucks.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Army's first lunar rocket soared tonight to about 65,000 miles in space, far short of the moon.

Berlin is a metropolis, of more than 3,300,000, almost equidistant from the Soviet frontier and the English Channel, its Western sectors an advance Western outpost behind the Iron Curtain. Germany is a land of 72,000,000 in the heart of the Continent, the pivotal area in the East-West struggle in Europe.

Lou Rossini returned to Columbia as a visiting coach last night. In his new role he directed New York University to a 93-70 basketball victory over the team he had coached for the last eight seasons. The game, the first between the schools since 1936, turned into a rout for the Violets, who had faded against the University of Cincinnati and the superb Oscar Robertson on Thursday.

Ever since the days of Kipling's "East is East" we have been thinking and talking increasingly about the relationship of apparently conflicting -- or at least different -- societies. Always we have sought some synthesis that would preserve the best in each.

HARTSDALE, N. Y., Dec. 6 -- Educational consultants want to merge two school districts in Westchester County to set up a high school program for gifted students. Meetings will be held next week to acquaint parents and taxpayers with the plan.

THE giant blooms of amaryllis will provide a spectacular winter-flowering display indoors. Bulbs can be potted now or, if held in a cool dry place, any tame up to early March. Plantings at weekly or bimonthly intervals during this period will give a cheerful succession of bloom.

A large number and wide variety of art attractions are to open in New York galleries this week in preparation for the holiday season. Quite a few of the group exhibitions have been designed to appeal to the Christmas shopper.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UPI) -- Messages from Santa Claus will soon begin pouring out to children across the nation from the town in Indiana that bears his name.
The volume of new equity offerings, which, until recently, has been running at a lower level than in any year since 1954, has begun to rise sharply.

INASMUCH as these reminiscences of Irene Foote Castle Treman McLaughlin Enzinger include life with four husbands, it is less confusing to refer to the author as Mrs. Castle, her best-known married name. She and Vernon Castle, her first husband, merit more than a footnote to the social history of this century's second decade.

The island's tourist season !got off to a good start this i month with last week's opening iof Laurence Eockefeller's DoI rado Beach Hotel. Situated about twenty miles west of San Juan, it contains 136 rooms, most of which are contained in ia semi-circular row of twoistory "beach houses." The hotel is part of what xqll eventually become a complete project comprising in itself a miniature resort.

IT was said of Henry Adams "that he was the only man in America who could sit on a fence and watch himself go by." Adams himself would have relished this homely metaphor because it contains an essential truth.

MIAMI BEACH -- In the publicity from Miami Beach at this time of year, the emphasis on luxury living tends to obscure an important fact: the Gold Coast still has accommodations during the high season for vacationists on limited budgets. This resort has more than 10,000 double rooms ranging from $6 to $12 daily per person without meals.
A fireman suffered two broken ankles yesterday while fighting a blaze in a Harlem tenement that had recently been condemned.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 6 -- The United Nations dispenses useful hints for fishermen once in a while. The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization is spreading the news of a technique in Ghana that involves listening to the voices of fish.

Carl M. Loeb Jr., president of the Community Council of Greater New York, said yesterday that critical shortages in manpower and facilities posed major problems for the future of welfare and health services in New York City.
NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 3 -- Rear Admiral Howard A. Yeager says the Navy's amphibious ships are wearing out and a modernization program is needed.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Dec. 6 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold tentatively proposed today an international scientific conference on the effects of atomic radiation.

IT was twenty-five years ago yesterday that Federal Judge John M. Woolsey handed down a decision in the case of James Joyce's "Ulysses." Often quoted, a landmark in the struggle against censorship, the decision was reported far back in the paper of Dec. 7, 1933.

There was no mention of interracial tensions in the manifesto issued by 250 members of the faculty of Emory University in Atlanta last week opposing the closing of schools anywhere in the United States. "We cannot afford a weakened educational system," the statement said. "To close the schools is to play directly into the hands of communism."
A "mutual cooperation" pact was signed last week by the International Typographical Union and the Amalgamated Lithographers of America.

LOS ANGELES -- Christmas will start a fortnight early this year for motorists in Southern California, with the opening on Saturday of one of the most notable freeway segments in the state's highway history.
Auction sales, which in the last week or two have been arranged for maximum impact on the Christmas shopper, continue to offer wares considered attractive as gifts.

WHEN David Dubinsky announced recently that his International Ladies Garment Workers Union would spend $1,000,000 in each of the next two years to promote the union label, he was emphasizing the contradictory nature of this tiny device: its potential power is as enormous as its present obscurity.

Your correspondent from Baltimore, George W. Williams, is properly horrified at the idea of mixing the races ("Letters," Nov. 23). The most casual observation of any representative group of American Negroes would reveal to him that three-fourths of our Negro population is already "mongrelized," to use his word.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 6 -- Three years ago yesterday Negroes deserted the city's segregated bus system in a mass protest demonstration.

The overwhelming majority of slum landlords are unwilling to take part in voluntary programs for the rehabilitation of deteriorating neighborhoods, a forum on the role of citizen organizations in neighborhood planning was told yesterday.

BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Louisiana State today rewarded Coach Paul Dietzel with a new five-year contract for winning the mythical national football title and a Sugar Bowl invitation. The pact calls for a salary of $16,500 a year.

American Banner Lines has opened branch offices in Toronto and Chicago as part of its program of expanded passenger activities, Roscoe H. Hillenkoeter, chief executive officer of the company, announced last week.
Hopes for an early settlement of the strike of 5,383 machinists against Eastern Air Lines continued dim yesterday as the union rejected a company offer of a wage increase.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Dec. 6 -- Life in Eastern Europe is shaking down into a recognizable pattern. The variations due to the differences in economic and cultural development may be noted but basically the forces at work are producing the same results.

ALTHOUGH he has occasionally turned his attention elsewhere -- as, for example in his excellent life of Charlemagne -- Harold Lamb has devoted the greater part of the last three decades to telling the story of the thrust and counterthrust between the people of our Mediterranean-European civilization and what we would no longer dare call, in Rudyard Kipling's phrase, "the lesser breeds without the law" that ringed them round about.
SOME cities invigorate the mind; some pamper the body. Some lift the spirit and a few warm the heart. Hong Kong captivates the eye.

Mrs. Garret A. Gifford of New Canaan, Conn., will give a tea in her home on Dec. 17 for the regional solicitors in Fairfield County for the Wheaton Fund. A campaign is in progress to raise $4,000,000 for an expansion program for Wheaton College in Norton, Mass.
BERLIN, Dec. 4 -- Two young men, strangers though they live only a few blocks apart, are in full agreement on their policy toward Berlin: they like the city and plan to stay here.
An old inland navigation safety practice appears to be making experimental headway on oceangoing American-flag ships. It involves combining whistle and light signals.

THIS is a prodigal season for cookbooks of a sort which should never be carried beyond the portals of the parlor into the kitchen. The magnificent illustrations, the choice of type, the handsome bindings are such that it would be profane to spatter them -- as some of the most cherished pantry volumes are -- with yolk of egg and the like.

WHEN I was 5, everything was certain and known, and I was positive that life was long and art short. I was already an actress in Washington, D. C., and even in 1905 Broadway was merely 230 miles away. Many birthdays passed before I perceived that increase of knowledge reduced certainty, and that there is more than one subway line to Times Square.
CLEAR varnish has been a popular finish for wooden furniture, paneling and trim for many years. To achieve a professional, smooth finish, extra care and the proper materials and methods must be used.

A NATIVITY scene in the Renaissance manner will be featured during the holiday season in the palm house of the New York Botanical Garden, Bronx Park. The display, which opens at 2 P. M. on Friday, may be seen daily from 10 A. M. to 4 P. M. through January 19.

Six sustaining members of the Junior League of Brooklyn will open their homes on Tuesday from 1:30 to 6 P. M. for a Holiday House tour sponsored by the league for the benefit of its Community Trust Fund. Tea will be served at league headquarters at 76 Montague Street in Brooklyn.
SARASOTA, Fla. -- Tourists who come to the Sarasota-Bradenton area this winter by automobile will get the benefit of some long-awaited highway improvements that have cost millions of dollars.

SEVERAL thousand scientists of many nations have recently been climbing mountains, digging tunnels in glaciers, journeying to the Antarctic, camping on floating Arctic ice. Their object has been to solve a fascinating riddle: what is happening to the world's ice?

ALGIERS, Dec. 6 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle came to Algiers tonight after a three-day survey of economic problems in eastern Algeria and the Sahara. He immediately found himself plunged into politics.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 6 -- Three candidates who had been opposed by Gov. Orval E. Faubus won election to the Little Rock school board today.

Speedier reporting and general improvement of world statistical information on raw materials was recommended last week in a resolution announced by the United States council of the International Chamber of Commerce.

OWNING a movie camera is a little like having a genie around the house. Its limitless possibilities await only the command of a master with enough imagination to call them forth. Of course, the new master of either a genie or a movie camera, is likely to quake at first encounter with the magic under his touch.

The possible "draft" of Civil Defense firemen into the Fire Department if they should be needed in an emergency is under consideration. Those drafted would be men who had applied for jobs in the Fire Department but had not yet been placed on a Civil Service list.

As was made eloquently clear by the letters written in response to Margaret Anderson's very thoughtful article on school integration in Clinton, the segregationists' basic fear is racial intermarriage.

JUST before the delegation from the Football Giants headed for the draft meeting in 1951, a curious reporter made an off-the-record inquiry of Jack Mara, the president of the club. Which player was sought above all others?
A campaign to revive industrial activity at Bethlehem Steel Company's Staten Island shipyard was announced by the company last week.

Dec. 7, 1941, was the day that President Roosevelt said "would live in infamy." Perhaps some of our present concern at Geneva with "surprise attacks" may be still linked to the memory. But the meaning of the phrase is changing, as it should. We can remember in a different mood and to a different end.

THE medley of objects shown here has been brought together to suggest gifts that will spread Christmas all through the house. While families may have longed for one or more of these furnishings, the practical economics of the budget may have deferred their purchase. Even penny-watchers, however, could consider many of the objects here.

A GREAT change comes in the life of 11-year-old Cristy and her Italian-American family when Poppa decides to move from a big city to the small town of Skippinghills, where he will operate his own shoe repair shop.
CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- An organization that seems to build humane animal quarters in medical schools was described here this week.

The Christmas selling season is off to a good start. Retailers in the New York area estimated that sales last week rose at least 10 per cent above those of the 1957 week. Sales during the week last year were depressed by bad weather.

The Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation announced last week that it had received $3,026,497 in contributions through its fifty-three chapters last year. It spent $446,458 of this on research projects seeking causes for the crippling diseases and cures for them.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- Resort operators in the Tampa Bay area are particularly optimistic about the coming winter season. What has raised their hopes is the promise of greatly increased air service to this section of the west coast -- if labor troubles do not interfere.

PARIS, Dec. 6 -- The new Gaullist regime in France, which emerged from Sunday's elections, left foreign policy in as much obscurity as domestic policy except so far as Gen. Charles de Gaulle has defined it. Foreign relations rarely play an important part in French elections.

TORONTO, Dec. 6 (UPI) -- George Armstrong scored two goals within a minute in the second period tonight to help the Toronto Maple Leafs down the Boston Bruins, 4 -- 1, in a National Hockey League game.

Mediation was pressed yesterday in an attempt to avert a strike of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union against nine city newspapers tonight.

A strike that would have involved 750 non-professional workers at Montefiore Hospital, the Bronx, was averted yesterday. The settlement followed a conference of hospital and union officials with Mayor Wagner.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. - Encouraged by the increased use of the Pennsylvania Turnpike Extension, which reaches into the northeast section of the Keystone State, resort owners in the Poconos are anticipating good business this year.
Two major food chain stores, Grand Union and A P yesterday announced reductions in the price of their private brands of ground coffee.

VERY shyly or very firmly -- or possibly at some delicate level of desire in between -- the children in this pre-Christmas season parade up to the Santa Clauses in the department stores. Their faith is in their faces as they address their earnest petitions to the genial, bewhiskered personage in the red suit.
SAN LUIS POTOSI, Mexico, Dec. 6 -- Additional troops worse moved into this capital city of the state of San Luis Potosi last night to prevent further disorder.
PEARL HARBOR, Hawaii, Dec, 6 (UPI) -- Seventeen years after Japanese bombs plunged America into World War II, the most highly defended weapon in military hands here may be a telephone.

PARIS, Dec. 6 -- For the third successive Sunday, Frenchmen will be voting tomorrow -- this time in limited numbers -- as part of the process of setting up the Fifth Republic.

High courage and a willingness to suffer are the virtues that a policy of disarmament will require of the American people, Clarence E. Pickett, executive secretary emeritus of the American Friends Service Committee, warned yesterday.

WOODS HOLE, Mass., Dec. 6 -- A new research vessel, the Chain, will leave here tomorrow on an eighteen-day cruise to help the United States make better use of the sea as an environment of national defense.

WARSAW, Dec. 6 -- Polish Communist leaders are complaining that the spirit of criticism in the country is being stifled. They have started a campaign to persuade Poles in the factory and the party that they can speak out without fear.

In December, 1954, when Republican Governor Thomas E. Dewey was preparing to hand over the New York State Administration to Democratic Governor-elect Averell Harriman, he announced that Mr. Harriman's budget director was "conducting all final budget-making conferences" and thus would have "responsibility for all decisions."

Honor classes can be just as frustrating for bright youngsters as regular classes, according to Dr. Milton M. Klein, who recently completed a Ford Foundation- sponsored survey of high school programs for gifted children. Writing in the current issue of the City College "Alumnus," Dr. Klein asserted that mere creation of special classes does not confer "any particular academic boon."

CHOPIN: Etudes (Op. 10 and Op. 25); Guiomar Novaes, pianist (Vox). Previously the two books of Etudes were available on two disks. Now Vox has brought them together on one disk. The performances are not among the great pianist's finest work on records, although naturally there are some beautiful details to the playing.
BRISBANE, Australia, Dec. 6 (Reuters) -- Crack bowling on an excellent pitch in sweltering heat put England back into the game today on the second day of the first cricket test against Australia.

SAN JUAN, P. R. -- The blue-gray bricks of a sloping, narrow street which is steeped in legend and indelibly marked by historical fact, are trod with increasing frequency these days by sandal-shod tourists seeking diversion and souvenirs. Calle del Cristo, known to continentals as Cristo Street, has emerged in the last few years as the focal point for visitors to the old section of this capital city.

DETROIT, Dec. 6 -- The final event of the nine-day Winter National Contract Bridge Championship started here this afternoon at the Sheraton-Cadillac Hotel with a big field entered in the Open Pairs Championship.

GENEVA, Dec. 3 -- European exporters of agricultural products face diminishing markets because of a general rise in farm productivity, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe reported today.
Three leaders of major communication mediums declared last night that a solution to the problems of civil rights and human relations was the most pressing issue of the day.

Measures now being taken to conserve underground water on eastern Long Island will probably prevent that area from becoming dependent upon New York City's upstate water sources as are Brooklyn and part of Queens, a geologist reported here yesterday.

A return to "old-fashioned" financial thinking in Government spending was asked yesterday by Maurice H. Stans, Director of the Bureau of the Budget.

NEW and better ornamentals for American gardens should result from a recent program of foreign plant exploration and introduction conducted by Longwood Gardens of Kennett Square, Pa., and the United States Department of Agriculture.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Washington Senators today traded Eddie Yost, Rocky Bridges and Neil Chrisley to the Detroit Tigers for Reno Bertoia, Ron Samford and Jim Delsing.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Dec. 6 -- Army's hockey team poured through the weak Massachusetts Institute of Technology defense for a 12-0 victory at Smith Rink today.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 6 -- A headlong clash between state and Federal authority developed here as the Civil Rights Commission prepared to open its first full-scale field hearing Monday.

THE names reverberate out of the New York Philharmonic's past. One carries a burden of grief. The other shines with quiet gratification. The one is Artur Rodzinski. The other is John -- now Sir John -- Barbirolli.
The post office is urging early mailing of holiday gifts and Christmas cards.
The Postmaster General warns us that as the deficit continues after the recent rise in rates he may have to raise them again. Isn't there a non sequitur concealed there ?

MEDFORD, N. J., Dec. 6 -- The first half of the national cocker spaniel field trial championship was concluded today. Seventeen of the twenty-two starters reached the second half despite gale winds that made rough going for the dogs and difficult shooting of the highflying pheasants.

HAMILTON, Ont., Dec. 6 (Canadian Press) -- The West rallied with a touchdown in the second quarter and three singles in the last half to defeat the East, 9 -- 3, in the fourth annual Shrine All-Star football game today.

The announcements last week by two railroads serving the New York area that they planned to cut back and abandon their passenger business were the latest steps toward disappearance of all passenger service on American railroads -- a prospect forecast by Howard Hosmer, an Interstate Commerce Commission examiner, in September.
TOKYO, The scene of international conferences in Asia shifted to Tokyo last week. The meeting was the International Conference of Social Work.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 -- The first commercial jet flight from Philadelphia International Airport is scheduled for Tuesday, nine days before the formal dedication of the l0,000-foot runway from which the huge Boeing 707 will take off.

Behrman's twenty- fourth play, written either alone or in collaboration, in thirty- five years, and, by his own pleasantly reluctant admission, the first he ever sidled up to with a sense of personal involvement so profound as to be now and then insupportable.

Displaying a predominantly uninspired defense, weak rebounding and a lot of sloppy ball-handling, the New York Knickerbockers provided a sad ending for local fans to a program that began on an amusing note at Madison Square Garden last night.

YOUR "Tshekid Khana, a South African chieftain," so identified in the caption to a picture accompanying John Bankham's review of "The Lost World of the Kalahari," by Laurens van der Post, is more likely to be Tshekedi Khama, ex-Paramount Chief of Bechuanaland, who was deposed and exiled during the Thirties for flogging two misbehaving white traders (who deserved it).

TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Dec. 6 -- Boston and Philadelphia will meet in the final tomorrow of the Payne Whitney memorial court tennis tournament. They eliminated teams from Long Island and New York today at the Tuxedo Racquets and Tennis Club.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 6 -- The democratic principles that were good enough for the Founding Fathers may be good enough for the modern generation too, but fifteen Princeton University students are not taking any chances.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 6 -- The Soviet proposal to transform West Berlin into a demilitarized free city may have a fine-sounding ring to it in Ghana or India or in any other far off place where communism has not yet become a menace.

IN your letters column, Mrs. Mallory Cross Johnson complained that the picture of Spanish censorship and restrictions drawn in the novel "Reap ers of the Storm," by Herbert Sturz and Elizabeth Lyttleton, was exaggerated.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Top-heavy majorities of Northern and Western Democrats overrode Southern protests today on a series of civil rights issues.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 6 -- Capt. Dick Johnson, a senior from Austin, Tex., scored 20 points to lead Navy to a 66-53 victory over Pennsylvania in the midshipmen's basketball opener today.

Dianne Gilmartin, 6, is crowned by her brother, Jimmy, 8 Dianne Gilmartin, 6 years old, was crowned queen of the twenty-fifth annual little sister beauty contest yesterday at the Tompkins Square Clubhouse of the Boys' Club of New York.

LOS ALAMITOS, Calif., Dec. 6 (UPI) -- Robert Strauss, a jockey and Ray Tremayne, a patrol judge, suffered painful injuries in a freak accident in today's fourth race at the Los Alamitos quarter-horse track.
WASHINGTON'S release this year, of fewer than twenty special stamps of low denominations, other than the stamps in regular use, contrasts sharply with the practice of some countries.

ONCE merely a photographic light measuring device and exposure calculator (which essentially it still is, of course), the photoelectric cell has assumed within the last year or two the status of symbol, the rallying point for a host of new devices designed to promote automation and simplification in amateur picture-taking.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- John Macy, a 28-year-old Polish refugee, today retained his title in the national Amateur Athletic Union senior 10,000-meter cross-country run. He had the remarkable time of 29:47.8.

IN a biographical note on the jacket of Vardis Fisher's "My Holy Satan -- a Novel of Christian Twilight," his publisher states that Mr. Fisher is a great scholar and that the only reviewer to challenge this, "did so unsuccessfully."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The Washington Star halted publication today, the second day of a strike by members of the American Newspaper Guild.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 6 -- For the first time in a decade and the second time in this century Venezuelans will enjoy tomorrow the privilege of choosing a President in a free direct election.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 6 -- The United Nations Administrative Tribunal, in a decision made known today, upheld the dismissal of Povl Bang-Jensen as a senior political officer of the world organization.

Hurrah for Mr. Adams for recognizing a very basic problem in education -- the "muttonhead" and his influence. May his article inspire "eggheads" to take the initiative to feel: "I'm proud of my role," rather than: "I'm ashamed that I'm different."

HERE is an engrossing book about the Emergency Service Division of the New York City Police Department, written by Norman Lobsenz. It is informative, interesting, grim, humorous and dramatic. When you have finished it, you will have shared the triumphs and the disappointments of these heroic policemen.
The Federal Maritime Board has been petitioned by the Prudential Steamship Corporation for subsidy assistance for its operations on Trade Route No. 10.

TELEVISION has a maddening habit of confounding those who wish to bury it. Just as criticism of the medium's ample allotment of pedestrian fare was rising in volume and vitriol, the networks offered last week-end a record number of special attractions that rose above the video norm.
Patrons have been announced for the performance on Jan. 9 of "Flower Drum Song" at the St. James Theatre.

EDWARD STEICHEN'S latest presentation at the Museum of Modern Art is a brilliant definition of photography as an art, seen in historical perspective, and the illuminating summation of a point of view.

DORADO BEACH, P. R., Dec. 6 (UPI) -- Wes Ellis, the 26- year-old Canadian open champion from Demarest, N. J., slogged over fairways through an intermittent shower today to shoot a one-under-par 71 for a two-stroke lead after three rounds of the Dorado Beach invitation golf tournament.
CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Seven candidates for the Sullivan Award were named today by a screening committee of the National Amateur Athletic Union at its annual convention here.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Dec. 6 -- Mrs. Philip Conway, chairman of the Bronxville Committee of the Adoption Service of Westchester, has named Mrs. William Leslie Jr. of 345 Pond-field Read chairman of the annual benefit Christmas tree sale.
MOSCOW, Dec. 6 -- Iran was accused today of violating a treaty with the Soviet Union by concluding a military pact with the United States.
BERLIN, Dec. 6 -- First Lieut. Richard Mackin, who parachuted from his United States Army aircraft into East Germany last Wednesday, was reported today to have been taken to East Berlin.

Americans smoke more cigarettes than Britons and they inhale to about the same extent. Yet lung cancer is twice as common in Britain as in the United States. To help clear up the mystery, scientists of the British Medical Research Council will collect thousands of cigarette butts off the streets, in restaurants and offices to find out the average length of the butt the British smoker throws away.

TOKYO, Dec. 6 -- Japanese Leftists are pulling their forces together for a nation-wide campaign against revision of the security treaty between Japan and the United States. They are receiving some not altogether welcome assistance from the Soviet Union and Communist China.
Stock market activity in recent weeks could well be described by the adjectives fascinating, tantalizing and bewildering.
SAN BRUNO, Calif., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Nice Guy took command at the head of the stretch and outlasted King's Canasta today and captured the $28,150 California Derby at Tanforan.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 6 -- Bruce Kessler of Beverly Hills, Calif., and Ricardo Rodriguez of Mexico City provided the thrills in today's international sports car races on the 4.5-mile Oakes course three miles from this capital city of the Bahamas.
MIAMI, Dec. 6 -- Fran Curci, the University of Miami's 148-pound quarterback, kicked a football today for the first time this season and set up a safety that upset the University of Oregon, 2 -- 0.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 -- The Redevelopment Authority's plan to clear an acre of ground on North Broad Street for the erection of a new $2,700,000 dormitory for men at Temple University was approved this week by the City Planning Commission.

ROME, Dec. 6 -- Old World aristocracy was very much by itself at a fete tonight for a select 1,200 persons that marked a climax of post-war high life. It brought back almost forgotten splendor to a nostalgic Rome and the rigors of the quadrille to a generation reared on rock 'n' roll.

MARIE BYRD LAND, Antarctica, Nov. 26 -- The American traverse party here in Marie Byrd Land is one of three at work trying to fathom the secrets of a continent shielded by an armor of ice up to 14,000 feet thick.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Drought-stricken northern Brazil seethed today, with mobs demonstrating against hunger, inflation and charges of Government corruption.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 6 -- Yugoslavia's pragmatic Communists are planning to try the production bonus as a means of increasing the productivity of the nation's workers.

The Deering Milliken Research Corporation will dedicate a new research center in Spartanburg, S. C., on Thursday. The corporation will move its facilities from Pendleton, S. C., where they have been since 1950.
THE ABBEY THEATRE. By Gerard Fay. 186 pages. Illustrated. New York, 11: Macmillan. $4.50.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Modern historical research has brought no solution to an old frontier mystery, the Department of the Interior announced today.
ALBUQUERQUE, N. M. -- Indian, Spanish, and "Anglo" traditions blend in the sunny Southwest to give Christmas and New Year's celebrations a flavor unique in the Americas.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 5 -- A Canadian trade delegation will arrive in Canberra in February to negotiate a trade treaty with Australia. Prime Minister John Diefenbaker of Canada announced here today.

BOSTON, Dec. 6 -- A resolve asking posthumous pardons for Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti, executed for murder in Massachusetts State Prison more than thirty years ago, was among legislative petitions filed this week in the Massachusetts State House.

PERIODICALLY, the Bronx Zoo receives for its reptile collection a batch of snakes from a gentle clergyman in South America. The clergyman seeks neither money nor honor. All he wants -- and gets -- in return is textbooks and chemistry equipment for the school of the mission to which he is attached.

ROME, Dec. 6 -- Premier Amintore Fanfani and his Government won a vote of confidence by a narrow margin in the Chamber of Deputies late tonight.

MANCHESTER, Vt. -- Judging from some of the developments that have been taking place in Vermont, in preparation for the winter's crop of skiers, this state seems to be well in the running for attracting more visitors than ever before in its history.

A LITTLE publicized but most welcome addition to the already vast resources of the LP repertory is the projected ten-album series, The History of Music in Sound, seven albums of which have already been issued in this country by RCA-Victor in conjunction with the Oxford University Press.

A 14-year-old boy was fatally crushed yesterday in an elevator at 380 Riverside Drive -- one of the buildings singled out early last week in the Mayor's new drive against slums. The boy was killed trying to do a good deed.

MIAMI BEACH -- The mild sunny climate that Miami Beach wraps up and sells to its winter tourists, a commodity which was missing last year at this time, seems to have returned to south Florida. LONDON, Dec. 6 -- The first tentative movements in Washington, London and Paris toward discussion of and perhaps even negotiation of Germany's future with the Soviet Union have raised the question of the survival of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in its present form.

CONCORD, N. H. -- Ski operators, hotel owners, innkeepers and tourist house proprietors in New Hampshire are preparing for what they believe will be a record influx of winter sports enthusiasts in the Granite State since winter visitors began trading in sleighs and ice skates for hickory runner, poles and boots, a little over a quarter of a century ago.
Carlos Henriquez pinned Paul Bohland of New York University in the last of eight bouts to lift Columbia's wrestling team into a 14-14 tie at University Hall yesterday.

When Boris Pasternak got the manuscript of Doctor Zhivago back from the Moscow Literary Monthly, Novy Mir, he did not receive a mere rejection slip. What he got was a letter about 10,000 words long, portions of which appear in our Book Review today, from three of the editors of Novy Mir.

THREE years ago, the London Economist published an anonymous article announcing "the discovery of a new scientific law -- herewith presented to the public for the first time -- and to be called Parkinson's Law." The footnote read "Why? Why not? -- Editor."

BONN, Germany, Dec. 4 -- A tall pine tree, the German Tannenbaum, has been festooned with lights and set upon a hill above Bonn. It can be seen from anywhere in the city and its dominating position reflects the thoughts of the West German capital's residents -- that Christmas is coming and there is much to do in preparation for the holidays.
The 1959 capital budget of $603,065,395 adopted by the Board of Estimate on Thursday was commended yesterday as "one bright spot in the city's sloppy fiscal picture."

The names of the 111 young women who will be presented at the twenty-third annual Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball have been announced by Mrs. Eugene W. Ong and Mrs. Colby M. Chester 3d, co-chairmen of the ball committee.
CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- The newly elected Legislature of Alaska will be called upon by the Western Tax Council, Inc., to ask Congress to put a ceiling on its authority to impose income taxes.

LAST week, Bosley Crowther referred to the long-range innovations found in some recent American films. The word "hell" is on its way to being accepted by American producers. However, what was brought to my mind by Mr. Crowther's observations was the snail's pace of progress in our films.
Factory sales of all kinds of electronic products will reach a record of $7,700,000,000 this year, a high industry official predicted last week.

THE poetry of Ovid (43 B.C.-18 A.D.), and in particular the "Metamorphoses," produces a series of paradoxical reactions, ranging from fascination, admiration, boredom to irritation, even exasperation. No Latin poet is his rival in the ability to produce an endless flow of flawlessly constructed elegiac couplets or hexameters, and nowhere is this facility more evident than in the hexameters of the "Metamorphoses."

The Rev. Dr. Henry Enoch Kagan of Sinai Temple in Mount Vernon is considered to be the first full-time "preaching rabbi" to be certified as a consulting psychologist who is licensed to practice psychotherapy. Just a few weeks ago Rabbi Kagan received his license from the State Board of Examiners for Psychologists.

GENEVA -- All is well in the mountains. Snow is falling and workmen are putting the finishing touches on ski trails for the new season. Now it is time to recall, and explain, the day last summer when Mont Blanc turned into a monster.

The National Sports Council, a one-man crusade to help the physical development of boys throughout the country, has added mental and spiritual guidance to its home training courses.
HARTFORD, Dec. 6 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon will have good friends in top leadership posts in Connecticut if a fight should develop in 1960 for the Republican nomination for President.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 6 -- The Los Angeles Rams utilized their favorite play -- the Bill Wade-to-Del Shofner pass -- in defeating the Baltimore Colts, 30 -- 28, today in a National Football League game before the third largest crowd in pro football history.

A SIDE from shrimp there is no shellfish more popular on American tables than crab. Whether the delectable crustacean comes from the East or West, its flesh is enjoyed chilled as an appetizer or hot as a cocktail accompaniment, in luncheon entrees and main dinner courses.
