Unemployment compensation rolls in Illinois totaled 136,051 for the week ended Nov. 22, an increase of 3,544, or 2.7 per cent above the previous week, when 132,507 were listed, Illinois unemployment offices reported. A year ago the total was 93,501. The primary cause of the increase was a seasonal lay-off of workers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The collecting of old navigation charts as a hobby came in for a few words of both praise and caution this week from Rear Admiral H. Arnold Karo, Director of the Coast and Geodetic Survey.

Entering the homestretch for 1958, the stock market settled down somewhat last week. December, normally a month of rising prices, was ushered in on a firm note in quieter trading. But stocks moved in a narrow range, ending the week mixed to slightly lower. There were wide moves, however, in both directions, in individual issues.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6 -- The cornerstone of Beth Sholom Synagogue, a six-sided aluminum and glass edifice in suburban Elkins Park, will be put in place at ceremonies tomorrow afternoon. Frank Lloyd Wright is the architect.

FLAMINGO, Fla. -- Mission 66, as the Government calls it, has opened a new experience for the yachting enthusiast. Designed to develop our National parks, the ten-year program has done an impressive job in one of the most desolate areas in the United States -- Florida's Cape Sable.

ATLANTIC CITY -- By car it is a comfortable 2 1/2 hour drive from Times Square to the Boardwalk here with its restful view of the Atlantic Ocean. Colder weather last week brought special reorders in high-priced coat and suit lines. In the moderate - priced lines buyers were caught short and there were few items available to fill their requests.

FORT KNOX, Ky., (AP) -- The Army is trying to develop a formula for a more weather-proof soldier.

C. B. S. Television presented last night a filmed discussion between Artur Rubinstein, Archibald MacLeish and Antoni Slonimski, Poland's leading poet, that delved into the question of Boris Pasternak and censorship.

The faculty of the Third Street Music School Settlement Saturday evening presented a concert of chamber works by six contemporary Americans. As a group, the compositions reflected no very strong stylistic pattern, although most showed a chromatic preference in varying degrees.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UPI) -- Striking editorial and business employees of The Washington Evening Star voted overwhelmingly today to end the three-day walk-out that had forced the paper to suspend publication.
CHICAGO, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The Chicago Beat's exploited Chicago Cardinals' miscues and George Blanda's accurate toe for a 30-to-14 victory before 41,617 in frigid, snow-powdered Wrigley Field today.

The United States now has weapons in operation that are capable of effectively meeting any nuclear attack the Soviet Union can launch, the commanding general of this region's Air Defense Command said yesterday.
ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 7 -- Curbs on overtime in the busy spring hat season were agreed upon here today by representatives of the country's millinery manufacturers and their 22,000 unionized employes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UPI) -- Cardinal Spellman announced today that a $250,000 pipe organ would be installed at the National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception as a memorial to Roman Catholic chaplains and service men who lost their lives in the two World Wars and in Korea.

Joseph De Nave, 21 years old, of 87 Seventy-third Street, Brooklyn, and Miss Kirsten Schmidt, 17, of 310 West Seventy-third Street, Manhattan, were killed yesterday at 2:20 A. M. when the Jaguar convertible in which they were riding overturned on Shore Road near Eighty-sixth Street, Brooklyn.

N. A. M. MacKenzie, president of the University of British Columbia, has been elected chairman of the board of trustees of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching. The announcement was made yesterday by John W. Gardner, president of the foundation.
Mayor Wagner's administration is definitely "on the hot seat" in the matter of slum housing conditions, Deputy Buildings Commissioner Bernice P. Rogers declared yesterday.

Business recovery continued in November but employment still lagged, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said in its Monthly Review, published today. It may be some time, the bank indicated, before unemployment is reduced to the levels of past periods of prosperity.
I should like to reply briefly to the letter in The Times of Dec. 3 of W. Stanley Rycroft, criticizing a sermon of mine as it was reported in your issue of Nov. 17.
Miss Estelle Lee has been appointed advertising manager of the Hat Corporation of America. She is thought to be one of the few women to hold a top advertising post in the men's wear field.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 7 -- All of the sick machinery that had gone back to the repair shops after the first two days of sports car racing here last week was on the track again today for the international Nassau Trophy race.

In Washington a bill authorizing a National Cultural Center has been approved by Congress and signed by the President. The 9.4-acre site is there and some day -- if about $25,000,000 in private funds can be raised within five years -- the building may be.

THE French excel at the art of cooking meats and making sauces, the Chinese are past masters in the preparation of vegetables and Americans have the greatest flair for making salads. This is the opinion of Robert Kreis, a European chef who began his career with a block of ice and made his fortune via the salad bowl.
"A Death in the Family," this year's Pulitzer Prize novel, will be done on Broadway next season.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Dec. 7 -- Arab reports of Israeli troop concentrations along the Syrian border of the United Arab Republic were vigorously denied today by the Israeli Army's official spokesman.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 7 -- The Protestant Foreign Mission enterprise has undergone a major revolution in the last quarter century, it was brought out here today as some 350 church officials began a four-day review of their overseas work.

The Very Rev. Orin A. Griesmyer was instituted as rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration in a solemn service there yesterday. The building, on Twenty-ninth Street just east of Fifth Avenue, is popularly known as the Little Church Around the Corner.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Dec. 6 -- An early solution to Iceland's Government crisis appeared today to be unlikely.

Football returned to Downing Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday as four Pop Warner Midget League elevens met in a double-header to determine the champions of the league's annual Broadway Bowl competition. The players ranged in age from 9 to 13.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The proposed International Development Association, considered a few months ago to have dim prospects, is very much alive.
ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 6 -- Forces pushing construction of the big, expensive Middle East Technical University on the outskirts of Ankara won a recruit this week in Harold E. Stassen.
AMSTERDAM, Dec. 7 -- Interim industrial reports show that most Netherlands enterprises have had an increase in orders. However, these have not yet affected employment.

The decision of the Montefiore Hospital directors to recognize and deal with Local 1199 of the Retail Drug Employes Union has both short-run and long-run public importance far beyond the event itself. In the first place, it has avoided a hospital strike -- an outcome that would have set a dismal precedent.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Counterfeiters are doing their Christmas shopping early this year.
Governor-elect Nelson A. Rockefeller received a promise of labor support yesterday in carrying out his campaign pledges for community betterment.
The six-day bicycle race, once the rollicking rage of Madison Square Garden, apparently is headed for a New York comeback.
SAN LUIS POTOSI, Mexico, Dec. 7 -- The citizens of this city turned out en masse today for what almost certainly will be the heaviest election vote in its 400-year history.
HARTFORD (UPI) -- Connecticut automobile dealers were told at their annual meeting that prospective customers have a selling technique of their own.
Grass-roots democracy still has a hard time flourishing in South America, but the outlook is hopeful, a group of United States business, labor and civic leaders reported yesterday.
ALBANY, Dec. 7 -- The Rockefeller Administration has taken control of the state budget that the Governor-elect must submit to the Legislature next Feb. 1.

DORADO BEACH, P. R., Dec. 17 (AP) -- Paul Harney, son of a Worcester, Mass., police sergeant, got his putter under control today and won the $30,000 Dorado Beach invitation golf tournament with a 72-hole score of 284. His final round was a 68.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 7 -- Iceland, at odds. with Britain in this General Assembly session over the limits of her

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Bobby Layne hurled the Pittsburgh Steelers to a 14-14 tie with the Washington Redskins today on sharpshooting last-half touchdown passes to Jim Orr, a rookie, and Jack McClairen.

Recent criticism by a Kings County grand jury of Mayor Wagner's practice of appointing committees when city crises develop has stirred interest in just how many committees there are and what they have accomplished.
The mother of a 14-year-old boy who died in the plunge of an elevator Saturday at 380 Riverside Drive charged yesterday that the elevator frequently had been overloaded, overused and in disrepair.

The New York Chapter of Americans for Democratic Action charged yesterday that City Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa had raised the issue of waste in school construction to discredit the proposed issuing of $500,000,000 in school bonds.
A sixty-foot-wide bas relief depicting the Triumph of Christ was dedicated yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle.
CHICAGO, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The gloom that settled over the restricted grain futures market last week was so thick it caused some traders to' cry out in despair for the future of the business.

Recently I watched the firemen from Engine 18 enter a building in which a fire raged completely out of control. With what seemed considerable danger to themselves these firemen fought, controlled and extinguished an extremely fast-moving fire. There was no confusion.
The leading Japanese shipping line, Nippon Yusen Kaisha, known as N. Y. K. Line, has announced final plans for the construction of two 22,800-ton liners for the Pacific trade.

MEDFORD, N. J., Dec. 7 -- Camino's Red Rocket, a 7-year-old red cocker spaniel, today won the national cocker field trial championship. Camino's Red Rocket, owned by Clark Gable, the movie actor, scored over twenty-two rivals. There were nine finalists.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif. Dec. 7 -- Ten Hollywood screen writers have volunteered to assist Mount Sinai Hospital in Beverly Hills in determining how certain motion pictures might be useful in the treatment of some forms of psychosomatic illness.

WASHINGTON (UPI) -Suppose every wheat field in the country were to be withered by drought or flattened by hail next year. Or suppose every wheat grower decided to go hunting instead of harvesting in 1959 and not a single bushel of wheat was gathered.
VATICAN CITY, Dec. 7 (UPI) -- Pope John XXIII lighted a statue of the Virgin Mary in an Italian town by radio signals tonight on the eve of the Roman Catholic feast day of the Immaculate Conception.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said yesterday that Sen. Hubert M. Humphrey of Minnesota, of all the potential Democratic candidates for President in 1960, comes closest to having the "spark of greatness" the next President will need.

The head of the Zionist Organization of America called on the Zionist movement in this country yesterday to "wrest the leadership" from those Jewish communal leaders who act "negatively" on issues affecting the welfare of Jewish communities.

An excursion into Americana was made Saturday evening by the Columbia University Orchestra conducted by Howard Shanet. The program, given at the McMillin Theatre, contained music that had been exhumed from the Edwin A. Fleisher Music Collection in Philadelphia.

What may in the long run prove to be one of the most important actions of the present session of the General Assembly was taken last Friday. By a unanimous vote the Assembly invited the World Health Organization to carry out plans for the observation of an International Health and Medical Research Year, preferably in 1961.

HOMER'S "Odyssey" is a case in point for those who argue that the best stories, like life itself, have no absolute ending. A superb adventure, it is based on the noblest of all themes -- the destiny of man. The long wanderings of Odysseus are both a moral testing and a triumph over menaces not even a de Mille could dream of.
BLAIRSTOWN, N. J., Dec. 6 -- Nine years ago, a skinny, bespectacled 9-year-old boy watched a Blair Academy soccer team suffer its only defeat of the season as it lost to unbeaten Lawrenceville.

MOSCOW, Dec. 7 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev and most of the members of the Communist party's Presidium went to a writers meeting today celebrating the "enormous" increase in party control over Soviet literature.

Jack Brause, realty investor, has added to his holdings in Union Square by purchasing the nine-story office building at 1 to 3 Union Square West, northwest corner of Fourteenth Street. The building, 50 by 100 feet, contains 50,000 square feet of office space and will be modernized by the purchaser.
Grace Protestant Episcopal Church at Broadway and Tenth Street began yesterday a month-long celebration of its 150th anniversary.

Postponement of the plan of buildings along the ocean front at Far Rockaway, Queens, scheduled for Dec. 19, was asked Saturday by Municipal Court Justice Abraham R. l_argulies, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the Rockaways.
Jewish children in the suburbs greeted Hanukkah Saturday night in much the same way that their Christian playmates will welcome Christmas.
JABALPUR, India, Dec. 7 (Reuters) -- Vinoo Mankad of India took four wickets and scored eighty-five not out for Central Zone against the touring West Indies cricket team today.

Time was, a business man who brought work home from the office would spread out his papers on the dining-room table after the dinner dishes were cleared away, or would move the unanswered mail, hunting equipment catalogues, bank statements, pipe cleaners and other oddments from his pigeonhole desk and do his work there.

THE Space Age seems further advanced in the city s department stores, on the toy floors, than it is at adults' proving grounds. On the sixth floor at Stern's a child is confronted by three Ages of Transportation.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 7 -- Venezuelans voted today for a President, Congress and state and municipal assemblies.
Trans World Airlines was set to return to the air last night after its planes had been grounded for sixteen days by a mechanics' strike.

GENOA, Italy, Dec. 7 -- The Leonardo da Vinci, new 32,000-ton flagship of the Italian Line, slipped down the ways of the Ansaldo Shipyards in Sestri Ponente this morning amid a deafening tooting of horns from every ship in the port of Genoa.
The chairman of British European Airways has expressed the hope that B. E. A. can install automatic landing equipment in "its next generation of airplanes."
William Wildermann is the only Metropolitan Opera singer who will undertake a new role during the company's eighth week. It will be that of Sparafucile in "Rigoletto."

LONDON, Dec. 7 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Union published today the details of its proposed measures for preventing surprise attack. These were put before an East-West conference of experts in Geneva Nov. 28.
Five new films will arrive in local theatres this week. The programs follow:

SWAFFHAM, England, Dec. 7 (AP) -- A score of pacifist demonstrators invaded a top secret missile base again today but the police again beat off their attempt to stop construction work on launching pads.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Italy went into the Davis Cup inter-zone final against the United States today when the doubles team of Orlando Sirola and Nicola Pietrangeli turned back the Philippines, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 3, 7 -- 5, in a rain-interrupted match.
One Portfolio in Contest Up 92% as Stocks Generally Show a Gain of 26% A group of security analysts have proved that they can pick winners.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 7 -- The election of three moderates and three segregationists to the Little Rock school board has created a potential deadlock that promises little hope for an early solution to the city's education problems.
The forty-seventh annual appeal for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund opened officially yesterday with gifts and messages of encouragement from many of the fund's old friends.
Liabilities in failures of retailers of apparel and accessories, dry goods and general merchandise climbed 87 per cent in November above the figure for the 1957 month.

ZURICH, Dec. 7 -- A 50,000,000-franc loan put on the market last Wednesday on behalf of the French company Saint-Gobain S. A., manufacturers of glass and chemical products, has been oversubscribed already.

In pre-season prognostications, West Virginia, North Carolina State, Kentucky and Kansas State were rated among the top collegiate basketball teams in the nation. After the first full week of action, it appears that the "experts" used cloudless crystal balls.

CAMDEN, N. J., Dec. 7 -- If you want a successful show dog, raise him in the city. That is what Pat and Anne Johnson of 2 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn, think and say. They said it today after their 17-month-old Dandie Dinmont terrier had won best of breed in the Camden County Kennel Club show.
MINNEAPOLIS (Science Service) -- Physicians here were urged to treat infections with more common sense and fewer antibiotics.
Volkswagen of America, Inc., which had operated here successfully without an advertising agency until last March, is again without an agency.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 7 (UPI) -- California produces 80 to 90 per cent of the earthquakes in the United States but has no corner on "high-risk areas" in the nation, Dr. Charles F. Richter said today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- This may be the week of reckoning for Bernard Goldfine in his tussle with the House Subcommittee on Legislative Oversight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The sudden spread of military regimes in the free world worries the Eisenhower Administration.

FIFTY years have passed since 17-year-old Mischa Elman first appeared on the stage of Carnegie Hall, and the Elman legend has been growing ever since. There are probably more anecdotes in circulation about Mischa Elman than about any violinist since Paganini.
The rugged play of the New York Rangers this season in their bid for a National Hockey League Stanley Cup play-off berth is beginning to take its toll.

ACCRA, Ghana, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The Government has proposed a new law banning strikes by civil servants and other government employes. Unions controlling non-government employes would have to give four weeks notice of a strike.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 7 -- Fresh steel order volume improved again last week. Prospects are good for a further increase this week. Sources of the new business, slated for delivery in January and February, were more varied than they were a month ago.

The Air Force through Maj. Gen. Walter C. Sweeney, Eighth Air Force Commander, paid tribute yesterday to the Army and Navy forces that conducted last summer's cargo sealift to the Air Force's big base at Thule, Greenland, and other northern ports.

A special benefit preview of the fifth nnual Winter Antiques Show, complete with cocktails and a buffet, will be held on Jan. 21 at the 107th Infantry (old Seventh Regiment) Armory, Park Avenue at Sixty-seventh Street.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 7 -- Obviously Khrushchev was aware that he played with fire when he chose to revive the Berlin question. Perhaps because of this he sought to limit immediate tension by presenting the West with a deliberately delayed threat to take effect only after six months.
Small-car manufacturers predicted yesterday that the trend of the future was in their favor. The big-car makers were not so sure.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- General dullness prevailed in the stock markets last week, without any clear or consistent trend. Government securities and industrial and commodity shares drifted gently lower during the first half of the week and became somewhat firmer toward the end of it.

CHRISTMAS shoppers who want to save time and stamina, as well as those who need fresh ideas, might visit the special Yule boutiques in many of the stores here. Some of these boutiques incorporate all types of gifts; others are strictly specialized.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., Dec. 7 A merger of the Morristown Chart Company and the First Bank and Trust Company of Madison has been approved by stockholders of each institution, creating the largest commercial bank in the county. It will be known as the Trust Company of Morris County and will have assets of more than $64,000,000 with capital funds in excess of $4,200,000, not including reserves.
Barnard College announced the election of two trustees and officers of the Board of Trustees over the week-end.
Governor-elect Nelson A. Rockefeller of New York and Governor Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey reached a working understanding over the weekend on a broad area of interstate cooperation.

Tito Gobbi, who returned to the cast of "Tosca" at the Metropolitan Opera Saturday evening after a season's absence, is a Scarpia so fascinating as to send old-timers back to memories of Scotti for an adequate comparison.

An International Longshoremen's Association official has proposed that a fact-finding board be appointed by Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey and Governor-elect Nelson A. Rockefeller of New York to investigate the cargo container dispute on the port's waterfront.

Once again one of the nation's basic industries, with the country engaged in a war on inflation and an all-out international economic war, has entered into a friendly agreement with labor to give the inflationary wage-price push another shot in the arm.

The decision of one of the nation's principal corporations to locate a large plant in southmost Texas marks a break-through toward industrial development of this border region. When completed, this multimillion-dollar installation near Brownsville will be a demonstration of American enterprise at the doorstep of Latin America as well as a means for marked economic advancement on both sides of the Rio Grande.

From Maine to Florida, gifts arrived yesterday in the forty-seventh annual appeal for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

Army's basketball squad is "taller than ever," according to George Hunter, the coach. It has two starters who are 6 feet 5 and a reserve who is 6 feet 6. This would have been impossible -- or at least illegal -- two years ago.

" The Empty Chair," Peter Ustinov's drama on the French Revolution, enjoyed the meticulous preparation and mounting common to attractions seen on "Omnibus." But the play, which was seen on Sunday afternoon over Channel 4, tended to waver between drama of persuasive power and a rather staid political minuet.
DETROIT, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The auto industry has scheduled production of approximately 600,000 cars for December, the highest single month's output since January, 1957, when 628,000 cars were made.

The Atomic Age is the subject of a book by William L. Laurence, science editor of this newspaper. It is scheduled for spring publication by Simon Schuster. Mr. Laurence, whose work has won him many journalistic awards, including two Pulitzer Prizes, was an eyewitness at the first testing of the atomic bomb.

Billy Flamio outpointed Jimmy Archer in a ten-round battle between Bronx welterweights at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. At the finish each man's left eye was closed. Blood from various cuts covered both fighters.

The commissioner of the National Football League saw "nothing wrong, in any way, shape or form with Sunday's game at Detroit." The man in the street, especially on the sidewalks of New York, apparently disagreed with Commissioner Bert Bell.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Dec. 8 (AP) -- A manslaughter charge against Charles Horace Stoneham, 30 years old, was dismissed today on the ground that the "grieved party" had been satisfied out of court.

The New York Rangers, who have been Sorely in need of added defensive strength, took steps yesterday to relieve that situation. The New Yorkers called up Jack (Red) Bownass, a 28-year-old defenseman, from the Buffalo Bisons of the American Hockey League.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Homer S. Saint-Gaudens, noted art authority, died today, apparently of a heart attack. His age was 79.

LISBON, Portugal, Dec, 7 (AP) -- Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar has ruled as dictator of Portugal for twenty-five years with the support of the Roman Catholic Church. Today there are indications that the relationship is cooling, aggravated by poverty in the nation.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 8 (UPI) -- Whittledy Cut, a 5-year-old mare with a spotty record, broke the Tropical Park record for six furlongs today while scoring a four and one-half-length victory in the feature.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Dec. 8 -- Glen Foster, at the helm of Ordeal, scored 225 of a possible total of 240 points to lead the Larchmont Yacht Club frostbite fleet yesterday. Foster took the first and last races of the six-race program to win for the third time in the last four winter dinghy regattas.

In a recent issue you recommended the expenditure of over $1,000,000 for the repair of the Soldiers and Sailors Monument. I understand that about $90,000 has already been spent to determine the extent of damage and work necessary for rehabilitation.
LITTLE ROCK, Dec. 8 -- Federal District Judge John E. Miller today set Jan. 6 as the date for a hearing on the Little Rock school integration case.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Cardinal-designate Amleto G. Cicognani, paid a farewell call on President Eisenhower today.

Jack Stroud, the offensive tackle, and Pat Summerall, the place-kicking specialist, of the Giants were not altogether fit yesterday for Sunday's finale against the Cleveland Browns. However, the New Yorker who is least likely to play is Ed Hughes, the defensive back.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI) -- The Air Force lowered today its rigid physical standards for admission to the Air Force Academy at Colorado Springs, Col., to permit the selection of candidates from a larger group of nominees.

ON, Dec. 10, 1908, a short, round-faced, curly-haired Russian violinist named Mischa Elman, aged 17, made his first appearance in America at Carnegie Hall. Last night Mr. Elman, now an American citizen and somewhat older, rounder and quite bald, appeared in the same hall to play a recital marking his golden jubilee.

The American Women's Voluntary Services, Inc., will give a theatre party at tomorrow evening's performance of "Cue for Passion" starring Diana Wynyard and John Kerr at the Henry Miller Theatre. Tickets may be obtained from Miss Fanshawe at 136 East Sixty-fourth Street.

A special performance of Verdi's "Otello" at the Metropolitan Opera House this evening will benefit the Metropolitan Opera Employes' Welfare Fund and the Casa di Riposa in Milan, which Giuseppe Verdi endowed for aged musicians.
Trans World Airlines resumed domestic and overseas operations yesterday after a seventeen-day shutdown caused by a mechanics' strike.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Supreme Court granted reviews today in five cases raising questions about the scope of its controversial 1957 decision in the case of Clinton E. Jencks.
BRISBANE, Australia, Dec. 8 (Reuters) -- England batted its way into a forty-run lead over Australia at the end of the third day of play today in their five-day test cricket match.

Negotiations are near completion for a televised series of high school basketball games, it was learned yesterday.

Twenty-three years of separation ended yesterday for this state's two central labor bodies.
A strike by delivery workers against nine New York newspapers was settled yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI) -- A squabble broke out today in an economic committee of the twenty-one American republics over whether the United States was living up to its promise to take new measures to help its southern neighbors.
Mayor Wagner praised neighborhood educational television systems yesterday as a useful tool in breaking through language barriers and solving other problems in the city's changing neighborhoods.

Johnny Bucek, 6-foot backcourt star who led the team in scoring last season, was dropped from the New York University basketball squad yesterday for "violation of rules laid down for the basketball squad."

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Lance Reventlow and Chuck Daigh, sharing the driving chore, whipped Reventlow's powerful Corvette-powered Scarab around the 4.5-mile Oakes Field course at an average speed of 87.549 miles per hour for 252 miles yesterday and won the Nassau Trophy race for sports Cars.
BOSTON, Dec. 8 -- President Eisenhower will send a special message to Congress in January urging further major revisions in farm programs.

The American Association of Theological Schools demanded yesterday that Dr. Duke K. McCall, president of Southern Baptist Seminary, resign as vice president of the association and as a member of its commission on accrediting.
New York was caught last night in a snowstorm that stretched across a wide belt of northern states.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Marie Torre, television columnist for The New York Herald Tribune, lost her legal fight today against a contempt conviction for refusing to identify a news source.

The Symphony No. 1 of Klaus Egge, Norwegian composer, was the major work on the Brooklyn Philharmonia's program Saturday night under the direction of Siegfried Landau at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The work was presented in its first New York performance under the patronage of King Olav V of Norway.
CAIRO, Dec. 8 -- Indonesia protested today against the attendance of the Soviet Union at an Asian-African economic conference here on the ground that the Soviet Union was neither Asian nor African.
Manhattan's Yuletide, a seasonal mixture of store-front lights, hymns for commuters and parties for children and charity seemed well under way yesterday.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 8 -- Harold Edward Holt will be Treasurer in the new Australian Cabinet announced tonight by Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies. He succeeds Sir Arthur Fadden, who has retired.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that steadily increasing public and private construction had blunted the force of the recession here, although the impact had been severe in other areas of the nation.

An issue of $28,559,000 of debentures of Metropolitan Toronto, Ont., is being offered for public subscription in the United States market today by a syndicate headed by Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and the Dominion Securities Corporation.
A 15-year-old boy was killed yesterday when he inadvertently opened the doors to an elevator shaft and plunged five flights.
LONDON, Dec. 8 -- A mid-fifteenth-century Flemish Book of Hours, illuminated on vellum and bound in calf, was sold today to three London book dealers for 32,000 ($89,600).

Ernie Squire, a messenger, drew up breathless to Window 31 of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York at 33 Liberty Street yesterday. There he delivered a sealed envelope and got a receipt stamped 1:30 P. M., which told him that in another few seconds the bids he had been carrying for several hundred million dollars of Treasury bills in the Government's weekly auction would have been worthless.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Following is the text of a policy statement issued yesterday by the Democratic Advistory Council:
JERSEY CITY, Dec. 8 -- Mayor Charles S. Witkowski asked major political groups here today to support the establishement of an informal charter-study commission by a committee of clergymen.
GENEVA, Dec. 8 -- The United States, Britain and the Soviet Union agreed today on the need for a control system to police a ban on the tests of nuclear weapons.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The cotton trade was assured today of ample supplies during the next twelve months when the Department of Agriculture estimated the 1958 crop at 11,581,000 bales. This compared with 10,964,000 in 1957.

ROME, Dec. 8 -- Pope John XXIII celebrated the Feast of the Immaculate Conception this afternoon by kneeling in prayer to the Virgin in Piazza di Spagna, a famous tourist site, and in the Basilica of St. Mary Major.

Northwest Airlines, Inc., is offering rights to its common stockholders to subscribe at par to 457,873 shares of 5 1/4 per cent cumulative convertible preferred, $25 par stock. Holders of record of Dec. 8, 1958, will get rights to one share of preferred for each three common held.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Supreme Court cleared the way today for natural-gas pipeline companies to raise their rates without first going through a rate proceeding at the Federal Power Commission.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The illness of John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, was identified by State Department associates today as diverticulitis.
Offerings and many of the leading actors participating in the San Juan (Puerto Rico) Drama Festival were announced yesterday. The season will run from Jan. 13 through March 8 at the Tapia Theatre.

While most stocks moved uncertainly yesterday, two groups and part of a third gave startling performances. These were the drugs, the natural gas companies and the oils with considerable natural gas properties.

Defense officials said yesterday that creation of a huge new missile-detection system in the Arctic was "solidly on schedule'' despite severe weather difficulties. It is the Ballistic Missile Early Warning System and strict military secrecy surrounds much of its detail.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The first issue of the Treasury's new series of 182-day discount bills sold at a price to yield an average interest rate of 3.082 per cent, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

It is more than two years since Fidel Castro and his small band of rebels landed in Oriente Province in Cuba. The censorship that the military dictator, President Batista, has imposed with brief intervals since then was amazingly successful in preventing the true situation from being learned. The really significant feature of recent sensational stories about Cuba is that the true seriousness of the situation is now known to everyone.
A CHRISTMAS gift for the family who enjoys watching television in the evening might be the Noble Farms popcorn kit.

The Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway has placed orders for forty-two new diesel locomotives and 600 freight cars. Alco Products, Inc., will build thirty of the diesels and the remainder will be built by the electro-motive division of the General Motors Corporation.
TEANECK, N. J., Dec. 8 -- Carmine G. De Sapio defended politics and politicians here today and urged young people to get into the occupation.

Peggy Wood was rapped by a Christmas package yesterday as she helped to unveil an oversized Times Square Christmas Station mailbox. Workmen helping to remove the Christmas bows and wrappings from the booth tugged the strings for the unwrapping and a large wooden bow fell, striking the actress above the left eye.
ALBANY, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Public Service Commission today denied a request by the New York Central Railroad to close six of its station buildings in the Bronx.

Connecticut and New Jersey residents who work in New York State have suffered for so many years such an injustice on their New York income tax that any promise of relief, however inadequate, probably will be welcome. Theodore Tannenwald Jr., appointed by Governor Harriman last January to study this problem of inequity along with representatives of Governors Meyner and Ribicoff, has now made his report.

THE sharp-faced, shadowy man with piercing gray-blue eyes who has been relieved as the Soviet Union's No. 1 policeman -- head of the dread Committee for State Security -- once said that he knew how to break every bone in a man's body without killing him.
BERLIN, Dec. 8 -- Otto Grotewohl, East German Premier, told West Berliners today it was not for them to decide the fate of the city.
The new luxury cruise liner Argentina steamed into port yesterday to complete a four-day trial and delivery voyage from the Gulf of Mexico.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- A top Congressional housing spokesman said today that more Federal aid for home building was needed to avert a construction slump next spring.
CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (AP) -- A variety of mildly bullish influences had little more than a steadying effect today in grain futures prices on the Board of Trade.
MOSCOW, Dec. 8 -- Soviet readers were told today that "sober-minded" people in West Berlin were not interested in the outcome of the city's election. No results of the voting were published here.
May I use a bit of space to suggest a proposal in keeping with Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa's charge of waste and extravagance by the Board of Education.
PARIS, Dec. 8 -- Antoine Pinay, Finance Minister in the Government of Premier Charles De Gaulle and himself a former Premier, quit the powerful Independent party in a huff today.
ATLANTA, Dec. 8 (AP) -- A jury weighing the Jewish temple bombing case against George Bright reported late today it was hopelessly deadlocked, but the judge sent it back to resume deliberations.

ALBANY, Dec. 8 -- The Democrats unveiled today the first section of a legislative program to provide first-year political embarrassment for Gov.-elect Nelson A. Rockefeller. Today's proposals dealt with labor problems.

THERE were moments at Carnegie Hall Sunday night when Byron Janis played as if he had arrived at last and was ready to take his place as one of America's outstanding pianists. There were others, unfortunately, when he sounded as if he were driven by inner demons that he could not harness and when his playing was just sound and fury.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Attorneys for the New York State Power Authority sought today to prove that the Tuscarora Indians live on private land, not a reservation.

Hiram Sherman has been signed for a featured role in "First Impressions," the musical adaptation of Jane Austen's "Pride and Prejudice." Mr. Sherman, who last appeared on Broadway in "International Soiree" earlier this year, will play the role of Mr. Collins, the longwinded, comic curate.
The promotions of Paul A. McManus and Clinton W. Schwer from assistant vice presidents to vice presidents of the Chase Manhattan Bank, were announced yesterday.
Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz yesterday called upon the incoming state administration to create an institui tion devoted exclusively to the custody and treatment of serious sex offenders.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 8 -- Israel accused the United Arab Republic today of an "act of war" in its bombardment of Israeli villages last Wednesday.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 8 (UPI) -- Barry MacKay and Alex Olmedo, of the United States played almost two hours in searing heat today before gaining the semi-finals in the Victorian tennis tournament with a 10 -- 12, 6 -- 4, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 3 victory over Australia's Bob Mark and Roy Emerson.
YONKERS, Dec. 8 -- Westchester County parkway police are investigating three acts of vandalism in which large rocks were thrown from parkway bridges onto moving automobiles.
Washington's preoccupation with the military aspects of the cold war has left the country perilously vulnerable on the economic front a United States industrialist declared yesterday.
More and more American manufacturing companies are leasing plants and equipment, according to a survey of 221 manufacturers by the National Industrial Conference Board.
Most of the 183 passengers of the cruise liner Arosa Star were back from Bermuda yesterday, where the vessel was immobilized Sunday for non-payment of debts.

Governor Harriman said yesterday he would continue to support "as a private citizen" legislation to outlaw discrimination in privately owned multiple dwellings. Such legislation was defeated in the Legislature's last three sessions.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The National Aeronautic Association has named Maj. Gen. Edward P. Curtis to receive the Collier Trophy Award for 1957.
Three gunmen escaped with $25,000 in cash and $22,000 in checks yesterday after threatening six employes of a supermarket here.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 8 -Secretary of State Dulles has sent a personal letter to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer reaffirming United States support for West Berlin. The letter is understood to express unqualified rejection of the Soviet proposal to make West Berlin a demilitarized free city.

TACOMA, Wash., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Los Angeles teamsters were unaware that Dave Beck owned property there that he eventually sold to the union at a $5,000 profit, a witness testified in Beck's income tax trial today.
HAVANA, Dec. 8 -- La Maya, a key town on the highway from Santiago de Cuba to Quantanamo, has been captured by the forces of Fidel Castro after a siege of two weeks, the rebel radio said today.
CROTON - ON - HUDSON, N. Y., Dec. 8 -- A new wildlife sanctuary of the National Audubon Society will be developed on 112 acres of one of the most scenic regions of the lower Hudson valley.
ANYONE who feels partial giving handmade, one-of-a-kind Christmas presents should have a heyday shopping at the Craft Shop of The Lighthouse, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street.

The A. E. Staley Manufacturing Company, processors of corn and soybeans reported yesterday that its net profit for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30 was $5,748,666. This compared with $5,175,249 cleared a year earlier.

In unanimously accepting a unanimous report of their Legal Advisory Committee, the directors of the Committee for Modern Courts have taken an action that holds great promise for the cause of court reform. The report "generally and enthusiastically" endorses the Judicial Conference modernization program. It says the plan "embodies the basic principles for a unified court system, its effective administration and the power to make its own rules."

SIXTEEN tables laden with Christmas gifts from every department of Tiffany's are now on display on this store's second and third floors. On some tables, the gifts are grouped according to price; on others, they are displayed for the various members of the family.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 8 -- Riots protesting the apparent election of Romulo Betancourt as President of Venezuela broke out in Caracas late today. They continued

The football season is over now, save for some bowl games in which Army will not participate, and so it is good-by to the lonely end. It was nice to meet him a couple of times on television this autumn, and to read about him often.

CAMDEN, N. J., Dec. 8 -- Harold M. Florsheim's Ch. Westhay Fiona of Harham, an airedale, added another best-in-show rosette yesterday to his impressive list. The terrier was selected by George H. Hartman at the Camden County Kennel Club fixture, at which 775 dogs were benched.

BOSTON, Dec. 8 -- Bernard Goldfine turned over records of five of his textile companies to the Federal Internal Revenue Service today. He lost a plea for a stay of a court order directing their surrender.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 8 -- A Protestant leader declared today that the traditional concept of separate home and foreign mission operations was obsolete and unrealistic.

The Minneapolis Lakers, led by their extraordinary rookie, Elgin Baylor, will oppose the New York Knickerbockers in the feature game of a National Basketball Association doubleheader at Madison Square Gar den tonight.

James J. Mahoney, a pressman for The Jewish Daily Forward, was elected president of the New York Printing Pressmen's Union yesterday in a run-off contest with Joseph Dwyer, president of the union for the last thirteen years.
Northern Insurance Company of New York has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering 145,200 additional shares. The new shares have a par value of $12.50.

The New York Chamber Ensemble began its ninth season Sunday night with a program that reflected the enterprise in programing and the variety of instrumental grouping that have been characteristics of the group since the start.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Market moved irregularly yesterday. Prices were 27 points higher to 9 points lower than on last Friday, with-the old-crop months showing the most strength. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

The eighth annual Hanukkah Festival for Israel was staged last night in Madison Square Garden before a capacity audience of 20,000 persons. It was held under the auspices of the Israel Bond Organization.
CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Eight dairy industry trade groups opened their annual convention on an optimistic note today.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 8 -- The growth of Argentina's debt is causing increasing concern among bankers and the envoys here of creditor nations.
ACCRA, Ghana, Dec. 8 -Prime Minister Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana warned African nationalists today to beware of new forms of colonialism and imperialism carried out by non-European powers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI) -- The Very Rev. John B. Coburn, dean of the Episcopal Theological School, Cambridge, Mass., today regretfully declined election as Bishop coadjutor of the Episcopal diocese of Washington.

The National Bank of Detroit yesterday declared a stock dividend of 10.44 per cent on the common stock to holders of record of Jan. 30. It is subject to approval of stockholders at the annual meeting Jan. 20 and the Comptroller of the Currency.

Cocoa futures opened sharply higher on the New York Cocoa Exchange but fell about 1 cent a pound during the day. Prices were weak at the close. Early strength was influenced by higher London quotations and carry-over buying orders from Friday. Stop-loss purchasing was noted.

DETROIT, Dec. 8 (UPI) -- The Army's chief of research and development said today that three years had been cut from the time required to send United States missiles from the drawing boards into the sky.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, Dec. 9 -Army Gen. Ivan A. Serov, chief of the Soviet internal security apparatus, was relieved of his post this morning.

SAN LUIS POTOSI, Mexico, Dec. 8 -- The Mexican Government asked tonight that this city suspend its near-general strike eight days while a commission discussed the problem with Secretary of Interior Gustavo Diaz Ordaz in Mexico City.

BOSTON Dec, 8 (AP) -- The Prudential Insurance Company America and the Hotel Corporation of America announced completion of negotiations today on the operation of a 25-story, 1,000-room hotel that will become part of Prudential Center -- a 31-acre development in the Back Bay section of this city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI) -- The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations said today that a recent ruling by the National Labor Relations Board would invalidate most of the estimated total of 125,000 labor-management contracts now in effect and prove disastrous unless reversed.
EVERY woman loves to find a good handbag under the Christmas tree.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 8 (AP) -- No Surrender, a six-time winner this year but without a victory since August, today captured the $4,500 Rogers Forge Purse at Pimlico by a neck front Social Lad.
The District Attorney's office moved yesterday into the investigation of the elevator-accident death of a Morningside Heights boy as the city's anti-slum drive picked up momentum.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -Former President Truman said today he would be willing to return to the Senate.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (UPI) -- Ed Lubanski and Mrs. Marion Ladewig led the qualifiers in the match game bowling tournament tonight, but Ray Bluth, a member of the St. Louis Budweisers, provided the excitement when he blasted the pins for a new series tourney record.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court took under advisement today the question of whether the Government can proceed with antitrust charges against the Radio Corporation of America and the National Broadcasting Company.

IT IS Osbert Lancaster's affable belief that "around none of the arts, with the possible exception of dry-fly fishing and twelve-tone music, has so formidable a mystique been woven as that which befogs architecture." In "Here, of all Places,"* he dispels the fog and dissolves the mystique with magnificently lethal relish.
Eastern Air Lines, Inc., has become one of the first of the nation's largest airlines to resort to equity financing to help pay the heavy cost of acquiring a fleet of turbo-prop and jet airplanes.

HONG KONG, Dec. 8 -- A joint communique issued in Peiping today by Communist China and North Korea demanded that all United States and other United Nations troops be withdrawn from South Korea immediately.

BIRMINGHAM, England, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The chairman of Tube Investments, Ltd., opened another, round today in the company's fight in association with the Reynolds Metals Company for control of British Aluminum, Ltd.
MARIE BYRD LAND, Antarctica, Dec. 1 -- New parts and a portable are welder flown out 600 miles by a Navy ski plane from Little America put the Byrd traverse party back on its tracks today.
Six clergymen in Yorktown Heights, N. Y., have endorsed a proposal to relocate the Wiltwyck School for Boys in that community, the school announced yesterday.

The first scientific study of what the dental drill does to tooth structures is being undertaken. Since the dental drill was introduced in the pre-Christian times, according to Dr. Eli D. Goldsmith, research coordinator and Professor of Histology at the New York University College of Medicine, the tooth has been regarded as little more than a hunk of granite to be drilled as best it can.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) has announced the election of Michael L. Haider as a director. Mr. Haider is president of the International Petroleum Company, Ltd., an affiliate of Jersey Standard with principal activities in Colombia, Peru and Venezuela.

IF there were any elements of auto-suggestion involved, they were entirely accidental. The Giants watched football games on television while in Detroit on Saturday, watching the action until they almost were bleary. Finally Jim Lee Howell, the kindly coach, turned off the dial.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI) -- Fourteen Washington area Chevrolet dealers and their association were fined $32,000 today on pleas of guilty to a price-fixing conspiracy.
CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (AP) -- A recommendation that all aliens be barred from the National Collegiate track and field championships has been mapped by Big Ten track coaches.

In what the Communists themselves first characterized as a plebiscite, the voters of West Berlin have turned out in record numbers and with a "No!" that is heard around the world have given a crushing and even contemptuous answer to Premier Khrushchev's proposal to turn their citadel of freedom into a defenseless "free" city open to Communist tyranny.

Republican leaders of the State Assembly hinted yesterday that they favored an increase in the gasoline tax. But they said they would be guided on tax questions by the recommendations of Governor-elect Nelson A. Rockefeller.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Perry Jones, captain of the United States team, named four player today to face the Italians in the Davis Cup interzone final. He also dispatched Ham Richardson to Perth to get adjusted to conditions.
A man described as the driver for a hold-up team operating for the last month in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx was arraigned yesterday in Ridgewood Felony Court, Queens.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 8 -- France has let it be known that she will not veto United Nations membership for Guinea when the matter arises before the Security Council tomorrow.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 8 -Tunisia called today for negotiations between France and the Algerian rebel government to bring about a settlement "in harmony with the natural right of peoples to freedom and independence."
WASHINGTON, Dec 3 -- Diplomatic sources said today that before his illness Secretary Dulles had engaged in some private correspondence with Chancellor Adenauer about the problem of Berlin.

AN annual Christmas sale at the Este Gallery, 32 East Sixty-fifth Street, once again presents many delightful possibilities to the collector of limited means. Some of these small drawings by master hands of the sixteenth to nineteenth centuries cost less than an umbrella or a modest art book.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Government began presenting defense testimony in the United States Court of Claims today in a $5,500,000 damage suit by the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation.
CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department at Agriculture follows:
ALBANY, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Governor Harriman named today four trustees of the Senate House Association.
LONDON, Dec. 8 -- The Baghdad radio broadcast tonight a statement by Premier Abdul Karim el-Kassem of Iraq that a "serious plot" against his Government had been discovered and foiled.

The Motion Picture Chapter of the American Veterans Committee is sponsoring a dance to be held at the Delmonico on Sunday. Proceeds will aid the operations in Israel of Cooperative for American Remittances to Everywhere (CARE).
