Blood will be given today to the New York Regional Red Cross blood program at the Consolidated Edison Company, 4 Irving Place, and Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn, 333 Jay Street.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 8 -- A Westchester tax of 15 per cent on admissions at the Yonkers Raceway was proposed today. The legislative committee of the Board of Supervisors said Westchester should be compensated for the "problems and inconvenience" of having the harness track in the county.

BRISBANE, Australia, Dec. 9 (Reuters) -- A marathon innings of 7 hours 38 minutes for fifty-eight runs by Trevor Bailey helped England gain a lead of 146 over Australia by the close of the fourth day of their first cricket test match today. Two days remain for play.
State Housing Commissioner Joseph P. McMurray proposed yesterday that the city's tax-abatement formula on new housing be made more flexible.

MONTREAL, Dec. 9 (UPI) -- Bernie (Boom) Geoffrion, a former champion, tied Andy Bathgate of the New York Rangers for the lead in the National Hockey League scoring race through games played last Sunday.

Andy Bathgate, the star right wing of the New York Rangers, is 26, handsome, blue-eyed and all business. Andy is a top man in his sport, and like every professional, he wants to make money. Above all, however, Bathgate is a team man.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of parents, lists the following films as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14. They will be shown Friday through Sunday, unless otherwise noted.
Harness racing commissioners from eight states ended a two-day meeting in New York yesterday by adopting a constitution and completing plans for an Association of Harness Racing Commissioners.
Fat crowns have been married to skinny brims by Miss May, a hat designer at 23 West Fiftyseventh Street. And, like Jack Spratt and his wife, one complements the other.

Today's new film is "A Nice Little Bank That Should Be Robbed," at neighborhood theatres. Tom Ewell, Mickey Rooney, Mickey Shaughnessy and Dina Merrill have the leading roles in the Twentieth CenturyFox comedy, produced by Anthony Muto and directed by Henry Levin.
Sherman Adams, former Assistant to the President, is arranging for the publication of a book he is writing on the Eisenhower Administration.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UPI) -- Two departments of the merged labor movement will conduct meetings in Miami Beach next month in an apparent rebuff to Walter P. Reuter, United Auto Workers president.
A group of "rock gardeners" in eastern Massachusetts is reaping a harvest expected to be of great value to the electronics industry.

Directors of the New Yorker magazine have voted a special year-end dividend of $2 a share on the common stock and also raised the quarterly rate to 50 cents. Payment of the dividends on Dec. 19 will bring total distributions this year to $3.70 a share.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 9 -- There are 70,000 square miles of fishing waters in the Bahamas archipelago, the crystal-clear pastel seas that ebb and flow around the islands. The cays and the reefs produce a variety of tiny marine creatures, and here to feed on this sea manna are the native and visiting game fish that have made the Bahamas one of the finest fishing sites in the world.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota is beginning to get the political breaks, and he is now just old and experienced enough to know how to exploit them.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UPI) -- The United States threw its support today behind proposals to create common markets in Latin America to encourage production.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev was reported today to have told Senator Hubert H. Humphrey that the Soviet Union has an intercontinental ballistic missile capable of firing a warhead about 8,700 miles.
BOSTON, Dec. 9 -- Farmers heard today proposals that would keep the Federal Government on the farm for some time in order to get it out of agriculture eventually.
Seven men who have been in jail since last August because they refused to answer questions about the Apalachin gangland convention lost another bid for freedom yesterday.
More than $8,500,000 worth of shares in two major companies are being offered on behalf of stockholders.
NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 9 (AP) -- A Navy tanker plane attempting an emergency landing smashed into two houses today killing it four-man crew and two babies in one of the homes.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- A golfer interested in the welfare of caddies was honored tonight at the Winged Foot Golf Club. He was Udo Reinach, a 72-year-old New York investment banker and philanthropist.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 9 (UPI) -- The Pacific Coast Conference terminated the probation of the University of California at Los Angeles today. As a result the Bruins will participate in profits of the Jan. 1 Rose Bowl football game between Iowa and the University of California.

ANOTHER year is being marked with the festive December Invitational Annual -- a massive exhibition that begins on East Twelfth Street and meanders on down to Sixth Street, managing to encompass nine galleries on the way.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 9 (AP) -The Rev. Maurice F. McCrackin ended today a fast that began Nov. 24, when he was sent to jail for contempt of court.

ONCE again the students of Pratt Institute have created a handsome exhibit on a very limited budget. And there is nothing sophomoric about the displays the second-year students have created for their annual good design show.

HONOLULU, Dec. 9 -- Hawaii's case for statehood is even stronger than Alaska's, Representative Leo W. O'Brien, Democrat of upstate New York said yesterday. Mr. O'Brien departed for the mainland after a two-week stay in the islands.
ENTREES that can be prepared in advance and then reheated just before serving time are a boon during the busy holiday season.
Two practical nurses were ordered to return to the estate of a retired lawyer $39,500 in cash and his household furnishings, which they alleged they had received as gifts.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 17 points (85 cents a bale) up yesterday. Old-crop months were strongest.

MELBOURNE, Dec. 9 (AP) -- A slender young Spaniard who has become the talk of the tennis world stood two games from a stunning victory today when rain interrupted his match with Barry MacKay of the United States.
DETROIT, Dec. 9 -- More plants of the Chrysler Corporation were closed today, bringing the total made idle because of a local strike to 31,000 workers.
The Long Island Rail Road extended a red carpet yesterday to a lost dog.

Automobile deaths and injuries on the city's streets and highways declined last week. Six persons were killed and 854 injured compared with eighteen killed and 880 injured in 1957, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday.
Ed Sullivan plans to film overseas a series of ninety-minute television programs titled "Sullivan's Travels."
The Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company borrowed $70,000,000 on thirtyfive-year debentures yesterday at an interest cost of 4.61 per cent.
CHICAGO, Dec. 9. (AP) -Grain futures dealers did business today on a preponderance of bearish influences and prices of most contracts on the Board of Trade slipped rather sharply.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- Heavily qualified optimism, uncertainty and pessimism about the year ahead were expressed today by ten top business leaders. No one forecast a boom in 1959. The predictions were made at the annual year-end Outlook for Business forum sponsored by the First National Bank of Chicago.
LONDON, Dec. 9 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan rejected Labor party pleas today for an inquiry into the conduct of the Suez adventure.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -The Democratic Advisory Council, in its policy statement this week, appears to have embraced a relatively new economic theory that is receiving increasing attention on both sides of the Atlantic.
A casual chat at a cocktail party last May between two opera-lovers, both long-time standees at the Metropolitan, led to a successful opening of grand opera last night on Staten Island.
Control of the Philadelphia Suburban Water Company was sold yesterday to a group of private investors, according to H. S. Schutt, president of the utility.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 9 -The international sports car race series completed here on Sunday was remarkable in many respects. Two of the youngest drivers, 23-year-old Lance Reventlow of Beverly Hills, Calif., and 19-year-old Pedro Rodriguez of Mexico City, emerged as two of the best.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- A witness swore today that Federal Judge James C. Connell of Cleveland received a silver champagne bucket in 1955 as a gift from Ohio Teamster Union leaders in whose favor he ruled recently.
Stocks pushed upward yesterday morning and held their moderate gains through this afternoon. Motors were weak and oils mixed. Most other major groups were stronger.
AMHERST, Mass., Dec. 9 -Creation of a new kind of liberal arts college in this area was proposed here today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 9 -A split between the directors of planning and execution of the Government's policy on the state oil monopoly was settled today when President Juscelino Kubitschek replaced the directors.

Ordinarily Rudolf Serkin, for his annual piano recital, will program three or four Beethoven sonatas and let it go at that. Last night he went quite -- for him -- far afield. It is true that there was a Beethoven sonata -- the A flat, Op. 110.
MODENA, Italy, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Enzo Ferrari, the builder of the famed Ferrari racing cars, said today he would no longer enter his cars in Italian races.

The defiance of the Civil Rights Commission by state and county officials of Alabama, led by Governor-elect John Patterson, could not have been calculated to do more damage to the Segregationist position if it had been planned by the N. A. A. C. P. itself.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UPI) -- The Right Rev. Arthur C. Lichtenberger of St. Louis, will be installed as presiding bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church in ceremonies at Washington Cathedral on Jan. 14, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -A "sky-post" observation tower is slated for construction by next April in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, the Department of Interior announced today.
Just how much the economy will improve in the next few months still depends on those long, wide, high-tailed 1959 model automobiles, according to the Guaranty Trust Company.
Retailers and some consumers will pay more for carpets after the first of the year.

IN recent speech, the president of one of this country's most prominent and fashion-conscious stores gave it as his opinion that America had "darn few" truly creative dress designers. Most experts agree that one of the greatest of those "darn few" was the late Claire McCardell. Remarkably inventive, she often was several years ahead of the times; yet her designs were always immensely practical and functional, as well as exciting.
ATLANTA, Dec. 9 (AP) -Georgia attempted today to prove bad faith and to discredit the character of one of three Negro women suing for admission to Georgia State College.

Next to the sections known as the Ordinary of the Mass there is probably no religious text that has been set to music so frequently as Todi's "Stabat Mater." Two of those settings -- one from the eighteenth century and a contemporary one -were presented last night at Clarion Concerts' second program of the season at Town Hall.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Butcher hog prices were steady to .25 cents a hundred pounds off today on a supply of 12,000 heads, somewhat more than expected. However, the total of 24,000 head for the week was 5,000 below last week's first two days.
OSLO, Norway, Dec. 9 -- The first international fur auction of this season ended here yesterday with almost 100 per cent success.
BERLIN, Dec. 9 -- The East German Communist party threatened today to prevent Dr. Otto Dibelius, Protestant Bishop of Berlin from making use of pulpits in the Soviet sector of the city.

TRENTON, Dec. 9 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner today dropped his support of the transit district legislation adopted by the New York Legislature and the New Jersey Senate. He had stanchly supported the measure since last January when it was proposed.
The city's largest sponsor of cooperative housing found yesterday that it was in a squeeze between higher tax payments and demands for lower rents.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Robert Frost, this country's poetry consultant, today called newspaper men to the Library of Congress to complain he was not being consulted.

Fewer installment buyers fell behind in their payments in October than did so the month before, according to the American Bankers Association. It said the October bank delinquencies showed improvement in every major category.
LONDON, Dec. 9 -- Prices continued to move narrowly and irregularly on the stock market today.
WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., Dec. 9 -- Students of Monmouth College, resentful of curtailed Christmas holidays, hung the college president in effigy yesterday.

In refusing to grant review the Supreme Court has now left Standing as final a recent decision of the United States Court of Appeals that the constitutional guarantee of freedom of the press does not provide absolute protection against revealing a confidential news source when it runs into conflict with the equally valid constitutional guarantee of fair trial.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- A $1,345,462,000 water resources program has been recommended by Army engineers for the Columbia and Willamette river basins.
Ships' officers and representatives of twenty major American flag ship operators reached final agreement yesterday on issues that caused a six-day strike in October.
Greater use of life insurance capital in financing social as well as economic projects was urged yesterday by Holger J. Johnson, president of the Institute of Life Insurance.
A former champion town crier of Britain -- who is still the crier of the town of Hastings -- bellowed out "Oyez, Oyez, Oyez" in Times Square yesterday.

Tile southeast corner of Third Avenue and Sixty-second Street has been purchased by a builder from Harry Horwitz, realty operator, for improvement with ; nineteen-story apartment house. The property fronts 113: feet at 1039 to 1047 Third Avehue and 123 feet at 202-04-06 East Sixty-second Street.
The Board of Education declared itself yesterday to be "firm in its resolve to proceed without let-up" in its schoolbuilding program.

A teamster union loan to the Flight Engineers International Association, which is striking against Eastern Air Lines, awaits only the formality of a request for it by the air union's Washington headquarters.

National Bulk Carriers, Inc., oil tanker owners and operators, has leased four floors in the twenty-four-story office building being completed by Senville Realty Construction, Inc., owner, at 360 Lexington Avenue at Fortieth Street.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 9 -- Columbia is negotiating for the services of Elizabeth Taylor and Joshua Logan as star and director of "I Burn the Candle at Both Ends."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Air Transport Association made an informal appeal today for Government approval of the agreement made by six airlines last month to assist each other in the event of strikes.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 9 -- Troops hurled tear-gas shells tonight to quell a new round of demonstrations here by thousands of opponents of Presidentelect Romulo Betancourt.
The Appellate Division yesterday reversed a Supreme Court injunction that prohibited the remarriage of Leo J. Goldwater, 55-year-old stockbroker of 111 East Fifty-sixth Street.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- A Federal grand jury indicted Bernard Goldfine today for contempt of Congress.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Tempers flared today as attorneys for the Tuscarora Indians and the New York State Power Authority clashed over their knowledge of history.

The Bank of New York has declared a dividend of $2.50 a share payable on Jan. 2 to stockholders of record of Dec. 19. After adjustment for the 50 per cent stock dividend paid on Oct. 1, the declaration represents about 7 per cent more than the previous quarterly payment, the bank said.
RENO, Nev., Dec. 9 -- Harry Bridges, West Coast longshore leader, went to court today to contest an old Nevada law that spoiled his elopement from San Francisco with a Japanese-American secretary.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 9 -- Local affiliates of the International Jewelry Workers Union in New York, Chicago and Providence, R. I., are in the process of bolting to other organizations.

Northrop Aircraft, Inc., had a net income of $1,454,840, equal to 92 cents a share on 1,583,739 shares outstanding in the three months ended Oct. 31, the first quarter of the company's fiscal year. A year earlier, the net income was $1,421,173, or 93 cents each on 1,527,967 shares outstanding.
MONTREAL, Dec. 9 -- The annual battle with ice in the Lachine Canal, worse this year than ever before, reached peak proportions today.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 9 -Some observers are inclined to believe that a plot to overthrow the republic, announced by Premier Abdul Karim el-Kassem last night, had its origins in southern Iraq and probably among landowning classes.

PARIS, Dec.9 -- Joel Le Tac sat down today with about 550 colleagues, in a semicircular chamber of the Palais Bourbon to start France's Parliamentary regime on a new career. M. Le Tac, trim and elegant in a gray pinstripe suit, sat in the middle of the National Assembly and was not conspicuous. But he is important because he represents the dominant political tInd in France today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UPI) -- Three postal unions took a step toward merger today by signing an agreement calling for unification of all postal employe organizations.
The spirit of charity and Christmas was expressed movingly in a letter that the fund for The New York Times Neediest Cases received yesterday from a school child in the Bronx.
Three school children and a teacher were injured yesterday when the New York Central train on which they were riding backed into a freight train in the Bronx.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- The Security Council approved today Guinea's application for membership in the United Nations.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- The United States, Britain, Australia and other countries decided today to propose the appointment of a United Nations "agent" on the Hungarian question.
The first domestic jet airliner service starts today.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday that he had discussed with Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. the opportunities for young lawyers to join his staff.

ACCRA, Ghana, Dec. 9 -- Nationalist representatives at the All-African People's Conference began committee work today to make the theoretical choice between violent and nonviolent action to achieve the independence of African territories.
The Association of the Bar of the City of New York appointed a steering committee last night to organize a statewide bar group to rally support for court reorganization.

HARTFORD, Dec. 9 -- Edwin H. May Jr. of Wethersfield was elected unanimously tonight Republican State Chairman. He is Representative from the First Congressional District (Hartford County), but was defeated for a second term last month.

City officials have made several public statements during the past two weeks blaming tenants for the slum conditions which exist in certain notoriously bad buildings. The Times on Dec. 2 reported that during a task force inspection in the Morningside area Mrs. Bernice Rogers, deputy commissioner of buildings, and George B. Stieffater, inspecting supervisor, "said that much of the trouble was tenantcaused."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The biggest move in a decade on Capitol Hill started its tortuous course this week.

LATER this month the Old Vic troupe, on tour from London, will perform "Hamlet" and "Henry V." Since they are sturdy dramas, they will doubtless make a deeper impression on the vast area of the Broadway Theatre than "Twelfth Night," which opened there last evening.

According to advices from Washington, prospects are more favorable for the establishment of an international development fund as an adjunct of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 9 -- The International Brotherhood of Teamsters, chief target of the Senate investigation on union rackets, called today for an end to the two-year-old inquiry.

The battle of the auto size is being joined. As motorcars travel at the same time toward extremes in both directions, the garage owners are the latest to step into the fray. While one set of garage owners announces that henceforth outsize autos will face a surcharge running from 15 to 30 per cent, another group offers reduced rates to operators of small cars, foreign and domestic.
ALBANY, Dec. 9 -- The legislative committee engaged in studying the Legislature's payroll and personnel practices held a closed session today to discuss its recommendations to the 1959 session.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UPI) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey said today that Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev was under doctors' orders to drink mineral water instead of vodka because of a kidney ailment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce today took action against the Stauffer Chemical Company of New York and San Francisco for doing business with a foreign concern whose rights to accept United States exports had been revoked.

MADELYN HOEY will draw the shades today in her little shop at 21 East Sixty-fifth Street. She always does, about a fortnight before Christmas. Drawn shades keep transients from the door. That leaves her more time to work with assistants -- a few old hands, a few boys and girls who come in after school closing -- to get out holiday orders.
LONDON, Dec. 9 -- The highest price in sterling that has ever been paid at auction for a rare manuscript was set at the Sotheby Co. salesroom today.
An American Christmas party was given yesterday for 400 children of United Nations delegates by the Arnold Constable department store. The children were from eighty countries.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Thirteen persons collected nearly $1,000,000 from a suburban bank because an official concealed bad checks for friends, a prosecutor said today.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Dec. 9 -- About 190,000 Danish mink pelts, worth about $8,000,000, were put on view here today by The Danish Fur Sales, an organization of the Danish Fur Breeders Association. Since the end of World War II, fur breeders here have concentrated on production of minks, with an output of about 700,000 pelts a year.
There are 90,000 social workers in this country and less than half of them are professionally trained, a social work recruitment specialist said here yesterday.

"GIFT OF THE MAGI," O. Henry's story of touching simplicity, was used as the basis for a play with music last night on a special program over Channel 2. Initiative and experimentation certainly are to be encouraged on TV, but perhaps it would have been wiser if this undertaking had been left undone.

New York's leading college basketball teams are composed almost exclusively of home-grown talent. It's also reliably estimated that 200 to 300 metropolitan area high school players go to out-of-town colleges each year, usually by invitation.

SAN LUIS POTOSI, Mexico, Dec. 9 -- This city of nearly 200,000 population, which has been virtually paralyzed for the last seven days, was nearly normal today under a truce period arranged between the citizens of the capital and the national Administration.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Senator Humphrey gave President Eisenhower today a confidential message from Premier Khrushchev on Soviet nuclear and rocket developments.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 9 -- The Civil Rights Commission today answered the first challenge to its power by seeking court action against registration officials in six counties.
R. H. Macy Co., Inc., announced yesterday installation of what it called the biggest automation program in department store history.
LONDON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Ellsworth (Spider) Webb of Chicago stopped Terry Downes, the British middleweight champion, after eight rounds in a bruising bout tonight.
CHICAGO, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Don Ellis, a 29-year-old Chicagoan by way of Houston, led the world invitation bowling tournament following completion of two final rounds in the Coliseum today.
WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 9 -Support mounted here today for the Metropolitan Regional Council to seek formal legal status in order to deal more effectively with pressing area-wide problems.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 9 -A new board of directors of Yacimientos Petroliferos Fiscales, (YPF), Argentina's state oil company, took office today in the first step of a reorganization designed to streamline operations and management.
CAIRO, Dec. 9 -- The Soviet Union was overwhelmingly defeated today in an attempt to turn the Asian-African economic conference here into a forum on the "cold war."

Venezuela had a fair, democratic election on Sunday which Romulo Betancourt, head of the Accion Democratica party, won by a decisive margin. Nothing should be allowed to annul this free decision of the voters, and it seems clear enough that nothing will be allowed to do so.
GENEVA, Dec. 9 -- Following is text of the first two articles of a draft treay, as approved by the United States, British and Soviet delegations, on suspensions of nuclear weapons tests:

LUXEMBOURG, Dec. 9 (Reuters) -- The Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, smallest member state of the Atlantic alliance, was in the throes of a political crisis tonight following a parliamentary vote of censure against a Cabinet Minister.
LITTLE AMERICA, Antarctica, Dec. 7 -- Two previously uncharted islands have been discovered in Terra Nova Bay on the Ross Sea.
PARIS, Dec. 9 -- A much-weakened National Assembly started France's new parliamentary regime off today by electing Jacques Chaban-Delmas, a Gaullist, as its permanent Speaker.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 9 -- The Protestant missionary of today is more often a teacher, an agricultural worker or a physician than he is a preacher.
A conference commemorating the tenth anniversary of United Nations adoption of its Universal Declaration of Human Rights heard calls yesterday for a more active United States policy to implement it.

Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, was requested yesterday to make a full investigation of the reported arrest recently of at least eighty physicians, scientists, students and other persons in Spain on undisclosed charges. The request was made by twenty-one writers, editors, educators and attorneys.
The number of children here with neglected dental problems increased during the last year, a city health official reported yesterday at the Greater New York Dental Meeting.
ALBANY, Dec. 9 -- The Democratic legislative leaders today accused the incoming Rockefeller Administration of reneging on a "major campaign promise" even before taking office.
WARSAW, Dec. 9 -- East Germany's Communist chief came to Warsaw today and immediately accused the West Germans of plotting to take back former German territory now controlled by Poland.

Tile one-story buiIding at Union Avenue and Ridge Road, North Arlington, N. J., has been purchased for investment by the; Baltimore Life Insurance Company. The deal was made through Ruland ,k BenjaminEarle Calhoun, Inc., mortgage correspondent for the buyer, and Frank W. Kennedy.
The number of deaths here from tuberculosis rose slightly last year, according to a survey published yesterday by the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association.

The city Administration was accused yesterday of having driven "thousands upon thousands" of persons out of their homes and into slums to make way for public improvements. The charge was made by Minority Leader Stanley M. Isaacs, Manhattan Republican.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -Democratic liberals are charting a three-point attack on the power of conservatives to bottle up legislation in the House of Representatives.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- United States officials leaned to the belief today that General Serov, had been removed as a result of dissension in the Kremlin.

I have long, admittedly somewhat vaguely, held a high opinion of the institution and of the management of the Port of New York Authority until I read in The Times of Nov. 26 that Austin J. Tobin, the authority's executive director, before a committee of the New Jersey State Assembly, "forecast a gradual elimination of railroads as a mode of commuter travel."
As we in this city were eloquently reminded last night, this is the tenth anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. This, in other words, is Human Rights Day.
All world and domestic sugar positions climbed to new highs for the life of the contracts yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 9 -Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's doctors advised him today to postpone a suddenly scheduled visit to London designed to repair two potentially dangerous rifts in British-West German relations.

For the first nine or ten minutes at Madison Square Garden last night, the Knickerbockers showed 7,156 fans how basketball should not be played. The New Yorkers floundered about the court, doing little right and lots wrong against the Minneapolis Lakers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Federal Power Commission said today that the consumer would not be left unprotected as a result of the Supreme Court's decision in the Memphis natural gas case.

SOMERVILLE, N. J., Dec. 9 -- Two persons were killed and fifteen injured tonight when a New York-bound Trailways bus crashed head on with a light pick-up truck. The bus driver had swerved to avoid an unlighted trailer truck.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- The Standard Oil Company, (Indiana), announced the formation today for a new international subsidiary to sell, trade and transport crude oil and petroleum products. It is caller the Amoco Trading Corporation.
COLLEGE PARK, Md., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Tommy Mont resigned today, apparently under pressure, as the head football coach at the University of Maryland.
A combination heating and air conditioning unit to be used by drive-in theatres for customers' cars soon will be marketed, BTU Industries of Englewood, N. J., announced yesterday.
HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Ten thousand Communists demonstrated in Parliament Square tonight for a voice in the Government, friendship for the Soviet Union and a cure for growing unemployment.
LONDON, Dec. 9 -- A government-appointed Court of Inquiry condemned today "disruptive" activities by Communist employes at London Airport.

SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Dec. 9 (AP) -- This craggy valley today needs only a few months' additional work to be ready for winter sports' biggest event -- the Olympic Games. The job of building a first-class home for the 1960 games is more than 70 per cent complete.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 24 -- The chunky little boy stood quietly but half-turned, ready to run if the strangers visiting his schoolyard proved unfriendly.
The city quickly dug itself out ffrom a 3.2-inch snowfall yesterday, but not without disruptions in train and subway travel and a total blackout for one radio station.
The New York subway tunnels may soon get a new look -- a clean one.

The removal of Gen. Ivan A. Serov as chief of the Soviet internal security apparatus is regarded by specialists in Soviet affairs as a political development of major consequence. They believe it is undoubtedly designed to strengthen the personal control of Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev over the Soviet secret police.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Dec. 9 (Reuters) -- An official inquiry today cleared British troops of allegations that they wilfully exposed Greek Cypriote prisoners to Turkish savagery in an incident last June in which eight Greeks were killed.
Newspaper delivery workers resumed their strike last night against nine major daily newspapers here.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Official sources said today that the United States still hoped France would establish 1,500mile intermediate-range ballistic missile bases as part of the Western defense system.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 9 -The national committee of Peronist trade unions called off today a forty-eight-hour general strike scheduled to begin Thursday.
Blood will be given today at City College, 139th Street and Convent Avenue, to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program.

MONTREAL, Dec. 9 -- Archie Moore, the ancient of the prize ring, will risk his world light-heavyweight championship here tomorrow night. He will meet Yvon Durelle of Baie Ste. Anne, N. B., in a fight listed for fifteen rounds.
Cincinnati was named the nation's No. 1 college basketball team yesterday in the first weekly ratings of the 1958-59 season by The United Press International board of coaches.

BERLIN, Dec. 9 -- Governing Mayor Willy Brandt urged the Western allies tonight to refuse any negotiations on the basis of the Soviet "ultimatum" to end the four-power occupation of Berlin within six months.
Word is expected soon whether the proposed return engagement of "Epitaph for George Dillon" can be maneuvered into the Fifty-fourth Street (Adelphi) Theatre.
"The vocal mechanism of many advertising executives is not up to the quality of the ideas they are attempting to present," according to a speech expert.

Although harpists frequently bewail the limited repertory for their instrument and the necessity of using transcriptions of piano music, Susann McDonald has assembled three programs of music originally written for harp.

TITO GOBBI, who ranks among Italy's leading baritones, sang his first Iago at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. Like Hamlet in the theatre, this is one of the most testing roles in opera, and Mr. Gobbi gave an impressive account of himself.
George Meany warned yesterday that if the trade union movement could not achieve its legislative objectives in any other way, it would establish a third political party.

Physicians in New York State who handled workmen's compensation cases were authorized by the Workmen's Compensation Board yesterday to increase their fees by approximately 30 per cent after March 1, 1959.
TOKYO, Dec. 9 -- A report made public today by the Japanese Government on the 1959 outlook on the economy predicts a growth of 5.5 per cent and a favorable trade balance of $160,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UPI) -- Vice Admiral Hyman G. Rickover fixed a copyright stamp today on a speech he will deliver in New York Thursday.
Thoroughbred racing showed slight gains in both attendance and wagering in 1958, the annual Associated Press survey of the sport disclosed yesterday.

The current municipal campaign against slum conditions has been characterized by Mayor Wagner as a "massive new attack" on this longstanding evil. We hope that the measures thus initiated will bring some improvement, but they are at most sorties against the flanks of a massive enemy, the advancing slum. The real attack on slums must be directed at the acute shortage of decent housing within the means of our low-income and low-middle-income families.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 9 -- There is little doubt that when the Berlin crisis comes to a head next spring the world may again hover on war's brink. Khrushchev appears determined to test Allied unity and resolve. He has scheduled the showdown for May.
SANTA CLARA, Calif., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Father Bernard J. Hubbard today forecast a bleak future for Alaska, the new forty-ninth state.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Dec. 9 (AP) -- West Virginia University played its best basketball of the young season early in the second half tonight to rout The Citadel, 89-61, for its thirty-ninth straight Southern Conference triumph.

Roy Campanella, famed catcher of the Dodgers, who was paralyzed in an automobile accident ten months ago, has signed with Little, Brown for his life story. He will be assisted in the preparation of his book by Dave Camerer and Joe Reichler, sports writers and close friends.
TOKYO, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Aiichiro Fujiyama said today negotiations with Washington for revision of Japan's 1951 security treaty with the United States would be delayed.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UPI) -- The Treasury Department reported today it had achieved 92 per cent of its 1958 sales for Series E and H savings bonds as of Nov. 30.

TRIS SPEAKER was such a phenomenal outfielder that a new generation of baseball fans has grown up in the mistaken belief that the Gray Eagle swooped into the Hall of Fame only because of his magic with a glove. It isn't true. Here was a rounded ballplayer of superlative skills, a man gifted in every department of play.
FRANKFURT, Germany Dec. 9 (AP) -- Another sign of unrest in the Soviet literacy would appeared today with the word that Alexander Tcheyshvili, a novelist, had received political asylum in the West.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 9 -- Navy's basketball team set a field house record in walloping Dickinson of Carlisle, Pa., today, 99 -- 35. It was Navy's second straight victory of the season.
LONDON, Dec. 9 -- The British Government is seeking a new and more realistic approach to Germany's reunification within the general framework of Western policy, qualified sources disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -General Cairns, a veteran of World War II fighting in North Africa and Italy, was born in New York on Feb. 14, 1910. He was graduated from the Military Academy at West Point in 1932 and commissioned a second lieutenant of cavalry.
Four more schools were ordered closed yesterday by Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. after fire department inspection teams found violations.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Dec. 9 -- Part of the busy day of Charles W. Kraus, Bergen County's Supervisor of Roads, included testing his department's work yesterday, but he hadn't planned it that way. At 11:40 o'clock last night Mr. Kraus, 42 years old, returned from Trenton, where he had worn his second hat, as a member of the Assembly, which had met in a long session.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission made public today a proposal by a half dozen railroads operating in West, South and Central States to make a selective 5 per cent increase in their interstate passenger coach fares.
The Power Authority of the State of New York is negotiating with investment bankers for the sale of $200,000,000 of revenue bonds. The securities are slated to be offered publicly on or about Jan. 6.

GENEVA, Dec. 9 -- An inspection system based on "the principle of mutual consent" was advocated today by the Soviet delegate to the conference on banning tests of nuclear weapons. Semyon K. Tsarapkin described a control organization in which the United States, Britain or the Soviet Union could block any decision to send inspectors to the site of suspected violations of a nuclear test ban.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The economy in early 1959 is not expected to get much help from any resurgence of business investment in plant and equipment.

Two companies that have spent years independently seeking an economical way to make boron trichloride -- a rocket fuel intermediate -have decided to join forces in a cooperative research project on the product.
MADRID, Dec. 9 -- The Spanish Government is seeking to set up controls on public investment and curb serious overspending by several of its semiautonomous agencies.

NEWARK, Dec. 9 -- The New York Central Railroad asked a Federal Court here today to clear the way legally for the closing of the railroad's ferry service from Weehawken to Cortlandt Street in New York.

EVANSTON, Ill, Dec. 10 (AP) -- American business and industry will hire more university and college graduates in 1959 at a slightly higher starting salary than in 1958.

TITO GOBBI, who ranks among Italy's leading baritones, sang his first Iago at the Metropolitan Opera House Tuesday. Like Hamlet in the theatre, this is one of the most testing roles in opera, and Mr. Gobbi gave an impressive account of himself.
CHICAGO, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- President Eisenhower contradicted former President Harry S. Truman today, declaring "I have had a little bit too much sense to waste my time getting mad at anybody."
Six detectives have had the kind of fun usually reserved for hunch players in mystery novels.

ALGIERS, Dec. 10 -- General Raoul Salan, in what appeared to be his final remarks as commander in Algeria, asked the army tonight to cooperate loyally with the civil administrators who will succeed him.
Yesterday was a difficult day for New Yorkers trying to adjust to life in a city virtually without newspapers.
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad was barred yesterday from taking any further action on the "eviction notice" it had served on the Biltmore Hotel and its concessionaires two weeks ago.
Directors of International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation yesterday proposed a two-for-one split of the common stock. They also announced plans to raise the dividend.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Thursday, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The elimination of Barry MacKay and Alex Olmedo from the Victorian tennis championship has darkened the United States Davis Cup picture and posed a major problem for the non-playing captain, Perry Jones.
The recent name change of the Pennroad Corporation to Madison Fund, duly noted in the business news section, underlines the complexity that has entered even this area of American business.

Net earnings of the Joy Manufacturing Company for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30 declined to $4,166,204 from $11,342,225 in the preceding year. The earnings are equal to $2.33 and $6.34 a share, respectively.

These menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are desired to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

That hot potato, the voluntary oil import program, is about to be taken away from the oil industry, much to its chagrin and surprise, observers in Washington report. The latest word is that the Government, which has not been pleased with the cooperation demonstrated by the oil industry, has decided to make the oil import limitations mandatory.
The offices of the Arosa Line United States, Inc., were closed for business yesterday. Leroy W. Gunston, general manager of the office, had submitted his resignation Monday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -Twenty Negro pupils from Front Royal, Va., have been enrolled in integrated high schools in the District of Columbia this week.

India is not satisfied with assurances from the United States Government that American arms provided Pakistan will not be used against India, Ambassador Mahomed Ali Currim Chagla of India said yesterday.

Plans have been completed for the eleventh annual Christmas Ball for post-debutantes, bachelors and young married couples, which will be held in the Ballroom and the Trianon Room of the Sheraton-East on Dec. 19.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- November produced a record in consumers' retail spending and better than usual performance in employment and unemployment, according to government reports issued today.
MADRID, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Four jair breakers who had kidnaped a United States naval officer and his family in their flight were killed today in a gun fight with policemen.

THREE prominent figures in the British theatre -Margaret Leighton, the actress; Peter Glenville, the director, and Kenneth Tynan, the critic -- contributed early yesterday morning to a brilliant installment of television -- more than two hours of uninterrupted good talk on the theatre.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 10 -- President Alberto Lleras Camargo said in a nation-wide radio speech today that he hoped "in a few days" to be able to end the state of siege imposed on Colombia a week ago today.

New York State borrowed $51,000,000 in the public market yesterday on serial bonds to finance the construction of highways and mental institutions. The obligations were sold at an interest cost of 2.86078 per cent to a syndicate headed by the Chase Manhattan Bank.
LUXEMBOURG, Dec. 10 (UPI) -- The Luxembourg Coalition Government resigned today in a dispute over an alleged case of attempted bribery in the Transport Ministry.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Don Ellis, a 30-year-old Chicagoan from Texas, moved into the sixth-round lead in the world invitation bowling tournament tonight. He had a twenty-four-game total of 122.15 Petersen points.
ST. LOUIS (AP) -- Bob Tewes, plagued by hard luck throughout his athletic career, may be the only basketball player in the nation wearing a helmet this season.

HONG KONG, Dec. 10 (UPI) -- Reports reaching here from Portuguese Macao said today that residents of the Chinese Communist offshore island of Lappa rose yesterday in a revolt that was crushed by Red troops in bloody reprisals.
TRENTON, Dec. 10 -- Police prejudice was advanced today as a factor in the high rate of juvenile delinquency in New York City.

Breeding practices for show dogs received some sharp barbs from two experts at the monthly meeting of the Dog Fanciers Luncheon Club in the Hotel Manhattan this week, James W. Trullinger of New York, an all-around judge of dogs, and Dr. William H. Ivens Jr. of Doylestown, Pa., a veterinarian and poodle exhibitor, threw the darts.

Stocks of light fuel oil, used mostly in heating homes, dropped by 5,613,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end total supplies were 155,826,000 barrels, compared with 161,438,000 a week earlier and 163,145,000 a year ago.
A plan was advanced last night for a "vertical" organization of all persons and organizations connected with the production and distribution of coats and suits.
Tonight's performance by the New York City Ballet celebrates the fifteenth anniversary of the opening of the City Center of Music and Drama.
MANILA, Dec. 10 -- Prelates from twenty Asian countries opened today the first Far East conference of bishops to discuss pressures upon the Roman Catholic Church in this part of the world.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Dec. 10 -- Darryle (Sammy) Kouns, Army's basketball scoring champion, stuffed in 27 points today as the unbeaten cadets routed Rutgers, 81 -- 60, at the West Point Field House.

The Rhinelander Real Estate Company has sold the four-story factory building at the northwest corner of the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue) and Thirteenth Street after an ownership of fifty years.
A plea for a little less "togetherness'' was made yesterday by a New York University professor.

A year ago Publicis, one of France's leading ad agencies opened an office here. One of the functions of Bernard Musnik, vice president of the operation in New York, was to send word on latest developments in the ad industry here to the agency's clients abroad.
Slum conditions in a "jungle" on the upper West Side were branded as "immoral, indecent and impossible" yesterday by the Rev. James A. Gusweller.
Imports arriving here last month for Christmas consumption helped the Port of New York register its second best monthly Customs collection of 1958.
William Saroyan's play "The Human Comedy" will be televised on the "Du Mont Show of the Month" next March.

Ordinarily Rudolf Serkin, for his annual piano recital, will program three or four Beethoven sonatas and let it go at that. Tuesday night he went quite -- for him -- far afield. It is true that there was a Beethoven sonata -- the A flat, Op. 110.
LONDON, Dec. 10 -- Reversing the recent trend, British exports showed a notable increase last month, the Board of Trade announced today.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- The United States has made preliminary approaches to Britain for permission to set up a radar station in the north of Scotland to give the United States warning of the approach of Soviet ballistic missiles.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UPI) -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Auto Workers, said today that he opposed formation of a labor political party.

The current crisis over Berlin keeps recalling to my mind what that clear-minded statesman, Don Luigi Sturzo, wrote way back in 1946, when he was a guest of our country. When Germany was being divided into four zones of military occupation he warned: "The occupation of Germany will last fifteen or twenty years and the longer it lasts the less likely it is to end peacefully." ("Nationalism and Internationalism.")
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 10 -- The motor vessel United States, most powerful towboat ever built for inland waterways, was christened today on the Mississippi River.

FOR the second year running, Seabrook Farms has set about to prove that the cook who "can't boil water" is in desperate straits indeed. Last year, the concern introduced four frozen main courses that could be served after simmering for twelve minutes in their plastic pouches.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- President Eisenhower termed "reprehensible" today the refusal of Alabama officials to produce voting records for the Civil Rights Commission.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Baltimore Colts go into the final week of the National Football League's regular season with a 201-yard lead over the Los Angeles Rams in total offense.
MONTREAL, Dec. 10 -- It was an elegant Archie Moore who showed up at the Montreal Boxing Commission office this noon to weigh in for his fight with Yvon Durelle.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 10 -- The Soviet Union urged France today to grant independence to the Algerian rebel government. Arkady A. Sobolev, the Soviet representative, accused American "oil monopolists" of joining "French colonialists" in opposing Algerian independence.
BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Dec. 10 -- The Binghamton and Elmira areas joined today in appealing for state help in meeting problems of metropolitan growth.

The first public offering of shares of The Upjohn Company, seventy-two-year-old maker of ethical drug products, is being made today by a syndicate of investment banking houses headed by Morgan Stanley Co.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UPI) -- School enrollment rose to to a record 42,900,000 this autumn, the Census Bureau reported today. It has increaed by nearly 9,000,000 in the last five years.
May I congratulate you on your editorial of Dec. 5 on "Lawyers and Court Reform?" You are quite right in calling to your readers' attention the regrettable apathy of many lawyers in this great cause.

Thomas Thacher, a member of the law firm of Simpson, Thacher Bartlett, was elected yesterday a member of the board of directors of the Park Association of New York City, Inc. The board acted at its meeting in the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park South.

I must take exception to the letter from Lieutenant Tewksbury of Nov. 24. In it he commended the present policy of reducing the manpower of our ground forces in favor of greater concentration on air and sea striking power.

MONTREAL, Dec. 10 (Canadian Press) -- Lachine Canal workers used steam jets, flame throwers, compressed air and plain elbow grease today to keep the nine-mile waterway open for twenty-one eastbound vessels and five westbound ships.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 10 -- The Argentine Government decreed price controls for thirty-five typical market-basket items today and threatened violators with military trials.
LONDON, Dec. 10 -- The stock market generally was more cheerful today. This was ascribed, in part, to the unexpectedly favorable export figures.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Eastern Hobo, omed by W. Taylor Leatherbury of Maryland, was the lone winning favorite at Pimlico today. He scored at 13-to-5 odds in the featured Cromwell Purse.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Thomas Moore, general counsel for the New York State Power Authority, described as unscholarly today a report submitted by Governor-elect Nelson A. Rockefeller to the New York Legislature on the State Constitution.
POINT MUGU, Calif., Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Navy fired a Regulus II guided missile from a ship in the Pacific missile range today.

It is hardly surprising that a policy statement issued by the party out of office at a time of partial recovery from a business recession should place much of its stress upon economic matters. Prayers for peace and the welfare of mankind were included with the gifts that reached the fund for the New York Times Neediest Cases yesterday.
BOSTON, Dec. 10 -- Threer 'Cardinals designate left Boston! by plane today for Rome to' receive their l@d hats from@ Pope John @III.

RENO, Nev., Dec. 10 -- By court order, Harry Bridges, leader of the International Longshoremen's Union, and Miss Noriko Sawada, American citizen of Japanese ancestry, obtained a marriage license today.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 10 (Reuters) -- The Pakistani Foreign Minister said today it was, "in favor of arbitration" to settle the country's border disputes with India.
GENEVA, Dec. 10 -- Britain presented a new draft article today on the control organization for a treaty banning tests of nuclear weapons.
PARIS, Dec. 10 -- The reduction of the Communist group in the National Assembly from 143 to ten has caused a severe financial loss to the party.
Former Senator Herbert H. Lehman declared last night that Americans who denied civil rights to their fellow-citizens were jeopardizing United States foreign policy.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Dec. 10 -- Malaya sharply criticized the Communist bloc's trade dumping practices today and announced a new policy of liberalizing dollar imports beginning Jan. 1.
A renewed strike by delivery workers against nine major city newspapers continued yesterday.

CAIRO, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Usually reliable sources said today that Rashid Ali Gailani was one of the men rounded up by Iraq's Government in connection with an atteempted coup. Rashid Ali is the former Premier who led a pro-Axis revolt in 1941.
HAVANA, Dec. 10 -- The 26th of July movement headed by Senor Castro claims to have "liberated" twenty-five sugar mills in Oriente Province and to have reorganized their labor unions.

Harold Callen has been assigned to dramatize the recently published novel "The Summer Lovers," by Hollis Alpert. Morris Helprin, head of a film company called Barbizon Productions and former president of London Film Productions, plans to sponsor the stage adaptation on Broadway next season.
The Transit Authority reported yesterday it had incurred an operating deficit of $3,377,372 in the two-month period ended Aug. 31. Of this, the month of August alone produced a deficit of $1,406,609.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission warned Christmas shoppers today to beware of fly-by-night peddlers who offered 'French" perfume at bargain prices.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- President Eisenhower said today the Western powers would not alter their basic policy on Germany and would stand firmly by their rights and duties in West Berlin.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Spending advocates in the Government drew a warning today from the chairman of the House Appropriations Committee.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 10 -- An international conference intended to settle the controversial problem of the extent of territorial waters and also the limits to exclusive fishing rights will be held in the spring of 1960.

ROME, Dec. 10 -- Neil McElroy United States Secretary of Defense, arrived here today to meet Italian leaders and United States officials in Italy. The installation of missile bases in Italy is understood to be high on the agenda of the United States-Italian military talks.
Beaten in their four previous meetings with Detroit, the New York Rangers attempted to break the Red Wings' hold in National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

Long Island University has no immediate ambitions to reclaim its former role as a national basketball power. However, the Brooklyn school is very much back in the game, on a sound and healthy basis that coincides with its status as one of the fastest-growing institutions in this area.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 10 -- A bomb today shattered the headquarters of a Southern California religious sect, killing at least nine persons. The bomber was presumed to be one of the victims.

The common shares of the Thiokol Chemical Corporation, a major manufacturer of rocket engines, began trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday morning. The ticker symbol THI was printed on the tape shortly after the start of trading as 100 shares were bought at $97.50 a share by Joseph W. Crosby, president of the Bristol, Pa., company.
The New York County Lawyers Association has approved in principle the Judicial Conference's new plan to reform the state's courts.

For the last two years word has been seeping down from Boston of an unusual concert program prepared by Herb Pomeroy's orchestra and John McLellan, a Boston disk jockey, called "A Living History of Jazz."

CHICAGO (AP) -- At least ten high school football players died on the nation's gridirons in the 1958 season, according to the National Alliance Football Safety Committee. There were fourteen such deaths in 1957.

Athletic directors opened the twenty-second annual schedule-making convention of the Eastern College Athletic Conference at the Hotel Manhattan yesterday. Officers were elected for fourteen units and dates were set for championship competitions in 1959 an 1960.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 10 (AP) -- United States air and naval forces in the Taiwan area are being reduced as the Communist threat to the Chinese Nationalist offshore islands lessens.
No progress was reported yesterday toward resolving the two-week strike of mechanics Eastern Air Lines.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved somewhat irregularly yesterday, and closed 28 points lower to 4 points higher. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

The Samaritan Home for the Aged will benefit from a theatre party to be held at the ballroom and the Trianon "The Gazebo" next Tuesday evening. The new comedy starring Walter Slezak and Jayne Meadows is scheduled to open at the Lyceum Theatre tomorrow.
HACKENSACK, N. J., Dec. 10 -- The five-year, $1,095,635 garbage removal contract between the Borough of Fair Lawn and Capasso Brothers of Ridgewood was declared illegal today because of fraud.
PARIS, Dec. 10 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle faces an imminent choice between stability and expansion in France's economic and financial policy.

Your editorial on "Lawyers and Court Reform," criticizing the apathy and hostility of "most bar associations" toward well-conceived plans for court reform, is unfair to those bar associations that have been actively supporting court reform.

WILL HARRIDGE is a kindly, gentle and avuncular man who has just retired as president of the American League. After serving twenty-eight years as the handsomest sort of window dressing for his circuit, Uncle Will is yielding his swivel chair to someone else, probably Joe Cronin, one of the finest swivel-chair fillers in baseball.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 10 -- The military leaders of Indonesia began a conference behind closed doors today in the mountain resort of Bandung. The Army Chief of Staff, Lieut. Gen. Abdul Haris Nasution, is chairman of the meeting.

Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper, a member of the United States delegation to the United Nations General Assembly, said yesterday that it was "a sacred duty" to keep alive the support of the underground hopes for freedom in the Eastern European nations held captive by the Soviet Union.
The staff at the Kudner Agency, Inc., received its Christmas bonus yesterday -with a pair of boxing gloves.
PARIS, Dec. 10 -- Thousands of university students demonstrated today in Paris' Left Bank Latin Quarter for more Government aid to education.

Cardinal Spellman's Chirstmas Party for the benefit of the New York Foundling Hospital netted $76,000 yesterday. The Cardinal said that the total was far above any received in the twelve previous years of the party.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 10 -- The election of Romulo Betancourt as President of Venezuela was conceded today by his two opponents, as order returned to Caracas after two nights of rioting.
WARSAW, Dec. 10 -- The visit of East Germany's Communist leaders to Poland has developed into a strange blend of publicity and secrecy.
The city is making ready a broad new program that will put at least as much emphasis on slum prevention as is now given to efforts to remove slum conditions.

SANDY POINT, Abaco, Bahamas, Dec, 10 -- Thirty-five minutes to the north of Nassau the Grumman amphibian makes an exploratory pass to find deep water. Then the pilot sets it down smoothly 100 yards offshore.

Events tonight: "La Gioconda," Metropolitan Opera, 8; New York Philharmonic, Leonard Bernstein, conductor and pianist, Johanna Martzy, violinist, F. William Heim, piccolo player, Carnegie Hall, 8:50; Susann McDonald, harpist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Cantata Singers, William Reese conducting, St. Michael's Protestant Episcopal Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Ninety-ninth Street, 8:30.
ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 10 -"We make a grave error if we assume that America is a Christian nation," the Rev. Dr. Roy G. Ross told a national group of Protestant churchmen who convened here today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The White House said today that President Eisenhower would not proclaim Alaska a state until after Jan. 1.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- A Soviet scientific vessel will be open for inspection by United States scientists and others at San Francisco next week, the National Academy of Sciences said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The recent increase in the cost of mortgage money has leveled off, according to Norman P. Mason, Commissioner of the Federal Housing Administration.

ROME, Dec. 10 -- Pope John XXIII made his first public speech in English today. He apologized for his incomplete knowledge of that language, and smilingly promised he would try to do better in the future.

Shimon Peres, Director General of Israel's Defense Ministry, emphasized yesterday that a major concern of his nation was to absorb the heavy influx of immigrants, particularly from East European countries.

LATER this month the Old Vic troupe, on tour from London, will perform "Hamlet" and "Henry V." Since they are sturdy dramas, they will doubtless make a deeper impression on the vast area of the Broadway Theatre than "Twelfth Night," which opened there Tuesday evening.

The world sugar positions opened strongly yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Buying by commission houses and Cuban interests and trade short covering pushed all months to new lifeof-contract highs.
The temperature here fell to a seasonal low of 14.4 degrees at 7:30 A. M. yesterday as frigid weather continued to grip most of the East.

Ski Sketch: Cal Cantrell, who lives in Monticello, taught skiing last season at Highmount, which is just a hop, step and a short schuss from metropolitan New York. This season he's heading for the real north country.
MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 10 -- Three parochial schools in Nassau County have been found unsafe because of fire hazards and will be closed by the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre.

ATLANTA, Dec. 10 -- A mistrial was declared today in the case of George Bright, the first of five men to be tried on charges of dynamiting a Jewish temple.

Medical specialists in anasthesia of the United States and Britain yesterday reached a first agreement on the standardization of equipment.
WACO, Tex., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Sam Boyd resigned as head football coach of Baylor today in the face of a gathering alumni storm. He had just wound up a second losing season.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 10 -- Twelve months ago Romulo Betancourt, whose election as President of Venezuela Sunday has been followed by disorders, was an outcast and exile. Even though he had been President from 1945 to 1948, mention of him in the Venezuela press had been outlawed.

The new $900,000 Katharine Sloan Pratt Hall of Packer Collegiate Institute on Brooklyn Heights was dedicated yesterday.
Cadet Peter M. Dawkins of the United States Military Academy stepped smartly front and center last night as the twenty-fourth recipient of the Heisman Memorial Trophy.

Electric power production last week rose to a record 13,017,000,000-kilowatt hours from 12,274,000,000 in the preceding week, the Edison Electris Institute has reported.

New York University's new Loeb Student Center at Washington Square held its first program yesterday, although construction of the building is only half finished.
Animal experiments indicate that at least half a dozen factors play a part in causing toothdecay, it was reported yesterday at the Greater New York Dental Meeting at the Statler Hilton Hotel.

Joel Silver, a 6-foot 3-inch sophomore, has been designated Johnny Bucek's replacement in the starting line-up of the New York University quintet, which meets Boston College at Madison Square Garden tonight. Bucek withdrew from the team earlier this week.

She tells the story of her life in "Sold for Silver," which World will publish Jan. 26.

A group of young Socialists staged a three-hour demonstration outside the Spanish Consulate here yesterday afternoon in protest against the recent arrests in Spain of Socialists and other opponents of the Franco dictatorship.

White Weld Co. and associates are offering $50,000,000 of Philadelphia Electric Company 4 3/8 per cent first and refunding mortgage bonds today. Due in 1986, the bonds will be offered at par to yield 4.375 per cent to maturity.
