Florida's football coach, Bob Woodruff, s0aid the 6-foot one-inch 185-pound quarterback signed the Southeastern Conference pact with assistant coach Dick Jones today.

Giulio Confalonieri of La Scala and Mario Colombo, director of the Associazione Lirica e Concertistica Italiana of Milan, will be in New York from March 16 to 20 to hear singers in the second talent search being conducted by American Opera Auditions, Inc.

The nation's steel industry, operating at the highest production rate so far this year, turned out 8,582,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings last month, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 10 -- President Urho K. Kekkonen said tonight in a nation-wide broadcast that Finland's relations with the Soviet Union constituted the cardinal issue of the country's foreign policy. He rejected Western advice on how the Government should conduct that policy.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- The British Government will politely reject Gen. Charles de Gaulle's proposal for regular consultations by France, the United States and Britain to increase the military effectiveness of the Atlantic alliance.
James R. Hoffa may be a hero to members of the Teamsters Union, but he is certainly building himself up as a major menace in the eyes of the general public -- and of the A. F. L. C. I. O. as well.
New York's nine major newspapers suspended publication yesterday because of labor troubles.
Every right-thinking, non- Scroogelike citizen of New York would doubtless like to see everyone happy at Christmas time. It is a joyful season, celebrating an important birthday.
Outside Julia Richman High School yesterday, a man gave away matches to advertise a new branch bank. Some school girls later said he wisecracked, "Burn down your school."
CAIRO, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Naguib Hilaly, last Premier of Egypt before the monarchy was destroyed by the 1952 revolution, died today at the age of 67.
"THE POWER AND THE GLORY" is well named. As acted on Wednesday evening, with Fritz Weaver in the leading part, it is the most engrossing and the noblest play the Phoenix has put on in recent years.
The proposal of James R. Hoffa to enroll New York City's 20,000 policemen in the Teamsters Union was condemned yesterday by Mayor Wagner and Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy.

A merger of the High School of Music and Art with the High School of Performing Arts was proposed yesterday. It was also suggested that the consolidated school be adjacent to The Lincoln Center For The Performing Arts.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Friday, Dec. 12 -- The United States told the General Assembly yesterday that a "continuing reign of terror" existed in Hungary, backed by Soviet troops.

PARIS, Dec. 11 -- Few public men in France have made such a triumphantly successful transfer from the Fourth Republic to the Fifth as Jacques Chaban-Delmas, who was elected speaker of the National Assembly Tuesday.
The political and military leaders of the North Atlantic alliance are meeting in Paris this week-end to consider their reply to the Soviet ultimatum on Berlin.
GENEVA, Dec. 11 -- The United States delegate to the conference on banning tests of nuclear weapons expressed "cautious optimism" today on the possibility of a formal agreement with the Soviet Union.

A low-pressure area that appeared to be driving heavy snow toward the metropolitan area yesterday shifted seaward late in the day. As a result the city may have been spared a three-to-six-inch fall that had been forecast.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- James P. Mitchell, the Secretary of Labor, said today that state, county and city government employes "deserve a better fate" than membership in the Teamsters' Union.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Senator Humphrey of Minnesota, an aspirant to the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1960 who is favored by Mrs. Roosevelt and other prominent leaders of the self-styled liberals of the party, unquestionably squeezed the maximum amount of personal publicity out of his long interview with Premier Khrushchev in the Kremlin.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The International Brotherhood of Teamsters and its president, James R. Hoffa, were told today that they must obey the orders of three court-appointed monitors and begin cleaning up the union.

Mayor Wagner invited the Rev. James A. Gusweller Thursday to City Hall for a talk about slum conditions on the West Side, where the minister has charged widespread bribery of building inspectors and other city employes.

FOR "J. B.," the title of Archibald MacLeish's new play at the ANTA Theatre, read "Everyman." Looking around at the wreckage and misery of the modern world, Mr. MacLeish has written a fresh and exalting morality that has great stature.
HAVANA, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The Cuban rebels announced today that Manuel Urrutia Lleo, their presidential appointee, had returned to Cuba from exile.
ROME, Dec. 11 -- Premier Amintore Fanfani's Cabinet suffered another stinging parliamentary defeat tonight.
MOSCOW, Dec. 11 -- The Soviet Union reaffirmed today its position that discussion of the unification of Germany without participation by the two German states was out of the question.
PARIS, Dec. 11 -- The French National Assembly ended its three-day inaugural session by demonstrating how it is beholden to Premier Charles de Gaulle.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Federal District Court orders were issued today to a state judge and five voter registrars who defied the United States Civil Rights Commission.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Secretary of State Dulles expects to leave Walter Reed Hospital tomorrow and to fly to Paris to head the United States delegation to the North Atlantic Council meeting.
GENEVA, Dec. 12 -- The United States, Britain and the Soviet Union agreed today on the structure of an organization to police a ban on tests of nuclear weapons.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Industrial production, hampered in October by strikes in the automobile industry, jumped three points on the Federal Reserve Board's index in November.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 12 -- The United Nations again rebuked the Soviet Union and Hungary today for their treatment of the Hungarian people since the anti-Communist revolt of 1956.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 12 -- Three of Alabama's voter registrars have resigned and reports persisted today that others might follow suit if pressure was put on them to register Negro applicants.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UPI) -- The Air Force abandoned today its plans for developing the Goose, a long-range ground-to-air decoy missile designed to confuse enemy air defense systems.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Secretary of State Dulles left Walter Reed Hospital today and flew toward Paris on a note of confidence that Allied unity and determination would frustrate Soviet threats to Berlin.
An attempt to settle the strike of truck drivers and other delivery men that has closed nine New York newspapers failed yesterday.

The state, like the city, is anxious to keep Robert Moses at work even though he reached the mandatory retirement age of 70 Dec. 18. Yesterday Governor Harriman and the State Commission on Pensions followed the Board of Estimate by taking legal action to make this possible.
JERSEY CITY, Dec. 12 -- The Erie Railroad ferry service from Chambers Street to Jersey City came to an end this evening in its ninety-eighth year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- In a farewell message to the inter-American economic conference, President Eisenhower expressed confidence today that "constructive measures" would be devised to help Latin America meet its economic problems.

Federal Judge Letts' "memorandum opinion" in the Teamsters' case is a clean-cut and courageous statement of what should be done with Provisional President Hoffa and his union -- both in the interest of the public and of the teamsters rank and file.

MIAMI, Dec. 12 -- Attorneys for the Teamsters Union were far from sure today that higher courts would even agree to review a Federal judge's decision giving three court-appointed monitors power to force a cleanup in the union.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Administration has decided to grant economic aid to Poland.
SANTA CRUZ DE TENERIFE, Canary Islands, Dec. 12 -- Mrs. Rosemary Mudie waved from a wind-tossed balloon here early today and shouted: "So long! See you in the West Indies or somewhere!"
Governor-elect Nelson A. Rockefeller announced yesterday that he would reappoint Francis A. McGarvey as Superintendent of the State Police.

Proximity and urgency are two of the elements that newspaper editors look for in the stories they consider of merit every day. It is these same elements that make the Neediest Cases a fund that deserves immediate consideration. One cannot read the cases without becoming aware of the proximity of the needy family or individual.

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- The Middle East kaleidoscope shifted again this week and the new pattern is tinted with red, Lebanon, only Arab state that had adhered to the Eisenhower Doctrine, announced it would no longer respect its terms. Thus Beirut changed from formal sympathy with the West to outright neutrality.

A Naval Academy proposal for a broader waiver of the rule against pre-college aid to athletes was defeated yesterday at the twenty-second annual meeting of the Eastern College Athletic Conference at the Hotel Manhattan.
A Federal judge lifted last night a temporary order restraining the Air Line Pilots Asssociation from striking against American Airlines, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Urban Renewal Administration announced today that it had set aside $4,000,000 for a West Side rehabilitation project in New York City. At the same time, the agency made a planning advance of $400,000 for the project.

MOSCOW, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Dr. Leon Orbeli, Soviet Physiologist, died yesterday, the Soviet press reported. His age was 77. He was a fifty-year veteran of military medicine and a close associate of Ivan Pavlov.
The public will have its first opportunity on Monday to buy voting stock of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, the world's largest food chain.
WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 12 -- Westchester's elaborate parkway-reconstruction plan died today.

The Soviets are now stepping up their "rocket diplomacy" of intimidation on widely scattered fronts. Such threats, more direct than the veiled warnings of atomic rocket bombardment hurled against Britain and France during the Suez crisis, have been issued by the official Soviet agency Tass in what it calls an "authorized statement" and by Premier Khrushchev in repeated interviews.
The Municipal Art Commission defended the Board of Education yesterday against Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa's charges of waste and extravagance in school design and construction.
PARIS, Dec. 12 -- The Government announced tonight the long-awaited start toward restoration of a normal civil administration in Algeria.

AS any mounted policeman knows, his horse is often the medium for striking up friendships. When Trooper Francis Simpson McGarvey clopped along the roads of Westchester forty years ago one such admirer of his steed was John D. Rockefeller Jr.

DON'T be misled by the title of Alec Coppel's play that opened at the Lyceum Friday evening. According to the office dictionary, any "Gazebo" is a summer house. "The Gazebo" in the title of Mr. Coppel's play refers to a graceful and airy little edifice in the rear of Jo Mielziner's inviting stage setting.
The head of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service will fly here from Washington today in an attempt to settle the deliverers' strike that has shut down nine New York newspapers.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- The Atlantic alliance's diplomatic high command gathered tonight to formulate a reply to the Soviet attempt at ousting the West from Berlin and to try to heal glaring breaches in Western unity.
ACCRA, Ghana, Dec. 13 -- The All-African Peoples' Conference ended today with an appeal for a trade and labor boycott of the white-ruled Union of South Africa.

Central heat and the storm sash have almost banished window frost, one of the most beautiful and fantastic of winter phenomena. It can still be found on the windows of a country cow barn or an unprotected attic window or, when the outside cold is deep enough, on a storm-sashed kitchen window in the suburbs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- By kind authority of Sam Feldman, the chief truck driver of the New York Newspaper and Mail Deliverers' Union, the chief Washington correspondent of The New York Times wishes to report that he has spotted a trend.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 13 -- Thomas L. Hickey, for many years a leader of the anti-racket forces in the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, was ousted tonight from his $20,000-a-year post as the union's general organizer in New York.

HAVANA, Dec. 13 -- The economic impact of the revolt led by Fidel Castro, which has been confined largely to the eastern half of Cuba since it began two years ago, is now being felt with considerable force in Havana.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The State Department appointed seven scientific embassy attaches today, thus resuming a program discontinued by the Eisenhower Administration in 1956.
PEIPING, Dec. 13 (Reuters) -- Chinese Communist newspapers have conceded mistakes in the running of the more than 26,000 communes set up in the last six months.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 13 -- Tough Khamba guerrillas are reported to have won local successes in their stubborn struggle against the Chinese Communist rulers of Tibet.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- President Eisenhower met for two hours this morning with members of his staff, preparing for Monday's presentation of his 1959 legislative plans to the Republican leaders of Congress.
LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Britain has begun to reconsider the role she must play in Western strategy and the weapons needed to fulfill this role.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sunday, Dec. 14 -- The General Assembly wound up its work for 1958 just before last midnight. Its final vote in effect rejected a plan seeking peace in Algeria.

Dr. Howard A. Rusk, speaking in Tokyo after a comprehensive tour of the Far East, states that he has observed a new appraisal of the value of human life in some of the "underdeveloped" countries. The old idea that life was cheap is being discarded, he says, and as a result there is an unusually fertile field for advancement in health and rehabilitation.
Shimon Peres, director general of Israel's Defense Ministry, declared last night that his nation's position on the international scene had improved.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Army put a monkey into space for fifteen minutes early today in the nose cone of a Jupiter missile.
ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 13 -- The Protestant Church is being considered strictly a "middle-class entity" when it should be finding ways to reach all people, a Methodist leader said today.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 13 -- The head of 5,383 striking mechanics at Eastern Air Lines threatened today to extend his union's picket lines to three other giants of the air transport industry.
Two leaders of the nine-day subway strike staged by motormen in December last year are to be dismissed by the Transit Authority.

AVENEL, N. J., Dec. 13 -- A father and two of his children were found dead in their trailer home early today, the victims of carbon monoxide poisoning. The man's wife and another child were taken to Perth Amboy General Hospital.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- A New program of United States aid to Yugoslavia, possibly totaling $137,000,000, will be announced in two or three weeks, officials said today.
PARIS, Dec. 13 -- To no-one's surprise, Premier Charles de Gaulle agreed today to be a candidate for President of France in the election Dec. 21.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Dec. 14.-- Improved relations between Cambodia and South Vietnam have been signalized by the release of twenty-two Vietnamese held by Cambodian authorities.
More than an inch of snow and day-long temperatures below freezing made most of the highways hazardous here yesterday and caused train delays of up to two hours.

Senator Hubert H. Humphrey said last night that he did not expect the Soviet Union would go to war over Berlin because of the unreliability of its satellites. But he said the American people must make up their mind that they were in a difficult situation.
Government taxing, spending and debt have reached new highs, Tax Foundation, Inc., reported today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- President Eisenhower will give Republican Congressional leaders a look at his legislative program tomorrow, but indications today were that some key sections were incomplete.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 12 -- The Communist party's performance in the Dec. 7 Venezuelan elections was far from spectacular despite a strong showing in this capital city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- After much internal debate, the Administration has decided to ask Congress for only $700,000,000 in new capital for the Development Loan Fund for the next fiscal year. This would hold the fund's operations at the present level.
LONDON, Dec. 14 -- The Soviet Union is a first-class naval power, second only to the United States, according to the 1958-59 edition of Jane's Fighting Ships, which was published here today.

DONIZETTI'S "Lucia di Lammermoor" received its first performance of the season last night at the Metropolitan Opera. The production, dating from 1942, does not get any fresher looking as the years pass, but it sounded charming, and that is what matters.

PARIS, Dec. 14 -- The indomitable John Foster Dulles left a hospital in order to fly here this week-end and inspect the condition of allied relationships. If what he discovers doesn't send him straight back to bed this will merely confirm the indestructibility of his physical and nervous systems.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 14 -- Henry Cabot Lodge said today that in view of the Soviet attitude it was "surprising" that the 1958 session of the General Assembly "did not actually do harm to the cause of world peace."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Premier Abdul Karim el-Kassem's Iraqi Nationalists appear to be ruling their country in uneasy partnership with the Communists after dealing a crippling blow to supporters of President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic.
Some of the conclusions reached at the now-ended All-African Conference at Accra seem sound and hopeful. Efforts to promote better understanding among peoples with common problems are praiseworthy.

Union printers voted overwhelmingly last night to tell publishers of the city's nine suspended daily newspapers that they were ready to go back to work. Mediators were still trying to settle a deliverers' strike.
New York City is a major center of white-collar work, the Department of City Planning reported yesterday.
At all masses yesterday, Roman Catholics renewed their pledge to shun objectionable motion pictures. They read in unison a promise to support the aims of the National Legion of Decency.
More than 400 clergymen in the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York were asked yesterday to report all instances of graft or corruption within their parish areas.
Insurgents swept into control last night of Local 808 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
PARIS, Dec. 14 -- The United States, Britain and France rejected Soviet proposals for the future of Berlin with an uncompromising "no" tonight.

The New York Giants were 2 minutes 7 seconds away from elimination in the National Football League when Pat Summerall booted the second longest, but most important field goal of his career yesterday at the Yankee Stadium. The ball, placed down by Charley Conerly, 49 yards away, split the uprights at 12:53 and accounted for the 3 points that enabled the Giants to gain a 13-10 victory over the Cleveland Browns.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The military services have been ordered to advise the Treasury daily of the amount of money they disburse.
ALBANY, Dec. 14 -- Controller Arthur Levitt, the only Democratic state official to survive the Rockefeller election landslide, announced today his legislative program for 1959.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 14 -- Eastern Air Lines announced tonight that it had reached agreement with machinist negotiators to end the strike that started Nov. 24.
RABAT, Morocco, Dec. 14 -- Alarming reports have reached here from the Rif Mountains of a potential rebellion.

AMONG his friends and critics Arthur Levitt is known as steady, serious and somewhat drab. Both the friends and critics are still debating the reasons for his surprising re-election as State Controller in face of the Rockefeller sweep on Nov. 4.
ALLENTOWN, Pa., Dec. 14 (AP) -- Six persons in a crowd drawn to the scene of a heavy gas main explosion were killed early today when a further explosion ripped apart a 120-year-old building here.

The Thirteenth U. N. General Assembly, which adjourned, like Cinderella, last Saturday night just before the stroke of midnight, did a lot of talking, though it did not accomplish much. Indeed, the Assembly cannot accomplish much in the way of action so long as the Communist minority refuses to accept decisions of the non-Communist majority.

The Rev. James A. Gusweller told Mayor Wagner yesterday that "almost every child on the block" could testify that policemen were taking bribes in the slum areas of his parish on Manhattan's West Side.

The "Committee of 21," made up of representatives of the American republics, has ended an important economic conference. The meeting was part of "Operation Panamerica." President Eisenhower stated the obvious in his message to the closing session when he said that "economic development of Latin America is of vital importance to the strength and well-being of the whole of the free world."
PARIS, Dec. 15 -- The members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization appeared tonight to be united in resistance to the Soviet threat to Berlin -- and on very little else.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Senate Republicans who identify themselves as "progressives" have three basic reasons for the movement they organized today to take over the minority leadership of the Senate in the Eighty-sixth Congress.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- A challenge to the conservative leadership of the Republican party in the Senate was issued today at the Capitol.
City officials were puzzled yesterday when no bids were made for Washington Market at an auction in the Biltmore Hotel.

ROME, Dec. 15 -- In a secret consistory held in the Vatican this morning, the Pope elevated twenty-three prelates to the rank of Cardinal and increased the membership of the Sacred College to seventy-four.

We have often lamented the fact that not enough use is made of the skills and experience of our senior statesmen when they leave public office. Some important opportunities for public service have been lost. There is now a felicitous exception to be noted.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Republican leaders in Congress reported after a White House conference today that President Eisenhower hoped to submit a balanced budget for the fiscal year 1960, starting next July 1.

WARSAW, Dec. 15 -- Poland and East Germany charged today that the West German Government was trying to dominate Europe. The two Communist regimes issued a communique declaring that the Government of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer was the principal threat to peace in Europe.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 15 -- Mudballs and eggs and a sizable rock were hurled by howling mobs of young Iraqis today at William M. Rountree, Assistant Secretary of State. None of the missiles hit him.

Justice Justine Wise Polier of the Children's Court said yesterday that pupils who attended two junior high schools in Harlem were receiving "inferior educational opportunities * * * by reason of racial discrimination."

In a situation reminiscent of the days when Hitler hurled his ultimatums at free nations, the United States, Britain and France have jointly and categorically rejected the Soviets' ultimatum to get out of Berlin.

WASHINGTON, Dee. 15 -- The Supreme Court held today that a Memphis Negro was entitled to bring a Federal court suit against bus segregation in that city even though he was not a regular rider of the buses.
No progress was reported yesterday in efforts to settle the delivery men's strike that has shut down nine New York newspapers. The strike began last Tuesday night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Supreme Court opened the way today for more judicial reviews of actions by the National Labor Relations Board. It held that board deci sions on the make-up of a collective bargaining unit could be scrutinized by Federal District courts.
GENEVA, Dec. 15 -- The United States sketched in the details today of an internationally staffed organization to police a ban on nuclear testing.
PARIS, Tuesday, Dec. 16 -- A large meeting of European officials of cabinet rank failed early today to break the deadlock between the six nations of the European common market and their neighbors.

Tax abatement and subsidies are not all the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad is seeking to keep its commuter lines operating into Grand Central Terminal. George Alpert, president of the New Haven, indicated yesterday that another fare increase might be in store for the 40,000 Connecticut and Westchester commuters who use the line.
Thomas Mallee, 70-year-old Republican leader on the upper East Side, was nominated last night to replace the late Thomas J. Curran on the New York City Board of Elections.

MANILA, Dec. 15 (UPI) -- Pascual Perez of Argentina put on a masterful boxing exhibition tonight and retained his world flyweight title by scoring a unanimous fifteen-round decision over Dommy Ursua of the Philippines.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 15 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold told the Security Council today that he would try his hand at resolving the latest border troubles between Israel and the United Arab Republic.
ALBANY, Dec. 15 -- Benjamin F. Feinberg is retiring tomorrow as chairman of the Public Service Commission. He is ill and he asked Governor Harriman to relieve him of his duties.

HONG KONG, Dec. 16 -- Foreign Minister Chen Yi announced today that the Central Committee of the Communist party decided Dec. 10 to approve a suggestion by Mao Tse-tung that he give up his job as Chairman of the Chinese People's Republic.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The Pennsylvania Power and Light Company dropped plans today to construct an advanced type of atomic power plant.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 16 -- A suit to enjoin the Ossining Board of Education from permitting another Yuletide display of the Nativity scene on the high school grounds was dismissed today. State Supreme Court Justice Elbert T. Gallagher disagreed with the contention of twenty-eight plaintiffs that the creche on public property violated state and Federal constitutional separation of church and state.

PARIS, Dec. 16 -- When one compares this NATO decathlon with previous gatherings of Allied ministers two novel facts stand out. The first is that France has a policy conceived more in nationalist than in alliance terms.
WHAT Shakespeare set down in "Hamlet," the Old Vic troupe speaks in the production that opened at the Broadway Theatre Tuesday evening.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Andrew Knutson testified today that he had been duped into writing the "Coya come home" letter to his wife, Representative Coya Knutson, Democrat of Minnesota, as the Congressional campaigns opened last spring.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 16 -- The University of Pittsburgh received a gift of $12,000,000 today for the advancement of the humanities, natural sciences and the social sciences. It was presented by the A. W. Mellon Educational and Charitable Trust.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -Cotton, rice and tobacco growers voted overwhelmingly in a national referendum to continue strict controls in the face of the Administration's new drive to "free" them from Government restrictions.
MOSCOW, Dec. 16 -- The Soviet people read today details of the agricultural failures, official incompetence and government chicanery in the last years of Stalin's rule.
RABAT, Morocco, Dec. 16 -King Mohamed V called on Socialistminded Abdallah Ibrahim today to form a widely representative government. Its major task will be to organize Morocco's first elections.
MADRID, Dec. 16 -- The Government has obtained a secret list of 1,000 Spanish citizens with illegal foreign currency deposits in Swiss banks.
Two religious schools in Brooklyn were ordered closed yesterday in the Fire Department's drive against fire hazards in the city's schools.
Operators of bingo games here will have to be fingerprinted before they can receive licenses.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- President Eisenhower said today he felt that American youths should be required to attend their "local free system" of schools for at least one or two years beyond high school.
George F. Kennan, former United States Ambassador to Moscow, has asserted that political compromise in Europe between the Soviet Union and the Western powers is still possible.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Several unidentified guests who did what "just isn't done" at the White House last week had Washington buzzing today.
PARIS, Dec. 16 -- The fifteen Atlantic powers tonight rebuffed Soviet claims on Berlin but expressed willingness to discuss the unity of Germany and European security with the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Powerful domestic opposition to Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's foreign policy is still plaguing him, according to diplomatic sources here.
Striking delivery men last night voted down a proposal that might have ended the week-old strike that has closed nine city newspapers.
In this month, more than any other, New York by night is a City of Light. Skyscraper window patterns are lower and brighter stars against the heavens.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -Representative Coya Knutson says two of her dearest dreams have come true.

The United States can afford to spend whatever is required for defense and foreign aid, "but we cannot afford to spend it if we are unable to find the means for paying for these expenditures in any other way than by printing paper money."

Having established a united front in the North Atlantic Council against the Soviet ultimatum on Berlin, the leaders of Western Europe have also had the good sense to avert a trade war that threatened to split free Europe.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 16 -- Assistant Secretary of State William M. Rountree met Iraq's Premier, Abdul Karim el-Kassem, for more than an hour today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -The National Agricultural Advisory Commission recommended today a one-year extension for the disposal of surplus farm commodities abroad. It also urged that $1,500,000,000 more in surplus products be authorized for foreign shipment.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- President Eisenhower urged his party's divided Senate ranks today to compromise and avoid a split over Senate leadership.
Longshoremen and employers on the New York waterfront reached a temporary agreement yesterday in the controversy over using huge containers for handling ocean freight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Jerome Benton Caplin, an executive of Capp Enterprises, Inc., testified at a Senate hearing today that he had been a Communist party organizer before World War II. He said that he quit the party before going into the Army in 1942.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, largest corporate enterprise in the world, plans to split its stock three-for-one and to increase its dividend by 10 per cent. It proposes to pay $3.30 a year a share on the new "split" stock. That is the equivalent of $9.90 a year on the existing shares.

BONN, Germany, Dev. 17 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer believes the West should await the result of the Soviet Communist party's congress next month to see whether a "useful conference" can be held with the Russians on German problems.

The New York Central Railroad received permission from the Public Service Commission yesterday for a 5 per cent increase in the price of a twenty-six trip ticket. It is effective Jan. 1. Monthly commutation rates were not affected.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Personal income rose sharply in November to a record level, the Commerce Department reported today.

The Guaranty Trust Company of New York and J. P. Morgan Co. Inc., two of New York's few remaining old-line "wholesale" banks, announced yesterday plans to merge through an exchange of shares. The new institution, to be known as the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York would rank as the third largest bank in the city and fourth largest in the country.
PEIPING, Dec. 17 (Reuters) -- Communist China announced officially today the decision of Mao Tse-tung to retire as Chairman of the Republic and to direct policy as Communist party leader.

Having rejected the Soviet ultimatum on Berlin with an offer of new negotiations on Germany, security and disarmament, the North Atlantic Alliance Council has pledged itself to speed the build-up of the one instrument likely to persuade Moscow that negotiation is the better alternative to force.
James A. Lundy, a former Borough President of Queens, was chosen yesterday by Governor-elect Nelson A. Rockefeller to replace Benjamin F. Feinberg as chairman of the Public Service Commission.
PARIS, Dec. 17 -- The military commanders of the Atlantic alliance demanded today that they be given more military muscle and the political leaders promised to try to supply it.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The Administration has ordered a substantial budget reduction in the program to develop a nuclear-powered airplane.

Assistant Secretary of State William Rountree has had an uncomfortable few days in Baghdad. Iraqi mobs greeted him on his arrival with shouts and stones, and he ended up leaving yesterday, a day sooner than expected.
GENEVA, Dec. 17 -- A seven-nation commission to direct the policing of a prohibition of tests of nuclear weapons was agreed upon today by the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- The Sovilet Union has put into operation service a new six-jet intercontinental bomber that is twice as fast as the speed of sound, the 1958-59 edition of 'Jane's All the World's Aircraft" reported today.
The delivery strike that has closed nine New York newspapers enters its ninth day today.
Magistrate Evelyn Richman yesterday ordered the head of a corporation owning an apartment house at 380 Riverside Drive to clean up 296 pending violations or go to jail.
Gov.-elect Nelson A. Rockefeller and Republican legislative leaders promised last night to obtain "effective action" on court reform at the forthcoming session of the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Those Senate Republicans whose minimum demand is for the top place in the minority leadership made their bid without any real hope of active support from the President. But, though they assumed that he, in the interest of party unity, would prefer a peaceful adjustment of the issue, they also hoped he would refrain from public advocacy of this.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- A special House committee, voting 3 to 2, today recommended that Representative-elect Dale Alford of Arkansas be barred from taking his seat pending further investigation of charges that fraud and other irregularities had figured in his election.

MOSCOW, Dec. 17 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's agricultural reforms continue apace and he has promised that they will mean not only more food but greater Soviet power and therefore success for communism.
MANILA, Dec. 17 -- More than 100 Roman Catholic prelates stationed in Asia closed their first Far East conference here today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration ordered development today of a rocket engine capable of launching space vehicles weighing several tons.

It has been suggested, for example, that all is not well with the "commune" program. It could be a mistake, however, to attribute too much significance to the retirement of Mao Tse-tung as titular chief of state until more facts are at our disposal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The United States today hurled an 8,500-pound Atlas ballistic missile into orbit. The missile, two and a half times as heavy as the payload of the Soviet Union's Sputnik III, became the fifth artificial satellite this country has put into orbit.

Court reform in New York State has received its greatest lift so far in the joint pledge of Governor-elect Rockefeller and the Republican leaders in both Senate and Assembly that the reorganization of the courts will be given "highest priority" in the coming session of the Legislature.
Final city action on the controversial $330,000,000 Narrows Bridge was deferred again last night by the Board of Estimate.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The Navy tonight abandoned the development of missile of 1,000-mile range just as it was to be declared combat ready.

ROME, Dec. 18 -- The rites for the elevation of twenty-three new Cardinals were brought to a close this morning with a public and a secret consistory. The Sacred College of Cardinals now has seventy-four members.
Christmas came a week early yesterday for eighty-one judges and five official coaurt referees of New York City.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- By a vote of 3 to 2, a House special committee about to expire has recommended a drastic action to a committee which will not exist until the incoming House selects it. Because of the nature of this vote a precedent was created, and there will be another if a majority of the next House accepts the recommendation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The United States granted permission today to Deputy Premier Anastas I. Mikoyan of the Soviet Union to come to Washington.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Scientists are now "almost certain" that man is physically capable of space flight.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 18 -- The chairman of a special legislative investigating committee declared today that it had "definitely proved that there was Communist influence" behind the Little Rock school desegregation dispute.

Nelson A. Rockefeller and the union leaders who unsuccessfully opposed his election as Governor have exchanged pledges of cooperation in promoting the state's economic growth. He told fifty-fove top unionists last night that he hoped they would forget their campaign differences and help him "do a job for all the people of the state."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Republican liberals were dealt a smashing blow today as Senator Thruston B. Morton threw his support to Everett M. Dirksen for the minority leadership of the senate.
GENEVA, Dec. 18 -- The East-West conference on preventing surprise attack adjourned in a deadlock today after thirty sessions in nearly six weeks.

MOSCOW, Friday, Dec. 19 -- Former Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin has admitted all the charges brought against him by his former traveling companion and fellow member of the "collective" leadership, Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Until today Senator Thruston Ballard Morton had been one of those inconspicuous but personable men who compose the quiet bloc in an institution too often maligned as the shrine of the winds.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board landed in the middle of two airline labor disputes today by stating an old fact.

PEIPING, Dec. 18 -- The Chinese Communist have slowed their dash toward communal living. A party resolution published here tonight calls a temporary halt to plans to set up large-scale communes in the big cities.

Gov. Orval E. Faubus of Arkansas has been campaigning for something, one hardly knows what, outside his home state. Yesterday he told a cheering audience in Monroe, La., that Democratic friends had urged him to "integrate in Little Rock, dangling before [him] the Vice Presidency."
CHICAGO, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The Rock Island Lines moved today to stimulate its sleeping-car and parlor-car passenger business by announcing a 28 per cent cut in round-trip fares, effective Jan. 25.
PARIS, Dec. 18 -- The Atlantic allies rallied strongly to the defense of Berlin but failed to resolve grave inter-Allied differences in six days of diplomatic conferences ending today.
The strike that has closed nine New York newspapers since Dec. 11 apparently will continue over the week-end at least.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Pee Wee Reese was named today to the coaching staff of the Los Angeles Dodgers, apparently closing a brilliant playing career in major league baseball.
NEWARK, Dec. 18 -- Mayor Leo P. Carlin vetoed today increases in salaries and expense allowances that the City Council had voted itself shortly after midnight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Bitterness between the liberal and conservative wings of the Republican party began to boil to the surface today in the spreading battle for the minority leadership of the Senate.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Scientists prepared further communications experiments today as the four-ton, eighty-five foot Atlas missile satellite tumbled end over end around the earth.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Foreign Agricultural Service reported today that world production of farm products would set a record during the year ending next July 1.
The president of the corporation that owns the apartment building where a boy was killed recently in an elevator accident was sentenced yesterday to thirty days in jail for violating housing laws.
DETROIT, Dec. 19 -- The Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Workers reached an agreement today establishing procedures for prompt settlement of future disputes over production standards
MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 19 -- Vincent (Jimmy) Squillante, garbage racketeer, was found guilty of extortion by a jury in Nassau County Court today.
KINGSTON, N. Y., Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Air Force today unveiled for newsmen the giant electronic brain it is putting into use to help direct the nation's air defense forces.
Governor - elect Nelson A. Rockefeller announced yesterday the selection of two more agency heads for his incoming Republican Administration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The International Monetary Fund announced today that Britain would repay $200,000,000 of her emergency $561,000,000 Suez loan by the end of April and the rest in monthly installments in 1960 and 1961.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The United States' intrument-filled Atlas missile satellite transmitted the voice of President Eisenhower from outer space today in a Christmas broadcast to all the world.

ROSALYN TURECK, American pianist, conducted the New York Philharmonic yesterday afternoon, and thereby made news. No woman, according to available records, has conducted this venerable orchestra in any of its regular programs.
Another attempt to make the world a safer place to live in has come to naught with the indefinite adjournment of the Geneva East-West conference on prevention of surprise attacks.
Nine newspaper unions agreed yesterday to hear an appeal from the striking delivery union for support in the walkout that has closed nine New York papers since Dec. 11.
BOSTON, Dec. 19 -- Bernard Goldfine and his secretary, Miss Mildred Paperman, were found guilty of criminal contempt in United States District Court today.
WARSAW, Dec. 19 -- Anastas I. Mikoyan ended his visit to Poland today and left behind him a promise and a mountain of speculation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The huge new Atlas communications satellite has raised as never before the question of what laws of man should govern space.
MOSCOW, Dec. 19 -- The Communist party's Central Committee hailed Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's agricultural policies today as an "example" for other Communist nations.

LUIGI DALLAPICCOLA, an uncompromising and original composer, has written his dramatic version of the story of Job. The "sacred drama," as he calls it, is entitled, not unexpectedly "Job," and it had its first United States performance at the Juilliard Concert Hall last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The United States and the International Monetary Fund are nearing agreement on a massive program of financial assistance for Argentina, understood to total more than $300,000,000.
GENEVA, Dec. 19 -- The conference on prohibiting nuclear tests adjourned today for two weeks, leaving most of its fundamental problems unresolved.
PERTH, Australia, Saturday, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Ham Richardson and Alex Olmedo scored singles victories against Italy and put the United States ahead, 2-0, in the Davis Cup interzone final today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Senate rackets investigating committee has voted unanimously to cite William Presser, Teamsters' boss in Ohio, for contempt of Congress.

PARIS, Dec. 19 -- One salient fact appears to have emerged from the past week's NATO conference. This is a growing acknowledgment that the alliance, as presently constituted, must be changed or at least enlarged in scope.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Goldfine appeared in United States District Court before Judge John J. Sirica, who set March 16 for the opening of trial after Goldfine pleaded not guilty to the contempt of Congress indictment.
TO THE 40,000 New York families who depend on farming for a living, no appointment in a state administration is awaited more anxiously than that of the Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets.

Symbolizing another giant stride into the space age, an American Atlas, a guided missile the size of a Pullman car and weighing four and a half tons, is now whirling around the earth as a bright star in the sky, bringing new assurance to the free world an opening new vistas of space exploration.

PARIS, Dec. 20 -- Foreign Minister Evangelos Averoff-Tossizza of Greece said today that a new Greek-Turkish-British approach to a Cyprus settlement envisaged a form of independence for the disputed British Crown colony.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 20 (Reuters) -- The Indonesian Government has put a blanket ban on all travel out of Sumatra, airline and shipping authorities said here today, amid reports of heavy fighting on the island.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 20 -- The Israeli Air Force reported that it shot down a United Arab Republic MIG-17 today over the Negev desert in southern Israel.
BAYONNE, N. J., Dec. 20 -- Two Staten Island youths were linked today to the hold-up killing of Assistant Municipal Attorney Stephen Sladowski here on Thursday night.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 20 -- Oil companies here will pay at least 60 per cent of their profits to the Venezuelan Government, according to a tax reform program, announced today.

PERTH, Australia, Dec. 20 (UPI) -- America set up a Davis Cup challenge round meeting with Australia for the fifteenth straight time today when Alex Olmedo and Ham Richardson defeated Italy's Orlando Sirola and Nicola Pietrangeli in doubles, 7 -- 9, 6 -- 4, 13 -- 11, 7 -- 5.

The Paris meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization brought out some differences of opinion, particularly between the de Gaulle Government on the one hand and the British and American Governments on the other hand.

By the calendar, we call it the arrival of winter. Actually, it is the occasion of the winter solstice, and it comes at 3:40 A. M. tomorrow. To all practical purposes, as we here in the Northeast and throughout much of the rest of the nation can testify, winter has been with us since Thanksgiving, and the calendar hasn't a thing to do with it.
This is the season for it, and the Humane Society of New York had a Christmas party yesterday -- one for dogs and cats.
VIENNA, Dec. 20 -- A 226-mile pipeline connecting Rumania's natural gas fields with Hungary's industrial centers was put into operation Thursday.

France will elect a new President today and nothing is more certain that that his name will be Charles de Gaulle. The complicated procedure established in the 1958 Constitution is being followed with solemnity, but for this time General de Gaulle might just as well be waiting for an American Electoral College formality.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The total vote in the Nov. 4 elections was 47,875,315, a mid-term record. Democrats outpolled Republicans in the House races by 6,051,004 to underscore their Congressional sweep.
Two Italian-American labor groups were reunited yesterday after fifteen years of separation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower helped open the $65,000,000 March of Dimes drive for 1959 today by greeting three of the National Foundation's poster children.
PARIS, Dec. 20 -- A drastic revision of France's policy on European integration has been demanded by the foreign affairs committee of the nation's dominant new Gaullist political party.
Eight newspaper unions rejected requests yesterday for financial aid and active participation in the deliverers' strike that has closed nine New York papers since Dec. 11.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- This year's communique from the North Atlantic Treaty Council is all fancy wrapping and no substance, like a bogus Christmas present.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The Western powers are prepared to offer the Soviet Union guarantees against German aggression in return for the reunification of Germany by free elections, officials said today.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 20 -- Witnesses at a three-day legislative hearing here this week sought to picture Little Rock's desegregation controversy as part of a Communist plot to foment racial unrest throughout the South.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey provided further evidence today that he intended to interest himself increasingly in foreign and defense policy in the next session of Congress.
The city itself is largely to blame for the spreading of slums, Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs charged yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Outlays by the Government have played an important role in reversing the recent economic slump.
UNION CITY, N. J., Dec 20 -- A general-alarm fire roared through three five-story tenement houses this evening and routed more than 100 persons in thirty families.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 20 -- Recent travelers from Iraq said today that virtual anarchy had prevailed in the oil port of Basra for six hours Dec. 9, when the Revolutionary Government in Baghdad announced the discovery and suppression of a plot to overthrow it.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower approved a new design today for the reverse of the Lincoln penny.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The United States scored additional space communications advances today with its orbiting Atlas missile satellite.
American Airlines, the country's largest air passenger carrier, was shut down yesterday by a strike of 1,500 pilots.

One thing we can be sure of about the visit the United States is to have next month from Soviet Deputy Premier Anastas Mikoyan is that it was canceived and arronged before our new four-and-a-half-ton Atlas missile tipped the balance as it took the air at Cape Canaveral. Mr. Mikoyan said, in his breezy, informal way that he would like to come here to talk with Ambassador Menshikov.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The House Committee on Astronautics and Space Exploration warned today that the nations of the world could be obliterated by an accidental war unless immediate steps were taken to establish international regulations for space launchings.
There is no doubt that "added taxes" will be needed to give the city a balanced expense budget for the fiscal year starting July 1, Mayor Wagner declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The Atlas missile satellite sent back simultaneously from outer space today seven radio-teletypewriter transmissions of President Eisenhower's Christmas message to the world.
SWARTHMORE, Pa., Dec. 21 (AP) -- Thirty-two men, including Peter Dawkins, All America football player of the United States Military Academy, today were named recipients of Rhodes Scholarships.

PARIS, Dec. 21 -- When NATO was first created its attentions focused directly on the Soviet bloc in Europe It had no direct connection with the Middle East until Turkey was admitted to membership in early 1952.

An imaginative attack, backed by a solid defense, led the New York Giants to a 10 -- 0 victory over the Cleveland Browns and the Eastern Conference championship of the National Football League yesterday at Yankee Stadium. By taking the play-off to break the regular-season tie, the Giants qualified to meet the Baltimore Colts for the league title next Sunday at the Stadium.
Mediation sessions on the deliverers' strike, which has tied up the city's nine major newspapers will resume today at 2 P. M. This will be the first joint meeting of both sides since last Tuesday.
PARIS, Dec. 21 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle was overwhelmingly elected today as the first President of France's Fifth Republic.
PARIS, Dec. 21 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle has assured the new civilian chief in Algeria that he is the undisputed boss there.
Strikes on two of the country's biggest air lines caused thousands of Christmas travelers to change their holiday plans yesterday.
NAHA, Okinawa, Dec. 15 -- Leftist leadership, which a year ago seemed to be making great headway, now appears to have been thoroughly repudiated by the 831,000 people of the Ryukyu Islands.
In prayer, song and meditation, many churches of New York began the joyful celebration of the Christmas season yesterday.

The new waterfront automation agreement is a good thing for the employers, the longshoremen, the port arbitrator and the public. At least for the time being, the shipping companies can continue to use the big cargo containers without interference from the International Longshoremen's Association -- with savings on pilferage and damage; there will be no cut in the size of the gangs.
Governor-elect Nelson A. Rockefeller served notice yesterday that "stringent economy" would be the watchword in the preparation of the budget that is to go to the Legislature about Feb. 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- A major factor behind the Administration's attempt to present a balanced budget to Congress is the shock at doubts expressed in foreign financial communities about the future stability of the dollar.

Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that he would go to Chicago Jan. 13 to join the Mayors of other large cities in discussing with railroad officials the problem of subsidizing their deficit-ridden commuter operations.
Richard C. Corden, one of the real spokesmen of Americans who decided to go to Red China in the Korean prisoner exchange, has come out of "paradise" . He says it was "too tough".
PAUL DELOUVRIER, who looks like a movie actor rather than the intellectual and economist he is, has suddenly had a harsh spotlight trained on him.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- A major new Government Statistical series revealed today that the American economy had been stagnant for a full year before the 1957-58 recession.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The Supreme Court may be the chilly embodiment of blind justice but it can occasionally overlook human error.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- William M. Rountree, Assistant Secretary for Near Eastern and South Asian affairs, whose car was pelted with mudballs, stones and eggs in Baghdad last week, returned from his Middle Eastern tour today.
One of New York's landmarks, Grace Protestant Episcopal Church at Broadway and Tenth Street, yesterday observed its 150th anniversary.
The Transit Authority announced yesterday that its "automated" IND subway entrance at Jackson Heights, Queens, was fully equipped.
TO judge by "Whoop-Up," which opened at the Sam S. Shubert last evening, the American Indian has the temperament of a Broadway reveler.
HAVANA, Dec. 22 -- Rebel forces reported today that they had captured the village of Sevilla and tightened their ring around Santiago de Cuba, the island's second largest city.
Federal and state road agencies told the Board of Estimate yesterday that a twelve-lane plan was the only one they could accept for the Brooklyn approach to the Narrows Bridge, on Seventh Avenue.

MOSCOW, Dec. 22 -- A 1959 Soviet budget emphasizing economic development and calling for increased expenditures on scientific research and social welfare was presented today by Finance Minister Arseny G. Zverev.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- United States oil experts expressed concern today that Venezuela's sudden decision to take a bigger slice of oil revenues might have global repercussions.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 22 -- The United States and Yugoslavia signed an agreement today for the sale of about $95,000,000 worth of American surplus agricultural commodities for domestic dinar funds.
ALBANY, Dec. 22 -- Passenger car tolls on the Thruway will go up 25 per cent beginning Jan. 1, and the cost of an annual permit will be doubled.
BOSTON, Dec. 22 -- Bernard Goldfine, Boston industrialist, was sentenced to three months in jail today for criminal contempt of a Federal court in a tax case.
Harry S. Truman said yesterday that he was "only kidding" when he said recently that he would like to be appointed to his old seat in the United States Senate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The House Committee on Unamerican Activities recommended today the contempt citations of two men who had refused to appear as witnesses in response to subpoenas, Representative Francis E. Walter, Democrat, of Pennsylvania, announced.
Governor-elect Nelson A. Rockefeller in a meeting yesterday with Republican legislative leaders and advisers studied the possibility of recommending new taxes to help balance the next state budget.

The bill which has been drafted by Governor Harriman's Committee on Improper Labor and Management Practices, for submission to the Legislature next year, should put an end to the violent political controversy which has bedeviled state government action on labor union abuses.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 22 -- This nation's twelve-day cabinet crisis ended today with the appointment of Prof. Louis Beal, a Roman Catholic, as Premier. Professor Beal, 56 years old, is a member of the Catholic party, a former Premier and a former Minister of Home Affairs.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- This was Christmas party day at the White House.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The new "talking satellite" has demonstrated the feasibility of a revolutionary communications system in which three satellites could handle all global messages of the United States Government.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 22 (AP) -- Any alumni rumblings that might have been heard against Terry Brennan were quieted today by the appointment of Joe Kuharich as Notre Dame's head football coach.
CAIRO, Dec. 22 -- The Soviet Union and the United Arab Republic signed an agreement today for Soviet aid in the construction of five airports and a number of industrial installations in Egypt.
Negotiations to settle the newspaper strike that began Dec. 9 were resumed yesterday for the first time since Dec. 16.

BOSTON, Dec. 22 -- One of the most prized possessions of Judge Charles Edward Wyzanski Jr. is a letter from Oliver Wendell Holmes, written in 1927. A passage has been inscribed on the Wyzanski book plate.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 22 -- A group of West German companies is considering a proposal to participate in the construction of the Aswan High Dam on the Nile, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- If James S. Milloy were not a publishing genius he never would have attained his present eminence in the field as a high executive of the Cowles Publications. But precisely because of his professional acumen the holiday season of 1958 is destined perhaps to take a modest place in the category of literature procduced at Christmas that is forever led by Charles Dickens' tale of Scrooge and Tiny Tim.
The much-traveled air lane between New York and Washington was hard hit yesterday by the grounding of the country's two biggest air lines.
Four men, two of them armed and all four working as a smoothly coordinated team, robbed a Brooklyn savings bank of $72,600 in cash yesterday morning.

Charles de Gaulle has now cemented his victory in a landslide election that has made him President of France. For the next seven years, beginning Jan. 8, he will rule the Fifth French Republic under his own tailor-made Constitution that ends the "rule by Assembly" in favor of a strong Executive and for that purpose invests him with greater Presidential powers than France has known since the days of the last Napoleon.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- President Eisenhower said today that he would send to Congress a balanced budget "in the general area of $77,000,000,000."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Conservative Democrats and Republicans joined today in welcoming President Eisenhower's announcement that he would present a balanced budget to Congress in January.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UPI) -- Harry L. Martin, information director of the American Red Cross and former president of the American Newspaper Guild, died last night of a heart attack at a hospital in Arlington, Va.
Former President Harry S. Truman walked twenty-seven blocks in below-freezing weather yesterday to catch up on the news.

Two weeks ago, at a meeting of Republican leaders and Cabinet members at the White House, President Eisenhower announced that he would propose "as close to a balanced budget as possible for fiscal 1960" (the fiscal year that starts July 1 next).
The chairman of the National Mediation Board put forward yesterday a proposal for a pre-Christmas settlement of the American Airlines strike.

MARTIN PAUL CATHERWOOD, named yesterday as State Industrial Commissioner for the Rockefeller Administration, is the product of an Indiana farm who has spent most of his adult life knee-deep in the industrial and labor problems of the big city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The United States Consumer Price Index rose again in November after a three-month breather. The increase -- two tenths of one per cent -- brought the index back to the peak established last July.
Governor-elect Nelson A. Rockefeller announced yesterday the appointment of a State Industrial Commissioner and a Commissioner of Standards and Purchases to take office with him Jan. 1.
A fire captain who resigned three years ago after a trial on charges of taking a Christmas gift was promoted yesterday to battalion chief.
The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that wiretap evidence may be used in New York State courts. Such evidence may not be used in Federal courts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The State Department said today that it had a good deal of evidence of unrest in mainland China but not of anything that threatened to upset the authority of the Communist regime.

The Fire Department announced yesterday that it had completed the inspection of all 2,004 public, private, parochial and nursery schools in the city. All or part of thirteen schools were still closed.
PARIS, Dec. 23 -- Christmas is not supposed to be a frightening occasion. Nevertheless, the implications of this missile-dominated holiday are cheerless in the grim extreme. Consider.
MADRID, Dec. 23 -- The Spanish Government has published a new law permitting foreign companies to seek oil on Spanish territory and exploit what they produce on a fifty-fifty basis.
Progress was reported in efforts to settle the newspaper strike last night as mediation sessions were adjourned until this morning.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 23 -- President Chiang Kai-shek said today that he would not seek a third term when his present term expires in May, 1960.
WASHINGTON, Dee. 23 -- The United States intends to continue to launch satellites without seeking the consent of other nations and without necessarily giving advance notice.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 23 -- Marshal Tito arrived here today and denounced interference in any country's internal affairs.

WHAT is good enough for Greenwich Village is good enough for West Forty-fifth Street. Especially in the case of Betty Comden and Adolph Green, who opened in "A Party" at the John Golden Theatre last evening.

The city plans to spend $603,065,395 for new schools, fire houses, libraries, hospitals and other public improvements in 1959. This will be $11,056,715 less than was provided in the 1958 capital budget.
MOSCOW, Dec. 23 -- The Soviet Union issued another call to the Western powers tonight to meet "around one table" to discuss the security of Europe.
David A. Brown of Los Angeles, who had raised millions of dollars for Jewish, Chinese and other charitable causes, died Monday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a short illness. He was 83 years old.
CAIRO, Dec. 23 -- For the first time, President Gamal Abdel Nasser, publicly accused the Communists in Syria today of working against Egyptian-Syrian unity and Arab nationalism.

President Nasser of the United Arab Republic has launched himself in a new role. At a "victory celebration" to mark the second anniversary of the British and French withdrawals from Suez induced by the United Nations, he presented himself as champion of Arab nationalism not only against the "imperialists" but also the Communists.
The Railway Express Agency, Inc., may have to go out of business a year from now.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The last-place Philadelphia Phillies continued their rebuilding process today, acquiring one of the top second basemen in the minor leagues for Rip Repulski, an outfielder, and two rookie pitchers.

ROME, Dec. 23 -- In a Christmas message broadcast to the world today, Pope John XXIII urged all Christians to unite against the threat of atheism and materialism from the far side of the Iron Curtain.

The Board of Estimate will hold a special meeting at 2:30 P. M. next Tuesday to take final action on the controversial Seventh Avenue approach in Brooklyn to the proposed $330,000,000 Narrows Bridge to Staten Island.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- In response to West German inquiries, the State Department has quietly encouraged German concerns to participate in the construction of the Aswan High Dam in Egypt.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Pentagon officials asserted today that the Atlas intercontinental ballistic missile had achieved the status of an effective military weapon with a range of more than 6,000 miles.
The once a year when Christmas comes is here at last. Although dimmed somewhat by a news blackout in New York City and by airline strikes, it is being celebrated with festivity and solemnity.
Continuing progress was reported yesterday in mediation sessions to settle the newspaper delivery strike.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The Democrats who are protesting the President's Christmas gift to the people of a fiscal '60 budget at least statistically in balance are united only in that they have protested. Some denounce it as unsound reckoning of prospective revenue, but these divide on whether the estimate was deliberately falsified for a political motive.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Dec. 24 -- The armistice barriers that divide Jerusalem were removed again today to let Israel's Christians cross into Jordan for Christmas.

On this day blessed by generosity, the unselfish remembrance of others, we traditionally thank our readers for their gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. These thans are doubly warm, for they are intended to convey also the gratitude of the families helped, who have no way except in their prayers, perhaps, to communicate with those who acted thoughtfully in the spirit of the Christmas season.

The observance of Christmas in New York City a hundred years ago reminds us that the more it changes the more it is the same. The New York Times file shows that "the city was all alive'" with preparations and "generally wore an air of jollity."
CLEVELAND, Dec. 24 (UPI) -- Paul Brown signed a new contract with the Cleveland Browns today, insuring his job through the 1968 National Football League season.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The United States showed no interest today in a Soviet suggestion for a conference on European security that would exclude the question of Germany's unification.
PARIS, Dec. 24 -- Reports that devaluation of the franc was imminent gained credence today.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 24 -- West Berlin's political and spiritual leaders told their people today that they could have faith in the future and should base their faith on the Christmas message of love among all mankind.
Governor-elect Nelson A. Rockefeller said yesterday that he would appoint Paul D. McGinnis of Albany as State Commissioner of Correction.
PEIPING, Dec. 24 -- Chinese Communist army officers are being sent to communes to help "reorganize and consolidate" them.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- If the Russians really want a ban on nuclear weapons testing, they will probably come to terms before the end of March, State Department officials said today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Leon H. Keyserling charged today that President Eisenhower's proposed $77,000,000,000 budget was "literally blind to the evolving world situation."
An attempted bank hold-up and a successful $3,000 hold-up of a foreign currency exchange concern took place within a hour in the Times Square area yesterday afternoon.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Dec. 24 -- Leaflets from the Greek Cypriote underground movement offering a permanent cease-fire were scattered among Christmas shoppers here today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- In this day of easy if imprecise economic labels, Leon H. Keyserling fits snugly into that Democratic group that President Eisenhower regularly excoriates as "the spenders."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Dr. Herbert F. York, the chief scientist of the Defense Departmen's space agency, was named by President Eisenhower today to direct all the Pentagon's research and engineering.
PARIS, Dec. 24 -- The Government of Guinea has refused to sign a series of protocols setting forth its new relations with France, according to French dispatches from Conakry.
A 31-year-old Brooklyn janitor, who admitted he killed his wife during an argument, received a suspended sentence as a Christmas gift yesterday in Kings County Court.
Unionized pilots on American Airlines continued yesterday to withhold comment on a strike settlement formula proposed by Leverett Edwards, chairman of the National Mediation Board.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 24 -- More than seventy Opposition members staging a sitdown strike in the National Assembly were forcibly evicted from the chamber today by about 300 Assembly guards and plainclothes policemen.

In the great symbolism that surrounds the celebration of the Christmas festival many elements have taken on different forms. The Christmas gift, for example, has its origin in the beautiful narrative of the Wise Men who offered gold, frankincense and myrrh to the infant Jesus in the manger at Bethlehem.

BAYONNE, N. J., Dec. 24 -- Two 18-year-old Staten Island youths were held without bail on murder charges today in the holdup-killing of Assistant Municipal Prosecutor Stephen F. Sladowski. He was killed in his grocery here last Thursday night.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 25 -- With the Soviet menace hard upon them this Christmas, West Berliners showed special appreciation today for the presence in Berlin of a United States Army garrison.

Foreign Minister Gromyko chose Christmas Day to tell the Supreme Soviet and the world that Berlin might become a "second Sarajevo" unless the West surrenders the free part of it in what could only be a first step toward the surrender of free Europe.
Striking mechanics at Eastern Air Lines have voted ratification of contract terms, but resumption of service was not forseeable for the heavy holiday travel crush.
The Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., predicted yesterday that a good year lay ahead for business in the city.

NEWARK, Dec. 25 -- The United States Attorney's office announced today the indictment of four persons, three of them from New York City, in an alleged $250,000 oil stock swindle. They were accused of selling worthless stock with a promise of quick profits.
Christmas came once again yesterday to Bethlehem in Judea and to the far corners of the world where the birth of Jesus is celebrated.

The American voter is much more interested in who is President than he is in the equally important question of who goes to Congress. Thus we learn that the mid-term vote in 1958 was perhaps three and one-half million larger than the corresponding vote in 1954.

HAVANA, Dec. 25 -- Big losses falling on insurance companies from the sabotage of property by property by rebels have led to the creation by the Government of a Cuban Institute of Re-insurance. The agency will underwrite insurance granted by privately owned companies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- This capital of the non-Communist world is quiet today, as befits the occasion of Christmas. The President is devoting himself to his family. The offices of the Government are deserted, and hence so are the streets of a city where government is the chief industry of the inhabitants.
PARIS, Dec. 25 -- France's financial exchanges will be closed tomorrow by order of the Ministry of Finance.

BANDUNG, Indonesia, Dec. 25 -- President Tito of Yugoslavia sought today to spur the forces that reject alignment with East or West to promote the principles of "active peaceful coexistence" as being in the "greatest interest" of all nations.

NOW it appears that the Old Vic has been saving its finest gift for Christmas Night. The performance of "Henry V," which opened at the Broadway, is the Old Vic at the top of its bent. And Laurence Harvey's portrait of the King is the most stimulating acting in the current repertory.
LONDON, Dec. 25 -- Queen Elizabeth asked her people today to remember at Christmas "with friendship and good-will" strangers from other parts of the Commonwealth who had come to work in Britain.
CAIRO, Dec. 25 -- Khalid Bakhdash, Syrian Communist leader; and perhaps as many as a hundred of his lieutenants, have been arrested this week.
NEWARK, Dec. 25 -- The Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company today announced that it would seek to abandon forty-two daily and week-end trains.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- The World Bank made $770,000,000 in loans this year -- the highest in its eleven-year history.
A mother, her 3-year-old son and her 5-year-old daughter were shot and killed here on Christmas Eve.
MOSCOW, Dec. 25 -- An organizer for the Young Communist party was named today to replace Gen. Ivan A. Serov as chief of the Soviet Union's powerful security organization.
In a world of turmoil, fear and tension, Christians joined yesterday in prayers for peace and goodwill.

TRENTON, N. J., Dec. 25 -- A New Jersey nursing home official warned today that unless the tate increased its allotment for the care of patients on public assitance, "most" private nursing homes would be forced to refuse to admit them.

MOSCOW, Dec. 25 -- Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko said today that the determination by the Western powers to keep their troops in West Berlin by force if necessary would only lead to the threat of starting a "big war."

Bill Russell and Bill Sharman led the Boston Celtics to their eighth straight victory, a 129-120 triumph over the New York Knickerbockers last night in the second game of a National Basketball Association double-header at Madison Square Garden.

HONG KONG, Dec. 26 -- Communist North Vietnam has asked Anti-Communist South Vietnam to a conference to discuss the Limitation of military commitments and the inauguration of commercial and other exchanges between them.
Former President Harry S. Truman will lecture on the Presidency next spring at Columbia University.
LONDON, Dec. 26 -- The Treasury declined today to comment on reports from the Continent that Britain was planning a further move toward convertibility of the pound sterling.
HAVANA, Dec. 26 -- President Fulgencio Batista has ordered 2,000 soldiers as reinforcements into Las Villas Province, where the rebels of Fidel Castro claim to have captured some fifteen towns.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The United States and several other nations of the Western Hemisphere are seeking some way to end Cuba's bloody civil strife.
PARIS, Dec. 26 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle met tonight in a marathon session with his Government on the outlines of a financial new deal for France.
An agreement to end the strike of newspaper delivery men was reached last night, subject to ratification by the union membership Sunday.

Top-seeded St Joseph's, Dayton, Utah and St. John's scored first-round victories as the seventh annual Holiday Festival basketball tournament of the Eastern College Athletic Conference began at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

Stepping up his campaign against local Communists, President Nasser now denounces them as "traitors" to the cause of Arab nationalism and accuses them of joining up with "reactionaries" to undermine his project of a pan-Arab empire under his rule.
TOKYO, Dec. 26 -- The wedding of Crown Prince Akihito and Michiko Shoda, the first commoner to be selected as a future Empress of Japan, is reported to be scheduled for late April.

PARIS, Dec. 26 -- A significant change in France's organic structure during the past revolutionary year has been the intrusion of the army into civilian affairs. This is a country of great military tradition. There have been periods, for example under the two Napoleons, when the Army's role has transcended that of national defense.
One of Governor-elect Nelson A. Rockefeller's first acts after he takes office next Thursday will be to seek economies in the state government.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Next year's budget request for foreign aid will be about $3,900,000,000, virtually the same as the Administration asked this year.
The Lehigh Valley Railroad has been temporarily prevented by the Interstate Commerce Commission from abandoning all of its passenger service next month.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UPI) -- America's four-and-a-half-ton satellite exchanged four more messages today with Army ground stations, ending a recess the Atlas missile was granted on Christmas Day.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The first accurate topographical map of the pock-marked surface of the moon is nearing completion at the Naval Observatory here.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The Government realized a net return of about 70 cents on each dollar's worth of surplus farm products moved out of Federal storage in the last year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The Roman Catholic Bishops of the United States asserted today that many Communist countries were waging a "war of extermination" against Christians.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- President Eisenhower announced today the designation of William L. Mitchell, a Federal career official, as Commissioner of the Social Security Administration.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The Justice Department will take part in special hearings on possible influence-peddling in the award of Boston television Channel 5.

Dr. Henry M. Wriston, former President of Brown University and an exceptionally acute enalyst of educational problems, has in several recent publications, given some wise advice. WASHINGTON, Dee. 27 -- The United States Government welcomed the announcements by several European countries today that they would ease restrictions on the convertibility of their currencies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The U. S. has long-term plans to launch satellites weighing forty tons or more.
