TOKYO, Dee. 28 -- Premier Nobusuke Kishi grappled with a grave political crisis within his own party today.

St. John's quintet will be seeking its first championship after five unsuccessful attempts in the Holiday Basketball Festival when it meets St. Joseph's of Philadelphia at Madison Square Garden tonight.
Dick Tracy's wrist-watch radio may come within everyone's reach in a few years.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 28 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower spent a leisurely Sunday today chatting with some of his old bridge - playing friends and watching the professional football game between the Baltimore Colts and the New York Giants.

Thanks to fire departments, underwriters, fire prevention weeks and building codes, disasters like the Chicago school fire are infrequent. When children do pay for the carelessness or poor judgment of their elders, people hasten to clean house.
Employes of several organizations will give blood to the New York Regional Red Cross Program today in a mass donation at the Wanamaker Building, 770 Broadway.

One immediate result of the visit of Philippine President Garcia to Japan is the announcement of a Japanese loan to the Philippines. The amount is not stated, but it is believed to be about $50,000,000. It comes within the framework of the reparations agreement and is a way to put some of that reparation to work.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's proclamation of the Abraham Lincoln Sesquicentennial Year:
ALBANY, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The following conditions were reported to the State Commerce Department today:
More than 1,300 persons attended the tenth anniversary Tiara Ball in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria last night.

BRISBANE, Australia, Tuesday, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Australia's Neale Fraser and Mal Anderson led the American pair of Ham Richardson and Alex Olmedo, two sets to one, in their Davis Cup challenge round doubles match today.
WARSAW, Dec. 29 -- A current rumor being combated by the Polish Government illustrates a paradox of propaganda that bedevils Communist Governments.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Louisiana State and Clemson took their final hard workouts today for the Sugar Bowl football game on Thursday. Both squads were reported in excellent physical shape.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today set at 9,200,000 tons the amount of sugar which may be marketed in this country during 1959.
It has been a cold winter so far, but if the birds have been told something man has not heard, the worst may be over.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Dec. 9 -- Political sophistication characterizes the Czechoslovak Communists.
LONDON, Dec. 9 -- A general election in the spring, probably in May, is now expected by Conservative Members of Parliament.
A special committee will be appointed by the Board of Higher Education to map a master plan for the expansion of the municipal college system.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Nelson A. Rockefeller Governor-elect of New York, resigned today as an adviser to the Eisenhower Administration.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- The Senate Rackets Committee said today it was looking into the report of a million-dollar loan from pension funds of the teamsters union to a Chicago trucking terminal.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The legendary Midas of the golden touch was a real and very rich king and a group of American researchers believe they have found his palace.
There'll be no more horse races down Belmont Park's unique straightaway course -- the Widener Chute.

Joseph Wolf, realty investor, has purchased the property at 263-65 Third Avenue and 203-05 East Twenty-first Street, the northeast corner, for improvement with a sixteen-story, airconditioned apartment building.
CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Nearly all wheat, corn and soybean futures contracts sank deeper for the season today on the Board of Trade.

RICHMOND, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Richmond's tall Spiders took control of the backboards in the second half tonight and defeated Columbia, 81 -- 59, in the opening game of the Richmond invitation basketball tournament.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- Charlie Chaplin has paid the United States Government $425,000 to settle claims that he owed $700,000 in back taxes and interest, the Internal Revenue Service announced today.
HONG KONG, Dec. 29 -- Communist China agreed today to lend the Government of Outer Mongolia 100,000,000 rubles to assist in building electric power, highway, industrial and other facilities.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Following are the texts of Nelson A. Rockefeller's letter of resignation and report and President Eisenhower's reply:
BUFFALO, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Dartmouth won the fifth annual queen city invitation basketball tournament tonight with a down-to-the-wire victory over Canisius, 72 -- 69.
Commodore Coenraad Bouman, master of the Holland-America Line flagship Nieuw Amsterdam, will be back on the bridge of the liner when she sails from here on Jan. 7 on a West Indies cruise.

Where sleep is concerned, Jim Lee Howell normally is a seven-hour-man. On Sunday night, after his Giants had been beaten so dramatically, 23 -- 17, by the Baltimore Colts for the world championship, Howell went to his home in Englewood, N. J. Did Jim Lee get any sleep that night?
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 29 -- A Chattanooga teamster official again denied today that he gave $18,500 in union funds to a Nashville truck line executive to be used to bribe a Tennessee judge in 1951.
The Standing Room Only sign is up these days at the main reading room of the New York Public Library.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Treasury bill rate fell slightly again this week. The Treasury disclosed tonight that the average interest rate on the week's issue of ninety-day bills was 2.69 per cent compared with 2.739 per cent last week.

John Burch McMorran, chief engineer of the State Power Authority, will be Superintendent of Public Works in the new state administration. Governor-elect Nelson A. Rockefeller announced the appointment yesterday at his New York office, 20 West Fifty-fifth Street.

The new year will be a good one and probably better than the one ending in the view of fourteen business and industrial leaders who took part in a syposium on the business outlook. The results were made public yesterday.

WHAT would America be like if Grant had never been President? His opponent in the first election was Horatio Seymour, who had opposed Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation. In the second election, Grant defeated Horace Greeley, who died before he could have taken office and whose Vice President would have been Benjamin Gratz Brown, who had opposed the renomination of Lincoln.

The election of Walker L. Cisler, Augustus C. Long and Stanley F. Teele as directors of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States was announced yesterday. They will begin three-year terms Thursday.

VIENNA, Dec. 28 -- The Bulgarian Cabinet has decreed that all civil servants and white-collar workers employed in state organizations must contribute thirty days' "voluntary" work each year in industrial enterprises.

In a one-sided but fast and exciting basketball game, St. John's University punctured a well-fashioned zone defense and defeated St. Joseph's of Philadelphia, 90-79, in the final of the Holiday Festival tournament at Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The executive directors of the International Monetary Fund and International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) formally recommended to the member governments today a major increase in the resources of the two institutions.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 29 -- West Germany is arranging settlements of $1,000,000,000 in commercial debts run up in its favor in the last five years. The money is owed by its European trading partners.
The Transit Authority has discharged two of the leaders of the 1957 subway motormen's strike. It has also suspended two other leaders of the strike for twenty days without pay.
RABAT, Morocco, Dec. 29 -- Tribal leaders in the Rif Mountains are pressing for a policy that would bring Morocco into open conflict with France.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 29 -- West Germany is reconsidering its proposed participation in the construction of the Aswan High Dam on the Nile.
Herbert Marshall and Cyril Cusack have agreed to act in "Goodwill Ambassador," a political satire by the late Harry Farrar Tarvin that was originally called "Pandora and the Harp."
The Los Angeles, Calif., Department of Water and Power is planning to sell $18,000,000 of electric plant revenue bonds on Jan. 14.

The bard who wrote that "full many a flower is born to blush unseen" might well have been looking ahead to the bleak and dreary weeks -- now happily ended, as these words in print attest -- when there went largely unchronicled for the millions deprived of their newspapers the happenings, great and small, that cause the world to spin.

Swingline, Inc., a Long Island City maker of stapling machines, announced yesterday it would extend its request for tenders of Wilson Jones Company common stock. The offer of $20 a share for 100,000 shares was extended until Jan. 13, 1959.

DENPASAR, Bali, Dec. 29 -- Observers believe that Presidents Tito of Yugoslavia and Sukarno of Indonesia will have an interesting talk on Communist China before Marshal Tito's ten-day visit to Indonesia ends Thursday.

Price may be the key to consumer purchases in the next few months, according to a survey released yesterday by the National Bureau of Economic Research. It found that fewer consumers planned to buy cars, household appliances and other durables in the next six months than a similar survey a year ago showed.

"Rawhide," a one-hour filmed Western series originally designed for use at the start of this season, will make its debut Jan. 9 over the Columbia Broadcasting System network. It will be televised each Friday from 8 to 9 P.M.
More gifts arrived yesterday from persons who have already contributed this year to the fund for the New York Times Neediest Cases.
LONDON, Dec. 29 -- Asia must develop technical and managerial skills to keep pace with capital investment, according to the annual report of the Colombo Plan's Consultative Committee.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The House Special Subcommittee on Legislative Oversight debated today whether to let its inquiry into Federal regulatory agencies die or to create a permanent body to keep an eye on the agencies.
ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- Several bills to continue and tighten residential rent controls were submitted to the Legislature today under Democratic sponsorship. They were announced by Governor Harriman.
Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn, the 15-year-old defender, increased his lead last night in the United States chess championship for the Lessing J. Rosenwald Trophy.

The city's accelerated Thanksgiving-to-Christmas drive on jaywalking was pronounced a success yesterday by Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley. The accident toll was 20 per cent less than in the same period of 1957, while fatalities were 21 per cent fewer.
The cloisters, the medieval branch of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in Fort Tryon Park, presents a curious and rather incongruous picture, these days.
New York's Knickerbockers will meet the Detroit Pistons in the second game of a basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight.
The retirement of R. J. Baker as secretary-treasurer of the American Merchant Marine Institute, effective Wednesday, has been announced by the board of directors. He will continue as a consultant.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The United States Government, the International Monetary Fund and private banks announced today loans and other assistance totaling $329,000,000 to Argentina. It was the biggest single aid program ever devised for a Latin-American nation.

Blanche Thebom sang her first Marina of the season last night in Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunov." She played the role with hard and bitter irony and her voice, although not always beautiful, was modulated to suit this conception.
NEW HAVEN, Dec. 29 (AP) -- A Yale University pathologist reported today the successful reversal of pregnancy in dogs with a drug made from spent brewer's yeast.
MIAMI, Dec. 29 -- Miami University of Ohio routed New York University, 75 -- 55, in the opening contest of the first Hurricane Basketball Classic tonight.

Arthur Krock's Nov. 19 column provided a valuable preview of the epic liberal-conservative struggle which is bound to take place in the Senate of the United States as soon as the opening formalities have been dispensed with on Jan. 7, 1959.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Reports from private discussions now current in the inner councils of Southern states where school racial segregation is still mandatory by law are that officials there recognize, though their constituents as yet do not, that the constitutional crisis over these statutes has passed into history.
MOSCOW, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Pravda used such terms as "economic storm" and "trade war" today to describe the week-end changes in Western Europe's currency regulations.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., Dec. 29 (UPI) -- A prominent scientist told the annual American Astronomical Society meeting here today that new telescopic observations had definitely established the existence of organic matter on Mars.
Samuel Barber's "Vanessa," which had its world premiere at the Metropolitan Opera last January, will receive its seasonal debut Wednesday, Jan. 7, with the original cast.

An offer of $15,250,000 was made yesterday for the two office buildings at 30 and 50 Church Street. The offer was submitted by Koeppel Koeppel, Inc., a realty investment company, during a Federal Court hearing on plan of reorganization of the bankrupt Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company. The company owns both of the twenty-two-story structures that lie between Cortlandt and Fulton Streets.

ROME, Dec. 29 -- Pope John XXIII granted an audience today to a traveling circus. He watched a pigeon act and was presented with a forty-five-day-old lion cub. The Pontiff appeared to take a fancy to Dolly, the little lioness.

Goldman, Sachs Co., a New York investment banking firm, announced yesterday that it would admit six new general partners. The appointments are effective Jan. 1, 1959. The new partners will be Arthur G. Altschul, John W. Callaghan, Charles L. Grannon, James D. Robertson, L. Jay Tenenbaum and Harold S. Wass.
Two executive appointments were announced yesterday at Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc.

A capital-gifts fund of $8,545,000 will be sought by Barnard College in celebration of its seventy-fifth anniversary in 1964. It will be used to improve the college's plant, increase faculty salaries and scholarship funds, develop the academic program and expand enrollment.
LONDON, Dec. 3 -- An earth tremor around the flanks of Mount Kilimanjaro in East Africa has probably saved a famous British game reserve from destruction.
The Board of Estimate is scheduled to take final action on the controversial Seventh Avenue, Brooklyn, approach to the Narrows Bridge at a meeting today at 2:30 P. M.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 29 -- The independent producing team of Aubrey Schenck and Howard W. Koch has formed a new association with United Artists to make theatrical and television films for the distribution corporation.

Today's new film is "Mad Little Island," a British-made comedy starring Jeannie Carson and Donald Sinden, at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse, near Seventh Avenue. The Rank Organization production was directed by Michael Relph. Monja Danischewsky prepared the screen play, which is based on a novel by Compton Mackenzie.
The holiday-shortened working period last week severely curtailed activity in the steamship charter market.
The Misses Linda Ashley Carr and Pamela Hale Meeker were honored at a dinner dance given last evening in the ballroom of the Colony Club.
LONDON, Dec. 9 -- Archaeologists have found the 7,000-year-old hunting and fishing encampments of a prehistoric race called the Maglemosians or "Bog-hoppers" on a tributary of the Thames.

VINCE LOMBARDI had just concluded the final briefing of his quarterbacks shortly before the championship play-off between the Giants and Colts Sunday at Yankee Stadium. He walked to the center of the clubhouse, looked around and shook his head.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Algae capable of multiplying a thousandfold in twenty - four hours have been discovered. They offer promising means of keeping air fresh on space ships and submarines.

Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday that both gross operating revenues and net income were higher in November than they were a year earlier. However, results were off for the first eleven months of this year.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Dec. 29 -- Receipt of an air mail Christmas letter from Tonawanda, N. Y., a suburb of Buffalo after it had taken a 6,000-mile detour to Germany, puzzled Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Hoffman of 817 Cleveland Avenue and postal authorities here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- William Worthy, who has been unable to get his passport renewed since he visited Communist China and Hungary in the winter of 1956-57, today challenged the right of the State Department to restrict a newsman's travel.
Northwest Airlines broke its long official silence on future plane orders yesterday. It became the last of the nation's major air carriers to announce the purchase of jet and turboprop aircraft.

RALEIGH, N. C., Dec. 29 (AP) -- North Carolina defeated Yale, 92 -- 65, and Michigan State rolled to an easy 82-57 victory over Duke tonight in the first round of the Dixie basketball classic before a capacity crowd of 12,400 in Reynolds Coliseum.

By a sweeping change in the methods of the Division of Safety Service in the State Labor Department the frequency rate of industrial accidents in one of the state's most hazardous industries, foundries, has been reduced 40 per cent during the last three years -- about twice as much as in the country as a whole. So Industrial Commissioner Lubin reports in this month's issue of the "Industrial Bulletin."
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 29 -- President Arturo Frondizi announced tonight the freeing of the peso and the end of import restrictions.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Dec. 29 -- A major traffic bottleneck in southern Westchester County became inevitable today. A short stretch of the Bronx River Parkway is scheduled to be closed early next month, and the resulting bottleneck may continue for more than a year.
Biblical scholars attending the annual meeting of the Society of Biblical Literature and Exegesis heard yesterday of early Christian manuscripts that came to light in the last year.
CHARLOTTE, N. C., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Fordham, Davidson, George Washington and St. Francis of Loretto, Pa., won opening-round games today in the Carrousel Classic basketball tournament.

Apropos your editorial of Dec. 2 regarding distribution of new and enlarged maps by the Transit Authority for New York's subway travelers, may I stress the importance of a better location for them than that presently given to the miniatures on display in the various cars.

NOTHING, not even fruit cake spices and gingerbread, has more of a winter holiday aroma than tangerines. And 4,000,000 boxes of the golden fruit, described by the Columbia Encyclopedia as belonging to the "kid-glove group of oranges," are expected to be produced this year.

Don Nogrady of Smithtown, L. I., advanced a round ahead of the field as play in the junior division of the annual Eastern indoor junior and boys' tennis championships began yesterday at the 102d Engineers Armory.

The Rath Packing Company reported its net income yesterday for the fiscal year ended Oct. 25 at $1 094,488, or $1.10 a share. This was slightly lower than the $1,277,406, or $1.29 a share, reported for the previous year.

GEORGE BALANCHINE introduced an altered version of his production of "The Nutcracker" for the New York City Ballet at the City Center yesterday afternoon. The changes, all in the second act, are designed to make the Sugar Plum Fairy the central figure in the scene, which takes place in her own kingdom.

CAIRO, Dec. 28 -- Ten inscribed pieces of gold, believed to have been the first of their kind used as a medium of exchange 4,000 years ago, have been reported stolen from the Cairo Museum. The manner of their theft apparently is a complete puzzle worthy of the efforts of a Sherlock Holmes.
The unnerving experience of being late for one's own debut was undergone by Warren Langlie, pianist, who appeared at Carnegie Recital Hall last night.
LONDON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Soviet submarines may be secretly cruising in waters where allied guided missile tests are under way, it was reported today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- Leading economists and statisticians expect 1959 to be a year of moderate economic expansion and steady prices.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, Dec. 9 -- To a visitor from Jakarta, Kuala Lumper is a city of incredible wonders, with sidewalks, double-decker buses and Saturday midnight movies.
BUFFALO, N. Y., Dec. 29 (AP) -- The National Gypsum Company announced today it had reached agreement to purchase the Huron Portland Cement Company of Detroit.
Cincinnati and Kentucky, idle last week, remained one, two yesterday in the United Press International major college basketball ratings.

Despite Soviet rocket-rattling over Berlin, Western Europe embarks over the year-end on a momentous financial and economic reorganization with equally momentous political overtones. The result should be to enhance its unity and strength, to the benefit of the whole free world.

MIAMI, Dec. 29 -- Ninety-two visitors to this winter vacation paradise had no time today to cast more than occasional wistful glances at the assorted sun-drenched diversions that occupied most of the teaming thousands here for the holiday season.

The New York Central Railroad cleared $2,633,054 in November, in contrast to a loss of $1,894,625 in the month last year. The income was achieved despite a drop in gross to $56,432,082 from $58,205,932. Net operating income rose to $3,531,531 from $261,521 in November, 1957.
Municipal Court Justice Mario J. Cariello was reported last night to be in the lead for election as Borough President of Queens. The post becomes vacant Jan. 1.
The steel industry expects to produce more raw steel this week than in any other week since late October, 1957, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
BOSTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The New England Council ski conditions bulletin:

Capital of the Manufacturers Trust Company, fourth largest bank in New York City and fifth in the nation, would be doubled under a proposal to be submitted to stockholders at the annual meeting on Jan. 28.

RABAT, Morocco, Dec. 28 -More than 80,000 Algerian refugees in Northern Morocco are in dire need of food, clothing, blankets, tents and medical supplies as winter winds and snow have struck their camps.
VIENNA, Dec. 29 -- An inventory of Hungary's agricultural situation, candidly acknowledging failures, was published recently in Nepszabadsag, official newspaper of the Hungarian Communist party.
The Citizens Budget Commission has selected The New York Herald Tribune and The Long Island Press to receive its top 1958 awards for superior coverage of municipal affairs.
TRENTON, Dec. 29 -- The Appellate Division of State Superior Court temporarily stayed a lower court ruling today that had declared a Fair Lawn garbage removal contract null and void.
Departmental hearings for the heads of the more than 100 city agencies on their budget requests for 1959-60 will begin Jan. 5 and continue through Jan. 28.

The United States may be getting over its jittery attitude toward the International Court of Justice, the successor to the Permanent Court of International Justice which languished under the old League of Nations. The present court, sitting at The Hague, and including an American member, hasn't had much to do.
A 23-year-old woman insurance agent, the object of a nation-wide search since last month, was accused yesterday in Felony Court of defrauding a loan company of $80,000 over the last three months.

The Morningside Citizens Committee wishes to call attention to the potential role of the Temporary State Rent Commission in programs designed to correct slum conditions in New York City and to halt the process by which residential buildings become slums in short periods of time.

SOMETHING like 8,416 wet and dry flies are being invented today by 6,314 of the 168,829 men and women who are satisfying their winter fly-tying craze while auditing the sincere inanities of television jollyboys. The other fly-tyers, contentedly free of the lonely hunger of creativity, are tying standard patterns.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregularly yesterday, 14 points off to 6 points up, in light trading. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
DUMAS, Tex., Dec. 29 (AP) -- A blizzard isolated Albuquerque, N. M., and stranded motorists in Texas on snow-blocked highways today. Two persons died in accidents caused by the storm.
DETROIT, Dec. 29 (AP) -George Romney, president of American Motors Corporation, predicted today that 6,000,000 automobiles would be sold in the United States in 1959, barring unforeseen developments.
PARIS, Dec. 29 -- The new fractional rate of the French franc, 493.7 to the dollar, represents a decision by Premier Charles de Gaulle to abandon the dollar as a yardstick and use gold instead.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 29 -- The Soviet Union and Norway have decided to join the Intergovernmental Maritime Consultative Organization, which will begin operations next week as the twelfth United Nations special agency.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Scientists were told today that more women must get into the science field if the United States is to keep pace with the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The United States and the Soviet Union will exhibit to each other next summer their scientific, technological and cultural accomplishments, unhampered by censorship except for an agreement to refrain from political agitation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Justice Department is planning to step up its use of a little-employed legal weapon in an expanding fight against labor racketeering -- the Sherman Anti-trust Act.

MOSCOW, Dec. 29 -- It will be a sobering New Year's Day in the Soviet Union. Anyone who thought that Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's talk about one drink to a customer was just talk will know better in 1959.

The Patio Theatre and parking lot at Flatbush Avenue and Lincoln Road in Brooklyn have been sold by the Twain Realty Corporation. They were bought by Dandy Properties, Inc., headed by David Wolfenson, a Queens builder, who plans two sixteen-story houses containing 500 apartments.
DETROIT, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The University of Detroit opened up late in the first half tonight and defeated Army, 98 -- 87, in the opening game of the Motor City Basketball tournament.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Dec. 20, 1958, totaled 570,927 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
LONDON, Dec. 29 -- Britain's decision to allow foreign holders of sterling to exchange it freely for any other currency lent buoyancy to the stock market today.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 29 -Prime Minister Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana said today he had received no offer of economic and technical aid from Sovunion so far.
LONDON, Dec. 29 -- With few exceptions, the British Government's decision to make the pound sterling more convertible was welcomed here today.
RABAT, Morocco, Dec. 29 -- The Government announced today its decision not to go along with the devaluation of the French franc.

Only stainless steel wool pads or sponges should be used to remove sticky food spots from stainless steel cooking utensils, the Committee of Stainless Steel Producers says. Regular steel wool and soap pads are not recommended because some of their tiny particles may be left inside the pans and form rust.

"The Bridge on the River Kwai," Sam Spiegel's production about life in a Japanese prison camp in Burma during World War II, captured four of the ten top honors in the annual Filmdom's Famous Fives balloting conducted by The Film Daily, motion picture trade paper.
The head of the teamsters' union drive to organize the city's 24,000 policemen announced last night plans to post picket lines in front of Police Headquarters on Jan. 12.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- The state's harness racing tracks are not satisfied with the law that gives millions of dollars of state revenue to them every year for construction projects. They want twice as much.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 29 -- Adelphi checked Hofstra, 71 -- 59, tonight in the Long Island Collegiate invitation basketball tournament. Adelphi is unbeaten in two tournament starts in the four-team round-robin.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee said today that he thought the public would back Congress in adopting a realistic legislative program to halt inflation.
Newspapers, advertisers and agencies attempted yesterday to assess the effects of the nineteen-day deliverers' strike that closed the city's nine major newspapers.
New York's nine major newspapers, unable to publish during seventeen days of a nineteen-day strike of delivery workers, resumed publication yesterday.
PARIS, Dec. 29 -- Finance Minister Antoine Pinay confirmed today what most Frenchmen already suspected: that the new year was going to be less than happy for them.
The City Housing Authority has submitted for Federal approval six sites upon which it plans to build 3,500 low-rent apartments in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx.
Eleven youths were held without bail yesterday in Brooklyn Felony Court in the fatal stabing of an 18-year-old Army private in the Ridgewood section of Brooklyn Sunday night.

Representative Herbert C. Bonner, chairman of the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee, has asked for a report on what long-range plans the Government has for the orderly development of a nuclear merchant marine.
PARIS, Dec. 29 -- High financial authorities in European capitals said today there was no longer any reason to maintain European discrimination against goods exported by the United States or Canada.
Since the end of the football season several letters have been received suggesting championship competition among the city's Public Schools Athletic League elevens.
ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 29 -- Two babies were suffocated and two adults were injured early today when fire swept a bedroom of their home in near-by Pleasantville.

Tickets are still available for next Tuesday's performance of "Flower Drum Song" at the St. James Theatre, which will benefit the New York Exchange for Woman's Work. They may be obtained from Miss Jessie Fanshawe, 136 East Sixty-fourth Street.
PARIS, Dec. 29 -- The European man in the street may well be asking himself the meaning of the recent monetary and tariff changes in Western Europe.

Sales of the electrical manufacturing industry's products this year will aggregate about $19,500,000,000, Joseph F. Miller predicted yesterday. He is managing director of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.
FOR many traveling Americans, the map of Ireland is just the face of a pretty colleen at Shannon Airport.
CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (UPI) -- Assistant Secretary of State Roy R. Rubottom Jr. said today the "notable strengthening of democratic institutions" in Latin America was one of the brightest spots of 1958.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- A new political deadlock has developed between Governor Harriman and Carmine G. De Sapio, leader of Tammany Hall and unofficial spokesman for the Democratic County organizations of New York City.
PARRIS ISLAND, S. C., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Marine S/Sgt. Ralph A. J. Grant pleaded not guilty here today to charges that he had assaulted and solicited money from members of an Ohio recruit platoon.
A top priority New Year's resolution for beginning bowlers or those who want to better their scores might be: Take lessons. In many cases, it would be wise to do what teacher says, not what he does.

Pan American World Airways predicts that traffic on its trans-Atlantic routes will show an increase of 11 per cent for 1958 over 1957. On its worldwide system, the line estimates there will be an over-all increase of 4 to 5 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- His religion may be a liability for a Roman Catholic candidate for the presidency, it was declared here today, but it need not mean his defeat.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Department of Justice has begun an antitrust investigation of the proposed merger of J. P. Morgan Co. Inc. and the Guaranty Trust Company.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Dr. James R. Killian Jr. warned today that some aspects of American education had deteriorated despite the challenge of Soviet science.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 29 -- Stuffed with sweets and flushed with excitement of watching a clown and a little ballet specially arranged for them, the children were perched on the edges of their seats.

World sugar futures soared yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The advance was one of the sharpest this year. Trading was influenced by increased rebel activity in Cuba and that Government's counter-offensive.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Dec. 29 -- Communist North Korea proposed today that South Korean fishermen be permitted to operate off the North Korean coast.

JOHN BURCH McMORRAN is a career engineer returning to his first love -- the Department of Public Works. For the man named yesterday to head the state agency started to earn his way as a 30-cent-an-hour laborer on a road gang forty years ago.
HAVANA, Dec. 29 -- Fierce fighting between Cuban Government and rebel forces in Las Villas Province continued today. The insurgents claimed the capture of 80 per cent of the province.
The Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation announced yesterday the opening of a new forest products research center in West Monroe, La.

BERLIN, Dec. 29 (AP) -- An official of a private West Berlin intelligence agency has been attested on suspicion of being a Communist spy. The West Berlin police said the man was Dr. Kurt Werner, 59-year-old refugee and head of an economic section of the League of Free Jurists.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Dec. 29 (Reuters) -- Dag Hammarskjold, United Nations Secretary General said here today that the concept of international organization appeared to be "uniquely fitted to the problems of economic development in Africa."

The American Smelting and Refining Company (Asarco) announced yesterday the election of Edward McLanahan Tittman as a vice president and director. He will be in charge of the company's smelting and refining operations.

A new Government peace proposal failed yesterday to end the long strike of flight engineers at Eastern Air Lines. A Federal mediator outlined the settlement plan to company and union negotiators at separate meetings in Miami, but both sides said no.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 29 -- Argentina has joined the march toward convertibility with devaluation of the peso, but she has put up high walls to protect her industry.

LUXEMBOURG, Dec. 29 (Reuters) -- The six-nation European Coal and Steel Community has lost several million dollars as a result of the devaluation of the French franc, sources close to the community's governing body said here tonight.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 29 (UPI) -- Coach Forest Evashevski repeatedly told his Iowa Hawkeyes today that overconfidence could be the greatest obstacle to victory in the Rose Bowl game on New Year's Day against aClifornia.
Traffic accidents across the nation killed 594 persons during the four-day Christmas week-end. The National Safety Council had estimated that the holiday would claim 620 lives.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 29 -- Ground has been broken for the North White Plains Shopping Center, Westchester's latest major retail marketing project. The $1,000,000 center will rise on a five-acre site in the town of North Castle, just north of the White Plains city line.

IT is the fate of "masters," be they "modern" or "old," to be taken too much for granted. To combat benign indifference -- the smiling nod and the passing on -- requires the kind of presentation found at the Peridot Gallery, 820 Madison Avenue.
PARIS, Dec. 29 -- The North Atlantic Council approved today notes rebuffing a Soviet attempt to oust the West from Berlin but giving the Kremlin an opportunity to climb down gracefully and negotiate.

DALLAS, Dec. 29 -- When football men talk of a team named Desire, there isn't any question of the reference to the Navy eleven of 1954. The Middies of that year beat Army and crushed Mississippi in the Sugar Bowl.
Filled With the holiday spirit, a subsidiary of International Business Machines Corporation here is using its biggest electronic computer to play Christmas carols during spare moments.
The appointment of George A. Mooney as executive director of the National Association of Investment Companies, effective Jan. 1, was disclosed yesterday.
Stocks rose to new highs on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Volume increased as the "traditional year-end rally" continued after the holiday hiatus.

The President's $77,000,000,000 balanced budget for the next fiscal year means more austerity for the military. The White House announcement last week provided no details, but indicated that the military part of the budget for the fiscal year 1960 would be slightly larger than the appropriations for the current fiscal year.

HAVANA, Dec. 29 (AP) -The bitter and bloody Cuban revolution was at a critical peak tonight. Rebels battled Government troops in streets and houses of Santa Clara in a bid to cut off Havana from the rich southeast sugar provinces.
CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

EIGHTEEN families are doing without so that the new show at the Museum of Contemporary Crafts can be as complete as possible. The exhibit, which opened earlier this month, is devoted to the furniture and sculpture of Wharton Esherick.
The New York State Racing Commission said yesterday that a certificate of incorporation had been filed for a proposed thoroughbred racing track in the vicinity of Rochester.
Dr. Lawrence G. Derthick, United States Commissioner of Education, predicted yesterday that the new National Defense Education Act would prove tremendously effective.

The second volume of "The War Memoirs of Charles de Gaulle: Unity 1942-44" will be issued in April by Simon Schuster. It is an account of General de Gaulle's struggle to have "Free France" recognized as the legitimate government of his country.
Vice Admiral Hyman G. Rickover said yesterday that education was the key to survival in the nuclear age.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Sergeant at Arms took the symbol of dignity of the House of Representatives out of safekeeping today for a polish job.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 29 (UPI) -- The Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory said today that the 8,800-pound Atlas satellite would be visible, weather permitting, over a large section of the United States during passages early tomorrow and again on Wednesday morning.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Theories of stellar atmospheres may have to be revised as a result of findings obtained from rocket exploration flights.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 29 -- Representatives of a dissident group of stockholders of the New York Trust Company met here this afternoon with an influential group of institutional shareholders to line up support.
ALBANY, Dec. 29 (AP) -- A system of regional centers for delinquent youths partly supported by state aid, was recommended today by the State Social Welfare Department.
With one important exception, the leaders in the United States championship tournament for the Lessing J. Rosenwald trophy won in the ninth round at the Manhattan Chess Club last night.
New housing construction increased sharply throughout the state in November, according to a report by Joseph P. McMurray, State Housing Commissioner.

ITHACA, N. Y., Dec. 30 (AP) -- General Electric Company. Scientists at the concern's advanced electronics center here have been experimenting in bouncing signals off meteor tails to receiving equipment in Washington.
The Appellate Division in Brooklyn yesterday reversed unanimously the conviction of a Nassau County health inspector who had been found guilty of taking fees illegally.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Court of Appeals here held today that the United States might not deport anyone to the Chinese mainland unless the Communist Government there gave its consent.
Ogden R. Reid announced yesterday his resignation as president and editor of The New York Herald Tribune, posts he had held since 1955.

The appointments of State Senator William S. Hults as Commissioner of Motor Vehicles and Dr. Harold G. Wilm as Commissioner of Conservation were announced yesterday by Governor-elect Nelson A. Rockefeller.
ROME, Dec. 30 -- Premier Amintore Fanfani has decided to fly to Cairo in a few days for talks with President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UPI) Roger M. Blough, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, predicted today that the American steel industry would continue its "rapid recovery" from the 1958 slump with increased production in 1959.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 3 to 12 points (15 to 60 cents a bale) lower, after fluctuating in a narrow range all day.

The International Geophysical Year, or IGY, man's most ambitious effort to gain better knowledge about the earth and the space around it, will come to a formal end at midnight tonight after eighteen months of unprecedented scientific explorations on an international scale.

The chances of new Federal civil rights legislation in 1959 were heightened by the election Nov. 4 of liberals of both major parties to Congress, an official of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- To most people the job of running a multi-billion-dollar international banking institution would be job enough. But not to Eugene Robert Black, a lanky, good-natured Southerner, who has been president of the International Bank for Recons truction and development for nine years. Mr. Black cannot resist assuming an international peacemaker's role as well.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Dec. 30 (AP) -- A Thor rocket blew apart shortly after launching tonight. It was the second ballistic missile to explode over the cape in eleven hours.

HAVANA, Dec. 30 -- A powder magazine across the bay from Havana exploded at daybreak today. No official information was available, but it was reported that the explosion had killed three to five soldiers guarding the deposit, which was owned by the Amera de Cuba, a private company.

RALEIGH, N. C., Dec. 30 (AP) -- North Carolina State checked Oscar Robertson in the first half and went on to upset second-ranked Cincinnati, 69 -- 6O, today in the Dixie basketball classic semi-finals.
DANBURY, Conn., Dec. 30 -- A lively controversy has erupted in this Fairfield County city over the proposed enforcement of Sunday "blue laws."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The American Association for the Advancement of Science expressed "profound hope" today that an East-west agreement could be reached to suspend nuclear test.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Representative Emanuel Celler believes the proposed J. P. Morgan-Guaranty Trust Company merger would have about the same effect on competition as the Bethlehem-Youngstown steel merger plan that was held illegal in a Federal District Court last month.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Labor's high command took over the scandal-stained International Jewelry Workers Union today at the unions own request.
Two former officers of Local 102, International Ladies Garment Workers Union, were sentenced yesterday to eighteen months in prison for extorting $700 from a Brooklyn dress company.
MIAMI, Dec. 30 -- All hands on both sides were pronounced fit today as the Syracuse and Oklahoma football squads completed heavy preparations for the silver anniversary Orange Bowl game on Thursday.
LONDON, Dec. 30 -- Eugene R. Black conferred with British Treasury and Foreign Office chiefs today in preparation for a mediation mission to Cairo.

IT may have been because they were writers that William P. McGivern and his wife Maureen Daly McGivern were forced to stay in Fort Lamy in French Equatorial Africa for two and a half weeks a year or two ago.
Asher Schwartz, counsel to the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, asked the public yesterday for impartial consideration of the question of blame for the recent newspaper delivery strike.
ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Dec. 30 -- The body of Alexander Schwartz, New York lawyer, was found at the base of Palisades here this afternoon. Hanging on a boulder 125 feet above was Mr. Schwartz's car.
LONDON, Dec. 30 -- The Ministry of Defense announced tonight that Admiral of the Fleet Earl Mountbatten of Burma would become Chief of the Defense Staff next July.

Karl Benz, the German genius who built one of the first commercially successful automobiles, turned out twenty-six engines before he had one considered suitable for production in series. No. 27 turned its first revolutions in 1893.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 30 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State and Attorney General William P. Rogers named a nine-member commission today to study methods of improving international judicial cooperation and assistance and report before Dec. 31, 1959.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 30 -- Argentine political opinion was mixed today on the drastic devaluation announced last night.
LONDON, Dec. 30 -- The United States, Britain and France, in notes to be delivered to Moscow in the next forty-eight hours, will ask the Soviet Union to negotiate the reunification of a free Germany.

The World Book Company of Yonkers has purchased ten acres and a stone mansion on South Broadway, Tarrytown, N. Y., from the Inch Corporation. It plans to occupy the mansion and an additional building to be constructed for executive offices.
CHICAGO, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
The election of Robert W. Purcell as chairman of the International Basic Economy Corporation has been announced by W. B. Dixon Stroud, president of the international financing and investment concern.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- A new sharp-eyed type of radar that can spot a man a mile away will be installed at Idlewild and Newark Airports and eight other major air terminals. It will be used to direct surface traffic.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 20 -- President Eisenhower's Committee on Scientists and Engineers concluded its work today with a report that gave another warning about the state of the nation's skilled manpower force.
ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- State tax collections, despite the recent recession, are running well ahead of last year's but not quite fast enough to keep abreast of increased state spending.
ALBANY, Dec. 30 (UPI) -snbw reports received today by the New York State DepartIment 0f Commerce: IBelleayre--1 to 7 inches hard snow, ,' bare spots; skiing poor to fair.

Donald Rubell of Brooklyn and Alan Green of Flushing, Queens, the defending champions in their respective divisions, led the way into the quarter-final round of the Eastern indoor junior and boys tennis championships at the 102d Engineers Armory yesterday.
Thirty-seven young women from this country and other nations were presented to society last night at the fourth International Debutante Ball in the main ballroom of the Astor.
IN "Third Best Sport," which opened at the Ambassador last evening, the problem is this: Can Celeste Holm be debased into an organization wife?

The heavily laden oil tanker African Queen grounded and split in two off Ocean City, Md., yesterday. All forty-seven members of her crew were taken safely to shore. Forty-five of the men were air-lifted from the stern of the broken vessel by nine Coast Guard, Navy and Marine Corps helicopters in a coordinated shuttle.
Rent reductions were ordered yesterday for all 359 apartmentsments in a Riverside Drive building whose owner was sentenced to jail Dec. 19 for failing to correct violations.
A supervisor for an engineering company plunged to his death at 11:15 A. M. yesterday while scores of fellow employes looked on helplessly.

Preston Sturges, movie director and playwright, has taken over the job of directing "The Golden Fleecing." The Lorenzo Semple Jr. comedy will be brought to Broadway during the week of Feb. 15 by the team of Courtney Burr and Elliott Nugent.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 30 -- Warner Brothers won out in bidding for screen rights to Erskine Caldwell's new novel, "Claudelle Inglish," to be published next month by Little, Brown Co.
WICHITA, Kan., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Cessna Aircraft Company today reported record sales and earnings for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30.
A plan has been tentatively drawn up for several United States Governors to visit the Soviet Union next June.

FISHING is a little different in Florida this year, and everything is fine, and everything is terrific, and everything is pretty good and quite all right. So say several wise old Florida heads who have never been known to exaggerate anything connected with Florida fishing very much, or to understate it noticeably either.
Donors of large gifts continue to keep the fund for the New York Times Neediest Cases ahead of last year's appeal despite a sharp drop in the number of gifts.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Farmers' efforts to gain greater production efficiency and stabilize their incomes were shown today in a report of the Farmers Home Administration.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Heinrich Himmler, late Nazi Gestapo chief, considered a scheme in World War II to drop propaganda leaflets in South Africa by attaching them to the legs of migrating storks.

Last year Robert D. Bass published "The Green Dragoon," a dual biography of Mary Robinson and Col. Banastre Tarleton, the British officer referred to by the colonists as "Bloody Tarleton" during the American Revolution. On Jan. 7, Holt will issue Mr. Bass' newest biography, "The Swamp Fox," Gen. Francis Marion.
"The Defiant Ones," captured the lion's share of honors voted yesterday in the twenty-fourth annual poll conducted by the New York Film Critics.
Three new films will open at local theatres today.

Clowning was the order of procedure in the opening game of a basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden last night, when the Harlem Globetrotters made monkeyshines while playing a team made up of members of the New York football Giants.
The scrolls and other fragments found in recent years near the Dead Sea provided new light and some heat yesterday for Biblical scholars.
TAMPAKSIRING, Indonesia, Wednesday, Dec. 31 -- President Tito and Premier Sukarno sought today to rally the uncommitted nations in a drive for the preservation of peace.
The Suffolk County (L. I.) Water Authority borrowed $2,500,000 yesterday through the sale of serial bonds to a syndicate headed by B. J. Van Ingen Co.
LONDON, Dec. 30 -- Stock market prices moved up again today. They were stimulated by the strength of the pound sterling and Wall Street.

RABAT, Morocco, Dec. 30 -A Minister of the Algerian provisional government said today the Algerian rebels would not resume secret contacts with French emissaries unless Premier Charles de Gaulle of France showed willingness to accept a political settlement of the war.
The National Opera Association will end its fourth annual convention today.

Two days behind schedule, the Soviet Union's national ice hockey team arrived here yesterday morning on its first trip to this country. The Russians will play eight games against American amateur teams.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 30 -- A brighter tax picture for the New York Central Railroad and most of the other property owners here was provided by new assessment roll filed today by John Marbach, City Assessor.

A traffic-relief program for immediate action was submitted yesterday to Mayor Wagner by his Inderdepartmental Traffic Council. The recommendations, which the group called a coordinated approach to help solve the city's acute traffic problem, are: ...
Futures closed irregularly higher yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges.
"The Ten Commandments," a play written for television by Ben Hecht, will be presented by the National Broadcasting Company's "Kaleidoscope" series on Sunday, Feb. 8, from 5 to 6 P. M.

A dinner dance was given last evening in the Georgian Suite at 1A Eas Seventy-seventh Street by Mrs. Ma. ckay Livingston of 25 East End Avenue and Goodhue Livingston of 720 Park Avenue and by Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Scott Jr. of 167 East Ninety-fourth Street! to honor their debutante daughters, :Miss Linda ]3ove LivingSton and Miss Ellen Scott.
The Radio Corporation of America is studying the possible use of special-purpose satellites to-speed mail delivery anywhere in the world.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Dec. 30 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion promised today to recommend the easing of some restrictions on Arabs who are citizens of Israel.
WARSAW, Dec. 30 -- The Polish Government is ending the year with a bit of good news for the peasants and some hopeful reports on industrial production.

Lew Fonseca, who is to baseball what Cecil B. DeMille is to the motion picture industry, has come through with another of his movie spectaculars, this one the 1958 world series. It is Lew's twenty-fifth and the first one in color.
Stocks moved irregularly higher on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Volume was slightly higher than on Monday but some of the steam apparently went out of the traditional year-end rally.
Nonprofessional employes at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx voted 628 to 31 last night to be represented for collective bargaining by Local 1199 of the Retail Drug Employes Union.

As the Year draws to an end, in the mail come -- with the tardy Christmas cards, and advertisements for January white sales -- the 1959 Credit cards, club membership cards and the quarterly income tax bill plus 1958 tax forms.

Northwest Airlines With the payment of $11,446,825 proceeds of a sale of convertible preferred stock to Northwest Airlines, Inc., further details became known yesterday about the airline's $83,946,825 jet aircraft financing. The financing also involved credit extended by a number of institutions.
HOSPITALS here are lacking in adequate recreational programs for children, a recent survey indicates.

EXCEPT for the normal -- and sometimes abnormal -- upheavals in the won-and-lost records of various teams in various sports, only one truly explosive action erupted during the local news blackout. That was the summary dismissal of Terence Patrick Brennan as Notre Dame football coach. It was a stunner.
Young Rubicam, Inc., has named Peter G. Levathes as vice president of radio and television and Robert P. Mountain as vice president in charge of the agency's new business department.
High school instruction in mathematics is better than is generally believed, a United States Office of Education official said yesterday.
PARIS, Dec. 30 -- Three new West African republics, members of the French Overseas Community, came out today in favor of a "primary" federation for their region.

MIAMI, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Three college students and a teen-age laboratory technician were arrested here today. The police said their arrests cleared up a series of thefts from hotel rooms totaling, more than $22,000.

The Horn Hardart Company has taken a long-term lease on the store, mezzanine and basement in 164 East Fiftyninth Street, according to Tankoos Co., brokers in the deal. The building, on the southwest corner of Third avenue, is owned by Leah McEvelia.

LATE this evening or in the small hours of tomorrow morning, some merrymakers are likely to get a sudden yen for a quiet little snack at home. If the refrigerator and pantry shelves are bare, this presents the problem of finding a grocery store that is still open. The following list might be useful.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP)--The automobile industry and the United States Public Health Service have agreed to work closely on research aimed at reducing air pollution by auto exhaust gases.

A continued rise in business activity should result in an increase of perhaps 5 per cent in demand for oil products in the United States in 1959, Eugene Holman, chairman of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), said yesterday in a year-end statement.

A $4,043,000 profit in November enabled the Pennsylvania Railroad to erase all the loss experienced earlier in the year. The road's income statement, issued yesterday, showed profit of $1,170,000 for the eleven months ended Nov. 30.
The City Housing Authority promised yesterday to investigate instances of hardship arising from higher rents that go into effect tomorrow for 86,000 of its 102,000 public housing tenants.
ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- A state court upheld workmen's compensation benefits today for a 17-year-old messenger who was shooting paper-clips with a rubber band and accidentally flipped one into his eye.
Motor Vehicle Bureau offices in the state will be open on the last four Saturdays of January, but only for registration renewals. The offices normally are closed Saturdays.
Miss Pamela Lane, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Morse Lane of 6 Henderson Place, was honored at a tea given yesterday by Mrs. J. H. S. Mayer at her home at 161 East Seventy-ninth Street.
CHICAGO, Dec. 30 (AP) -- A stout rally, which brokers said was long overdue, raised all grain futures today on the Board of Trade.
Recently The Times published a letter from Eugene M. Friedman of Dover, N. J., in which he stated that "New York City has no one to blame but itself for its unbearable atmospheric conditions."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Satellites may soon be used as navigation aids, Navy scientists aid today.
LONDON, Dec. 30 -- The relative weakness of the United States dollar was a factor in the week-end decision of the West European countries to make their currencies more convertible.
ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- Governor Harriman is leaving behind a sheaf of suggestions and new programs for the Rockefeller administration.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Government will revise its census-taking methods in 1960. The new system will include some do-it-yourself features.
HONG KONG, Dec. 30 -- Food supplies continued to be a serious problem for residents of the larger cities and workers in the big rural enterprises of Communist China.
For the Gold and Silver Ball last night the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza was decorated with yellow chrysanthemums and balloons clustered with silvered smilax.
A device that uses rays emitted by isotopes to gauge the contents of sealed containers such as steel drums or milk cartons has been developed by the Nuclear Corporation of America.
ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller is to be sworn in as New York's forty-ninth Governor since it became an independent state at a private ceremony in the Executive Mansion tomorrow night.
Teak, that hard, durable Far Eastern wood favored by shipbuilders, now is being used increasingly by well-heeled land-lubbers for home and office flooring in this country.
umnist for The New York Herald Tribune, chose prison yesterday rather than reveal a news source. Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan ordered her to begin a ten-day sentence Monday
BALTIM0RE, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The $4,718.77 received by each member of the Baltimore Colts for winning the National Football League title is only the beginning.
One of the deans of the maritime fraternity in New York will retire today with the kind of shipping memories few men possess.

Beaten in their last two meetings with Boston, the New York Rangers will seek undisputed possession of third place in the National Hockey League race when they face the Bruins at Madison Square Garden tonight.
BRISBANE, Australia, Wednesday, Dec. 31 -- The United States won back the Davis Cup from Australia today.
LONDON, Dec. 30 -- Sir Winston Churchill told his countrymen today to stand by old friends despite momentary differences.

Eighteen Fire Department officers have been summoned to appear Monday at 10 A. M. at the Municipal Building to be tried on charges of neglect of duty. It will be the Department's first mass trial of its kind.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission revoked today the broker-dealer registration of J. A. Latimer Co., for transactions in the common stock of U. S. Hoffman Machinery Company, and the Artloom Carpet Company.
The new crisis in Berlin has diverted attention from Khrushchev's ambitious plan to outproduce the free world. Yet this project calls for serious consideration.
PARIS, Dec. 30 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle reorganized French defense today with a view to the threat of nuclear or "subversive" war.

A threat of a proxy fight for control of Loew's, Inc., the nation's largest motion picture company, has apparently been thwarted. This was disclosed yesterday when it was reported that more than 235,000 shares of Loew's capital stock had been acquired by Nathan Cummings, chairman of Consolidated Foods Corporation, Chicago food processors.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The National Mediation Board called for an end to the Eastern Airlines strike today and suggested the way to do it.

BOSTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Judge Charles E. Wyzanski Jr. of United States District Court today awarded a total of $62,689.27 in fees to lawyers who acted for the plaintiffs in a minority stockholders suit against Bernard Goldfine, the East Boston Company and the Boston Port Development Company.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UPI) -- The Defense Departments civilian research chief said today that the United States was "closing the missile gap" with the Soviet Union. He said the nation now could put a two-ton payload into orbit.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Senate Republican liberals nominated John Sherman Cooper of Kentucky today to oppose Everett M. Dirksen of Illinois for the minority leadership.

Against the global backdrop of the cold war Israel's recent move in aid of resolving the Arab refugee problem is hardly perceptible. It may not even loom large in the Middle East, which is now split from one end to the other by the forces of nationalism. The true worth of an action, however, must be measured on its own grounds, and by this standard Israel has made a large step forward indeed.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 30 -- Fred T. Bonham, retired personnel director of The New York Times, who died last Sept. 21, has left gifts to his alma mater, the University of Tennessee, and future students that eventually may top $500,000.
DALLAS, Dec. 30 -- Snow fell in Dallas today as the Texas Christian football team arrived from Fort Worth for its Cotton Bowl game with the Air Force Academy New Year's Day.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that he preferred a tax on the proceeds of off-track betting on horse races to other proposed ways of raising new revenues.

The Automatic Canteen Company of America plans to expand into the manufacture of music vending equipment through a merger with AMI, Inc., of Grand Rapids, Mich. Directors of both companies have approved the merger, Nathaniel Leverone, chairman of Automatic Canteen, announced yesterday.
James R. Hoffa yesterday killed plans for a teamsters' union move to cut off deliveries of vital supplies to police installations in this city.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 30 -- Alaska's long-sought statehood will be signed, sealed and proclaimed at noon Saturday.
TOKYO, Dec. 30 -- Premier Nobusuke Kishi bowed to the demands of dissident factions within his Liberal-Democratic party today in an attempt to end a prolonged dispute.
When the new value of the French franc was announced last week-end, reports generally described it as a 17.55 per cent devaluation. Foreign-exchange specialists here say this is wrong
Two sons of President Fulgencio Batista of Cuba and several other persons close to his family flew from Havana to New York yesterday.
YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N. Y., Dec. 30 -- A new application by the Wiltwyck School for permission to occupy a 144-acre estate on Illington Road was rejected by Yorktown officials today.
CAIRO, Dec. 29 -- Every Communist party member in Syria is either under arrest or being sought, an informed Egyptian source said today. Those already netted number in the hundreds, it was raid.

PARIS, Dec. 30 -- France today enjoys the novel experience of having not only a lame-duck President but a lame-duck regime. For not until next month when President-elect de Gaulle replaces Rehe Coty will the Fifth Republic be entirely launched.

One by one, the nation's railroads are finding 1958 has not been the bleak year the industry had feared. Last January, when a Senate Commerce subcommittee was investigating the "precarious plight" of the railroads, the presidents of even the wealthiest carriers talked of lean 1958 earnings, possibly the leanest since before World War II.
LONDON, Dec. 30 -- The Tower of London rumbled with the sounds of rebellion tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- A 2,000-year-old mechanical model of the solar system has been identified in a Greek museum.

A plan to stimulate foreign investment by deferring tax payments on income earned and reinvested abroad is "much to be desired," the Guaranty Trust Company of New York says in the January issue of its business and economic review, the Guaranty Survey, out today.
A record budget request is being drawn by Superintendent of Schools John J. Theobald.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- United States officials think Anastas I. Mikoyan is coming to Washington to try to maneuver this country into bilateral discussions with the Soviet Union on world issues.
MOSCOW, Dec. 30 -- What is a thinking Russian to think at the end of another year of "cold war"?
MADRID, Dec. 30 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco declared tonight that Spain was enjoying the "most fertile period of internal peace and stability that she has known for over 200 years."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Secretary Arthur S. Flemming announced today that the health, education and welfare programs of his department would constitute more than $3,000,000,000 of President Eisenhower's' $77,000,000,000, balanced budget for the fiscal year 1960.
New Year's Eve here tonight will be a little more expensive and a little more crowded than a year ago in the night clubs, hotels and elsewhere.

Believing that English is growing in importance as an international language, the Ford Foundation is making grants of $601,000 to help expand and improve the teaching of English in foreign countries. Countries mainly in Asia and Africa are intended to be the ultimate beneficiaries.
After months of acrimonious debate, the Board of Estimate late yesterday cleared the way, for construction of the $320,000,000 Narrows Bridge between Brooklyn and Staten Island.

THERE was a lively underworld in New York City before the first criminal gangs, made up mostly of the light-fingered and the violent banished by court order from Britain, began to swarm to the Five Points and around East River waterfront groggeries in the Eighteen Thirties.
WARSAW, Dec. 30 -- Poland's writers, condemning the Government's censorship policies, have called for a "defense of the freedom of expression."
A message of qualified optimism for peace in 1959 will be delivered to the American people by radio tonight on behalf of Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev of the Soviet Union.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Dec. 31 -- A disbarred lawyer and a parolee accused in Connecticut of thefts of nearly $30,000 in cash, Jewels and securities waived extradition here today and were returned to Greenwich, Conn.
The largest insect in the world, a banana-peeling beetle, will go on exhibition today at the American Museum of Natural History.

PARRIS ISLAND, N. C., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Staff Sgt. Ralph Grant was found not guilty today of soliciting and accepting money from a Marine Corps recruit platoon. He was also cleared of charges that he had struck two recruits.

The Deering Milliken Research Corporation recently opened a $2,000,000 research building in Spartanburg, S. C., and announced a program for promoting several new textile products. The building, which houses practically all known textile research equipment, is a windowless, one-story structure of 80,000 square feet.
LONDON, Dec. 31 (AP) -Lord Attlee sized up Presidents Roosevelt, Truman and Eisenhower today.
WASHINGTON. Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Navy is starting the construction of a new class of nuclear-powered Polaris missile submarines, apparently to be heavier than any submarine now afloat.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 31 (UPI) -A young United States schoolteacher said today that a simple question on the Cuban civil war caused a group of Cuban secret policemen to seize him and a friend at gunpoint from an American airliner in Havana airport.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Federal Aviation Agency has become the Government's newest bureau. It absorbed the Civil Aeronautics Administration and a part of the Civil Aeronautics Board at the start of the new year.

The Standard Express Operations Agreement under which the railroads must give the Railway Express Agency twelve months' notice of any intent to withdraw from express operations has been amended, Alfred L. Hammell, president of the agency, announced yesterday.
PARIS, Dec. 31 -- Paris newspapers commented today on the danger of misuse of the sweeping new defense powers assumed by the French Government.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- Field Marshal Earl Alexander of Tunis, Alec Guinness, a fishery scientist, a hospital porter and a lighthouse keeper were among more than 2,000 persons named in Queen Elizabeth II's New Year's Honor List. Mr. Guinness received a knighthood.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 31-An ice skating party ended in tragedy here today when a boy fell through the ice and a car rolled down a small embankment to pin a would-be rescuer in the water. The boy drowned.

Two six-story apartment buildings at 89-04 to 89-14 Thirtyfourth Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens, were bought by David Green for investment in a deal negotiated by L. V. Hoffman Co., broker. The property, 200 by 115 feet, covers the blockfront from Eighty-ninth to Ninetieth Streets and houses 108 families.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (UPI) -- The Atlas satellite stopped "talking" today. The Defense Department indicated it believed the moon's batteries were dead or dying.
If the American public is wise and foresighted it will band together and express its voice for the maintenance of passenger railroad service.

More than 500 witnesses will be examined about reports of graft and other misconduct by city employes in New York's slum scandal. The Department of Investigation budget will be increased $75,000 to $100,000 to make this possible.

Several large gifts received yesterday continued to keep the fund for the New York Times Seediest Cases ahead of last rear's appeal.

A visit to a neck of land, projecting into Long Island Sound at Rye disclosed a group of men and women participating in Westchester County's newest organized sport. They were running retrievers in a field trial called a "fun" trial.

OTTAWA, Dec. 31 -- A gold rush is on in Bay Street, the heart of Toronto's financial district. It started several weeks ago when the Bank of Nova Scotia, one of Canada's eight nation-wide commercial banks, began selling negotiable certificates for bar gold held in its vaults.
BOSTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The presidents of the Boston and Maine and the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroads disputed today a Harvard professor's prediction that both roads faced bankruptcy.
PARIS, Dec. 31 -- None of the tough financial decrees that are furrowing the brows of Frenchmen is getting more attention than the Government's new income tax laws.
ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- Governorelect Nelson A. Rockefeller and a large group of Republicans arrived tonight to take over the control of the state after four years of Democratic administration.
MIAMI, Dec. 31 -- Eastern Air Lines and its striking flight engineers signed a three-year contract tonight, ending a thirty-eight-day walkout. The tie-up had made idle 16,000 employes of the carrier.
RALEIGH, N. C., Dec. 31 (AP) -- North Carolina State defeated Michigan State tonight, 70 -- 61, and won the Dixie Basketball Classic for the seventh time in ten years.

NEWARK, Dec. 31 -- Newark advanced its urban renewal plans today. A contract was signed with a group of city planning consultants to conduct an exploratory study and preliminery plan for the central business district.

Glenn Davis, a former Ohio State University track star, was named the winner of the James E. Sullivan Memorial Award yesterday. The Amateur Athletic Union prize went to Davis after the closest vote in the award's twenty-nine-year history.

The property at 48 to 54 East Thirty-fourth Street in the block east of Altman's department store has been sold by the 450 West Thirty-fourth Street Corporation, Caesar P. Kimmel, vice president. It is 75 by 100 feet and is partly vacant.

Mayor Wagner endorsed yesterday the entire traffic relief program submitted to him Tuesday by his Interdepartmental Traffic Council. He announced that he would direct all city agencies concerned to "proceed as soon as possible with its implementation."

The fur usually flies when the New York Rangers and Boston Bruins get together, and last night was no exception. Pulling themselves together after giving up two goals in the first period, the Rangers outfought their old foes for a 4-3 triumph.

Two programs of traditionally Viennese character have become a regular part of New York's celebration of New Year's Eve. Both were given again last night. At Hunter College there was the fifth annual "Music From Old Vienna" and at Town Hall the eighteenth "Continental Star Parade."

Alejandro Olmedo y Rodriguez, who grew up in the highlands of Peru, had his head back in the clouds yesterday.

DENPASAR, Indonesia, Dec. 31 -- Bali's most famous guide, President Sukarno of Indonesia, happily pointed out the sights today to President Tito of Yugoslavia on the latter's first visit to this celebrated island.

HONG KONG, Dec. 31 -- A picture of great economic growth is given in a year-end review of accomplishments in Communist China for 1958 issued in Peiping today.

EL PASO, Tex., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Wyoming turned two HardinSimmons mistakes into touchdowns in the second quarter today. Then staved off the determined Border Conference champions and gained a 14-6 victory in the twenty-fourth annual Sun Bowl game.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Neil H. McElroy, Secretary of Defense, made no changes today in the roles and missions of the separate armed services as he issued new directives further putting into effect the Pentagon Reorganization Act passed by the last Congress.

FIRST-CLASS decorating can be achieved with secondhand furniture. The only requirements are time, an acquiescent spouse and a certain amount of artistic ingenuity.
The Columbia Gulf Transmission Company, a new subsidiary of the Columbia Gas System, Inc., has acquired the 850-mile natural gas pipeline of the Gulf Interstate Gas Company of Houston, Tex.

Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower was named honorary chairman of the 1959 national Heart Fund campaign yesterday. Dr. Paul Dudley White, Boston heart specialist, was named honorary cochairman. This is their second successive year in these capacities.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -President Eisenhower's budget will announce a new device, involving swapping of Governmentheld mortages for Government bonds, aimed at "saving" several hundred million dollars.

Prof. Walther Unruh, German theatre stage consultant who is helping to design the backstage area of the new Metropolitan Opera House in the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, was named yesterday as consultant for another of the auditoriums being built in the center.

THE Eastern look is going south so far as Altman's is concerned. Its current collection of resort fashions is full of so-called "Burmese" jackets, houseboy pants, cord pipings and frog fastenings. Also, it is all aglow with "lantern" colors, such as green tea, poppy, bamboo beige, mimosa yellow and "Kabuki" shock shades.
