We applaud Mayor Wagner for his forthright stand on the issue that Henry Feinstein has exploded in the face of the people of New York. And we welcome the Mayor's pledge not to tolerate unionization of the police "by the Teamsters or anyone else."

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Silky Sullivan, the come-frombehind horse, started slow and finished slower today in his 1959 racing debut at Santa Anita Park. Showing nothing, he finished sixth in a sevenhorse field in an overnight sprint.

Another dictator, Gen. Fulgencio Batista of Cuba, has fallen, and good riddance to him. In this hour of triumph and trial one must think first of Cuba and the Cubans who have suffered humiliation, anguish and glory for nearly seven years and especially in these last two years of revolution.

In observing with pleasure the installation of new street lamps on the Bryant lark block of Fortysecond Street one is dismayed by glaring inconsistencies in the city's plans to advance better street lighting.

Three ways to improve auto drivers are under intensive study at Columbia University's Safety Education Institute According to Dr. James L. Malfetti, executive officer of the institute, two of the methods also would spotlight probable violators and accident causers before they got behind the wheel.
LONDON, Jan. 1 -- "There shouldn't be any shortage of eggs in the Defense Ministry canteen this year," remarked an elderly general. "Not with all those chickens coming home to roost."
Three members of a scientific expedition left yesterday for Chile, where they hope to fill an important gap in knowledge about glaciation and to help in predicting world climate.
LONDON, Jan. 1 (Reuters) -The British Overseas Airways Corporation next spring expects to become the first airline to operate a round-the-world route entirely by jet and turboprop aircraft.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Jan. 1 -- The creation of the Women's Reserve of the Boy Scouts of America was announced here today.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., Jan. 1 -- President Eisenhower told the leaders of the Soviet Union today that "it seems to us critically important" that the Soviet Union work toward a peaceful solution of the Berlin situation.
LONDON, Jan. 1 -- A slight contraction of business volume and some profit taking took some of the buoyancy from the stock market today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The Government today blamed labor - management disputes in 1958 for 23,500,000 man-days of idleness.
Mayor Wagner's approval of a one-way traffic pattern on Fifth Avenue was sharply criticized yesterday by the head of two stores on the avenue.
For a quarter of a century Fulgencio Batista was a key figure in Cuba in political maneuvering, military coups, many successes and a few setbacks.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 1 (AP) -In a move it terms "unprecedented in the history of banking in this country," Cleveland's Society for Savings has completed a metamorphosis from mutual savings institution to commercial bank.

Sir John Barbirolli conducted his first concert in fifteen years with the New York Philharmonic last night at Carnegie Hall. It was a "preview," and Sir John refrained from making any comments on the selections.

Charles Grutzner wrote a succinct and graphic account recently concerning the slum and housing problem in New York City. However, his conclusion -- that only sufficient new housing at low enough rents or an increase of New Yorkers' income is the only solution -- is much too defeatist.
Yesterday the salaries of eighty-one judges in the five counties here rose to $34,500 a year. The increases of $2,500 a year each were voted by the Board of Estimate Dec. 18.

Walter Lippmann's new book based on his recent interview with Premier Nikita Khrushchev, will be published later this month by Atlantic-Little Brown. Called "The Conununist World and Ours," it describes the two-hour meeting Mr. Lippmann had with Mr. Khrushchev the mood and temper of their exchange and the points at issue, which the author says "revealed the Russian aspirations."
BOSTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Fires killed at least 11,500 persons in the United States in 1958 and caused a record property loss of $1,305,000,000, the National Fire Protection Association estimated today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Followin are the texts of a message from Marshal Kliment Y. Voroshilov, Soviet chief of state, and Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev to President Eisenhower and of the President's reply to Marshal Voroshilov:
BONN, Germany, Jan. 1 -Anastas I. Mikoyan's trip soon to the United States has revived the latent fear among many Germans of a SovietUnited States "deal" at their expense.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Robert Dunlop's White Cachet, the New England sprint champion, recorded his sixth straight triumph by winning the $11,475 New Year's Handicap today at Tropical Park.
ALBANY, Jan. 1 -- Governor Rockefeller today named William R. Brennan Jr., Deputy Superintendent of the State Banking Department, as acting superintendent until a permanent appointment is made.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -House investigators have recommended a broad study to determine whether the Federal regulatory commissions have "neglected their obligations to the public."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce Lewis L. Strauss predicted today that the peak income and production rates achieved in late 1958 would be bettered in the new year.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 1 (Reuters) -- Australia scored 96 runs for the loss of one wicket today in reply to England's first-innings total of 259 in their second cricket test match here.

About 92 per cent of New York State recipients of public assistance have lived in the state five years or more and fewer than 1 per cent have been residents for less than one year, Industrial Commissioner Isador Lubin reported yesterday.

The New York Times of Nov. 24 carried an item entitled "Refugees Get Homes" in which Dr. Tibor Kerekes is reported as saying that the problem of Hungarian refugees will be completely resolved by the end of this year.
Eastern Air Lines reported last night that it was resuming operations today in the wake of a thirty-eight-day strike.

The patrolman on the beat, the detective sergeant, the desk lieutenant and other members of the police force appeared yesterday, almost without exception, antagonistic to James R. Hoffa's campaign to enroll them in the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

ONE way of classifying novelists is into the predictable and the unpredictable. No matter how they may vary in minor details and circumstances, many novelists have only one recurring theme, one general segment of life that they know and one point of view that they can dramatize. Most of the world's great novelists belong to this group.
LONDON, Friday, Jan. 2 -The following notice appears in the "Personal" column of today's London Times:

It should not come as a surprise to anyone who buys meat or potatoes or theatre tickets or commutation tickets to find that the cost of being well read also has risen. The revolution in Cuba brought a cancellation of some airplane flights and some visits by ships.

TAMPAKSIRING, Indonesia, Jan. 1 -- President Tito of Yugoslavia sailed for Burma today with his reputation as a leader of the world's uncommitted nations enhanced by his ten-day state visit to Indonesia.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Louisiana State grabbed a loose ball deep in Clemson territory today and made it pay off for a 7-0 Sugar Bowl victory.
Frank Merrill Jr., currently operating out of Charles Town (W. Va.) race track, was the leading trainer of the 1958 thoroughbred horse racing season, The Associated Press reported yesterday.
BARTOW, Fla., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Mrs. Claire C. Goldfine has been granted a divorce from H. Maxwell Goldfine, son of Bernard Goldfine, Boston industrialist.

Fleeing Cuban supporters of abdicated President Fulgencio Batista arrived at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday on an airliner whose pilot declared he had been forced to leave Havana at gunpoint.

FOUNDATION manufacturers are busy building garments designed to iron out wrinkles resulting from heavy holiday indulgence. There is even some talk that waists are going to be important again, so girdle makers are concentrating on waist cinchers.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1 -The cohorts of King Momus saluted the new year in dismal weather today, with most of the glitter and music of their string bands missing.

HAVANA, Friday, Jan. 2 -Fulgencio Batista resigned as President of rebellion-torn Cuba yesterday and fled to exile in the Dominican Republic. The rebel forces of Fidel Castro moved swiftly to seize power throughout the island.

FOURTEEN table settings designed to help prospective brides of varying tastes and incomes went on view today at Tiffany's. The silver, china and crystal used in the settings, which will be on display through January, are available at this store.

DIONE LUCAS is a purist in the kitchen. This diminutive, British-born food expert -- she is considered by her colleagues as one of the finest technicians concerned with cuisine -- has little time for kitchen gadgetry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -Washington viewed the collapse of the Batista dictatorship in Cuba today with mixed emotions. There was little regret at Fulgencio Batista's departure. But there was apprehension about what might follow.

Ski operators seemed destined to round out the holiday season with one of the most successful financial year - end stands in many years as thousands of enthusiasts appeared at resorts yesterday for a weekend of sport.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 1 -- Venezuelans reacted in a spirit of jubilee to the news of President Fulgencio Batista's flight from Cuba. Parades and demonstrations were organized in Caracas and the interior. Cars honked horns and people waved flags in the streets during the entire day.

OMAHA, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The Strategic Air Command reshuffled control of some of its bases today, slicing the nation north to south into three areas, each under the control of one of its numbered air forces.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 31 -- The European Economic Community will tackle in the new year a task of making it possible for a business or professional man of one of the sixmember states to set up shop in any of the other countries.
TRENTON, Jan. 1 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner will announce within the next few days the appointment of Ned J. Parsekian of East Orange as State Director of Motor Vehicles.
HOBOKEN, N. J., Jan. 1 (AP) -- An ex-policeman was found shot dead early today in his parked car. The police held his employer and a woman friend as material witnesses.

International goodwill abounded at Madison Square Garden last night when the Soviet Union's national ice hockey teams engaged in a spirited contest with a group of American stars. The outcome was most appropriate from the friendship standpoint, for at the conclusion of play the score was 5-all.
The peaceful mien of Cuba, known as the "Pearl of the Antilles" since early in the sixteenth century, belies the violence that has marked her politics.
THE story of a small-town prosecutor who ignored the voice of his conscience provided an intriguing dramatic program on "Playhouse 90" over Channel 2 last night.

"He Who Must Die," Frenchlanguage drama filmed on the island of Crete by Jules Dassin, producer-director, has been named by a group of foreign film importers as the winner of the sixth annual Joseph Burstyn Award as the best foreignlanguage feature of 1958.

At exactly midnight, Greenwich Time, last Aug. 25, two Soviet scientists, looking something like divers with their moleskin face masks, special breathing apparatus and heavy furs, tried to launch a huge weather balloon.

FIFTY city-owned bridges span Gotham's many waters. The four largest are close to fifty years old or older. Brooklyn Bridge counts seventy-five years; Williamsburg Bridge, fifty-five; Queensboro Bridge will be fifty, come March, and Manhattan Bridge will touch a half-century next December.
ALBANY, Jan. 1 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller dedicated himself today to enlarging man's freedom of opportunity everywhere in a world of peace as he took office as New York's forty-ninth Governor.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 1 (UPI) -- A young pilot brought his rented plane back today from an unauthorized flight to Cuba. The plane was full of bullet holes that, he said, it had received in a dogfight with a Cuban war plane.
A record total of construction contracts in the United States for the year 1958 was assured yesterday.

The retired head of the State Banking Department said yesterday that New York banks had succeeded in bringing risk assets in line with capital after a tendency last year to let them rise beyond acceptable limits.

FIDEL CASTRO and his beard were a trademark of Cuban insurgency long before they became the symbol of victory over the Batista regime yesterday. The elimination of a "superfluous layer of administrative control at the borough level" has been effected in a reorganization of the city's Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.
The American Standards Association published new standards yesterday for uniform methods of determining floor areas of public buildings and of school buildings.

The Social Security system on which 75,000,000 American wage-earners and their families rely for protection against the economic hazards of old age was pronounced sound yesterday by a Federal advisory council.
CAIRO, Jan. 1 -- A new round-up of suspected Communists in Egypt was begun last midnight. More than 200 have been arrested so far, an authoritative source said today.

BRISBANE, Australia, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Jack Kramer, the tennis promoter, signed one member of Australia's Davis Cup team for his touring professional troupe today and appeared certain to land another before the week is over.

DALLAS, Jan. 1 -- The United States Air Force Academy and Texas Christian University football teams fumbled and booted away every scoring opportunity today in a 0-0 tie in the Cotton Bowl. It was the first New Year's Day game here in which neither team tallied since Arkansas and Louisiana State played in 1947 and the first to end in a deadlock since 1948.
BRISBANE, Australia, Friday, Jan. 2 (UPI) -- Alex Olmedo admitted today he might seriously consider a professional offer from Jack Kramer, but not for at least one year.

In the newly independent Federation of Malaya the Paramount Ruler, Sir Abdul Rahman, has addressed the Legislative Council in the Malay language. This is a part of the new nationalism in Malaya and is more significant than the surface fact. Malaya is a "plural" community. It has more than 3,000,000 Malays, more than 2,000,000 Chinese and more than half a million Indians.
Some Galapagos iguanas are living in luxury at the American Museum of Natural History, enjoying modern civilization so that science can learn about their antediluvian ancestors.
The Liberal party called upon the Rockefeller Administration yesterday to throw the state's full resources and manpower into the job of defeating the recession.

Europe's moves toward greater currency convertibility offer hope to United States exporters, the First National City Bank of New York says in its January bank letter out today. But Europe's failure to agree on the relation of the Common Market to other nations complicates investment decisions of United States concerns overseas.

NEWARK, Jan. 1 -- After a fifty-year interval control of Essex County's government today passed into the hands of the Democrats.
CALCUTTA, India, Jan. 1 (Reuters) -- The West Indies declared at 614 for five today and quickly took two Indian wickets for 29 runs for a commanding position in their third cricket test match.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 1 -For the Indian National Congress, Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's party, 1959 looks like the year of decision.
BOSTON, Jan. 1 (UPI) -- Les Colwill scored two goals as the New York Rangers took undisputed second place in the National Hockey League with a 5-2 victory over the Boston Bruins tonight.

The last big party of the debutante season, the annual Debutante Assembly and New Year's Ball, took place last night in the Waldorf-Astoria. For the fete the Grand Ballroom was decorated with white smilax enhanced with tiny white lights. It adorned the columns, balconies box fronts and stage.

Net operating earnings of the Bank of America, National Trust and Savings Association, San Francisco, were $77,018,825 or $3.01 a share last year, S. Clark Beise, president, reported Thursday. These compared with net operating earnings of $71,974,951, or $2.81 a share, in 1957.
The new Congress "promises far less danger" to civil liberties and "perhaps some positive gains," the American Civil Liberties Union said in its annual report yesterday.

The "little old lady" who robbed a bank at Thirty-fourth Street and Seventh Avenue a month ago was caught yesterday trying to rob one at Thirty-fifth Street and Seventh Avenue. On Dec. 3 the "grandmotherly" hold-up woman walked out of the First National City Bank branch with $3,420.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 2 -- Gov.-elect Edmund G. Brown, in his last official opinion as California's Attorney General, ruled today that state-supported colleges could not subsidize fraternities that restricted membership on racial or religious grounds.
Panama has served notice on the other maritime members of a new United Nations agency that it intends to play a major role in its deliberations from the outset.

RALEIGH, N. C., Jan. 2 (AP) -- Two young Negro boys, sent to training school after a kissing incident involving white girls, will be returned to their families as soon as proper home care and guidance can be assured, a North Carolina official sad today.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 2 (Reuters) -- The English touring cricket side bowled itself back into the second test match against Australia during the closing hour of the third day's play today.

The new year is being greeted by a lively market for new capital. More than $350,000,000 of new debt securities, both corporate and local government, are slated to be marketed by investment bankers next week.

BOSTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Shoe workers in Boston, Lynn and Salem ratified a new two-year union contract today. Locals in three other areas vote on it Monday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Pentagon ended today its contract with the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation for J-38 engines. It had previously canceled the Goose missile, which used the engine.
CAIRO, Jan. 2 -- The honeymoon of the Iraqi Government and the Communists still was progressing brightly two weeks ago.
LONDON, Jan. 2 -- The reserves of gold and convertible currencies held by Britain as central banker for the sterling area fell by $145,600,000 last month.
The new 5,100-ton Polish freighter Krynica unloaded cargo here yesterday and will sail early next week to make other calls at United States ports before returning to Poland.

PARIS, Jan. 2 -- Efforts have been made in the last few days to interpret the common monetary action by ten European nations as a reconciliation between Britain and France and between the two parts of Europe that they led in negotiations on the common market.
PARIS, Jan. 2 -- Hopes for Socialist participation in the next French Cabinet, to give it a broad "national" character and Left-wing sanction for unpopular economic measures, faded today.

HAVANA, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Armed Cuban rebels fired on The Havana Post building today and temporarily detained three Associated Press men covering the city's post-revolt convulsion. The three were released after questioning.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia Dec. 11 -- As the only highly industrialized state ever taken over intact by the Communists, Czechoslovakia provides a unique laboratory for the student of communism.

HAVANA, Jan. 2 -- Gen. Fulgencio Batista left Cuba hard-hit, but a survey taken among financial and economic experts here today indicated that recovery could come quickly.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Members of the family and friends of General Batista huddled in motel rooms today in fear of rebel sympathizers.

CAIRO, Jan. 2 -- Eugene R. Black, president of the World Bank, continued today his talks with the two leading finance officials of the United Arab Republic on settlement of financial problems between Egypt and Britain arising from the Suez war of 1956.

LONDON, Jan 2 -- The Admiralty announced today that Britain's first nuclear-powered submarine, the Dreadnought, would be based on a United States design and would not be armed with ballistic missiles.

ALBANY, Jan. 2 -- Governor Rockefeller ruled out today any increase in the state's personal income tax on returns due next April 15. But he left open the possibility of rate rises on returns due in April, 1960.

MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 2 (UPI) -- The accurate arm of Buddy Humphrey of Baylor and the talented toe of the placement artist, Phil Blazer, made the South the favorite for the tenth annual Senior Bowl football game tomorrow.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 2 -- The little Himalayan kingdom of Nepal has been offered a long-term credit of 30,000,000 rubles by the Soviet Union. This would amount to $7,500,000 at the official rate of exchange, or $3,000,000 at the more realistic tourist rate.
A Long Island war veteran has been awarded $1,500 for money he gave to a building contractor for "extras" in a house purchased under the G.I. bill of rights.
CHICAGO, Jan 2 -- Fidel Castro's lawyer in the United States said today that the Cuban Consulate here and those elsewhere had been seized to gather evidence for possible "war criminal" trials.

In 1958 the "Big Three" of the automobile industry, General Motors Corporation, Ford Motor Company and Chrysler Corporation, turned out 3,969,852 cars. That compared with 5,928,488 in 1957, a drop of 33.6 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today reversed itself and authorized the Pennsylvania Railroad to increase its New York-New Jersey commutation fares for Jersey Shore patrons by 16 cents a ride.

LONDON, Saturday Jan. 3 (AP) -- The Soviet Union will make preparations to equip an expedition to the moon which would establish an observatory and an intermediary base there for a future space flight," the Moscow radio said today.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange began on a "national" note for 1959. The year's activities started yesterday with 200 shares of National Can -- symbol NAC -- trading at 13 3/4, unchanged from the final price for 1958 on Wednesday.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 4 to 36 points (20 cents to $1.80 a bale) yesterday with the old months of March and May showing the most strength.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UPI) -- The Maritime Administration today awarded a contract for construction of an interfaith memorial chapel at the Merchant Marine Academy, Kings Point, L. I.

THIS year a number of the large Christmas group shows, always a gallery feature, will linger on into January. JERUSALEM (Israeli sector), Jan. 2 -- Rag Hammarskjold's talks with Premier David Ben-Gurion ended today with a technical discussion of ways to prevent further incidents along the Israeli-Syrian border.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- A defense worker discharged as an alleged security risk more than two years ago was cleared by the Government today, after the Supreme Court had agreed to review his case.

Bobby Fischer, 15-year-old United States chess champion, and Arthur B. Bisguier, former holder of the title, fought for five hours last night in the tenth round of the tournament for the Lessing J. Rosenwald Trophy. They adjourned on even terms after forty moves had been recorded at the Manhattan Chess Club.

Former Senator Herbert H. Lehman yesterday attacked a proposal that would transfer jurisdiction over immigration and passport legislation in the House of Representatives to the Committee on Un-American Activities.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- With a stroke of his pen at noon tomorrow, President Eisenhower will proclaim Alaska the forty-ninth state of the Union. He will then issue an order making Old Glory conform to the new situation.

The baseball commissioner, Ford C. Frick, said yesterday he was not ordering American major leaguers now playing winter league ball in Cuba to come home because of the revolutionary situation in Cuba.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- S. Hazard Gillespie Jr., president of the New York State Bar Association, has been selected as the next United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York.
Trans-Atlantic steamship lines failed to reach the 1,000,000 mark in passenger carryings in 1958, they announced last night.
The story behind the Broadway stage hit "Sunrise at Cambello" will be told on the National Broadcasting Company television network on April 5.

NEWARK, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Eddie Dixon, a Newark patrolman, was told today he must choose between being a policeman and a professional boxer.
ITHACA, N. Y., Jan. 2 (AP) -- The second round of Cornell's invitation hockey tournament produced two shutouts tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission announced today that it would not permit a group of Western railroads to increase their coach fares by 5 per cent on selected routes until the proposal had been fully investigated.
A steering apparatus failure aboard the new Moore-McCormack liner Argentina was called responsible yesterday for the collision Wednesday between the liner and the tanker Atlantic Viscountess.
The nation's money managers are continuing to tighten bank credit, according to figures made public yesterday.

The retirement of Bernard Wakefield, chairman of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., real estate brokerage concern, was announced yesterday. Mr. Wakefield and the late J. Clydesdale Cushman founded the company in 1917.
LONDON, Jan. 2 (Reuters) -- British European Airways expects to buy six Fairey rotodynes, the world's first vertical take-off airliner.
The Rev. Dr. Wendell Q. Halverson will be installed on Tuesday as General Presbyter of the Presbytery of New York.

Moves by Western European nations to freer convertibility of their currencies were praised yesterday by Philip Cortney, chairman of the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce.
HONG KONG, Jan. 2 -- Communist China plans to produce bigger harvests this year but to cultivate less land than before.
CAMBRIDGE Mass., Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Atlas earth satellite will make passages Monday visible to most of the United States.
Prices of world sugar futures fell sharply yesterday in heavy trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange following news of the collapse of the Batista Government in Cuba.
Reports of 1958 results issued yesterday by banks were marked by increased earnings.

AFTER hiding in cellars for six years, the Shakespearwrights, as they have previously dubbed themselves, have acquired a proper upstairs theatre with upholstered seats at 115 Macdougal Street. They opened in "King Lear" last evening and propose to call themselves the Players Theatre in the future.
After a New Year's Day drop, the number of donors to the New York Times Neediest Cases increased yesterday. There was a decrease, however, from the amount received on the same date a year ago.

HAVANA, Jan. 2 -- Fidel Castro proclaimed Dr. Manuel Urrutia provisional President of Cuba today as members of his revolutionary militia moved into this city from the fighting fronts.

Imports of crude oil and products in the week ended Friday, Dec. 26, averaged a new peak of 2,031,600 barrels a day, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The bunching of oil tankers in order to get the crews home for the Christmas holiday accounted in part for the rise.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -The White House said today that the fifteen trustees who will represent the public on the thirty-member board for the National Cultural Center would be announced next week.

PARIS, Jan. 2 -- Next week President-elect de Gaulle is expected to name the Fifth Republic's first Premier. Nobody can be absolutely sure of his choice until this is finally announced. Nevertheless all indications point to Michel Debre.

"A Reviewer's ABC," however, not only demonstrates the falsity of the assertion but also, and more significantly, adds a cubit to Conrad Aiken's literary stature.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 3 (Reuters) -- Prime Ministers Jawaharlal Nehru of India and Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana expressed hope today that African colonies would gain independence "through constructive and peaceful methods."

TO give any floor the elegant look of marble, homeowners can now install a new kind of plastic floor tile which closely simulates the appearance of actual marble. Made of pure vinyl, these new tiles come in various marble-like shades, and even have the translucent appearance which is characteristic of the real thing.
A Navy-gray ship has been "feeling" the harbor's pulse with delicate instruments. Now she has left her two-year task about half - complete -- for a much-needed rest and overhaul at Norfolk, Va.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla. -Work is under way in the historic bayfront area here on construction and improvements which will cost $311,665, and have been a matter of controversy, bitter at times, for several years.
HAVANA, Jan. 3 -- Maj. Ernesto (Che) Guevara, an Argentine physician who is the most famous of Fidel Castro's lieutenants, is left with only one grievance.

The Waterfront Commission is gravely concerned over the drifting back of known thugs to positions of dominance on New York's piers.
An airport costing $6,000,000 is to be built at Addis Ababa, the capital of Ethiopia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower proposed today that the United States alter its policy in Latin America by making a distinction in official attitudes toward dictators and democratic leaders.

OTTAWA, Jan. 3 -- The attitude of Prime Minister John Diefenbaker's Conservative Government toward cultural matters will be subjected to Opposition scrutiny and criticism along with more mundane affairs of economics and foreign policy when Parliament convenes Jan. 15.

Cliff Bertrand, a New York University freshman, turned in an impressive performance last night in winning the 100-yard handicap dash in a Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union track and field meet at the 102d Engineers Armory.
A city-wide police search failed yesterday to produce leads to the whereabouts of an infant girl who was kidnapped two hours after her birth Friday night in St. Peter's Hospital, Brooklyn.

On the one hand, there are the programs we have sponsored as a nation, our economic aid and loans. On the other hand, there are personal contributions we make to family, community and job -- the details with which our lives are woven.

AMERICAN inventiveness flowered at its usual healthy rate in the year just past, if not more so. For kitchen and factory, for motorist and builder, the inventions have poured forth, chiefly to save time and money, lessen effort and increase efficiency.

The change is slight, but the span of daylight now lengthens toward March and the vernal equinox. That is one thing you must say for any January: Its daylight hours increase rather than diminish. Cold may strengthen, as the old saying goes, and snow may deepen and ice may thicken on pond and river, but sunset comes later, day by day.

Our system of government permits our National Legislature this year to be overwhelmingly Democratic, while the executive branch continues for two years, at least, to be Republican. Consequently, when the Eighty-sixth Congress assembles on Wednesday. President Eisenhower will have to deal with a Senate in which there are sixty-four Democrats and only thirty-four Republicans, and a lower house in which there are 284 Democrats and 152 Republicans.

A BRONZE-AGE boy had to kill a wolf single-handed before he could wear the warrior's scarlet, the mantle of manhood. For Drem, the test was doubly difficult because of a crippled right arm. At age 9, he realized that he must work twice as hard as other youngsters to get ready for the wolf kill by his fifteenth year.

Gifts and pledges to the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts rose to $41,295,104 in 1958.
HIBBING, Minn., Jan. 4 (AP) -- With its 34-year-old captain scoring three times, the Soviet Union hockey team routed the United States' best amateurs today for the second time, 7-1.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- The Chicago Tribune published today an interview with Fidel Castro in which the victorious rebel leader said Cuba's relations with the United States would be "respectful" if the United States treated Cuba in a "friendly and respectful manner."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Secretary of Labor, James P. Mitchell, predicted today that jobs would remain scarce in early 1959 but that nonfarm employment would rise to a record before the year ended.
Many considerations, some of them literally out of this world, enter into the calculation of the Soviet space rocket's speed.
New York's weather bureau has a new "eye" with which to spot storms from farther away than ever before.

A $15,000,000 bulk-cargo marine terminal, said to be the largest publicly owned, facility of its kind in the Gulf Coast area, has been opened on the Mississippi River at Burnside, La., thirty miles below Baton Rouge.
" Aida" had its first performance of the season at the Metropolitan Opera Saturday evening. The tenor Dimiter Uzunov made his first appearance with the company as Radames. Fausto Cleva conducted.

THE big, handsome blond who paced nervously in front of the Louisiana State bench during the Sugar Bowl game on New Year's Day was unfamiliar to the vast majority of the television viewers. There even was the suspicion some fourteen months ago that he also was unknown to the members of the American Football Coaches' Association.

The police and agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation searched fruitlessly yesterday for clues to an infant girl who was kidnapped from a Brooklyn hospital Friday night two hours after her birth.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Anastas I. Mikoyan, a Soviet First Deputy Premier, will meet at noon tomorrow with Secretary of State Dulles.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- A leader in the fight to limit Senate debate said today that the issue was "somewhat in doubt," with about one-third of the ninety - eight - member Senate still uncommitted.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 4 (UPI) -- Art Wall, the quiet man from Pocono Manor, Pa., admitted he got "lucky on the greens" today and scrambled into first place at the end of three rounds in the $35,000 Los Angeles open golf tournament.

In two months, the lighting along the Franklin D. Roosevelt (East River) Drive will be four times as bright as it is now. Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack announced yesterday that work would begin today on the installation of 833 mercury vapor lamps along the drive to replace the incandescent bulbs now in use.
The nation's shipbuilding and ship-repair industry again looks to the Federal Government as its main source of support during the coming year, just as it did in 1958.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Following are some of the major issues that will confront the new Congress:
BERLIN, Jan. 4 -- A prominent West German Socialist turned his back today on a student congress called to protest the atomic armament of the West German Army.

George (Punch) Imlach, Toronto's general manager and coach, successfully confused all hands last night as the Leafs beat the New York Rangers, 4 to 2, in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden.

The New York Teachers Guild said yesterday that schools were specifically exempted from the city's safe-occupancy regulations. It called for laws limiting the number of pupils to safe numbers and for other corrective action.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The grain futures market showed some signs last week of breaking out of its prolonged slump, which carried about half the market to new low prices for the season again and again.

Surgery is still the major form of cancer treatment, according to a biennial report issued yesterday by the Memorial Center for Cancer and Allied Diseases and the Sloan-Kettering Institute for Cancer Research.

Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn successfully defended his United States chess championship by drawing in the eleventh and final round of the Lessing J. Rosenwald Trophy tournament at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday.

THE old master, Igor Stravinsky, goes on to fresh mastery in his latest work, "Threni: Lamentations of the Prophet Jeremiah." In this composition for six soloists, chorus and orchestra he has written with memorable feeling of the essence of prayer and penitence.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Three tall New York Knickerbockers were disqualified for six personal fouls each but Richie Guerin and Ron Sobie sparked the club to a 122-114 victory over the St. Louis Hawks today in the National Basketball Association.

There is no doubt that the quality of hockey being played by American boarding school skaters has improved in recent years. But, judging from the developments in the recent Lawrenceville tournament at Princeton, our schoolboys are still behind their Canadian cousins.
The city's expense budget for the fiscal year starting July 1 will be substantially above $2,000,000,000. This was conceded yesterday by sources in close touch with the city's fiscal problems.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- A new approach to the troubling issue of the right to confront accusers in loyalty-security cases is being urged upon the Supreme Court.
The Board of Regents has proposed that the state increase aid to education by $123,343,000 for the 1959-60 school year. The board's recommendations were disclosed yesterday.
Joseph F. Carlino, majority leader of the State Assembly, said yesterday that the institution of a withholding system for state income taxes would not necessarily result in a "double bite" this year.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 4 -- Argentina has renewed assurances to her European creditors that they will receive full payment on schedule for $450,000,000 of consolidated debt.

The Hoffa-Feinstein plan to picket the police must have blown away any idea that "unionization" would be a boon to members of the force. It also let loose a fury of public protest and stirred Mayor Wagner to vigorous action against Mr. Feinstein and his objectives.
Retailers throughout the country regard the outlook for the first half of 1959 as good, according to a survey completed by the National Retail Merchants Association.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Texas leadership of the Democratic party has arrived in the capital with a strategy for the first phase of the Eighty-sixth Congress.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 4 -- For the first time in the thirty-five year corporate history of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer the company now has in its employ a member of the Goldwyn family. Samuel Goldwyn Jr. has joined the studio as an independent producer at the invitation of Sol C. Siegel, head of studio operations.
The Long Island Rail Road has taken advantage of a buyer's market in used passenger coaches to add some refurbished equipment to its car fleet.

PARIS, Jan. 4 -- The Batista regime's collapse in Cuba might be said to have particular interest in this present age. For this is an age par excellence of military dictatorships. The world is accustomed to that phenomenon in Latin America. But, of recent years, its spread in Europe, Asia and Africa has led political analysts to seek reasons for the trend.

ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- Governor Rockefeller announced today his choice of James William Gaynor as State Housing Commissioner at $20,000 a year. Mr. Gaynor is former executive director of the New York City Housing Authority.

This port's noisy air, sea and whistle salute was used 220 times last year to greet maiden arrivals. The vessels ranged in size from the 428-ton Consul Horn to the 30,029-ton liner Hanseatic. The Hanseatic was not a new ship, but a conversion of the liner Empress of Scotland.

ON his first and only previous visit to the United States, in 1936, Anastas Ivanovich Mikoyan was mainly impressed by corn flakes, puffed wheat, Eskimo pies, automats and canned food. He said he thought very highly of them.
Casting has been completed for a brace of two-character plays -- "Kataki" and "Dear Liar." Both are scheduled for production late this winter.
Although consumer prices and earnings reached record highs in New York at the year-end, employment in the city was less than that in the similar period of 1957.

A program to revitalize and beautify Fourth Avenue between Seventeenth and Thirty-second Streets was advanced yesterday by the Fifth Avenue Association. The association recommended that the name of the seventy-foot-wide section be changed to Park Avenue South, since Fourth Avenue joins Park Avenue at Thirty-second Street.
The Unitarian Fellowship for Social Justice told Senator Lyndon B. Johnson yesterday it was "disappointed" that he had opposed rule changes to end the filibuster.
Many children were among the contributors yesterday to the fund for the New York Times Neediest Cases.
Twenty thousand employes of American Airlines were laid off at 12:01 A. M. today as a result of the sixteen-day strike of the line's pilots.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia -- Man's efforts to reach the moon are at present only mildly interesting for this Central African region. A feat of great moment has occurred in the bush country here with the taming of the fierce Zambesi River. A huge hydroelectric dam has been completed at Kariba Gorge, a long, narrow pass through which the Zambesi stampedes after its leap at the great Victoria Falls 250 miles upstream.

IT is less than two years since the publication of "The Crisis of the Old Order," by Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., which was the first of a proposed four-volume work entitled "The Age of Roosevelt." That the second volume, "The Coming of the New Deal,"* is published today is impressive evidence of Mr. Schlesinger's awe-inspiring industry.
ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- Republican majorities in both branches of the Legislature were pledged today to give their full support to Governor Rockefeller's entire legislative program.
The steamship charter market has started 1959 as inauspiciously as it began and ended 1958.
The number of baptized persons affiliated with the Protestant Episcopal Church increased 3.53 per cent last year to a record total of 3,274,867.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 4 -- James F. Oates Jr., chairman of the board and president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, has been named a charter trustee of Princeton University.
MOSCOW, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Following are the texts of announcements today on the Soviet Union's cosmic rocket:

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Jan. 4 (AP) -- A 20-year-old girl from Wilmington, Mass., and a 27-year-old Yonkers carpenter emerged as champions of the senior divisions in the 1959 Middle Atlantic outdoor speed skating championships today.
The New Year's Day that shook Havana was covered in just eight words in the travel diary of a 7-year-old boy from Roslyn Heights:

SYDNEY, Australia, Monday, Jan. 5 (UPI) -- Ashley Cooper, Australia's Davis Cup star and the world's first-ranking amateur tennis player, announced today that he had agreed to turn professional for a three-year contract totaling $140,000.

Handel and Milton were an unbeatable combination Saturday night at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum. "L'Allegro and Il Penseroso" is a rare example of an important composer's setting to music of major English poetry untranslated.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- As in the world outside the home, scientific developments dominate the news inside it at the International Home Furnishings Market that opened here today. It is a semi-annual wholesale showing of furnishings at which buyers replenish their stocks.

Former Senator Herbert H. Lehman said yesterday that it would be a calamity if legislation on passport and immigration matters were put under the jurisdiction of the House Committee on Un-American Activities.
A five-story building containing eighty-five apartments at 1 Club Drive, Woodmere, L. I., was bought by an investing client of Albert Friborg, attorney, for cash over mortgages of $535,000.
JAKARTA, Indonesia Jan. 4 -- Several foreign leaders, including President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic, are expected to visit Indonesia in 1959, official sources said today.

HONOLULU, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Bobby Layne of the Pittsburgh Steelers passed the Hawaii Professional All-Stars to a 47-27 triumph today over the College All-Stars in the thirteenth annual Hula Bowl football game.
Regular readers of The New York Times are so accustomed to enjoying the finest in journalism that it is easy for them to accept it without giving it any extra thought.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower wound up a ten-day holiday on his farm in Gettysburg, Pa., today and returned to the White House for his busiest time of the year.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 3 -- Parkinson's Law operates in Communist as well as capitalist lands, the Yugoslavs have discovered.

I see in the paper of Dec. 30 the headline "State Democrats Back Rent Curbs." As a dissenting Democrat I would like to submit a dissenting opinion. I don't back rent curbs or controls. Rather, I oppose them. And perhaps if I state my reasons some other people may see the danger of such controls.

The Manufacturers Trust Company reported yesterday net operating earnings of $20,505,676, or $4.07 a share, last year, compared with $20,467,206, or $4.06 a share, in 1957. The bank made no report of profits or losses from sale of securities.
Cardinal Spellman returned yesterday from a twelve-day flying tour of United States military bases overseas.

Domestic cotton prices turned firmer toward the end of last week. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed an improvement for the week of 12 to 26 points (60 cents to $1.30 a bale).
Three aircraft companies with plants on Long Island announced jointly yesterday their intention of joining forces on missile and space projects "whenever advisable."
Union photoengravers voted yesterday to accept a new two-year contract with the Publishers Association of New York City providing for a $7 wage increase over the two years and other benefits.
CAMAGUEY, Cuba, Jan. 4 -- Fidel Castro, the rebel leader, has given orders to end the general strike that has paralyzed much of Cuban life since New Year's Day.
TULSA, Okla., Jan. 4 (AP) -- Van Cliburn has been dropped from the United States Junior Chamber of Commerce's list of ten outstanding young men of 1958.
LONDON, Jan. 4 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan congratulated Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev today on the Soviet Union's "outstanding achievement" in firing a moon rocket.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 (UPI) -- The Chicago Black Hawks rallied for three goals in the second period tonight and defeated the Boston Bruins, 5 -- 3. The victory moved the Hawks into second place in the National Hockey League. They had been tied with the New York Rangers.
MOSCOW, Monday, Jan. 5 -- The Soviet Union's cosmic rocket raced today toward an orbit around the sun.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 4 -- A year ago the trend in steel mill activity was sharply downward. Last week it was up relatively sharply with order volume improving and premium time being paid to get steel out in the New Year's holiday period.
Seven physicists who hold Nobel Prizes have agreed to appear as guest lecturers on a network television program offering a course in atomic-age physics.

Basing its argument on the assumption that "the cost of good education is great but so are its benefits,"-the Board of Regents is distributing to Governor Rockefeller and members of the Legislature its 1959-60 program proposals "for the pursuit of educational excellence in New York State." This program is broad in scope, costly in dollars, breaks new ground with innovations in state policy and enlarges the state's share of responsibility for education.

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- The stock market ended the year with a bang. The Financial Times index of industrial ordinary shares on Wednesday bounded past its three-and-one-half-year high to set a new record of 225.5.
A term of derision heaped upon the investment trusts in Congressional hearings during the early Nineteen Thirties has come back to haunt the mutual funds today.
General Telephone Corporation revenues and net income set new highs for both the eleven and twelve months ended Nov. 30, 1958, the company reported over the week-end.

ZURICH, Jan. 4 -- Confidence in the economic future of Europe was so strong on the Stock Exchange here last week that heavy buying in expectation of a general rise pushed the year-end closing of many Swiss blue-chip stocks to new peaks.

FOUR years ago George F. Gels wandered into a stamp snow in town. He had no special interest in stamps; he just had time to kill. A display of new 4-cent Lincoln stamps caught his eye. He collects Lincoln items.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Jan. 4 -- Arthur Knapp Jr. and the yacht Agony from the Larchmont Y. C. won two of four races on the third day of the twenty-eighth Frosbite Y. C. regatta in Manhasset Bay today and was declared the winner with 35 points.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 4 -- The Tennessee Valley will not make any payments to the Treasury from power revenues during the 1959 fiscal year, which ends June 30.
Ch. Artru Hot Rod, a buff cocker spaniel, was no less effective at the national specialty of the American Spaniel Club last night than he had been in the event a year ago.

The assumption of power as Provisional President of Cuba by Dr. Urrutia yesterday ends one phase of the revolution. The final scene in one of the most extraordinary dramas in the history of Latin America is due tomorrow when Fidel Castro arrives in Havana.
ROME, Jan. 5 -- Pope John XXIII applauded today at a special performance of "Assassinio nella Cattedrale," an Italian operatic version of T. S. Eliot's play "Murder in the Cathedral."

We who worry over the growing unpopularity of Americans in Canada rejoiced over the Hays-Coffin Report, which showed genuine desire on our part to remove causes of misunderstanding. But our Administration at once wrecked its effect, first by tightening restrictions against importation of Canadian oil and metals, secondly by a blow to Canadian pride in the Seaway, which Canadians consider 90 per cent a Canadian achievement.

A Carnival in Rio, the eighth annual Carioca Ball, will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on Jan. 23. Sponsored by the Brazilian Cultural Society, the event will establish the Carmen Miranda Memorial Fund, named for the late Brazilian film actress and singer, and benefit the New York Heart Association.

A Marine Corps major was mugged and robbed in midtown Manhattan early yesterday, but he noted the license number of the automobile in which his assailants fled. The police found the car less than an hour later and arrested two suspects.
James R. Hoffa faces new curbs from the court-appointed monitors of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 5 -- State assistance in a study of ways to reduce alcoholism in Westchester was asked today by the County Mental Health Board. A grant of $50,000 a year for three to five years was proposed to the State Health Resources Board in Albany.

IT used to be a young painter's privilege to lean on tradition until the force of accumulated painting experience carried him naturally beyond it. But a time came when experiment seemed an end in itself and the echo of a tradition in a young painter's work became a source of embarrassment.

Soviet Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's handsome gift to Cyrus S. Eaton, Cleveland industrialist, arrived here yesterday. It was a team of three matched horses, known as a troika, and a two-wheeled carriage for them to pull, also known as a troika.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 5 -- Twentieth Century-Fox Television is preparing a series of ninety-minute filmed dramas to be offered for presentation once a month starting next September. The shows will be produced personally by Martin Manulis, executive head of production, who introduced the Columbia Broadcasting System's "Playhouse 90" programs.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Jan. 5 -- A Federal Court judge permanently restrained the Commerce Oil Refining Corporation today from constructing a $55,000,000 refinery at Jamestown R.I.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 5 (AP) -- Officials of some of the nation's smaller colleges sat down today to discuss common problems. They spent most of the time on the first item on the list -- money.

Arthur J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, and State Supreme Court Justice J. Vincent Keogh will address the Brooklyn Real Estate Board on Jan. 15 at a dinner in the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 5 -- The South African Government is trying to ban social gatherings in Johannesburg that are attended by non-whites.
In San Juan, P. R., there is a 10-year-old stud horse named Battle Morn that is owned collectively by the 3,000 shareholders in the San Juan Racing Association.
Visitors to Central Park this summer will no longer have to worry about the meaning of the hieroglyphics on the obelisk behind the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
The nation's two leading maritime unions announced plans yesterday for a joint attempt at organizing the crews on 10,-000,000 tons of American-owned shipping flying foreign flags.
A four-alarm fire fifty feet from Long Island Rail Road tracks in Forest Hills, Queens, kept thousands of commuters from getting home on time last night.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 5 -- A controversy within the Government has delayed Argentina's exchange reform. The Central Bank postponed today the opening of free trading in the peso from Wednesday to next Monday.
Marie Torre, television columnist for The New York Herald Tribune, began a ten-day jail term yesterday for refusing under Federal court order to disclose a source of information.
Detailed designs for jet and turboprop freight planes have been proposed by United States and foreign manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (UPI) -- Mrs. Clare B. Williams, assistant chairman of the Republican National Committee, said today that the Democrats had used "falsehoods of fear and doubt about America's accomplishments" to win the November elections.
A 2-year-old boy was burned to death yesterday in a tenement fire, despite the efforts of a janitor who helped rescue three brothers.

Six Finnish girl gymnasts arrived at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday for a tour of exhibitions and contests in the East, South, Middle West and Canada. They will be joined today by seven male members of the team who had arrived earlier for competition in Sarasota, Fla.

Columbia University will get a large share of the several-million-dollar estate left by Henry Krumb, a mining executive and former university trustee. This was learned yesterday when Mr. Krumb's will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court.

The number of persons employed part time in the United States has been increased. Whether that can be attributed to the financial effects of Christmas or to the longer range aim of owning, eventually, a second-hand car it is hard to say.
JUNEAU, Alaska, Jan. 5 -- The axe fell today on Alaska fish traps.
SALLY VICTOR, one of the few gifted and successful custom milliners left in America, could never be called a "mad hatter."
First National City Bank of New York is asking brokerage houses and other Wall Street customers if they would be inconvenienced by removal of the bank's headquarters uptown.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 5 (AP) -- The United States Civil Rights Commission won the right to look at voter registration files today. In turn, however, it abandoned its attempt to force Alabama officials to testify about Negro voting.
A New York ear specialist, Dr. Samuel Rosen, has been invited to deliver the main address at the Indian Association of Otolarynologists' annual congress on Monday in Gwalior, India.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The United States raised serious new questions today about the reliability of a proposed international inspection system in monitoring an atomic test ban.

Garrett Co., one of the country's oldest vintners, has leased a floor in the office building nearing completion at 360 Lexington Avenue, at the northwest corner of Fortieth Street. The lessee will move early next year from the Bush Terminal Building in Brooklyn, where it has been a tenant since 1917.
Lower interest rates during last year's recession and rising expenses continue to be reflected in the operating earnings of major New York City banks.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The Executive Board of the National Basketball Association today upheld the league president's refusal to allow a protest by the New York Knickerbockers of a game lost to Cincinnati Dec. 3.

ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- In her first news conference since becoming New York's First Lady, Mrs. Nelson A. Rockefeller sidestepped lithely about the Executive Mansion this morning, sometimes in stocking feet, discussing modern art, hobbies, and politics -- but not the Presidential race of 1960.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The twelve Federal Reserve Banks reported today that their earnings fell last year for the first time since 1955.
The city's first license for legalized bingo was issued yesterday to the Church of the Holy Resurrection, 675 East 183d Street, the Bronx.

Adjourned games, with one exception, were decided last night in the annual United States championship tournament for the Lessing J. Rosenwald Trophy at the Manhattan Chess Club. Bobby Fischer retained the title Sunday night.
LONDON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Seven hundred women working for British European Airways have been ordered to shorten their matron-length skirths next month.

Crisp stalks of celery from California and Florida are now in abundance and are priced at about 25 cents each. This attractive price makes the vegetable a logical candidate for Creole Baked Celery. Prepared in this manner, the celery makes a good accompaniment for a meat loaf or baked ham.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- A proposal to give the House Committee on Un-American Activities jurisdiction over immigration and passport bills was killed today.

BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, B. W. I., Jan. 5 -- Three men and a woman who took off from the Canary Islands in the balloon Small World twenty-four days ago floated into Barbados by sea today at the end of a 3,000-mile Atlantic crossing.

Casey Stengel's great urge to shift players from one position to another hasn't diminished. In fact, with the opening of another spring training not far away, New York fans may as well get ready for the inevitable and sometimes mystifying maneuvers the Ol' Perfessor has in mind for 1959.

WASHINGTON, Jan 5 (AP) -- Seventy-six private power companies will seek to justify, in a hearing scheduled to open tomorrow, the expense of a series of advertisements attacking public power as unfair competition.

LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Jan. 5 -- African troops commanded by Belgian officers patrolled the African quarter of this city tonight after rioting that cost fifteen Negroes their lives and injured about 100.
Legislative approval of State Judicial Conference proposals to modernize the court structure was urged yesterday by the Committee on Law Reform of the New York Chamber of Commerce.

New York has become a leading importer of black-market babies, and the chief sources are Chicago, Miami and Greece, according to testimony yesterday before the Joint Legislative Committee on Matrimonial and Family Laws.

Under different political circumstances the completion of the first half of the vehicular tunnel linking Kashmir and India would be hailed as a great engineering feat and an imaginative economic enterprise. But as long as the present tension between Pakistan and India over the ultimate disposition of Kashmir remains it becomes a further aggravating factor in an unhappy dispute.
The resignation of Mrs. Bernice P. Rogers as Deputy Buildings Commissioner was announced yesterday by Commissioner Peter J. Reidy. He called her "a competent and dedicated public servant."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Yields of this week's ninety-one-day and 182-day Treasury bill issues moved in opposite directions, the Treasury disclosed tonight. The shorter issue sold to yield a slightly lower interest rate than last week and the 182-day issue showed a slightly higher rate.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Eight granite pylons to be erected in Battery Park in New York will commemorate members of the armed forces who died in Atlantic coastal waters in World War II
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 4 -- The Pan American oil company today started drilling the first well in its Argentine development area at Cerro Dragon, west of Comodoro Rivadavia.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Jan. 5 -- A national budget calling for increased expenditures but holding income taxes at current levels was presented tonight to Israel's Knesset (Parliament).
A $30,196.542 shipbuilding contract for the construction of three dry-cargo ships has been signed by Moore-McCormack Lines and the Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company of Chester, Pa.
Arguments sent the weekly luncheon meeting of the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association into overtime yesterday at Leone's Restaurant.

In September last, at the third Pugwash Conference, an international group of seventy scientists from twenty nations met in Kitzbuhel and Vienna to discuss urgent problems arising from the development of weapons of mass destruction and the arms race.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan 5 -- Lawyers for Negro students will seek to block a move tomorrow to delay implementation of a desegregation mandate issued by the Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals.

With all the furor over picketing the police, the subject of an editorial in The Times of Jan. 2, the real issue of possible police unionization by the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association has been obscured by the public's preoccupation with the Teamsters' organizing threat.
The "third man" controversy in the country's airlines is being solved by putting a fourth man in the cockpit of new jet planes.
Commodity futures moved generally up yesterday on the New York exchanges but the more active items were off.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Following is the text of a statement on the detection and identification of underground nuclear tests, prepared by the President's Science Advisory Committee with the concurrence of the State and Defense Departments and the Atomic Energy Commission:
McMURDO SOUND, Antarctica, Jan. 2 -- American scientists have proposed a broadened exchange program with Russian stations in the Antarctic.
HEIDELBERG, Germany, Jan. 5 (AP) -- A 26-year-old doctor died of smallpox in a hospital today. Her death brought to two the number of persons dead after contracting the disease.
LONDON, Jan. 5 (Reuters) -- The twelfth specialized agency of the United Nations will open its first assembly here tomorrow with 300 representatives from twenty-eight nations attending.
Salary increases totaling about $19,000,000 annually are being considered for the city's teachers by John J. Theobald, the Superintendent of Schools.

Twenty-six players are being assembled for "Look After Lulu" Noel Coward's farce arriving March 3 at Henry Miller's. One member of the contingent is George Baker, a J. Arthur Rank movie star, who will come here from London.

SACRAMENTO, Jan. 5 -- Edmund G. Brown, Democrat, was inaugurated as California's thirty-second Governor here today. In his inaugural address he proposed to conduct a "responsible liberal" administration.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- President Eisenhower prepared Congressional leaders today for a new defense budget, including missile development funds, totaling $40,900,000,000. That would be about the same as for the current fiscal year.
ITHACA, N. Y., Jan. 5 -- Superior rebounding helped the Cornell basketball team defeat Columbia, 68 -- 52, at Barton Hall tonight. The game was the first Ivy League engagement for each this season.
OTTAWA, Jan. 5 -- Important talks concerning the economic issues affecting relations between the United States and Canada opened here tonight.
Eight Negro parents who have kept their nine children home from Harlem public schools took steps yesterday toward filing charges against the city school system.

The United Transit Employes Council resolved last night to seek reinstatement of two transsit employes discharged after the eight-day strike in December, 1957. The Council represents ten independent craft unions in the city subway system.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- A new or a re-elected Governor of New York automatically becomes a possibility for the next Presidential nomination of his party. This is a classic sequence in American politics. But an unusual aspect in the case of Governor Rockefeller has persuaded politicians generally that he wants his party to begin thinking of him positively in that connection, and at once.
Clients' budgets for advertising and other agency services are generally showing strong increases above 1958 levels, according to a survey of agency executives.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Sales of wholesalers fell 11 per cent in November, but exceeded those of 1957, the Bureau of the Census reported today.
Income debentures bearing 7 1/2 per cent interest and representing obligations of the Sheraton Corporation of America hotel chain are on the market today.

The Paramount Pictures Corporation disclosed yesterday the sale of its 335,200 shares in the Metropolitan Broadcasting Corporation. This equaled about 23 per cent of the outstanding shares. The stock was sold to John W. Kluge of Washington, D. C., and associates for $4,000,000 cash.
CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- Control of The Chicago Daily News, one of Chicago's two afternoon newspapers, was sold today to Field Enterprises, Inc., publisher of The Chicago Sun-Times.
PARIS, Jan. 5 -- The French educational system is to be profoundly reformed in a more democratic pattern and with special emphasis on scientific studies.

Gustaf Bolinder, Swedish explorer, author and lecturer who died two years ago, made three expeditions into the Sierra de Perija, the mountain range between Colombia and Venezuela. He was accompanied by his wife and on one occasion by their infant daughter. On their journeys they traversed a fifty-nine route never taken by white people and met hostile tribes- men whose customs, langua es and ceremonies they observed.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 5 -- West Germany told the Soviet Union today that its westward expansion since 1945 "filled the German nation with the deepest anxiety about the continuance of its national existence and political freedom."
SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Jan. 5 (UPI) -- The mystery of a ghost submarine found in the Bay of Biscay without a crew was solved tonight.
HACKENSACK N. J., Jan. 5 -- City Magistrate Edward C. Evertz postponed action today on 183 motorists who received summonses last week for driving the wrong way on a one-way street.
The Columbia Broadcasting System and American Heritage magazine will cooperate in the production of a television film series dramatizing Civil War events.
MONTICELLO, N Y, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Authorities here disclosed today the arrest of a harness racing driver accused in the alleged fixing of a race last Sept. 5 at the new Monticello track.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Southern Democrats said today they would open an extended "educational" debate against the move to abolish the filibuster when the Senate convened Wednesday.

NOW that Christmas is out of the way, practically every store in town is concentrating on dressing anybody who wants to get out of town, at least on a southern route. The resort shops are booming and some of their hottest news is in bathing suits.

One hundred housing authorities subsidized by the Public Housing Administration will offer for sale on Jan. 13 temporary loan notes totaling $72,473,000 to finance the development of low-rent projects. The notes will come due on various dates between April 10, 1959 and Feb. 5, 1960. Major borrowers are:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today threatened "appropriate enforcement proceedings" to make sure officers, directors and large stockholders reported transactions in the listed stocks in their companies.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 5 -- A rebuilt one-mile stretch of the Hutchinson River Parkway in Harrison, known as "death valley" because of its many fatalities, will be partly open to traffic at the end of the week although the rebuilding will not be completed until next summer.

ADELBODEN, Switzerland, Jan. 5 (UPI) -- Fritz Wagnerberger gave West Germany a surprise sweep of Europe's first major Alpine ski test of 1959 by winning today's giant slalom at the Adelboden international races.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The new Government of Cuba has formally requested United States recognition. The request arrived this morning from the newly named Cuban Minister of State, Dr. Roberto Agramonte.

An elaborate study of the distribution of radioactivity in water, soil and plant and animal life among the lower reaches of the Delaware River Basin has been started. The study will serve as a check for the future on the effects of the use of isotopes and nuclear-powered ships.
Earnings of the Carrier Corporation rose slightly in the fiscal year ended Oct. 31 despite a drop of $11,000,000 in sales.
The Soviet lunar rocket has a good chance of staying in orbit around the sun for millions of years in the opinion of a leading American astronomer.

The Stuttgart Chamber Orchestra, which made its bow here in 1954 under the direction of its founder-conductor, Karl Muenchinger, returned to Town Hall last night. The ensemble played Mozart's Symphony in A (K. 201), Vivaldi's Concerto Grosso in D Minor for Two Violins, Cello and String Orchestra and the Haydn Symphony No. 45 in F sharp ("Farewell").

Sally Sarell bowled a 176 game last Tuesday and raised her average to 146 plus, hitting the 1-3 pocket regularly with a good hook. The 20-year-old native of Ashtabula, Ohio, had never bowled until two months ago.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- Sales at the American Furniture Marts thirty-fifth international furnishings market, which opened here today, will be the largest in its history, Lawrence H. Whiting, president of the mart, predicted today.

The Bell System plans to introduce this month a pushbutton telephone designed for people in business who make or take many calls. Known as a "call director," the new unit is a small button-studded desktop device with a telephone cradle at the left side.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Anastas I. Mikoyan proposed tonight a top-level conference of Soviet and United States leaders to work out major problems that divide the countries.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Ken Venturi fashioned an eight-under-par 63 in an amazing comeback today and captured the $35,000 Los Angeles open golf tournament.
About half a million telephone customers in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens, Staten Island and Nassau County will start dialing their own long-distance calls in February.

LONDON, Jan. 5 -- The Colonial Office announced tonight that, as a result of the breakdown of talks with political leaders of Malta, it would revoke the island's present constitution and establish an interim regime.

Where are we going in space? A comprehensive answer to that question in the form of a long-range space program should be the immediate objective of any evaluation of the latest achievement of Soviet science and organization.
MONTREAL, Jan. 5 (AP) -- A. R. L. (Andy) McNaughton, Montreal consulting engineer, let it be known today that he had served as an international agent for the Cuban rebel leader Fidel Castro.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 5 -- President Tito's Government has dropped its charges of anti-state activity against a group of twenty-five pro-Soviet Yugoslav Communists, it was learned today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 5 -- General wage increases and participation in television residual payments are key points in the new collective bargaining contract modification proposals submitted by the Screen Extras Guild to motion picture producers.
TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 5 (UPI) -- The Japanese champion, Kosei Kamo, third-seeded in the Dixie tennis tournament, routed Rufus Ashby of Tampa, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2, in the opening round today.
CHICAGO, Jan. 5 (AP) -- There were some soft spots in the grain futures market today. But brokers on the Board of Trade said they hardly were an indication of any significant weaknes.

The Creole Petroleum Corporation virtually has completed a $7,300,000 expansion and modernization program at its terminal at Amuay, Venezuela. An affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), Creole is Venezuela's largest oil producer.

Stock prices ended the year with a show of strength. But dividend yields declined. At the year-end the dividend yield on the 500 common stocks comprising the Standard Poor's index was 3.24 per cent, well below the 4.66 per cent at the start of 1958.
The election of Charles F.[ IV[yers as president of Van N'or-I -nan Industries, Inc., was an-] nounced yesterday by Donald P. Hess, chairman.
CHICAGO, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
TRENTON, Jan. 5 -- New Jersey plans to seek the indictment of a number of union officials early next month.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 5 -- George T. Davis, local attorney, and Prentice-Hall, New York publishing company, were arraigned in Superior Court of Marin County today on charges of a conspiracy to smuggle a manuscript out of San Quentin prison.

TELEVISION today engrosses the average child to the tune of twenty to thirty hours of viewing a week. Time that was formerly spent in a variety of children's activities is now spent quietly in front of the set.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 5 (AP) -- A Nobel Prize-winning scientist today warned against concentrated applied research at the expense of basic research.

WHEN people speak of John Thomas (Pat) Clancy, the first thing they mention is his wit. They say he is a full-powered dynamo given to informality, loud shirts at outings and a love of law and of the Borough of Queens.

The Levittown Regional Center in Levittown, N. J., will begin operations late in the summer as one of the largest shopping centers in the East. When completed, the center will have sixty stores in six master buildings and parking space for 5,000 cars.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Housewives in hundreds jammed small food stores here today as a strike-lockout involving more than 1,000 chain stores continued.

Today's new film is "The Life and Loves of Mozart," a German-language drama with English sub-titles, at the Seventy-second Street Playhouse, 346 East Seventry-second Street. The Bakros International Films release was directed by Karl Hartl and stars Oskar Werner.
A diaper and a note purportedly written by the kidnaper of a newborn infant in Brooklyn were found in a Coney Island subway station yesterday as the police pressed their search for the child.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The Administration today named Robert D. Harrison of Nolfolk, Neb. an adviser and consultant to its farm surplus disposal program today. The job carries a salary of $13,970 a year.
WASHINGTON, Jan 5 -- Secretary of State Dulles canceled his trip to Canada today because of a virus infection.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board ordered the International Typographical Union today to abandon closed-shop hiring of mail-room employes on New York City newspapers.
ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- Oswald D. Heck, the Speaker of the Assembly, threw his support today to a withholding system for the state income tax, stressing it as a way to combat "chiseling."
MADRID, Jan. 5 -- The United States commanders on the three huge Strategic Air Command air bases in Spain are skilled products of a new line in fighting men.

Chairman Francis E. Walter of the House Committee on Un-American Activities has been proposing that the Eighty-sixth Congress endow him and his committee colleagues with power to deal with immigration and passport questions, perhaps renaming the group the Committee on Internal Security. The inference might be that any citizen wishing to leave this country for a while or any foreigner wishing to come here is under suspicion of being un-American.
Economy in city operations is not just something to be preached; it must be practiced "at every level of activity," city department heads were told yesterday.

PERTH, Australia, Jan. 5 (UPI) -- Alex Olmedo, America's Davis Cup hero from Peru and Los Angeles, reached the third round in the men's singles today at the West Australian tennis championships by defeating Alick Bridge of Perth, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 2, 2 -- 6, 6 -- 3.
As the new year begins, the United States Olympic Committee shifts into high gear in its efforts to raise $1,500,000 for its activities in 1959 and 1960.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Washington let pass today without notice the second anniversary of the President's enunciation of the Eisenhower Doctrine.

RABAT, Morocco, Jan. 5. -- Rebellious Rif tribesmen in northern Morocco were given forty-eight hours today to return to order. The Government declared that the Moroccan Army would be called in if the mountain rebels did not heed this ultimatum by King Mohamed V.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (UPI) -- Former President Harry S. Truman arrived in Washington today. He told newsmen who met him at the airport that he was in town to attend the opening of Congress Wednesday when many new Democras will take their seats in the House of Representatives and Senate.
HAVANA, Jan. 5 -- Dr. Manuel Urrutia, Provisional President of Cuba, came to the capital today and took up residence in the Presidential Palace tonight.

FROM all the potboiling twaddle written about fishing, an occasional book leaps out like a fish clearing water. Such a one recently reached the bookstores: "The Atlantic Salmon" by Lee Wulff (A. S. Barnes Co., $10).
A gift of $25 came to the fund for the New York Times Neediest Cases yesterday from Carolyn Wilson in Nokomis, Fla.

CAIRO, Jan. 5 -- Talks between Eugene R. Black, president of the World Bank, and representatives of the United Arab Republic over settlement of Cairo's financial problems with Britain still were in recess today.

While a report from New Jersey had a Councilman rallying to the side of Eddie Dixon yesterday, the Newark middle-weight underwent a physical examination here for the most important date of his dual career.
The city is full of buyers from stores throughout the country. More are coming in each hour. Hotels are jammed, and showrooms of manufacturers are taking on the appearance of a subway crush.
GUATEMALA, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Guatemala announced today that she was establishing a Navy with the primary duty of routing fishing boats and smugglers from her territorial waters.
An officer of a local of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union was accused yesterday of betraying his union's members for $1,000 and a fur coat worth $825 wholesale.
THE most that can be said for last night's Carnegie Hall performance of Hugo Wolf's "The Corregidor" is that it was another example of Thomas Scherman's zeal to present unfamiliar music.
The steel industry plans to produce 2,109,000 net tons this week. This would be the highest since the first week of October, 1957, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

The old steam ferryboat Tompkinsville was struck amidships in New York Harbor late yesterday by a tank barge driven adrift by high winds. Eighteen of her 1,800 passengers, riding from the Battery to St. George, S. I., were injured.
