ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- A complete revision of the legislative payroll system is in prospect to meet criticisms that developed last year.
Senator Richard B. Russell of Georgia was accused yesterday of adopting the racist tactics of Hitler in proposing a plan for "voluntary relocation" of Southern Negroes to other parts of the country.
WETUMPKA, Ala., Jan. 5 (P) -- A Negro school teacher accused of teaching voodooism resigned today.

WATCHING pro football on Sunday afternoons was getting to be as habit-forming as taking hashish or smoking opium. There also was something phantasmagoric about the Giants this season and the illusions of unreality they supplied were as irresistible as any narcotic.
ALMOST thirty-six years after the Theatre Guild's original production, an English version of H. R. Lenormand's "The Failures" was put on at David Ross' Fourth Street Theatre last evening.

A REASONABLY priced collection of Dan Cooper fabrics, heretofore available only at this designer's Textile House in New Hampshire, now can be ordered at retail through the Dan Cooper showroom, 10 East Fifty-fourth Street. They range from $2 to $5 a yard.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Average wholesale prices in primary markets rose 0.2 per cent during the week ended Dec. 23, 1958, but declined 0.1 per cent during the week ended Dec. 20, 1958, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The indexes for Dec. 23 and Dec. 30 were 119.3 and 119.2 (1947-49 equal 100), respectively, compared with 119.1 for the week ended Dec. 16.

LONDON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Britain agreed today to grant up to 5,000,000 ($14,000,000) in export credits to the Sudan, which sits squarely between President Gamal Abdel Nasser's United Arab Republic and British Africa.
A long tradition of feuding in the Democratic organization in Queens was kept alive yesterday as four Queens Councilmen defied the party leadership and named John T. Clancy as Borough President.

LONDON, Jan. 5 -- Prospects for a foreign ministers' conference will be influenced, perhaps decisively, by Anastas I. Mikoyan's talks with Secretary of State Dulles and other United States leaders, diplomats said today.

MOSCOW, Jan. 5 -- The radio transmitting system of the Soviet cosmic rocket went dead today. This development was announced in the day's only communique about the flight of the one-and-a-half-ton vehicle, which has broken away from earth's gravity and streaked past the moon toward an orbit around the sun.
LONDON, Jan 5 -- The demand in the stock market switched today from industrial shares to British Government securities.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association today agreed to co-sponsor a program of research and study in the field of conditioning and training of athletes. The study will be made in conjunction with the United States Olympic Development Committee.

WE often hear that a novelist seldom draws a character directly from one person in real life. He -- or she -- we are assured, takes a trait here, a look there, an experience somewhere else, to form a fictional identity. This selectivity produces splendid blond heroines or darkly malevolent villains or whatever, depending on the de mands of the story and the creative capacity of the storyteller.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The State Department denied today the United States had been weighing down Latin-American dictators with military medals.
Stocks were higher on heavier volume yesterday. Market values on the New York Stock Exchange rose about $1,000,000,000.

The New York Pro Musica's beautiful production of the medieval "The Play of Daniel," which was given last year at the Cloisters and Riverside Church, opened a week's run last night at the Chapel of the Intercession of Trinity Parish of Trinity Church, Broadway and 155th Street.
LONDON, Jan. 5 -- The Government published today a bill to liberalize the law covering mental illness.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 5 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer celebrated his eighty-third birthday today, seemingly as fit as ever and willing to make only the slightest confession to the march of time.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 5 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru appealed today for greater flexibility in the administration of justice and application of the rule of law to keep in tune with a rapidly changing society.
DETROIT, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The auto industry went back into higher output volume today after two holiday-shortened weeks that temporarily slowed its best output level of many months.
Mayor Wagner told a group of business men yesterday that his Administration was pledged to conduct city affairs on the "highest principles of morality."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Insurgent House Republicans started today the most serious challenge to the leadership of Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. in his twenty years as head of the House Republicans.

TOKYO, Jan. 6 (Tuesday) (AP) -- The International Trade and Industry Ministry said today it would limit cotton textile exports to Southeast Asia to 490,000,000 square meters (588,000,000 square yards) this year.
IF SPICES are the hallmark of a civilized cuisine, as many believe, the American kitchen seems to be maturing.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 5 -- Dr. Emilio Nunez-Portuondo, Cuba's chief representative at the United Nations under the Batista Government, has resigned.
Brooklyn's new Supreme Court building was dedicated yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The Army has protested against the substantial support it has to provide the other military services, despite cuts in its manpower and appropriations.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- A Californian was arrested at National Airport today for attempting a "citizen's arrest" of Col. G. Gordon Moore, brother-in-law of Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

Now that the deserved applause for the scientific merit of the latest Soviet rocket feat has been given, it is time for us of the West, and particularly for the United States, to assess the implications of this feat and the lessons to be drawn from it.
The International Geophysical Year has been described as the most nearly universal effort in the history of mankind.
TOKYO, Jan. 5 (UPI) -- The Chinese Communists hailed the Russian rocket today and termed it the "fruit of the leadership of the Soviet Communist party."

The second, though unsuccessful, attempt of the "Little Old Lady" to rob a bank and similar bank hold-ups in recent months call for immediate preventive measures. Not only has the job of teller become a highly dangerous occupation, but the public at large, in particular bank customers, will soon consider walking into a bank as hazardous.

WASHINGTON, Jan.5 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Dec. 27, 1958, totaled 491,938 cars, the Association of American Railroads nounced today. The report, usually issued Thursday, was delayed owing to the New Year holiday.
MINNEAPOLIS, Jan 5 (AP) -- A two-for-one stock split was recommended today by directors of the Pillsbury Company, Minneapolis Milling concern.

A sadly incomplete exhibition on "Contemporary Italian Music" opened yesterday afternoon at the New York Public Library without its principal exhibits. Because of a combination of circumstances, as yet not fully explained, a collection of composers' manuscripts, scenic designs for contemporary operas, photographs and 500 copies of an unusual catalogue, all gifts of the Italian Government to the library, did not arrive in time for the yesterday's ceremonies.

ROME, Jan. 5 -- Antoine Pinay, French Minister of Finance, had a long, confidential talk today with Pope John XXIII. Later M. Pinay conferred at length with the Vatican Secretary of State, Domenico Cardinal Tardini.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 5 (AP) -- Jay La Croix' Revara scored his third victory of the Tropical Park meeting by winning the featured seventh race today.

Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., will be merged into the General Telephone Company about March 5 if stockholders of both companies approve. This was disclosed in a proxy statement issued yesterday by General Telephone.

GENEVA, Jan. 6 -- Scientific advisers in the delegations to the Big Three conference here on prohibiting nuclear weapon testing are expected to examine together the United States report on underground explosions.
ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- The need for voting tax increases cast a noticeable pall over members of the new Legislature tonight as they assembled for the formal opening of the 1959 session tomorrow.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 6 -- The annual scholarship benefit concert of the Friends of the Westchester Conservatory of Music will be held Saturday evening at the White Plains High School. At the concert, 13-year-old Linda Eiberger, who has been a scholarship student at the Conservatory for six years, will play Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 15 in D flat.
The city made a major move yesterday to attract new industry to New York and to persuade industry already here to remain.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Some State Department officials believe that Soviet agreement to a ban on nuclear tests that would be subject to inspection has been made less likely by doubts raised yesterday on the reliability of a previously proposed control system.
Increases in industrial advertising budgets in 1959 are expected to parallel rises in consumer ad budgets, according to a study made by the National Industrial Advertisers Association.

Rose Melville, an actress who died in 1946 at the age of 68, achieved her greatest success in a play entitled "Zeb." It was launched before World War I. Miss Melville's part was an unimportant one, at the start. Her role was that of a pig-tailed teen-ager with a cute and saucy tongue and a lot of bounce.
The Transit Authority said yesterday that it would continue to redeem soap coupons for subway and bus rides for three more months.
HAVANA, Jan. 6 -- President Manuel Urrutia Lleo dissolved the Cuban Congress today.
The U. S. S. Independence, the nation's newest aircraft carrier, rested yesterday like an uneasy giant at Pier K in the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn.
CHICAGO, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
JERSEY CITY, Jan. 6 -- An ordinance that would give 3,100 city employes pay rises of up to $250 a year was passed unanimously on first reading today by the Jersey City Municipal Commission.

PARIS, Jan. 6 -- Admiral Robert P. Briscoe said today that the Mediterranean could be sealed off from enemy submarines in case of war. Admiral Briscoe, vho retired Yah. 1 as commander of the Western lliance's Southern EuroFean forces, said the snbmarine threat could be met by closing the Strait of Gibraltar
The hold-up technique of passing a bank teller a threatening note was used successfully in Brooklyn yesterday by a lone bandit.

Pearl S. Buck, author and humanitarian, testified yesterday that children of American servicemen were "dying like flies" in Korean orphanages because of delays in arranging for their adoption in the United States.

Directors of the Cerro de Pasco Corporation deferred action yesterday on the declaration of a stock dividend to common shareholders. Last year the company paid a stock dividend of 5 per cent in February while 25 cents cash was paid in March, 20 cents each in June and September and 25 cents in December.
Earnings of the Tishman Realty and Construction Company in the year ended last Sept. 30 fell to $1.50 a common share from the record $2.02 in the previous year.

Fresh garden flowers are the theme of a new collection of decorative prints by Greeff Fabrics, Inc. The eight floral designs, all of which have a contemporary look, are handprinted in gorgeous colorings on either gossamer Arnel sheer or a crisp chintz.

An insurgent stockholder group seeking representation on the board of the New York Trust Company asserted yesterday that it had the support of the "largest single ownership interest" in the bank. It said this represented nearly 3 per cent of the outstanding stock.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 6 -- The Central Bank issued today a list of products that can be imported through Argentina's new unified exchange market. With surcharges imposed and prior deposits required for most imports, the list was equivalent to a highly protectionist tariff schedule.
MOSCOW, Jan. 6 -- High-ranking Soviet Communists have accused former Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin of lying to them in his confession three weeks ago.
CHICAGO, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The grain futures market resumed its recent general upward trend today with small to moderate gains in almost all contracts on the Board of Trade.

FOR the past two decades one man has commanded more space on Boston's sports pages than any other individual. He is Theodore Samuel Williams, the controversial clouter who is the most admired and most hated man in New England. Tempestuous Ted arouses emotions in one direction or the other and few regard him with indifference.
ACCORDING to the German movie people, who should know better, the big thing in Mozart's private life was his passionate love for a young singer, who may or may not have existed at all.

Ranco, Inc., plans to expand its line of control mechanisms with the acquisition of the Wilcolator Company of Elizabeth, producer of gas and electric oven controls. The transaction involves an exchange of stock worth about $3,000,000.

The city has sold a plot of land 100 by 95 feet on the east side of Riverdale Avenue, 360 feet north of West 260th Street in the Riverdale area of the Bronx. The buyer, an investing client of John T. McCormick Jr., paid $20,000 for the plot.

The toppling of Latin-American dictators, of which Cuba's Batista is the latest example, is but a stage in the development of the ecological revolution of the Latin-American people. The ultimate goal is to become and remain an affluent society in the modern sense of the word.
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 6 (AP) -- A New Haven County Superior Court judge upheld the state in its attempt to stop five test cases challenging Connecticut's birth control law.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Two weeks ago Joseph William Martin Jr. was looking forward cheerfully to an active role as leader of a lean but loyal Republican minority in the new House of Representatives.
CAIRO, Jan. 6 -- Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, conferred here today with ministers of the United Arab Republic on the problem of Israel and the Palestine refugees.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Jan. 6 -- Rhode Island inaugurated a Republican Governor today -- the first time in twenty years.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Republican members of the House of Representatives ended today the twenty-year reign of Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr. of Massachusetts as their leader.

LATE one recent afternoon, a harried oilman telephoned from Texas to Ronald Kytan of Charles Co. Would Mr. Kytan please deliver one dozen red roses to a guest at the Ritz Hotel, London, not later than the following morning?

The most serious and revealing commentary applicable to the latest Soviet success in the space race was made by Dr. T. Keith Glennan, head of the newly created National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

SUPERSTITION doesn't die. Even in the Time of the Atom, even in an age when men shoot robot talkers and measuring agents far beyond the moon, there's still lively demand for love philters, for conjure medicines, for oils, herbs and stones to attract reluctant affection or to repel all manner of evils.

MONROVIA, Liberia Jan. 3 -- Soviet-bloc traveling salesmen are energetically bringing economic warfare aginst Western countries to West Africa south of the Sahara. The long-cherished Russian dream of obtaining a foothold in Negro Africa appears to be becoming a reality.
ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- When the Legislature convenes here tomorrow, one of the thirty-three "freshman" lawmakers will not need a Capitol map to find the Assembly chamber.
CHICAGO, Jan. 6 (AP) -- It became clear today that Joe Cronin was the solid No. 1 candidate to succeed Will Harridge as president of the American League.
HONG KONG, Jan. 5 -- An increasing number of children in Communist China are being put into boarding schools established as part of the country's new system of communes.

The Michigan Survey Research Center, in a sampling of opinion on the business outlook taken late last year, found that the American consumer had developed a sort of split personality in his view of the economic future. More families reported improvement in their private budgets than had been the case in the last previous survey of the kind, made in May and June.

Mrs. Philip Cortney is chairman of the committee arranging a gala benefit preview in which Edith Piaf will open her engagement in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. The event, which will aid the French Hospital in New York, will take place on Jan. 26.
PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 6 -- A group of religious and lay leaders has released a petition requesting Congress to eliminate the House Committee on Un-American Activities as a standing committee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Anastas I. Mikoyan met with Vice President Richard M. Nixon for more than two hours today. The Soviet First Deputy Premier used the session to further his program of promoting negotiations that might settle major differences with the United States.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, is having bad luck with his health; and since he comes as close as possible to being the foreign policy of the United States, the Administration is naturally concerned.

Mayor Wagner's announcement yesterday of a city-sponsored "industrial park" of 100 acres in the Flatlands section of Brooklyn represents precisely the kind of orderly planning of land use and encouragement of sound industrial expansion that government should be engaged in. Much of the credit goes to one of the ablest and most energetic men in the Wagner Administration, James Felt, chairman of the City Planning Commission.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- A twenty-year study of the effects of radiation on human beings was proposed today by the Committee on Pathological Effects of Atomic Radiation of the National Academy of Sciences.
The 18,500-gross ton passenger ship Leilani has been withdrawn from the San Francisco-San Pedro-Honolulu run by Hawaiian Textron, Inc.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 6 -- The Argentines sized up their austerity program today and agreed on one thing -- to spend less.

LECH - AM - ARLBERG, Austria, Jan. 6 -- The Soviet Union seems about to collect handsome dividends on a patient, long-range Middle Eastern policy. This policy quietly encouraged Kurdish nationalism during three decades. The dividends are likely to include control of Iraq's oil, disintegration of what remains of the ruined Baghdad Pact land outflanking of Turkey and Iran, two countries with which the United States has defense agreements.
LONDON, Jan. 6 -- The United States and the Soviet Union clashed briefly today at the opening session of the first assembly of the Inter-governmental Maritime Consultative Organization.
The International Ladies Garment Workers Union suspended yesterday a local official who had been indicted on charges of selling out his members.

MOSCOW, Jan. 5 -- While the Soviet rocket races out into space, earthbound Muscovites are buying up available tangerines, taking mid-year examinations and wading through slushy rains in attending to mundane chores.
SYRACUSE, Jan. 6 -- Seven Air Force men were killed and sixteen injured in a pre-dawn flash fire today in a Syracuse University barracks. Twenty others escaped, most by diving out of windows.

Consolidated net income of the Avco Manufacturing Corporation for the fiscal year ended Nov. 30 amounted to $11,597,000, equal after preferred dividends, to $1.24 a share on the average number of common shares outstanding during the period.

PERTH, Australia, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Alex Olmedo, the Peruvian star, and Barry MacKay of Dayton, Ohio, gained the semi-finals of the men's doubles in the West Australian tennis championships today. They defeated Geoff Strang and Bruce Francis of Australia, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 0.
THE secret of how to alter the looks of a room without changing its furnishings substantially is bared in part in an exhibition opening today at Bloomingdale's.
Net operating earnings of The Chase Manhattan Bank rose last year to $55,648,375, or $4.25 a share from $55,474,064, or $4.24 a share, in 1957.
Monkeys chattered, birds trilled and fish burbled last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The creatures were guests of honor at the traditional midwinter meeting of the New York Zoological Society.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 6 -- A group of scientists and physicians emphasized today that the major current poliomyelitis problem was to achieve the vaccination of 50,000,000 persons in the nation.

Stockholders of the Reynolds Metals Company will soon be asked to approve the issuance of 2,500,000 additional shares of common stock and an offering of 1,000,000 shares of new $100-par preferred stock.

The case for greater state aid to New York City's municipal colleges lies not alone in their own need for more funds, which would be sufficient reason for state interest, but even more convincingly in the argument for equitable treatment. There is good reason to hope that the 1959 Legislature will at last recognize this argument by granting substantial justice.
The forty-seventh annual appeal for the New York Times Neediest Cases has achieved the second highest return in the fund's history.
Irregular movements swept the stock market yesterday as six days of rising prices gave way to uncertainty and a moderate decline.
BERLIN, Jan. 6 -- A military academy, designed to give the East German Army a professionally trained, reliably Communist officer corps, was inaugurated in Dresden yesterday.
McMURDO SOUND, Antarctica, Jan. 3 -- Further evidence has piled up that a deep trough or valley divides East Antarctica from West Antarctica.
PARIS, Jan. 6 -- From the mass of recent economic decrees emerges the fact that France now follows a policy of economic liberalism.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Governor Rockefeller tonight appointed Maj. Gen. Melvin L. Krulewitch, a Marine reservist who fought in World Wars I and II and the Korean War, as chairman of the State Athletic Commission. His salary will be $16,900 a year.

Francois Mauriac and Sir Harold Nicolson, writers; Marc Chagall, painter, and Francis Poulenc, composer, have been elected honorary members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters and its affiliated National Academy of Arts and Letters.
ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- Two bills to allow commercial banks to expand their branch operations were filed tonight with the Legislature by Democratic legislators for introduction tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UPI) -- Steel industry spokesmen said today that any restrictions on importation of iron ore would hurt national defense and lead to higher steel costs.

A thirty-one-game exhibition schedule and a quick dash north has been mapped for the Yankee spring training campaign of 1959. The Bombers also revealed yesterday they were dropping their instructional school because they believed they had hit upon something better.
LONDON, Jan. 6 -- The Soviet Union may be developing Baghdad as a headquarters for penetration of the Arab world east of Suez through Communist party activities and subversion.

Mr. Hoffa is faced with a new experience this week: the necessity, under sanctions of Federal law, to obey orders rather than to issue commands -- and to rescind a good many orders he has already issued.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 6 -- Another deconcentration order against the German industrial empires that created the Nazi war machine has apparently been jettisoned.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The nation's two largest mail order houses have issued their 1959 spring and summer catalogues. One raised slightly the prices it charged a year ago, while the other made a slight reduction.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 6 -- Jurists from Asian and African countries have urged that in the newly developing free nations special care be taken to protect the freedom of the individual.
LONDON, Jan. 6 -- Two young Englishmen went on a hunger strike today as part of a campaign against the installation of United States rockets in Britain.

The parents of Lisa Rosa Chionchi, who was kidnapped from a Brooklyn hospital less than three hours after birth last Friday night, made a desperate promise yesterday: to allow the kidnapper visiting rights, if only the child would be returned unharmed.
LONDON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Sir Winston Churchill welcomed tonight the return of West Germany to the European community and praised France's role in helping to bring the Germans back.

The New York State Power Authority took first steps yesterday toward the permanent financing of the $720,000,000 Niagara Project, hydroelectric twin of the authority's $335,000,000 St. Lawrence Project now nearing completion at Massena, N. Y.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The National Alliance Football Committee (N. A. F. C.) today made one penalty change in the football rules that govern 20,800 high schools and small colleges.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Jan. 6 (UPI) -- Tom Nugent, a New Englander who turned Florida State University into a football power during the last six years, signed a four-year contract today as the head coach at the University of Maryland.
More than $43,000,000 in utility and railroad securities are being offered to investors today. The offerings are:

OTTAWA, Jan. 6 -- United States and Canadian Cabinet members ended two days of talks today without reaching any definite answers to the questions before them. They decided instead to continue the study of the problems.
Frank D. O'Connor, Queens District Attorney, ordered a "full investigation" yesterday of charges that James J. Crisona had offered trust funds in return for political aid.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- On the eve of the formal opening of the new Legislature tomorrow, 594 bills had been pre-filed for introduction in the Senate and 796 for introduction in the Assembly. Last year 524 were pre-filed in the Senate and 699 in the Assembly.
HARTFORD, Jan. 6 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff, will be sworn in tomorrow for a second four-year term

The president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday he was confident his company would develop a missile capable of destroying enemy intercontinental ballistic missiles (ICBM's).
Futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 8 points (40 cents a bale) lower to 12 points (60 cents) higher than on Monday.

Second place in the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association, the target they set for themselves, appeared to be safe for the Knickerbockers as they turned back the Syracuse Nationals, 118 -- 108, at Madison Square Garden last night.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 6 -- The Justice Department and lawyers for Negro students urged today that the Little Rock school board be ordered to start immediate action to proceed with desegregation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- A toss of a silver dollar resulted today in the designation of E. L. Bartlett as the senior Senator from Alaska. The junior Senator from the new state will be Ernest Gruening.
PERTH, Australia, Jan. 6 (AP) -- "It hurts me, but I am not going to let it get me down," Alex Olmedo said today after reading of more criticism in the United States over America's Davis Cup victory.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 6 -- The old Hollywood complaint that theatre owners spend too much time on the golf course and not enough time tending the "store" now has support from the Motion Picture Research Council. This is the scientific and engineering branch of the Association of Motion Picture Producers.

The Appellate Division, First Department, disbarred two lawyers and censured a third yesterday. The court acted on disciplinary proceedings brought by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- President Eisenhower soon will ask the Senate to approve a number of shifts of United States Ambassadors in Africa, the Middle East and southeast Asia.
ALBANY,Jan. 6 -- Farm leaders of the state urged Governor Rockefeller today to help them block expansion of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters into the field of agriculture.

The Erie Railroad, which operated at a deficit of more than $4,000,000 in 1958 and which had to postpone many projected additions and betterments to its plant, may soon be able to increase its working capital by several millions of dollars.
Robert Moses, oblivious of time, returned yesterday from a winter holiday with his sights set firmly on three major objectives.
Gloria Vanderbilt and Jean Pierre Aumont will star in a television dramatization of a Leo Tolstoy story, "Family Happiness." The play will be directed by Sidney Lumet, husband of Miss Vanderbilt.
ALBANY, Jan. 6 (UPI) -- Skiing conditions reported today to the State Commerce Department:

LONDON, Jan. 6 (UPI) -- Stewardesses of the British European Airways seized the initiative today in the battle of the hemline and demanded a completely new and better-fitting uniform. The company conceded that improvements could be made.

The Bendix Aviation Corporation had a net income in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30 of $21,171,902, or $4.18 each on 5,063,825 shares outstanding. Malcolm P. Ferguson, president, reported yesterday. In the previous fiscal year the net was $27,499,034, or $5.44 each on 5,056,788 shares.
ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Is there a politician in the house? Apparently not. At least no politician here is admitting it this week.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (UPI) -- The Bureau of Mines said today that octane ratings for gasoline sold in stations throughout the United States reached record levels during 1958.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The Army told the Interstate Commerce Commission today that railroad passenger service was necessary for adequate defense plans.

BOSTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The National Fire Protection Association said today that the ninety-three deaths in a recent Chicago fire was "an indictment of those in authority who have failed to recognize their life safety obligation in housing children in structures which are fire traps."
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 6 (AP) -- Jim Henry scored 29 points in leading Vanderbilt tonight to an astonishing 75-66 victory over Kentucky's basketball team, ranked No. 1 in the country.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The United States probably will recognize the Provisional Government of Cuba tomorrow.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Jan. 6 -- Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower's recommendation to President Eisenhower that the United States adopt a correct but not cordial attitude toward Latin-American dictators has passed unnoticed here. Such a policy toward the Dominican Republic has been in effect for some time.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Strong liberal blocs in both parties will confront the old Senate leadership with immediate challenges as the heavily Democratic Eighty-sixth Congress convenes tomorrow.
CHICAGO, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company reported record sales of natural gas as sub-zero cold spurred fuel consumption.

Continued growth in the use of cellophane as a packaging material was forecast yesterday by Donald F. Carpenter, general manager of the film department of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc. Mr. Carpenter also announced that du Pont's new cellophane plant at Tecumseh, Kan., was in commercial production.
BOSTON, Jan. 6 (UPI) -- A rare Florentine painting of the sixteenth century, believed lost for more than a century, was put on display today by the Boston Museum of Fine Arts.
Queens Republicans are looking hopefully toward recapture of the Borough Presidency in this November's off-year election as a result of Democratic dissension.

IT must be a heady experience to have an orchestra like the Philadelphia at one's disposal. The sumptuous tone, rainbow of colors and vividness of response that can be summoned up would undoubtedly tempt the most ascetic of conductors to make a bold splash.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 6 -- The Syrian Minister of Agrarian Reform Mustafa Hamdun, has issued a decree confiscating about 35,000 acres of land from thirty-nine Syrian landowners, according to information here.
Thirty-seven bids and offers were received for 110 airplanes by the Aircraft Exchange, Inc., in its first week of business that ended at 3 P. M. yesterday.

A COUPLE of first-rate sailfish tournaments start in Florida this coming week-end and the Broadway odds today are eight to five that women will win them. Nobody can win any money betting against odds-layers.

Although the year began with a cold wave, the 1959 proxy fight season shows every evidence of warming up rapidly. Shivering investors may be glad to hear that the year's first indicated battle for corporate control is being fought in sunny Hawaii.

All New Yorkers know that Broadway bends at Eleventh Street. Tradition has it that Hendrick Brevoort had prevailed upon the city fathers when planning to extend Broadway to the north to turn the street enough off the straight line to preserve a particularly beautiful broad tree on his farm.

NASSOS DAPHNIS, who was born in Greece in 1914 and has lived in the United States since 1930, is a nonobjective painter whose recent work is on view at the Castelli Gallery, 4 East Seventy-seventh Street.

The scholarship fund of the Skidmore Alumnae Club of New York will gain as the result of an exhibition of paintings and sculpture by art department faculty members and alumnae of the college. The event will take place at the James Graham Sons Gallery, 1014 Madison Avenue, from Jan. 19 through Jan. 31.
LEOPOLDVILLE, Belgian Congo, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Order was gradually being restored here today after bloody rioting by Africans demanding independence.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 6. (UPI) -- The Government acknowledged today that the United States had the weapons to wage germ warfare during the Korean War but said they were not sent overseas.

As chairman of the Superior Officers Council of the New York City Police Department, representing the 5,000 higher-ranking officers and detectives of the department, and president of Sergeants Benevolent Association, I wish to express my endorsement of your Jan. 5 editorial entitled "Mayor Wagner and the Police."
A sharp rise in visitors to museums in the city is creating an almost insurmountable problem of protecting art treasures from damage, museum officials declared yesterday.
JOHN Frederics is the Clark Gable of the millinery industry.

A new edition of "The Autobiography of Mark Twain," containing betwen 30,000 and 40,000 words of material not heretofore published, will be issued by Harper on Feb. 4. The book was edited by Charles Neider from the original manuscript left at Mark Twain's death and now in the Mark Twain collection at the University of California, Berkeley.

The African independence movement, which aims at "total liberation" of the continent from colonial rule, has now spread to the hitherto immune Belgian Congo. But in disregard of the doctrine of nonviolence proclaimed by its foremost exponent, Prime Minister Nkrumah of Ghana, it has exploded into prolonged anti-white riots in the colony's capital of Leopoldville.
The National Hockey League, in a move aimed at discouraging farcical player transactions, yesterday took the first step toward increasing the waiver price from $15,000 to $25,000.

The Boston, Mass. Metropolitan District borrowed $6,372,000 yesterday on serial bonds due from 1960 to 1989. The securities were sold at public bidding to a syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at an interest cost of 3.5847 per cent.
SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Ashley Cooper made his professional tennis debut tonight. The Australian star played for nothing and lost.

AKRON, Ohio, Jan. 6 (AP) -- An Akron man said today that he and other Americans held prisoners in Cuba by Batista supporters were virtually neglected by United States officials during the months they were imprisoned.
The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association charged Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy yesterday with "totalitarian and uninformed opposition to a grievance procedure."
ALGIERS, Jan. 6 -- French civilian officials are settling down to administrating Algeria after nearly eight months of military control.

DUBLIN, Jan. 6 -- Sean F. Lemass, Minister for Industry and Commerce, said last night he had proposed to give two United States companies exclusive rights to hunt for oil in Ireland. He said he also had proposed to grant drilling licenses for an unspecified period.
While Fidel Castro was leading his forces to victory in Cuba, his 9-year-old son, Fidel Jr., was quietly living and attending school in Queens.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Octavus Roy Cohen, well-known writer of books, plays and motion pictures, died today of a stroke. He was 67 years old.
One of the most spectacular bursts of peacetime growth in a maritime nation's merchant marine was registered by the Greek fleet last month.
KANSAS CITY, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The next big step in education should be the creation of Federal scholarships by the new Congress, former Senator William Benton of Connecticut urged today.
LONDON, Jan. 6 -- The strength of British Government securities was again the feature of the stock market here today.

American Machine and Foundry Company has called for redemption on Feb. 9 at 103 3/4 and accrued interest its 4 1/4 per cent debentures due on July 1, 1981. The called securities are convertible into common stock at $31.25 a share at Irving Trust Company, 1 Wall Street, until Feb. 4.

WITH its annual "Nutcracker" series most successfully behind it, the New York City Ballet last night returned to the repertory system, which will prevail throughout the final four weeks of its season at the City Center.
At a traditional installation service last night, the Rev. Dr. Wendell Q. Halverson became the new General Presbyter of the Presbytery of New York.
MOSCOW, Jan. 6 -- Soviet scientists asserted today that their cosmic rocket, which now is heading into an orbit around the sun, was "our first attempt to launch a new interplanetary rocket."

Bitter cold aggravated by gale-force winds continued to plague the metropolitan area yesterday but the weather was expected to start moderating slowly today. The Weather Bureau said wind gusts, which reached seventy miles an hour yesterday, would diminish to fifteen to twenty-five miles an hour today. men. Mr. Cavanagh warned against forcing oil heaters beyond their capacity, and against leaving children unattended.
TULSA, Okla., Jan. 6 (UPI) -- The United States Junior Chamber of Commerce made known today its selection of America's ten outstanding young men of 1958.
LONDON, Jan. 6 -- The British aviation industry introduced today another entry to the list of faster-than-sound combat aircraft.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 6 -- The political machine of Col. Gonzalo N. Santos, power behind the government of the State of San Luis Potosi for eighteen years, has suffered a second major setback in the resignations of the state treasurer and vice treasurer.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation today announced revisions in the prices of some stainless and low-alloy steel products. The price changes are to be effective tomorrow.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 6 -- A Federal District Court jury failed today to reach a verdict in the income tax fraud trial of two Chattanooga Teamster officials.

New selling by Cuban interests yesterday continued to depress world sugar contracts on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The market was influenced by the belief that activity in Cuba would become normal and the sugar flow would be uninterrupted.
Curt Conway, actor, has taken an option on a new play called "In the Counting House," by Leslie Weiner, described as a serious play with comic currents.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Consumer credit rose by $142,000,000 after seasonal adjustment in November, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. It was the largest rise in more than a year.
MIAMI, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Mrs. Gene Markey, the owner of the Calumet Farm at Lexington, Ky., said today that reports she planned to sell the thoroughbred establishment were "utterly ridiculous."

CINCINNATI, Jan. 6 -- The nation's college football coaches went strongly on record today in favor of returning goal posts to the goal line. With two alternative suggestions also designed to encourage field goal kicking, the American Football Coaches Association will submit the recommendation to the National Collegiate Athletic Association Rules Committee.
ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- The Legislature was urged today to permit counties to abolish junior drivers licenses if they wish.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- Without professional help, the American homemaker is usually capable of producing only chaos when she decorates her own home. This opinion was expressed here yesterday by Michael Greer, president of the National Society of Interior Designers, at the opening of the International Home Furnishings Show.

CAIRO, Jan. 6 -- Premier Amintore Fanfani of Italy arrived today for a four-day official visit to the United Arab Republic. He received a warm welcome from United Arab Republic officials at Cairo airport.

COMMACK, L. I., Jan. 6 -- Governor Rockefeller, whose paternal grandfather was noted among other things for handing out friendship dimes, has rejected one from the Smith's Lane School student council here.

The election of Walter A. Hensel as the first president of DataGraphic Systems, Inc., was announced yesterday. The company was formed recently to develop new techniques, processes and systems in the microfilm and reproduction field.
HAVANA, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The Revolutionary Government announced it would rule by decree for at least eighteen months, when new elections are planned.

NEWARK, Jan. 6 -- A rate analyst for the New Jersey State Board of Public Utility Commissioners held today that increases in commuter fares for users of Hudson River ferry service were "unreasonable" when compared with the cost of living.
MANILA, Jan. 6 -- Malaya and the Philippines agreed today on a program of bilateral cooperation in economic and cultural matters to strengthen both countries against Communist inroads.
JUNEAU, Alaska, Jan. 6 -- Weather and health conspired today to block a "full speed ahead" signal for the forty-ninth state.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- Tube Investments, Ltd., a British concern, and Reynolds Metals Company, of the United States, opponents of the Aluminum Company of America (ALCOA) in the battle for the British Aluminium Company, were reported today to be close to gaining control of the company.
Cab drivers at La Guardia and New York International Airports will be warned today not to discriminate against short-haul passengers.

With a brilliant defeat of Leonard W. Barden of England in the eighth round, Wolfgang Uhlmann of East Germany maintained his lead in the international chess tournament at Hastings, England, according to a report from London yesterday.
WILLISTON PARK, L. I., Jan. 6 -- Four members of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union were arrested tonight on an indictment growing out of a dispute with the newspaper, Newsday.

At the time when all freedom-loving Americans of both hemispheres are rejoicing over the news of the downfall of the odious Batista regime in Cuba we should not forget that some of the leading figures in that regime have sought refuge in this country.

When the Senate organizes for business today it will have before it a proposal by Senator Paul H. Douglas of Illinois, supported by other liberal Senators, to permit the majority, after a decent interval for reflection and debate, to get on with the country's business. This proposal is perhaps the most important single subject that will come before either house of the Eighty-sixth Congress.

THE Columbia Broadcasting System's "Radio Program Consolidation Plan," which went partly into effect this week, sounds on the air as if it were one more step toward local radio and away from network broadcasting.
A group of tenants at Frederick Douglass Houses is preparing to challenge rent increases that went into effect Jan. 1. The rise affected 86,000 of the city's 102,000 families in public housing.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 6 -- Yale University announced today the appointments of Prof. Brand Blanshard as chairman of the Philosophy Department and Prof. August deB. Hollingshead as chairman of the Department of Sociology. Both appointments become effective July 1.
HONG KONG, Jan. 6 -- Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China sent a message of congraculations today to Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev on the successful launching of the Soviet artificial "planet."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The Navy has used a rocket to take motion pictures of cloud formations from an altitude of eighty-five miles.

Mrs. Reinaldo Herrera of 755 Park Avenue, chairman of the patroness committee for the fifteenth annual March of Dimes fashion show, will meet with her committee members at her home on Monday afternoon.
Five New York City banks announced executive appointments yesterday.

In at least one business office in town this department has learned -- and probably in many more -- about once in every five years and usually about now, toward the year's end, department heads are encouraged by management to circulate among employes a memorandum headed something like this: "SUBJECT: Good Housekeeping."

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Jan. 6 -- Gen. Fulgencio Batista and other leading members of his Cuban Administration refused to talk on the telephone tonight when a newsman called to ask about the deposed dictator's plans.
DETROIT, Jan. 6 (UPI) -- The Soviet Union's national hockey team routed the University of Michigan-Michigan State University All-Stars, 7-3, tonight.

Blood will be given today to the New York Regional Red Cross Program at the New York Telephone Company, 140 West Street; St. Francis College, 25 Butler Street, Brooklyn, and C. W. Post College, Brookville, L. I. A bloodmobile also will call, for a community donation, at the West Brighton Armory, 321 Manor Road, Staten Island.
Bernardo Altmann, for the last nine years a member of the New York Philharmonic's 'cello section, made his solo debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The Urban Renewal Administration announced today that it had set aside more than $7,000,000 for a project on New York City's lower East Side. The agency also announced a planning advance of $244,216 for the project.
MONTPELIER, Vt., Jan. 6 -- When Vermont's Legislature convenes tomorrow for its forty-fifth biennial session it will not know for certain who will be the state's next Governor.

A proposed plan to increase teachers' salaries by $19,000,000 was criticized yesterday by two major teacher organizations. The groups -- the New York Teachers Guild and the New York Teachers Union -- said the plan did not meet the teacher salary problem.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The Justice Department again expressed the view today that of the four original applicants for Miami's television Channel 10 only one, L. B. Wilson, Inc., was now eligible to compete for the outlet.
PARIS, Jan. 6 -- The Government moved today to encourage the sharing of industrial profits by French workers and management.

The eight-story building containing thirty-four apartments and occupying a plot 60 by 125 feet at 412 West End Avenue at Eightieth Street has been sold by the Isaac Engel Realty Company. Assessed at $240,000, it was bought by the West Side Holding Corporation in a deal negotiated by Irving Bira and Joseph Lefkowitz, brokers.
TOKYO, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Japan's stock market, booming since last year, climbed to a new high today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission said today it was looking for ways -- perhaps a new law -- to bear down on the "substantial but undetermined number" of securities that were being sold illegally under false claims of exemption from regulation.

" ALL Star Jazz" finally found itself last night on Channel 2. The program starring Louis Armstrong put aside its exhibitionist tendencies, concentrated on its music and came up with a sixty-minute hit.
MEXICO CITY, Jan. 7 -- Students and representatives of labor organizations demonstrated today against Guatemala.

ALGIERS, Jan. 7 -- At least 220 nationalist rebel fighters were killed and sixteen captured in the last thirty-six hours in the biggest battle in Algeria since spring, according to French military sources tonight.

SKI SKETCH: In keeping with his oft-repeated declaration that "Skiing is the ideal winter sport for youngsters from 2 to 92," Jim Wales has purchased new skis to replace those blown off his car last year.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa renewed his attack on the Board of Education yesterday with a Charge that the board was deliberately squandering building funds to set the stage for demanding more.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 7 -- A Peronist manifesto attacking Argentina's stabilization plan made austerity an increasingly political issue today.
Thirty Cubans, mostly wives and children of aides to the rebel leader, Fidel Castro, left New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, yesterday for Havana.
SANTIAGO DE CUBA, Jan. 7 -- Raul Castro has returned to this center of Cuba's revolutionary war.
ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- Following are the highlights of the message delivered to the 1959 Legislature today by Governor Rockefeller:

NO one could ever accuse the major leagues of being a breeding ground for radicals. They have more arch-conservatives than the Union League Club, more tories than Parliament. What was good enough for father is good enough for them oven though they did make one concession to modernity by using electricity for night games instead of gas filament lamps.
IRENE OF NEW YORK is two persons: Herself and her son-in-law, Bob Greene. They aim, and succeed, in making hats that "don't knock people dead but ones people admire and want to put on."
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Thursday, Jan. 8 -- The Nationalist Defense Ministry reported today that Chinese Communist batteries fired 33,401 rounds against the Quemoy Islands yesterday.

Governor Rockefeller's first annual message to the Legislature is a confident, constructive statement of program combined with a sobering appraisal of New York State's problems. It recalls, and acts on, the main themes of the campaign that made him Governor. It is economical of words, sparing as to rhetoric.

The Swan Lake Ball a benefit dinner dance for the New York City Center of Music and Drama, was held in the Starlight Room of the WaldorfAstoria last night to celebrate the center's fifteenth anniversary.

Louis Robbins, an investor, has purchased the twelve-story and penthouse apartment building at 38 Central Park South between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas and plans to alter it to professional suites.

The Chicago Black Hawks have been kicked around for many a season in the National Hockey League. But last night the charges of Coach Rudy Pilous more than demonstrated that they are taking no more such abuse.
LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Britain accorded formal recognition today to the new regime in Cuba.

DURING the year 1923, the American painter Marsden Hartley became deeply absorbed in the possibilities in lithography and experimented freely. The prints of that year, together with drawings ranging from 1908 almost to 1943, the year of Hartley's death, are exhibited at the Babcock Galleries, 805 Madison Avenue.

Imports of oil last week were at a historic high for the second consecutive week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. In the week ended last Friday, they totaled 2,145,200 barrels a day, compared with the former peak of 2,015,400 in the preceding week.
The armed guard at a neighborhood bank in Brooklyn was startled yesterday morning to see an elderly man he knew and respected walk into the place and shout: "Every one down on the floor!"
A bill to curb alleged "distress" sales that presumably require merchants to dispose of merchandise at sacrifice prices was signed yesterday by Mayor Wagner. It took effect at once.

France will pay interest of 4 1/2 to 4 7/8 per cent if it is required to borrow under a $200,000,000 two-year stand-by credit agreement it has negotiated with a group of United States commercial banks. The agreement supplements short-term credits totaling $250,000,000 negotiated with central banks in West Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium and Britain.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- George H. Pierce, 86-year-old Republican Senator from Olean, became chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee today in one of fourteen shifts in the State Senate committee chairmanships. All new chairmen are Republicans.
The fund for The New York Times Neediest Cases was, helped yesterday by a gift from a group of mentally retarded children in an upper West Side school.

Beveridge Webster, who gave the first of three piano recitals last night in the Lexington Avenue Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, often has been called a pianist's pianist. He is a strong, dependable artist with the soundest of musical instincts, and when in top form he is a superb technician.

The Dance Committee of the New York Public Library will sponsor a salute to the New York City Ballet in honor of its tenth anniversay. This will take the form of a retrospective exhibition of the company's achievements during its official existence under its present name and for the fifteen formative years preceding.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -An aluminum dome, 200 feet in diameter, will dominate the United States exhibition in Moscow next summer, it was disclosed here today.
TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 7 (AP) -- The top-seeded men's and women's singles players won today in the Dixie international tennis tournament, but two of the seeded men stars were eliminated.
That legend of "local boy makes good" has found a new angle in Puerto Rico.

April 23 is the opening date for "Destry Rides Again" at the Imperial. Andy Griffith is the only performer set for the Harold Rome-Leonard Gershe musical, the staging and dancing of which will be devised by Michael Kidd.

The Institute of International Education announced yesterday the election of four new trustees. They are: Henry W. Balgooyen, executive vice president of the American and Foreign Power Company; Robert W. Dowling, president of the City Investing Company; David M. Keiser, chairman of the Cuban-American Sugar Company, and Blanche Thebom of the Metropolitan Opera Company.

" VANESSA'' returned to the Metropolitan Opera last night for the first time this season. The opera with a score by Samuel Barber and a libretto by Gian-Carlo Menotti has been granted an opportunity to make a place for itself in the repertory.
The shipping industry was told yesterday to include in its budgeting for proposed technological improvements "any human costs" that might result from ensuing decreased waterfront employment.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- One of the first resolutions introduced as the new House of Representatives convened today would authorize further investigation of the Federal regulatory agencies.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- A coroner's jury today reported it was unable to determine the cause of a fire in Our Lady of the Angels Parochial school on Dec. 1. The blaze took the lives of ninety pupils and three teachers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Congress gave Alaska, the fortyninth State of the Union, a hearty welcome today. It also made plans for early consideration of the Territory of Hawaii as the fiftieth.
ALBANY, Jan. 7 (UPI) -- Skiing conditions as reported to the State Commerce Department today:

Business continued to improve in December, according to the latest monthly review of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. However, it said, the trend of the economy will depend in large measure on a rise in capital spending.
The N. B. C. Television Network has followed the lead of the C. B. S. Television Network in abandoning its so-called "must buy" policy governing the acceptability of advertisers' orders.
BAKERSFIELD, Calif., Jan. 7 (AP) -- Leslie O. Stafford, a laborer, emerged smiling today after twelve and a half hours underground in a collapsed cesspool.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 7 -- Leon Uris, whose most recent novel, "Exodus," deals with the development of the State of Israel, next will turn his attention to the drama of the Warsaw ghetto, which the Germans destroyed in World War II.
Melvin Levin Krulewitch, the newly appointed chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, said yesterday that he would announce no policies until he had become familiar with his duties.

ALBANY, N. Y., Jan. 7 -- A bill to license chiropractors, which has been debated in New York for years, was introduced again today in the first session of the Legislature by Senator Dutton S. Peterson, Republican, of Odessa.
ALBANY, Jan 7. -- Following is the annual message delivered today by Governor Rockefeller to the State Legislature:
The Ford Foundation announced yesterday that twenty governmental leaders and scholars from Yugoslavia would study and travel in this county in 1959 and 1960.
Pleas for higher salaries for teachers and other school employes were voiced yesterday at a series of meeting held by Dr. John J. Theobald, the Superintendent of Schools.
MONTPELIER, Vt., Jan. 7 -- The Vermont Legislature set up machinery today for a recount of the 1958 vote for Governor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Anastas I. Mikoyan, a Soviet First Deputy Premier, has achieved at least two limited objectives in Washington: he managed to start informal bilateral conversations with the United States, which were opposed by Washington in the past, and he provoked some reflection and review of United States policy on Germany.
JUNEAU, Alaska, Jan. 7 -- The Democratic administration of the Forth-ninth state declared a policy today of operating on a balanced budget.
CHICAGO, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Road and the Union Pacific Railroad put in a bid for more passenger business today by announcing fare cuts on their Chicago-Denver service.

TACOMA Wash., Jan. 7 (AP) -- The former president of the Western Conference of Teamsters testified today he cosigned checks that went to a Chicago friend of Dave Beck, but said he did not know at the time that the checks were so intended.

State Supreme Court Justice Jacob Markowitz approved yesterday Referee Louis M. Loeb's recommendations for the sale of $50,000,000 of securities of Universal Oil Products Company through investment banking houses.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 7 -- The conviction has grown strong among informed West Germans that a high-level conference of the Big Four powers will be held within a few months.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 (AP) -Grain futures brokers decided today that the recent price rally may be near the end of the line. They chose to cash some of the accumulated profits and study further immediate prospects before extending their positions in the market.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The need to practice "fiscal responsibility" at home while meeting American obligations to the free world abroad is the theme President Eisenhower will develop in his State of the Union Message to Congress Friday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Business inventories rose in November for the first time in thirteen months, the Department of Commerce reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads today estimated the net income of Class I rail systems in November, 1958, at $62,000,000.

Consolidated net operating income of the Marine Midland Corporation, New York State bank holding company, was $15,347,386 or $1.75 a share in 1958, the company re ported yesterday. The Fifth French Republic will be formally launched today when Charles de Gaulle becomes its first President and assumes command as head of the strongest Government France has known for nearly a century. With his inauguration France enters upon a new era -- an era which calls for drastic readjustments and sacrifices that will try the French national character but which holds, too, the promise of a French renaissance.

PARIS, Jan. 7 -- France's revolution that began May 13 enters a new phase tomorrow when Charles de Gaulle, its motor force, gives up the Premiership to become President of the Republic. In theory, at least, this signifies General de Gaulle's renunciation of active day-to-day direction of affairs for the role of, in his own words, "guide" and "arbiter."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen of Illinois climbed to the leadership of Senate Republicans today on a record of eight years in the Senate and sixteen years in the House of Representatives.

Governor Rockefeller's Inaugural Address is, as you state editorially, a state paper touched with eloquence, perhaps with greatness. Men of goodwill, regardless of political affiliation, will be inspired by the nobility of the sentiments expressed. They will wish him well as he undertakes the arduous duties of his office and strives to realize the hopes and realizations of the people on whose behalf he will serve.

The Bach Aria Group last night offered the second of the three concerts it is giving this season at Town Hall. This time there were only three vocal soloists: Eileen Farrell, the group's regular soprano, and two guest artists, Maureen Forrester, contralto, and Martial Singher, baritone.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- When you want to know the score in the Senate there are two men to go to. One is Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, the celebrated prophet of the Democrats. In a stormy scene in the East Bronx yesterday, the Department of Licenses tried to stop the city's first licensed bingo game and failed. Domestic earnings of General Public Utilities Corporation are expected to be about $2.84 a share, or 6 per cent above the 1957 figure, two executives of the holding company told yesterday's meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts.

Electric power production last week was 12,364,000,000 kilowatt hours, down from 12,379,000,000 in the preceding week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. In the similar period of 1958 it was 11,692,000,000 kilowatt hours.

Undefeated in nine rounds of the annual international chess tournament at Hastings, England, Wolfgang Uhlmann of Leipzig, East Germany, yesterday wound up his schedule with a score of 8 -- 1 to win first prize, according to a report from London.

At least one scientific advancement has bypassed the City Jail, Sheriff John J. McCloskey said yesterday. He lamented that because of the city's struggle to live within its nearly $2,000,000,000 budget, the jail has to get along with an old-fashioned icebox.

Bank clearings in the New Year's holiday week ended Jan. 7 were below those of the similar week a year earlier, which did not include a holiday, Dun Bradstreet reported yesterday.
