PERTH, Australia, Jan. 8 (AP) -- A strained stomach muscle forced Alex Olmedo to the sidelines today. As a result, Barry MacKay of Dayton, Ohio, and Earl Buchholz of St. Louis were left to alone to carry on America's hopes for a singles title in the West Australian tennis championships.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn disclosed yesterday that sixty-four Brooklyn lawyers were under investigation as a result of Supreme Court Justice George A. Arkwright's inquiry into ambulance chasing.

Democratic invention must, in the nature of things, lag behind felt need in the creation of political institutions to govern a changing world. So we have, in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, a metropolitan area with a population of about 16,000,000 growing toward 20,000,000 long before we have government apparatus fitted to deal with it adequately.
LONDON, Jan. 8 -- Industrial stocks again had widespread declines here today and British Government securities again were the only firm section in the market.
The Grand Ballroom of the Plaza was transformed into a rose garden for the sixth annual Ball of the Roses last night.

Borrowings of Federal Reserve member banks declined, on average, $164,000,000 to $626,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Excess reserves declined $97,000,000 from a revised figure of $672,000,000 a week before to $575,000,000.

IT IS probably the thought of putting ice cream into a hot oven that stops many home cooks from attempting Baked Alaska. Actually, it is a fairly easy dessert to make. But for those who do not want to take the necessary time, the new ready-to-serve version at Leonard's Bakery should be a delight.
Directors of the New York Central Railroad called a halt yesterday to joint studies that had been under way thirteen months with the Pennsylvania Railroad as to the feasibility of a merger.
Gino Marchetti, Baltimore defensive end, led the voting for The Associated Press' 1958 National Football League's AllStar team, dominated by the champion Colts and the New York Giants.
A dozen men commandeered a truck carrying paper napkins yesterday and kidnapped the driver and his son for a short time. Later, the truck and its cargo were found, almost destroyed by fire.

GENEVA, Jan. 8 -- The Big Three conference on a controlled ban of nuclear weapon testing remained stalled today. Neither the Soviet Union nor the United States and Britain showed any willingness to budge from their positions.
FOR stage-struck youngsters, opportunity sometimes knocks, but more often it hides.
JACK DEMPSEY has repeatedly said: "The luckiest thing that ever happened to me was the long count in my fight with Gene Tunney. It stirred up so much controversy that it made me famous."
GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 8 -- Residents of this community are opposed to easing zoning regulations to permit industrial and business expansion.
LONDON, Jan. 8 -- A New British challenge for the America's Cup is expected to be announced by the end of this month, Owen Aisher, a prominent yachtsman, said today.

A horseowner lost his harness racing license, two other men were barred from participation in the sport in this state and a driver was censured in actions disclosed yesterday by George P. Monaghan, New York State Harness Racing Commissioner.
ROME, Jan. 8 -- Enrico Mattei, Italian fuel chief, predicted today an international oil price war.
CHICAGO, Jan. 8 -- Mathematics, they say at the University of Illinois, can be fun for both pupils and teachers. And, they say, youngsters who find that the subject is an adventure learn it faster.
A 75-year-old man was accused yesterday of parlaying $9,000 in relief payments into $21,000 by playing the stock market.

TRENTON, Jan. 8 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner made it clear for the first time today that out-ofstate motorists convicted of violating New Jersey's new speed rules would have their driving privileges in this state revoked.

KINGSPORT, Tenn., Friday, Jan. 9 (AP) -- A Southeast Airlines plane carrying ten persons was thought to have crashed last night in this corner of Tennessee near the North Carolina and Virginia borders.

Events today: New York Philharmonic, Sir John Barbirolli, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; "The Magic Flute," Metropolitan Opera House, 8; Anna Russell, concert comedienne, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Andres Segovia, guitarist, Town Hall, 8:40.

Loans to business by the larger New York City banks declined $228,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with a decline of $249,000,000 in the corresponding week a year ago.

In the face of warnings of a fast-developing "missile gap," the Administration has rejected Air Force recommendations for increasing the planned force of intercontinental ballistic missiles, informed sources revealed yesterday.

Mrs. Mary Breckinridge, founder and director of the Frontier Nursing Service, Inc., will give the annual progress report and an informal talk to members of the Services New York Committee on Thursday. Her appearance will be at a tea given by the committee in the ballroom of the Cosmopolitan Club.

After a long absence from the Broadway scene, Arthur Hornblow Jr., Hollywood producer, is planning to return. The former press agent, adapter and executive stage producer says he will put on a modernized treatment of "The Captive," which was a controversial play in 1926.

CAIRO, Jan. 8 -- Dr. Walther Becker, the West German Ambassador here, sought an explanation today from the Egyptians of the announcement yesterday by Premier Grotewohl that agreement had been reached for the establishment of consulates general in Cairo and East Berlin.
The five-year-old Monthly Investment Plan, which is the New York Stock Exchange's answer to competition from mutual funds, has added a new twist.
In a struggle that was decided in the closing seconds, Seton Hall's basketball team defeated Muhlenberg College, 57 -- 55, at Madison Square Garden last night.
Siri Garson-Montecino, a Norwegian-born mezzo-soprano, made her New York debut last night in Carnegie Recital Hall.

The election of three new directors of the Texas Company was announced yesterday by Augustus C. Long, chairman of the oil company. They are Gilbert W. Humphrey, Ogden Phipps and Dwight P. Robinson Jr.
PARIS, Jan. 8 -- Citizen Rene Coty rode off to Le Havre this afternoon while Charles de Gaulle, his successor as France's President, took the opposite direction toward the Elysee Palace.
United States customs officials have detained a group of exhibits that the Italian government sent here in a cultural exchange project.

DUBLIN, Jan. 8 -- Eamon de Valera intends to resign as Premier of Ireland in the next few weeks and seek election as President. He made the decision known to close associates within the last few days.
TRENTON, Jan. 8 -- This city was gripped tonight by its worst transportation strike in fifteen years. It began at 4:30 A. M. when 265 bus drivers and mechanics left their jobs.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 8 -- The Belgian House of Representatives voted today to send a commission to the Congo to investigate the riots in Leopoldville last Sunday and Monday. Forty-two persons were killed and 205 injured in the disorders.
State Controller Arthur Levitt said last night that he proposed "to make a fight right down the line" to prevent Governor Rockefeller from establishing the proposed division of local government.

RALEIGH, N. C., Jan. 8 -Governor Luther H. Hodges released a letter today in which he accused Canon L. John Collin of St. Paul's Cathedral in London of seeking publicity in connection with a North Carolina race episode.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Eduardo Adriana of the Netherlands Antilles broke the Central American shot-put record today with a put of 47 feet 10.31 inches in the Central American and Caribbean Games.

More than 1,000 persons attended the annual Dawn Patrol Breakfast of the Greater New York Councils of the Boy Scouts of America yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The breakfast opened a campaign for $1,185,800 in the coming year.
Richard J. Gray, chief spokesman for 3,000,000 building trades unionists, was reported last night to be about to step down after a half-century of union leadership.
The election of John D. Leary and Lynn A. Townsend as directors of the Chrysler Corporation was announced yesterday by L. L. Colbert, president of the automotive manufacturer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Few of the estimated total of 2,000 bills introduced in the House of Representatives as Congress convened yesterday called for budget balancing economies such as President Eisenhower seeks.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -George Meany, president of the merged labor movement, belittled the conference-table approach to Soviet power today.

The first proxy contest in the ninety-year history of the New York Athletic Club will take place in the annual election of officers next Tuesday in the clubhouse at Seventh Avenue and Central Park South.

The First National City Bank of New York announced plans yesterday to extend to approved applicants for personal loans lines of credit against which they will be able to draw checks. Repayment will be in predetermined monthly amounts.

Rumors of devaluation of the Brazilian cruzeiro and of changes in the bonus for exporting coffee depressed prices of that commodity on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. The B months fell 32 to 81 points (hundreths of a cent a pound) on 76,750 bags and the M positions declined 10 to 135 points on 14,500 bags.

PARIS, Jan. 8 -- One week before his forty-seventh birthday, Michel Debre received a gift today from the man he admires above all others. He was named first Premier of the Fifth French Republic by President Charles de Gaulle.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson forced the filibuster battle toward a decisive stage today and confronted Senate liberals with the prospect of a major defeat in the first showdown vote.

Within six days after the collapse of the Batista dictatorship the new revolutionary Government of Cuba has consolidated its position sufficiently to win widespread international recognition, including that of the United States.

The Pennsylvania Railroad has sold its Harborside Terminal Warehouse at 34 Exchange Place, Jersey City, to the Harborside Terminal Company of New York. The sale, which eventually will include the railroad's adjoining Piers D and F, is subject to approval by the New Jersey Public Utility Commission.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 8 -- The Musicians Guild of America announced today it had filed with the National Labor Relations Board office in Los Angeles "unfair labor practice" charges against the American Federation of Musicians, its Hollywood Local 47, and Melville Productions, Inc.

Hopes for a quick end of the three-week-old strike at American Airlines rose last night. Representatives of the company and the Air Line Pilots Association were reported to have made substantial progress at a meeting in Washington with Leverett Edwards, chairman of the National Mediation Board.
A new group of plastic dishes, designed for the dual purpose of storing and serving food, will be available next week in the housewares department of Macy's.
The police took a suspect into custody yesterday in the Brooklyn kidnapping of a two-hourold baby. But after several hours of questioning detectives said she had no connection with the crime.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- In responding Monday night to two questions from members of a group assembled by Eric A. Johnston, Soviet First Deputy Premier Mikoyan offered suggestions for solving the East-West impasse over the future status of Berlin.
CHICAGO, Jan. 8 (AP) -The grain futures market turned higher today just as some brokers an the Board of Trade were talking about a probable downward trend.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- In his conversations in Washington this week, Anastas I. Mikoyan, a Soviet First Deputy Premier, repeatedly emphasized his country's opposition to the nuclear rearmament of Germany.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Five corporations manufacturing hand tools and four of their officers were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.

PARIS, Jan. 8 -- Premier Michel Debre announced his Cabinet tonight, retaining eighteen ministers from the government headed until today by the new President, Charles de Gaulle, and naming nine new members.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Meyer Lansky, formerly a major figure in gambling in this country, has been subpoenaed by the Senate Select Committee on Improper Activities in the Labor or Management Field for questioning late this month.
An ostrich who learned the hard way that one doesn't go wading in a frozen pond is living in a sling at the Bronx Zoo.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Jan. 8 -- The circumstances under which Marcos Perez Jimenez, deposed Venezuelan dictator, received a visa for entry into the United States became known today.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 8 -Stockholders of National Theatres, Inc., approved today a proposal to buy controlling interest in National Telefilm Associates.
DETROIT, Jan. 8 -- Anastas I. Mikoyan told Detroit's top industrial leaders tonight that "we are all tired of the cold war and would very much like to have a hot peace."
HAVANA, Jan. 8 -- Fidel Castro rolled into Havana this afternoon with 5,000 of his victorious rebels to receive a delirious welcome from the city's populace.
CAIRO, Jan. 8 -- Premier Amintore Fanfani of Italy negotiated agreements with the United Arab Republic today covering a wide range of activities.
NAGPUR, India, Jan. 8 -- The Congress party, which has ruled India since her independence, committed itself today to a program of bigger and bolder economic planning.
The Port of New York Authority allocated $24,000,000 yesterday to start construction of the Narrows Bridge.

Following is the text of a report on the future of the Metropolitan Regional Council, made public yesterday by the Special Committee on Metropolitan Governmental Affairs of the Regional Plan Association:
The following reports were provided by operators of the ski areas. Messages were filed at telegraph offices yesterday at the times indicated in parentheses.

An increase in freight rates on cargoes moved between Atlantic and Gulf Coast ports and the West Coast of South America will become effective March 1. The announcement of the increase was made yesterday by the Atlantic and Gulf - West Coast of South America Conference.
A public hearing to consider the sponsorship of bingo games by a Greek Orthodox church in the Bronx will be held Tuesday at 10:30 A. M.

The statement in your editorial of Jan. 3 interpreting recent events in the Middle East as a showdown between "the nationalist forces of President Nasser and the Communist movement in the Arab world" inclines toward oversimplification. The situation is far more complex.

SINCE people here have been reading that America has "gone Japanese" in a big way, the tendency to follow "stateside" trends in all things has had the curious result of creating a new Tokyo boom in the traditional arts of flower arrangement and the tea ceremony.

The problem of unionizing the Police Department now confronting the city administration seems to be generating more heat than light. Lest the usual cockeyed solution result from this typically emotionally charged situation, some clear thinking had better be done on this important policy question before it is too late.

HENRY JAMES' novel "The Wings of the Dove" arrived on the television screen last night. As presented on "Playhouse 90" over Channel 2, it was an opulent offering, containing some diverting performances but moving at a sluggish pace to its inevitable conclusion.
CHICAGO, Jan. 8 -- The consumer is being canonized like a long-suffering martyr at the many discussion sessions held at International Homefurnishings Show here.
CHICAGO, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
CHICAGO, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The nation's automobile insurance industry combined forces and funds today to push a program aimed at cutting traffic deaths, injuries and property damage.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The Pentagon announced today the immediate expansion of the Atlantic Air Defense Identification Zone to include the entire coast of Florida and adjacent areas of the Gulf of Mexico.
BOSTON, Jan. 8--The problem of transportation was emphasized today by Governor Foster Furcolo in his second Inaugural Address to the Legislature.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- No other members of the Supreme Court plan to follow Chief Justice Earl Warren out of the American Bar Association. His decision to drop out was made public this week.
Several donors to the fund for the New York Times Neediest Cases said yesterday they hoped the forty-seventh annual appeal would set a record for receipts.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., Jan. 8 (AP) -- An Indian elephant named. Sally today trampled and killed one of her former handlers who returned to work only three days ago.
Seasonable temperatures returned to the metropolitan area and much of the nation yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Soviet Union can be expected soon to become the first nation to send a man into space, a report issued by the House Select Committee on Astronautics and Space Exploration predicted today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -Economic experts of the twenty -one American republics set out today on the task of negotiating and drafting a charter for an Inter-American Development Bank.
Brighter prospects for the current fiscal year were forecast for the Stanley Warner Corporation by S. H. Fabian, president, at the annual stockholders' meeting yesterday in Wilmington, Del.
PARIS, Jan. 8 (Reuters) --Following is an unofficial translation of statements by Gen. Charles de Gaulle today on his installation as President of France and by Rene Coty, whom he succeeded:...
RYE, N. Y., Jan. 8 -- Gregory Kelley of the Skating Club of Boston led the qualifiers for the senior men's title as the Eastern States figure skating championships began at Playland Ice Casino today.

The Columbia Broadcasting System and Talent Associates, Ltd., independent producer, are searching for a female singing star to appear in a two-hour musical, "Meet Me in St. Louis." It would be televised on Sunday, April 26, from 9 to 11 P. M.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy remained adamant yesterday in opposing any changes in the Police Department grievance procedure.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The National Association of Manufacturers today termed Mr. Reuther's theories "economic nonsense."
JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector), Jan. 8 -- The trickle of Jewish emigration permitted from Eastern Europe has become a small flood.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Treasury announced today that it would raise $3,250,000,000 in cash by two new offerings, one of them $750,000,000 in twentyone-year bonds.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Arvis Chalmers of The Albany Knickerbocker News was elected president of the New York State Legislative Correspondents Association today. He succeeds Walter V. MacDonald of The New York World-Telegram and Sun.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -Fred A. Seaton, Secretary of the Interior, noted that Senator Lyndon B. Johnson had accused the Administration of a "deficit of vigor" and commented:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The Senate Elections subcommittee said today that it lacked evidence to sustain a labor protest against the seating of Senator Barry M. Goldwater for his second term.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 8 -The Indian Government's decision to take over wholesale trading in food grains is meeting stiff resistance from merchants all over the country.

The building containing seventynine apartments and ten stores at 1805 Forty-ninth St. in the Boro Park section of Brooklyn has been purchased by the Mogro Corporation for investment. It is on a plot 210 by 100 feet covering the blockfront on Eighteenth Ave. from Forty-eighth to Forty-ninth Sts. Lennard Sons, Inc. was the broker.

Endicott, N. Y., borrowed $3,250,000 yesterday on bonds secured by general taxation to finance expansion of the water distribution system. The securities were sold to a syndicate headed by Kidder, Peabody Co.
FLORIDA'S definitive fishing historians are writing new and vivid chapters in the fascinating annals of their special field. Happy is the recorder of events who deals only in triumphs.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon heard some honeyed words today from a strange quarter -Senator Wayne Morse, Democrat of Oregon.
TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 8 (UPI) -- Gov. George Docking said today that Kansas newspapers would be subject to the state's 2 1/2 per cent sales tax, or use tax.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals ordered a new trial today in the case of Lee J. Behringer, who has been trying to regain an $8,000-a-year state job from which he was ousted by the Harriman Administration.
Marketing of a line of factoryrebuilt television picture tubes priced 35 per cent lower than new ones was started yesterday by the Radio Corporation of America.
CAIRO, Jan. 8 -- Jet fighters of Israel and the United Arab Republic clashed shortly after noon today.
The Metropolitan Opera reported yesterday that it had a good year. It lost only $553,383 last season.

The Waterfront Commission began issuing subpoenas last light in an effort to head off what it called a possible new attempt by underworld figures to gain control of the International Longshoremen's Association.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 8 -- While geenrally satisfied that its 490-member institutions are observing the rules more closely than ever before, the National Collegiate Athletic Association made clear today that it would continue to crack down hard on violators.

" Sleeping Beauty," Walt Disney's feature-length film cartoon of the classic children's story, will open at the Criterion Theatre. The date will depend on the departure of "A Night to Remember," the Criterion's current tenant.
Your editorial of Jan. 3 on "Facts and City Planning" was most timely. Once again your paper stands at the front rank not only in leading but in enlightening the people.
BOSTON, Jan. 8 -- The Jewish Advocate gave its "Man of the Year" award today to Cardinal Cushing.

Loew's, Inc., the world's largest motion picture company, announced yesterday a sharp recovery in operating results, a move to eliminate three dissident directors and a realignment of its executive committee.
BOSWELL, Okla., Jan. 8 (UPI) -- Fifteen children burned to death today when fire swept a four-room cottage.
The city pushed forward a major move yesterday against "sharp-shooting" landlords who, it was charged, seek to benefit both from lower taxes and higher rents.
PATERSON, N. J., Jan. 8 -Henceforth only the fathers of babies born in this city's three hospitals will be able to visit the maternity departments.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- President Eisenhower told Americans today that political or ideological differences were no excuse for bad manners.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The new leaders of House Republicans said today that they would seek an influential voice in the formation of the Eisenhower Administration's legislative programs.
LONDON, Jan. 8 (UPI) -- The land of Keats, Shelley and Shakespeare immortalized the garbage collector in poetry today.

WHEN Beth Sumner first saw Mr. Alagarsami he was clinging desperately to the outside of a third-class railway coach. Beth was inside it and her being there was almost as remarkable as his precarious perch outside. White ladies didn't often travel third class in Southern India. The train was just pulling out of Madurai station bound for Kasappur. Beth hauled Mr. Alagarsami through the window and may even have saved his life.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 --Republican leaders are discussing plans for an extensive party face-lifting operation before the 1960 election. The principal aim would be to change the public's conception of the G. O. P. as the party of big business.
Operating revenues and earnings of Northwest Airlines, Inc., in 1958 were the highest in its thirty-two-year history, Donald W. Nyrop, president, reported yesterday.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 8 -- A spokesman for the Chinese Nationalist Defense Ministry said here today he did not expect any immediate Chinese Communist air or sea-borne attacks against the offshore islands or Taiwan.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 8--West Germany instructed its Ambassador in Cairo today to ask President Gamal Abdel Nasser for immediate clarification of the United Arab Republic's decision to establish consular relations with East Germany.

Jackie Robinson, once a quick thinker on the baseball diamond, moved swiftly last night to give a fire alarm at the Belmont Plaza Hotel, Lexington Avenue and Forty-ninth Street. Two persons were injured in the blaze.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- The Foreign Office received a report tonight from Eugene R. Black, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, on his discussions in Cairo. The message appeared to have encouraged optimism here about the chances of settling British-Egyptian financial differences.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 8 (AP) -- Mainrock, who failed to win in five previous starts, took the fifth race and paid $269.10 for $2 at Tropical Park today.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The House of Deputies approved today the contract between the Government and Ansec, Argentine subsidiary of the American and Foreign Power Company, which owned eighty - seven electric power plants covering ninety cities and towns in the interior of Argentina.
One of the Communist party's top leaders, Charles Loman, has been suspended from his state party posts by New York State Communist leaders.
The Port of New York Authority yesterday named Claudio R. Arce manager of its Caribbean trade development office at San Juan, P. R.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Fred A. Seaton, Secretary of the Interior, disclosed today that he had ordered vigorous action against illegal acquisitions of Federal oil and gas land leases.
In defiance of his boss, Eddie Dixon will take his future in his fists when he fights Gene (Ace) Armstrong at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Mrs. Ogden E. Edwards, benefit committee chairman, has announced that the annual luncheon and fashion show of the Fifth Avenue Fellowship of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church will take place in the ballroom of the Biltmore on Feb. 7.
Following are thumbnail sketches of four of the milliners whose showings of spring hats were held yesterday:
A South African ichthyologist told here yesterday how he and nine other members of a scientific expedition had crossed Africa last fall in three Fiberglas motorboats and two utility land vehicles.

Subfreezing weather and a scarcity of new powder snow were the problems besetting most winter resort operators in the East yesterday. They were prepared, nevertheless, to play hosts to another invasion by ski enthusiasts over the week-end.
J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., reported yesterday net operating earnings for 1958 of $8,390,554, or $23.97 a share. This compared with $8,139,955, or $23.26 a share cleared in 1957.

KANSAS CITY, Jan. 8 (AP) -- A Federal law requiring students receiving loan assistance to sign a Communist-disclaimer affidavit and take an oath of allegiance was assailed today at the closing session of the Association of American Colleges.
Harmonie and Dartmouth maintained their first-place tie in Division I of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class C competition yesterday.

One of the nation's leading polio experts suggested here yesterday that the ban on summertime tonsil and adenoid operations in children might be lifted under some conditions. Dr. Albert B. Sabin of the University of Cincinnati College of Medicine suggested that children protected by three or more recent doses of the Salk vaccine might undergo operations during summer "polio season" if there were not much polio in the community.
A proposal that the Metropolitan Regional Council receive "full and effective" legal status was put before the Regional Plan Association yesterday.
A record in the number of children aided was reported for 1958 at the annual meeting yesterday of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Ashley Cooper and Mervyn Rose, two of the newer Australian pro tennis players, were beaten in straight sets in the first round of a $14,560 tourney tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The Air Force said tonight that it was working on new techniques for recovering the nose cones of Discoverer satellites, "including recovery by use of aircraft."
BERLIN, Jan. 8 (Reuters) -Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin will leave Feb. 6 to visit the United States, Japan and Southeast Asia, a spokesman said today.
Russia's official reaction to the fall of the Batista Government is that another link in the chain of dictatorial governments supported by the United States has been broken.
Five floors in the new office building at 100 William Street, corner of John Street, have been leased by the Fireman's Fund Insurance Company and affiliates.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 8 -- The judiciary system of the state was described at a forum here today as a hodgepodge of inefficient, costly and uncoordinated courts.
Carlo Bergonzi proved to be no match for a case of bronchitis in last night's "Aida" at the Metropolitan Opera.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (UPI) -- A scientist said today the society would have to decide soon whether individuals should retain the right to say how many children they would have.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 8 -- The appointment of John Herbert Davis to head the United Nations aid program for Palestine refugees has been agreed upon by Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold and the countries most concerned with the relief operation.
The Coast Guard cutter McCulloch, battered and pounded by days of North Atlantic storms, is running for shelter in Newfoundland, the Coast Guard reported here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Defense Department, in a major reversal of policy, has recommended a substantial increase in the production of plutonium for nuclear weapons.
The Israel Bond Organization reported yesterday that $46,540,650 was raised last year through the sale of Israel bonds for consolidating Israel's economic framework.
COMBINE the first names of Vincent Borg and Harmik Gasparian and you have a new hat label of fresh distinction.
Fidel Castro, the Cuban revolutionary leader, appeared for three minutes at 2 o'clock this morning on CBS-TV in a live telecast from Havana.

The settlement of the American strike ended the last of the walkouts that have grounded four of the country's five biggest domestic air lines in the last three months. It was the worst siege of labor-management conflict in the history of the industry.
NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 9 -- Oyster boats docked in the East Norwalk channel of the Norwalk River have been locked in ice since the middle of last week.

BERLIN, Jan. 9 -- The East German Government hinted today that it might agree to the continued presence of Western troops in a free city of West Berlin if they were designated as United Nations forces.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Herb Score signed his 1959 contract with the Cleveland Indians today, hoping to have a healthy year and earn an increase in pay.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 9 (AP) -- Favored Eddie Moylan of Trenton led four seeded players into the semi-finals of the Dixie international tennis tournament today. Moylan ousted Reg Bennett of Great Britain.
The Pennsylvania Railroad loses $786,177 a year on its service from New York City to New Jersey shore points, an official of the road testified yesterday.
The American Museum-Hayden Planetarium, which was closed this week for repainting, will reopen today with a new show called "The Sky Is The New Frontier."

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The continuing good volume of export business was not enough today to extend the recent higher trend in grain futures on the Board of Trade, but it held losses generally to a minimum against moderate profit-taking.

THERE was nothing to surprise or offend at yesterday afternoon's New York Philharmonic concert at Carnegie Hall. In Sir John Barbirolli's second week as guest conductor, the program had nothing to disturb patrons who are not happy with the radical experiments of the twentieth century.
ALBANY, Jan. 9 (UPI) -- Skiing conditions as reported to the New York State Commerce Department today:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Congress received President Eisenhower's message today with much indifference, some criticism and some praise. The most conspicuous reaction was unspoken. It came from the second row of the House chamber, about midway in the President's speech. It was an unrestrained yawn by the Senate Democratic leader, Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Dick (Pancho) Gonzales and Francisco (Pancho) Segura tonight crushed a pair of Australian hopefuls in the second-round singles matches of the Victorian professional tennis championship.

A biographical study of Susan B. Anthony by Alma Lutz is planned for Feb. 15 publication by Beacon Press. The author emphasizes Miss Anthony's passion for human liberty in all aspects -- the financial, political, racial and moral.

"The Diary of Anne Frank," the Twentieth Century-Fox version of the stage success, produced by George Stevens, and introducing Millie Perkins in the title role, will have its world premiere on March 17 at the Palace Theatre. The next day the drama will begin a two-a-day, reserved seat engagement.
The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday put an official stamp of approval on last Friday's Denny Moyer-Gaspar Ortega welterweight bout.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 -- Furniture men expect a 10 per cent or more increase in business this year. That appeared today to be the consensus of both retailers and manufacturers at the Winter Furniture Market being held here at the American Furniture Mart and the Merchandise Mart.

ANDRES SEGOVIA gave his annual recital last night in Town Hall. In a way it was a milestone in the great Spanish guitarist's career, for it was fifty years ago that he made his first appearance on the concert stage.
Prices of United States Government securities declined slightly in moderately active trading yesterday following the Treasury's announcement of plans to borrow $3,250,000,000 next week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The index of average wholesale prices at the primary market level declined 0.1 per cent to 119.2 per cent of its 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

HARLAN, Ky., Jan. 9 -- The United Mine Workers has served notice on coal operators in the large Kentucky coal fields of Harlan and Bell Counties that the union was ending the present wage agreement after sixty days. Operators toda said that that was done under a provision of the old contract.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 9 (Reuters) -- Alfried Krupp hit back today at criticism about the planned extension of his industrial empire.

CAIRO, Jan. 9 -- Dr. Walther Becker, the West German Ambassador to the United Arab Republic, had a brief meeting this afternoon with Ali Sabry, Minister for Presidential Affairs. The meeting was in connection with the Ambassador's urgent request for an explanation of the report that Cairo and East Germany were to exchange consular representatives.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 -- David M. Kennedy was elected chairman today of the board and chief executive officer of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago. He succeeds Walter J. Cummings, who was named chairman of a newly created executive committee.
In view of his performance in the ten-round main bout at Madison Square Garden last night, Eddie Dixon, the Newark policeman had better return to his cop's beat and leave the fight beat to others.
Following is the text of President Eisenhower's State of the Union Message to Congress yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 9 -- The United States would look with favor on simultaneous talks with the Communist group on means of reducing the danger of surprise attack and the more political aspects of disarmament.

The Hartford Fire Insurance Company group, a substantial holder of shares in the New York Trust Company, has disclosed that it will vote its holdings for management in the New York Trust proxy contest that will be decided next Wednesday.

The Bell System's operating revenues and net income showed sizable gains for the three and twelve months ended Nov. 30. The report placed operating revenues for the twelve months at $6,719,505,165, against $6,274,716,327 a year earlier.
NEWARK, Jan. 9 -- Overbrook Hospital, Essex County's mental institution in Cedar Grove, has lost its accreditation because it is "overcrowded and understaffed."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to reopen the proceeding in which it was denied authority to control the Central of Georgia Railway Company.

Soon we will have with us what is known as the "holdout season." Major league baseball contracts must be in the mails by Thursday. The players then have until reporting time for spring training to mull over the figures. If they fail to report they become holdouts.
The city government went electronic yesterday in turning out pay checks for 130,000 of its employes.
CHICAGO, Jan. 9 -- Anastas I. Mikoyan gave Chicago's leading lawyers tonight a revelatory picture of inside Kremlin politics and past Soviet police excesses.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 9 (AP) -- The United States satellite Atlas will be visible over the week-end, the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory said today.
The fund for the New York Times Neediest Cases benefited yesterday from a number of stock sales and interest payments.

NAGPUR, India, Jan. 9 -- The ruling Congress party took the first step today toward transforming India's 612,000 villages into farming cooperatives. The new pattern of rural society was outlined in a brief resolution that provoked a sharp six-hour debate. But the outcome was never in doubt.

GRINDELWALD, Switzerland, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Penny Pitou of Gilford, N. H., today capped a fine performance by American girls in the Grindelwald international ski meet by winning the downhill and combined championships.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 9 -- Princeton fought off a determined Yale team tonight in Dillon Gymnasium and captured its second Ivy League basketball decision, 71 -- 55, before a crowd of 2,000.

MANY New Yorkers have become acquainted with preserved kumquats in Chinese restaurants here. The slightly bitter but flavorful fruit is traditional for dessert in such establishments. The fresh fruit is available here only briefly each year, and now is the time for home cooks to try preparing the preserved version.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 9 -- Eliot Daniel, president of Local 47, American Federation of Musicians, denied today a statement by the Musicians' Guild of America that the National Labor Relations Board headquarters in Washington had approved the filing of a complaint against the union.
LONDON, Jan. 9 -- The Belgian franc weakened in foreign exchange markets today under strong selling. Financial circles here discounted talk of possible devaluation, however.
BOSTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- A union spokesman said today that Federal mediators would not be able to prevent a scheduled strike Jan. 19 of 1,500 trainmen employed by the Boston and Maine Railroad.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 9 -- Circuit Court Judge George C. Wallace defied the Federal Civil Rights Commission for a second time by denying it access to voter registration records, the agency's chairman contended today.
THERE is no reason why "Rawhide" should not prove as habit-forming as any other of television's Western opiates.

PRINCESS IRENE GALITZINE is the latest couturier to toss her hat into the ring of Italian high fashion. This designer, who lists Greta Garbo among her customers, will have a showing for foreign buyers and the press in Rome on Jan. 18.

PANAMA, C. Z., Jan. 9 -- It is believed here that the United States may soon send to the Foreign Ministry of the Republic of Panama a note concerning the latter's recent extension of territorial waters from three miles to a total of twelve miles.
Commodity futures closed mostly higher yesterday on the New York exchanges in featureless trading. Most of the volume involved evening of holdings for the week-end.
American Airlines, grounded by labor trouble since Dec. 20, reached an agreement with its striking pilots yesterday.
LONDON, Jan. 9 -- London straphangers who refuse to leave subway trains when requested to do so were warned today that they might be shunted onto sidings.
CHICAGO Jan 9 (AP) -- The report of today a livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows.

HAVANA, Jan. 9 -- The most exhausted men in the world today must be the Cabinet Ministers and other high officials of the new Cuban regime. Most of the time since Provisional President Manuel Urrutia Lleo arrived in Havana Monday, the Council of Ministers has been meeting.
An English - language presentation of H. Leivick's widely known Yiddish play "The Golem" will open here Feb. 24 at St. Mark's Playhouse, Second Avenue and Eighth Street.

A panel of high school students decided yesterday that their responsibility to the community could extend to an interest in politics. They felt, however, that their participation could only be indirect.

The directors of the Regional Plan Association yesterday approved a resolution urging recognition of the Metropolitan Regional Council as an official tri-state planning agency. It would consider problems affecting twenty-two counties in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- President Eisenhower said today that the United States was buying "certain bombers that cost their weight in gold exactly. Actually, he understated the facts.
SINCE the latter part of the nineteenth century, when the "January White Sales" first became a boon to this nation's homemakers, "linens" have come a long way.
Two men held up a messenger for a Harlem check-cashing agency yesterday and took a paper bag away from him. When they discovered the bag contained only a ham sandwich they went back and punched him.

THERE are dangers in training a hunting dog that do not immediately meet the eye, and some of them may have dark social implications. A man training a dog can train himself into a different personality, and not necessarily a better one.
Thirty minutes of ring warfare from which he emerged a bruised and bowed warrior last night left Eddie Dixon undecided whether to pursue his career as a fighter or to remain a policeman.
The many occasions in a man's life when he needs to know his wife's size -- anniversaries, her birthday, Valentine's Day -- call for some sleuthing. To get the facts, he can do one of several things.
Charles Atlas, who has spent more than half of his sixty-six years building muscles by mail, preaches moderation as the key to healthy living.
PARIS, Jan. 9 -- The experts who drafted the French economic plan count for its success on the prestige of President Charles de Gaulle on the free play of economic forces.
GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 9 -- Opposition by residents to industrial expansion was given as a major reason today for a plant's decision to move to Greer, S. C.
Reluctant witnesses prevailed yesterday as the Waterfront Commission began a new investigation into possible links between the International Longshoremen's Association and criminal elements.

ALL history is ancient history now. Or so it seems as we learn about each day's new atomic wonder, each month's launching of something or other that may lead to regular interplanetary commuter service for the exurbanites of outer space. Yet the kind of history that concerns us most centers our own destinies and tries to answer eternal questions: what are we doing here and where are we bound?
MEXICO CITY, Jan. 9 -- Part of a conspiracy to overthrow the Government of Guatemala is based in Mexico, Col. Arturo Ramirez Pinto, Guatemalan Ambassador to Mexico, said today.
DETROIT, Jan. 9 (AP) -- United States factories are building this week 133,567 cars and 21,837 trucks, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Events of the last quarter-century have outpaced by far any of the forecasts offered 1933 by President Hoover's research committee on social ends.

GENEVA, Jan. 9 -- The three-power conference on a controlled ban of nuclear weapon tests settled down to business today when the Soviet Union dropped its insistence on discussing nothing but the duration of the proposed treaty.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Sales of new automobiles and Christmas merchandise lifted retail volume to a record level in December. At the same time, the 1958 total reached a historic high for a year, the Department of Commerce estimated today.

The United States Lines' America, this country's second largest passenger ship, slipped smoothly into the Hudson yesterday afternoon, showing no outward signs of the bustle that had surrounded her in the previous thirty-two hours.

The President's appeal for courtesy and good manners in the reception given Anastas I. Mikoyan during his visit here is timely and needed. The demonstrations Mr. Mikoyan has encountered in various cities have come close to physical violence. Orderly expression of abhorrence for Soviet crimes is one thing; efforts to injure or impede Mr. Mikoyan on his trip are quite another.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today blamed the negligence of a jet pilot for the mid-air collision of his jet with a commercial airliner last May near Brunswick, Md.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 9 -- Various groups besieged the Government today with pleas for relief from the strict application of Argentina's economic stabilization program.
Chemical "claws," which grab metal atoms and so can soften hard water, remove rust scale and prevent food from spoiling, may also help cure disease, a scientist said here last night.
RABAT, Morocco, Jan. 9 -- The Moroccan Government's showdown with restive tribesmen in the Rif Mountains has entered a critical stage.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 9 (AP) -- The Department of Justice called off today a proposed antimonopoly suit against Pitney-Bowes, Inc., of Stamford, the nation's largest manufacturer of postage meters, when the concern agreed to take steps to bring freer competition in the industry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- If you should see a ruddy-faced 220-pound 6-footer hovering just a little tensely over Anastas I. Mikoyan, a First Deputy Premier of the Soviet Union, it will undoubtedly be "K. O."
VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 9 -- (UPI) -- Troops from Communist North Vietnam have penetrated nine miles into Laos and are helping Laotian Communists escape, a Government official said today.
HAVANA, Jan. 9 -- The struggle for power among the various revolutionary factions that overthrew the Government of General Batista appears to be continuing.

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 9 (AP) -- Acquisition by National Vulcanized Fibre Company here of the Parsons Paper Company, Holyoke, Mass., has been approved by the directors of both companies, it was disclosed today.

That the A. F. L.-C. I. O. is opposed to Negro segregation is beyond any question. By its constitution it is pledged "to encourage all workers without regard to race, creed, color or national origin to share in the full benefits of union organization." It has set up a special department charged with the duty of protecting all the civil rights of its members.

ATLANTA, Jan. 9 -- United States District Judge Frank A. Hooper ruled here today that segregated seating on Atlanta trolleys and buses was unconstitutional. But he declined to issue an injunction forcing officials to stop it.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Fifty-two Senators, representing a majority of the Senate, joined today in bipartisan sponsorship of a bill to admit Hawaii as the fiftieth state.

The Griscom-Russell Company of Massillon, Ohio, announced yesterday receipt of an order for three steam generators for a nuclear plant. It said the order, from the Atomics International division of North American Aviation, Inc., was valued at "several million dollars."
The De Laval Separator Company has acquired the exclusive rights to make, sell the equipment, and license a new automatic process for making cheddar cheese, the company announced yesterday.
MADRID, Jan. 9 -- At least seventeen persons were reported drowned and 114 missing in floods that swept the Spanish village of Rivadelago early today after a dam gate broke.
Casey Stengel has been picked as their "pin-up boy" by the news photographers of New York.
PARIS, Jan. 9 -- With the elevation of Ten National Assembly Deputies to Cabinet bank, an equal number of new personalities will enter Parliament.
ALL of the twentieth century's esthetic action stations are manned in this week's exhibitions of work by European and American painters.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The new Federal Aviation Agency today named Brig. Gen. George S. Cassady of the Air Force to be deputy director of the Bureau of Air Traffic Management.

HANOVER, N. H., Jan. 9 -- Dartmouth's defending Ivy League basketball champions opened the first half with 17 straight points and went on to crush Columbia, 69 -- 40, tonight at Alumni gymnasium. Dartmouth stayed tied with Princeton for the Ivy lead.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- James R. Hoffa, president of the Teamsters Union, canceled plans today for a special union convention to oust the union's court-appointed monitors.

The twelve-story office building at 350 Broadway, at Leonard Street, has been purchased by the Estate Securities Company, realty operators. It is on a plot 60 by 175 feet and is assessed for more than $1,000,000. The building was bought by the operators from the 350 Broadway Realty Company and was resold to the Broadway-Leonard Company, a syndicate of investors.

Stocks pushed ahead yesterday in a market that produced a number of spectacular gains and looked stronger than it was. Market values on the New York Stock Exchange rose about $1,750,000,000.

In his State of the Union Message yesterday President Eisenhower again dedicated this nation to a policy that seeks peace with justice and freedom. We aim to substitute the rule of law for rule by force, and for that purpose the President urges Congress and all of us to build an America able to meet the Communist challenge to our way of life.

Beginning March 1, business men may visit Moscow, Leningrad or Odessa at a special prepaid rate. This was announced yesterday by the Cosmos Travel Bureau, Inc., of 45 West Forty-fifth Street, appointed by In-tourist, the official Soviet travel agency, to handle bookings here.
Both here and in Soviet Russia much discussion still centers around improvement of current educational practices. Two of the issues concern children at opposite ends of the scholastic ability scale.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 9 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer ordered the Federal Government today to see whether it could take action against another of West Germany's recently multiplying cases of anti-Semitism.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The "Rose Book" given to Sir Winston and Lady Churchill by their children on their golden wedding anniversary became today part of the Smithsonian Institution's latest traveling exhibit.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- President Eisenhower expects the Joint Chiefs of Staff to support before Congress the "economy budget" for defense that he forecast today in his State of the Union message.

Representatives of seven Eastern railroads that opened joint discussions last October on what effect a consolidation of the Pennsylvania and New York railroads might have on their operations dropped the idea of further talks yesterday.
Mayor Wagner was assured yesterday that any city-backed bill to legalize and tax off-track betting on horse races would have the enthusiastic support of the eighty-one Democrats in the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Liberal Senators fighting to destroy the filibuster were decisively beaten today by the compromise forces of Senator Lyndon B. Johnson.

The Massachusetts Port Authority is planning to sell $75,000,000 of bonds to investment bankers. The proceeds are to be used for the acquisition of the Mystic River Bridge, the Logan International Airport, Bedford Airport and certain Boston port facilities.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 9 -- Fifty-three police officers, most of them above the rank of lieutenant, were shifted to new assignments in a shake-up ordered today by Public Safety Director William V. McLaughlin.

Dr. Morris Greenberg said here yesterday that he disagreed "violently" with a suggestion that the present practice of avoiding summer tonsil and adenoid surgery might be lifted under some circumstances.

"Scotch Symphony," George Balanchine's lovely ballet set to three movements of Mendelssohn's music of the same name, had its first presentation of the season last night by the New York City Ballet at the City Center.
An Italian shipment of musical manuscripts and scenes and designs for operas that had been held up by the United States Customs finally arrived at the New York Public Library yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 9 -- One of the most attractive surprise packages New York importers ever received from India arrived three months ago in the person of Miss Raj Chawla. With ideas as Western as her colorful saris, her unorthodox attitude toward her country's exports has been applauded.

The Pittsburgh - Des Moines Steel Company, fabricator and erector of structural steel with headquarters in Pittsburgh, leased offices in the new building at 200 East Forty-second Street from Joseph Durst, owner and builder. Collins, Tuttle Co. is the agent for the building.
CHICAGO, Jan. 9 (UPI) -- Men are better weight-losers than women.

Mrs. Nelson A. Rockefeller yesterday sewed into the hem of a plaid cotton dress the first union label of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union. Looking on were her husband, Mayor Wagner, former Senator Herbert H. Lehman, union leaders and workers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The occasion of a State of the Union message is many things:
PARIS, Jan. 9 -- Signs multiplied today that the virtual political truce enjoyed for seven months by President Charles de Gaulle would not be extended Michel Debre, his successor the Premiership.
A series on cancer control will be shown on the stations of the National Broadcasting Company's educational television project starting Feb. 10.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that this year's winter wheat crop lacked the outstanding promise of the 1958 crop at this time a year ago. This is mainly because moisture conditions are less favorable.
RYE, N. Y., Jan. 9 -- Gregory Kelley of the Skating Club of Boston won the Eastern States senior men's figure skating championship tonight at Play-land Ice Casino.

More than 100 bishops and nearly 2,000 clergy and lay leaders will attend next week the installation of the Right Rev. Arthur Carl Lichtenberger as Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Jan. 9 (UPI) -- The Soviet Union hockey team crushed Colorado College, 11 -- 5, tonight for its fourth victory in this country without defeat.
The Metropolitan Opera is having a run of misfortune. Thursday night Carlo Bergonzi started his "Aida" and could not finish because of a throat infection. (He was replaced by Dimiter Uzunov.)

A group of tenement dwellers, whose "rent rebellion" has the support of the Chelsea Community Council, won a court encounter with their landlord yesterday.
Several weeks ago I read with interest the article by Milton Bracker on the progress of the National Cultural Center in Washington.

CAIRO, Jan. 9 -- Britain and the United Arab Republic will resume their stalemated talks on financial problems that arose from the British-French attack on the Suez Canal two years ago. The talks have been in recess since September.

KINGSPORT, Tenn., Jan. 9 (AP) -- The burned wreckage of a Southeast Airlines plane was sighted today near the top of Holston Mountain and a ground party found that the ten persons aboard had been killed.
Outdoor advertising -- two penciled signs and a sketch hung on the gate of a Manhattan home -- reunited a lost dog with her family yesterday.

The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, Inc., the nation's largest food chain, yesterday reported earnings up slightly for the thirty-nine weeks ended Nov. 22.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Jan. 9 -- Gen. Fulgencio Batista broke an eight-day silence today to go to the defense of the man he chose to succeed him as head of Cuba. His successor, Maj. Gen. Eulogio Cantillo Porras, is now under arrest.
A unified probation system for the Magistrates', Special Sessions and Domestic Relations Courts will be recommended by the city's Juvenile Delinquency Evaluation Project.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The Soviet Union wants the United States and its major allies to present their own plan for dealing with Berlin.

"THE PRESS AND THE PEOPLE," one of the educational television features of the New York State Board of Regents on Friday afternoons over Channel 11, is both a worthwhile and a needed program.

AT the wholesale furniture market in Chicago this week designers and manufacturers deplored the severe, streamlined modern style, one they have valiantly tried to make the general public accept for more than a decade.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- President Eisenhower, in his seventh State of the Union Message, called on Congress and the American people today to work with him on a long-range plan for the security, solvency and growth of the nation.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Morse DellPlain, president of the Welsbach Corporation, was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of having evaded $60,804 in income-tax payments.

The Rochester Telephone Corporation is offering to its stockholders 195,312 shares of new capital stock for subscription at $21 a share at the rate of one new share for each six shares held. The offering will end on Jan. 26.

LONDON, Jan. 9 -- Industrial shares made a remarkable recovery here today and prices rose sharply.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 9 -- By a vote of 135-1, the National Collegiate Athletic Association conceded today the desirability of exempting the service academies from a newly adopted rule barring pre-enrollment aid to athletes.
The key problem of the months ahead will be "persistent unemployment above normal levels, rather than inflation," according to Dr. Jules Backman, Professor of Economics at New York University.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 9 (Reuters) -- England's inconsistent batsmen survived early shocks today and recovered from 98 for five to reach 190 for six on the first day of the third cricket test against Australia.

ZAMORA, Spain, Jan. 9 (AP) -- From the dam that went out early today to the Village of Rivadelago the ground drops 1,690 feet in three miles. The torrent roared down on the villagers before many could flee their homes.
BOSTON, Jan. 9 -- Federal District Judge Charles E. Wyzanski Jr. appointed today five directors to liquidate two companies controlled by Bernard Goldfine. Boston industrialist.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Representative Francis E. Walter, Democrat of Pennsylvania, took issue today with a proposal to transfer the jurisdiction of the House Committee on Un-American Activities to the House Judiciary Committee.

LONDON, Jan. 9 -- The battle for control of the British Aluminium Company is just about over. Tube Investments, Ltd., a British concern, announced today that it and the Reynolds Metals Company, its United States associate in the fight, owned about 80 per cent of British Aluminium's outstanding common shares.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 9 -- The West German Government has recalled its Ambassador in Cairo "for consultations" as a result of the United Arab Republic's reception of Premier Otto Grotewohl of East Germany.
HAWAII, the home of the luau, outrigger canoes and Waikiki Beach, is sending fashion leis across the Pacific to the New York stores.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 5 to 14 points (25 to 70 cents a bale) yesterday.
PERTH, Australia, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The starring role of the American - Australian tennis campaign passed today from ailing Alex Olmedo to Earl (Butch) Buchholz, 18-year-old St. Louis schoolboy.
Nine financial specialists from Asia, Latin America and Africa will begin on Monday a six-month study of the operations of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
FRANKFURT, Germany, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The Federal Bank cut the West German bank rate today from 3 to 2 3/4 per cent, the lowest since a national bank was founded in 1875.

TIJUANA, Mexico, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Fifty golf professionals laced par today, with Jerry Barber of Los Angeles and John McMullin of Alameda, Calif., leading the parade through the first round of the $20,000 Tijuana open.

The open letter from Carleton Putnam published as an advertisement in your Jan. 5 issue by a committee opposing the Supreme Court's decision that racial segregation in education is unconstitutional attempts to make several points which require rebuttal.
BOSTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Orlando Cepeda, heavy-hitting first baseman for the San Francisco Giants, today was named the National League's rookie of the year for 1958.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Maj. Archie J. Clapp Jr., assistant secretary of the Marine Corps General Staff here, patented this week a pocket computer for helicopter pilots. It makes possible quick calculation for a proper load, reducing the likelihood of a crash.

THE future of "Playhouse 90" is being evaluated by the Columbia Broadcasting System. The impatience characteristic of New York City pedestrians is still observable after a year of anti-jaywalking education, the Greater New York Safety Council said yesterday.

INDOOR gardeners can achieve interesting effects with climbing plants, particularly philodendrons, by providing them with naturalistic supports. For philodendrons, the best supports to use are moss-sticks or moss-poles, either of which can be made at home. The plants' roots grow into the moss which keeps them moist but not wet.

MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Jan. 10 -- The Hamilton, Ont., Thistles, seeking a repeat Douglas Medal curling victory, reached the semi-final round in the annual bonspiel at the St. Andrews Golf Club rink today.
MOUNTAIN LAKES, N. J., Jan. 10 -- Wesley Brimlow, the police chief of this small, quiet, residential town, was shot at and injured slightly by unknown assailants early this morning.

WHEN drawers in desks or chests show signs of sticking, try rubbing the edges with paste wax to lubricate them. Apply only a light coating, and buff off the excess to prevent stickiness. This also works well on windows and small sliding cabinet doors.
