Russia last week was engaged in a new, persistent and complicated "peace offensive." Its impact on world opinion was strong. But its real objectives, and the question of whether an accommodation between East and West actually was possible, remained obscure.

DRAMATIC use of color in flower arrangements and table settings will be featured at the sixth annual Symposium sponsored by the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State, Inc. The sessions, which run from Tuesday through Friday, will be held in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at Eighty-second Street.

There have been several recent reports of a growing anti-American attitude in the Philippines. The closer attention that Manila is paying to Asian neighbors is cited as a shift in emphasis. This, however, is a misconstruction, since there is certainly nothing "anti-American" in the praiseworthy aim of better regional relationships.

A boy or girl going to college in September will be one of about 820,000 students entering one of nearly 1,900 institutions. And despite the fears of many parents, there will be an estimated 80,000 more places than students. The difficulties are that they are unevenly distributed and that most students and their parents do not know where the vacancies are
John Reilly of Mount St. Michael's broke the open 600-yard meet record last night at the freshmen-novice track championships of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association.
MOSCOW, Jan. 10 -- What is it like at a meeting of the most powerful Communist leaders in the world?

PORT - AU - PRINCE, Haiti, Jan. 10 -- Numerous Haitian political prisoners benefitted by clemency from President Francois Duvalier today. The President issued a decree granting full pardon to many persons sentenced by military courts.

MOSCOW, Jan. 10 -- The eerie beeps and chirps from Lunik, the Soviet cosmic rocket, have died away as presumably it has started its endless journey in the great void around the sun. But the voice of its makers is stronger than ever, orbiting the earth in full propaganda cry about this latest "proof" of the Soviet Union's scientific superiority.

LONDON, Jan. 10 -- The United Nations Inter-Governmental Maritime Consultative Organization, which is holding its first assembly here, is facing a lusty Donnybrook over membership in its Maritime Safety Committee.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board, bowing to the Supreme Court, said today it would apply the Federal Labor Relations Law to the hotel industry hereafter.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The President's State of the Union Message was couched in brave and hopeful terms. While it was intentionally left vague as to specifics, its dominant and unmistakable theme was a warning to the new and heavily Democratic Congress not to endanger the whole structure of national and international security by recklessly tampering with fiscal soundness to wit, his projected budget balanced at $77 billion.
MADRID, Jan. 10 -- Spain's foreign trade has shrunk in the last year to the point of "grave crisis."

GROSSINGER, N. Y., Jan. 10 -- Leo Lebel, a 28-year-old University of Hartford student, won the world barrel jumping championship today for the fifth consecutive year by leaping over fifteen barrels for a distance of 25 feet 11 3/4 inches, in the ninth annual international event in the Grossinger Country Club ice skating arena.

HARTFORD, Jan. 10 -- Bills looking toward the elimination of the town and city courts in the 169 communities of the state are being drafted. They would substitute a state Common Pleas Court system and will soon be introduced in the General Assembly.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Jan. 10 -- Residents of this city go to the polls Tuesday to vote on a $2,500,000 bond issue designed to update municipal airport facilities for jet operations. If voters approve, a total of $4,000,000 would be spent on a new terminal structure and runways, with the additional funds to be provided by the Federal Government.
A three-point merchandising program is to be introduced for spring selling by the M. C. Schrank Company, lingerie manufacturer, that in effect all but does the retailer's work for him.
IF testimony were still needed to prove that photography can be a peer of painting it could be found in the current exhibition of photographs at the Museum of Modern Art.
WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 10 -- Zoning to permit taller business buildings in restricted shopping areas here and large campus-like office centers in residential parks is planned by city officials.

The Tuberculosis Preventorium for Children in Farmingdale, N. J., has taken Thursday's performance of "Whoop-Up" for its annual theatre benefit. The musical at the Shubert Theatre features Susan Johnson and Paul Ford.
THE downfall of Gen. Fulgencio Batista in Cuba is one of the great events in modern Latin-American history. It is also typical of the whole climate and trend of developments throughout the region.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The operations of the Federal Government will exert a slight drag on the American economy starting in the middle of this year.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 10 -- A number of West German companies are seeking approval of mergers or other moves to re-concentrate the coal and steel industries along the lines prevailing before World War II.

Fordham University, pressed hard in the early stages by a strong Army team, edged ahead midway in the first half and then ran away for an 80-69 basketball victory over the cadets at the Fordham gymnasium in the Bronx last night.

"I HAVE a lot of trouble choosing my work. I mean, it seems very hard just to pick one job out of all the rest -- for the rest of your life. Maybe after you decide what you want to be, you don't like it so much. I feel kind of scared. I'll be getting out of school next year.

New York for forty-nine years has had a ritual every January. The calendar is turned ahead about five or six months so that, despite ice or snow, folks can turn their thoughts to June and July and glorious days for vacationing.
AN itinerant 'cellist stopped off the other day and unfolded a tale about the vicissitudes of making a career in Latin America.

Emissaries of college basketball coaches are scouring the country these days in search of high school seniors seeking to trade their court talents for room, board, books, tuition and $15 a month for laundry bills.
NEWARK, Jan. 10 -- Eddie Dixon, the fighting Newark policeman, will be brought up within the month on departmental charges of violating a regulation against earning money from outside employment.

The Feb. 12 performance of "Redhead" has been chosen by the Neighborhood Children's Center as its annual theatre benefit. The musical starring Gwen Verdon is scheduled to open at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre on Feb. 5.

A twenty-four-foot-long wooden boat struck an ice floe in the Hudson River last night and sank in sixty feet of water. Its two crewmen jumped overboard and were picked up by a passing tugboat. They were in good condition.

According to the reckoning of Soviet scientists, Lunik, the cosmic rocket launched on Jan. 2, had swung into orbit around the sun Wednesday. Their calculations showed that it will reach its top speed of 72,000 miles an hour (about twenty miles a second) next Wednesday, when it reaches its nearest point to the sun, about 91,500,000 miles.
TORONTO, Jan. 10 (UPI) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs routed the Boston Bruins, 4 -- 1, tonight to move within a point of the fifth-place Bruins in the National Hockey League race.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Lew Hoad whipped Tony Trabert, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2, and Pancho Gonzales defeated Mal Anderson, 6 -- 2, 3 -- 6, 8 -- 6, in the third round of the $14,500 Victorian professional tennis championships today.

How can parents tell whether a high school is doing a good job? Does the percentage of students going to college, or the number qualifying in such tests as the National Merit Scholarship, provide indicators?

A SPECIALIST among specialists in an age of specialization is Walther Unruh, a professor at the Berlin Technical University and consulting engineer in theatre and stage techniques. Professor Unruh has the field almost entirely to himself.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- High officials of the Eisenhower Administration considered, then rejected, the idea last fall of summoning a special pre-election session of Congress in an effort to force the enactment of labor reform-legislation.

OCALA, Fla. -- Many of the millions of tourists who visit Florida each year may be completely unaware of the Ocala National Forest, even though it is only ten miles from Ocala and four miles from Silver Springs.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 10 -- Harvard edged Columbia, 68 -- 65, tonight in an Ivy League basketball game. The Crimson was sparked by George Harrington and Bob Bowditch, who combined for 39 points.

LONDON, Jan. 10 -- Norwich City, a 4,000-to-1 shot for the English soccer cup, defeated Manchester United by 3 -- 0 today in one of the biggest upsets in the sixty-six-year history of the competition. Manchester United was the 19-2 choice to regain the cup.

WHATEVER else it may be, the age clearly is one of the Hollywood confessional. Lillian Roth crying tomorrow; Diana Barrymore having too much, too soon; Edward G. Robinson Jr. on his father, his son. Now there is Mary Astor. In "My Story" she is wandering back down the uneven path of her life, trying to find how it all happened.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- As the Soviet Lunik disappeared into the solar system this week, it left behind a trail-blazing path that opens a new dimension in man's exploration of his universe.
The entire art collection of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Pearlman will be shown in New York for the first time as a benefit for Greenwich House and the Greenwich House Music School.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The diplomatic winds out of Moscow were unseasonably warm this week. Chiefly responsible for the change in climate was a dapper little man named Anastas I. Mikoyan, veteran Bolshevik, durable competitor in the world's toughest political league, trouble - shooter, super-salesman, and trusted confidant of Soviet boss Nikita S. Khrushchev.

A BEST - SELLING Danish novel which has also been made into a moving picture, "Young Love," is the story of the awakening of a 17-year-old girl to what are generally, if absurdly, called the facts of life -- in other words, to sexual experience.

IN his new book about the Negev of Israel Nelson Glueck successfully combines archaelogical exploration of the religious and historical past with popular exposition. He introduces us to scientific archaeology at the same time that he shares with us his profound Biblical knowledge and religious faith.
PARIS, Jan. 10 -- France shuffled her political line-up this week, but Gen. Charles de Gaulle was still calling the signals from his new position.

The Ford Foundation has given a grant of $525,000 to help ten private Midwestern colleges make "a joint attack upon their common economic and educational problems." To carry out this program, the colleges have formed an organization known as the Associated Colleges of the Midwest.

JACKSON was everywhere -- up and down the toiling line, with the sick, where the rations were distributed -- and always on foot, until the men began to offer their horses. "He's tough," an admiring voice observed in the ranks after the general had passed by.

TIJUANA, Mexico, Jan. 10 -- Tommy Bolt of Crystal River, Fla., and Ernie Vossler of Midland, Tex., shared the lead at the half-way mark in the $20,000 Tijuana open golf tournament today with thirty-six hole totals of 134, ten strokes under par.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Confidential polls indicated today that Senate liberals would lose all pending tests on curbing the filibuster.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Jan. 10 -- Long Island business men are feeling optimistic about 1959 and the following decade.
The homemade silk garments of a belle of long, long ago who lived in the land where silk originated have been identified by the Cooper Union Museum as the earliest known Chinese silk garments.
Soviet-American exchange of scientists in Antarctica is being suspended, despite efforts on both sides to continue it.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Winter's so-called "January thaw," often a nuisance to the skier and farmer alike, may be an actual annual occurrence.
The High School Teachers Association announced yesterday that the city's evening high school teachers had reaffirmed their resolve to resign in a body on Feb. 2.
Candy fanciers are in for a treat. The price of cocoa, the raw material of chocolate, has dropped more than 25 per cent from the 1958 high set early in June.

MOSCOW, Jan. 10 -- The Soviet Union called today for an urgent twenty-eight-nation conference within two months to conclude a peace treaty with a divided but neutralized Germany. Communist China would be among the participants.

EASTERN Air Lines, back in business again after its long strike, will introduce the new Lockheed Electra turbo-prop on its New York-Miami route tomorrow. The planes, which cruise at 400 miles an hour and with a maximum passenger capacity of ninety-one, will make the trip in 3 hours 15 minutes, cutting about 30 minutes off the present flying time with propeller-driven craft.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- A single theme -- the oldest in the American character -- has dominated the opening week of Congress: let's get going; we can and must do better than we are.
American Airlines went ahead yesterday with plans for part resumption of service this morning.

EVERY year the American Contract Bridge League elects an honorary member, selecting someone who has made conspicuous contributions to the game of contract bridge. Without any reflection on those who have been so honored (and this writer is quite proud to be one of them), it may be submitted that two of the most deserving candidates have somehow been overlooked.

MONTREAL, Jan. 10 (UPI) -- Dickie Moore's twenty-second goal of the season led the Montreal Canadiens to a 1-0 victory over Chicago tonight and snapped the Black Hawks' eight-game unbeaten streak. A National Hockey League crowd of 14,501 saw Henri Richard set up the goal with 7:15 to play.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 10 (Reuters) -- Australian bowlers claimed England's four remaining first-innings wickets for 29 runs today in the rain-shortened second day of play in the third cricket test match.

Britain and Egypt seem to be on the way to settle the financial dispute that arose out of the Suez intervention of late October and early November, 1956. The details are not of as much importance as the prospect of agreement. Britain is reported ready to release a considerable part of Egypt's sterling balance held in London and frozen more than two years ago.
An all-out fight for adoption of the controversial $500,000,000 bond issue for school construction was promised yesterday by Mayor Wagner.

Unlike the alchemists who searched unsuccessfully for a way to make gold, modern chemists unexpectedly discovered nylon and made money for their company. The twentieth anniversary of the public announcement by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. of the discovery of the synthetic is being marked this year.

ALTHOUGH much of Africa is still, for the traveler, a source of adventure rather than of mere sightseeing, the problems which it presents to the adventurer are not quite the same as those which confronted the explorer and big game hunter of sixty or seventy years ago.

Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday the appointment of Joseph J. Caputa, New York City lawyer, as the State Rent Administrator. He will succeed Robert C. Weaver, who held the $18,500-a-year post under Gov. Averell Harriman.
BONN, Germany, Jan. 10 -- number of West German newspapers condemned today a recent outcropping of anti-Semitism in the Federal Republic.
A large-scale movement of Soviet Jews to Birobidzhan in Siberia may be proposed to the Soviet Communist party congress opening Jan. 27 in Moscow, according to the American Jewish Committee.
ATHENS, Jan. 10 -- Greece and Italy, foes in World War II and often at odds since then despite their partnership in the Atlantic alliance, are again the closest of friends and resolved to remain so.
The element of change, characteristic of domestic advertising agency operations, is proceeding with even greater dispatch abroad.

NO one ever bothered, in the desperately gay interlude between World Wars I and II, to conduct a beauty contest among the great liner ladies of the North Atlantic. Had there been one, any old-time ship news reporter, full of mellow recollections clinging like immemorial barnacles, would have voted for the Ile de France.

With holiday business behind them, retailers are concentrating on completing their spring plans. In New York, interest in spring is reflected in busy manufacturers' showrooms and resident office conclaves and fashion showings.

The Soviet Union's latest and greatest rocket has revived forebodings about the outcome of the nuclear armaments race. These had been dulled by the theory, which was popularized at the summit conference in 1955, that the nuclear stalemate makes another World War impossible.

THIS week's events include the premiere of a ballet by George Balanchine on Wednesday, and the first appearance hereabouts in a number of seasons of Charles Weidman. The ballet is "Native Dancers," set to the Fifth Symphony of Vittorio Rieti. It will be danced by Patricia Wilde, Jacques d'Ambroise and a company of twelve.
LOS ANGELES -- Often overlooked amidst the brouhaha about California's warm weather and palm trees is its phenomenal growth as a winter sports playground.
TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 10 (AP) -- Eddie Moylan of Trenton and Kosei Kamo of Japan gained the final of the Dixie international tennis tournament today.
The Greater New York Chapter of the American National Theatre and Academy will hold three theatre parties this winter. Proceeds will further ANTA's work in devolping a repertory theatre.

There is no such thing as the ideal college candidate, admissions officers are fond of saying, but B. Alden Thresher, admissions dean for Massachusetts Institute of Technology, got a letter the other day from a boy he thinks comes close to the ideal.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 10 (UPI) -- Jon Konrads, the Latvian immigrant lad who is the star of Australia's powerful swimming forces, tonight became the first man to better 9 minutes for the 880-yard free-style.

Twenty-nine newspaper circulation executives from fifteen states and three Canadian provinces will take part in a two-week seminar beginning tomorrow at the American Press Institute, Columbia University.
The U. S. S. Independence, the fourth of the Forrestal class of huge attack carriers, was commissioned yesterday into the Navy.
ATLANTA, Jan. 10 -- A Federal District Court enjoined Georgia State College today from barring Negro applicants solely because of race.

NOTHING could be more out of tune with the very essence of Doris Humphrey's character than for all of us to sit about grieving over her passing. She was the least sentimental of human beings, indomitable, indefatigable, realistic.

AESCHYLUS is the latest writer to have trouble with the middle commercial. His trilogy, "Oresteia," was condensed last Sunday into an hour-long version for "Omnibus," which in itself was a formidable chore of compression.
WARSAW, Jan. 9 -- Faculties of Polish universities are wondering whether a new education law under which they have begun operating will increase or narrow their academic freedoms.

A fleet of five futuristic-looking freighters will be built as a result of a new long-range subsidy contract between the Gulf and South American Steamship Company of New Orleans and the Federal Maritime Board.
The head of the Philippine Trade Unions Council asked yesterday that the Protestant churches provide labor leaders in the Far East to keep the unions from falling to the Communists.
Flocks of birds are flying about in Macy's.

In your "Letters" column of Jan. 4 Johnny Messner protests the Federal "cabaret tax" as injurious to musicians. I could not agree with him more. I furthermore agree with his suggestion that at least the name of this constricting excise be changed.

WHETHER the Boyle family in Edward Mannix's novel is typical of Jersey City's lower middle class I don't know, but each member of it embodies one or more all too human types found in many cities of the eastern United States.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 10 (UPI) -- Circuit Judge George C. Wallace today charged that the Civil Rights Commission would not cooperate with him. The judge refused to say whether he would produce voter registration records as ordered by the United States District Court here.
HAVANA, Jan. 10 -- The Revolutionary Directorate turned over to the Provisional Government this afternoon the arms that the directorate held at the University of Havana.
CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- Every week a fleet of twenty-one armored trucks of Thillens, Inc., laden with $9,000,000 in cash from downtown banks, makes the rounds of 1,400 Chicago area factories.
There was an air of fantasy last week in the prospect of increased United States-Soviet trade prompted by the visit of Russia's Anastas I. Mikoyan.

WASHINGTON -- The Federal Government has taken a sudden interest in making sure that tourists know what baggage is and what it is not. This interest stems from the fact that the Government exercises wide control over all exports from the United States, and personal baggage carried by or shipped with tourists constitutes an export.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The House space committee said today the United States faced "national extinction" unless it undertook a "bold and dynamic" program to surpass the Soviet Union in the race into space.

LIKE some other statesmen, David Ben-Gurion has become a national leader late in life. It is more than doubtful whether many would have recognized in him at the age of 30, or even 40, "an apocalyptical figure, the providential statesman, the prophet in a business suit, the Lion of Zionism," to use a few of the epithets that appear on the jacket of Robert St. John's biography.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The new Congress was precisely forty-eight hours old this week when Senator Lyndon B. Johnson laid to rest the prophecies this his big new Democratic majority would be an unmanageable affliction for the next two years.
WHAT a joy it is to hear a really fine new voice, to see a rising star on the operatic horizon!

PERHAPS we can say there are two sorts of good narrative, the kind that moves us by its macroscopic energy and the kind that moves us by its microscopic clarity; if so, Mr. Updike's subtle and astringent first novel is of the second sort.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Thomas S. Gates Jr., Secretary of the Navy, is expected to resign shortly.

Pie crusts made from ingredients other than pastry are nothing new: the graham cracker shell has been a culinary stand-by almost as long as the cracker itself. The most recent addition to the roster of nonpastry crusts, and one that provides an interesting contrast to pie fillings, is made with crumbled shredded wheat. Two recently devised recipes for pies calling for such a shell are listed below.
Only 220 active issues on the New York Stock Exchange made gains of any size in 1957. Last year, 436 issues -- almost double the 1957 number -- rose 50 per cent or more.

ON the morning of Dec. 7, 1941, when the bombs fell on Pearl Harbor, Richard Mast, a rifle private in the United States Army, was on Interior Guard Duty, a role that entitled him -- for the duration of his duty only -- to wear a pistol.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Buzz Sawyer ran the best two-mile race of his life tonight, a 9-minute 4.6-second clocking on a flat track, to chop 14.8 seconds from the Amateur Athletic Union all-eastern indoor track meet record.

A group of leaders in the anti-polio fight who took part in a symposium at the University of Michigan last week emphasized that the major current polio problem was to achieve the full vaccination of the 50,000,000 persons under 40 in the United States who are not yet immunized.

A week from this Tuesday President Eisenhower begins his last two years in office. When his two terms are over he will have served during four Congresses, three of them controlled by the Democratic opposition.

MOST of the regular hunting seasons are over now in this part of the country, except for rabbits and bobcats, and the commercial preserves are taking up the slack. It is a trend that has become so rapid that it is almost a runaway.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Tony Jackson and Alan Seiden flipped in two free throws apiece in the last fifty seconds tonight to lift tenth-ranked St. John's of Brooklyn to an 86-85 victory over surprising George Washington.

Representatives of seventeen Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound member clubs talked over Herman Whiton's plan to provide sailing instruction next summer for young adults at a meeting in the New York Yacht Club last week.

Legislation expected to be considered by the new Congress may affect pension and other welfare plans. Measures for taxing insurance companies, limited tax exemption of self-employed retirement programs, and, possibly, amendments to the Federal disclosure law covering employe benefit funds are among those slated for consideration.
Several of your readers declare in "Letters" that varsity letters should be awarded for academic as well as athletic merit, or not be awarded at all.
PARIS, Jan. 10 (UPI) -- A French court fined a Frenchman $2,026 today for selling Dutch made liquor under a Scotch whisky label.
WHEN Frenchmen went to bed election night, Nov. 30, there was only one bright star in their political firmament -- that of Premier (now President) Charles de Gaulle.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 10 -- Russ Waters, one of Army's lonely ends, combined with two of his varsity football teammates, Ed Bagdonas and Gil Roesler, to help the Black Knights upset Manhattan in track today.
CANADA'S broadcasting and television system has undergone a radical revision but the listening and viewing public is unlikely to notice the difference, at least for some time.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Jan. 10 (UPI) -- The anthracite industry and the United Mine Workers union have agreed "in principle" on terms of a new contract for some 21,000 miners, it was announced here today.

"A BIOGRAPHER must either love or hate his subject." Twice recently this was said to me, once by a well-known lecturer and critic, and again by a popular reviewer. They meant, of course, that the writer of a life must not remain indifferent to the personality of the man he is recreating.
NEWARK, Jan. 10 -- While Essex County Democrats are enjoying the political plums of successful election campaigns in the last two years, there are signs of discontentment among Republicans.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The jailing of a television columnist this week provoked considerable discussion, public and private, about the meaning of that much-sounded phrase, freedom of the press.

PHILODENDRONS -- so varied and adaptable -- are increasing in popularity. About 400 species were known some twenty years ago; since then the number has risen considerably. In addition to new kinds found in the tropics, many hybrids have been developed in southern California and Florida.

The Eighty-sixth Congress has begun its work with a larger Democratic majority in each House than the Eighty-fifth Congress possessed, but without much shift of power from one party to another, or from the conservative wing of each party to the liberal wing. Senate Majority Leader Senator Lyndon B. Johnson seems likely to succeed in preventing any real strengthening of the anti-filibuster procedure.
LONDON, Jan. 10 -- Britain remains willing to confer with the Soviet Union on the future of Germany but not under the terms proposed in the latest Soviet note, diplomats said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The controversies which marked the opening of the Eighty-sixth Congress were basically struggles for control. Each of the groups which won and lost the various contests included "liberals" and "conservatives," as those terms are now being loosely applied.

SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 10 -- The American Smelting and Refining Company's smelter at near-by Garfield, Utah, has become the property of the Kennecott Copper Corporation as a result of a $20,000,000 purchase deal made in mid-1958. The transfer of the smelter, one of the world's largest, gave Kennecott the integrated operation it had long sought in Utah.
CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- An experiment in combining psychiatry and religion was declared a success today.

RYE, N. Y., Jan. 10 -- Laurence Owen, the daughter of Maribel Y. Vinson, a former national figure-skating champion, was crowned senior ladies' Eastern figure skating champion as the three-day sectional contests came to an end at Playland Ice Casino tonight.

BREAKING a two-year silence, Norman Fox in ROPE THE WIND (Dodd, Mead, $2.75) tells of Terry Mullane setting out from the Gallatin region of the Rockies on a quest that took him deep into Washington and the Colville Reservation where, fifteen years earlier, the Government had cooped up the Nez Perce Indians.

IN the multitude and variety of recently opened shows -- and the number last week probably set a record for a single week -- there were no overwhelming events but a fair sprinkling of more than ordinary interest. Among these graphic art was represented in two exhibitions.
Buyers from the nation's department and specialty stores were arriving in New York last week for a look at the spring lines.
The President's State of the Union message last week raised, and attempted to meet, three of the basic security issues that will be the subject of hot debate in Congress.

HOW does one capture a water buffalo or a calf elephant? How do lions communicate when planning a raid on a cattle kraal? Why are some beasts hunters and others hunted? Wynant Hubbard, in his fifteen years' experience in the African veld, has acquired a philosophical, almost poetical feeling for that land.
American Export Lines hopes to get Federal approval in the new session of Congress for a superliner for New York-Mediterranean service.

THIS unerring guide to the future is being launched a mite later than usual. Since the planets and stars are in slightly different positions from normal, there is a distinct possibility that the predictions cannot be fired with the same flawless accuracy as in the past. This venture into space may even orbit around the most distant star. Perhaps that's where it belongs, too. Push the button, Buster.
This city's second largest manufacturing industry will be honored this week with the observance of Printing Week.
ONE of the Eternal City's big 1958 tourist attractions was being unceremoniously dismantled last week (at a reported cost of some $125,000) under the vigilant direction of American technicians.

ON New Year's Day just past seventy-six British commoners read in the papers that they were to become knights. They had reached the base of the aristocratic pyramid that culminates in the Queen and instead of being plain Mr. William or Henry So-and-so they will now be Sir William or Sir Henry So-and-so.

WHEN contemporary chamber music comes up for discussion, not many people in this country think of Shostakovich. Nevertheless, the Russian composer has written at least six string quartets plus a piano quintet, and nearly all these works are available on records.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Jan. 10 -- There was no racing after the third event today at the only race track operating in the East. Charles Town, whose meeting started Dec. 18 and is scheduled to go through Feb. 7, had to curtail today's operations after two horses had gone down and two others had tossed their riders.

PROFESSOR of History at Princeton University, Gordon A. Craig is equally well known for his studies in modern German history and in recent diplomacy. He has now combined these two fields in a short and thoughtful book which originated in his Albert Shaw Lectures on Diplomatic History, delivered recently at Johns Hopkins University.
Finding a home for a child is the most gratifying experience in the world for Mrs. Henry J. Taylor. To achieve it she has helped to raise nearly $500,000.

IN full spate already, 1959 exhibitions include this week a retrospective, at the Zabriskie Gallery, of work by Abraham Walkowitz whose first show took place in 1900. These luminous, dreamy paintings and drawings measure not so much the march of time as its lightest and slightest footfalls.

IT'S winter now, agreed, but winter eventually will give way to spring. Into this office the other day came the first harbinger of that happy season, and one that will be hard to beat. Galley proofs of a new book, it was, and the title -- "The Power of Prayer on Plants."
JORHAT, India, Jan. 10 (Reuters) -- Eric Atkinson, 29-year-old medium pace bowler, took six wickets for 10 runs in a rout of East Zone by the West Indies touring cricket team today.

Officials of the Bureau of Mines and representatives of the oil industry met last week at Dallas, Tex., to discuss the possible use of underground nuclear explosions for the economical utilization of our vast oil-shale resources.
STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 10 -- Traffic on the main line of the New Haven Railroad was crippled today by a spectacular twenty-seven-car wreck of a freight train here.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The White House announced tonight the resignation of Earl E. T. Smith as United States Ambassador to Cuba.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 10 -- Bucking gusts of winds that approached gale proportions, Arthur Tokle today leaped 143 and 145 feet for a clear-cut triumph in the Bear Mountain Sports Association Class A ski jumping tournament.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Jan. 10 -- Malcolm Roberts of the Lone Star Boat Club scored two victories to lead the way into the singles semi-finals of the twenty-seventh Luckenback Memorial invitation squash racquets handicap tournament at the Nassau Country Club today.

BY 1965, when nearly every family bad two cars, and four-car families were not uncommon, Detroit had not only over-produced, but had supersaturated the market. This, despite the Texas law making it illegal for an owner to keep a car longer than fifteen months; despite the fact that most states had reduced the age limit for driving licenses to 12 years. (It was much lower in Florida.)

Olmedo's visit as a United States tennis player has been one of the exciting highlights of our Australian season. This magnificent athlete, whose quiet modesty, supreme courtesy and exemplary behavior on and off the court have been a lesson to many of our Australian players, never once betrayed anything but the most amazing calm in the face of all difficulties.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo. -- With the New Year, Coloradans ushered in their "Rush to the Rockies" Centennial celebration. Not since the Mountain and Plain festivals of the Gay Nineties have residents been so steamed up over a state-wide celebration.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The addition of two counselors in science and mathematics to the education staffs of four states was pronounced today "a very successful enterprise."

THREE of the eighteen stories in this generally competent volume of short stories by Soviet Russian writers are skillful evocations.
