BOSTON -- New England rallied toward the end of 1958 from the effects of the recession. Observers were confident of brighter prospects in 1959.

Sales of the commercial printing industry in the nation last year failed for the first time in ten years to surpass sales for the preceding year, according to the New York Employing Printers Association.
A record outflow of gold last year has focused attention on the willingness of the United States to put its fiscal house in order and the ability of her industry to compete in world markets.

The American housewife can expect more meat for her table this year, according to George Stark, chairman of the board of directors of the American Meat Institute, Chicago. He predicted that per capita consumption would increase to about 156 pounds this year, or four pounds more than the 1958.

Now that the farce of Virginia's "massive resistance" to the Supreme Court decision on schools has been recognized, the rest of the country should prepare for a rather shocking eye-opener. It appears that we Virginians, by surrendering the "state right" to segregate by law, can insist that segregation by free individual choice is a natural human right and, moreover, that it can be maintained in schools without violating the court decision.
Zino Francescatti gave his only New York recital this season Saturday evening in the Hunter College auditorium.
CHICAGO, Jan. 11 (AP) -The grain futures market ended this week on a note of weakness but with more gains for the period than losses.
The advertising industry had more of everything last year than in 1957 -- except more business.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico -- One hundred new manufacturing plants opened in Puerto Rico last year despite the recession in the United States. And there was every expectation that this trend would continue, although on a more moderate level.

ATLANTA -- Motor vehicles continued to be the most productive source of revenue in the seven Southeastern states of Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Mississippi, Tennessee and the Carolinas in the fiscal year 1957-1958.

NEW ORLEANS -- Business was off in the New Orleans area in 1958 compared with 1957. The Chamber of Commerce of the New Orleans Area attributed the decline to a "series of rolling business adjustments."

WILMINGTON, Del. -- Capital expenditures planned for 1959 by manufacturing concerns in the Wilmington metropolitan area show a 19.9 percent increase over those planned at the same time last year, Gerrish Gassaway, executive vice president of the Delaware Chamber of Commerce, said in an optimistic view of 1959 business.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The Administration will ask Congress for more than $100,000,000 to cover the cost of dealing with the Lebanon and Taiwan crises last summer.
Flute recitals are by no means common events on the local scene but this week's bill at Carnegie Recital I-Iall lists two.

BERLIN, Jan. 11 -- Mayor Willy Brandt said tonight that the Soviet Union's bid for a peace conference on Germany betrayed a certain "softening" of the Communist campaign to wrench West Berlin from the Western world.
PARIS, Jan. 11 -- The Socialist party, now free of any governmental responsibility, decided today that its future political role must be that of constructive opposition.
A committee open to all lawyers in this state has been formed to work for the reorganization of the state's judicial system.
HAVANA, Jan. 11 -- The sudden resignation late yesterday of the United States Ambassador to Cuba, Earl E. T. Smith, caught the Cuban people by surprise.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 11--Swedish observation posts have detected atomic fall-out particles larger, and thought to be more radioactive, than any yet reported except from the immediate area of a test explosion.

Ford, Bacon Davis, Inc., engineering and business consultant concern of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, has announced the election of Charles C. Whittelsey as chairman. He will continue as president and chief executive officer.

Edgar Allan Poe is the subject of a new biography by Frances Winwar, called "The Haunted Palace." It will be published next Monday by Harper to commemorate the birth of the American writer 150 years ago. It deals with both the man and the artist, tracing the tragic facts of his life and the specific circumstances of the creation of his works.

The flotation of new Canadian bonds payable in United States dollars was materially lower in 1958 than in the year before, according to a survey by the Canadian bond house, Wood, Gundy Co., Ltd. There well could be a notable increase in such financing in the coming year, however.
A legislative committee reported yesterday that fewer than half of the state's jobless workers had any form of health or hospital insurance.

John Corigliano, concertmaster of the New York Philharmonic, was the soloist at yesterday afternoon's concert in Carnegie Hall under the direction of Sir John Barbirolli. He played the Walton Violin Concerto.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 11--California's new Democratic Governor, Edmund G. Brown, proposed to Anastas I. Mikoyan today that a "second peace conference" be held by the Soviet Union and the United States under the great California redwood trees.

The outlook for the oil industry in its centennial year of 1959 is clouded by uncertainty. This arises from problems of prices, legislation by the new Congress, imports and political developments abroad.
ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- Governor Rockefeller was reported eager today to return to a pay-as-you-go policy for highway construction.
The office equipment and supplies industry expects an increase of 10 per cent for sales of its products this year over 1958.
Sales of distilled spirits in this country probably set a twelve-year high in 1958.
DETROIT -- For the auto industry 1958 was a year of reduced sales, sharply curtailed profits and considerable red ink. But it was a year in which the small-car idea gained backing.
Beer and ale consumption last year was about the same as in 1957, according to Edward V. Lahey, president of the United States Brewers Foundation.
ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- A legislative investigation into the cost of the state's relief programs was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas has shattered the anti-filibuster liberals in the Senate, but in personal political terms this may prove to be the most costly victory he has ever won.

LONDON, Jan. 11 -- Puritanism is under fire in Britain. Political agitation is developing against blue laws and self-apointed censors interfering with what many consider to be the pursuit of happiness or, at least, their own business.
VIENNA, Jan. 11 -- A new uniform wage policy has been adopted by East European Communist governments in recent weeks.

The textile industry in 1959 has hopes of continuing to operate at more profitable levels than in previous years, despite some curtailment of output. The industry made a good showing in 1958, when the recession slowed most business.
The nation's foreign trade held to a high level in 1958 despite the recession.
HOUSTON, Tex. -- Cautious enthusiasm pervaded all segments of the Texas economy as 1959 began.
The year 1958 was not a happy one for domestic sulphur producers.
DETROIT, Jan. 11 (AP) -- John S. Knight announced today the appointment of Lee Hills, executive editor of the Detroit Free Press and Miami Herald, as executive editor of Knight Newspapers.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Deputy Premier Anastas I. Mikoyan of the Soviet Union paid an unscheduled visit today to a middle-class San Francisco home.
New recommendations for improvements in the state workmen's compensation system are proposed in a special report by former Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Callahan.
Insurance of bank deposits, twenty-five years old this year, provided a feeling of security during the 1957-58 business recession.
Virtually unhampered by the 1958 business recession, the construction industry has advanced to a record level of activity on the strength of public works and private home building.

Four young men plunged amid the ice floes in the Hudson River yesterday to fulfill a traditional rite of the Greek Orthodox Church. They were competing to recover a crucifix dropped into the river at 1 P. M. by the Rev. David Leondarides, pastor of St. Michael's Church at 327 West Fortythird Street.
MOSCOW, Jan. 11 -- Polish painters who have invaded this capital of "Socialist realism" with abstract canvases felt the first blast of official displeasure today when they read Moscow newspapers
Profit-sharing plans weathered the recession well in 1958.
Two films, both of which arrive Wednesday, are the week's openings. The programs follow:

Following up Leo H. Hirsch's excellent suggestion, in his letter published Jan. 4, that the capital gains tax could be avoided by those who would immediately place their receipts in Government bonds, the proposal could under present circumstances profitably be extended to state governments and state government bonds. This would have considerably more attraction to investors because of the tax-exempt status of interest on state bonds.
The Metropolitan Regional Council ends its quest for public expression on its future with an open hearing tomorrow at City Hall.
HARTFORD -- Connecticut's economy was on the rebound at the year's end. Employment was rising and the ranks of the jobless decreasing.
For the first time in history, margarine production exceeded that of butter during 1958, according to the National Association of Margarine Manufacturers.
The mutual funds are proud of themselves these days.
With American Airlines back in operation after a twentytwo-day strike, Federal mediators moved yesterday to ward off labor trouble on Pan American World Airways.
ATLANTA -- The Southeast's over-all economy at year's end appeared to be well on the way toward full recovery from the recession.

PHILADELPHIA -- In spots the silver lining was showing through the gloom of the 1958 recession as the new year began in the Philadelphia metropolitan area. Manu facturers and business men were looking ahead more optimistically, if cautiously, than they had in a long time. Behind this was the continuing advance of industrial activity and employment and the Christmas boom in sales.
Exchange seats were at a premium for one of Wall Street's biggest attractions in 1958. Reason: The heaviest stock trading in several years.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The first few days of the Eighty-sixth Congress have produced a perplexing image of the whole and the parts.
Recession was the wrong term for what the nation's lead and zinc industries experienced during most of 1958.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The Administration's effort to negotiate an atomic test ban with the Soviet Union faces critical examination this week in Congress.
The paper industry in 1958 showed a good example of strength in the face of adversity. Everything was satisfactory except profits.

The merger of Fletcher D. Richards, Inc., and Calkins Holden, Inc., reported here last week, has been confirmed. The new agency will be called Fletcher Richards, Calkins Holden, Inc. Its billings will come to some $35,000,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon contends that the United States is ahead of the Soviet Union in developing military missiles and is catching up rapidly in other phases of the space race.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The Eisenhower Administration has definite hopes of being able to cut taxes next year. It plans to try to show that this is a real possibility, provided Congress holds the line on spending this year.

JAMES JONES' third novel, "The Pistol,"* is published today almost exactly a year after the publication of his second, "Some Came Running." The contrast between them is so great that it seems as if Mr. Jones were determined to make it as great as possible. "Some Came Running" was as long as seven novels combined.

The outlook for American-made wool products is bright this year in spite of the inroads of synthetic fibers and synthetic-wool mixtures in the view of G. Norman Winder, president of Woolens and Worsteds of America, Inc.
Twin spectres, inflation and recession, continue to haunt the nation's money managers.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 11 -- Indonesia's Communist party chief and other political leaders conferred with President Sukarno today on matters that could lead to fundamental changes in Indonesia's governmental and political systems.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon is moving quietly to kill widespread speculation that his political course will become increasingly independent of President Eisenhower's between now and 1960.

About 121,000,000 Americans had some sort of health insurance at the end of last year, the Health Insurance Institute estimates. This protection against the cost of hospital and doctor bills was provided by insurance companies, Blue Cross-Blue Shield and other health-care plans.
Congress will be the battlefield this year on which the fight for national retail pricefixing will be fought.
The missile and space business has precipitated a dizzy scramble for a fast-expanding array of avant garde contracts.
MOUNT HOPE, N. Y., Jan. 11 -- The Hamilton (Ont.) Thistles, skipped by Ross Tarlton, successfully defended in the Douglas Medal bonspiel today.

The consensus of yesterday's New York Times Youth Forum was that the Federal Government would have to increase its assistance to medical education if the nation was to have the health services it needed.

A process that solidifies quicksand into a stone-like substance able to support large buildings and tunnels was adopted for scores of engineering projects in 1958. It is expected to have substantial further development this year.
Less than a year ago half the railroads in the industrial Northeast were on the brink of bankruptcy -- to hear them tell it; and even the normally thriving roads elsewhere weren't well.

WENGEN, Switzerland, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Four spectacular spills cost Wallace (Bud) Werner of the United States his chances for victory today in the Slalom of the Lauberhorn ski races. A pair of Austrian dare-devils overcame an icy course for a one, two finish.
Aided by another spurt in tanker activity, the steamship charter market last week managed a sharp increase in volume although there was no noticeable over-all gain in rates.
LONDON, Jan. 11 -- The trend of industrial share prices on the stock exchanges last week was downward, but a recovery Friday offset some of the losses.
Sugar prices were high last year, especially in the Eastern part of the nation.

Private pension plans were affected more by legislation in 1958 than by the recession. Enactment of a law designed to police pension funds and the new Social Security law that increased old age benefits highlighted developments in the field last year.
The nation's coal industry felt the impact of the industrial recession last year and production dropped nearly 20 per cent.
MILWAUKEE, Wis. -- Wisconsin business men are inclined to be cautious in their appraisals of business for 1959. Generally, they look for some improvement.

SALT LAKE CITY -- An accelerating trend to industrialization and tourist business in a region where mining and open-range agriculture once ruled marks the economic outlook for Utah and some neighboring states this year.

Baby food sales reached a record of more than $300,000,000 in 1958 and manufacturers expect them eventually to reach $500,000,000 a year, according to Edward J. Jordan, president of Beech-Nut Life Savers, Inc.

Plans to unite the Universalist Church of America and the American Unitarian Association are progressing, the Rev. Donald W. McKinney said yesterday at the First Unitarian Church, Pierrepont Street and Monroe Place, Brooklyn.

The men's clothing industry felt the brunt of the recession early last year. Profits were only 0.59 per cent of sales in 1957 and the 1958 figure is believed to have been smaller. When the family reduces expenditures because of adverse economic conditions, it is the head of the household who usually skimps first and most.
WASHINGTON -- Massive governmental financial moves during 1958 helped cure a serious recession but raised wide spread fears of future inflation.

RARELY in the annals of cuisine is there evidence of a chef with a pure vocal line. The virtuoso in the kitchen is apt to be tone deaf in the shower. However, it is by no means uncommon to find a professional tenor, basso or baritone with a marked talent for cooking. Many have an especial flair for salad making.

The women's multi-billion dollar outerwear industries came through a fairly profitable year in 1958 by cutting production in most categories of garments. Some radical style changes kept consumer demand strong throughout most of the year but the new fashions did not produce the dollar volume that was predicted when they first emerged.
IMPORTANT changes will have to be made in New York City schools before parents of public school youngsters can exert any significant influence on the kind of education their children will receive.

The New York Stock Exchange's Monthly Investment Plan continued to be popular in 1958. The latest count, made at the end of November, shows that 153,000 plans were started since MIP was launched late in January, 1954, and 76,000 of the plans were in force in November.
Frank Pace Jr., president of General Dynamics Corporation, called 1958 "a period of outstanding accomplishment" for the company. He added that prospects for the present year "seem excellent."

the A group of buildings on southeast corner of Second Avenue and Forty-sixth Street has been purchased by the Willinm Kaufman OrganizaLion, builders, for improvement with a nineteen-story apartment house.

European manufacturers are promoting color extensively in women's gloves for the new season, it is reported by Alfred Mayer, president of the Kayser-Roth Glove Company, a division of the Kayser-Roth Corporation.

The legalizing and taxing of off-track betting on horse races would help both the city and the state substantially in balancing their expense budgets for 1959-60. City Budget Director Abraham L. Beame declared yesterday.
JUNEAU, Alaska -- Born a giant among states three days after the New Year, Alaska wears a "we'll show 'em" mien as it tentatively flexes its economic muscles.
DULUTH, Minn. -- Recent months have not been rosy for this city and its Iron Range environs of northeastern Minnesota. Neither have they been too bad.

OTTO EDELMANN is accustomed to coping with the Wagnerian and Straussian orchestra in a big theatre like the Metropolitan Opera. His bass-baritone is big and solid enough for such roles as Hans Sachs, Wotan and Baron Ochs.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Jan. 11 -- Six teen-aged Bronx boys, one of them critically hurt, were held in hospitals or jails today as the aftermath of a Mount Vernon hold-up. It was followed by a wild chase in which a policeman was wounded and a crash that wrecked two stolen automobiles in front of police headquarters here last night.
The desire for brand-name identification resulted last year in an increased call by business managements for industrial designers to fashion "corporate images."

MINNEAPOLIS -- Recovery from the recession is expected to continue through most of 1959 in the states of the Ninth Federal Reserve District -- Minnesota, North Dakota, South Dakota, Montana, northern Wisconsin and Upper Michigan.
It was cold and windy yesterday in Queens and the temperature was in the upper twenties. Ear muffs, scarves, hooded jackets and gloves were in order.

One significant sign that the national economy is recovering from the worst of the recession is the improvement in corporate profits. Continuation of the steady quarterly advances made in 1958 could swell this year's total to $21,000,000,000.

Securities set records last year. On the New York Stock Exchange more shares were listed, more money was borrowed and prices rose about 37 per cent, submerging all save a few of the high water marks reached in earlier years.
The nation's hotels increased their sales enough in the last four months of 1958 to pull their volume for the year almost even with the 1957 total.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Representative Frank Thompson Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, takes over the championship of the National Education Association's big Federal aid bill this week in the House Committee.
WILMINGTON, N. Y., Jan. 11 (AP) -- An Olympic skier, Art Tommy of Ottawa, beat his younger brother, Fred, by a second and a half today and won the Empire State giant slalom on Whiteface Mountain.

There were no return bouts between members of the New York Knickerbockers and the Philadelphia Warriors yesterday before 6,280 fans at Madison Square Garden. Tempers flared once or twice, but basketball, rather than fisticuffs, was the order of the day as the Knicks downed the Warriors, 111 -- 105.

Contemporary mankind was described yesterday by Bishop Frederick Buckley Newell "as the first generation ever to be able to look into the future and not know whether or not there will be another generation."

CLEVELAND -- Soaring costs of mortgage and construction loans combined to limit 1958 home starts in Cuyahoga County to the lowest level in more than fifteen years. As a result local builders are in a quandary at the start of the new year.
STAMFORD, Conn. Jan. 11 -- Workers toiled through the day here today to restore service on the crippled New Haven Railroad.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 11 -- An unusual political new year will be ushered in here tomorrow by Scandinavia's most glittering pageant -- the opening of the Swedish Parliament in the royal palace.
At the top of a roller coaster ride, home mortgage lenders are wondering when they will start a new descent.

ATLANTA, Jan. 7 -- Consumers in the 57,000-square-mile service area of the Georgia Power Company used a record 8,900,000,000 kilowatt hours of electrical energy last year, eclipsing the former high mark of 8,600,000,000 kilowatt hours set in 1957.

THERE were horrified gasps and protests of indignation at the start of the 1958 baseball season when the experts got their first look at the monstrosity of a ball park the Dodgers were to use. It had only one thing in its favor -- plenty of room for the customers. That it didn't have room for the ballplayers was incidental, inconsequential, irrelevant, immaterial and incompetent -- especially if the witness was Walter O'Malley.

Manufacturers' sales of pharmaceutical products last year increased about 8 per cent above the 1957 level. This year's business "shows promise of continuing its upward trend," according to an industry official.
According to the Moscow radio, the Soviet Union is building atomic power stations that will produce electricity as cheaply as coal-burned stations.
WASHINGTON -- The big antitrust news of 1958 -- and of some years past -- was a decision handed down in New York by Judge Edward Weinfeld of Federal District Court.
Users of industrial diamonds in this country last year were told of increased sources of this important machining substance, which is used in the making of dyes and diamond-grinding wheels.

The nation's twelve big trunk airlines raised their earnings last year 11 per cent above the depressed level of 1957. The industry calculates that it cleared about $30,000,000. The final figure for 1957 was $26,993,000.

CHIOAGO, Jan. 11 (UPI) -The New York Rangers exploded for three goals in the third period tonight to beat the Chicago Black Hawks, 4 -- 3, before a crowd of 15,214. By winning, the Rangers moved to within 3 points of second place in the National Hockey League.
The 1958 annual meeting season produced the greatest number of proxy contests for corporate control in American history.
The business of selling the correct time to industry continues to grow.
The car and truck renting and leasing industry continues at an accelerating pace.

The direct debt of the Federal Government rose substantially in 1958. There was a shift, too, in the ownership of a sizable part of the debt from corporations, individuals and unclassified investors to commercial banks.

Group Securities, Inc., reproted net assets of $145,996,350 as of Nov. 30, the end of its fiscal year. This was an increase of $51,162,718 from the total a year earlier. The big mutual fund group added 6,455 stockholdrs during the year for a new high of 43,244 on Nov. 30.
Wilson Co., Inc., third largest meat packer in the United States, and its domestic subsidiaries have reported consolidated net earnings of $7,760,991 for the fiscal year ended Nov. 1.

FRANK THOMPSON Jr., Representative of New Jersey's Fourth District, had a reputation as a fighter before he entered Congress. His four years at Washington have enhanced that reputation. Ever ready to espouse a good cause, he has battled for measures as diverse as Federal aid to education and a national cultural center, assistance for small business and more democratic Congressional procedure.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11--The Senate heads this week into the closing stages of debate on limiting the filibuster, with victory visually assured for the moderate compromise proposed by Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas Democratic leader.
DENVER -- Major business barometers indicate that 1958 was a record year for the Denver metropolitan area as the city maintained its economic growth.

Senator Kenneth B. Keating told a group of Presbyterian laymen yesterday that he was making a major effort to obtain for New York State a "greater and more equitable" share of Government defense contracts.
ATLANTA, Jan. 11 (UPI) -The State Board of Regents agreed today to stop registration at Georgia's nineteen colleges and universities as a counterattack against a Federal desegregation order.
NEWARK, Jan. 11--Culex pipiens, a common house or rain-barrel mosquito, is not only the most pestiferous of mosquitos in Essex County but also one of the more difficult to control.

Sales of vinyl-metal laminates as finish material for many products have risen from about 1,000,000 square feet in 1955 to 20,000,000 square feet last year. Scott Campbell, vice president and general manager of the Clad-Rex Corporation, makers of the material and a subsidiary of Simoniz Company, said that barring a severe business slump, sales this year should far exceed last year's figure.

AN absorbing close-up of Fidel Castro, leader of the Cuban revolutionary forces, was provided in his appearance yesterday afternoon on "Face the Nation" over Channel 2. The interview was held in Havana on Saturday, relayed to Miami and shown on the network by means of tape recording.
One of the few industries that increased production in 1958, the recession notwithstanding, was manufacturing of plastics.
The Prison Association of New York yesterday urged the establishment of a state institute of sentencing to devise "a more rational, uniform and judicious approach to present sentencing procedures."

Savings, in chronic short supply since World War II, may catch up with the demand for investment funds. Economists who foresee such a possibility in the year ahead think two economic areas -- corporate spending and individual saving -- will determine the balance.
The recession took its toll of 1958 telephone expansion plans.
Few lumbermen were sorry to see 1958 slip into oblivion.
Jan Gorbaty, pianist and faculty member of the Chatham Square Music School, who made his recital debut here in 1953, offered an impressive performance at Town Hall yesterday afternoon.
LONDON, Jan. 11 -- The visit to the United States by Anastas I. Mikoyan has been widely reported in the British press.
The volume of commodity futures trading on the New York exchanges last year was about the same as in 1957. However, there were sharp increases and declines in trading activity for several items.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 11 (AP) -- Eddie Moylan, the nation's fourth ranking player in 1956, displayed the skill that earned him that distinction today by defeating Kosei Kamo, Japan's Davis Cup star, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 4, in the men's final of the Dixie international tennis tournament.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -President Eisenhower is a lawabiding type. One of the laws he abides says that his annual Economic Report must be filed with Congress by Jan. 20.
The packaging industry, a fast-moving giant, continued to forge ahead on most fronts last year. Some fields faltered in the wake of the recession but others reached new highs.

A new time-saving route from downtown Brooklyn to Manhattan will be established today with the opening at 1 P. M. of the new cloverleaf entrance from the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway to the Brooklyn Bridge.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Diplomatic sources here expressed the view today that the Western power eventually would have to make counter-proposals to the Soviet Union modifying their positions on Berlin, Germany and military disengagement in Europe.
Two floors in the Tishman Building, 666 Fifth Avenue, at Fifty-second St. have been leased by Fuller mlth Rou Inc., advertising agency.
WASHINGTON -- The Federal regulatory agencies, those pervasive bodies that quietly exercise broad powers over American business, found themselves the focus of unaccustomed public attention in 1958.
The Gramercy Chamber Ensemble is a flexible group of musicians that can supply the man (or woman) power for chamber music combinations that don't turn up on standard programs.

CHICAGO -- The end of last year saw Chicago still burdened by the afternmath of the 1957-1958 recession but this city began the new year with rising spirits. The index of Chicago-area production hit a high for the year in December, and was at the highest point since September, 1957. But employment lagged seriously.
PARIS, Jan. 11 -- The state-operated Renault automobile industry continues to use the American system of negotiations between employers and employes for wage revisions.

The Big Sisters, Inc., a Protestant organization that aids maladjusted boys and girls, will be the beneficiary of the Jan. 30 performance of "Tall Story." The comedy by Howard K. Lindsay and Russel Crouse will open the preceding night at the Belasco Theatre.
A strong finish after a serious slump was the story of the home furnishings industry for 1958. Manufacturers and retailers view 1959 with "cautious optimism."

Louis Dejoie, a former Haitian Senator who was defeated by President Francois Duvalier in the 1957 elections, predicted here yesterday that the Duvalier regime would fall within weeks or, to be conservative, within months."

Purchases of life insurance by individuals hit a high last year, but those of group life and industrial life dropped. The net result was a loss of about $1,200,000,000 in over-all purchases. The 1958 figure was $66,700,000,000; that for 1957, $65,500,000,000.
The present capacity of the country's producers of manmade fibers is 2,307,000,000 pounds a year, according to the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The diplomatic corps in Washington had a new mystery tonight: Is Vyacheslav M. Molotov, former Soviet Foreign Minister and at present Moscow's Ambassador to Outer Mongolia, going to be the Soviet Ambassador to the Netherlands, or not?

BONN, Germany, Jan. 11 -The West German Government is prepared to urge its allies to counter Moscow's peace-treaty move with concrete proposals for a big-power conference on the entire German question.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Jan. 11 -- Keen foreign demand appears forthcoming for certain Dutch stocks. Whereas recently demand has centered in Philips and Unilever, in the past week AKU came into the limelight because of optimistic statements by its president. He forecast expansion, especially in the sphere of fully synthetic fibers.
The copper industry has rallied smartly from the recession blues of a year ago.
WASHINGTON -- The foreign aid program has survived the ordeal of another Congressional review with some cuts and bruises but without critical damage.
Two retired pier superintendents of the United States Lines -- Irving L. Saunders and Cyrus S. Young -- will be honored at a testimonial dinner tomorrow at the Downtown Athletic Club.
The threat of a strike this summer is the biggest cloud on the steel industry's fairly bright horizon.
Jason Robards Jr., Maria Schell and Maureen Stapleton will star in the three-hour television adaptation of Ernest Hemingway's novel "For Whom the Bell Tolls."
TRENTON -- The advent of 1959 finds New Jersey business and industrial leaders somewhat apprehensive as to the immediate future in their respective fields.
ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 11 -American and Turkish negotiators are writing into a new military pact specific guarantees of United States support in the event of Communist aggression against Turkey.
The paint, varnish and lacquer industry expects record sales this year if the nation's industrial recovery continues.
The natural gas industry wound up its operations in 1958 in a blaze of glory.
AKRON, Ohio -- On the upswing since the recession's lowest dip here in mid-1958, Greater Akron's economy gives every sign that it will experience improvement in 1959.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 11 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru extended India's hand in friendship today to the people of Pakistan.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 11 -- A Government - sponsored trade mission will leave for the United States and Canada Feb. 25. John McEwen, Minister for Trade, said in Canberra tonight. The mission will be the first of its kind to go to North America from Australia, he added.

The Italian and United States motion picture industries have signed a new three-year film agreement. It will go into effect Sept. 1 when the old pact expires, it has been announced by the Motion Picture Export Association of America.
Increasing demand and record sales for California wines this year are forecast by the Wine Institute of San Francisco.
OMAHA, Neb. -- Never have the economic skies looked brighter in Nebraska and western Iowa than at the start of this new year.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 11 -- After seven straight victories, Art Tokle, the flying carpenter from Lake Telemark, N. J., was beaten in a ski jump today.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Jan. 11 -John E. Brownell of the Williams Club was the winner of the singles in the twenty-seventh Luckenbach Memorial invitation handicap squash racquets tournament at the Nassau Country Club today.

The Longer Days The days are getting longer, make no mistake. To be sure, the change is one seen more easily on the calendar page than through the window, but it is there nonetheless. Since just before Christmas the sun has been working a bit harder than before, adding a moment's daylight here, another there.

For the third consecutive year, a new record was reached in the number of disabled persons rehabilitated to employment through the State-Federal vocational rehabilitation program in 1958. The 1958 total of 74,320 disabled persons rehabilitated and successfully placed in employment was 3,380 more than in 1957.

SEATTLE--Pacific Northwest business, moving sharply downward in the first half of 1958, staged a substantial recovery after the midyear. Most economic observers expect a further gradual improvement through 1959.
DUBLIN, Jan. 10 -- The couture spring collections were opened here this evening with showings by Miss Irene Gilbert and Raymond Kenna. Later this month Miss Sybil Connolly will show her collection.

MOSCOW, Jan. 11 -- The Soviet people got their first look today at details of Western policies regarding Germany and of the accusations the United States, Britain and France have been making against the Soviet Union.
The Alfred P. Sloan Foundation has donated $500,000 to the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. This brings the total contributed so far to $41,780,406.
There is an old rural proverb that pretty well sums up the continuing dilemma of the trucking industry:

Private industry is "more ready now than ever before to pitch in and help produce the huge volume of middle - income housing needed today," according to Joseph P. McMurray, outgoing State Housing Commissioner.
Many defense contractors pressed the Government hard last year for bigger profits and it looks as if they may get them this year.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Iraq refused today to give diplomatic recognition to Communist East Germany, but agreed to examine the idea at some future date.

Tea consumption in this country last year was at the second highest level in history, according to Robert Smallwood, chairman of the Tea Council of the U.S.A., Inc. Sales to groceries and institutions totaled 108,100,000 pounds, a figure that was topped only in 1954 when sales hit 112,200,000 pounds.

ON weekdays from dawn through early afternoon Piers 27, 28 and 29 on the Hudson River are heavily citrus-scented. Stacked crates of oranges, lemons, grapefruit, tangerines are set out in endless rows in the dark sheds -- all that a city of 8,000,000 souls eats.
An exhibition of clocks and watches that were made during the period of richest development of time pieces opened yesterday at the Staten Island Museum, 75 Stuyvesant Place, St. George.
The women's hosiery industry did well in 1958 and expects to do even better this year, according to William F. Williamson, president of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.
The nation's railroads drastically reduced public borrowings for equipment in 1958.

High levels of unemployment and an upsurge in industrial strife worry union leaders as they map collective bargaining and political goals for 1959. These worries cast a gray shadow over the gratification labor derives from the prospect of general economic revival and its own successes in the 1958 national elections.
The thirteenth week of the season at the Metropolitan Opera, marking the midpoint of the season, will feature a number of notable firsts and lasts.
The nation's electric utilities stumbled in 1958 but had recovered nicely by year-end. The final weeks found them turning out 7 per cent more power than they had in the like 1957 weeks.
SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., Jan. 10 -- The electric brain that will compute the scores of 1,000 Winter Olympic contestants in 1960 already is champing at its electronic bit.

The use of new scientific feeding methods for beef and hogs will be greatly accelerated this year, it is predicted by Hugh O. Dermody, assistant general manager of the agricultural sales division of Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc. These methods will enable the farmer to market his animals sooner and at lower feeding costs, he said.

SAN FRANCISCO -- It is hard to find the word "boom" in West Coast economic lexicons for 1959. Nevertheless, there is wide belief that the year will produce a moderately or fairly strong economic upturn.
The Administration is taking steps to increase its planned force of intercontinental ballistic missiles.

The Krainis Baroque Ensemble gave its first New York concert last night at the Lexington Avenue Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association at Ninety-second Street. Fittingly enough, it made its debut in the first of two programs devoted to the vocal and instrumental chamber music of one of the greatest baroque composers, Handel.
The next Soviet step into space will probably be made with a rocket fired to orbit the moon, possibly as early as Feb. 1.

Plans for one of the most notable stock splits in many years were announced in 1958, when directors of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company submitted for stockholders approval next April a three-for-one split of its common stock.
Wool prices have been declining since the beginning of the last quarter of 1957 and only now are showing signs of leveling.
Discount houses did a brisk business during the recession in the first half of last year, according to Stephen Masters, president, Masters, Inc.

KANSAS CITY -- This metropolitan area of six counties in two states enters the new year in what is probably the brightest economic circumstances since Lewis and Clark stopped here on their way West early in the last century.
America's fifth-largest manufacturing industry -- chemicals -- almost matched its record high 1957 sales last year in spite of the recession.

Four new members of the New York City Youth Board will be sworn in by Mayor Wagner today at 4 P. M. at Gracie Mansion. They are Nicholas D. Biddle, Jonathan B. Bingham, Peter Campbell Brown and Dr. Mary Huff Diggs.

The recession dealt harshly with some segments of the rubber industry in 1958. But by the end the year its recovery was so well along that manufacturers were forecasting a 13 per cent gain in rubber use in the new year.
The tobacco industry, unlike most other businesses, did not show any bad effects of the recession last year.
CHICAGO -- Already Chicago, which next April will welcome the biggest salt water vessels, is having second thoughts about the immediate effects of the St. Lawrence Seaway.
UDAIPUR, India, Jan. 1 -Lakshmi Devi, a bride when 12 years old and a widow since 13, scuffed the dust with her bare toes in honest embarrassment.
Bankers are wondering how long they must wait before business demands for bank credit catch up with the rising pace of industrial production.

WASHINGTON -- Crop Production, 1958 Annual Summary, Acreage, Yield, Production by States by American Farmers. Compiled by the Department of Agriculture, Agricultural Marketing Services, Crop Reporting Board. Free.
ZURICH, Switzerland, Jan. 12 --The nationalist upheavals in Leopoldville in the Belgian Congo last week were reflected in disturbances to stock exchange business.

Shipments of metal cans increased 3 to 4 per cent in the year just past compared with 1957 and had a dollar value of about $1,500,000,000, the Can Manufacturers Institute has estimated. Its estimate was based on a 2.9 per cent rise in shipments for the first ten months of 1958.

PARIS, Jan. 11 -- The ensuing twelve months will' see difficult moments in relationships between the United States and France. The new French Government is avowedly nationalistic. It will react against the Fourth Republic's habit of relying on Washington almost as a client state.
The domestic quicksilver industry is beginning to get that sinking feeling again.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 11 -- Steel orders, output and backlogs increased again last week. There also was new evidence that steel operations in the first quarter would be moderately ahead of those in the fourth quarter. Although no boom was expected in the near future, some observers forecast an operating rate in the 80's by April.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 11 -- A syndicate of independent movie interests has been organized to make a motion picture of "The Scarlet Feather," seventh in a series of historical American novels written by Dale Van Every.

One of the most important economic indicators is the machine tool industry, one of the country's smallest in terms of number of companies. Its members are the first to get the word when producers in any line decide to expand.

The new year is starting off with the investment return on prime-risk bonds approximating 4 per cent. This is about one-half of 1 per cent more than at the close of last year and is not far below the post-war high for long-term interest rates touched in 1957.
The aluminum industry is going right on building more production capacity, undeterred by its 1958 recession setback and apparently as confident as ever of burgeoning future markets.

Luther Hodges, governor of North Carolina, has announced that a new Research Triangle Institute will be established in the center of the small triangle formed by the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill, Duke University in Durham and North Carolina State College in Raleigh.

According to the reply of the Governments of the three Western powers to the Soviet note on Berlin these Governments are prepared to discuss the question of Berlin in the wider framework of negotiations for a solution of the German problem as well as that of European security.
Parenthood was described at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday as "a grave and noble calling" because parents "are sculptors of souls."

Coffee drinkers in the United States are enjoying the lowest-price brew in eight years. Special sales and temporary reductions announced by roasters during the last few months of 1958 dropped prices to World War II levels.
Spurred by heavy volume in the final quarter, the jewelry industry last year enjoyed record sales.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 11 -- Twenty-nine passengers and seven crew members were killed today when a West German Lufthansa airliner crashed and burned in a rainstorm while approaching Galeao Airport.

The Treasury's savings bond program in 1958 scored an improvement over that for the year before. Although redemptions of the bonds continued to exceed sales of new bonds, the sales nevertheless rose in 1958 and the redemptions declined.
So many new or improved products have come upon the American scene that the standard of living seems to have gained an age in a generation.

Higher output and lower prices seem in prospect for the 1959 cotton crop. Legislation by the last Congress, which provided for an increase in acreage to be planted to cotton and a lower support price for part of the crop, accounts for this outlook.
All Angels' Protestant Episcopal Church observed its 100th anniversary yesterday.
The nation's railroads are expected to put new construction projects in place this year at a faster rate than industry and government generally.

Carrying out an extensive program of industrial development, Puerto Rico requires an ever-increasing amount of electric power. It is supplied by the Puerto Rico Water Resources Authority, which provides all power for the island commonwealth.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UPI) -- Senate staff experts declared today that the Federal Communications Commission had "hesitated and delayed" in establishing a nation-wide television policy.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 11 -- The Brazilian Government has moved to increase exports, especially coffee, by raising cruzeiro payments to shippers for dollars earned. The Bank of Brazil, which receives all foreign exchange and pays arbitrary fixed rates, issued a new higher exchange schedule covering three categories -- coffee, cocoa and miscellaneous raw products of agriculture and mining.

Printing is the second largest manufacturing industry in New York City and, with publishing, the sixth largest industry in the United States. Once a year, during Printing Week, the industry examines with a critical eye its contributions to the nation's well-being.

SHARPLY at 8 o'clock this morning, 205 women will nudge their way into the Jade Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Over sloshing scrambled eggs, wrapped roll baskets and lukewarm coffee, the thirtysecond National Press Week of the Couture Group of the New York Dress Institute will have begun.
An important breakthrough in the battle to make oil the fuel for home generation of electricity occurred last year.
House-to-house sales rose "dramatically" last year despite the recession in the early part of the year, according to H. A. Schanz, chairman of the National Association of Direct Selling Companies.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 11 (AP)--The National Football League's Eastern Conference All-Stars stormed back in the final quarter today and whipped the Western Conference All-Stars, 28--21, in the ninth annual Pro Bowl.
Recession and recovery. The two R's. That sums up the course of the American economy in 1958. And in 1959? The outlook is for a continuing improvement though it will undoubtedly be at a slower pace.
Retailers did well last year despite the recession and this year they are confident they will do even better.
Despite the recession early in the year, Americans continued to eat well in 1958.

In the just concluded annual convention of India's dominant Congress party there was no indication of any significant change in foreign policy. Proposals that seemed to have some sort of extremist tinge were promptly pushed aside. The course will continue to be as moderate as Prime Minister Nehru can make it.
ROME, Jan. 11 -- Many Italians feel that Mr. Mikoyan's consummate salesmanship last week brought the Kremlin much nearer to its old objective of direct dealings with Washington.
The Douglas fir plywood industry showed no signs of a slowdown in growth in 1958.
Institutional investors accounted for almost one-quarter of the trading activity on the New York Stock Exchange during a two-day period studied by the Exchanging last fall.
HONOLULU -- Hawaii had a good year in 1958 despite the four-month strike in the sugar industry. The prospects are that the territory will enjoy another good year in 1959.
The year just passed was one of record-breaking borrowing by state and local governments. From all indications, such activity in 1959 will run to the same size.
WASHINGTON -- A good many patents issued to industry during 1958 are aimed at man's needs in the space age, whether he goes aloft or remains on the ground.

The stretch-yarn leotards, so popular late in 1958 that retailers sold them as fast as they could be delivered, will continue to be popular this year in many new versions, according to Ahred P. Slaner, president of the Kayser-Roth Hosiery Company.
TRENTON, Jan. 11 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner and his "economic ambassadors" met in Princeton last week and set in motion plans for accelerating a drive to entice industry to New Jersey.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 11 -Argentina will begin tomorrow to adjust her new free market economy to the commercial and financial operations of the rest of the world.
Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs, according to The Times of Dec. 21, stated that the city itself is largely to blame for the spreading of slums.

The rise in stock margin requirements last October from 70 to 90 per cent, the highest level in eleven years, stimulated interest in convertible bonds as a method of beating the high margin requirement.
A Jesuit priest's answers to criticism raised against Roman Catholicism in the United States are being presented in a series of three programs on "The Catholic Hour" over Channel 4.
The Israel Bond Organization adopted plans yesterday for a new $300,000,000 issue of Israel bonds to help Israel absorb 100,000 immigrants this year.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy expressed confidence indirectly yesterday that Mayor Wagner would support him in his fight to keep control of police grievance decisions.
Company economists had more to say and were listened to more carefully by management in its decision-making last year than at any other time in business history.
Producers for four forthcoming plays were busy over the week-end filling major casting assignments. They engaged the following actors and actresses:

As we approached mid-January a year ago it was fairly clear, that, as one authority put it, after more than three years of uninterrupted expansion "some of the exuberance has gone out of the economy." Figures made public in the second week of January, 1958, showed that the Federal Reserve Board's index of production had fallen another three points in December, to 136, or nine points under its August, 1957, level.
Virtually nine out of ten apartments demolished in New York City are wrecked to make way for public improvements.
PROVIDENCE, R. I. -- Rhode Island closed out 1958 with the hope that a new state-wide development plan would pave the way for a brighter future.
Mutual funds proved recession-proof in 1958.
The timber resources of the United States will take a giant step forward this year as Alaska -- with 44,000,000 acres of commercial timberland -- enters the Union.
The closed-circuit communications industry has passed its tenth birthday and its adherents predict a bright future for the relatively young medium.
Hour by hour, minute by minute, a clock is ticking out the economic future of America.
Prices for second-hand ships were marked down severely during 1958 as poor freight market conditions continued to exert a depressing effect on the ship sales market.

The appointment of a permanent watchdog committee to review the construction practices of the Board of Education and other city agencies was recommended by City Council President Abe Stark yesterday in a letter to Mayor Wagner.
WITH a five-year trail of legal foolscap behind it, Jack Benny's parody on the motion picture, "Gaslight," arrived on Channel 2 last night. It was a disappointing miscarriage of entertainment.

Despite the recession, the ranks of preferred stock on the New York Stock Exchange with large dividend arrears thinned considerably last year. The most spectacular development was Alleghany Corporation's payment of $149.87 1/2-share arrears on its 5 1/2 per cent preferred, wiping out its twenty-seven-year 'debt" to stockholders.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Angry colleagues may move this week to strip Senator Leverett Saltonstall, (Republican of Massachusetts), of his appointive power in a dispute over the chairmanship of the Republican Senatorial Campaign Committee.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 11 -- A young ski jumper at Hotchkiss School in Lakeville, Conn., Is causing considerable comment hereabout. He is Mark Ottey, a quiet 16-yearold junior.
BALTIMORE -- Emerging from the recession with less hurt than most communities, owing to its diversification, Baltimore has organized to improve its position.
The ferrous scrap trade suffered a sharp contraction of its domestic and foreign business last year. And prices received by dealers also showed a substantial decline.
The Superior Oil Company (California) reported yesterday a sharp rise in earnings for the quarter ended Nov. 30.
VIENNA -- Austria enjoyed a moderately prosperous year in 1958 despite a decline in export trade.
Five thousand city parents and 1,000 teachers will receive an opportunity to express their opinions about a new type of report card being used in some elementary schools.

Alfons Landa, president of Penn-Texas Corporation declared yesterday that he might resign this year. He also said that he might be involved in a proxy fight with another concern even before his resignation.

ANKARA, Turkey -- The search for oil in Turkey went on more diligently than ever in 1958. The field of exploration spread to virtually every part of the country. Twenty-one companies, most of them United States, now are surveying 231 areas licensed to them by the Petroleum Administration.
The American consumer is leading the way to business recovery, the National Retail Merchants Association's annual convention was told last night at the Statler-Hilton Hotel.
MOSCOW, Jan 12 -- The Soviet Government wants Vyacheslav M. Molotov to be its next Ambassador to the Netherlands, but the Dutch have been hesitant with their reply to the Soviet request.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden -- The highly industrialized economy of Sweden continued to expand last year but at a rate considerably less than before.
LONDON, Jan. 12 -- The Stock Market opened the week on a cheerful note. Industrial shares advanced further and closed at the day's best; British Government securities also made fresh headway.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 12 (Reuters) -- Norman O'Neill and Les Favell, with an unfinished fourth-wicket stand of 97, placed Australia in a strong position at the end of the third day in the third cricket test against England today.
HELSINKI, Finland -- Finland is still working hard in the middle of economic troubles, and experts here are expecting this year to be very much like 1958 -- something they call "gray."

Daniel J. Ferris, honorary secretary-treasurer of the Amateur Athletic Union, yesterday identified a number of foreign track and field aces who will compete in indoor meets in this country this season.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 12 -- James Mason and David Niven will co-star for Michael Powell, British director-producer, in "The Reason Why."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- Representative Oren Harris, chairman of the House Commerce Committee, introduced a bill today that would ban pay-as-you-see television until Congress enacts regulatory legislation.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 12 -- Grim visaged soldiers in three-cornered hats and breastplates preceded King Gustaf Adolf into the Hall of the Realm today for the opening of Parliament.
BOSTON, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- A 17-year-old Boston University freshman, holder of a world record in the high jump, returned to the classroom today, bent on becoming a teacher.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) -- During 1958 Israel's economy closely resembled a man on a treadmill: it had to run with all its might to stay in the same place.
Like many an individual, many a nation worried last year about the adequacy of its rainy-day savings.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland -- This self-governing state within the United Kingdom had an increase in trade of 42,000,000 ($117,600,000) in 1957, and the returns for last year are expected by the Ministry of Commerce to show a further rise to a record figure of 630,000,000 ($1,765,000,000).

The haste to develop petroleum resources abroad, much of which are virtually untapped, receved a severe jolt near the end of last year by the decision of the Venezuelan provisional government to increase sharply its revenue from oil.

The series at the Cherry Lane Theatre called "Monday Nights at Nine," begun very successfully last fall by Mabel Mercer, was resumed last night with Mae Barnes occupying the small stage. Miss Barnes, a singer with a slightly hoarse, rough-edged voice, roamed widely through the fields of popular music from raucous rhythm tunes to gentle folk songs.
HAVANA, Jan. 12 -- Fourteen persons found guilty of "war crimes" were sentenced to death by firing squad at Santiago de Cuba today.
The number of foreign countries that have adopted some form of social security has risen greatly since 1940, a recent Federal survey disclosed.
RABAT, Morocco, Jan. 12 -The Moroccan Government imposed a 10 per cent tax today on all monetary transfers from Morocco to other countries of the franc zone.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa disclosed yesterday a demand that the Board of Education yield to him the power to audit its expenditures.
THE amount of discpiline a parent can instill in a child depends largely on the warmth of his relationship with the youngster.

Events tonight: Clarion Concerts, Newell Jenkins, conductor, Albert Fuller, harpsichordist, Samuel Baron, flutist, Gerald Tarack, violinist, at Town Hall; Ruben Varga, violinist, Carnegie Recital Hall; Philomusic Society, Ammina Celli, mezzo-soprano, Mitchell Andrews, pianist, at Kosciuszko Foundation, 15 East Sixty-fifth Street,, and Toscanini Memorial Program.
MANILA -- The Philippine economy is proving resilient under the punishment it is taking from Government mismanagement and favored interests.

VIENNA -- Bulgaria's Central Statistical Bureau reported that the principal industrial production plans were surpassed during the first three quarters of 1958. Reports for the last quarter are lacking.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- Representative James Roosevelt urged the House today to abolish its Committee on Un-American Activities.
AUCKLAND, N. Z. -- For New Zealand, 1958 was a year of severe economic crisis. The world-wide recession was acmestic troubles.

BRUSSELS, Belgium -- The 1958 external trade of Benelux just about equaled the 1957 total of $11,371,000,000 and prompted officials to call the economic union "the fourth commercial power of the world."
ZURICH, Switzerland -- Prosperity has been maintained in Switzerland. There are still no signs of a slump.

BONN, Germany -- West Germany's unparalleled housing boom continued last year despite higher wages for most of the 2,100,000 workers employed in the building trade and a general leveling-off of this country's post-war industrial development.

Ira Aldridge, a Negro born in New York in 1807, left his native land for England, where sympathy for his people was strong. There he became the first of his race to play the major Shakespearean white roles and his tours of the Continent brought him honors and decorations from royalty and heads of state.

OSLO, Norway -- Last year was the first since the crisis in the early Thirties that Norway failed to increase her gross national product. It fell about 1 per cent lower than that of 1957 compared with an average annual increase of 3.5 to 4 per cent during the last ten years.

ROME -- Tourism, the most important item among Italy's "invisible exports," contributed the equivalent of an estimated total of $450,000,000 to this country's balance of payments in 1958. This was nearly 20 per cent higher than the net foreign currency earnings of the travel industry in the previous year.
Lenox Hill Hospital will be the beneficiary of the second annual Neighborhood Dinner Dance to be held in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria on Feb. 5.
WARSAW -- Poland, wrecked by World War II and hamstrung by a decade of Stalinist rule, still faces years of effort before she can hope to reach economic sunlight.
The Lehman Corporation wound up 1958 with higher assets than it had at the end of any previous quarter or year. This was shown in the annual report mailed yesterday.
CHICAGO, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Losses were more numerous and a bit broader than the gains in prices of grain futures today on the Board of Trade.

A number of tournaments of local and national interest are about to close their doors to potential competitors. The tournament season has become so crowded and so many bowlers want in that most tournament committees don't mean maybe when they state a closing date is on such and such a day.

LONDON--Although Britain's aircraft and engine exports in 1958 totaled around 150,000,000 ($420,000,000) against 116,471,110 ($326,119,108) in 1957, the industry should do even better in 1959.

BONN, Germany -- A major problem plaguing the West German economy throughout 1958 was the accumulation of huge stockpiles of hard coal and coke adding up to what the Government officially described as a coal crisis.
LEWISBURG, Pa., Jan. 12 (UPI) -- Representative William J. Green went on trial today with six others on charges of conspiring to defraud the Federal Government.

An effort to have the city's transit labor affairs investigated by the Senate Select Committee on Improper Activities in the Labor or Management Field was started yesterday by a group of independent transit unions.
PARIS, Jan. 12 -- Breakfast could hardly have been a jolly affair this morning at the home of M. Dupont, that average Frenchman.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced yesterday 3 to 17 points (15 to 85 cents a bale) with new crop months strongest.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The Treasury has disclosed semi-officially its intention of asking Congress for another increase in the national debt limit this year.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya -- The Federation of Malaya, moving toward the third year of independence, faces 1959 a little more optimistically even though it will have a budget deficit of about US$30,000,000.

CAIRO -- Despite the political distractions of union with Syria, revolutions in Lebanon and Iraq and an army coup in the Sudan, Egypt continued apace in 1958 toward her goal of becoming the industrial center of the Arab World.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- An order was placed today for the nation's first space vehicle designed to carry a man into orbit around the earth.

TRURO, N. S., Jan. 12 (Canadian Press) -- The executive committee of the Marine Workers Federation decided yesterday to urge the Canadian Government to repossess the former Canadian National Steamships fleet.

WADESBORO, N. C., Jan. 12 (UPI) -- A Superior Court judge refused today to upset a juvenile court ruling that sent two Negro boys, aged 8 and 10, to a reform school on charges of forcing a 5-year-old white girl to kiss them.
TOKYO, Jan. 12 -- Premier Nobusuke Kishi appointed four new Cabinet ministers today in an effort to heal a rift within the governing Liberal-Democratic party.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia -- Yugoslavia's unorthodox economic machine -- part Karl Marx and part Adam Smith -- was sputtering badly as it turned into 1958.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- The House voted today to let Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., ousted Republican leader, keep the limousine, chauffeur and other benefits of the post he had held twenty years.
LONDON -- Oil is a big business in Britain and it is rapidly growing bigger in size and complexity.
PARIS -- France faces 1959 with a complete transformation in her economy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 --United States officials hope that Anastas I. Mikoyan will have something new to propose on Germany when he meets Administration leaders, including President Eisenhower, late this week.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia -With the exception of the copper processing and engineering industries in Northern Rhodesia, manufacturing is, in general, more advanced in Southern Rhodesia.
A 1-year-old boy died in a Brooklyn rooming house fire last night. His two brothers, 3 and 4 years old, suffered serious body burns.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (UPI) -- Senator Joseph S. Clark introduced a bill today for a ten-year, $6,000,000,000 urban renewal of housing program.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 12 -Argentina entered its third month today under a state of siege that has suspended guarantees of individual and political rights.
BONN, Germany -- West German's foreign commerce, on a steady upswing for a decade, continued its relentless rise in 1958. Prospects at the outset of 1959 were for more of the same.

BONN, Germany -- The tremendous surge forward of the West German economy slowed in 1958. But its inner strength was displayed even more clearly in what was a year of economic adversity for most of Europe as well as the United States. There was no recession in West Germany as there had been in the United States.

HAVANA, Jan. 12 -- Fidel Castro said in an interview last night that he had no intention or desire to run for President in the next electoral campaign.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan 12 -- The appointments of fourteen Westchester commissioners and other officials were filed with the Board of Supervisors today by County Executive Edwin G. Michaelian. The supervisors may confirm the appointments next week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP)--The Supreme Court refused today to rule on a contention by New York State that it alone was entitled to custody of money held by the American Express Company on travelers checks uncashed in fifteen years.
